title: Raisina Dialogue 2023 begins in New Delhi today
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Minister Ali Sabry and Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman will attend the eighth edition of the Raisina Dialogue, India’s premier conference on geopolitics and geo-economics, which begins today (2) in New Delhi, where Bill Gates, Co-Chair of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, will also be present. The first discussion is titled ‘Lessons and Look Ahead: Black Swans and Lighthouses at Raisina Dialogue 2023.’ Vinay Mohan Kwatra, India’s Foreign Secretary, will moderate this discussion.  The Raisina Dialogue is seen as an important forum for shaping global policy debates and promoting international cooperation. Since 2016, the Observer Research Foundation (ORF) has hosted India’s flagship conference on geopolitics and geo-economics, in collaboration with the Ministry of External Affairs of the Government of India, annually. The other distinguished participants other than Gates would be the Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs, France, Catherine Colonna, Secretary of State for Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Affairs, UK, James Cleverly, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Denmark, Lars Lokke Rasmussen, and Minister of Foreign Affairs, Indonesia, Retno Marsudi. The Raisina Dialogue has addressed a wide range of issues, including climate change, cyber security, terrorism, global governance, and the Indo-Pacific region’s future. The conference featured prominent speakers from various countries, including heads of state, ministers, and senior officials. The 2023 edition of the Dialogue will incorporate topics on geographies, sovereignty, security, society democracies, dependencies and debt traps. Participants will discuss and clarify responses to challenges in both the real and virtual worlds, as well as discover and chart opportunities in a rapidly changing post-pandemic landscape. The Raisina Dialogue brings together policymakers, experts, and thought leaders from around the world to discuss issues related to international security, diplomacy, and economic development. The Raisina Dialogue was first held in 2016 and has since become a major platform for discussions on global issues. The conference is named after Raisina Hill, the location of the presidential palace in New Delhi, India. The conference is usually held in New Delhi and attracts participants from over 100 countries.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Grama Niladharis opt out of household survey
author: Author not found
Content: Grama Niladharis islandwide opted out of the task of carrying out a survey of all households with regard to their source of income, expenses, number of vehicles etc. According to Grama Niladharis, the Government had guaranteed them a sum of Rs 300 per household to facilitate the task. According to the information received through Divisional Secretariats, among other details sought by the Government are the precise number of members in each household, their occupations, photos of each family member, income and expenditures, the engine capacity of each vehicle in the households, whether the households are equipped with toilet facilities and the type of commode etc.  The survey is planned to be conducted online, while the Divisional Secretariats have conveyed to the Grama Niladharis that they point blank refused to comply with the task entrusted to them. These Officers have reportedly refused to comply with the instructions conveyed to them due to a clause which had stipulated that the details sought from the public should not be bogus and if it so, it could be a punishable offence. Due to the objections raised by these Officers, the task is said to have been entrusted to Management Assistants of the Divisional Secretariats. But they too have reportedly refused to conduct the survey due to the possibility of the public furnishing fake information. As a result, the task has now been entrusted to Development Officers who are newly recruited graduates. By Anuradha Herath

title: Former Head of Rakwana Children’s Home arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Rakwana Police yesterday (1) arrested the former Head of a Children’s Home in Rakwana on charges of concealing information with regard to acts of abuse of 11 girls who were under the care of the children’s home. The suspect is the wife of the main suspect in the case and she was due to be produced before the RakwanaMobile Court on the same day. Her husband had been apprehended in connection with the incident on 26 February and upon being produced before the Pelmadulla Chief Magistrate, he was remanded till 8 March. Police said in the wake of her husband’s arrest, the former head of the children’s home had been avoiding arrest. However, a team deployed by the Rakwana Police OIC Police Inspector C.P. Gunasekera apprehended the woman near a fuel station in the Rakwana Town. BY L. Niroshana – Kahawatta

title: Approvals for RE projects to be expedited
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said he held discussions with several State institutions on expediting granting approvals to 330 Renewable Energy (RE) projects that will integrate 2,300 MW to the National Grid by 2026. The Minister also said discussions included expediting approvals as well as cancelling provisional approvals of projects that cannot be continued. Police said in the wake of her husband’s arrest, the former head of the children’s home had been avoiding arrest. However, a team deployed by the Rakwana Police OIC Police Inspector C.P. Gunasekera apprehended the woman near a fuel station in the Rakwana Town.

title: Islandwide TU action misfired – Ratnapriya
author: Author not found
Content: The trade union action held yesterday (1) with the participation of professional trade unions was not successful, even though the unions claim otherwise, Director General of Trade Unions to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Saman Ratnapriya said. Ratnapriya accused the JVP of being behind the spate of strikes that had been organised in several sectors. “One of the main slogans was the demand for elections. But a majority of the 22 million people in this country do not believe that an election should be held at this juncture. Only 500 to 2,000 persons attended a protest organised by the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and the Frontline Socialist Party (FSP). But now, the JVP has created an artificial situation and has been demanding an election,” he alleged. “That is why trade unions which claimed that they did not have political affiliations have been calling for an election and promoting the JVP slogan. Thereby, they too were associated with the political party to win their slogans. The demand for taxes to be reduced isn’t feasible,” he added. He said the President held discussions with the trade unions on 25 February. “The President queried if they wanted the IMF bailout or not and said he (the President) would arrange for them to meet the IMF representatives. The President also pledged to discuss the alternate proposals that had been submitted by the trade unions which are striking this week,” he further said. The DGTU lamented that the striking trade unions had left the discussion table on a positive note, but were now going back on their word. “But strikes will only show political instability in the country. It will only show that there is turmoil in the island. The message that is going out is that the IMF should not give assistance to a country which is politically unstable and in turmoil,” he said. Meanwhile, the trade union action was only partially successful, as only 44,540 public servants out of 148,451 in six provinces participated in it, according to a Government survey. The survey had been conducted in North Western, North Central, Southern, Central, Eastern and Uva provinces. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Rename income tax as ‘Padeniya Tax’
author: Author not found
Content: If the doctors are not happy about the newly introduced income tax scheme, they should rename it as ‘Padeniya Tax,’ because former President of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Anuruddha Padeniya along with ‘Viyath Maga’ are responsible for pushing the country into dire economic straits, having collaborated with former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, President of the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF), Dr. Rukshan Bellana stressed.  “The entire country is faced with the present economic debacle due to their misguided policies which created chaos in several fields including agriculture. These parties have dragged the country into a state of bankruptcy. So, how can one expect an overnight recovery,” he queried, noting it had been the GMOA which had pushed former President Rajapaksa to lock down the country during the first Covid-19 wave when several parties including the GMOF had said otherwise. The fertiliser issue was also orchestrated by the then GMOA Chief, he alleged.  “The GMOA under its former President was known to interfere in political decisions including its move to prevent the Government from entering into several agreements,” he alleged. “Therefore, if the doctors are unable to accept the Inland Revenue Tax, they can rename it as ‘Padeniya Tax.’ It has not only affected them, but several other professional categories in the country,” he lashed out. He urged all parties to accept President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s plea to bear patience till 2024 for an anticipated economic growth rather than strike. “Agitate if you want, but striking is not the solution,” he said.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SLAF celebrates 72 years
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) celebrates 72 years today (2). In the seven decades that passed, the SLAF has come under the leadership of 17 Commanders. Today (2), its leadership is in the hands of its 18th Commander, Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana. The SLAF has come a long way since its first flight in a humble Chipmunk and de Havilland DC 1, passing through Mig 27s, Kfir C7s, and F-7s today. Many other aircraft have seen the largely ceremonial Air Force of the ‘70s emerge as a successful and battle-hardened Air Force of the 21st century, a spokesman said. The Royal Ceylon Air Force was formed on 2 March 1951, heralding the dawn of Sri Lanka’s military air power. On 2 March 1972, the Royal Ceylon Air Force was re-designated as the Sri Lanka Air Force with Ceylon becoming a Republic. Following the slogan Surakimu Lakambara, the SLAF has accomplished its duty to the country for the past 72 years, the spokesman added. The SLAF has consistently secured the airfields on the island and actively assisted the people in their time of need. Its role during the COVID-19 crisis and numerous other natural disasters has taken it close to the hearts of the people of Sri Lanka, who remember it for bringing them much needed relief in times of trouble by developing infrastructure in the health sector and assisting with the public vaccination drive, he further said and added, moving beyond Sri Lanka, the country is the proud owner of an extremely large Exclusive Economic Zone. Therefore, the SLAF successfully deployed the air asset to protect this vast area from illegal intrusion and fishing activities, extinguishing the fire in maritime vessels, and conducting Search and Rescue Operations, Maritime Pollution Monitoring and Control within the Sri Lanka Search and Rescue Region.

title: Professionals stage anti-tax strike
author: Author not found
Content: A number of professional trade unions engaged in a one-day trade union action yesterday (1), demanding the Government to amend newly introduced income tax scheme. Trade unions from essential services such as power, petroleum, water, ports, teachers, university lecturers, and banks, engaged in the trade union action. The schools were open and the teachers who supported the strike reported to work by wearing black attire.  The petroleum trade unions launched a work to rule campaign. Many employees engaged in duties while wearing black arm bands and hoisting black flags. Sri Lanka Telecom workers held a protest in front of Telecom headoffice. Electricity workers and bank tellers were also on strike while dock workers staged lunchtime protests at the Colombo Port. Train operations were not affected by the strike. Most banks across the country were closed as banking unions joined the strike. The agitations and protests carried out by doctors, nurses and several sections of the hospital staff affected the services of the National Hospital, Colombo and several hospitals around the country.  It was reported that National Hospital, Colombo, Teaching Hospital Kurunegala and Hospitals in Galle and Anuradhapura and Vavuniya were and several other parts of the country were affected by the agitations and protests carried out by doctors and other categories of health service.  The OPD services had been crippled while patients had been turned away. However, hospitals carried out admissions. The clinic patients in hospitals too were also affected by protests of doctors, nurses and hospital staff as they too had been sent home.  Meanwhile, Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe when contacted said that the membership of his outfit had also refrained from attending their work in the private sector.  The Association of Medical Specialists and the Government Dental Surgeons Association too refrained from attending to private sector services. There too only emergencies were to be carried out.  However all emergencies had been carried out, they added.  Pix by Sajeewa Chinthaka, Venura Chandramalitha, Manjula Dayawansha and Sarath Kumara By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Sirisena’s appeal dismissed with costs
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Civil Appellate High Court yesterday (1), dismissed the appeal, filed by former President Maithripala Sirisena, requesting to be discharged as a respondent in the 108 cases filed in relation to the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. The appeal was dismissed with costs, when the case was taken before Colombo Civil Appellate High Court Judges Frank Gunawardena and Sanjeewa Morais. Sirisena was further ordered to pay a sum of Rs 21,000 as costs. The Colombo District Court, on 7 January 2022, rejected the request made by Sirisena to be discharged from the 108 cases, filed by the families and victims of the Easter Sunday attacks, for the failure to prevent the attacks despite being warned of the same. Sirisena then filed the instant appeal before the Colombo Civil Appellate High Court against the decision of the Colombo District Court. He said, as he is not the President anymore, victims of the Easter Sunday attacks should claim compensation from the Government or by making the Attorney General a party to the action and not from him in his personal capacity. However, this appeal was so dismissed by the Colombo Civil Appellate High Court with costs. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: INDIAN CEO FORUM MEETS US AMBASSADOR
author: Author not found
Content: Indian CEO Forum (ICF) met US Ambassador Julie Chung and her team at the US mission in Colombo on 1 March 2023 and discussed opportunities for mutual collaboration to support the people of Sri Lanka in the current situation. ICF has over 70 companies as members including some companies headquartered out of the USA and headed by Indian nationals in Sri Lanka. CEOs apprised the Ambassador about various social initiatives taken by Indian companies in Sri Lanka that encompass areas such as promoting employment for women, mental health initiatives, and food and nutrition for children. Ambassador Julie Chung was appreciative of the timely Indian help to Sri Lanka and stressed that the common agenda of both the US and India is to assist Sri Lanka to handle the current economic crisis. She offered her guidance on various initiatives which Indian companies want to undertake to help the people of Sri Lanka. Ambassador Julie Chung was also appreciative of many Indian-born American entrepreneurs and executives heading various companies in the US. ICF was represented by T.S. Prakash, Manoj Gupta, Umesh Gautam, Sanjay Baid,  Anurag Sharma,  Ashish Chandra and Harikrishnan Sundaram.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sri Lanka stagnates at 146th position
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s rankings in World Bank’s (WB’s) ‘Women, Business and the Law 2022 Index’ remained unchanged at 146th position out of 190 countries over its previous year’s (2021) rankings with an unchanged score of 65.6 points out of a possible 100, the WB’s latest ranking in this regard, released yesterday (1) showed. Higher scores indicate greater equality vis-à-vis employment and entrepreneurial opportunities for women versus men and lower scores, the obverse. ‘Gender equality is essential to end extreme poverty and boost shared prosperity,’ the report quoting WB’s Chief Economist and Senior Vice President Carmen M. Reinhart, said. The WB defined ‘Women, Business and the Law ‘as an index that measures laws and regulations that affect women’s economic opportunity in 190 economies.  ‘In this regard, this project presents eight indicators structured around women’s interactions with the law as they progress through their lives and careers: Mobility, Workplace, Pay, Marriage, Parenthood, Entrepreneurship Assets, and Pension,’ it said. The indicators build evidence of the critical relationship between ‘legal gender equality’ and ‘women’s employment and entrepreneurship,’ the report added. Meanwhile, 12 countries had the perfect score of 100 out of 100 in this latest index, meaning that both men and women have equal opportunities as employees and businesspersons. They were, in alphabetical order, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Latvia, Luxembourg, Portugal, Spain and Sweden. In related developments in the SAARC region, three countries had higher ratings/points than Sri Lanka. They were Nepal (80.6 points), India (74.4) and Maldives (73.8). Nepal was 93rd and 94th equal out of 190 countries together with Kenya, India (124th) and Maldives (126th). In the previous year 2021 too these three countries scored the same number of points as at last year, namely 80.6, 74.4 and 73.8 points respectively. Last year, Sri Lanka shares the 146th and 147th positions with Marshall Islands, whereas in 2021 Sri Lanka occupied the 146th position and Marshall Islands (140th), respectively. Three other SAARC countries scored lower points than Sri Lanka last year. They were Pakistan (55.6 points), Bangladesh (49.4) and Afghanistan (38.1), respectively. These three countries scored the same number of points in 2021 as well. Bhutan, the only other SAARC country, has not been captured in either of these surveys. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Govt warns tax evaders
author: Author not found
Content: The Commissioner General of Inland Revenue has been directed to take immediate action to identify those working in specific professions who have failed to pay taxes and not provided proof of income. State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya gave these instructions at a meeting held yesterday (1) with officials of the Inland Revenue Department at the Ministry of Finance. In light of the increased emphasis on State revenue, Siyambalapitiya informed the Commissioner General of Inland Revenue that attention should be paid to identifying tax evaders, in addition to collecting revenue through taxation. The State Minister has also advised the Department to prepare a system to deal with relevant personnel and take prompt action. Problems related to collection of tax revenue were also discussed. (TR)

title: Kerosene prices reduced
author: Author not found
Content: The price of a litre of kerosene, which previously stood at Rs 355 has been reduced by Rs 50 to Rs 305. At the same time, the revised price of industrial kerosene, which previously stood at Rs 464 is now Rs 330 following a reduction of Rs 134. The price revision is effective midnight yesterday (1). Price of petrol 92 Octane, 95 Octane EURO 4, Clear Diesel, and Super Diesel 4 Star Euro 4 will remain unchanged for the time being, according to the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation statement released. (TR)

title: SLPI calls for applications for journalism course
author: Author not found
Content: Applications are now being accepted for the tenth batch of the Sri Lanka Press Institute’s one-year diploma course for new entrants into journalism, the mid-career programme for working journalists, and the training programme for regional correspondents. This includes curriculum development, staff training, and technology investment. Many who have followed these courses are now career journalists and work in various media organisations in the island. The Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission oversee the course and view the institute as an NVQ Qualified Training Institute. Emphasis is laid on amateur and professional journalists currently working in the media industry, apprentices seeking to enter the media industry, and undergraduates studying media subjects for external Degrees. The minimum qualification required is to pass GCE Ordinary Level with a credit pass for Sinhala language and the GCE Advanced Level. Those who have studied Communication and Media Studies for the Advanced Level and are awaiting results could also apply. It is  a one year course conducted in the Sinhala medium. The course will be co-ordinated by Emeritus Professor Sunanda Mahendra, and the panel of lecturers will include professors and veteran journalists from Kelaniya, Colombo, Sri Jayawardenepura, and Sri Palee Campus. An application form prepared by the applicant with educational qualifications and experience could be sent by post or via email to [email protected]

title: Export Earnings shrink for Fourth Month
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s merchandise export earnings contracted for the fourth consecutive month to January 2023 on a year on year (YoY) basis, with the contraction in export earnings in January 2023 being by 11.3 per cent to US$ 987 million, compared to a higher export figure of $ 1,103 million experienced in January 2022, Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) Tuesday’s (28 February) showed. The contraction in merchandise exports in January 2023 was led by garments, Sri Lanka’s number one foreign exchange earner last year shrinking to $ 424 million, from $ 516 million made a year ago in January 2022, industrial exports, other than garments and rubber products exports contracting to $ 284 million in January 2023, from $ 294 million in January 2022, agriculture exports other than tea exports shrinking to $ 91 million in January 2023, compared to a higher figure of $ 113 million experienced in January 2022 and rubber products exports shrinking to $ 73 million in January 2023 from $ 82 million made in January 2022, respectively. Meanwhile, merchandise imports contracted by 29.2 per cent YoY to $ 1,388 million in January 2023. Consequently Sri Lanka recorded a trade deficit of $ 410 million in January 2023. In related developments, the contraction in merchandise imports expenditure in January 2023 was led investment goods imports contracting by 48.6 per cent YoY to $ 198.9 million, food and beverage imports shrinking by 36.8 per cent YoY to $ 118.3 million and non-food consumer goods imports shrinking by 42 per cent YoY to $ 100.2 million in January 2023. However, the country’s fuel import bill rose by 11.8 per cent YoY to $ 481 million in January 2023.   Consequently, Sri Lanka registered a trade deficit of  $ 410 million in January 2023. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Cabinet approves National Policy on Gender Equality
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the implementation of the National Policy on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment and National Action Plan on Women, Peace and Security 2023-2027. Cabinet approval was granted on 5 September 2022 to formulate a National Policy for Women’s Empowerment to minimise the existing gender imbalances. Accordingly the Cabinet of Ministers approved the proposal presented by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Women, Child affairs and Social Empowerment the National Policy on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment under eight                            main areas with the contribution of all relevant parties. In 2000, the United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution entitled Women, Peace and Security and many developed and undeveloped countries in the world have introduced National Action Plans to implement the resolution. Accordingly the Cabinet of Ministers          approved the proposal presented by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Women, Child affairs and Social Empowerment to implement the National Action Plan on Women, Peace and Security 2023-2027 which has been drafted with the participation and agreement of all parties. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Former Lotteries Board Chairman enlarged on bail on two sureties of Rs 1 M each
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Manjula Thillakaratne on Tuesday (28 February) ordered former Deputy Minister and former Chairman of the Development Lotteries Board (DLB) Sarana Gunawardena, to be enlarged on bail on two sureties of Rs 1 million each after handing his indictments. Gunawardena has been accused and indicted before the High Court of misusing official vehicles belonging to the DLB, while serving as Chairman. The accused was present in Court when the case was called after being noticed at the previous hearing. The Judge fixed the pre-trial on 17 May. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: First day cover to mark first World Seagrass Day
author: Author not found
Content: A commemorative stamp and first day cover were issued to mark the first World Seagrass Day on 1 March 2023, under the chairmanship of Minister of Transport and Highways and Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena. The event was attended by Environment Minister Naseer Ahmed, foreign diplomatic representatives including ambassadors and high commissioners, the Secretary of the Ministry of Environment, officials from the Department of Posts, local and foreign environmental activists, school students, and others.

title: Four suspects enlarged on bail on two sureties of Rs 1M each
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya on Tuesday (28 February), ordered four suspects including a broker who had been remanded on charges of hoodwinking people from poverty-stricken families, by promising them cash while selling their kidneys to locals and foreigners, to be enlarged on bail. The Court thus ordered each of the suspects to be released on two sureties of Rs 1 million each. The Additional Magistrate instructed the Colombo Crimes Division (CCD), to expedite its probe into the case and file a progress report at the next hearing. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Temp wooden fence erected at site of fatal mishap
author: Author not found
Content: The officials from the Urban Development Authority (UDA), on 27 February, erected a temporary wooden fence at Hulan Wanguwa Junction, on the Norton Bridge – Diyagala road, which grabbed headlines on 19 February, after a private bus carrying a group of devotees, returning from the Sri Pada Sacred site, fell into a precipice. Following the accident three persons succumbed to their injuries while 26 others sustained serious injuries. The majority of pilgrims visiting the Sri Pada site, via Hatton, tend to use the Norton Bridge – Diyagala route as a shortcut to reach Nallathanniya. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: RTI prevails over Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law
author: Author not found
Content: In a landmark judgment, the Court of Appeal yesterday (28), held that the provisions of the Right to Information (RTI) Act shall prevail over the provisions of the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law. This was when the appeal filed by the Designated Officer, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament, K.A. Rohanadeera and the Secretary-General of Parliament Dhammika Dassanayake against Journalist Chamara Sampath and the Right to Information Commission was taken up before Court of Appeal Judges Sampath B. Abayakoon and P. Kumararatnam. Sampath had requested from the Information Officer of Parliament the list of names of MPs who have handed over their respective declarations of assets and liabilities in 2018 and the list of names of MPs who have handed over their declarations from 2010 up to the date of his request. The Information Officer, however, refused the request on the basis that he has to make an application in terms of the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Act, No. 1 of 1975 to the Speaker of Parliament, which is a separate Act that governs the declarations of the Members of Parliament. The Designated Officer too had held the same view. Sampath being aggrieved by the decision of the Designated Officer, appealed to the Commission in terms of Section 32 of the RTI Act, challenging the decision. After hearing the parties, the Commission, by the order appealed against, had reversed the decision of the Designated Officer and had ordered that the information requested by Sampath shall be released to him. The Commission had determined that the public authority in terms of the RTI Act being the Parliament of Sri Lanka and only one Information Officer and a Designated Officer have been appointed in relation to the said public authority, it is the duty of the Secretary-General of Parliament to provide the information requested by the respondent. They also stated that although the Speaker of Parliament is a separate institution within the Parliament of Sri Lanka, as the Chief Executive Officer of the Parliament, it is the duty of the Secretary-General to provide the information requested, which would not amount to any breach of the privileges of the Members of Parliament. The Commission had also noted that secrecy and the confidentiality of the declaration of assets and liabilities by the Members of Parliament would not be violated in terms of the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law as what the respondent requested is not the details of the declarations tendered, but only a list of the Members of Parliament who filed their declarations of assets and liabilities in accordance with the law. Rohanadeera and Dassanayake then filed the instant appeal in the Court of Appeal on 15 grounds including that the said Order is wrong and contrary to law, the Commission erred in law by concluding that the Parliament of Sri Lanka is the relevant Public Authority in the case of the information requested by the respondent. They also stated the Commission erred in law and fact by failing to acknowledge that even the Leader of the House and the Leader of the Opposition have separate Information Officers and Designated Officers, by failing to acknowledge that it is the Speaker of Parliament who has ‘possession, custody, or control’ of the information requested by the respondent and that the Commission erred in law when it held that the Parliament has institutional possession, custody and control of the information requested. Further, they noted the Commission erred in law by concluding that there is no impediment for the Secretary-General of Parliament to release the requested information, the Commission failed to appreciate that the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law is a special law which regulates all aspects relating to Declarations of Assets and Liabilities in Sri Lanka and that the Commission failed to acknowledge that the Declarations of Assets and Liabilities will prevail over the provisions of the Right to Information Act No. 12 of 2016, which is a general law. It had been their stand that the information requested by the respondent is in the possession, custody or control of the Speaker of Parliament and the Secretary-General of Parliament is in no position to interfere with the functions of the Speaker. It has also been urged that disclosure of any information on the assets and liabilities of the parliamentarians under the Right to Information Act would constitute a breach of the powers and privileges of the Parliament. Justice Sampath B. Abayakoon, delivering the judgement, said: “Members of Parliament are persons who are elected by the people and maintained by the people. They are expected to abide by the laws of the country at all times and provide examples for others to follow. Under the provisions of the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law, any person who comes under the provisions of the Law, fails to provide the relevant declaration of assets and liabilities as required, would be committing an offence punishable with a fine or imprisonment of either description or both such fine and imprisonment. It is therefore important for the public to know whether the relevant authorities have acted as required by law or not. The only way to obtain that information would be by seeking the list of the name of the Members of Parliament who have provided their declarations under the RTI Act. I am of the view that even if the declaration of assets and liabilities by the Members of Parliament who are required to provide that information should be with the Speaker of Parliament, there cannot be any impediment to the Secretary-General of Parliament as the Chief Executive Officer of the institution to inquire into and provide a list of the names as requested by the respondent in terms of RTI Act, which in any way would not amount to encroaching on the powers of the Speaker of Parliament in my view. I find no basis for the submission that the Secretary-General is not expected to go on a voyage of discovery to provide the information required either, as the respondent has requested information available well within the Parliament of Sri Lanka. I am of the view that providing the list of names of the Members of Parliament who have tendered their declaration of assets and liabilities as required by law is not disclosing the information they have provided in the declarations. I find that the argument advanced on that basis had also been an attempt to frustrate the purposes of the RTI Act. I am of the view that it is not open to any Information Officer or a Designated Officer of a public authority to deny information to frustrate the very intention of the Legislature when the RTI Act was enacted in order to expand the scope of combating corruption, promoting accountability and good governance.” Thereby, Court held that the provisions of the RTI shall prevail over the provisions of the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law when it comes to providing information as required by the RTI, subjected to the limitation imposed in terms of Section 5 of the RTI Act. Thishya Weragoda with S. Wimalaratne instructed by Niluka Dissanayake represented Sampath while Mahen Gopallawa SDSG with Avanthi Perera DSG represented the appellant. By Faadhila Thassim

title: No attempt made on President’s life – Police
author: Author not found
Content: Police rejected recent claims that the CID has launched an investigation into an alleged assassination attempt on President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The Police Media Division said the website of a private radio station posted an article about the CID launching an investigation into a conspiracy to assassinate the President, based on information they had received. The article had said a group affiliated to a local political party, conspired to assassinate the President while overseas, and that an attempt on the President’s life would be made within the next two weeks. However, Police confirmed that no such information was received by the CID and therefore no investigations were conducted in this regard. “The news is completely false,” Police said. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SL to become party to two Int’l Nuclear Conventions
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka will become a party to two major international conventions on nuclear obligations, following the Cabinet approval to consider nuclear energy as an alternative to meet Sri Lanka’s future energy needs earlier. Addressing the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (28), Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said the Cabinet approved the combined proposal, presented by the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of Power and Energy, to proceed in becoming a party to those conventions. “In accordance with that decision, a steering committee and nine action committees have been appointed to study matters related to electricity generation using nuclear energy. The International Atomic Energy Agency has given its recommendations regarding the self-assessment report prepared by the working groups and it is possible to proceed with the nuclear power generation project in line with the recommendations,” he said. Speaking further he said the Cabinet also approved to expand market opportunities for Jet A-1 Aviation Fuel. “The Jet A-1 Aviation Fuel is currently supplied by the Sri Lanka Petroleum Corporation. Due to the foreign exchange crisis that the country is currently facing, the operations of Sapugaskanda Oil Refinery, where Jet A-1 fuel is produced, has been disrupted and the import of Jet A-1 fuel has also become a challenge for Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC). Due to this, the supply of Jet A-1 fuel required for the cargo and passenger flights has been disrupted and as a result the focus has to be on alternative measures to supply the required Jet A-1 fuel for those aircraft,” he said. Gunawardena also noted that it has been accepted that giving the opportunity to supply Jet-A fuel to Sri Lanka, under the maximum supply limits, to the parties who supply Jet A-1 aviation fuel to the other countries, is more appropriate. It will not to hinder the supply of fuel produced at Sapugaskanda Refinery. Therefore, the Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Power and Energy to give that opportunity to other parties who are capable of supplying jet A-1 fuel to the country. Meanwhile, the Cabinet also approved the pilot project to operate Battery powered electric buses. Gunawardena said it is appropriate to introduce buses operating on solar energy to reduce the cost of importing fossil fuels and to face the international energy crisis. “The Minister of Transport and Highways presented the implementation of a public-private partnership project for the operation of battery powered electric buses, by the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB), covering the Western Province. This project will be centred on the commercial cities of the Colombo and Gampaha District. The Cabinet approved the implementation of a pilot project based on a formal feasibility study,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: WCT development project unaffected – SLPA
author: Author not found
Content: The West Container Terminal (WCT) development project is proceeding as scheduled and is unaffected by the accusations made against the Adani Group, the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) said. Despite Adani Group of India, which purchased a 51 per cent stake in the West Container Terminal (WCT), coming under fire by a research group for allegedly using opaque accounting methods and inflating its financial metrics to hide its debt levels and generate higher profits, the Sri Lanka Ports Authority said the WCT development project is moving forward as planned and that the allegations have had no impact on the project. Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone signed a BOT agreement with its local partner John Keells Holdings PLC and the SLPA for the USD 700 million worth project in September 2021. SLPA Managing Director, Susantha Abeysiriwardana told Ceylon Today that the project is expected to be partially operational by 2025 and fully operational by 2027. Adani Group and its partners will develop and operate the terminal for a period of 35 years. He added that the development project is exempted from VAT, and no tax regulations would impact it. Adani Port’s investment for WCT is USD 700 million, of which 70 per cent is a loan obtained by the joint venture as agreed.   Adani Group is facing severe criticism over allegations by Hindenburg Research.   Hindenburg Research is a short-selling research firm that investigates companies and publicly trades. In their research findings, they claimed Adani Group‘s founder and Chairman, Gautam Adani, who is one of the wealthiest people in India, had built a complicated web of front companies and subsidiaries to siphon money and inflate revenue. The Adani Group has denied the allegations made against it and has initiated legal action against the company that made the allegations, claiming that the report was aimed at damaging the company’s reputation and causing a drop in its stock price. Hindenburg Research had previously released a report in 2020 on Nikola Corporation, which alleged that the company had misled investors and that its founder, Trevor Milton, had made false statements about the company’s technology. By SuLochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Rice production exempted from Social Security Levy
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the proposal to remove the Social Security Levy on the purchase of paddy, rice production, and marketing. Speaking at the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (28), Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said Cabinet approval was granted to implement a programme to distribute Nadu rice that has been purchased by the Government for Rs 100 per kg to ensure a fair price for the paddy farmer, among low-income earners free of charge. He said in addition to the amount paid to the farmer per kilo of paddy, the paddy producers pointed out that an amount of approximately Rs 6 or 7 has to be spent on 1 kg of rice as Social Security Levy. This is apart from the additional cost that has to be borne for water, electricity, storage and transport until the final product is handed over to the customer. “They also pointed out that the farmers could be provided with a higher price and a certain concession can be granted to minimise the production cost. Considering these facts, Cabinet approved the proposal tabled by the President to revise the Social Security Contribution Levy Act No. 25 of 2022 to release the purchase of paddy, rice production, and marketing. This will ensure a price higher than Rs 100 for 1 kg of Nadu rice,” he said.  By Thameenah Razeek

title: Bandula contradicts President on holding LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana contradicted President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s recent statement in Parliament that there was no Local Government Election to begin with as the Election Commission has not legally set a date to hold the election. Gunawardana, who was responding to journalists during the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (28 February) on the tragic death of a protester, claimed that as an election has been declared and nominations have been submitted, no rally is permitted under election law, with the exception of the May Day rally. Journalists inquired about the death of the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Nivithigala PS candidate, who was injured during a JJB-organised protest on Sunday (26 February). In response, Gunawardana said the Police used minimum force to disperse the crowd led by JJB. He said the Government has instructed Security Forces to always use the least amount of force during protests. Further, he said the Police had granted permission to hold free meetings at Viharamahadevi Park and its surrounding area on 26 February. “Minimum force has been used to control the crowd when they marched straight towards Fort despite the Court orders. The Police said they would not use batons, only water cannon and tear gas. During protests, it is common for people to trip and fall. During the protest held against giving Hambantota Port to China, a large number of people were hospitalised and arrested,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Professional TUs to stage islandwide strike today
author: Author not found
Content: A large number of professional trade unions will stage an islandwide strike today (1), protesting the newly introduced income tax scheme.  These trade unions vary from the essential services sector, including power, health, petroleum, water, ports, postal, education and banks. The Government and Semi-government Trade Union Alliance will support the trade union action by wearing black bands and hoisting black flags. According to Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin, teachers are requested to wear black attire to work and black flags will be hoisted in schools. The petroleum trade unions will engage in a work-to-rule campaign. Doctors have pledged to throw their weight behind the massive trade union measures being taken by the Alliance of Professionals affected by the amended Inland Revenue Act today (1). GMOA Media Committee Member, Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam, when contacted yesterday (28), said the decision had been taken following an emergency General Committee meeting to support the massive strike scheduled for today (28). “It was unanimously decided at the Emergency Central Committee of the GMOA held today (1) to extend maximum support to the massive trade union action to be held tomorrow with the participation of all employees and trade unions in the government, semi-government and private sectors against the oppressive tax policy,” he said. He warned that protests were to be carried out in 12 districts where GMOA members would actively participate. Decisions were also taken to intensify protests in front of hospital premises or outside them in a public place.   The GMOA warned it would resort to a strike by 8 March if the Government continues to maintain an indifferent attitude. The Association of Medical Specialists (AMS) warned they would resort to limited trade union action today (1) against unfair taxation. AMS President and General Secretary, Drs. LakKumar Fernando and R. Gnanasekeram said the Executive Committee had studied the situation and decided on limited trade union action for 24 hours commencing from 8:00 a.m. today (1). However, the AMS would perform all patient related clinical work in state hospitals as usual. More protests will rock the state health service when the Alliance of Health Professionals (AHP) and the All Ceylon Nurses’ Union (ACNU) would also Stage protests against the Government and Health Ministry. Meanwhile, the Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA), yesterday (28) said they would assign all their buses, including school and office services, to facilitate the public, despite the scheduled trade union action. LPBOA Chairman Gemunu Wijerathne told Ceylon Today that even though all the services are suspended, the LPBOA has decided to operate all the buses as usual and claimed that it is unethical to State sector employees to organise such protests that inconvenience persons. Chairpersons of the Bank of Ceylon (BOC) and the People’s Bank assured uninterrupted service today (28), despite the trade union action. The duo said they expect bank employees too would ensure a maximum service. They requested the employees to report to work as usual considering the present situation in the country. They made these remarks at a meeting held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (28 February) in regard to the issues in the banking sector. By Dilanthi Jayamanne and Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Court orders to release body for burial
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage, yesterday, ordered the Kompannavidiya Police (formerly Slave Island Police), to hand over the remains of Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Nivithigala PS candidate P. Nimal Amarasiri to his son for burial. The victim died, after being subjected to tear gas and water cannon fired by the Police, during an anti-Government protest demonstration staged in Colombo, on 26 February, to demand that the Local Government Election be held as scheduled. The Fort Magistrate gave this order, at the conclusion of the Magisterial Inquest into the death of the 61-year-old, who was a resident of Dombgammana Dela, Niwithigala, Ratnapura. The Magisterial Inquest into the death was held by Magistrate Thilina Gamage, on visiting the National Hospital in Colombo as per submissions made to him, by Kompannavidiya Police yesterday (28 February). The Police informed the Magistrate, that they had been informed via phone, as to the death of the victim, by the National Hospital Police. Amarasiri passed away while being treated at the Emergency Ward at the hospital on 27 February. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Bolivian arrested with cocaine stock worth Rs 230M
author: Author not found
Content: A 26-year-old Bolivian national was arrested with cocaine soaked clothes valued at over Rs 230 million and the consignment weighed over 4.6 kg. The arrest was made by officers attached to the Customs Narcotics Control Unit, yesterday (28) morning at the green channel, on locating the cocaine consignment concealed in a cloth bag and backpack. “The clothes, fabrics, and parts of the cloth bag, including the pockets, were soaked in liquid cocaine,” Customs Media Spokesman Sudatta Silva said. “Customs investigations found the suspect arrived from Brazil via Dubai on EK 650 and this was her first trip overseas,” he said. Investigations were conducted by the Narcotics Control Unit of Customs with the assistance of the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB). By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Opposition proposes special motion to fund LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: A group of Political Party representatives including Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, Dullas Alahapperuma, Prof. G.L. Peiris and Dilan Perera, who met Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena in Parliament yesterday (28  February), proposed that Parliament should immediately allocate funds for the Local Government Election through a special motion. A statement from the Opposition Leader’s Office said the MPs requested the Speaker to implement this proposal in regard to the request made by Election Commission Chairman Nimal Punchihewa to intervene in ensuring that the Local Government Election is held as scheduled. The MPs have also requested that the House should be convened before 8 March. “The MPs requested that Parliament should make sure that people’s sovereignty is safeguarded,” the statement said. Speaker Abeywardena has said there should be a consensus between the ruling party and the Opposition MPs for the steps that should be taken by Parliament with regard to holding the election. Meanwhile, MP Alahapperuma said the Provincial Councils are inactive at present and the power is in the hands of Governors appointed by the President. “In the future, the samething will happen to local authorities,” he said.  “Taking this situation into consideration, the Speaker said a Party Leaders’ meeting has been called and a decision can be made about the future activities during that meeting,” the Opposition Leader’s Office said.  By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: No attempt made on President’s life – Police
author: Author not found
Content: Police rejected recent claims that the CID has launched an investigation into an alleged assassination attempt on President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The Police Media Division said the website of a private radio station posted an article about the CID launching an investigation into a conspiracy to assassinate the President, based on information they had received. The article had said a group affiliated to a local political party, conspired to assassinate the President while overseas, and that an attempt on the President’s life would be made within the next two weeks. However, Police confirmed that no such information was received by the CID and therefore no investigations were conducted in this regard. “The news is completely false,” Police said. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SL to become party to two Int’l Nuclear Conventions
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka will become a party to two major international conventions on nuclear obligations, following the Cabinet approval to consider nuclear energy as an alternative to meet Sri Lanka’s future energy needs earlier. Addressing the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (28), Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said the Cabinet approved the combined proposal, presented by the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of Power and Energy, to proceed in becoming a party to those conventions. “In accordance with that decision, a steering committee and nine action committees have been appointed to study matters related to electricity generation using nuclear energy. The International Atomic Energy Agency has given its recommendations regarding the self-assessment report prepared by the working groups and it is possible to proceed with the nuclear power generation project in line with the recommendations,” he said. Speaking further he said the Cabinet also approved to expand market opportunities for Jet A-1 Aviation Fuel. “The Jet A-1 Aviation Fuel is currently supplied by the Sri Lanka Petroleum Corporation. Due to the foreign exchange crisis that the country is currently facing, the operations of Sapugaskanda Oil Refinery, where Jet A-1 fuel is produced, has been disrupted and the import of Jet A-1 fuel has also become a challenge for Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC). Due to this, the supply of Jet A-1 fuel required for the cargo and passenger flights has been disrupted and as a result the focus has to be on alternative measures to supply the required Jet A-1 fuel for those aircraft,” he said. Gunawardena also noted that it has been accepted that giving the opportunity to supply Jet-A fuel to Sri Lanka, under the maximum supply limits, to the parties who supply Jet A-1 aviation fuel to the other countries, is more appropriate. It will not to hinder the supply of fuel produced at Sapugaskanda Refinery. Therefore, the Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Power and Energy to give that opportunity to other parties who are capable of supplying jet A-1 fuel to the country. Meanwhile, the Cabinet also approved the pilot project to operate Battery powered electric buses. Gunawardena said it is appropriate to introduce buses operating on solar energy to reduce the cost of importing fossil fuels and to face the international energy crisis. “The Minister of Transport and Highways presented the implementation of a public-private partnership project for the operation of battery powered electric buses, by the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB), covering the Western Province. This project will be centred on the commercial cities of the Colombo and Gampaha District. The Cabinet approved the implementation of a pilot project based on a formal feasibility study,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: WCT development project unaffected – SLPA
author: Author not found
Content: The West Container Terminal (WCT) development project is proceeding as scheduled and is unaffected by the accusations made against the Adani Group, the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) said. Despite Adani Group of India, which purchased a 51 per cent stake in the West Container Terminal (WCT), coming under fire by a research group for allegedly using opaque accounting methods and inflating its financial metrics to hide its debt levels and generate higher profits, the Sri Lanka Ports Authority said the WCT development project is moving forward as planned and that the allegations have had no impact on the project. Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone signed a BOT agreement with its local partner John Keells Holdings PLC and the SLPA for the USD 700 million worth project in September 2021. SLPA Managing Director, Susantha Abeysiriwardana told Ceylon Today that the project is expected to be partially operational by 2025 and fully operational by 2027. Adani Group and its partners will develop and operate the terminal for a period of 35 years. He added that the development project is exempted from VAT, and no tax regulations would impact it. Adani Port’s investment for WCT is USD 700 million, of which 70 per cent is a loan obtained by the joint venture as agreed.   Adani Group is facing severe criticism over allegations by Hindenburg Research.   Hindenburg Research is a short-selling research firm that investigates companies and publicly trades. In their research findings, they claimed Adani Group‘s founder and Chairman, Gautam Adani, who is one of the wealthiest people in India, had built a complicated web of front companies and subsidiaries to siphon money and inflate revenue. The Adani Group has denied the allegations made against it and has initiated legal action against the company that made the allegations, claiming that the report was aimed at damaging the company’s reputation and causing a drop in its stock price. Hindenburg Research had previously released a report in 2020 on Nikola Corporation, which alleged that the company had misled investors and that its founder, Trevor Milton, had made false statements about the company’s technology. By SuLochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Dearth of 2,100 schoolteachers in South – Yapa
author: Author not found
Content: There is a shortage of 2,100 schoolteachers in the Southern Province at present, Secretary of the Southern Province Education Ministry Office, Ranjith Yapa said. He said, this teacher shortage was visible concerning all major subjects and stressed that this unwelcome situation has emerged over the failure of the Education Ministry to enrol new teachers to the cadre since 2019. Yapa added that, however, the Ministry has called for applications from graduates to be enrolled as teachers and he hoped the existing teacher shortage could be resolved to a great extent in March. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Family’s monthly living expenses up by over Rs 58,000
author: Author not found
Content: A family in Colombo’s living expenses rose by an average Rs 58,487.04, Year-on-Year (YoY) last month (February 2023), Census and Statistics Department (CSD) data released yesterday (28) showed. Of this increase, the price of such a family’s food commodities bill increased by an average Rs 19,916.82 YoY to last month and their non-food commodity bill by Rs 38,570.22, YoY, it said. The main, YoY increase in such a family’s food bill last month was their milk powder bill increasing by an average Rs 3,153.44, sea fish bill by Rs 2,187.71, rice bill (Rs 1,522.10), fresh fruits bill led by plantains (Rs 1,250.13), chicken (Rs 1,247.36) and bread bill by Rs 1,247.02, respectively.  The main YoY non-food drivers of inflation last month were such a family in Colombo’s average transport costs increasing by Rs 13,400.37 last month, ‘housing, water, electricity, gas and other fuels such as firewood ’ (Rs 7,762.32), clothing and footwear (Rs 2,130), furnishing, household equipment and routine household maintenance (Rs 2,128.41), health (Rs 1,964.40), recreation and culture including to buy newspapers and books (Rs 1,125.41), education (Rs 1,850.04), communication expenses (Rs 826.71), alcohol, tobacco and narcotics (Rs 868.52) and the purchase of toilet soaps (Rs 675.72), respectively. Meanwhile, Colombo inflation decelerated for the fifth consecutive month to last month (February 2023) after a 58-month hiatus to 50.6 per cent YoY aided by food inflation decelerating to 54.4 per cent for the fifth consecutive month to last month, though non-food inflation accelerated by 48.8 per cent, over the previous month January’s figure of 47.9 per cent. Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe recently said he expects inflation to end the year at the single digit level. Prior to last month, the last time Colombo inflation decelerated for five consecutive months was 58 months ago, from November 2017 to April 2018, where Colombo inflation decelerated from 7.6 per cent to 3.8 per cent in the review period. The reason for the deceleration in Colombo inflation from November 2017 to April 2018, was the return of rains which rejuvenated agriculture, led by Maha 2017/2018 paddy cultivation and the revival of cheap hydroelectricity generation as well. Prior to that period, Sri Lanka suffered at least a year-long drought, impacting Yala 2016, Maha 2016/2017 and Yala 2017, respectively, not least cheap hydroelectricity generation. Nonetheless, Colombo inflation has been in double digits for 15 consecutive months to last month. Prior to last month, the last time Colombo inflation was in double digits for at least 15 consecutive months was more than 14 years ago, when Colombo inflation was in double digits for 32 consecutive months, from June 2006 to January 2009. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Rs 430M allocated to replant fallow fields
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Agrarian Development has allocated Rs 430 million for the year 2023 to be used to replant fallow fields. The Department has planned to replant 12,500 acres of fallow fields in the Maha Season with the use of these funds. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said the goal is to replant 47,000 acres that have become fallow fields for almost five years. Amaraweera advised the Department of Agrarian Development to provide the necessary technology, financial allocations, seeds and other inputs for cultivation of fallow fields. He further instructed the Department to also use such funds for the renovation of dilapidated canals, preparation of embankments, and removal of weeds presently in rice fields. (FT)

title: India urges Sri Lanka authorities to exercise restraint
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian High Commission has strongly taken up the recent attacks on Indian fishermen with Sri Lankan authorities and requested a probe. The High Commission tweeted that it has also asked the Government of Sri Lanka to investigate the matter and ensure that use of force and violence in any form are not resorted to against the fishermen. Meanwhile, according to latest official reports, the Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) detected 9,231 Indian fisher boats poaching in Sri Lanka’s territorial waters in 2021 alone, according to SLN’s 2021 Annual Report. However, of this number (9,231), only 19 Indian fishing vessels, equivalent to only 0.21 per cent of the total Indian fisher poaching vessels, together with a total of 157 Indian fishermen found in these 19 boats, were arrested by the SLN in 2021, statistics further showed. (PA)

title: Lorry collides with bus in Thambuththegama
author: Author not found
Content: One person died and two others were hospitalised when a lorry rear-ended a bus in Thambuththegama. The Police Media Division said the accident occurred when a lorry plying from Anuradhapura towards Thambuththegama crashed into a parked bus. Three individuals were injured and rushed to the Thambuththegama Hospital. One of them was pronounced dead on admission. The deceased is a 30-year-old resident of Eriyagama, Malwanagama. Both drivers were arrested. The lorry driver was released on a surety of Rs 500,000 while the bus driver was released on a surety of Rs 200,000 after being produced before the Thambuththegama Magistrate on 27 February. Thambuththegama Police are conducting investigations.  By Aloka Kasturiarachchi
