title: Cabinet Decisions
author: Author not found
Content: Preferential Trade Agreement with Bangladesh It is expected to strengthen relations with key trade stakeholders at the regional level to develop market access opportunities for Sri Lankan exporters by removing market barriers and to achieve the objectives of attracting investment as well as to further enhance economic cooperation as a remedy to the existing problems in regard to domestic supply. Thus, Cabinet approval was granted on 14 June 2021 to enter into a Preferential Trade Agreement between Sri Lanka and Bangladesh. It has been identified that a Preferential Trade Agreement with Bangladesh can further boost bilateral trade over existing trade agreements. Accordingly, the proposal made by the President to speed up negotiations on the proposed Preferential Trade Agreement with Bangladesh under the guidance of the International Trade Office was approved by Cabinet. Agreement between ‘Sight For All’ and Ministry of Health The Australian Community Project Institute ‘Sight For All’ has agreed to donate medical and surgical ophthalmic equipment to eye units in selected hospitals in Sri Lanka and to provide a grant to develop health staff skills. Under this, it is expected to provide modern facilities for eye surgeries at Badulla Provincial Hospital, Ratnapura, Batticaloa, and Kalubowila Teaching Hospitals and Tangalle Base Hospital, and to develop the skills of eye health workers and improve equipment in the eye units of Divisional hospitals. A grant of Rs 99.42 million is to be received under this project. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Health to enter into an agreement with the Australian Community Project Institute ‘Sight for All’ to accept the grant. Sri Lanka Export Development Act No. 40 of 1979 Considering the impact of the depreciation of the rupee as well as the value/ cost of the global market, the value of insurance, and shipping charges, the CESS tax has been revised on the sub quantities of precise units on selected goods under 677 combined classification codes (HS Codes) and the relevant regulation for that has been published by the Extraordinary Gazette Notification, dated 14 November 2022, under Section 14 of the Sri Lanka Export Development Act No. 40 of 1979. Such regulations imposed as per the provisions of the said Act should be forwarded to Parliament for its concurrence within four months from the date of publishing such regulations. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the resolution furnished by the President as the Minister of Investment Promotion to submit the said regulation published in the Extraordinary Gazette Notification dated 14 November 2022. New Act to protect victims and witnesses of crime Cabinet approval was granted at their meeting held on 8 March 2021 to introduce a new Act with proper provisions so that internationally recognised standards and practices can be followed instead of the Protection of Victims of Crime and Witnesses Act which is in effect at present. The clearance of the Attorney General has been granted for the Bill drafted by the Legal Draftsman. Accordingly, Cabinet approval was granted to the resolution submitted by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms to publish the said draft Bill in the Government Gazette and forward to Parliament.

title: HRCSL calls for IGP’s report on firing tear gas on protesters
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) yesterday (27) requested the IGP to submit a report, within 24 hours, on the incident involving the Police using tear gas and water cannon to disperse Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) protesters at Union Place in Colombo on 26 February. In a tragic turn of events, JJB Nivithigala Pradeshiya Sabha Candidate Nimal Amarasiri, who was admitted to the National Hospital of Sri Lanka (NHSL) succumbed to the injuries sustained during the protest. JVP General Secretary Tilvin Silva stressed that President Ranil Wickremesinghe must take the responsibility for this tragic death. HRCSL stated that its attention has been drawn to the incident in which approximately 28 people were injured, after Police used tear gas and water cannon during a protest march organised by the JJB. Also, the JJB recently lodged a complaint with the HRCSL citing that the authorities have failed to serve justice by apprehending those responsible for the attack on a National People’s Power meeting held recently in Kalagedihena, Gampaha. The complaint was made by Attorney-at-Law Sunil Watagala  The HRCSL said that further investigations will be conducted based on the facts presented in the IGP’s report. Meanwhile, Police said that the protesters were not attacked and batons were not used on them. Police said they had to fire tear gas and water cannon at Ibbanwala Junction as the protesters disrupted the Police when they were explaining that they could not go ahead with the protest according to Court Orders. To control the tense situation the Police had to fire tear gas and water cannons, the Police Spokesman said. Furthermore, SSP Thalduwa said five Police personnel were also admitted to the hospital as a result of injuries sustained during the protest. The Police used tear gas and water cannon to disperse the JJB protesters at the Ibbanwala Junction in Colombo 02 on Sunday. Police prevented protesters from entering areas which were cordoned off to them following a Court order. However, as protesters attempted to move forward by breaking the Police chain, tear gas and water cannon were used to dissuade the group. Two Court orders were issued on 25 February preventing 26 persons, including JJB Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake, from staging protest marches in Kollupitiya, Slave Island and Colombo Fort areas as well as the Hospital Square. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan and Amra Liyakath

title: Import restrictions on cosmetics, beauty tools to be removed
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said a new circular is currently being prepared to remove the import restrictions on cosmetics and beauty tools. He said a stock of cosmetics and beauty tools, stored in four containers at the port, will be sold in a public auction. These containers are stuck at the Port as the importers have not followed certain regulations. Siyambalapitiya revealed this to the media after a programme in Dehiowita. “With the ban on imports, the Government had to stop the release of 1,500 containers. Some containers were released later and there are still 650 containers still stuck. Also, cosmetics that were previously banned were later granted approval by the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) and the Sri Lanka Tourism Board,” he said. Speaking further, the State Minister said when the approval was obtained from those two institutions, the middlemen who make their living from cosmetics faced several difficulties. “As a result, a circular is being prepared to solve these types of issues. Customs in Sri Lanka Ports have halted the release of four containers of cosmetics and beauty tools, because they were imported from the United Kingdom, India, Pakistan, Singapore, Dubai and China without proper approval. There was a suggestion to dispose of these, but I was informed that among these are standard cosmetics too,” he said. Siyabalapitiyam said after informing the President, steps were taken to check the quality of the cosmetics.

title: Mayantha quits COPF Chair post
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Mayantha Dissanayake, who confirmed his resignation from the Chairmanship of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), claimed that it is his duty to comply with Party Leader’s decisions, no matter whether they were right or wrong. He also noted that he would inform of his resignation to the Speaker in writing. Addressing the media yesterday (27), he noted that the controversy with regard to the chairmanship erupted because there was no unity among the COPF members. “I decided to submit my resignation as there is no unity among the COPF members and also it is my duty to obey the party leader no matter whether he is right or wrong,” Dissanayake said. Dissanayake was appointed Chairman of COPF by the Parliament Committee of Selections on 23 February despite the nomination of SJB MP Harsha de Silva for the same post by the Opposition. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Govt’s message to public is ‘shut up and sit down’ – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: The message of the Government to the public is loud and clear and it is to ‘shut up and sit down,’ Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa stressed. Premadasa made this remark condemning the use of tear gas and water cannon on protesters of Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), who gathered in Colombo to demand the Local Government Election. “No leader or party has ever been right all the time, it’s why we need to tolerate dissenting voices within a democracy. Today NPP protestors were tear gassed and many sustained serious injuries. The government’s message is loud and clear to the public, ‘shut up and sit down’,” he tweeted.  The JJB protest was staged against the government, demanding the holding of elections without delay. The protesters took to the streets on 26 February amidst two court orders being issued by both the Fort Magistrate’s Court and the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court, preventing a total of 26 persons, including JJB Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake from entering several areas in Colombo during the protest.  Police fired tear gas and water cannon to disperse the group of protesters at Ibbanwala Junction, near Town Hall in Colombo, during the protest. A total of 28 sustained injuries and were admitted to the National Hospital in Colombo. One of them succumbed to injuries while receiving treatment at the hospital ICU yesterday (27). By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Range Bandara claims SJB won’t last
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) is dying a slow death due to imprudent and imperfect political practices of its leader Sajith Premadasa. The Party will not survive until next General Election, UNP General Secretary Palitha Range Bandara claimed yesterday (27). He said the SJB has become weaker as its members are divided into several groups. By the time of next General Election, only Sajith Premadasa and Lakshman Kiriella will remain as SJB members. There is a slight possibility that S.M. Marikkar and Tissa Attanayake might be with them, he said. The UNP General Secretary claimed that former SJB MP Mujibur Rahuman was sacrificed for the selfish political agendas of certain people.  “Premadasa is not a person who is ready to take over responsibilities. On several occasions he has escaped when he had a huge responsibility. “The SJB is divided into several groups. Some members work with Leader Premadasa, some work with Sarath Fonseka, some with Rajitha Senaratne, some with Harsha de Silva, a group is with Patali Champika Ranawaka. Tamil speaking members are in another group,” Range Bandara claimed.      He also claimed that the majority of politicians who broke away from the UNP and tried to form their own political party, couldn’t survive in politics for long time. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: People in North agreeable to local mechanism – HRCSL
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL), following its recent visit to the Northern Province, to look into pressing human rights-related issues, noted that despite people being in favour of an international mechanism for accountability and reconciliation, they were agreeable to an internal mechanism, provided that the Truth Commission comprises members with competency and integrity, and allows for the participation of the representatives of the victims without any control by the Government. In light of the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) sessions, beginning in Geneva next month, the HRCSL, led by its Chairperson retired Supreme Court Judge Rohini Marasinghe, visited the Northern Province from 16 to 18 February and concluded their mission by presenting a report with number of rights-related recommendations to President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The main concern of the Commission was to address the disparity between the North and the South on the security issue. On the Truth Commission, the HRCSL said that the Act of Parliament, establishing a Truth and Reconciliation Commission, constituted under the powers of Parliament, should be equipped with sufficient powers to function independently and transparently and to address issues placed before them without any political interference. The Truth Commission, the HRCSL said, must be able to build the trust and confidence of the victims and/or the families of the victims from its inception, or the Government should take steps to do so as a precondition to the establishment of the Commission. To build the trust and confidence of the victims and their families, it is fundamental that issues pertaining to land, enforced disappearances and missing persons and long-term detainees are meaningfully addressed and resolved by the government as a threshold concern, the report said. The Commission observed that there were conflicting views from the participants about the central purpose of a truth commission. The Commission also expressed concern about persons detained under Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), some of whom have been held for more than 14 years, which was a gross violation of their fundamental human rights under the Constitution and a violation of their rights under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The HRCSL also recommended that the Parole Board take cognizance of the nature of the offence committed and the behaviour of the convicted prisoners mentioned and advise the authority to refer for a pardon or for a nolle prosequi for those awaiting the conclusion of the trial whenever it deems appropriate. The Commission recommended these matters to the Ministry in charge of the prisoners for an appropriate solution. As such, it has now become relevant and urgent concerning the issue of reconciliation. The HRCSL also recommended to the government the strengthening of border control, by the Navy, along the coast, island-wide. It also recommended to have a consistent security policy applicable to all provinces in the country dependent on the intelligence data collected by the Security Council and the policy of the government on the national security of the people in Jaffna. The HRCSL said there was severe harassment, by the Military, caused to the people crossing the checkpoints, through body searches on women or directing passengers to alight from the buses and / unload goods from the lorries. Also the HRCSL observed that an identification pass system for fishermen in Mannar to fish is a violation of a fundamental right. The Commission observed that the livelihood of farmers concerning cultivation and livestock rearing is disrupted, as their lands are primarily in the possession of the military, Wildlife and Forest Department, and Archaeological Department. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Two monks among three arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Three persons, including two monks, were arrested yesterday (27) for aiding a suspect, who was in the custody of the Katunayake Airport Police, over several murders, to flee the country. According to the Western Province South Crimes Division, the two monks and the other person, who had operated as the driver of the vehicle transporting the suspect, were arrested in Hettipola. The suspects are the Chief incumbent of the Hettipola Rittadeniya Sri Jaya Lankarama Viharaya, Poththewala Indrasara (40) and monk Diwulwewa Deepananda (38). The other suspect, 27-year-old Kamburugamuwa Weerasinghe Arachchilage Dhilan, is a resident of Kalubowitiyana in Ambewala.  On Sunday (26) Four Katunayake Airport Police officers, including the OIC, were arrested for releasing the wanted criminal from Police custody. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said the suspect, a Navy deserter, wanted for several murders and subject to a travel ban, arrived at the airport on 24 February with the intention of flying to Dubai. The main suspect, who escaped, was identified as a 28-year-old Kalutara South resident. He had committed 19 murders, nine by himself and ten with the assistance of others.

title: Court appoints expert panel to probe Schaffter’s death
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (27) appointed a five-member panel of medical specialists, headed by Prof. Dr. Asela Mendis, who is a Senior Lecturer in the Department of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Colombo, to determine conclusively, whether the demise of the Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Dinesh Schaffter last December, was a suicide or murder. The other four medical specialists, named by the Additional Magistrate in the panel, are Prof. D. C. R. Perera, Prof. D. N. Fernando, Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) Dr. D. R. Ruwanpura and JMO Dr. Sivasubramanium. Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya mentioned that she was forming the said panel, as per Provisions contained in Sections of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act. Accordingly she ordered the Court Registrar, to submit all medical reports pertaining to the deceased, such as his post-mortem reports and the forensic post-mortem report, compiled on the victim, prepared by Consultant Psychiatrist Dr. Neil Fernando, to the panel of medical specialists, for their perusal. Later further proceedings of the case were deferred to 14 March by the Court. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Speaker to discuss EC’s letter with political Parties
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena will hold a discussion, in Parliament today (28), with political Parties, on the letter he received from the Election Commission (EC), seeking his intervention to have funds released for the conduct of the Local Government Election 2023, Ceylon Today reliably learns. Meanwhile, the Speaker said his response to the said letter, will be sent to the Ministry of Finance. The Speaker said he received the letter from the EC last Friday (24). BY Anuradha Herath and Krishan Pathirath Jayasuriya

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SC fixes date to consider Petition against failure to fund LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights Petition filed by Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Ranjith Maddumabandara, against the failure to provide funds to hold the Local Government Election in March 2023, was fixed for support on 3 March by the Supreme Court yesterday (27). This was when the Petition was taken before Supreme Court Justices Yasantha Kodagoda, S.Thurairaja and Priyantha Fernando. While Additional Solicitor General Nerin Pulle requested Court to fix the case for 11 May, President’s Counsel Upul Jayasuriya, appearing on behalf of the Petitioner, requested for it to be fixed on an earlier date before 9 March, which was when the Local Government Election was initially due to be held, considering it a matter of urgency. Thereby Court fixed the Petition to be taken up on 3 March. Meanwhile, President’s Counsel Upul Jayasuriya also requested for a Judge-Bench devoid of Justice S. Thurairaja on the basis that he had already formed an opinion on a similar matter before the same Court in regard to the Local Government Election. Justice Thurairaja however opposed such statement on the basis that he had not formed any opinion and that he had not favoured any case. While stating that such statement is unfair, Justice S. Thurairaja said that each case has been decided based on the facts and submissions made before Court. It was noted in the Petition that the failure to provide funds for the Local Government Election, notwithstanding the fact that an estimated sum of Rs 10 billion has been allocated to the Election Commission for conducting elections, other than parliamentary elections, under the Activity Budget Estimates for the fiscal year of 2023 and/or Budget for the year 2023 is a violation of Fundamental Rights. It was also stated that the Minister of Finance has no mandate by the people of Sri Lanka to act in such a dictatorial manner disregarding democratic values that are enshrined in the Constitution. He thereby sought an interim order, restraining the respondents and relevant authorities from withholding any funds allocated by the Activity Budget Estimates for the purpose of conducting the Local Government Polls 2023. He also sought an order to be issued to tender the circular prohibiting the financing of the Local Government Polls 2023. Nine, including the Secretary to the Treasury of the Ministry of Finance, Commissioner General of Elections, Chairman of the Election Commission, members and the Attorney General were named as respondents to the Petition. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Jaffna TH, Tellipalai BH in quandary as incinerator malfunctions
author: Author not found
Content: Tellipalai Base Hospital and Jaffna Teaching Hospital (TH) are currently facing a dilemma due to a technical fault in the incinerator used to destroy clinical waste. Jaffna Teaching Hospital Director Dr.T. Sathyamoorthy yesterday (27), when contacted, said the hospital was trying to get a separate incinerator installed, while the operation of the incinerator, at Thellipalai, had been temporarily stopped for repairs.  He said the issue with regard to the incinerator had been discussed with the Jaffna City Council, while an area had been identified in Gombeyan Mayanan, where clinical waste from Hospital would have to be discarded, without causing harm to the people of that particular area.  Dr. Sathyamoorthy said that he had received a letter from the Governor’s Office a week earlier, saying the place identified in Gombeyan Mayanan was unsuitable for setting up the incinerator and that an alternate place should be selected. “Since the matter is still under discussion with the Governor of the Northern Province and remains to be resolved, steps have been taken to incinerate the hospital’s medical waste through private companies. The Hospital generates about 400 tonnes of clinical waste daily. While natural waste is processed, plastics are handed over to the Municipal Council. He said that cardboard and bottles that get collected were sold outside the hospital.  Dr. Sathyamoorthy noted that setting up of an incinerator and operating it required a certain amount of funds. Similarly, medical waste is not allowed to accumulate in the hospitals, so that it does not harm the people. “The public need not be afraid, as measures have been taken to incinerate clinical waste by giving it to private sector companies.” The TH Director reassured. Authorities at Thellipalai BH, when contacted said there had been a few issues with the incinerator, so much so that, some of the waste items remained as the combustion process did not occur as it should. They said that there was an issue with the standard of the mechanism so that the Jaffna TH had called for its repair. Meanwhile, informed sources yesterday (27) said that till recently the Tellipalai Base Hospital incinerator had also disposed waste of the Jaffna Teaching Hospital, and Jaffna District.  Being faced with the recurring problem of the incinerator, there had been attempts to send the waste from Jaffna for disposal in Vavuniya, much to the annoyance of the politicians of that District. Earlier, waste from Jaffna TH had even been disposed of at a no- man’s land in Ariyalai, in the suburbs of Jaffna District. However there had been severe opposition from the people in the area – specially when they had sourced the garbage to the Jaffna TH.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Import restrictions on cosmetics, beauty tools to be removed
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said a new circular is currently being prepared to remove the import restrictions on cosmetics and beauty tools. He said a stock of cosmetics and beauty tools, stored in four containers at the port, will be sold in a public auction. These containers are stuck at the Port as the importers have not followed certain regulations. Siyambalapitiya revealed this to the media after a programme in Dehiowita. “With the ban on imports, the Government had to stop the release of 1,500 containers. Some containers were released later and there are still 650 containers still stuck. Also, cosmetics that were previously banned were later granted approval by the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) and the Sri Lanka Tourism Board,” he said. Speaking further, the State Minister said when the approval was obtained from those two institutions, the middlemen who make their living from cosmetics faced several difficulties. “As a result, a circular is being prepared to solve these types of issues. Customs in Sri Lanka Ports have halted the release of four containers of cosmetics and beauty tools, because they were imported from the United Kingdom, India, Pakistan, Singapore, Dubai and China without proper approval. There was a suggestion to dispose of these, but I was informed that among these are standard cosmetics too,” he said. Siyabalapitiyam said after informing the President, steps were taken to check the quality of the cosmetics.

title: Civil society demands Govt refrain from undermining EC’s legal mandate to hold LG polls
author: Author not found
Content: More than 81 civil society members are deeply concerned by reports of continued pressure on the Election Commission to postpone the local government elections, scheduled for 9 March. They demand that the President and the government refrain from acting in a way that undermines the Election Commission’s legally mandated and constitutionally valid local government elections. “It is now clear that this pressure comes from within the government, specifically the executive branch and we condemn attempts, by certain powerful members of the political and bureaucratic elite, to undermine the people’s franchise, sovereignty, and representative democracy giving the economic crisis as an excuse,” they said in an official statement released recently. The signatories include, A.M. Faaiz, Aruna Shantha Nonis, Austin Fernando, Bernard Edirisinghe, Bhavani Fonseka, Dr. Brito Fernando, Dr. Maduranga Kalugampitiya, Dr. Rajan Rajasingham, Dr. Mario Gomez, Dr. Ramesh Ramaswamy, Nimal Chandrasena, Dr. Paikiasothy Saravanamuttu, Dr. Vinya Ariyaratne, Fr. Jeewantha Peiris, Gamini Viyangoda, Jehan Perera, Joe William Jude Fernando, Lionel Bopage, President’s Counsel M.A. Sumanthiran, Prof. Jayadeva Uyangoda, Nuwan Bopage, Prof Neil DeVotta, Dr. Radhika Coomaraswamy, Ruki Fernando and Rajan Hoole. They further noted, “with the socio-economic challenges posed by the economic upheaval, we must rally together to counter initiatives to undermine the democratic processes, people’s franchise, and popular sovereignty. We note that mismanagement of the political front by undermining the democratic process can only deepen political instability. It will in turn impact adversely the recovery from the present economic crisis,” they said in the statement. They reminded the President, the government, and public servants of their constitutional obligation to extend the fullest support and cooperation to the Election Commission to fulfil its constitutional duty of conducting free and fair elections and concluding the local government election as scheduled. “We therefore earnestly urge the President and the government, public service officials and others to refrain from any action or inaction that would subvert the democratic process.” They emphasised to the country’s political leadership that playing with the people’s franchise and democratic rights for partisan gains has in the past caused huge political and social costs. “The United Front Government in 1975 manipulated the Constitution and the judiciary to stay in power for two more years only to suffer an unprecedented electoral disaster in 1977. A few years later, the United National Party Government of 1977 manipulated the Constitution in 1982 to extend the life of the Parliament for another full term through a referendum, instead of holding the constitutionally due parliamentary election. This blatant constitutional and institutional manipulation to legalise an unconstitutional and illegitimate political ambition, soon plunged the entire country into a protracted violent conflict, causing unprecedented political instability and suffering to the people. Sri Lankan citizens are still struggling to recover from the social, economic and political aftershocks of that most arbitrary act of political manipulation carried out by a government leadership for narrow, selfish and partisan gains.” The civil society demanded that all members of the public service fulfil their constitutional obligation of facilitating the local government election as scheduled, without allowing themselves to commit illegal acts under undue and unethical pressure. Also, they urged the international community to encourage the government to guarantee that the Sri Lankan citizens exercise their right to franchise without any hindrance. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: French Govt ready to assist SL – Ambassador
author: Author not found
Content: French Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Jean Francois, said the French Government is ready to provide all possible support in the face of the economic crisis, that Sri Lanka is facing, both within and outside the Paris Aid Group. The French ambassador made these comments when he met the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva recently. The Ambassador further appreciated the Sri Lankan Government’s efforts to steer the current economic programme in the right direction. The Minister pointed out to the Ambassador that according to the guidance given by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the President has taken many difficult and politically unpopular decisions in order to rise from the economic crisis that Sri Lanka is facing. He said, the Government and the people of the country have fulfilled all the promises made to the IMF, so the French Government is requested to provide the necessary support to sign the agreement with the IMF immediately. The Ambassador told the Minister that the French Government will provide all possible support to Sri Lanka in this regard. Pointing out that there are a large number of ships owned by businessmen and companies in France, the Minister                           requested the Ambassador to encourage those ships, sailing in the Indian Ocean, to obtain services from the Ports of Colombo and Trincomalee. The Minister also emphasised that French businessmen and companies are invited to invest in Sri Lanka’s shipping, aviation and energy sectors. He also requested the Ambassador to resume direct air services from Paris to Colombo. The Ambassador gave a positive response to and said that several French airlines have already expressed their willingness to conduct   direct flights to Sri Lanka and through this, a large number of French tourists are expected to visit Sri Lanka. Given the fact that  90 per cent of the technical equipment used for the operations of the Katunayake Airport is manufactured in France, the Minister pointed out the available opportunities for implementing a closer    joint programme with  France in the implementation of Sri Lanka’s aircraft operations and requested the Ambassador to provide the necessary support for that. The Economic Consul of the French Embassy and the Secretary of the Ministry also participated in the discussion.

title: Leprosy eradication conference held in Kalmunai
author: Author not found
Content: A regional conference on eradication of leprosy was held at the Office of the Regional Director of Health Services, Kalmunai on 22 February 2023. The conference was chaired by the Regional Director of Health Services (RDHS), Dr. I.S. M. Rifaz. The conference was organised by the Alliance Development Trust (ADT) in partnership with RDHS, Kalmunai. Specialist in Dermatology at Kalmunai Ashraff Memorial Hospital Dr.  I. L. Mahil and Epidemiologist at the Regional Health Services, Kalmunai, Dr. M. A. C. M. Fazal, participated as resource persons. Statistics pertaining to the status of leprosy in Kalmunai were presented during the conference. In addition, discussions focused on suggestions and proposals to completely eradicate leprosy in the region. Several officials and dignitaries including the Head of programmes, The Leprosy Mission England and Wales, Sian Arulanantham, Deputy Director, RDHS Kalmunai, Dr. Wajith, Director, ADT, Raghu Balachandran, officials attached to RDHS Kalmunai, representatives of ADT, PHIs, representatives of religious organisations, interfaith leaders, and representatives of non-governmental organisations participated in the conference.

title: Around 164 dengue cases reported from Galle
author: Author not found
Content: Galle District Regional Epidemiologist D. Eranga Hettiarachchi said around 164 dengue patients have been reported in the last six weeks. More dengue cases, he added, had been reported from the MOH divisions of Galle Municipal Council, Baddegama, Balapitiya, Habaraduwa, and Akmeemana. Dr. Hettiarachchi, who stated that no dengue deaths had been reported during this six-week period, also said a dengue control programmes had begun at the medical officer of health division level. He also mentions that there has been a decrease in the number of dengue patients reported this year, compared to the same time last year (2022). Dr. Hettiarachchi said fishermen in Ambalangoda, Hikkaduwa, and Galle worked to raise awareness about dengue control.  BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Rs 400M allocated for parachute paddy cultivation
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Agrarian Development has allocated Rs 400 million for the expansion of parachute paddy cultivation this year. Accordingly, arrangements have been made for paddy cultivation in 13,000 acres under this programme. The Department has taken measures to provide nursery trays to farmers, free of charge, through this allocation and also technical knowledge. The Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera, instructed officials in charge of the project, to provide parachute nursery trays under the Agriculture Sector Modernisation Project and the Small Scale Agri- Entrepreneurs Participation Project currently under the Ministry of Agriculture. Amaraweera said, although the Parachute Cultivation method, which is a very successful rice cultivation method in China, is currently being used in our country, local farmers still do not have a proper understanding of such method. He said that in order to increase the yield of paddy cultivation in our country, new cultivation methods should be introduced and by using the parachute method, it is possible to increase the current yield of paddy per acre and increase the income of a farmer byRs 35,000 per acre.

title: ITALY-SRI LANKA BILATERAL DIALOGUE SETS STAGE FOR GREATER COLLABORATION IN TOURISM
author: Author not found
Content: A recent bilateral dialogue on Tourism, organised by the Italian Embassy in Colombo, brought together key stakeholders in the tourism and hospitality sectors, from Sri Lanka and Italy, with the goal of exploring and leveraging on synergies and opportunities for collaboration between the two countries. Ambassador for Italy in Sri Lanka, Rita Giuliana Mannella, delved into the relationship between Sri Lanka and Italy, calling it a strong and abiding one. “While celebrating ancient links coupled with strong socio-political ties, we are excited about the possibilities for partnership and collaboration in the spheres of culture and tourism, which have the potential to deepen the dynamic and mutually rewarding relationship between our countries,” she said. A delegation comprising the Special Ambassador of the Bid Committee of Expo 2030 Rome, Prof. Romeo Orlandi, Legal Adviser to the Councillor for Culture of the Municipality of Rome Miguel Gotor Lorenzo Bimbi and CEO and Founder of Mancini Worldwide Alessandro Mancini, representing the largest collective of tour operators and agents in Italy, directed the dialogue to reflect the modern day Italian traveller.  Orlandi spoke of Rome’s candidature for World Expo 2030 and inherent benefits Sri Lanka would gain with its success, while Bimbi journeyed through what Italy has to offer the contemporary traveller.  Through examples, Mancini showcased the quantifiable increase in visitor numbers if a destination is marketed with the correct branding and marketing. Adding to the discussions were Communication Manager of the University of Gastronomic Sciences of Pollenzo Paolo Ferrarini and External Relations Manager of the ALMA School of Italian Cuisine Candida D’Elia, both of who were enthusiastic on leveraging collaborations in the culinary arts with stakeholders in Sri Lanka. In his closing remarks, Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha stressed the importance of establishing long-standing partnerships in education and training to enrich Sri Lanka’s hospitality sector. “Sri Lanka’s vibrant tourism sector is helmed by innovative private enterprise and supported by professional vocational development institutions. They are eager to learn, grow, and adapt to the changing needs of tourists, in order to provide visitors with the best Sri Lanka has to offer,” he said. Engaging in the discussions and sharing ideas from Sri Lanka were the Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority Priyantha Fernando, Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau Chalaka Gajabahu and Sri Lanka Institute of Tourism and Hotel Management Shirantha Peiris.  Representatives from The Hotels Association of Sri Lanka, Chefs Guild of Sri Lanka, Colombo City Restaurant Collective, Vocational Training Authority, outbound and inbound tour operators, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and leading voices in the tourism and hospitality sectors added to the lively dialogue.  Italy and Sri Lanka share a rich and storied relationship that dates back centuries and Italy has been a close friend to Sri Lanka throughout challenging times, reaching out during the catastrophic tsunami, the Easter attacks, pandemic and economic crisis. In his opening remarks, State Minister for Foreign Affairs Tharaka Balasuriya reiterated these strong ties and the rich shared passion in culture, tradition and the culinary arts. “Italy has always been a close friend of Sri Lanka, and we look forward to enriching these ties in tourism and hospitality. So much of Sri Lanka remains to be discovered and we look forward to close collaboration with our Italian colleagues in the years to come.” Sri Lanka has been a fast-growing destination of choice for Italian holidaymakers averaging more than 35,000 arrivals prior to the pandemic. Italy is also home to a thriving Diaspora of approximately 300,000 Sri Lankans. This initiative by the Italian Embassy is the first in a series of stakeholder dialogues between Italy and Sri Lanka, aiming to explore, build, and hone collaborative opportunities that will strengthen ties between the two countries.

title: HC DISMISSES INITIAL OBJECTIONS RAISED BY JOHNSTON, TWO OTHERS
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Manjula Thillakaratne yesterday (27) dismissed the initial objections raised by the defence, pertaining to the lawsuit filed against three accused, including former Minister Johnston Fernando. Fernando, former Chairman of Lanka Sathosa Eraj Fernando and former Working Director Mohammad Shakeer, have been charged by Commission to Investigate Allegations on Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) of causing a loss of revenue, to the tune of Rs 40 million, to the State, by employing a group of Lanka Sathosa workers, to engage in political work apart from their official duties from 1 January to 31 December nine years ago. That was while Fernando had been serving as the then Minister of Internal Trade and Cooperatives. When the case was convened, the Judge fixed the Pre-Trial Conference, related to the case, to be heard on 10 May. The Attorney General has indicted the aforementioned trio before the High Court. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Four BIA cops arrested after suspect flees custody
author: Author not found
Content: Four Katunayake Airport Police officers, including the OIC, were arrested in an incident in which a suspect, who had been arrested at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), has fled Police custody. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said the suspect, a Navy deserter, wanted for several murders and subject to a travel ban, arrived at the BIA on 24 February with the intention of flying to Dubai. Another individual had also arrived at the airport to accompany him on his departure. However, the two individuals had gone to the departure terminal, where they were informed that the suspect had been placed under a travel ban. Therefore, the incident was reported to the Airport Police, and he was arrested. Later, two men in saffron robe arrived at the Police station to discuss the main suspect’s release. Meanwhile, when he was taken out of the cell, the main suspect escaped from Police custody. According to Police investigations, the two people who came down to the station were disguised as monks. The main suspect was identified as a 28-year-old Kalutara South resident. He had committed 19 murders, nine by himself and ten with the assistance of others. Accordingly, the OIC, a sergeant and two Policemen were arrested, and the sergeant was remanded after they were produced before the Negombo Magistrate. The OIC and two Policemen were released on bail. A special investigation is being conducted by a group of Senior Police personnel, including DIG Western Province Rohan Premaratne, Negombo SSP Saman Sigera, SSP Negombo District III Katunayake Eric Perera. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Karannagoda Report recommends regulating social media
author: Author not found
Content: The Karannagoda Committee report filed before the Court of Appeal on Friday (24) recommended that social media platforms where a few could use to mobilise a large number of protesters and pose a threat to national security, should be regularised as per the national security requirements of the country.  It also recommended establishing a National Security Secretariat (NSS)  to support the National Security Council. The Report of the Board of Inquiry(BOI) prepared by a three-member committee headed by Admiral of the Fleet Wasantha Karannagoda to ascertain lapses by the Armed Forces and State Intelligence Services during the recent incident of violence was filed before the Court of Appeal by Attorney, Uditha Igalahewa. The Report of the Board of Inquiry to Ascertain Lapses if any, by the Armed Forces and State Intelligence Service during May 2022 cited these observations. It showed that furthermore, no clear instructions had been issued regarding action to be taken to quell mob violence, which amounts to wilful neglect of duty. The report said, as a result, the troops on the ground could not prevent the damage to public property and harm to persons. It said, the Army Commander had taken the initiative away from the ground Commandeers to take appropriate action to quell mob violence as and when the ground situation demanded. A grey area exists in the conduct of Silva on 31 March 2022 and particularly on 9 May 2022 which is questionable to the board. One of the reasons cited is that Silva tried to justify his actions through the media by giving an interview to a Sinhala newspaper on 29 May 2022 knowing well that there is a BOI already appointed to look into the incidents, thereby undermining the purpose of the BOI. For what purpose over 4,500 troops of Air Mobile Brigade, Special Forces and Commandos were brought by Silva to Colombo and were not deployed on time to save the Prime Minister, his family and others who were trapped inside Temple Trees. Meanwhile, the report also showed that violence took place on 9 May 2022 afternoon along Galle Road and Galle Face could have been mitigated if not prevented, if the Secretary of Defence acted upon the INT report hand delivered to his residence on a Sunday by the SIS at 5 pm on 8 May 2022 followed up with a WhatsApp message on the following morning. However, the IGP had acted on the same INT report, which had been copied to him and delivered at 4.30 pm on which report he has deployed the Police. However, due to miscommunication and poor assessment of the evolving ground situation, the number of policemen deployed was not sufficient to deal with the situation effectively. The three Services (and the Police) had displayed a lack of training Aid to Civil Power. Furthermore, most of the Riot Control units were not properly equipped to deal with violent mobs. The Armed Forces and the Police had shown a reluctance to apply minimum force to quell activity of the rioters due to fear of prosecution. The Board concludes that the lack of legal protection afforded to Operational Troops for lawful actions has resulted in reluctance to act decisively at a time of necessity.

title: Asgiri Mahanayaka warns Buddhism under threat
author: Author not found
Content: The Mahanayaka Thera of the Asgiriya Chapter, Most Ven. Warakagoda Sri Gnanarathana Thera, at the Sri Dalada Maligawa claimed that various organisations and institutions, at local and international level are conspiring to destroy Buddhism, and in order to overcome these challenges, all Buddhists around the world must unite and work towards a common goal, rather than being divided into Theravada, Mahayana, and Tantrayana. He said Sri Lanka, where the Theravada Buddhist philosophy has been protected, will be affected by this impact and that at this time, despite sectarian differences, the Maha Sangha, as a whole, will be able to overcome these challenges by working together. The Mahanayaka Thera was speaking during a visit by Dhanawardena Guruge, who was appointed as the Samagi Jana Balavegaya’s head of Buddhist Affairs. He said the Buddhist philosophy provides the foundation for Buddhists to coexist in this country and that conspiracies against the Buddhist philosophy should be defeated by maintaining that unity and harmony. Guruge also received the blessings of the Most Venerable Thibbatuwawe Sri Siddhartha Sumangala Mahanayake Thera of the Malwathu Chapter. He also paid homage to the Sri Dalada Maligawa. Guruge said he will use his position to expand Buddhist religious work he has done in various parts of Sri Lanka, such as Bodh Gaya in India. He pointed out that he held such responsibilities during Ranasinghe Premadasa’s presidency and that he was a vital cog to the development of religious harmony among all sections of the population. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: PM’s Media refutes resignation rumours
author: Author not found
Content: There is no truth whatsoever in the media reports that Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena would resign, Prime Minister’s media division announced in a statement yesterday (26). “Furthermore there has not been any request or pressure from any quarters for the Prime Minister to resign. These false reports are a part of a conspiracy to disrupt the plans being implemented by the Government,” the statement added.

title: Courts ban JJB protests
author: Author not found
Content: The Fort Magistrate yesterday (26) issued an order preventing Jathika Jana Balawegaya Leader, MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake and 25 others from engaging in protest or demonstration in several areas in Colombo Fort, Police said. The Fort Police told the Fort Magistrate that a group of protesters were planning to hold a protest demonstration in the Kollupitiya, Slave Island and Fort Police areas and had planned to enter the President’s Office and several other buildings. Therefore, the OIC of the Fort Police had requested the Magistrate to issue an order preventing the protest march. The Magistrate ordered the protesters not to enter the President’s Secretariat, President’s House, Finance Ministry and Galle Face Green. Additionally, they were ordered not to block the roads and cause inconvenience to the public and motorists and they were prevented from damaging public property and barred from engaging in acts which could lead to any violence, police said. Meanwhile, the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court also issued an order preventing MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake and 25 others from engaging in protests in Hospital Square in Colombo. The order was issued based on a request made by the Maradana Police OIC, following information received about a protest which was scheduled yesterday in Colombo, including the National Hospital, Eye Hospital, the Cardiology Unit of National Hospital and the Hospital Square in Maradana, Colombo. Accordingly, the request was made upon consideration of the inconvenience possibly caused to the patients and residents. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Large crowd joins JJB-led protest demanding LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: A large crowd, led by Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), took to the streets yesterday (26), to protest the postponement of the Local Government Election, despite Court orders issued by the Fort and the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Courts, barring 26 people, including MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake, from entering several Colombo locations. However, the protest began at around 2:30 p.m. from Viharamaha Devi Park and several roads adjacent to Town Hall were closed due to the march. Meanwhile, during the protest, Police used tear gas and water cannon to disperse protesters at Ibbanwala Junction near Town Hall after they continued walking despite Police warnings. JJB members Sunil Handunnetti, Tilvin Silva, Dr. Nalinda Jayatisse, K.D. Lalkantha, Wasantha Samarasinghe, Eranga Gunasekara and JJB Leader Anura Dissanayake were seen speaking at the rally. They warned President Ranil Wickremesinghe that they cannot be stopped by tear gas and water cannon and demanded the Local Government Election be held. Nearly 20 persons who were injured during the NPP protest were taken to the General Hospital in Colombo. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Kanchana discusses continuous power supply
author: Author not found
Content: Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera recently held a meeting with engineers and officials of the Ceylon Electricity Board’s System Control Unit to discuss the needs and challenges for continuous power supply. Alternative strategies to mitigate the effects of insufficient rainfall and to obtain the necessary fuel and coal were discussed. State Ministers Indika Anuruddha and D.V. Chanaka, as well as the Ministry Secretary and top officials of the Electricity Board participated in the discussion.

title: New jetty opened at Vedithalativu
author: Author not found
Content: Commander North Central Naval Area, Rear Admiral Prasad Kariyapperuma opened a newly constructed jetty at the Vedithalativu Naval Detachment in Mannar yesterday (26). The new facility was built with a view to further improving operational efficiency ofthe Navy. The facility has been a long-felt need of the Navy as there was no secure berthing facility for small craft patrolling in the sea area of Vedithalativu. The construction of this jetty commenced in November 2022 and the remaining work was expeditiously carried out on the directive of Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera and under the supervision of Commander North Central Naval Area, Rear Admiral Kariyapperuma. The new facility was made possible with the manpower and industrial expertise of the Navy and it will be a great convenience to small craft patrolling in the sea area of Vedithalativu. On the other hand, it would further expand operational efficiency of the Navy as it would pave the way to deploy naval personnel and assets at short notice. Senior officers of the North Central Naval Command and a group of naval personnel of SLNS Buwaneka were also present on this occasion.

title: Rs 50 Tax on eggs imported by outsiders other than STC
author: Author not found
Content: If an outsider other than the State Trading Corporation (STC) imports eggs, the Government will levy a tax of Rs 50 per egg, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya warned. He claimed the Government is doing this to protect local egg producers. He also highlighted that, with the Secretary to the Ministry of Trade’s approval, the State Trading Corporation has been granted permission to import eggs after following quarantine protocols. Siyambalapitiya told the media that the tax on those eggs is Rs 1 per egg and that they cost around Rs 30 in Sri Lanka. He said these eggs are not provided to retail sellers, but rather to chocolate, scone, and bakery owners. Sri Lanka State Trading Corporation has obtained the first consignment containing 2 million eggs. According to the Finance Ministry, the levy on eggs has been reduced from Rs 50 to one rupee for a three-month period. The revised levy went into effect on 21 February. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Let MPs have first taste of Indian eggs – Canteen Owner
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to dispel public fear regarding imported eggs, the All Island Canteen Owners’ Association Chairman Asela Sampath challenged the proponents of egg importation from India to make an omelette in front of the media using an egg imported from India. He said the front runners should also demonstrate to the media how to disposeof the eggshell. Addressing the media, Sampath proposed presenting the first batch of imported eggs from India to Parliament, to be used to prepare food in Parliament, such as puddings and watalappam. He added that MPs could demonstrate that these imported eggs do not endanger the lives of Sri Lankans by applying them to their faces in front of the media, as they do in facials. “Show us and then we will purchase imported eggs without any fear. Then we will be able to use the imported eggs to prepare our food and provide food items using these eggs at Rs 25, making food such as egg kottu, egg fried rice, and egg roti,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Lightning strike kills one, injures another
author: Author not found
Content: A person succumbed to injuries when a bolt of lightning struck him while he was bathing inside a cast iron barrel and another was injured in the incident in Delwala on Saturday (25). Police said a man and woman were admitted to the Kalawana Hospital after they were struck by lightning. However, the man succumbed to injuries and the woman was transferred to the Ratnapura Hospital for further treatment. The deceased was identified as a 42-year-old and the injured is 36-years. They are residents of Pebotuwa. Preliminary investigations revealed that the man was bathing inside a cast iron barrel during bad weather. Delwala Police are conducting further investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SL Military Unit to help in health disasters world wide – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe announced the establishment of a separate unit to send military personnel overseas to assist in times of health disasters ushering in a new chapter in military medicine. The President said that it is set up in addition to the unit set up to send personnel during natural disasters. He also said plans were afoot to send a group of military personnel to Turkiye to assist in the catastrophe that struck the country. He was speaking at the inauguration ceremony of the 6th annual academic sessions of the Sri Lanka College of Military Medicine (SLCOMM) on the theme ‘Resilience of Military Medicine in Times of Crisis,’ which was held at the Eagles Lagoon in Katunayake. He also said the Government had dispatched military personnel to Nepal and they were dispatched during natural disasters. “But I am looking at the possibility of using our military medical personnel to send abroad when people are faced with health disasters. These occur more frequently than natural disasters, and I will discuss this with the military to set up a unit in this regard. “That’s a new chapter in military medicine,” he said. Wickremesinghe also said, under the Indian credit line,  the Government is to get more medicine to address the shortage of medicine during this crisis situation. He added the Government was working on making more foreign exchange available to the medical sector. He further said discussions were in progress with the Ministry of Health to upgrade the Medical Research Institute (MRI) as one of the best medical research laboratories in the region. He said it is discussed to introduce a health insurance scheme where the Government can assist those in the low income category, when they need to get the services of the growing private hospitals in the country.. The President said, the Government was seeking the possibility of introducing paying wards in Government hospitals and to introduce non-paying wards in private hospitals where the Government will take the tab for treatment in non-paying wards in private hospitals. The Army, Navy and Air Force medical Corps comprise experienced officers in military medicine and could rise to the occasion like during the separatist war in the North and East. While facing the war they also rendered a service during the tsunami catastrophe in 2004, during floods and during Covid-19. Hence, they are experienced in both the military and civilian fields. He said, he appreciates the commendable service that has been rendered in Military Medicine in the country. He added that the SLCOMM which commenced in 2016 has blossomed into a fully-fledged medical organisation. The President commended the contribution of past presidents and the present president of SLCOMM made towards military medicine in the country.

title: Two sisters killed in fire
author: Author not found
Content: Two women, in their 70s, were found dead after a fire had broken out at the rear end of their home in St. Mary’s Mawatha, Kayts on Saturday (25). The Police Media Division said the victims were identified as sisters aged 72 and 74 years. A son and husband of one of the dead had passed away and she had then come to live with her sister. However, the cause of the fire has not yet been ascertained. The bodies of both victims are lying at the Jaffna Hospital while the Kayts Police are conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Leopard strays into home, seized by wildlife officials
author: Author not found
Content: A leopard was found in the Herole Estate in Hatton yesterday (26) morning, according to Hatton Police. It is reported that the animal may have found its way into the house when it chased a dog for prey. When the house owner went into the washroom for his morning ablutions, he found to his consternation a medium-sized leopard sleeping inside. He had then locked the door and informed Police. The leopard was rescued by Department of Wildlife Conservation officials in Nallathanny following information from the Hatton Police. Police also said residents frequently bring to their attention animals such as stray dogs and pet dogs being hunted by leopards. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Bus transporting pilgrims goes down precipice, injuring 32
author: Author not found
Content: A bus transporting pilgrims to the Nelligala International Buddhist Centre in Kandy overturned, injuring 32 passengers. According to Peradeniya Police, the accident occurred on 25 February, where 26 persons who sustained injuries were admitted to the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital and six to the Kandy National Hospital. Investigations revealed that a group of members of the Senior Citizens’ Welfare Society of Moratuwa were in the bus at the time of the accident and that 48 persons including the driver and conductor had been in the bus. The accident had taken place 300 metres away from the destination while the bus attempted to give room to another bus which resulted in the bus going down a 70 -foot precipice. However, soldiers deployed for the security of the temple had pulled the injured out of the bus and taken them to hospital with the help of villagers. Peradeniya Traffic Division Police is conducting investigations. BY Kamal Suraweera – Kandy

title: Cyber Security Bill to be tabled this year
author: Author not found
Content: The Cyber Security Bill will be tabled in Parliament this year, as proposed in the Information and Cyber Security Strategy of Sri Lanka (2019: 2023), State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath said. He also said this Act will result in the establishment of the Cyber Security Regulatory Authority, the protection of critical national information infrastructure, and the reduction of the risk of maliciously misusing digital systems from various cyber threats. Herath expressed these views while attending a workshop in Colombo on Sri Lanka’s next cyber security strategy, which was co-organised by the Sri Lanka Computer Emergency Response Team (Sri Lanka CERT) and the World Bank. A hundred invitees from the IT sector, including officials from ministries, departments, and other Government organisations, were recently invited to the workshop. Herath said as the country’s IT sector has grown, the Government has paid special attention to cyber security issues. He praised the World Bank for providing technical and expert advisory support for Sri Lanka’s next cyber security strategy and stated that this effort is critical at a time when the country is undergoing digital transformation. “The Government has already taken steps to protect citizens’ privacy from the negative effects of digitisation. As a result, the Data Protection Act, which governs the processing of personal data, was passed by Parliament last year. The Data Protection Authority is scheduled to be established by March 2023. The Government has identified cyber security as an essential element in digitisation and it is necessary for the national security, national economy, and the security of various sectors of the country,” he said. He highlighted that beginning March 2024, all payments and charges of Government organisations will be implemented only through digital electronic payment facilities, and that the necessary steps have already been taken to drive the country towards a digital transformation.

title: Avocado propagation in 200 acres in Badulla District
author: Author not found
Content: The Agricultural Sector Modernization Project, a foreign-funded Ministry of Agriculture project, is working to expand the Hass avocado as an agricultural crop in Sri Lanka, a spokesman said and added in the first phase, 200 acres in the Badulla District were chosen for avocado propagation. According to the Ministry of Agriculture, in this country, the only avocado species that can be easily exported to the foreign market is the HASS avacado, and seedlings of this avocado species have recently been imported from Australia and planted in the Bandarawela area. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera visited the avocado nursery, where 3,000 seedlings are being prepared for transplant. The HASS avocado’s specialty is that it is in high demand in the international market for its health-promoting avocado oil, which is produced using both the fruit and its buttery pulp. The Agriculture Sector Modernization Project has identified approximately 1,000 families in the Badulla District who are capable of cultivating the HASS avocado and has provided them with all of the necessary technology, plants, and financial assistance. Organisations that deal with crop purchase through the ‘Buy Back’ method are also introduced. In three years, this cultivation can generate income, and one tree can produce 200 kg of avocados. The Badulla District was selected because the environment is conducive to HASS avocado cultivation. Amaraweera went on an observation tour said the modernisation project will provide technology, knowledge, and infrastructure to grow a variety of new crops for export.
