title: NEARLY 1000 ARRESTED IN DRUG BUST RAIDS
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 1,000 suspects were arrested in 2022, over illegal drug related offences, following joint illegal drug bust raids conducted by the Sri Lanka Police and the STF, based on intelligence information provided by Sri Lanka Army, the Army said in a statement. Accordingly, The Army Commander has instructed the Commandants of the Civil Defence Force and all senior Army officials to expedite the on-going drug busts. During these raids a total of 717 kg of Kerala Ganja, 685 kg of Ganja, 14 kg of Ice and 2 kg of narcotics were seized. Also, 831 suspects who were arrested with narcotics have been handed over to the Police for further legal action. Furthermore, 20 illegally locally manufactured bottles of liquor and 57 bottles of foreign liquor were seized and 89 suspects arrested. The Army also seized 59 cartons and four boxes of illegal tobacco, 75,181 pills and 10 drug cards while 61 suspects were arrested by the Police and the STF. So far in 2023 the Police and the STF have conducted joint illegal drug busts and have nabbed 138 suspects based on Army intelligence information. As a result of these raids in 2023,  43 suspects were nabbed and 52 kg of Kerala Ganja was seized from their possession, 21 suspects were arrested and 24 kg of Ganja was seized, while 73 other suspects were rounded up in possession of Ice and other narcotics.

title: Mudalige, 48 monks among 57 arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Convener of Inter-University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Wasantha Mudalige and 56 others were arrested after they forcibly entered the ‘Isurupaya’ Education Ministry premises, in Battaramulla, Police said. According to Police, a total of 57 persons, including Mudalige and 48 student monks, were arrested. The IUSF and Buddhist and Pali University student Monks held a protest demanding the re-commencement of academic activities at the university and to take action against the Sri Lanka Police for using excessive force against them, during the Satyagraha on 22 February, at Pitipana Junction in Homagama. Later, they forcibly entered into the Ministry of Education premises and protested near the office room of Education Minister Susil Premajayantha, on the 3rd floor. Meanwhile, the Education Ministry, in a statement released yesterday evening, said it was decided to re-open the university next Monday (27), in several stages following a discussion with university administration. “It was in that backdrop, the student Monks forcibly entered Isurupaya. As a result, we had to take legal action,” the ministry said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Allowances for A/L paper marking to be increased
author: Author not found
Content: A special discussion will be held with the Finance Ministry today (24), to address the matter concerning the allowances of teachers involved in GCE Advanced Level examination paper marking, which has been postponed indefinitely due to the refusal by teachers to participate in the task, as a result of low allowances, Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha said yesterday (23). The Department of Examinational announced on Wednesday (22), that A/L paper marking was postponed indefinitely. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (23), Premajayantha accepted that the number of teachers who applied for paper marking is significantly less than past years. He said, although 19,000 teachers are needed for the process, only 15,000 have applied so far. He also said, a Cabinet Paper was submitted a month ago to increase the payment provided and despite the difficulties, the Cabinet approved it and accordingly, teachers’ stipend has been increased to some extent. Minister Premajayantha added that 1,300 university professors are needed to complete the evaluation procedure and stressed that they also raised certain concerns over participating in the task too. Meanwhile, Premajayantha who participated in an event to distribute uniform material to the students in Sapugaskanda said the circular with regard to increasing allowances for paper marking will be released next Monday (27). “Therefore, I hope that trade unions will encourage the teachers to apply for paper marking, considering the future of the students,” the Minister said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: ‘EC hasn’t legally set a date for LG election’
author: Author not found
Content: In order to hold one, there was no election to begin with, as the Election Commission (EC) has not legally declared a date for holding the Local Government Election, President Ranil Wickremesinghe claimed in Parliament yesterday (23). The President who attended the Parliament sittings yesterday made a statement focused on the upcoming LG Election. “The EC has not legally fixed a date for the election. There are no funds to allocate for an election either. Even if there are funds, there was no election to begin with,” he said. The President also said the Parliament Select Committee (PSC) proposed by a group of SLPP MPs, should be appointed soon to probe into the conduct of the EC and all the matters related to holding the LG Election. The President said, according to his understanding, there is no official date for holding the election, despite ‘rumours’ that it would be on 9 March. He alleged that the EC had set the date for the election at a meeting of its members, where there was no proper quorum. Meanwhile, the EC said 9 March was legally fixed to hold the election according to the Constitution of Sri Lanka and the election law. The announcement to hold the election on 9 March was made with the approval of all the members of the EC, the Commissioner said. Ceylon Today learns that the EC will meet today (24), to reach a final decision on the LG Poll. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: AG informs Court two charge sheets filed against Nishantha
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (23) informed the Court of Appeal that two Contempt of Court charge sheets have been filed against State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha. This was when the Contempt of Court case, filed by lawyers Vijith Kumar and Priyalal Sirisena and the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JSASL), was taken up. It was stated, in the Petitions, that Nishantha, who spoke at a media conference, held at the SLPP Headquarters on 23 August, had expressed critical views on the manner in which Magistrates acted in granting bail to the suspects involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ protest movement and that the MP has damaged the honour and the image of the Judiciary. The petitioners further charged that Nishantha has committed contempt of Court through the aforementioned act, adding that it is a punishable offence in accordance with Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. Accordingly, the petitioners requested the Court to issue an order, to summon before the Court, the original video clips of the relevant press conference which was aired by several private television channels. Furthermore, the petitioners also requested the Court to issue an interim order for Nishantha to refrain from making any statements that may be in contempt, in the future. Moreover, the petitions sought an order to be issued to the Attorney General to file a charge sheet against the respondent, charging him with contempt of Court and a summons to be issued to the concerned MP, to appear before the Court and further to question the reasons why he should not be punished. Senior State Counsel Hasini Opatha, on behalf of the Attorney General, yesterday (23), further requested for an order to be issued for Nishantha to produce a voice sample to the Government Analyst. The decision in regard to this request is due to be delivered on 28 March. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Arrested for hurling slipper at foreigner on train
author: Author not found
Content: Bandarawela Police yesterday (23) arrested a suspect who hurled a slipper at a foreign woman travelling in the Udarata Menike train, in the afternoon of 21 February. Video footage of the incident went viral on social media platforms. The video showed the suspect removing one of his slippers and hurling it in the direction of the foreign woman who was travelling on the train. After examining the video footage, Senior Inspector of Police of Bandarawela Pradeep Kalupahana notified Ella, Bandarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Police stations to arrest the suspect. Police added that the incident had taken place between Bandarawela and Kinigama Railway Stations and the suspect is also believed to be a resident of Bandarawela. The suspect arrested was due to be produced before the Bandarawela Chief Magistrate’s Court. BY Nishantha Abeyguawardena – Badulla

title: PAFFREL to sue those who hampered Polls
author: Author not found
Content: The authorities have spent more than Rs 500 million of public funds on the Local Government Election so far, People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) Executive Director Rohana Hettiarachchi said. He said if the election could not be held because the country is in crisis, the political leaders and State officials who aided and abetted the failure of holding the election should be held accountable. Addressing the media, he claimed it is a crime that the officials are not performing their duties towards the public. Meanwhile, the PAFFREL has requested the Election Commission (EC) for information on the officials from the Ministries of Finance and Administration, Police, Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, and Government Printer, who did not assist the commission to conduct the election properly. In a special statement, the PAFFREL said that if the EC has not acted appropriately in taking action against such officials, they will take necessary legal actions against those officials in question. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Power tariff hike not to pay bonuses – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: While pointing out that electricity tariffs were not increased to provide bonuses to Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) engineers, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said that steps have been taken to cut overtime allowances of the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) employees as well. Wijesekera, speaking in Parliament yesterday (23), claimed that after the tariff revision, the required loan facilities were given, and State banks provided necessary funds and that some parties would like if the electricity supply cannot be provided for their own personal agendas. Speaking during the debate on the Gazette Notification, under the Essential Public Services Act, Wijesekara stressed that CEB Engineers’ Union requests bonuses and has threatened to take to streets if their demands are not met. He said, the tariffs were not increased to pay bonuses to anyone, but solely to cover the expenses of the CEB and to provide uninterrupted electricity power. Wijesekara went on to say that some parties complain about the tariff hike while people used to spend aroundRs. 2,000 per day to obtain fuel for electricity generators during long power cuts. Wijesekara also tabled the long term power generation plan in Parliament. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: President behaving like a ‘madman’ – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: “President Ranil Wickremesinghe is now behaving like a madman,” Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said. Addressing a public rally, Premadasa alleged the mastermind behind all the attempts to delay the Local Government Election is none other than President Ranil Wickremesinghe. “The President is ranting like a madman, declaring that there will be no election because the Election Commission has not legally declared an election. If there is no election, how did the UNP members submit nominations?” he questioned. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Harsha loses COPF Chair to Mayantha
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Blawegaya (SJB) MP Dr. Harsha de Silva lost the Chairmanship of Committee on Public Finance (COPF). He was replaced by his Party colleague Mayantha Dissanayake. The Parliamentary Committee of Selection appointed SJB MP Mayantha Dissanayake as the new Chairman of COPF yesterday (23). The inaugural COPF meeting of 4th Session of 9th Parliament was held under the new Chairman yesterday afternoon (23). Meanwhile, Dr. de Silva tweeted saying all Government MPs had backed the appointment of Dissanayake, overruling the original appointment, in which he was named. “Actually it was my name that was proposed by the Opposition as the nominee from the Opposition. It was approved two days ago. But today the Government abused their power and used Mayantha to get their way. Good luck to everyone,” he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SC informed that President will not sign death warrants
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (23) informed the Supreme Court that President Ranil Wickremesinghe has decided that he will not sign the implementation of capital punishment ordered by any Court. This was when the Petitions, filed against former President Maithripala Sirisena signing death warrants of four persons convicted of drug-related offences in 2019, was taken up before a five-Judge Bench comprising Justices Vijith Malalgoda, S. Thurairajah, Gamini Amarasekara, Murdu Fernando and Priyantha Fernando. Additional Solicitor General Nerin Pulle, appearing on behalf of the Attorney General, informed Court that the Secretary to the President had submitted Wickremesinghe’s decision to refrain from signing the implementation of capital punishment. The Petitioners noted that if such undertaking made by Wickremesinghe is fulfilled, the Petitions filed in this regard would be withdrawn while retaining the right to continue the case. The petitioners, including the Centre for Policy alternatives, noted that resuming the death penalty goes against the global trend towards its abolishment and also goes against decades of Sri Lanka’s domestic and international policy practice. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: HRCSL summons Health Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) issued notice to the Health Ministry, over allegations of violating the human rights of patients by creating a shortage of medicines, increasing price of drugs and the postponing of surgeries. The notice was issued following a petition filed by the Sri Lanka Medical Association and the Medical and Civil Rights Professionals’ Association of Doctors (MCPA).   The Health Ministry Secretary, the Director General Health Services and the Chairman of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) have been named as respondents. The officials from the Ministry and the NMRA have been asked to appear before the HRCSL on 3 March 2023 with the relevant documentation.  “This is the first time that the HRCSL has recognised the shortage of medicines and the increase in the price of medicines as a violation of people’s human rights,” MCPA President Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Health assistants strike demanding withdrawal of circular
author: Author not found
Content: In a spate of health sector strikes against the Government, health assistants countrywide struck work outside hospitals, for a period of five hours, starting at 7.00 a.m. yesterday (23), demanding the Health Secretary withdraw a Circular that slashed extra duty payments, which affected their pay and to provide hospitals with adequate medicinal drugs.   General Secretary of United Health Service Association (CHSA) Nandana Pushpakumara accused the government of making it “difficult for health workers and the public to even breathe.” He said, the latest action being the 15% slash on the extra duty payments, which would directly affect the wages of health assistants and demanded that State sector hospitals be given the required medicinal drug consumables. Secretary of the United Health Workers Union (UHWU), Ven. Tempitiye Sugathananda Thera said, the demands had also included a call for the reduction of the unjustly increased interest rates on bank loans, an increase in the cost of living allowance, which had not been revised since 2013, to match the current inflation. The Monk also requested to provide a transport allowance, streamline health assistant transfers, in order to overcome the shortage, repeal the unjust tax system, provide a five-day work week and reduce the increased electricity tariffs. The Sri Lanka Janaraja Saukya Sewaka Sangamaya and the Sri Lanka Nidahas Saukya Sewaka Sangamaya also participated in the strike.  Meanwhile, the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) queried as to whose unseen hand was behind the circular issued by the Health Secretary. The GMOA said, that all health service trade unions had been thrown into a quandary over the particular circular and that his outfit was ready to take leadership in taking stringent trade union action against the circular. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: NARCOTICS AT GA DEPT TO BE INCINERATED
author: Author not found
Content: New Regulations will be introduced within the next two months to incinerate over 3,000 kg of drugs held at the Government Analyst’s Department, Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said. He added that due to the shortage of storage facilities, there have been difficulties in storing seized drugs at the Department, until the end of a particular Court case and thereby measures will be taken to incinerate large amounts of seized drugs. Rajapakshe said, necessary steps have already been taken to formulate regulations and after such regulations are passed in Parliament, measures will be taken to incinerate seized drugs of over 1kg. He added that new technology will be introduced for such purpose and established in identified locations. He further noted that in the past, there were several complaints that Court cases were prolonged due to the failure on the part of the Government Analyst’s Department to submit reports on time, noting that while the Department did not have sufficient laboratories in the past, there are a considerable number of laboratories now making services more effective. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Gammanpila threatens to take Govt to Court
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader, MP Udaya Gammanpila threatened to sue the Government if it does not pay the salaries of State employees who had taken leave to contest the Local Government Election. He said, this decision should be taken by Cabinet, and that they will go to Court with the election candidates who applied for leave as State employees. He was speaking at a media briefing held at the PHU Headquarters on Wednesday (22). “State employees who contest the LG Polls have obtained no pay leave under the provisions of law. However, when they obtained the no pay leave, they expected the Government to hold the election within seven weeks from the conclusion of nominations as per the Local Authorities Elections Act. According to the Doctrine of Legitimate Expectation, when the people have taken a decision relying on the government’s decisions, they will be entitled for compensation if the Government changes its decision. Hence, unless the Government decides to pay salaries of the contesting State employees immediately, we will file legal action against the Government,” he said. Speaking about holding a Presidential Election, he said somebody has reportedly misled the President that he can hold the Presidential Election after 18 November 2023.  “He does not want to hold any other election before the Presidential Election because the Government will face a humiliating defeat in any other election and it would have a negative impact on the Presidential Election. That is why the President wants to postpone the LG Election by one year. According to Article 31(3A) (a), the President can declare his intention to seek a second term after completion of four years of his first term. The presidential term completes four years on 18 November 2023. However, sub-section (e) of the same article says that a President who was not elected by the people is not entitled to exercise this right. Therefore, the President cannot hold the Presidential Election this year as expected,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: SC grants leave with FR petitions against Police curfew
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (23) granted leave to proceed with two Fundamental Rights Petitions, filed against the imposition of a Police curfew by the Inspector General of Police (IGP), in several Police Divisions in the Western Province on 9 July 2022. This was when the Petition was taken before Supreme Court Justices Mahinda Samayawardena, Shiran Goonaratne and Preethi Padman Surasena. Leave to proceed was granted under the provisions of the Constitution with regard to right equality, freedom of speech and expression, freedom of peaceful assembly, freedom of association and freedom of movement. Police curfew was imposed in several Police divisions in the Western Province on 9 July 2022 and public were advised to stay at home, as travelling between Police divisions was strictly prohibited. Further, it was stated that strict action would be taken against those who break the curfew, considering that it will be an obstacle to maintain law and order. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Two CAA Inspectors remanded over bribe
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis on Wednesday (22), remanded till 7 March, two Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) Inspectors, who were charged with bribery by Commission to Investigate Allegations on Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC). The two suspects were charged with soliciting a bribe of Rs 10,000, in order to refrain from filing legal action for changing the fixed price of packets of incense sticks being put into the market by a complainant. The two suspects were identified as residents of Polonnaruwa and they were arrested on 9 February on a tip off. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Opposition protest in Chamber again
author: Author not found
Content: The Opposition, for the second time in this week, held a protest in the Parliament Chamber, yesterday morning (23), demanding fot the Government to hold the Local Government Election 2023 as scheduled. President Ranil Wickremesinghe was also in the Chamber when the protest commenced. The Opposition MPs started stepping into the Well after President Wickremesinghe’s statement about the LG Poll. The President said there is no election to be postponed as the Election Commission has failed to legally call for the election. There are no funds to spend for an election as Well, the President said. The Opposition, even during the President’s statement, disrupted him, raising Points of Order, while the Government MPs supported the President by clapping thumping the tables. When the President concluded the statement, the Opposition MPs stepped into the Well with placards and demanded the election. They chanted slogans ‘Prodawa wana – Chande thamai ona’ (No more crooked attempts – We need an election) and ‘Diyaw diyaw chande diyaw.’Give us the election now! None of Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MPs were in the Chamber during the protest. The President left the Chamber, while the protest was taking place. The Opposition on Tuesday (21), held a protest in the Chamber to demand the election. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Five nabbed with cannabis in Yala
author: Author not found
Content: Okkampitiya Police arrested five persons with 122kg of cannabis and a locally manufactured firearm on 22 February. They were arrested in the Yala National Park. On complaints received by Police, saying illegal activities were going on within the Park,  Police conducted a raid and arrested the five suspects with the cannabis.  The Wellawaya Magistrate remanded the five suspects until 1 March. The suspects were identified as aged between 30 and 44 and residents of Kuttigala, Thanamalwila and Hambantota. Meanwhile, Okkampitiya Police also set fire another cannabis stock of 350kg. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: LG Polls corpse lies at ‘Wickremesinghe funeral parlour’ – Dullas
author: Author not found
Content: The corpse of LG polls now lies in the ‘Wickremesinghe funeral parlour’, MP Dullas Alahapperuma said in Parliament yesterday (23). While claiming that media and several other parties pointed fingers at the Treasury Secretary, Government Printer and the Election Commission for attempting to disrupt the Local Government Election, Alahapperuma noted that it is very clear who really wants to postpone the election. Alahapperuma questioned as to why the United National Party (UNP) handed over nominations for the Local Government Elections, if the election was not legally declared as claimed by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. He said, what was said by the President in Parliament yesterday (23), was completely false and added it is now clear who is behind the move to postpone the LG Polls. Alahapperuma said the entire Opposition would stand together to fight against the attempts to postpone the LG Polls. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Lorry topples leaving 23 injured
author: Author not found
Content: Twenty two estate workers and the driver of the lorry, in which they were travelling were injured, when the vehicle toppled. The accident occurred along the Bandarawela – Ettampitiya Road as the driver had lost control of the vehicle due to brake failure. The Police Media Division said, the group of workers and the driver were admitted to the Bandarawela Hospital on 22 February. However, 11 of them were transferred to the Diyatalawa Hospital for further treatment. Bandarawela Police are conducting further investigations into the accident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: NHSL Director ordered to submit medical reports
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya issued another reminder to the Director of the National Hospital of Sri Lanka to submit the bed ticket and all medical reports of Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Dinesh Schaffter related to his admission to the accident ward of the hospital on 15 December 2022. The Magistrate said this is the second reminder that is being issued to the hospital, to comply with the request made at the previous hearing and over its failure to abide by it till now. Meanwhile, the Additional Magistrate said a five-member panel of medical specialists will be named by her on 27 February, to reach a conclusive determination, with regard to the mysterious death of Dinesh Schaffter. She said after naming the five-member panel of medical specialists and based on their conclusions, she will be able to deem with certainty, whether the late businessman died by suicide or whether his death amounts to a murder. When the case was convened yesterday (22), as per an order issued previously by Court, Director General of Health Services Dr. Asela Gunawardena and UGC Chairman Sampath Ameratunga, submitted a list of medical specialists to the Additional Magistrate. The Court announced that the panel of medical specialists will be formed based on their seniority. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Sirisena’s appeal judgment fixed for 1 March
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Civil Appellate High Court, yesterday (22), reserved judgment on the appeal, filed by former President Maithripala Sirisena, against the decision taken by the Colombo District Court to reject the request made by him, to discharge him as a respondent in the cases filed in relation to the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, for 1 March. This was when the case was taken before Colombo Civil Appellate High Court Judges Frank Gunawardena and Chamath Morais. While the judgement was due to be issued yesterday (22), as there was no representation for Sirisena, the judgment was reserved for 1 March. He said, as he is not the President anymore, victims of the Easter Sunday attacks should claim compensation from the Government or by making the Attorney General a party to the action and not from him in his personal capacity. The Colombo District Court on 7 January 2022 rejected the request made by Sirisena to be discharged from the cases filed by the families and victims of the Easter Sunday attacks. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President appoints probe committee on 5G towers
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe appointed a special committee yesterday (22) to probe the reports that 5G telecommunication towers in Anuradhapura pose a threat to the Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi. The President appointed the committee following a request of Atamasthanadhipathi, Ven. Pallegama Hemarathana Nayaka Thera. The committee members are Telecommunications Regulatory Commission (TRC) Chairman Prof. Niranjan Gunawardena, Director General of Department of National Botanic Gardens Dr. S.A. Krishnaraja, Additional Director TRC H. Ranatunga and Anuradhapura Government Agent Janaka Jayasundera.

title: Sri Pada pilgrims bring in 8 tonnes of non-degradable waste
author: Author not found
Content: During the ongoing Sri Pada Season, pilgrims trekking the holy site disposed of a total of eight tonnes of non-degradable waste on the Nallathanni Sri Pada route and the Sri Pada Reserve, Acting Secretary of the Maskeliya Pradeshiya Sabha Sivaram Rajaveeran said. He said during the past few weeks, around 500,000 pilgrims had descended on the Sri Pada sacred site and garbage has begun to pile up in the aforementioned areas. Rajaveeran said the Maskeliya Pradeshiya Sabha is working tirelessly to remove this environmentally-unfriendly material. By Channa Addarage – Hatton

title: Over 6,000 professionals protest in Fort
author: Author not found
Content: Over 6,000 professionals flocked to Fort, the heart of Colombo City, to demonstrate against the newly introduced income tax system, demanding the Government introduce amendments or repeal it before they launch an islandwide strike next week. Professionals from over 40 trade unions demonstrated holding placards and shouting slogans outside the Fort Railway Station yesterday (22), obstructing vehicular traffic. Protesters then took to a stage which had been erected for those gathered and members of the public who were present in Fort, accusing the President and the Government of turning a deaf ear while pretending that no action could be taken to amend the Act. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe said changes beneficial to the 225 Parliamentarians had been introduced subsequently when all along the President and the Government had been stressing that no changes could be made to the Inland Revenue Act. “What did the IMF have to say to that,” he queried? Rushed amendments were introduced to safeguard the vehicles, fuel and chauffeurs of the Parliamentarians, he alleged. “Therefore, if the President and State authorities are unwilling to be flexible and amend the Act ,so that it would be fair, all professional trade unions will take the strike to the next level by next week,” he warned. Trade unionists from the University, Information Technology, Banking, Inland Revenue, Ports and Shipping, Dockyard, Ports Authority, Electricity and Water Boards addressed the rally. Meanwhile, GMOA Media Committee Member, Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam, when contacted, said the meeting they had been expecting to have with the President had not materialised. “Even if the Government had reached agreement with the IMF to impose taxes, the money which gets collected from it does not amount to much,” he said. Dr. Ratnasingam warned that doctors will join all other professionals next week to launch a strike if authorities fail to pay attention to their demands and amend the Act.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: ‘Tough decisions warranted to rebuild country’
author: Author not found
Content: Acknowledging that some of his decisions are hard to process and they make him unpopular, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said yesterday (22) that without those decisions, the country could not be put on the right track. The President said this during an event held in his honour yesterday (22) at Royal College, Colombo. President Wickremesinghe is an alumnus of the school. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, who is also a Royalist and the President’s classmate, attended the event. “This is what I learnt at Royal College, do what is right and do what is good for your country. Remember that. Every decision I have taken, I have thought twice or thrice on what is the burden it will impose on us. How unpopular should I become? Should I even take this decision? And when I felt that it was in the country’s interest, I took it because my first task is to revive the economy. We can’t be a bankrupt country. We can’t be a beggar nation, so we have to learn that there are hard decisions to be taken in life. And I assure you, we will by this year, see a very good improvement in our economic condition and then we will set the stage for the economic recovery of this country, not to go back to an old system which brought us down, but to a new system,” he said. President Wickremesinghe also urged all citizens, including politicians, professionals, teachers, those engaged in agriculture, the business community, and members of the Security Forces, Police and civil servants, to work together to overcome the present economic crisis and promote reconciliation efforts. The President called on the present generation of Royalists to dedicate themselves to serving the country and transforming it into a place where they would like to reside. He urged young Royalists to take up the challenge and shape the future of the nation. President Wickremesinghe also highlighted that Royalists are trained to live in harmony with all races and religions, emphasising that the country cannot be divided on the basis of race or religion. He invited all politicians who are also Royalists to collaborate with the Government in its efforts to revive the country’s collapsed economy, emphasising that it was not a political invitation, but rather a call for a collective effort to address the economic crisis. “Royal College today has in its records, four Prime Ministers and two Presidents. This is an outstanding record for any school. We also have a Sultan of Maldives who was also a Prime Minister, Muhammad Fareed Didi and the man who modernised the Maldives, President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom spent a year or more at Royal College. I think the disease of modernisation; he must have gotten from Royal College. Now, we are here as the Royalists from the same class. So this is what education at Royal has brought us and I hope you will do even better than us. That is my hope. Records are meant to be broken. Are any of you willing to break that record?” When we gained independence, we were second to Japan and the London Times said we will be another Switzerland. That is who we were. Today, we are a country which has only Afghanistan below us. We don’t know what the future is. So, when we build this future, it’s an economy that must last for 25 years. It must be a new Constitution that must last for 100 years. It must be a society not for us. None of us here are going to live for 25 years. It is a country for you all, he said. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Minister Vidura Wickremanayake, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, State Minister of Justice and Prison Affairs Anuradha Jayaratne, Members of Parliament Rauff Hakeem, Gevindu Kumarathunga, Priyankara Jayaratne, Duminda Dissanayake, Mahindananda Aluthgamage, Dilan Perera, Yadamini Gunawardena, Kavinda Jayawardena, and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of  Staff Sagala Ratnayake were also present at the occasion.

title: Voters in Padukka post money orders to EC
author: Author not found
Content: A group of voters in Padukka yesterday (22) posted money orders to the Election Commission (EC), with instructions to use the funds to hold Local Government Elections as scheduled. They posted money orders of Rs 100 and Rs 200 addressed to the EC Chairman. Meanwhile, Pivithuru Hela Urumaya Leader, MP Udaya Gammanpila said if the Government sets aside 1 per cent of its daily expenditure, it can easily collect Rs 15 billion to hold LG Polls. He said the real reason for postponing elections is not lack of funds, but the Government’s shrinking vote base. “According to the most recent poll, the Government’s voter base has shrunk to 10 per cent. Otherwise, finding Rs 9 billion isn’t that hard. Although it is a large figure for us, it is a small figure for the Government. The Government spends Rs 15 billion daily. If there is truly no money, the Government has four options,” he explained. “The most peaceful way for the people to express their displeasure against the Government as a result of these economic difficulties is to hold elections. People will be unable to express their displeasure against the Government if this opportunity is lost. Therefore, holding elections is good for the country,” he said. He said this during a media briefing yesterday (22). By Thameenah Razeek

title: SC rejects Siridhamma Thera’s FR petition
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights Petition filed by Convener of the Inter-University Bhikku Federation (IUBF), Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, challenging his arrest and detaining under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) was rejected by the Supreme Court yesterday (22). This was when the Petition was taken before Supreme Court Justices S. Thurairaja, Priyantha Fernando and Mahinda Samayawardhena. Following submissions made by the parties, Court held that the Petitioner has not established sufficient facts to consider the Petition. President’s Counsel M.A. Sumanthiran appearing on behalf of the Petitioner observed that detaining the petitioner under the PTA has violated his Fundamental Rights and is illegal. Making Submissions on behalf of the Attorney General, Senior State Counsel Shaminda Wickrama said, ‘’Your Honour, investigations have revealed that the actions of the Petitioner including entering State Institutions forcefully and damaging public property are serious offences under the PTA. According to investigations, the acts of the petitioner have angered the Public who have already been battered by the economic crisis. Further, the petitioner was arrested and detained under the PTA as there was sufficient proof to do so and no Fundamental Rights have been violated, I thereby request for the Petition to be dismissed without taking it to consideration. ‘’ Ven. Siridhamma Thera was among several other protesters who were arrested following a protest march, organised by the IUSF against the incumbent Government, at Union Place in Colombo on 18 August. Police initially obtained a 72-hour detention order on three activists including Ven. Siridhamma Thera. He was later held along with the Convener of Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Wasantha Mudalige for over 90 days. Colombo Additional Magistrate T.N.L. Mahawatta on 23 November ordered Ven.Siridhamma Thera to be enlarged on bail. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Why wasn’t I announced as COPF Chair?
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Dr. Harsha de Silva queried as to why his name was not officially announced by Parliament as Chairman of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), even after the name was approved by the Speaker. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (22), Dr. de Silva claimed that although Chief Government Whip Prasanna Ranatunga said the Chairmanship of COPF was given to the Opposition, his name was not announced as the Chairman to date. He requested the Speaker to release an announcement regarding the approval of his name as the COPF Chairman. In response, Chief Government Whip Ranatunga said the Government is of the opinion that it does not need this position and the position should be given to the Opposition. However, the Chairman should be appointed with the agreement of all parties, he said. Dr. Harsha de Silva was re-elected as the COPF Chairman on Tuesday (21). By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: A/L paper marking ‘postponed indefinitely’
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Examinations officially announced that the evaluation of G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination answer scripts will be postponed indefinitely. Ceylon Today learns that this might result in a delay in holding other critical school examinations scheduled for this year as well. The Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) on Tuesday (21) revealed that evaluation of A/L Examination answer scripts will be postponed indefinitely, owing to the lack of interest by teachers to apply for the task citing low allowances. In response to this, Commissioner General of Examinations Amith Jayasundara said though the evaluation of A/L Examination answer scripts will be postponed indefinitely, he will come up with a special plan to address the issue. The plan will include steps such as carrying out evaluation in two stages. Therefore, there won’t be a long delay as alleged by trade unions, he added. “A Cabinet Paper has been submitted to increase the allowances of teachers for evaluating answer scripts. Once I receive an official update about increasing the allowance from the Treasury, I will immediately communicate it to teachers. Thereafter, the application process for invigilators will be reopened,” he said. However, the Commissioner General failed to provide an exact time frame required to increase allowances, but said it shouldn’t take too long. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Clarify Purpose of US Defence Delegation Visit to the House
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of the National Freedom Front (NFF) MP Wimal Weerawansa, while charging that plans being underway to place all intelligence information collected by Sri Lankan intelligence services under an official of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) of the United States, yesterday (22) demanded a clarification to the House from either the President or Prime Minister on the recent controversial visit of a 20-member US Pentagon delegation headed by US Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defence for Indo-Pacific Security Affairs (PDASD) Jedidiah P. Royal. Weerawansa, while alleging that the Pentagon delegation had visited the State Intelligence Service (SIS) office, reiterated that plans are afoot to place all intelligence information under one CIA official who would take the final call on dispatching intelligence information.  “We heard that the armed US delegation paid a visit to the SIS office after disarming all local officials. Plans are underway to bring the SIS information handling and decision-making under CIA officials. This officer is to decide which information to send and which not to. A similar operation was in place in 2001 and it was withdrawn in 2004,” he said. He also noted that as per the information he possesses at the moment, this Pentagon delegation used the VVIP lounge at the BIA to enter and leave the country, disregarding immigration authorities, under the guise of a ‘top secret mission’. He also inquired from Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Sabry, who was on his feet to present regulations under Colombo Port City Economic Commission Act, whether he had been aware of the lightning visit of the US delegation. “I was absolutely unaware of the visit. It was handled by the Defence Ministry,” Sabry responded. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: BANGLADESH HC MARKS INT’L MOTHER LANGUAGE DAY
author: Author not found
Content: The Bangladesh High Commission in Colombo marked the International Mother Language Day 2023 at Independence Square on Tuesday (21). Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena participated in the event. Other dignitaries present were State Minister of Higher Education Dr. Suren Raghavan, State Minister of Foreign Affairs Tharaka Balasuriya and Heads of Diplomatic Missions and UN and international organisations. People from all walks of life including academia, intellectuals, political and cultural personalities, top government officials as well as hundreds of students and scouts from schools islandwide also joined the observance. On this occasion, the Independence Square turned into a grand assembly of different language speakers. The Prime Minister and other dignitaries scribbled in respective mother tongues their feelings about the Day on canvas with brush and paint. The programme began with the choral rendition of the immortal Ekushey song by the children of the High Commission officials and their family members. The entire hall stood in solemn silence for one minute as a mark of respect to the Language Martyrs. To mark the day, under the patronage of the High Commission and with the assistance of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Education, an islandwide creative writing and painting competition for children was launched two months back on the theme ‘Mother Language: Unity in Diversity.’ In yesterday’s event, the winners of the competition were awarded. The day’s attraction was an absorbing multilingual cultural performance by students and performers of the Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre, Russian House in Colombo, Maldivian Educational and Cultural Centre, Iranian Cultural Centre, SAARC Cultural Centre, Bangladesh High Commission and singers from Sri Lanka. In song, recitation and dance forms in as many as eight languages, they showcased their respective cultural traditions and love for their mother tongue and mother land. The finale was a K-pop performance. All the items drew huge appreciation from the crowd. In his welcome remarks, High Commissioner of Bangladesh Tareq Md Ariful Islam reflected on the significance of the day, shared its historical perspective and emphasised the role of mother tongues in promoting an inclusive society and a peaceful world. State Minister of Higher Education Dr. Raghavan spoke in three languages–English, Sinhala and Tamil, about the importance of preservation of mother languages and linguistic diversity. UN Resident Coordinator Sarat Das spoke about the significance of multilingualism.  The event was organised in partnership with the Ministry of Education of Sri Lanka, United Nations in Sri Lanka and Sri Lanka Scout Association. A blood donation camp was also arranged by the High Commission in collaboration with the Sri Lanka Scout Association at the General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University Hospital. The day’s in-house observance began at the Chancery early morning with ceremonial hoisting of the National Flag at half-mast followed by a one-minute silence, special prayers and reading out messages of high dignitaries of Bangladesh.

title: Premajayantha attends World Copernican Congress in Poland
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha attended the World Copernican Congress held in Torun, Poland from 19-21 February, at the invitation of the Minister of Education and Science of Poland, Przemysław Czarnek. Minister Premajayantha met Minister of Education and Science of Poland Czarnek and discussed ways and means to advance bilateral cooperation in the education sector. The Minister also had the opportunity to meet Ministers, scientists and scholars from around the world to discuss key developments in science education and best practices to promote freedom of scientific research for societal benefit and progress. The participating Ministers adopted the Torun Declaration to ensure freedom to conduct scientific research as well as to promote freedom of scientific criticism and debate. The World Copernican Congress is an international event to mark 550 years since the birth of the famous Renaissance astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus. The Congress seeks “to present the state of research on the life and activities of the great scientist and astronomer, as well as his impact on the development of science, culture and the arts.” Participation of foreign country delegates was funded by the organisers. Chairman of the Arthur C. Clarke Institute for Modern Technologies (ACCIMT) Prof. Chandana Jayaratne also participated in the Congress.

title: Faulty machinery leads to worker’s death
author: Author not found
Content: A machine operator was killed when a faulty machine restarted during repairs at a private factory in Kotadeniyawa.   The Police Media Division said the machine operator had been inspecting a machine that had stopped working due to a technical fault during which the machine restarted, critically injuring the operator, who passed away shortly thereafter. The victim is a 37-year-old resident of Madiyathalawa. Kotadeniyawa Police are conducting investigations based on statements obtained on 21 February. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Cuty Rose exhibition of craft, patchwork, needlework
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Cuty Rose’ was established in 2011 and has enrolled 275 students. Classes are conducted in dress making, Brazilian Embroidery, batik and tie and dye, to name a few popular courses. Classes are conducted at Wellampitiya, Dehiwala and Denara Training Centre in Thimbirigasyaya, Colombo 5.  This is the third exhibition organized by Cuty Rose. Patchwork and Needlework exhibits made by students will be held on 25, 26 February 2023 at the Arina Hall, Kotikawatha. Farzana Mohideen, Director of Cuty Rose, announced a needlecraft exhibition and competition among 50 best students in the group. The girls are preparing to submit the exhibits for the competition which will be followed by a prize-giving on 26 February 2023.

title: Legal Action Cannot Resolve Economic Problems – President
author: Author not found
Content: In a backdrop where the Supreme Court is set to give a verdict tomorrow (21) on holding the Local Government Election on 9 March, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said although the Court is expected to give a decision on the election date, the country’s economic problem is not something that can be resolved through legal action, even if all judges, including the Chief Justice, are involved. It is Parliament that is responsible for addressing and improving the state of the economy and the upcoming LG Poll in not the means to change the current Government, the President added. During a meeting with businessmen and lawyers in the Kandy District, the President warned that if the International Monetary Fund (IMF) does not provide financial assistance to the country, the people will have to endure a lot of difficulties like 12-hour power cuts, due to the non-availability of fuel and a shortage of fertiliser for the Yala season. The President revealed the progress of discussions with the IMF so far during the speech. Although Sri Lanka expected to deliver 15 tasks set up by the IMF by 15 February, for obtaining financial assistance, the country could not make it because ‘one person’ obstructed revising the electricity tariffs, which was one of the IMF tasks. As a result, getting IMF assistance was delayed by another six weeks, the President stressed. When a country goes bankrupt, it has to go to the International Monetary Fund. Apart from that, there is no other organisation in the world that provides aid when a country goes bankrupt. Each nation that experienced an economic catastrophe recovered after engaging in negotiations with the IMF. It took Greece 13 years to recover from the collapsed economy. I have no hope of being President for 13 years, he said. “The IMF indicates that our tax revenue should be 15 per cent of the Gross Domestic Product as it was in 2019. So far it has gone down to 9 per cent. They have asked us how we expect to get assistance from money collected from the people of other countries as taxes, while we are giving tax relief to our people. “The government started negotiations with the IMF last August. Accordingly, it was possible to agree on the staff level agreement in September. They assigned us 15 tasks to complete. The IMF gave us until 31 December 2022 to implement these tasks. But we couldn’t fulfil it. Then we made plans to get time until 31 January 2023. Even at that time, we failed complete those 15 tasks. Finally, the deadline was pushed back to 15 February. By 6.00 p.m. on 15 February, we completed all and sent the progress report to Washington. Only one of these fifteen issues was being delayed. It was related to the increase in electricity tariffs. The Electricity Board incurs Rs 230 billion each year in losses. According to the IMF, government taxes should not be used to support institutions. It was informed that if this occurs, the IMF will not provide assistance. However, one person in this country opposed the decision to increase the electricity tariff.“There is only one way to rebuild this collapsed economy. That is the International Monetary Fund,” the President said and added, however, different political parties are presenting different stories and he suggested that they inform him if there is another way to resurrect the collapsed economy. “Therefore, we are prepared to allow those who oppose our policies to meet the International Monetary Fund and submit proposals. It remains to be seen whether the International Monetary Fund will accept those proposals,” he added. “The IMF also suggested that all the countries should get on one platform and discuss the matter. However, as China is a world power, their procedure is different. Tomorrow (23) the Finance Ministers of the G20 countries are scheduled to hold a discussion in Bangalore, India. During the meeting it is expected to look into how to restructure the debt of countries whose economies have collapsed. There, I hope to discuss the debt restructuring method of Sri Lanka with the Chinese Finance Minister. As per their stand, we have two or three options to implement. “I took over this country when nobody else was willing to step up.  Despite the inevitable criticisms, I am committed to taking all necessary action to rebuild our economy. Our goal is to provide some relief to the people by the end of this year and begin our economic development plan at the start of next year. With a focused and sustained effort, we can build a strong and prosperous economy that benefits all citizens of our country,” he elaborated.

title: Harsha raises concerns over removal of Kimbulawala street food stalls
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Dr. Harsha de Silva raised concerns in Parliament over several reports of a decision taken by the Urban Development Authority to remove the street food stalls located in Kimbulawala. While claiming that street food stalls could be seen everywhere in the world, MP de Silva inquired why the food stalls are going to be removed. He advised that arbitrary decisions not be taken and requested to discuss the matters with the street food vendors and provide fair solutions. Responding to MP de Silva, Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena said attention was paid to the matter due to the risks posed to pedestrians and vehicles using the road. “We have considered the dangers posed to pedestrians and vehicles on the road. We have also identified 3,000 spots that are easily accessible to the public and are safer. Therefore, measures are being taken to remove any stall across Sri Lanka that is considered to pose a risk of accident to pedestrians as well as vehicles,” he said. Minister of Urban Development Prasanna Ranatunga said that initially business operations were conducted from Friday to Sunday, only. However, now the street food stalls are operational everyday and the stores on the other side of the road have filed complaints stating that they are unable to run their businesses as a result, he stressed. “Therefore, the UDA is looking at introducing a system for the street food stalls to follow when conducting business,” the Minister stated. By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: FR Petition in SC against failure to release funds for LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: A Fundamental Rights Petition was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday (21), by Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Ranjith Maddumabandara, against the failure to provide funds to hold the Local Government Election in March 2023. It was noted in the Petition that the failure to provide funds for the Local Government Election, notwithstanding the fact that an estimated sum of Rs 10 billion has been allocated to the Election Commission for conducting elections, other than parliamentary elections, under the Activity Budget Estimates for the fiscal year of 2023 and/or Budget for the year 2023 is a violation of the Fundamental Rights. It was also stated that the Minister of Finance has no mandate by the people of Sri Lanka to act in such a dictatorial manner disregarding democratic values that are enshrined in the Constitution. He thereby sought an interim order, restraining the respondents and relevant authorities from withholding any funds allocated by the Activity Budget Estimates for the purpose of conducting the Local Government Polls 2023. He also sought an order to be issued to tender the circular prohibiting the financing of the Local Government Polls 2023. Nine, including the Secretary to the Treasury of the Ministry of Finance, Commissioner General of Elections, Chairman of the Election Commission, members and the Attorney General were named as respondents to the Petition. By Faadhila Thassim

title: A/L paper marking to be delayed – CTU
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Teachers’ Union said evaluation of G.C.E. Advanced Level (A/L) Examination answer scripts will be postponed indefinitely, owing to the lack of interest by teachers to apply for the task citing low allowances. Speaking at a media briefing yesterday (21), CTU General Secretary Joseph Stalin said the evaluation of A/L answer scripts was scheduled to begin today (22). “A Cabinet Paper has been submitted to increase the allowances of teachers for evaluating answer scripts. However, to this date, we did not get any response from them. Owing to this situation, the teachers show lack of interest to engage in evaluation. This delay will definitely affect holding upcoming exams as well,” Stalin said. He added that this issue will also impact practical tests. “The Examinations Department is not talking about the reason for this delay,” he claimed. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Deposits won’t be refunded – Punchihewa
author: Author not found
Content: The deposits collected from Political Parties and Independent Groups for the Local Government Election will not be returned as the election is not postponed or cancelled yet, Election Commission Chairman Nimal Punchihewa told Ceylon Today, adding that total deposits for the LG Poll amount to Rs 186 million. He said deposits will not be refunded unless the Court cancels it. Also, if the LG Poll is postponed, the money will not be refunded as well.  Each political party paid Rs 1,500 whereas independent groups paid Rs 5,000 each. “We will have to wait for the Court’s decision on 23 February and then take the next steps,” he added. He also pointed out that the LG Polls are presently fixed for 9 March and there is no dispute on that. He said even if the postal vote is presently decided to be indefinitely postponed it is “active” until the Court decides. The postal vote was scheduled by the EC for 22, 23, and 24 February. The EC notified Political Party Secretaries that it would be unable to distribute the ballots for postal voting as originally anticipated. Already, citizens awaiting the LG Polls have criticised the Government for shelving it citing the economic crisis and lack of funds. Several protests have been staged demanding the poll be held as scheduled and they are awaiting the judgment. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: YouTuber Sepal released after tendering apology
author: Author not found
Content: YouTuber Sepal Amarasinghe, who was remanded over his controversial statements on Sri Dalada Maligawa, was released from the case after he tendered an unconditional apology, in open Court, to the country’s Buddhists and the Chief Prelates, before Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (21). When the case was convened, Senior Deputy Solicitor General (SDIG) Dileepa Peiris, who appeared on behalf of the complainant and the Attorney General, stated, that they are ready to conclude the case, if the suspect is willing to tender an unconditional apology. The Counsel appearing for the suspect, then conveyed to Court that his client was prepared to tender an unconditional apology to the Buddhists here as well as the Chief Prelates, in relation to the controversial remarks, uttered by him, targeting the Sri Dalada Maligawa.  Furthermore, Amarasinghe also apologised to the complainant Ven. Aguruwelle Jinananda Thera, representing the Buddhist Information Centre and others who were in Court. Accordingly, SDSG Peiris informed the Court, that they are ready to conclude the case filed against the defendant. Therefore, the Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis ordered to conclude the case and also released Amarasinghe, who had been in remand custody since 5 January. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: AASL ordered to recruit 50 Air Traffic Controllers immediately
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva instructed officials of Airport and Aviation Services Ltd. and its Management to take prompt action to recruit 50 trainee Air Traffic Controllers to resolve the issues in the sector due to Air Traffic Controllers leaving the country. He gave these instructions after visiting the Ratmalana Civil Aviation Services Training School recently. The Minister also held discussions with trainees and consultants on the present situation, issues and requirements of the training school. Trainers at the facility informed the Minister about the technical issues barring training activities. The Minister instructed the Chairman of Airport and Aviation Services Ltd., to facilitate with financial inputs to resolve all such issues. It was decided to recruit 50 trainee Air Traffic Controllers by 1 April. The Minister emphasised that the Government spends nearly Rs 5 million to train an Air Traffic Controller. “Therefore, Air Traffic Controllers leaving the country after such training is an unbearable loss to both the country and the aviation industry,” he said. The Minister also instructed officials to recruit new Air Traffic Controllers subject to a bond of Rs 10 million and a compulsory service period of 10 years. The Minister also thanked the trainers of the Civil Aviation Services Training School and the representatives of the Air Traffic Controllers’ Association for their invaluable assistance in this connection. A number of top officials of the Ministry and Civil Aviation Authority were also present at the occasion.

title: UNP sacks 1,137 LG members
author: Author not found
Content: The UNP Working Committee unanimously decided to suspend the Party memberships of 1,137 UNP Local Government members, due to their extending support to other political Parties. The UNP said these members have also submitted nominations for the Local Government Election 2023, from other political Parties. About 300 had requested for an opportunity to provide explanations, the Working Committee decided to dismiss the request. Accordingly, new members will be appointed to the vacant seats in the future. (MD)

title: Parliament sittings end abruptly
author: Author not found
Content: Parliament sittings came to an abrupt end yesterday (21) due to a protest by Opposition MPs, forcing the Speaker to adjourn Parliament till today (22). Opposition MPs protested in the Chamber over possible postponement of LG Polls and this led to Parliament sittings being limited to less than an hour. The Opposition MPs held placards and protested near the Speaker’s Chair, demanding to hold the LG Polls on the scheduled date. “We want the election. (diyawu diyawu chande diyawu),” they shouted, displaying placards. After a few tense moments, the Government proposed that sittings be adjourned. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena then adjourned the sittings till 9:30 a.m. today (22). By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Disaster in the making – Commuters
author: Author not found
Content: A disaster is imminent as boats assigned to transport State employees from Jaffna to Delft are overloaded with passengers, employees warned.  They claimed that to date only the boats Wadatharaki and Kumuduni ply from Jaffna to Delft free of charge. Boats belonging to the Cooperative Societies charge money, they lamented. Thus, daily commuters said due to the excessive number of passengers, a serious accident could take place in the near future, putting the lives of many at risk. By Rasadi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Debate on Essential Public Service Act tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: The debate on the Proclamation made by the President under the Essential Public Service Act will be held tomorrow (23), as decided by the Committee on Parliamentary Business, Secretary-General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake said. The Committee on Parliamentary Business met yesterday (21) afternoon and the meeting was chaired by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena. The debate will be held from 9:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. According to the powers vested in the President in terms of the Essential Public Service Act No. 61 of 1979, this Proclamation has been published in Gazette No. 2319/80 of 17 February 2023. Thus, all services connected to the supply of electricity, the supply or distribution of petroleum products and fuel and health services have been declared as essential services. Thereafter, as previously decided by the Committee on Parliamentary Business, two Private Member Bills, namely Institution of Building Services Engineering Technology of Sri Lanka (Incorporation) Bill and the Rathanatissa Peace Foundation (Incorporation) Bill are to be directed to the Legislative Standing Committee following its Second Reading.

title: Tamil factions must learn from Southern political parties – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said the approach of Tamil factions, to win the aspirations and political rights of Tamil people, must be based on the past experiences of political parties in the South. Devananda said this while addressing the media after attending an event in Kilinochchi. “The opinions being made by certain factions for personal political gains would create unwanted inconvenience to Tamil people. It would also cause obstacles to the efforts to win their political aspirations,” Devananda said. “I met various factions during my Kilinochchi visit and promised to take necessary action to address their issues very soon, after listening to their grievances,” he said. BY Naalir Jamaldeen
