title: Father and son arrested over arson attack
author: Author not found
Content: Following the rekindling of a feud between two families, a house at Kosgahawatta, in Mahabellana,  was set ablaze by a father and his son, who had even  thrown the pet dog of other family into the blaze, Alubomulla Police said. Police said due to the severity of the flames the entire house had been gutted except for a few cups and saucers in the kitchen. All the school stationery and text books belonging to a girl, who is to sit for the upcoming GCE Ordinary Level Examination, had also been damaged in the fire. The father and son duo, who are both three-wheel drivers, have been arrested. BY Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo and Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupititya

title: Fmr DLB chair allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta, on Monday (20),  allowed bail for former Chairman of Development Lottery Board (DLB) Sarana Gunawardena, who has been charged with causing a loss of Rs 3.51 million to the State. The former DLB head has been accused, by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), of causing the loss through the misuse of three vehicles belonging to the DLB, while serving as its Chairman from 1 August 2006 to 31 July 2007. Judge Thotawatta released the former Deputy Minister on a cash bail in Rs 30,000 and on two sureties of Rs 500,000 each. The pre-Trial Conference pertaining to the case was fixed for 23 March. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SL Envoy to Indonesia presents credentials in Jakarta
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Indonesia, Admiral Jayanath Colombage presented credentials to President of the Republic of Indonesia, Joko Widodo, on 20 February at the Istana Merdeka, the Presidential Palace in Jakarta. During the brief media interaction prior to presenting credentials, Ambassador Colombage highlighted the longstanding bilateral relations between Sri Lanka and Indonesia in the political, economic and defence spheres since the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries in 1952. The Ambassador recalled the Bandung Conference, the first large-scale Afro-Asian Conference which Indonesia and Sri Lanka jointly organised in 1955, and resulted in the formation of the Non-Aligned Movement. He also mentioned that the people of the two countries share civilisational, cultural and religious links which date back several centuries. Colombage highlighted that Sri Lanka and Indonesia are strategically important in maritime trade in the modern era. He stressed the importance of developing more connectivity between the two countries not only for the well-being of Indonesia and Sri Lanka, but also for the whole world. Colombage was previously Foreign Secretary and Director General of the Institute of National Security Studies in Sri Lanka. He served in the Sri Lanka Navy for 36 years and is a former Navy Commander.

title: ‘Story of the World’; Book on Geopolitical Alliances launched
author: Author not found
Content: The book, ‘Story of the World: Geopolitical Alliances and Rivalries Set in Stone,’ written by Col. Nalin Herath, Director Media of the Ministry of Defence was launched during a ceremony held at the Rock House Army Camp, Mutwal recently, in the presence of Premitha Bandara Tennakoon, State Minister of Defence and General (Retd) Kamal Gunaratne, Defence Secretary. The author, Col. Herath, who is well known among military officers for his familiarity on current affairs, penned his maiden volume, titled ‘Globe in a Nutshell’ when he was serving in MINURSO in 2017. It was sought after by military personnel and IR students worldwide for their studies and reference. The latest version, ‘Story of the World: Geopolitical Alliances and Rivalries Set in Stone,’ that contains 725 pages, is another giant leap forward in his life as it marks the launch of his subsequent literary masterpiece. This volume presents a collection of facts on geopolitics, history, culture, international relations, and it consists of an in-depth analysis about the new world order in the context of present geopolitical developments, particularly the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The glossary of International Relations and related terms with the description depicted in the book provides fresh thoughts and avenues for future research in the field. Areas such as ‘Strategic importance of Sri Lanka’ and the acts of major two powers on it including the country’s foreign policy are some of the noteworthy topics that he has illustrated openly.    This is a methodical compilation covering the spectrum of the focus which enlightens the readership on international organisations, border conflicts, internal conflicts, recent pandemic and rivalries over natural resources and trade etc. by extracting respective countries and regions including key fonts of such disparities. The most impressive and attention-grabbing part of the volume is suggested movies so as to enhance the experience of readership on historical wars. The actualities are well-organised, factual, and consistent and also this literary masterpiece is apt for both scholars of international affairs and related research. Senior Lecturer Dr. Harinda Vidanage, Head of Department of Strategic Studies – KDU made the keynote address and Brig. (Retd) Sri Mudannayake delivered the special guest’s speech during the event. Chief of Defence Staff Gen. Shavendra Silva, Director General of Civil Security Department Maj. Gen. (Retd) Ranjan Lamahewage, Director General of the President’s Media Division Dhanushka Ramanayake, Commandant of the National Defence College Maj. Gen. Amal Karunasekara, Chief of National Intelligence Maj. Gen. (Retd) Ruwan Kulathunga, Acting Director General – INSS Rear Admiral Dimuthu Gunawardena, Additional Secretaries of the Defence Ministry including senior officials, Senior Military and Police Officers, heads and lecturers of universities, intellectuals, journalists and distinguished guests were present at the occasion.

title: A Fitting Tribute for Lance Corporal Deshapriya
author: Author not found
Content: Peacekeeping troops of the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilisation Mission in Mali (MINUSMA) on Thursday (16) presented a formal military salute and bid farewell to the late Lance Corporal M.G.L. Deshapriya (42) of the 6 Sri Lanka Army Service Corps who had passed away on 11 February 2023 following a sudden cardiac arrest on admission to the MINUSMA Bamako Level – 3 Hospital. In conformity with UN traditions, MINUSMA troops presented a salute lowering flags and honoured their comrade during the formal military parade before floral tributes were made to the coffin, draped in the UN flag by Daniela Kroslak, Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General for United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilisation Mission in Mali (MINUSMA) and Deputy Chief of MINUSMA Operations in the presence of a gathering of MINUSMA Officers and Other Rankers, including the Commanding Officer of the Sri Lankan Combat Convoy Company (CCC) of the MINUSMA.  The remains of late Lance Corporal M.G.L. Deshapriya (42), a father of two children, resident in Medawachchiya is to be brought to Sri Lanka shortly for final funeral arrangements.

title: Food in 18% of eateries unfit for consumption – PHIs
author: Author not found
Content: Eighteen (18) per cent of the eateries across the country have been classified as ‘C’ grade, after inspection teams found that the food they prepared was unfit for human consumption, the Public Health Inspectors Union of Sri Lanka (PHIUSL) revealed. PHIUSL President Upul Rohana yesterday (20) said a survey carried out countrywide on food handling institutions, which mainly constituted eateries and hotels, had revealed that 18 per cent of the food prepared by them are unfit for human consumption. Fielding questions Rohana said that majority of them had been established in places which did not have proper water supply and sanitation facilities. The lack of permanent staff, mainly due to poor wages, was another grievous problem faced by these hotels and eateries. This made it difficult for PHIs to ensure health condition of the food handlers serving in those eating houses and hotels. The situation was very prominent when comparing them with those food handling establishments which had permanent staff. During the survey, 27 per cent of establishments were detected as average in their food preparation. What the PHIUSL wants to accomplish is to upgrade the ‘C’ grade to ‘B’ grade by providing them with the guidelines, regulating those institutions and “we would also have to take legal action against those who fail to comply,” Rohana warned. He noted that inspections carried out during the survey had also shown that 55 per cent of eateries and hotels in the country were of good quality.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: EC informs SC holding polls hampered by lack of funds
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission yesterday (20) informed the Supreme Court that the Government has failed to provide the funds required to hold the Local Government Election on 9 March, due to which the EC has faced difficulties in holding the Election as scheduled. The EC, through a motion, noted that although an undertaking was previously given to Court that the Election will be held as scheduled, it will not be possible to do so due to the shortage of funds coupled with other difficulties, including fuel shortages. The Election Commission on 18 January gave an undertaking to the Supreme Court that the Election will be conducted in accordance with the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance. President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, on behalf of the EC, observed that the steps taken in connection with the LG Election, thus far, would continue after the nominations process, too. This was when the Petitions filed by a group of MPs, seeking an interim order to be issued to the Election Commission, for steps to be taken to hold the Local Government election in March 2023 was taken up. Previously, the Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, Mahinda Siriwardana, informed the Supreme Court that the Treasury will find it extremely challenging to find additional resources for an election, as only Rs 18 billion per month is left for Government expenses. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: SLMA urges extreme caution if legalising cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMA) urged the President’s Secretary, Saman Ekanayake to be extremely cautious when considering any form of legalising cannabis, by relaxing laws on cultivation, for “doubtful economic benefits.” In a letter to the President’s Secretary, the President of the SLMA, Dr. Vinya Ariyaratne and the Chairperson of the Expert Committee on Tobacco, Alcohol and illicit Drugs, Prof. Narada Warnasuriya observed that cannabis products had fallen steeply during the six to seven years in world markets ‘due to over-supply’.  The Duo, expressing the SLMA’s concern, said that cannabis was the most widely used psychoactive substance in the globe. It is also the widely used illegal drug by young people. “Despite the claims of medical benefits, there are many health harms from cannabis, including mental disorders such as depression and schizophrenia, cannabis use disorders and serious lung ailments,” they pointed out noting that it also affected the brain development of adolescents and was associated with self-harm, suicide and road traffic accidents, one of the major killers in Sri Lanka. Dr. Ariyaratne and Prof. Warnasuriya said the current economic crisis had been made the latest excuse for interested parties to go ahead with their objectives. “Though we are convinced that the ‘Committee to explore feasibility of cultivating cannabis for export’, had been appointed in good faith by the government, we wish to place the following queries before this committee,” they said outlining some of the questions. They queried as to whether the need for new policies or laws, as growing cannabis for medicinal purposes was allowed. “Has an independent and credible international market survey been carried out estimating the market share we can get, the prices, the profits and the actual amount of foreign currency that the country and the government will earn,” they queried noting that the surplus of hemp production around the world, leading crashes in market prices, putting farmers in debt and causing billion-dollar losses to cannabis companies. They asked if any multinational cannabis companies be allowed to grow cannabis in Sri Lanka, alone or in collaboration with a local partner or the government and if so, will these entities be allowed repatriate their profits in foreign currency from Sri Lanka, they questioned. The duo queried as to whether the committee would take into account the large investments made by the tobacco industry in cannabis companies although the cannabis companies were making billion-dollar losses? The SLMA President and the Expert Committee Chairman noted the danger of promoting use of cannabis by giving it the level of publicity it receives now. “As you may be aware, there is a concerted effort to promote cannabis through social media. The current publicity relating to decriminalisation and legalising will ensure a synergistic effect, resulting in normalising cannabis use,” they warned. Evidence shows that such publicity related to one substance could lead to increase in use of other substances as well, the duo added.

title: Govt briefs JICA on trade reforms to restore economy
author: Author not found
Content: The Government yesterday (20) told Director General of the South Asia Department, of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), Teruyuki Ito, that reforms would be implemented to restore Sri Lanka’s economy. This follows Japanese trading house Mitsubishi Corp’s and Taisei Corp’s decision to withdraw from Colombo due to incompatible business and economic climates. Mitsubishi is expected close its operation at the end of March and to operate from one of its offices in the South Asian regions. State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe tweeted that he met the JICA Director General yesterday (20) and reiterated that the reforms that should have been carried out over many years, are now being carried out progressively. Further, he noted he was happy to note that JICA will extend their fullest support to Sri Lanka’s recovery process and towards growth.  JICA which is a governmental agency of Japan, that provides development assistance to developing countries, also signed the construction of BIA’s Terminal-2 expansion deal, where Japanese’ Taisei Corporation Sri Lanka was involved, but suspended the project calling for an environment conducive for business and the government to restructure its debt as the government is not in a position to repay the loan.  JICA expressed it would withdraw from funding, but it would want the government to transfer the project to another Japanese company. There have been reports about a Chinese company expressing interest in the project. But the JICA loan is conditioned on the participation of only Japanese companies.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Businessman’s kidnappers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Grandpass Police have arrested a four-member gang, who sought a ransom of Rs 7 million, after having abducted a wealthy businessman of the area. Police said, during the probe they seized the ransom money along with the van used to abduct the businessman. The van had been taken on rent. Police said the incident had taken place on 10 February. They added that when the businessman had gone to a Mosque in Grandpass, for religious observances, on a motorcycle, the gangsters, who were travelling in a van impeded the path of the motorcycle and bundled him into the van. Later they had tied the businessman’s hands and blindfolded him. After taking him to a house, the gang demanded the aforesaid ransom. The abducted businessman had then called one of his friend’s and managed to obtain the ransom money and was freed. Police said the suspects were arrested at a house situated at Negombo Road in Wattala and they are due to be produced before Court. BY Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Solution for economic problems through educational reforms – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha elaborated that solutions for the current economic issues of the country could be sought through educational reforms. In addition, he said the production of the country should be combined with modern technology. The Minister made these remarks at the launch of Sri Lanka-Korea National Vocational Training Institute’s language lab. The Foreign Employment Promotion and Resource Centre of the Vocational Training Authority of Sri Lanka, was inaugurated and apprentice students were registered to study Japanese. The elderly care course was also launched here with the intention of educating foreign job seekers on the subject. Premajayantha went on to say that a new education transformation process that integrates the three sectors of general education, vocational education, and higher education must be implemented in order to change the entire educational system. Technical solutions to these problems should be sought with organisations like the Vocational Training Authority of Sri Lanka. Also, it was stated that it was improper to make politically popular decisions. “The 2030 Sustainable Global Development Goals (SDGs) can only be achieved if we use technology properly. We should not settle for the available labour resources or neglect emerging technology. We can learn from Japan’s success in developing the country within a decade by fusing Information Technology and Artificial Intelligence,” he said.

title: President wants Minipe project expedited
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed the officials to speed up the Minipe Left Bank Canal Rehabilitation (MLBCR) Project which has been delayed for over three years and finish the project by the next Maha season. The President provided these instructions while joining an observation tour of the Minipe Anicut construction site on Sunday (19) afternoon. The cost of the project is Rs 3,000 million and the construction work is carried out by China Gexhouba Group Company Limited (CGGC). The President also pointed out the possibility of obtaining the support of the students of engineering faculties in Sri Lanka for the future work of the project. The existing anicut is not sufficient to release water to the left and right bank canals when water is released twice a day from the Rantambe Hydro Power Plant during peak demand for electricity. In order to provide more reliable and continuous water supply to Minipe agricultural lands, the Minipe Dam was raised by 3.5m and the renovation of the 74 km-long main canal on the left bank of Minipe commenced. After the reconstruction of the Minipe Anicut, constant water supply to farmers will be ensured and the cultivable land on both sides of the left bank of Minipe could be cultivated without obstruction in the Yala-Maha Seasons while providing benefits to 15,000 farmer families. Minipe Anicut, which was built in 1948, was last renovated in 1980. The specialty is that the renovation work is happening again after a lapse of 40 years. Senior Advisor to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff of the President Sagala Ratnayake, Director of Minipe Left Bank Canal Rehabilitation Project (MLBCRP) Management Division Engineer D.B. Wijeratne, Project Director Indika Valisundara and other officials attended the occasion.

title: Court orders speedy probe into Subasinghe’s death
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (20) ordered the CID to conduct a speedy probe into the mysterious murder of the owner of the Opex Holding Private Limited Onesh Subasinghe and to report back to him soon. The Chief Magistrate gave this order, having considered submissions produced before him by the CID. The CID pointed out, that they commenced an investigation into the incident, following a complaint lodged by Subash Subasinghe, a sibling of the deceased,. The CID informed Chief Magistrate Alwis, that during the course of their probe, they had already recorded statements from five individuals, including those who were employed as servants, at the residence of the late businessman. They added that from the statements recorded, it has come to light that the spouse of the deceased conveyed to the latter on a few times, that she wanted to leave Sri Lanka and that not willing to consume Sri Lankan cuisine. The CID also explained, that the statements recorded had revealed, that on a few occasions, the late Onesh Subasinghe, informed his servants that his life was in imminent danger. The prosecution stated that further investigations into the incident, were yet proceeding. Taking the submissions into perusal, the Court instructed the CID, to expedite its probe into the matter and submit fresh submissions at the next hearing. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Smuggled vehicle parts destroyed
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Customs destroyed smuggled vehicle body parts seized in the past few years yesterday (20). Vehicle cut portions and other parts from vehicles were destroyed. Customs Spokesman Senior Customs Director Sudattha Silva said that the vehicle parts had been seized by the department’s income review unit and declared as State assets. The vehicle parts were destroyed under the supervision of the Customs Additional General, yesterday (20) at Rank Containers Terminal, Orugodawatta. (NV)

title: Two senior soldiers removed from post after street fight
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Executive Officer of the Nelum Pokuna Theatre, Major General L.S. Balachandra and Brigadier General Staff of SFHQ in Mullaitivu Suresh Perera, had been removed from their posts following a brawl on the road recently over allegedly overtaking a senior’s vehicle, Sri Lanka Army said. The Army also has launched an inquiry into the brawl which took place on 15 February while on their way to attend an event at Mechanised Infantry Regiment in Dambulla. Apart from these, several facilities that had been given to them were also stripped. Ceylon Today learns that the two officers, with their spouses were heading to attend an event organised to celebrate the promotion of an Army officer. A brawl escalated when the Brigadier’s vehicle overtook the Major General’s vehicle. After that, verbal confrontation erupted on the road between the two officers.

title: EC informs SC holding polls hampered by lack of funds
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission yesterday (20) informed the Supreme Court that the Government has failed to provide the funds required to hold the Local Government Election on 9 March, due to which the EC has faced difficulties in holding the Election as scheduled. The EC, through a motion, noted that although an undertaking was previously given to Court that the Election will be held as scheduled, it will not be possible to do so due to the shortage of funds coupled with other difficulties, including fuel shortages. The Election Commission on 18 January gave an undertaking to the Supreme Court that the Election will be conducted in accordance with the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance. President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, on behalf of the EC, observed that the steps taken in connection with the LG Election, thus far, would continue after the nominations process, too. This was when the Petitions filed by a group of MPs, seeking an interim order to be issued to the Election Commission, for steps to be taken to hold the Local Government election in March 2023 was taken up. Previously, the Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, Mahinda Siriwardana, informed the Supreme Court that the Treasury will find it extremely challenging to find additional resources for an election, as only Rs 18 billion per month is left for Government expenses. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: SLMA urges extreme caution if legalising cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMA) urged the President’s Secretary, Saman Ekanayake to be extremely cautious when considering any form of legalising cannabis, by relaxing laws on cultivation, for “doubtful economic benefits.” In a letter to the President’s Secretary, the President of the SLMA, Dr. Vinya Ariyaratne and the Chairperson of the Expert Committee on Tobacco, Alcohol and illicit Drugs, Prof. Narada Warnasuriya observed that cannabis products had fallen steeply during the six to seven years in world markets ‘due to over-supply’.  The Duo, expressing the SLMA’s concern, said that cannabis was the most widely used psychoactive substance in the globe. It is also the widely used illegal drug by young people. “Despite the claims of medical benefits, there are many health harms from cannabis, including mental disorders such as depression and schizophrenia, cannabis use disorders and serious lung ailments,” they pointed out noting that it also affected the brain development of adolescents and was associated with self-harm, suicide and road traffic accidents, one of the major killers in Sri Lanka. Dr. Ariyaratne and Prof. Warnasuriya said the current economic crisis had been made the latest excuse for interested parties to go ahead with their objectives. “Though we are convinced that the ‘Committee to explore feasibility of cultivating cannabis for export’, had been appointed in good faith by the government, we wish to place the following queries before this committee,” they said outlining some of the questions. They queried as to whether the need for new policies or laws, as growing cannabis for medicinal purposes was allowed. “Has an independent and credible international market survey been carried out estimating the market share we can get, the prices, the profits and the actual amount of foreign currency that the country and the government will earn,” they queried noting that the surplus of hemp production around the world, leading crashes in market prices, putting farmers in debt and causing billion-dollar losses to cannabis companies. They asked if any multinational cannabis companies be allowed to grow cannabis in Sri Lanka, alone or in collaboration with a local partner or the government and if so, will these entities be allowed repatriate their profits in foreign currency from Sri Lanka, they questioned. The duo queried as to whether the committee would take into account the large investments made by the tobacco industry in cannabis companies although the cannabis companies were making billion-dollar losses? The SLMA President and the Expert Committee Chairman noted the danger of promoting use of cannabis by giving it the level of publicity it receives now. “As you may be aware, there is a concerted effort to promote cannabis through social media. The current publicity relating to decriminalisation and legalising will ensure a synergistic effect, resulting in normalising cannabis use,” they warned. Evidence shows that such publicity related to one substance could lead to increase in use of other substances as well, the duo added.

title: Travel ban on Doctor over youth’s death
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (20) impounded the passport of a doctor, who had been operating an Ayurvedic Medical Centre in Wellampitiya. This was in connection with a lawsuit filed against the doctor, who has been charged with causing the death of a youth, after injecting him with a vaccine. The suspect doctor, whose overseas travels were banned, was identified as Mohammad Careem, a resident of Colombo 9. Wellampitiya Police, informed Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya, that the deceased, identified as Dananjaya Pinnaduwa, a resident of Wennawatta in Wellampitiya, had visited the doctor concerned on 27 January, to seek treatment for an illness. They added that the deceased had passed away, after the suspect doctor had injected a vaccine. The Police further said in the aftermath of the death of the youth, a short post-mortem had been conducted and an open verdict issued. Accordingly the prosecution urged the Court, to issue an order to ban the overseas travels of the suspect doctor, in order to expedite its probe into the death. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Dream Big: Visit Australian Education Fair today
author: Author not found
Content: Visit International Scholar, Australian Education Fair, at Cinnamon Grand Hotel (Ivy Room) today (21). Since 1999, International Scholar has placed over 3,500 students in highly prestigious institutes globally.  They are one of the largest overseas education consultancy providers and pride themselves on ensuring that students choose the education options that fit them best. Today, International Scholar will be hosting an Education Exhibition at the Cinnamon Grand Hotel, Ivy Room, from 10 a.m.  Kumar Sangakkara – former Sri Lankan cricketer and Dr. Dinuk Jayasuriya are Directors of International Scholar.  There will be 15 representatives from prestigious Australian universities attending the event.  Students visiting the exhibition will also be able to get information about study opportunities in the UK, New Zealand, Malaysia, Japan and Dubai. Dr. Jayasuriya, a Director at International Scholar, stated, “We understand how important education decisions are, especially when it involves international study.  As such, we encourage prospective students to visit our exhibition and speak directly with representatives from our partner universities.  This is an opportunity to ask any questions you may have about various degrees and understand the benefits of certain universities over others. You may also want university representatives to address any concerns you may have.” Further, International Scholar will provide career guidance, assistance with visas and other relevant services with regard to making your dream come true. The service of International Scholar is free of charge for all students. So, if you dream of studying overseas, dream big and visit the International Scholar Education Exhibition Today (21), at Cinnamon Grand Ivy room, from 10 a.m. For free registration visit www.international-scholar. com or call 011 2553466/ 2593571

title: Lie to say no money to print ballot papers
author: Author not found
Content: Despite having all the resources to print ballot papers, to say that ballot papers cannot be printed without an advance payment is a premeditated lie to postpone the Local Government (LG) Election, SJB Parliamentarian Eran Wickramaratne said on Sunday (19). Addressing a press conference, held at the Opposition Leader’s office in Colombo, Wickramaratne alleged that UNP leader and President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s actions recently implied two things: That he would not hold Local Government elections and that he would protect the Rajapaksas during the rest of his term, in whatever way he could.  He also said that this is the first time that an election has been obstructed by deviating from the Constitution and the law. “In the last Budget, Rs 10 billion was allocated for the election to be held in 2023. The talk that there is no money now is a blatant lie,” said Wickramaratne. Wickramaratne also said that from a historical perspective, the printing costs of the May 2010 Parliamentary Election were paid to the Government Press on 12 August 2010, i.e. four months later. Similarly, money was paid to the Government Press for the expenses of the Parliamentary Poll held on 17 August 2015 only on 21 October 2015. Likewise the printing costs for the 2019 Presidential Election were made to the Government Press only after eight months, he said. “In spite of these precedents, to declare that ballot papers cannot be printed without paying money in advance, despite having all the necessary resources for printing only for this election, is a premeditated lie to postpone the Local Government Election, he said. ‘The concerned officials should pay attention to the fact that the Sri Lanka Bar Association has warned them, including the Treasury Secretary and the Government Printer, not to engage in activities that sabotage the holding of the L.G. Election,” said Wickramaratne. He also warned that if the Executive President and Parliament decide to hold elections in the way they want, that is not only a violation of the law, but also the usurpation of the people’s right to sovereignty. As prescribed by Article 104 of the Constitution, “Every authority must support the Election Commissioner to hold an election when it is called and obstructing it is a criminal offence and punishable with imprisonment of public officials, especially heads of institutions, who have sworn to uphold the Constitution-must be mindful of its consequence,” said Wickramaratne. Therefore, he advised public officials to act honestly and thoughtfully, as there are many examples in the recent past where even if the politicians called them to their offices and warned, or even issued illegal orders, those officials ended up being punished for engaging in acts that are against the Constitution. “All members of Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) were previously in the United National Party (UNP),’ said Wickramaratne. But Wickremesinghe has changed the UNP Constitution in such a way that he has made himself UNP leader for life, the SJB MP said. Therefore, to protect democracy, about 90 per cent of the MPs and members from the UNP, formed the SJB. (PA)

title: Professional business women of SL and Lahore sign MoU
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s Women’s Chamber of Industry and Commerce (WCIC) signed an Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Lahore Women’s Chamber of Commerce and Industry (WCCI) at the Bandaranaike International Convention Hall( BMICH) on 18 February. The delegation from Lahore was in Colombo attending the Pakistan trade fair. WCIC Chairperson Anoji de Silva and President WCCI Lahore Sahar Malik signed the MoU. Two Vice Chairpersons of WCIC Gayani de Alwis and Renuka Senanayake were also present along with the delegation from the Lahore Chapter. This is the first international MoU entered into by the WCIC. WCIC Chairperson Anoji de Silva said, “there are opportunities for both sides to collaborate for mutual benefit and we must keep this partnership alive. Women’s Chamber of Industry and Commerce is the premier organisation supporting entrepreneurs and professional business-women. The membership is open to women who believe they can contribute to society as well as benefit from the many facilities the organisation creates. (SRM)

title: Three injured in bus, train collission
author: Author not found
Content: Three persons were injured in an accident involving a SLTB bus and a train near the Ariviyal Nagar Railway Station near Kilinochchi. Other passengers miraculously escaped without any injury, according to Kilinochchi Police The Kilinochchi Police said that the accident had occurred yesterday (20) at around 8.30a.m when the SLTB bus, transporting the employees of the University of Jaffna collided with the Yaldevi train, which was travelling towards Murikandy. The injured passengers are being treated at Kilinochchi District Hospital and the Hospital sources confirmed that they are out of danger and will be discharged. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ceylon Tea brand name damaged by smallholders
author: Author not found
Content: Robert Harley, the ex-Chairman of the Central Province Tea Factory Owners Association, said that the Ceylon Tea brand name had suffered irreparable damage due to the country’s tea industry having been taken over by small estate owners. He made this remark while attending an annual event, held by the Kurunduwatta Tea Factory recently, to distribute school stationery to students residing in the Gampola Ganga Ihala Korale village. Harley is also the owner of the Kurunduwatta Tea Factory. This particular event was held without the involvement of politician and only State officers were invited. BY Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: A sip of Ceylon Tea to soothe earthquake – affected Türkiye
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Türkiye Hasanthi Urugodawatte Dissanayake visited Adana on 16 February 2023 to receive the first donation from the Government of Sri Lanka to Türkiye, a consignment of 1,500 kg of Ceylon Tea organised by the Sri Lanka Tea Board which came via Turkish Airlines to Istanbul and then to Adana. Adana, an area affected by the earthquake, has become a hub for the distribution of emergency cargo coming from all over the world. The donation was made to the Turkish Embassy in Colombo, and Ambassador Dissanayake together with the Honorary Consul for Sri Lanka in the Mediterranean Region, Beşir Uğurin received the consignment upon arrival in Adana. Representative of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Ankara Ozkan Durmaz and AFAD representative in Adana Vehbi Kaplan were also present. The Ambassador called on Mayor of Adana Metropolitan Municipality Zeydan Karalar, and expressed her heartfelt condolences on behalf of the Government and the people of Sri Lanka over the tragic loss of life, injuries and devastation caused by a series of earthquakes in Türkiye on 6th February 2023. The Mayor of Adana thanked the Ambassador for visiting Adana to receive the first donation made by the Government of Sri Lanka which will be distributed to the affected people. Further, the mayor also appreciated the role of Honorary Consul for Sri Lanka for the Mediterranean Region Beşir Uğur, who donated over 80,000 kg from his company BETA Tea. The BETA Tea Company was founded by Beşir Uğur in 1985 in Türkiye. He opened an office in Sri Lanka in 1987. BETA Tea is considered the pioneering Turkish business enterprise to enter Sri Lanka and is a leading tea company that promotes Ceylon Tea in Türkiye and several other countries in Central Asia and Russia where the tea is exported. Ambassador Dissanayake also visited the tea packaging plant in the outskirts of the Adana city.

title: UNDERSTANDING NEEDS OF FOOD-INSECURE COMMUNITIES
author: Author not found
Content: The United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) welcomed Stephanie Wilcock, Director for Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean of the US Agency for International Development (USAID)’s Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance (BHA) on a visit to Sri Lanka. During the visit, Wilcock met with poor rural communities to understand their food and nutrition needs, and how WFP’s US-funded programmes will help them overcome challenges brought on by the economic crisis.   As part of the visit, Wilcock travelled to Ratnapura, where she spoke with food-insecure families faced with high food prices and unemployment. The community will soon receive US-funded cash assistance through WFP worth LKR 20,000 (approximately US$ 55) for four consecutive months which will empower them with the choice to meet their essential needs in local markets, while also helping to boost the economy. “Sri Lanka continues to experience significantly high levels of food insecurity, affecting over 30 per cent of the population, most notably among the poor” said Gerard Rebello, Acting Country Director for WFP Sri Lanka. “We are extremely grateful for the invaluable support from the Government and people of the United States, which has been critical in enabling WFP to expand its emergency assistance. The funding from USAID will help WFP address humanitarian needs and prevent food insecurity from deteriorating further.” The United States has funded nearly one-third of Sri Lanka’s emergency operation requirement, with a contribution of US$ 20 million (LKR 7.3 billion) in 2022. The funds allow WFP to provide cash, food assistance and value vouchers to food-insecure families, and to support national food and nutrition programmes, including school meals and Thriposha, a fortified blended food product for pregnant and nursing mothers and young children.  USAID’s long-time support for the Government of Sri Lanka through WFP has helped improve the country’s capacity in disaster risk management, particularly against natural hazards. During the trip, Wilcock also visited an emergency operations centre in Ratnapura to observe how US funding has enabled district-level emergency coordination systems development. Wilcock was given an overview of how the centre provides timely information to safeguard communities from natural hazards such as floods and landslides. WFP, with funding from donors like the US, has reached two million people since June 2022 through its emergency operation, with plans to reach 3.4 million people with food and nutrition assistance in the coming months.

title: SJB protesters dispersed with tear gas
author: Author not found
Content: Police used water cannon and tear gas to disperse the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) protesters at the Technical Junction in Maradana, yesterday (20). Earlier, Police had obtained a Court Order, from the Fort Magistrate, preventing the SJB from engaging in the protest demonstrations, citing inconvenience caused to pedestrian and vehicular movements. However, the SJB held the protest despite the Court Order. The Order also prevented protesters from entering the President’s office, President’s House, the Finance Ministry and the Galle Face area.     By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Govt Approval Static at 10%
author: Author not found
Content: A poll conducted in early February 2023 based on an islandwide nationally representative sample of responses from over one thousand Sri Lankan adults showed that Government approval has stayed static, at an extreme low level of 10 per cent while Sri Lanka satisfaction has declined to 4 per cent which was at 7 per cent in October 2022. These were as per a Gallup Style ‘Mood of the Nation’ poll conducted by Verité Research, which assessed the approval, satisfaction, and confidence of the nation in relation to the Government, the country, and the economy. The poll was conducted as a part of the syndicated survey instrument by Verité Research also provides other organisations the opportunity to survey the sentiments of Sri Lanka. The poll results are Government approval rating:  To the question, “Do you approve or disapprove of the way the current government is working?” only 10 per cent said they approve (with an error margin of ± 2.04 per cent). This is the same extreme low level as it was in October 2022. In June 2022 the approval rating was at an all-time low of 3 per cent. Sri Lanka satisfaction: To the question, “In general, are you satisfied or dissatisfied with the way things are going in Sri Lanka?” only 4 per cent said they were satisfied (with an error margin of ± 1.50 per cent). This rating was at 7 per cent in October 2022 and 2 per cent in June 2022. Economic confidence: Multiple choice questions on the condition and trajectory of the economy are used to generate an economic confidence score. The score can range from negative (-) 100 to positive (+) 100. A score above zero means more people see the economic conditions positively rather than negatively. If everyone thinks that the economy is in a poor condition (instead of good or excellent), and everyone also thinks it is getting worse (rather than better), then the score will be a (-) 100. In February 2023, 0.3 per cent rated the economic conditions as excellent, 6.0 per cent rate it as good; and 6.3 per cent rate it as getting better. The resulting score was a (-) 78.4 (rounded off as negative 78). This rating was (-) 78 in October, and (-) 96 in June. The present poll was conducted in early February 2023 and is based on an islandwide nationally representative sample of responses from over one thousand Sri Lankan adults. The sample and methodology were designed to limit the maximum error margin to under 3 per cent at a 95 per cent confidence interval. The specific error margins are reported with the results. The polling partner was Vanguard Survey (Pvt) Ltd.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 3 killed, 6 injured in road mishaps
author: Author not found
Content: Three people were killed and six others injured in two separate incidents when the vehicles they were travelling in went down a precipice in two different locations. Two persons were killed and two others injured, when the three-wheeler they were travelling fell down a 500-foot precipice on the Ratnapura-Deniyaya Road. The accident had taken place on 17 February when three individuals from Heyawatta were on their way to buy medicine from a pharmacy in Buthkanda. The three-wheeler driver had lost control of the vehicle and it had gone down a steep precipice. Two passengers were killed on the spot and the other passenger and driver were admitted to Kolonne Hospital. The victims were identified as 61-year-old and 62-year-old residents of Heyawatte. However, the driver was arrested and Kolonne Police are condcuting further investigations. Meanwhile, one person was killed and four others hospitalised when a tractor went down a 300 meter precipice in Balangoda on 18 February. Police said the tractor was transporting tea leaves and the victim was the driver of the tractor. He is a 44-year-old father of two. The four others who were injured were admitted to Balangoda Base Hospital and identified as plantation workers. BY Atauda Pathirana (Urubokka) and Nalinda Valeboda (Balangoda)

title: LG Polls of little use at present – Thondaman
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman said a Local Government Election would be of little use at the present juncture. “This time, what is needed is not a Local Government Election, but a Presidential Election or a Parliamentary Election. Only that can bring about change in the country,” he said. Meanwhile, he told a gathering in Matale yesterday (19) that steps are being taken to raise plantation workers’ wages from Rs 2,000 to Rs 2,500. Following the Rs 1,000 salary hike, there has been a clash between trade unions and plantation companies. “You cannot embark on a journey with such tensions. Companies that claim to be in the process of forming a partnership are actually doing something else behind the scenes. A Court case is pending in this connection. Steps are being taken to raise plantation workers’ wages from Rs 2,000 to Rs 2,500,” he said. By Chandrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: EC urges Returning Officers to return official vehicles
author: Author not found
Content: With Local Government Elections being postponed indefinitely and President Ranil Wickremesinghe maintaining there will be no election until next year, the Election Commission has urged Returning Officers to return vehicles deployed for election duties and to revert to their ordinary duties. Commissioner General of Elections Saman Sri Ratnayake sent a letter to all Returning Officers and Assistant Returning Officers with a list of instructions about the steps taken in connection with the Local Government Elections. Ratnayake informed them to work normal office hours from today (20) and to suspend overtime for election duties. All District Election Offices including the Head Office should be closed during weekends and public holidays and the Election Commissioner General’s prior approval must be obtained if it is necessary to open the office on weekends or holidays for any special duties. The services of presently employed casual workers and retired officers shall be terminated after office hours with effect from 17 February. Also, the staff officers temporarily assigned from other government departments/ offices for election duties should be released to their respective workplaces. Ratnayake also informed that all vehicles that were obtained from various institutions for staff transport should be temporarily released to the relevant institutions with immediate effect. However, the Commissioner General informed that instructions will be issued in regard to Police Officers deployed for additional security of the office and arrangements should be made to obtain Police protection until then.

title: Water tariff hike in the offing
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Water Supply, Jeevan Thondaman, said with the increase in electricity tariffs, they are obligated to raise the water tariff as well, and that it should be done soon. He said yesterday (19) while addressing a gathering in Matale that the main reason for doing so is that many water projects are powered by electricity. He also highlighted that the increase in electricity tariffs increased the cost of water supply. “We recognise the difficulties that the people of the country are experiencing in the current situation. Following the signing of agreements with the International Monetary Fund, plans are being developed to implement solar water supply projects in order to reduce costs. Water charges can then be reduced,” he added. Further, he said the Government requires revenue to provide free essential services such as education and health care in the country. “As a result of such crises, taxes must be raised. As a result, I implore the people to be patient within the time frame set for the sake of the country and future generations. Despite the fact that the country’s current situation is unsustainable, the Government is taking steps to reduce the prices of essential goods,” he said. BY Chandrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: Fisheries Ministry mulls allowing TN fishers to fish in Lankan waters
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (19) the Ministry was considering permitting Tamil Nadu fishermen to fish in Sri Lankan waters twice a week. Discussions will be held with the relevant authorities, including fisheries federations, to investigate the possibility of limiting traditional fishing vessels to two days of fishing in Sri Lankan waters due to their low engine capacity of 40 to 50 horsepower. The Minister however, said trawlers will not be allowed to fish in northern waters whatsoever as engines have a 150 horsepower. The final decision will be taken during President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s New Delhi visit expected to take place soon, Devananda said. “In case, permission is granted to Tamil Nadu fishermen, the possibility of using tax income for fishery development in the Northern Province without transferring it to the Treasury,” Devananda said. Indian Ministers Murugan and Annamalai had requested to consider the possibility of permitting them to fish in Lankan waters off the Northern coast. However, trawlers will not be allowed to enter Sri Lankan waters, Devananda further said. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Katana City Plan to get off ground soon
author: Author not found
Content: The Urban Development Authority (UDA) has prepared a draft development plan for Katana, in response to Minister of Urban Development and Housing, Prasanna Ranatunga’s instructions. A discussion about public comments and suggestions for the draft Katana City Development Plan was conducted recently. The Katana City Development Plan was created for the Katunayake-Seeduwa Municipal Council and Katana Provincial Council and will be in effect from 2023 to 2033. The goal is to transform the Katunayake-Seeduwa jurisdiction into a world-class airport that offers transportation, air cargo, and tourism services, as well as to transform Katana into a comfortable city with a self-sufficient economy. The Katana City Development Plan draft was presented to the Chairman of the Katunayake Seeduwa Municipal Council, Chamith Nishantha and the Chairman of the Katana Regional Council, Sisira Fernando by MP Kokila Gunawardena. The draft will be distributed to other members of the two local government bodies and plans will be made to solicit public feedback and suggestions. The UDA has set aside 60 days for this, after which the Katana City Development Plan will be published in the Gazette. The Katana City Plan will be implemented in accordance with main strategies including economic and tourism development, land and building development, sustainable environmental development, and infrastructure development.

title: Key political figures make historic pledge on LGBTQ rights
author: Author not found
Content: Representatives of several major political Parties came together to discuss their views on non-discrimination of LGBTQ Sri Lankans. Ceylon Workers’ Congress Leader, Minister Jeevan Thondaman, SLPP MP Premnath C. Dolawatte, SJB MP Mayantha Dissanayake and Freedom People’s Congress MP Prof. Charitha Herath shared their views during the discussion jointly hosted by NextGenSL and the Canadian High Commission to Sri Lanka. Attorney-at-Law Aritha Wickramasinghe, Equality Director of iProbono moderated the panel discussion. Premnath Dolawatte, who recently presented a Private Member’s Bill to Parliament seeking to decriminalise LGBTQ Sri Lankans, said he was hopeful that the majority of MPs in the House would support his Bill and join the effort to protect the rights of the LGBTQ community. “I know the ultimate fight should be for non-discrimination and decriminalisation of the LGBTQ community is only one aspect of it. But, we must start somewhere,” Dolawatte said, sharing his views at the event. Describing himself as an “untamed elephant,” the SLPP MP said he did not speak to the LGBTQ community before presenting his Private Member’s Motion to the House. “Consider this an act of an untamed elephant. I haven’t spoken to the LGBTQ community nor have I spoken to any foreign mission in Sri Lanka. I only did my part, as a lawmaker, to ensure the rights of citizens of my country,” he added. “Minister Ali Sabry has assured that the Government will support the motion. Minister Prasanna Ranatunga has also communicated to me that the ruling party will back the Bill. So, I am hopeful that the motion will secure a majority in Parliament. However, it is now with the Attorney General’s Department and those who are aware of the system know that getting a document out of the AG’s Department is no easy task. Also, getting a Private Member’s Bill passed in Parliament is also a time-consuming process. But, with your support, I am confident that we will be able to get this done,” Dolawatte said. MP Mayantha Dissanayake from the Samagi Jana Balawegaya said he was in favour of the Private Member’s Bill presented by Dolawatte. “We are a progressive party and we understand the need for change. I briefly spoke to our Party Leader, Sajith Premadasa, and shared my views on this matter with him. We haven’t made a formal policy statement on this yet, but we are in favour of this because we want to do the right thing by the country.” “When this is presented to Parliament, there will be stiff resistance from many quarters. That’s something we must expect. But I, as a Parliamentarian and a person who values human rights, will champion this cause within my party and within our parliamentary group. There are many countries in the world that have made progressive steps in this regard and we must follow those examples,” Dissanayake added. “Addressing the concerns of religious circles will be a critically important step and I am confident that we will be able to convince them by directly engaging with the right information. For instance, this is perfectly in line with the fundamental teachings of Buddhism such as compassion and that should be the basis of our engagement with Buddhist monks,” the MP said. “We inherited a country that needed change. We must now deliver,” Dissanayake said, adding that his traditional upbringing in Kandy would not deter him from supporting this cause. Joining the discussion, Freedom People’s Congress MP Prof. Charitha Herath said they will support decriminalisation of same-sex relations, if and when the Bill is presented to Parliament. “We must engage with two domains to achieve the desired results. One is the political domain and the other is the cultural domain. We can change old-fashioned political and cultural establishments through constant engagement,” Herath explained. “The technical approach alone will not usher in meaningful change. That is why I highlight the importance of cultural discussions as well to overcome the existing barriers. Sometimes, I feel that these cultural platforms are forgotten by the younger generation.” “If you look at this region, India has made significant progress in the recent past while we are lagging behind. We must explore the reasons for this and address them adequately,” the MP added. Minister Jeevan Thondaman, the youngest Cabinet Minister to hold office in Sri Lanka, countered the argument that culture was a barrier in achieving non-discrimination for the LGBTQ community in Sri Lanka. “There is more than enough evidence from ancient history that same-sex relations existed and they were very much embraced many, many centuries ago. There are ancient statues, literary works and many other things to prove this point. So, where did we go wrong?” Thondaman, the Leader of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress (CWC), queried. “The answer is quite clear. It is the colonisation and westernisation of our ancient civilisations. Their beliefs and values became a dominant factor and we lost many of ours.” “Culture has never been a barrier to us. It is the colonial mindset that has become a barrier. It is time we understand the reality,” he added. “I am a member of a minority community and a representative of a marginalised group of people, I request you to take these little victories. It will eventually lead you to the promised land. Ten years ago, a dialogue of this nature would not have been possible. Today, we are trying to sit with you and understand the gravity of this issue,” Thondaman said, pledging support to legislative reforms decriminalising same-sex relations. David Sood, Counsellor, Political and Trade from the Canadian High Commission to Sri Lanka delivered the opening remarks while Bhoomi Harendran and Kaushalya Sendanayaka Arachchi, a representative from Equal Ground shared observations from the civil society perspective.

title: Attention must be paid to mental health of schoolchildren – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe acknowledged that attention paid to mental health in schools was insufficient and that much more needs to be done for those with mental health issues and those who were differently-abled. He said one of the major issues confronting the country was a lack of trained personnel in this field. Wickremesinghe was speaking during a meeting with a youth group to discuss the Government’s Policy Statement and future plans and was responding to a query if Government would provide mental health education, particularly in schools. Shortcomings in the education sector were one of the major topics that were discussed, with the youth group emphasising the need for proper mental health education at school level as well as a proper education mechanism for the inclusion of the differently-abled. The President met a group of young people on 16 February to discuss his Policy Statement and the Government’s plans for the country’s future. During the conversation, they expressed their expectations of the Government and discussed a variety of issues. The youth group also brought up the issue of taxes, adding that while taxes were not a novel concept in many other countries, it was not so in Sri Lanka. The President explained that the Budget could be scrutinised and debated by Parliament to ensure the Government was adhering to it. He said there were many committees to study the Budget, such as the Committee on Public Enterprises, Committee on Public Accounts, and Public Finance Committee. He added the Parliamentary Budget Office Bill to strengthen the process further. They said, “Transparency is a big question with the new taxes. People are feeling it because suddenly they are forced to pay a huge portion of their salary.”  “Transparency is there because in a big Budget we have line items. If you read it, you can never say what it is. It’s in any budget, it’s Parliament that ensures the money is spent wisely, and it takes two to three years. So, Parliament must exercise its powers now. The last time, I think the Opposition didn’t fill their quota of the Chairman posts in oversight committees. So, all that passed by. Even this time around, during selection time, they did not come to Parliament. I think the rest who were present just got some opposition names into it. So, that is where the transparency comes in and nowhere else. You can ask them as to why the money is being spent and other relevant questions,” the President explained. The President also discussed the country’s economic situation and the challenges the Government faces, noting that Sri Lanka was facing an abnormal economic situation and had to restructure debt to get out of it. He added that the Government had to cut down on some expenditure and find money in other areas, such as raising electricity tariffs. The President acknowledged that it is not an easy job, but someone has to do it. “Sri Lanka was in an abnormal economic situation, and we had to get out of it. But to get out of it, we have to restructure debt. To restructure debt we had to cut down expenditure or find money for it. In some areas we have cut down, but in other areas, we have to find the money. Like yesterday we had to raise electricity tariffs because there is a Rs 230 billion loss. So, if you don’t raise it, you won’t have power. We are all paying for past sins. This is how we get out of it fast and this is what we have to do. I don’t think there’s any other way out. It’s not a job, that anyone would like to do, but someone has to do it,” he said. The youth group also raised the issue of individual accountability and suggested that parliamentarians should have some degree of education. The President agreed but noted that it will take some time for this to happen. He explained that many young people either have a Degree or business experience and it is up to the voters to choose the member they want. “Where individual accountability is concerned, MPs have a system where you can give a preference. If you don’t want any of them, you vote for the party and you can choose whom you want. However, it’s a very expensive procedure. So, I want to appoint Committee to look into how we can have a better system of Elections without spending the money we spend on Elections. In a parliamentary election, the bulk of the money is spent by individual candidates, not by the parties.” The youth also asked the President “Why does everyone shout in Parliament? Do you think they shout to avoid responding to questions posed to them?” In response, the President said that it is done to get media attention and was not appropriate. He said he has seen similar behaviour in other countries and that it was not unique to Sri Lanka. “That is bad. Now it’s done to get media attention. There are people when they argue, may shout at each other.  But, not like this, they just keep shouting. It’s setting a bad example to the country. There is a price. When we look at the UK, it is not so. There are times when people cheer but this is just being done. I think we have to bring some control over it,” he added. Overall, the meeting was an opportunity for the President to hear the views of the youth and discuss the Government’s future plans. The youth group expressed their concerns and ideas with the President who responded to questions and comments.

title: Japanese Envoy attends handover ceremony
author: Author not found
Content: Japanese Ambassador Mizukoshi Hideaki attended the handover ceremony of the Night Navigation System of Trincomalee Port on 17 February. Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva and several top officials of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation and Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) participated in the event. The SLPA expects the daily operational capacity at the Trincomalee Port to increase with the commencement of Night Navigation Operations. At present, the Trincomalee Port is being developed to facilitate cement, mineral sand, and fuel imports. The adjoining lands will be utilised for port-related industries. The port, which was incurring losses until recently, has started generating record profits during the past six months. Under the latest development plans, ample opportunities are available in Trincomalee for a wide array of port-related investments, such as tank farms and LNG storage facilities. The SLPA points out the lands in the port’s vicinity could be well-utilised for these purposes. Trincomalee Harbour, a natural deep-water harbour, is considered the fifth largest natural harbour in the world. According to records, the Trincomalee Port was known as ‘Gokanna’ in ancient times. On 2 March 1815, Sri Lanka surrendered to the British, and with the recognition of the Trincomalee Port’s strategic positioning, the British set up a Royal Naval and Air Force base there. After independence in 1948, the Trincomalee Port was nationalised in 1967 and later vested in the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) in 1979. Despite its world-class recognition among industrial and tourist ports, the development and operations of the Trincomalee Port were hampered due to the rapid development of the Colombo Port and the lack of potential to perform night operations. Vessels calling at the port at night had to enter the following day, after anchoring in the outer harbour, which caused interruptions to port operations and its efficiency. The Sri Lankan Government and the Japanese Government entered into an agreement to implement grant aid under the Japanese Non-Project Grant Aid Programme 2017, also known as the Economic and Social Development Programme. As a result, this grant aid of 1 billion Japanese Yen was provided for the Night Navigation Operations Project at the Trincomalee Port, which included a state-of-the-art Vessel Traffic Management System, Radar Equipment, Lighthouse Equipment, 16 Navigation Buoys, two Mooring Buoys, two 400KV Generators, 14 Fire Pumps with machinery, and a Pilot Vessel provided by the Japan International Cooperation System (JICS) with the invaluable assistance of the Government and the People of Japan. The Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) has implemented many programmes to attract more local and foreign investors to the port.

title: 13-year-old killed in motor accident
author: Author not found
Content: A 13-year-old succumbed to injuries following an accident on the A9 Road, Kebithigollewa on Saturday (18). The Police Media Division said a car travelling from Medawachchiya towards Vavuniya crashed into two pedestrians who were crossing the road. The pedestrians were identified as a mother and daughter who were residents of Punewa and the deceased was the 13-year-old daughter. The driver was also admitted to hospital due to an emergency medical complication and is currently receiving treatment under Police protection. Kebithigollewa Police are conducting further investigations into the accident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi
