title: People can use their vote next year – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said, with the economy’s recovery next year, people will be able to use their vote to make the necessary changes in the country and create the future they desire. He pledged to prioritise the country’s economic recovery while ensuring that law and order is maintained to prevent anarchy. The President made a commitment to restore the country’s economy and establish a functioning democratic society before the end of this year.  Speaking at the ‘Imagine’ 32nd Rotary District Conference in Colombo on Saturday (18), the President emphasised the importance of economic recovery and improving citizens’ quality of life.  He affirmed that all government decisions would be based on these priorities. In his address, President noted that democracy depends on the maintenance of public order which requires law and order.  He underscored that without these essential components, democracy would be replaced by anarchy.  He assured the audience that he would do his utmost to prevent such a scenario from occurring. The President lauded the Rotary District 3220 for its invaluable assistance during past crises, such as the anti-polio campaign, tsunami, and medicine shortages.

title: Guard of honour for Major General Chandrasiri
author: Author not found
Content: General Officer Commanding (GOC) of 24 Infantry Division Wipula Chandrasiri who was promoted Major General with effect from 4th February 2023 was accorded a ceremonial guard of honour at the Malwatte Parade Grounds of  the Sri Lanka Army on Tuesday. Here, Major General Chandrasiri inspecting the guard of honour. Pic by M. A. P. Deen – Ampara

title: COMPETENT AUTHORITY TO MANAGE BUDDHIST AND PALI UNIVERSITY – PRESIDENT
author: Author not found
Content: A competent authority will be appointed and necessary rules will also be introduced to maintain discipline and order in the Buddhist and Pali University as proposed by Nayake Theras of Maha Sangha, President Ranil Wickremesinghe assured yesterday (19) when he met the Karaka Sangha Sabha (Sangha Committee) of Malwathu and Asgiri Chapters. He also said steps will be taken to upgrade the Buddhist and Pali University to an International Buddhist Studies Centre. President Wickremesinghe held a special discussion with the Ven. Nayake Theras of the Sangha Committee of the Malwathu and Asgiri Chapters at the President’s House in Kandy. The President emphasised that the proposal made by the Ven. Nayake Theras of the Malwathu-Asgiri Sangha Committee on the need to revamp Pirivena education will be implemented. The President accepted the invitation of the Ven. Nayake Theras of the Malwathu-Asgiri Sangha Committee to hold the 2023 Vesak Festival with State patronage to promote Buddhist revival.

title: Protest in front of Galle District Secretariat
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held in front of the Galle District Secretariat against the postponement of Local Government Elections and the electricity tariff hike, on 18 December. Protesters demanded that the Government immediately reduce the electricity tariff and hold Local Government Elections.

title: 3 suspects apprehended, lorry with cattle seized
author: Author not found
Content: In a raid, Habaraduwa Police said three suspects were apprehended on 18 December in Unawatuna, while a lorry transporting five buffalo and two cattle without a licence was seized. According to investigations, the buffalo and cattle were being transported from Agunukolapalassa to Beruwala. The raid was carried out on information received by the Police. When the Police attempted to halt the lorry, the driver made a U-turn and continued driving regardless of the Police call to halt. The Police then gave chase and eventually stopped the lorry. The three suspects then jumped into the sea. Later Police made a sea search and apprehended them. The suspects are Beruwala and Aluthgama residents. Police believe the suspect was stealing the cattle and taking them for slaughter. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: 35 youth arrested with drugs in Sri Pada
author: Author not found
Content: Hatton Police said 35 youth who visited Sri Pada (Adam’s Peak) with various drugs in their possession were arrested on 17 and 18 February. Further, the Hatton Police OIC said, 12 youths were arrested during checks at roadblocks with the assistance of Police sniffer dogs. The others were arrested based on Police investigations. According to the OIC, this is a unique case, as all suspects are between the ages of 18 and 25. Preliminary investigations showed these youths were part of tour groups who came to pay homage to Sri Pada (Adam’s Peak) with their parents, friends, and residents of their area. He urged parents to exercise caution when sending children on such trips with various individuals. By C.D.H. Hewage – Watawala

title: Petrol 95 earns highest profit
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) reported that its fuel cost breakdown as of 18 February 2023,  Petrol 95 earned the highest profit of Rs109.44. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera revealed that Rs 16.21 was earned per litre of Petrol 92, while a profit of Rs 3.25 was earned for Auto Diesel. As for Super Diesel, for every litre of 95 Octane petrol a profit of Rs 109.44 was made. Minister Wijesekera said on the other hand, a loss of Rs 21.49 has been incurred per litre of Kerosene.

title: Beach clean-up endeavour!
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to prevent ocean hazard and pollution caused by the irresponsible attitude of the public in throwing waste plastic items into the sea, Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka launched a mass plastic waste collection under the Plastic-Free Ocean Project in Pottuvil Point beach, where nearly 1000kg of plastic bags waste was collected. UK based Cefas , Coast Conservation Department,  Pottuvil, Kottukal Fisheries Society , Pottuvil Youth  Federation and Dream Garden Hotel Guests  under the guidance of the UK,  Dr David Sivyer – Marine Senior Scientist, Dr Peter Randall -Fisheries Scientist and Charlotte Reeve – Marine Scientist participated in the evdeavour.  The project was coordinated by by Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka President A Muzzamil and Secretary H.M. Imam. Foreign tourists also joined the beach clean-up endeavour. Pic by M. A. P. Deen – Ampara

title: CEB Assures 24/7 Power Supply
author: Author not found
Content: With a 66 per cent increase in the electricity tariff, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) assured a 24/7 power supply across the country, cancelling the power cuts imposed over a year ago in January 2022. The electricity tariff increase was announced after the PUCSL informed the CEB on 15 February evening that they approved the hike, without its Chairman Janaka Ratnayake. Addressing the special media briefing yesterday (16), Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said the entire country will receive uninterrupted power starting 16 February as the massive tariff hike made it possible now. He noted that with the approval of the electricity tariff revision, an additional loan of Rs 22 billion from the Bank of Ceylon (BoC) has granted to purchase coal. He also said the People’s Bank has informed that a loan of Rs 50 billion is possible. “It would have been easier for us if the proposal we made in January 2023, had been implemented in January itself. We can ensure a continuous supply of electricity from today (16). Also, we will receive the necessary funds through banks to import coal, fuel, and naphtha,” he said. Denying reports that the tariff increase was done to cover the CEB’s earlier losses, Minister said that was not the purpose of current tariff revision. “This is a difficult decision to make. The tariff increase was not intended to cover the CEB’s long-standing losses, but rather to manage ongoing costs. This tariff increase is cost-reflective. We had one condition in order to obtain that facility from the IMF. From 1 January, money from the Treasury or the Central Bank will no longer be given to State-run institutions like the CEB, Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC), and SriLankan Airlines,” he said. In addition, he highlighted that in previous years, CEB did not have enough money to run, but the Treasury assisted it by providing funds. “I do not believe that there will be another increase in the electricity tariff in the near future. By implementing this system, our Government hopes that the electricity supply will be maintained and that the burden will be reduced and the people’s electricity bill will be reduced through the next electricity tariff revision. The President advised us not only to ensure continuous electricity supply, but also to develop a suitable programme for these low-income families,” he said. In terms of assisting low-income families, he pointed out that the Ministries of Finance and Power and Energy will collaborate on a project for low-income people who use less electricity in the future. “It cannot be completed quickly. We will need some time. In addition, the President advised the implementation of a USD 100 Million credit line aimed at government-run educational institutions and all religious shrines. We will implement it within the next three months,” he said. The monthly electricity tariff of Rs 214 has been increased to Rs 753 for customers who consume up to 30 units of electricity per month. The monthly fixed charge for the lowest electricity tariff tier for up to 30 electricity units comprising nearly 1.45 million consumers has been increased to Rs 400 as part of that increase. The electricity tariff of Rs 677, which was between 31 and 60 units, has been increased to Rs 2,178, and the fixed charge is Rs 550. The electricity tariff of Rs 1,625, which was for between 61 and 90 units, has been increased to Rs 3,970, and the fixed tariff is Rs 650. There are 1.55 million consumers using between 31 and 60 units and 1.4 million between 61 and 90. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Apeksha Hospital pharmacist remanded over bribery
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, yesterday (16) remanded, till 28 February, a pharmacist attached to the Apeksha Hospital in Maharagama, who was arrested for taking a bribe of Rs 22,000 to provide 600 mg of carboplatin, to a patient with ovarian cancer. The suspect was identified as a resident of Ambagahapura in Maharagama. The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), told the Court that when the complainant had inquired from an individual, whether the drug in question could be supplied to him, he had referred him to the suspect. Later the complainant had rung the suspect and the latter had told him, that he could supply him the medicinal item, but for the aforementioned sum, the CIABOC said. The prosecution stated that the complainant, had mentioned that as he had become suspicious of the suspect, demanding a hefty sum to provide the drug, when it is given free of charge by the hospital, he had lodged a complaint with the Bribery Commission, on 15 February. The Bribery Commission officers informed Chief Magistrate Alwis, that they had launched a probe into the incident and that they had managed to apprehend the suspect, when he was about to receive the bribe from the complainant, adjacent to an International School situated close to the hospital. The commission added that the probe into the incident had also revealed that the stock of medicine in question, had been received by the hospital concerned, as a donation and in certain items, the Government seal was yet in place. The Counsel appearing for the suspect told the Court, that his client, despite working as a pharmacist at the Cancer Hospital, had also managed a private pharmacy. He explained that the medicinal stock, in question belonged to his client’s pharmacy and maintained that it did not belong to any State Hospital. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Police say unaware of drug raid
author: Author not found
Content: The two soldiers, attached to the Intelligence Unit of the Sri Lanka Army, who were arrested for fatally shooting a woman in the Borella area in the night of 13 February, did not have any connection with a Police operation and the Police were not informed about their activity, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said. Speaking to Ceylon Today, SSP Thalduwa said, an investigation has been launched as to why those two soldiers engaged in an activity in the area without informing the Police. The two suspects were identified as Lance Corporal Lahiru Kumara of the SL Army Intelligence Corp, a resident of Batapola and soldier Tharindu Kumara They were remaded until 21 February by Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya. The deceased was identified, as 25-year-old Melani Kanchana, a resident of Thalgahakumbura, Borella. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: US delegation meets Defence officials
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation, led by US Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defence (PDASD) for Indo-Pacific Security Affairs Jedidiah P. Royal, paid a courtesy call on the State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon and Defence Secretary Gen. Kamal Gunaratne on separate occasions yesterday (16). The US PDASD, accompanied by Defence Attaché of the US Embassy Lt. Col. Anthony Nelson, on arrival at the State Ministry of Defence in Colombo, was welcomed by State Minister Tennakoon. The brief discussion held, during the occasion, was centred on matters of further strengthening the existing ties between the US and Sri Lanka. Assistant Defence Attaché at the US Embassy Seth Nevins, U.S. South Asia Desk Officer Lt. Col. Christian Mitchell and Sri Lankan Defence Ministry Senior Assistant Secretary (Defence) Harsha Withanarachchi were also present. The US delegation also visited the Defence Headquarters Complex in Sri Jayewardenepura, Kotte and met Secretary of the Ministry of Defence Gen. Kamal Gunaratne. The Defence Ministry Secretary held discussion with Royal and the mutually supportive relations existed between the two countries was recalled. Further, during the exchange of views, the two high officials also discussed the matters of defence cooperation enhancement and regional security stability. Military Liaison Officer (MLO) of the Ministry of Defence Maj. Gen. Dinesh Nanayakkara, Assistant Defence Attaché in the US Embassy Seth Nevins and US South Asia Desk Officer Lt. Col. Christian Mitchell were also present. Royal also met US Envoy to Sri Lanka Julie Chung. As Sri Lanka has grown in importance as a strategic partner in the Indo-Pacific region, the 20-member US delegation arrived on 15 February ight and left the country within a few hours. The US Envoy tweeted yesterday (16) welcoming him to Sri Lanka and stated that she and Jed Royal had discussed how the US is working with Sri Lanka on shared goals such as promoting Sri Lanka’s sovereignty and maritime security, enhancing regional stability, and promoting a free and open Indo-Pacific. The US delegation were said to have arrived in Sri Lanka during their participation at the air show in India. Aero India is Asia’s largest aviation event and hosts government delegations and corporate executives from 26 countries. It’s the first time the US military displayed its combat air power over the Air Force Station in Bangalore, India. It ends today (17). Royal is a career member of the Senior Executive Service. He oversees IPSA’s extensive portfolio – spanning China, Taiwan and Mongolia, East Asia, South and South East Asia, and Afghanistan, Pakistan and Central Asia – and works across the national security enterprise to synchronise IPSA activities with foreign policy objectives. While in India, he said that the US and India partnership created tens of thousands of jobs in India and enabled critical transfers of technology and manufacturing expertise to India. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sabaragamuwa Uni closed indefinitely
author: Author not found
Content: Following a clash between two student groups, academic activities of University of Sabaragamuwa were suspended indefinitely except, for the students of 2020/2021 group. The students were requested to vacate the university premises and hostels before 4.00 p.m. yesterday (16). A total of nine students of the Faculty of Management of the University were hospitalised following an altercation between two student groups. The Police Media Division said that the quarrel between the two groups of students had occurred on Wednesday (15). The injured students were admitted to the Balangoda Hospital. Samanalawewa Police are conducting investigations to arrest those responsible for the attack.   Meanwhile, some students of Sri Jayewardenepura University had also been in an altercation during a party held inside the university premises in light of Valentine’s Day. Police said the altercation occurred between the students of the Management Faculty and Arts Faculty on Wednesday (15). Mirihana Police had gone to the University on a call made to 119 Emergency Line and they had sorted out the issue. However, later that night, the two groups had got into another fight in front of the Arts faculty. The students had used rocks, glass bottles, iron rods and other sticks during the fight. Following the quarrel one student was admitted to the Kalubowila Teaching Hospital with injuries while several other students were discharged after treatment. Police added that the faculty gate and glass windows of buildings were damaged owing to the altercation. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: PUCSL Chair to seek legal advice on tariff hike
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka  (PUCSL), Janaka Ratnayake, will seek a Court Order to investigate the legitimacy of the electricity tariff hike that was approved by the PUCSL on 15 February, when he was not present. He said he left for Australia on 12 February, while the Director General of PUCSL, left for the United States after appointing an Acting Director General. However, addressing the media, yesterday (16), from Australia, Ratnayake claimed that other commission members have approved the proposal of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) brought forward to increase the electricity tariff by 66 per cent, without him or the Director General. He noted that the other officials were summoned to the Presidential Secretariat on the evening of 15 February and asked to sign the proposal for an increase in electricity tariffs. However, Ratnayake said he will seek legal advice on whether this decision is legal, and that if it is not, he will continue to fight for justice on behalf of the public. On 15 February, Ratnayake informed the General Manager of CEB, in writing that the majority of the Commission Members had rejected the proposal of the Commission and therefore the tariff revision proposed by the Commission cannot be implemented. But, again on 15 February 2023, Acting Director General of PUCSL, in writing and signed, had forwarded the recommendation of the majority decision of the commission to implement the CEB proposal. However, the document was signed by the Acting Director General, members of the commission Chaturika Wijesinghe, Douglas N. Nanayakkara and S.G. Senarathna. They have signed the document where it has mentioned that the tariff proposal submitted via the said letter is hereby approved with effect from 15 February 2023 and CEB and LECO are required to publish the same in national newspapers. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: PUCSL Chair’s office sealed on Court Order
author: Author not found
Content: The office of PUCSL Chairman, Janaka Ratnayake, was sealed by the Kollupitiya Police on a Court Order, issued by the Fort Magistrate. Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (16) ordered the Kollupitiya Police, to temporarily seal off the office, based on submissions made by Kollupitiya Police, until the PUCSL Chairman who is in Australia at the moment, returns to the country. Accordingly, Kollupitiya Police had received a complaint alleging that a group of people from Colombo 3 were planning to break in and destroy important documents in the office.  Meanwhile, addressing the media from Australia, Ratnayake claimed the direction to seal his office was given by a specific politician present at the meeting to approve recent electricity tariff hike, held at Presidential Secretariat on 15 February. “I am grateful that the decision was made. We never know who is attempting to frame me by tampering important items/documents in the room or misplacing important items. Protection is required right now. I am ready to open the office and allow the Police to conduct their investigation,” he said. He thanked the Kollupitiya Police for enforcing the Court order issued by the Fort Magistrate. The reason for sealing his office was to demonstrate that a third party was attempting to destroy or misplace important documents in the office, so the office was sealed, he claimed. “I’m glad about this because everything in the office is State property except for my table and chair. The Police are protecting the office and waiting for me to arrive to open it,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek and Hansi Nanayakkara

title: TISL files FR Petition over procurement of medical supplies
author: Author not found
Content: Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) filed a Fundamental Rights Petition (SC/FR 65/2023) yesterday (16) in the Supreme Court, naming 47 Respondents, in relation to the steps taken by the Cabinet of Ministers, the Minister of Health, the Ministry of Health, and the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) to procure medical supplies from two Indian private companies. This case was filed in the public interest and challenges the role of the Cabinet of Ministers in procuring medical supplies through unregistered private suppliers, the role of the NMRA in providing a Waiver of Registration to procure medical supplies from unregistered suppliers, non-compliance with procurement guidelines, including the emergency procurement process and abuse of process by the Minister of Health and the Chief Executive Officer of the NMRA. In its petition, TISL alleges that the citizens’ fundamental right to equality (Article 12(1)) and the right of access to information (Article 14A) have been violated, along with serious disregard for the health, safety and wellbeing of the people and in total abuse of public trust and public funds. TISL seeks further information on these transactions. The petition seeks interim orders against the procurement based on this unsolicited proposal and the placing of any orders, approvals for Waiver of Registration of 38 drugs, importation of said drugs into Sri Lanka and making payment for such drugs The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), the Director-General of Customs, the Inspector-General of Police, Savorite Pharmaceuticals (Pvt) Limited, Kausikh Therapeutics (P) Limited and the Attorney-General are also named as Respondents in this petition.

title: HRCSL on three-day official visit to North
author: Author not found
Content: Chairperson of Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) retired Supreme Court Judge Rohini Marasinghe and several officials from her office left for Jaffna, on a three-day official visit yesterday (16), to assess the ground situation of human rights in the Northern Province and is scheduled to meet the heads of the families of the missing persons associations. She will be in Jaffna until 18 February and will be holding meetings with the Police, religious leaders and all the other law enforcement authorities to bring awareness on human rights as well as the current issues related to HR violations taking place in the North.  She is currently holding meetings at Jetwing Hotel in Jaffna, where human rights defenders are also participating in the meetings.  Jaffna HRCSL Head T. Kanagarajah said the HRCSL team will visit various places to check on the work related to human rights, the current situation in the North and will be meeting people to inquire about their grievances. (SRM) By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SC fixes date for support of Rahman’s LG Petition
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights petition filed by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Member of Parliament Mujibur Rahman, against the Cabinet Decision to not accept deposits for the Local Government (LG) Election, was fixed for support on 23 February by the Supreme Court yesterday (16). This was when the Petition was taken before Supreme Court Justices Murdu Fernando, Priyantha Jayawardena and Achala Wengappuli. Rahman, who is contesting for the Colombo Municipal Council, at the upcoming LG Election, filed the Petition against the directions given by the Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Neel Hapuhinna, based on a Cabinet decision to not to accept deposits from the LG Election candidates. Hapuhinna issued a letter, on 10 January, to the District Secretaries (DSs), ordering them not to accept deposits from candidates. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Italy lauds SL’s economic recovery
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion was held on Tuesday (14), between State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe, who is on an official visit to the Republic of Italy, and Edmondo Cirielli, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Italy.  Sirielli said the Republic of Italy appreciates the steps taken by Sri Lanka to revive and strengthen its economy. Much attention was paid to expediting bilateral MoUs necessary to implement the ‘Migrant-Worker Plan’ aimed at securing employment opportunities in the Italian Republic for the people of Sri Lanka. Pointing out that the tourism sector primarily contributes to the economic stability of the country, the State Minister requested the Italian Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs to provide support in attracting more Italian tourists to Sri Lanka. The Italian Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs said the Republic of Italy will support the tourism sector too.

title: Cabraal grounded till 6 April
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawela, yesterday (16) extended till 6 April, the overseas travel ban on former Central Bank Governor Ajith Nivard Cabraal. The former CBSL Governor has been charged with causing a CBSL Treasury Bonds scam, to the tune of USD 500 million. When the case was convened, the Additional Magistrate informed that his decision on whether there was legal recourse or not to further sustain the case, will be delivered on the said date. The defence lawyers had previously raised initial objections in Court, stating that there was no legal authority, to further maintain the private plaint filed against their client, by former Governor of the Southern Province and civil activist Rajith Keerthi Tennakoon. Tennakoon, in his private plaint has charged that Cabraal, had flouted Provisions contained in Sections 386, 388 and 392 of the Penal Code, as well as the Provisions contained in Section 56 (1) of the Registered Stock and Securities Ordinance Act No. 7 of 1937, via his actions. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: CEB fails to provide 36,000 connections
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) has failed to provide 36,000 service connections and 1,200 bulk supply connections across the island, due to a lack of funds to purchase transformers, wires, and meters and to open Letters of Credit. General Manager Engineer Rohan Seneviratne said during previous breakdowns, the CEB had failed to attend to them and they had to go to check the breakdowns after purchasing fuel with their own money. He also said many industries had requested bulk supplies. If those requests were not met, the country would suffer a significant loss, he added. “We went through a rough time. However, with the new electricity tariff increase, we hope that everything will be resolved. We are hoping to improve the service quality. I guarantee to provide service connections within a month. We have a new programme that we will launch right away,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Fmr CAASL Chair assumes duties as Hilton Hotel Chair
author: Author not found
Content: Former Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka (CAASL), Upul Dharmadasa, assumed duties as the new Chairman of Hotel Developers (Lanka) PLC, which operates the Hilton Hotel, Colombo. Speaking at the event, he stated that Sri Lanka has many ways to boost tourism and create innovative activities to entice visitors to spend more time in the country. He stated that Hilton Colombo is superior to many other Hilton hotels around the world, and that some visitors still remember some of the workers’ names for the excellent service they received. He also made a point of introducing wine tasting, golf, and musical shows, collaborating with many stakeholders, to promote nightlife. He stated that tourists do not often come to Sri Lanka for casinos because they have plenty in their own countries, so new products that would suit Sri Lanka must be developed. Dharmadasa, a student of the Ceylon Hotel School specialising in F&B, is currently sitting for a MBA (UK). Following his migration to USA with the Air Ceylon experience, he excelled in the travel industry in Los Angeles through the well-known name brand in the USA under Upul’s Travel Service, by servicing the approximately 750,000 Sri Lankans living in the USA and 400,000 in Canada. Advancing along with the technology he developed Utravel.com in 2017, based in Los Angles and it is now available and operated around the world as a Global Travel booking engine. He is also a former member of the hospitality sector of Sri Lanka and served at Hotel Intercontinental, Holiday Inn, and Oberoi, and was Head of the Food and Beverages on board Lanka Kalyani, the cadet training ship of the Ceylon Shipping Corporation, before migrating to the United States to join his wife, Barbara. He is a former employee of the Air Ceylon which was the National Carrier of Sri Lanka. There, he completed Nutrition and Food Service Professional Training at the University of North Dakota, USA and worked as an in-house hospital dietician before starting his Upul’s Travel Service. He is among the 5% of the travel professionals in the USA who bears the designation of CTC (Certified Travel Counsellor) the programme offered by the Institute of Certified Travel Agents in Wellsley, Massachusetts for travel professionals those who completed the comprehensive travel programme. After several decades, Dharmadasa  returned home in 2020 to take over the position at Chairman of the CAASL, where he was notably empathetic towards the staff needs at all levels and was often seen at their weddings, funerals, and other social functions, and the entire staff became one family, pulling the tug towards one direction. His concern extended to the staff at all levels, including the minor staff of Abans Company who carried out the janitorial services, he was considered to be the silent contributor to the organisation’s success, further Dharmadasa thanked the previous board of CAASL for their audacious contribution to the aviation industry and being empathetic to employee grievances. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Need to streamline construction sector’s financial operations
author: Author not found
Content: There is a need for a clear agreement on payment timelines to help streamline the construction sector’s financial operations, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake said. He made this remark during the Construction Industry Revitalisation Committee meeting convened at the President’s Office on Wednesday (15). The committee aims to identify and address the issues facing the construction industry in Sri Lanka in light of the current economic crisis. During the meeting, Ratnayake emphasised the need to systematically address the problems facing the construction industry and to revive it. To this end, it was proposed to establish an executive committee under the Construction Revival Committee, composed of representatives from the Office of the President, Ministry of Finance, Urban Development Authority, Sri Lanka Institute of Development Administration (SLIDA), Department of Irrigation, Water Supply and Drainage Board, Ministry of Transport and Highways, as well as stakeholders from the private sector. The committee discussed various problems affecting the industry, such as high bank interest rates, import restrictions and customs duties, and payment mechanisms for government projects. In particular, Ratnayake highlighted the need for a clear agreement on payment timelines to help streamline the construction sector’s financial operations. Representatives from the private sector in the construction industry also presented their concerns, and heads of relevant line agencies attended the meeting. Overall, the Construction Industry Revitalisation Committee’s efforts are a positive step towards addressing the issues facing the construction industry in Sri Lanka and reviving it during this economic crisis.

title: Several top cops transferred
author: Author not found
Content: Several senior Police personnel have been transferred on a directive of the Public Security Ministry Secretary. The transferred took place due to the exigencies of service. The Police Media Division yesterday (16), stated that the Inspector General of Police (IGP) ordered the immediate implementation of the transfers, subject to the approval of the National Police Commission. Accordingly, DIG K.P. Karunanayake was transferred from the position of DIG-in-Charge of Community Police and Environmental Protection to DIG-in-Charge of the Western Province (Traffic) and DIG D.R. Wijesinghe was transferred from DIG-in-Charge of the Western Province (Traffic) to DIG-in-Charge of the Galle District. Additionally, Acting DIG L.A.U. Sarath Kumara was transferred from DIG-in-Charge of the Batticaloa District to DIG-in-Charge of Western Province (Crime) and Acting DIG W.K.J.R. Dias was transferred from the position of DIG-in-Charge of Western Province (Crime) to DIG-in-Charge of Community Police and Environmental Protection. Meanwhile, Acting DIG L.A.U.N.P. Liyanage was transferred from the position of DIG-in-Charge of the Galle District to DIG-in-Charge of the Batticaloa District. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: France ready to assist Sri Lanka in debt restructuring – Pactet
author: Author not found
Content: France stands ready to assist Sri Lanka in its efforts to restructure its debt, assured French Ambassador Jean-François Pactet at a recent meeting with the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce’s Sri Lanka-France Business Council. The meeting was attended by Ambassador Designate of Sri Lanka to France Manisha Gunasekera, members of the French business community, as well as Sri Lankan partners of French companies. Ambassador Pactet assured the gathering of France’s support in Sri Lanka’s economic recovery efforts, highlighting France’s contribution to sectors such as water, energy, urban development, agriculture, and renewable energy, as well as the contributions French companies can make to the Sri Lankan economy in sectors such as logistics, digital technologies and health. SLFBC President Ashiq Lafir briefed the Ambassador on the Council’s mission and initiatives in promotion of bilateral trade and investment between France and Sri Lanka. During a roundtable discussion, the SLFBC discussed the potential for further developing business linkages and addressed the challenges to bilateral trade and investment in the present economic context, as well as the role the private sector can play in overcoming these challenges. (SRM)

title: Forex crisis has impacted Ayurveda Medicine
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s ongoing forex crisis has also negatively impacted the Ayurveda medicine system, North Western Provincial Ayurveda Commissioner S.M.A.R. Seneviratne said. Seneviratne said, prices of several ingredients used to manufacture indigenous medicines had spiked in recent times. According to Seneviratne, the State Pharmaceuticals Corporation (CPC) is continuing to bring down indigenous medicinal items through tenders, while certain products are imported from India, China and a few other Asian countries. By J. Ekanayake – Yakwila

title: Potato lands not for any other use – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera advised officials of the Ministry not to use potato cultivation lands to cultivate other crops or for construction purposes.  There are only a few limited areas of land dedicated to potato cultivation in the country, including those in Welimada, Nuwara Eliya and Jaffna, Amaraweera said adding that there is a higher demand for local potato than the imported variety. Amaraweera noted the country’s annual potato requirement is 230,000 MT ,adding that 154,000 MT of potatoes will have to be imported in 2023. He added if other crops are cultivated on these lands, there is a possibility of diseases spreading. (FT)

title: Astrological workshop on 12 March
author: Author not found
Content: An Astrological workshop and certificate awarding ceremony, organised by Astrological and Ayurvedic Council of Gampaha in collaboration with Sripalee Astrological Service Kandy, will be held on 12 March at Hotel Grand, Janiru  Naiwala Gampaha.  The Key note lecture will be delivered by Prof. Hariharan Krishnamurthi, son of the Late Prof. K.N. Krishanamurthi. More inquiries of the event can be obtained through +940713448369 or [email protected].

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Canteens to increase prices by 10%
author: Author not found
Content: All Island Canteen Owners’ Association (AICOA) has decided to increase the prices of fried rice, kottu, and a packet of rice and curry by 10 per cent, based on the massive electricity tariff hike, which came in to effect since yesterday (16). Addressing the media, AICOA Chairman Asela Sampath emphasised that they are forced to increase prices of the food items by the actions of the newly appointed PUCSL officials and the CEB. “We refused to increase the prices of food times last time when the electricity tariff hike took place. We were sensible towards the consumer’s situation and the prices of a few essential goods, such as wheat flour, were reduced at that time,” he added. He emphasised that the CEB is trying to scam the public through the recent electricity tariff hike to spend the money on white elephant projects. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Dougy urges Police to probe attacks on Indian fishers
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said there are several media reports on Indian fishermen being attacked in Sri Lanka, when they encroached. He urged the Police to conduct an inquiry and submit a report on it to him.  The Minister said no one should resort to violence and urged the Police to find the truth behind these claims. Devananda, who has paid attention to the news, published in some media, that an attack has been carried out on Indian fishermen, urged the people not to resort to violence under any circumstances and said the issue should be handled in such a way that the ties with India are not affected.  The minister has taken various efforts to control the activities of Indian fishermen, who are illegally fishing in Sri Lankan waters, but they have been ineffective. He has even met the Indian Foreign Minister S. Jeishankar and other Tamil Nadu politicians who came to the Northern Province recently. Indian Minister L. Murugan, Bharatiya Janata Party’s Tamil Nadu State President K. Annamalai have  also made  statements regarding the fishermen issue and assured that they have plans to meet many other high-level leaders of New Delhi and Tamil Nadu soon. By T. Pratheepan- Jaffna

title: Agri Ministry gives Rs 30M as compensation
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Agriculture has provided Rs 30 million as compensation to farmers whose cattle and goats perished in the Northern and Eastern Provinces due to the extreme cold weather in December 2022. In the first week of December 2022, a large number of cattle and goats perished in many areas of the Northern and Eastern Provinces due to the extreme cold weather conditions caused by Cyclone Mandous in the Bay of Bengal.  The cheques for compensation was handed over by the Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera, to the Additional Secretary of the Livestock Division, Dr. L. W. N.  Samaranayake. While Rs18 million has been allocated to the Northern Province, Rs 11.9 million has been allocated for the Eastern Province. Over 514 cattle, 630 calves, 305 goats and 144 kids died in the Northern Province due to the cold weather. Further, 423 cows, 299 calves, 65 goats and 45 kids died in the Eastern Province. (FT)

title: Another accident at Radella shortcut injures three
author: Author not found
Content: Another accident took place on 14 February injuring three individuals on the Radella shortcut route which was closed following the deadly multiple-vehicle crash that killed seven people and injured 53 others. According to Nanu Oya Police, a three-wheeler travelling at high speed from Hawa Eliya, Nuwara Eliya to Talawakelle ran off the road on the Radella shortcut route. The driver and two others were seriously injured and admitted to the District General Hospital Nuwara Eliya on Tuesday (14) night. The shortcut route was reopened to vehicles weighing less than five tonnes after it was closed due to the recent multiple-vehicle crash. The accident occurred on 14 February at 7.30 p.m. The three-wheeler was moving along the Karberg estate, where the bus accident occurred,  when it ran off the road and fell into the drain on the side of the road. Estate workers and the Nanu Oya Police removed the injured from the three-wheeler and took them to hospital. Meanwhile, the three-wheeler was severely damaged. Nanu Oya Police are investigating. BY Neeta PathmaKumari – Norwood

title: SL, India to sign power grid linking pact – Moragoda
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka and India will sign a pact to link their power grids and start negotiations on an upgraded trade agreement within two months, a Sri Lankan diplomat has told Reuters news agency yesterday (15). India has provided USD 4 billion in assistance to its southern neighbour since the crisis hit early last year, but Sri Lanka is now seeking to enhance trade and investments as it moves to close a USD 2.9 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, Sri Lankan High Commissioner in New Delhi, Milinda Moragoda has told Reuters. “We have to have growth, otherwise basically the economy will shrink,” Moragoda has said. “As far as growth is concerned, India offers that prospect. So we will have to move on that. Tourism from India, investment from India, integration with India. That’s what we have to do.” A key part of Sri Lanka’s economic recovery plan rests on developing its renewable energy resources in the island’s north, from where power can be transported into southern India through a cross-border transmission cable. The two countries resumed talks on linking their electricity grids last year, and Moragoda said a memorandum of understanding on the project would be signed within two months, which will be followed by a feasibility study. First proposed more than a decade ago, the project has made little progress so far. But Moragoda said Sri Lanka hoped to get the transmission line in place within two to three years so that renewable power produced on the island can be sold to India. “We need to have more sources of foreign exchange and electricity will be ideal,” he said. The neighbours will also start negotiations within weeks on enhancing an existing free trade agreement, Moragoda said, as part of a push by Sri Lanka to seal deals with key trading partners, including China and Thailand. “On our side, we are just about to nominate the (negotiations) team,” he said, adding that the focus would be on enhancing trade in sectors including textiles and garments, a major foreign exchange earner for Sri Lanka. India is Sri Lanka’s biggest trading partner accounting for about $5 billion each in bilateral trade in 2021.  (Reuters)

title: SLMA goes to HRCSL against Health Ministry for violating rights of patients
author: Author not found
Content: Amidst severe shortage of many essential medicinal drugs, The Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMA) petitioned the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) against the Health Ministry for violating patients’ right to life and their right to healthcare. SLMA Past President, Prof. Indika Karunathilake when contacted yesterday (15) said the Association had also expressed its concerns in the petition with regard to the process of procurement of medicinal drugs. The Council has been warning health authorities on the shortage since early last year. But proper efficient action was not taken. He said the SLMA had noted that monetary assistance had been given through the Indian Credit Line (ICL), the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank. “But we have informed the HRCSL of our worry as to how the money was being utilised,” Prof. Karunathilake said noting that a large number of non-essential medicines had also been given registration by the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) during the current crisis.  The SLMA past president said that the Sri Lankan people had the right to benefit from a health care service provided through transparent, efficient, accountable mechanism. He said the situation should be addressed to ensure the re-establish the provision of essential supply of medicines for the Sri Lankan patient. The SLMA president elect, Dr. Ananda Wijewickreme when contacted said the current shortage of medicines had been predicted by the SLMA last February so that the Health Ministry and authorities had been in possession of adequate time to correct the situation. The government audit has in a report indicated the looming short age of drugs last year and made several recommendations.         Fielding questions as to whether the country would see an end to this prolonged shortage of medicinal drugs, he alleged that the chances were high for manipulation of bad situations so that it was difficult to say regarding the solution to the situation.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Indian visa centre closed until further notice
author: Author not found
Content: A break-in and possible theft are being investigated by the Police at India’s visa application centre, IVS (Pvt) Ltd., located at Philip Gunawardena Mawatha, Colombo 5, according to the Indian High Commission. The Indian High Commission said the incident took place on 15 February and the centre will remain closed until further notice as the investigations are underway. The Indian High Commission said this was due to a security incident at the visa application centre on 15 February. All applicants are requested to reschedule their appointments with IVS (Pvt) Ltd. as soon as possible. The High Commission should be contacted for any urgent consular or visa matters. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: 20 -25 days required to print ballot papers
author: Author not found
Content: At least 20 -25 days were required to complete printing ballot papers for the upcoming Local Government (LG)Election, Government Printer Gangani Liyanage said. Speaking to Ceylon Today, she said for the printing process to run smoothly, the Department of Government Printing must be excluded from the Circular issued by the Finance Ministry prohibiting State institutions to make purchases on credit basis. If that is not the case, then the Election Commission (EC) should provide the funds without any delay and provide security to continue printing of the ballot papers, she said. Meanwhile, Ceylon Today learns that the EC has sent another letter to the Treasury requesting to release funds for the LG Poll. BY J.T. de Silva

title: Air India unveils ‘historic’ orders for 470 jets
author: Author not found
Content: Air India has announced orders for a total of 470 Boeing and Airbus passenger jets as it races to tap surging demand for affordable air travel from the nation’s growing ranks of middle-class consumers. India’s largest international airline and second-largest domestic carrier is buying 220 Boeing aircraft valued at USD 34 billion and 250 passenger jets from European plane manufacturer Airbus. The Boeing purchase is the United States plane maker’s third-largest sale of all time, in dollar value, and its second of all time in quantity. US President Joe Biden called the agreement “historic” and discussed it by telephone with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The call was part of a flurry of high-level reactions as the scale of India’s needs provided a rare bonanza for the competing plane giants in an industry where the winner usually takes all. Air India is seeking to reinvent itself by expanding its operations and modernising its fleet. The new jets will help the airline’s owner, Tata Sons, compete against upstart discount rivals including India’s dominant carrier, IndiGo. “India is going to be the world’s third-largest market in the aviation sector,” Modi said in a videoconference with Tata Sons Chairman Natarajan Chandrasekaran and French President Emmanuel Macron. Over the next 15 years, it is estimated India will need more than 2,000 aircraft and “today’s historic announcement will help in meeting this growing demand,” he said. The Boeing order includes 190 737 Max aircraft, 20 of its 787s and 10 of its 777Xs. The purchase includes customer options for an additional 50 737 MAXs and 20 of its 787s, which would make it 290 aeroplanes for a total of USD 45.9 billion at list price. Toulouse, France-based Airbus will provide Air India with 40 wide-body A350 Airbus aircraft and another 210 narrow-body A320neo planes, Chandrasekaran said in the call. Airbus did not disclose the financial terms of the deal, which could be worth tens of billions of dollars. “Today is a historic moment for India, for Air India and for Airbus,” Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury, who was also on the call, said. The size of the order “demonstrates the appetite for growth in the Indian aviation industry. It’s the fastest growing in the world.” Chandrasekaran said the A350s will be used to “fly all ultra-long distance across the globe.” Single-aisle A320s are typically used on short-haul routes. He said the airline has “significant options” to increase its order. “It is important for the industry because given the recent turbulence in the China market, the alternative growth market is India,” said independent aviation adviser Bertrand Grabowski. “India is also sending a strong political signal that it wants to remain attached to the West at a time when it has appeared ambiguous on Russian sanctions,” said Grabowski, a former banker with extensive experience in international deals. Demand for air travel in India and elsewhere in Asia has boomed over the past decade, fuelled by fast-growing economies that have raised incomes and made travel more affordable for millions of people. “There’s a lot of catch-up to do” for Air India, said Brendan Sobie, a Singapore-based independent aviation analyst. It is competing with newer budget airlines that moved faster to tap demand on domestic services as well as foreign carriers that are formidable competitors on international routes, he added. Tata Sons, India’s oldest and largest conglomerate, regained ownership of the debt-laden national carrier last year. The Tata Group pioneered commercial aviation in India when it launched the airline in 1932. It was taken over by the Government in 1953. Modi and Macron applauded the Airbus deal, with both saying it is a sign of the strengthening “strategic partnership” between their countries. Macron called the deal a “new success” and an opportunity to “develop new areas of cooperation with India.” Tata is integrating Air India with Vistara, which it jointly runs with Singapore Airlines, and with Air Asia India, which it runs with Malaysian discount operator Air Asia. (Al Jazeera)

title: Seven arrested over Bank CDM robbery
author: Author not found
Content: Seven suspects were arrested in connection with the recent robbery of a Cash Deposit Machine (CDM) from a private Bank in Gampola. Four masked menrobbed the ATM machine with nearly Rs 8 million in cash from a private Bank in Gampola at around 12.40 a.m. on 25 January 2023. Police investigations revealed that among the seven suspects, four are from the same family. Police spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa told the media yesterday (14) that two suspects were arrested from Galaha, two from Puttalam and three from Gampola. He added the suspects had stolen the CDM machine and had taken Rs 7.6 million in cash after which they had discarded the CDM machine in a precipice 200 meters from the location. Police found the CDM machine and they also recovered over Rs 1.8 million in cash, a van, a motorcycle, gold chains, a gold ring, two washing machines, three mobile phones, and a gas cooker which were bought from stolen money.  Police spokesman said the suspects had purchased several more items and are also reported to have settled several debts.  SSP Thalduwa further said that a pistol that had been stolen from the residence of MP Ali Sabry in Puttalam during anti-government protests last year (2022) had also been recovered from the possession of the suspects. Police suspect the group had used the said firearm to carry out the robbery. He said the group had been involved in a similar robbery of a State Bank in Gampola as well as two gold jewellery stores on previous occasions. He added that the Gampola Police is conducting investigations into all incidents involving the suspects.  BY AlokaKasturiarachchi

title: Hospital minor staffers storm Keheliya’s office
author: Author not found
Content: Close to 100 State health service minor employees allegedly barged into the Health Minister’s office and then the Health Secretary’s office calling for the annulment of a circular in which instructions had been issued for the reduction of their overtime payments. Following the incident, sources said yesterday (15) that there had been great concern as to whether the group was about to surround Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella’s office, preventing him from leaving. However, the Health Minister is said to have informed the minor staff that he was unable to assist them as it was all in the hands of the Health Secretary. The group thereafter converged on the Health Secretary’s office. However, Ceylon Today learnt that the meeting ended without an agreement. When contacted, the Sri Lanka Nidahas Saukya Sewaka Sangamaya said they had merely gone to the Ministry to iron out a few issues in regard to the circular issued by the Health Secretary and that they had not surrounded the Health Minister’s or the Health Secretary’s office.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 4 Police officers, OIC sentenced to death
author: Author not found
Content: Four Police officers including an Officer-in-Charge (OIC) were sentenced to death by Hambantota High Court over the death of an individual during a raid on a gambling den in Tissamaharama. The incident took place on 28 June 2005. According to submissions, a group of Police officers attached to the Crimes Division of the Tissamaharama Police carried out the raid during which they had shot and killed an individual. Among the four Police officers sentenced to death, two are serving in the Police. One is attached to the Crimes Unit of the Hungama Police while the other is attached to the State Intelligence Services. One Police officer is not part of the Police at present, while another is reported to have retired from service.

title: Sritharan refuses to show up in Courts
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK) Kilinochchi District MP S. Sritharan said yesterday (15) that he had refused to accept a letter asking him to be present before the Jaffna Magistrate on 20 February as it was written in the Sinhala language. The MP stated that he conveyed his refusal to accept the letter to the Police. Sritharan added that he had informed Police as he was unable to read Sinhala, he was not ready to accept it. He further said he will only accept Court summons if they are in the Tamil Language sent via Registered Post and not sent through the Police. BY Sashikumar – Mullaitivu

title: CA stays Colombo Fort MC proceedings
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (15), issued an order staying the proceedings of the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court against Western Province Senior Deputy Inspector General of Police (SDIG) Deshabandu Tennakoon over alleged criminal breach of trust with regard to Rs 17.8 million recovered from the President’s House on 9 July 2022. This was when the Petition filed by Tennakoon against the summoning by the Fort Magistrate was taken up before Court of Appeal judges Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and R. Gurusinghe to decide on interim orders and notices. The Colombo Fort Magistrate on 26 January summoned Tennakoon to appear before Court on 16 February with regard to criminal breach of trust over Rs 17.8 million recovered from the President’s House on 9 July during anti-Government protests. Tennakoon later filed a Petition challenging such issuance of summons. When the Petition filed by Tennakoon was taken up yesterday (15), Court issued an interim order staying the proceedings of the case and summoning of Tennakoon until the final determination of the Petition. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Badulla doctor caught with 145 narcotic capsules
author: Author not found
Content: A doctor attached to the Badulla Hospital who was arrested with 145 narcotic capsules was remanded until 17 February by the Badulla Magistrate. Police said the doctor was arrested by the Police Special Task Force (STF) on 14 February during a raid conducted on atip-off received by the Passara STF. The suspect is a 43-year-old resident of Badulla. Badulla Police are conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Swiss Envoy calls on Public Security Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Swiss Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Dominik Furgler, called on Public Security Minister Tiran Alles at his Ministry premises last morning, a Ministry media release said. During the discussion, the Swiss Envoy had conveyed to Minister Alles that his Government was willing to provide technical knowhow to further develop the Sri Lanka Police Department and to support measures being taken to conduct training workshops for Police Officers. Furgler had also stressed the importance of safeguarding human rights and setting up a Truth Commission. Alles had observed that the Truth Commission should be devoid of bias.

title: Sorry, No rough paper!
author: Author not found
Content: Incidents were reported in G.C.E. Advance Level (A/L) examination centres, that invigilators have showed hesitancy to provide rough work papers to candidates as a result of the prevailing paper shortage, When asked whether this was happening, Ceylon Teachers Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin said he too was informed of such incidents. He urged  A/L examiners to be sensitive to the needs of candidates during examination duties.  “No matter what type of pressure they get from the authorities because of the paper shortage, examiners should make sure to be sensible towards candidates. They should remember that this is a highly competitive examination that candidates were facing which decides their future,” he added. He said the CTU is looking further in this regard and will take action if such allegations were proved against any individual. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Court orders popular actress to return house to grandmother
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Poornima Paranagama, yesterday (15) ordered popular actress Ruchini Tanasha to hand over a house in Colombo 3, which had been given to her as a gift by her grandmother back to the latter, over her failure to adequately care for the elderly woman. The Judge in her verdict stated that the grandmother had written the house to the plaintiff as part of her lastwill 13 years ago, but stressed that the actress had failed to look after her and said she had  mistreated her. The Court thus determined that the actress’ actions could not be condoned and ordered her to pay compensation to the tune of Rs 5 million and pay a monthly stipend of Rs 30,000 till such time as the property is legally handed over to the defendant. Judge Paranagama said the plaintiff identified as 72- year-old Jayanthi Perera, had proved allegations against her granddaughter beyond reasonable doubt. The case was filed seven years ago and explaining her verdict, the Judge said the accused film actress had forced her grandmother out of the house, under the pretext of repairing the roof and said that since then she had not looked into the wellbeing of the elderly woman. The Judge added that the accused actress testifying said she had not been aware that the plaintiff had been afflicted with a heart ailment and that if she had been notified of it, she would have provided her with prompt medical care and that she had not met her till the plaintiff had filed a case against her. A group of lawyers led by Counsel Iraj de Silva represented the prosecution, while Counsel Niranjan de Silva appeared for the defence. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Planter fired over high handed act
author: Author not found
Content: The planter of the Mathuratta plantation, who harassed a woman for selling vegetables by the roadside in Ragala, Highforest area, was fired on the orders of Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development and General Secretary of Ceylon Workers’ Congress Jeevan Thondaman. The CWC immediately summoned the Mathurata Plantation to address the issue of threatening the woman during a time of severe economic crisis in the country. Over his complaint, the plantation company also offered a written apology to the woman and said they will not repeat it. The woman was harassed to the extent of having to remove the vegetables from where she had set up a temporary shack to sell them. Selling vegetables was her sole means of income to feed her family. The official, who had arrived on his motorcycle, was abusive and threatened her and ordered her to vacate the place.  Minister Thondaman who was opposed to such treatment towards plantation workers, immediately informed the company who accepted the fault and immediatelyfired the officer. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
