title: US suspects three objects it shot down were ‘benign’
author: Author not found
Content: The White House has said there is no indication three flying objects blasted out of the sky over the weekend by the US military are linked to alleged Chinese spying. The objects may be “tied to commercial or research entities and therefore benign”, spokesman John Kirby said. US and Canadian officials have not yet located or recovered any wreckage from the three downed aircraft. Beijing earlier accused the US of “a trigger-happy overreaction”. China has denied one of its balloons, which was destroyed by a US fighter jet earlier this month off South Carolina, was being used for espionage, saying it was merely a weather-monitoring airship that had blown off course. At Tuesday’s daily news conference, Kirby said it will be difficult to determine the purpose or origin of the three other objects that were destroyed over Alaska, Canada and Michigan until the debris is found and analysed. “We haven’t seen any indication or anything that points specifically to the idea that these three objects were part of the PRC’s [People’s Republic of China] spying programme,” the White House National Security Council told reporters, “or that they were definitively involved in external intelligence collection efforts”. (BBC)

title: US to investigate Boeing 777’s mysterious nosedive
author: Author not found
Content: US air safety officials say they will investigate why a Boeing 777 jet unexpectedly lost altitude and nearly plunged into the Pacific Ocean. United Airlines flight 1722 had left Maui on 18 December and was climbing when it suddenly plummeted 1,400ft (425m), reports say. It stabilised at just 775ft in altitude and went on to land safely in San Francisco 27 minutes early. It adds to a number of near misses involving planes this year. The flight was going normally until 71 seconds after take-off from Kahului Airport when it suddenly dropped in elevation, according to Flightradar24, an aviation website. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), which investigates US plane crashes, will produce a report about the incident within three weeks. Passenger Rod Williams told CNN: “There were a number of screams on the plane. Everybody knew that something was out of the ordinary, or at least that this was not normal.” He said it was “sobering” to think they were probably about five seconds away from hitting the water. The flight’s pilots filed an internal safety report after landing, a United Airlines representative told BBC News. They have a combined 25,000 hours of flying experience. An investigation by the airline resulted in additional training for the pilots, which United said was ongoing. (BBC)

title: Sorry, No rough paper!
author: Author not found
Content: Incidents were reported in G.C.E. Advance Level (A/L) examination centres, that invigilators have showed hesitancy to provide rough work papers to candidates as a result of the prevailing paper shortage, When asked whether this was happening, Ceylon Teachers Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin said he too was informed of such incidents. He urged  A/L examiners to be sensitive to the needs of candidates during examination duties.  “No matter what type of pressure they get from the authorities because of the paper shortage, examiners should make sure to be sensible towards candidates. They should remember that this is a highly competitive examination that candidates were facing which decides their future,” he added. He said the CTU is looking further in this regard and will take action if such allegations were proved against any individual. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Court orders popular actress to return house to grandmother
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Poornima Paranagama, yesterday (15) ordered popular actress Ruchini Tanasha to hand over a house in Colombo 3, which had been given to her as a gift by her grandmother back to the latter, over her failure to adequately care for the elderly woman. The Judge in her verdict stated that the grandmother had written the house to the plaintiff as part of her lastwill 13 years ago, but stressed that the actress had failed to look after her and said she had  mistreated her. The Court thus determined that the actress’ actions could not be condoned and ordered her to pay compensation to the tune of Rs 5 million and pay a monthly stipend of Rs 30,000 till such time as the property is legally handed over to the defendant. Judge Paranagama said the plaintiff identified as 72- year-old Jayanthi Perera, had proved allegations against her granddaughter beyond reasonable doubt. The case was filed seven years ago and explaining her verdict, the Judge said the accused film actress had forced her grandmother out of the house, under the pretext of repairing the roof and said that since then she had not looked into the wellbeing of the elderly woman. The Judge added that the accused actress testifying said she had not been aware that the plaintiff had been afflicted with a heart ailment and that if she had been notified of it, she would have provided her with prompt medical care and that she had not met her till the plaintiff had filed a case against her. A group of lawyers led by Counsel Iraj de Silva represented the prosecution, while Counsel Niranjan de Silva appeared for the defence. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Planter fired over high handed act
author: Author not found
Content: The planter of the Mathuratta plantation, who harassed a woman for selling vegetables by the roadside in Ragala, Highforest area, was fired on the orders of Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development and General Secretary of Ceylon Workers’ Congress Jeevan Thondaman. The CWC immediately summoned the Mathurata Plantation to address the issue of threatening the woman during a time of severe economic crisis in the country. Over his complaint, the plantation company also offered a written apology to the woman and said they will not repeat it. The woman was harassed to the extent of having to remove the vegetables from where she had set up a temporary shack to sell them. Selling vegetables was her sole means of income to feed her family. The official, who had arrived on his motorcycle, was abusive and threatened her and ordered her to vacate the place.  Minister Thondaman who was opposed to such treatment towards plantation workers, immediately informed the company who accepted the fault and immediatelyfired the officer. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SABOTAGING ELECTIONS RANIL’S PLOY TO STAY IN POWER – ANURA KUMARA
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake alleged that the Government Printer was influenced by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to halt printing ballot papers for the upcoming Local Government (LG)  Election. He claimed there was enough material at the Department of Government Printing to print ballot papers.  He alleged that President Wickremesinghe was sabotaging the Election to remain in power. Speaking during a media briefing held at JVP headquarters yesterday (15) Dissanayake questioned whether the Government should be allowed to carry out such attempts.  Dissanayake said the President’s loyalties lie only with the 134 SLPP MPs who voted him into power and not with the citizens.

title: Corridors to Colombo to have ‘Park and Ride’ Bus Services – Report
author: Author not found
Content: Five major corridors, vis-à-vis the Galle, Kandy, Negombo, Horana and Low Level Road, used to enter the Capital City of Colombo are to be introduced with ‘Park and Ride’ bus services, a recent Cabinet Sub Committee report said. This Cabinet Sub-Committee Report titled ‘National Energy Potentials, Strategies and the Roadmap for Next Decade-December 2022’  presented to parliament further said that parking facilities have already been established in two corridors. “Furthermore, main provincial cities like Kandy, Galle and Anuradhapura too are to be introduced eventually with ‘Park and Ride’ services,” it added. ‘All public transport media systems should be equipped with GPS, CCTV facilities, etc., so that their movements can be monitored like in other countries,’ the report recommended. The report in this connection also said that the main reason for the public to move away from using public transport is mainly due to unpleasant travelling experience. ‘Overcrowding needs to be eliminated by introducing sufficient numbers of buses along with appropriate time tabling and improving the human relations skills of the bus conductor, introducing an online payment system or an appropriate prepaid card system at least in urban areas to reduce congestion,  it said.  Commuters should also be able to use maps such as ‘Google transit maps’ to plan and connect their travel with major public transport modes, the report further recommended. BY Paneeetha Ameresekere

title: Launch of Chief Magistrate’s Court Law Journal today
author: Author not found
Content: The launch of the Chief Magistrate Court Law Journal, of the Lawyers Association of the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court, is set to be held under the aegis of Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya today (16). The event is also set to be graced by the President of the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, BASL President-elect President’s Counsel Kaushalya Navaratne, President’s Counsels Counsel Lal Alwis, Neville Abeyratne and Nalinda Indatissa, High Court Judges Manjula Thillakaratne and Adithya Patabendige and Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis. The keynote address is due to be delivered by Kalinga Indatissa PC. The Chief Magistrate’s Court Law Journal has been edited by Counsel Chinthaka Fernando. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Hand grenade found in Buttala Hospital premises
author: Author not found
Content: A hand grenade was found on the grounds of the General Hospital-Buttala on 14 February, Buttala Police said. While cleaning the hospital grounds and repairing the fence, a person found the  grenade in a blue bottle. Officers from the Special Task Force, Buttala camp, have made arrangements to defuse the bomb after informing Buttala Police about the incident. Buttala Police are conducting further investigations. BY NandunGunathilaka – Bibile

title: Geetha attends Sanath Gunathilaka’s book launch
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe joined the book launch of ‘Hada Vila Mata Pipi Aravindaya’ written by veteran actor Sanath Gunathilaka at the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute Auditorium on14 February.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Govt fearing Elections, no people’s mandate – Charitha Herath
author: Author not found
Content: MP Dr. Charitha Herath said the Government is acting in a manner that they are terrified to face the Local Government election, knowing that they do not have the people’s mandate. Speaking at a media briefing, the MP said with the Supreme Court’s decision last week, they hoped that the election process would run smoothly. He said they could see the ruling party and the party that the President represents interfering in the election process raising fears among the public in addition to the Government’s fear of facing the oncoming Election. “The people are supporting other parties and this ‘elephant-pohottu’ faction seriously opposes the oncoming Election because it is clear that they do not have the people’s mandate anymore. Anyone can label this Election as not that important as it is only for local government authorities. However, this Election is very important as it is being held at a critical juncture,” he said. Herath said this is a country that sacked a President based on popular opinion two-and-a-half years ago. It was like a referendum and people bear the same opinion to this date, he added. “Politically, there is a distortion related to public opinion in the country at the time. During the Covid-19 threat, we prioritised the lives of people over Elections. But that was a Government that had a public mandate. However, postponing an Election when there is a ‘successor president’ who does not have a mandate is scary,” he said.

title: Hidden hand behind halting of printing ballot papers – Handunnetti
author: Author not found
Content: JVP Politburo member Sunil Handunnetti said all the funds received by the JVP led  Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) to contest the upcoming Local Government election will be made transparent. In response to the question raised by several Government and Opposition MPs recently with regard to funds received by the JJB for the Election, Handunnetti said politicians of the likes of Johnston Fernando who raise concerns on JJB finances should look into his own finances in the first place. Speaking to the media, he added that the JJB as a responsible party will submit all campaign finance-related documents soon to the public. Handunnetti also said that within a JJB Government, they will be making laws to abolish privileges not only for Presidents, but also to former ministers and formers MPs. He said they will pass a Bill in that regard and added that in a JJB government, as a first step, as soon as it is passed they will implement that new Act and remove  privileges and create public governance accountable to the public. “We believe that people representatives should not get any privileges that are not available to the public. It should be abolished by law. We have already entrusted the responsibility of making the laws to our legal committee”, he said. Speaking further Handunnetti requested the Election Commission to make inquiries from the government printer as to what had actually taken place,  because there must be a hidden hand behind the halting of printing ballot papers in the middle of an Election.  “We ask her not to succumb to pressure of some hidden forces and work for the common people. We request the Election Commission to call her and question her on this. We have checked that none of the other printing works of the printing press have been stopped. Halting printing ballot papers is suspicious,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: No Power Cuts from Today?
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Power and Energy has agreed to halt power cuts from today (15), on humanitarian grounds, top Government sources said last night. According to a top official of the Ministry, country’s utility regulator Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) has given its majority consent to the tariff increase proposal put forward by the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB). However, this was with the exception of its Chairman Janaka Ratnayake. Meanwhile, officials of the PUCSL and the CEB informed the National Council earlier yesterday that they failed to reach a consensus on increasing the electricity tariff as they failed to come to a final decision at previously held discussions. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, who chaired the National Council meeting, said a decision is expected today (15), as mentioned in the previous agreement. Officials representing the PUCSL and the CEB informed that they had discussed the matter Monday (13) afternoon. The officers informed the National Council that they could not reach a final decision regarding the matter. Later, PUCSL officials said the commission will meet last afternoon (14) to discuss the matter and take a final decision. The Speaker said when the National Council met earlier the PUCSL informed the it will inform the Council of the final decision regarding increasing the electricity tariff before today (15).  The PUCSL met accordingly, and taken the decision to approve tariff hike on the basis of power cuts be not carried out hereafter.

title: Jaffna MC budget defeated for third time
author: Author not found
Content: The Jaffna Municipal Council (MC) Budget 2023 was defeated for the third time, yesterday (14), by eight votes. The budget was presented by new Mayor Emmanuel Arnold, who was declared Mayor through Gazette Notification recently. A total of 40 members voted with 24 voting against and only 16 for. Tamil Eelam Liberation Organisation (TELO) member and Deputy Mayor, T. Eesan, People’s Liberation Organisation of Tamil Eelam (PLOTE) and SLFP Member S. Santharooban were not present in the house at the time of voting. Former Jaffna Mayor Visvalingam Manivannan resigned when the budget was defeated on a previous occasion. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Cabinet greenlights JICA grants
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved agreements to accept JICA grants for the health service supplies system to ensure uninterrupted essential services and transport facilities. The relevant Cabinet Paper was submitted by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies. Considering the prevailing economic crisis in Sri Lanka, the Japanese Government has agreed to provide Japanese Yen 5 billion as a grant (approximately USD 38 million) under the JICA programme to supply fuel (mainly diesel) to ensure the continuous functioning of essential and emergency health services. (TR)

title: Thief who stole Magistrate’s car arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The man who stole the official vehicle belonging to the Kuliyapitiya Additional District Magistrate, was arrested at Oliyamulla, Wattala yesterday (14), Police said. The magistrate’s car was also taken into Police custody. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa yesterday (13) told the media that investigations commenced after the Magistrate lodged a complaint with the Piliyandala Police. He said the suspect had contacted the Magistrate via a phone call and demanded Rs 500,000 to hand over the car. The suspect was arrested after Police traced his location through the phone call. Although the suspect was identified as a 27-year-old resident of Kelaniya, SSP Thalduwa said that he was living in an apartment in Homagama. Police seized two air rifles and knives during the search of the suspect’s residence in Homagama. Piliyandala Police and the Mount Lavinia Division Crimes Investigations Unit are conducting further investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Health Ministry owes reagent suppliers Rs 20B – AHP
author: Author not found
Content: Laboratory tests required by patients in State hospitals have been put on the line with the Health Ministry owing reagent suppliers over Rs 20 billion, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) said. AHP President, Ravi Kumudesh yesterday (14) lamented that even the full blood count (FBC) tests were in jeopardy as a result of the prevailing situation in State hospital labs. Bills of over 12 months are pending while the Health Ministry has been paying them like pouring drops of water onto a heated pan. The five suppliers have been providing the necessary reagents as and when these minute payments are made. He said, of them, four were for European brands. However, the policies of the Health Ministry and some of the specialists would have to be amended if this situation is to change and patients are to at least have their laboratory tests conducted without being inconvenienced. This dependence on using machine specific reagents and purchasing reagents from those who can quote the lowest price must end. “Just because the reagent cost is low it does not mean that the quality is poor as all reagents available in the market have National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) approval,” he pointed out, adding that only after a validation could assumptions be made of the quality. Kumudesh said at present the lab services were forced to experiment and come up with in-house preparations sans the assistance from the Health Ministry. The AHP President said in 2019 the State Pharmaceuticals Corporation (SPC) expenditure on pharmaceutical purchases had been Rs 36 billion. This was with cancer patients being afforded medicinal drugs to last their lifetime and lenses being given free of cost to cataract patients. In 2022, even without the expenses for the months of November and December the SPC Expenditure shot up to Rs 44 billion.   Kumudesh, lashing out, said the Health Ministry and the Government did not seem to have any plan to resolve the present issue like several other issues which it has allowed to fester.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Fertiliser companies request Rs 17B in dues
author: Author not found
Content: Accordingly, fertiliser companies have to pay Rs 11 billion for providing chemical fertiliser and Rs 6,000 million for providing organic fertiliser. Although Rs 4,000 million was paid as arrears last year, representatives of the respective fertiliser companies said they will have to pay an additional Rs 17 billion. This was disclosed during a discussion held with Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera. Following the discussion, Amaraweera said arrears will be settled based on the funds provided by the Government. The Government has spent Rs 6 billion for the distribution of fertiliser islandwide as per the Government’s fertiliser distribution programme this year. (FT)

title: Government Analyst’s report finds alien DNA
author: Author not found
Content: The CID yesterday informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, that the report compiled by the Government Analyst (GA), related to the death of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Director Dinesh Schaffter, had mentioned that there was alien DNA. The Magistrate, ordered the CID to produce four individuals before the Government Analyst at the earliest, including the security officers at the Borella Cemetery and a Police officer, in order to determine the identity of the DNA samples and whether it matches with any of them. The Magistrate gave this order to the CID, having considered a request made by the latter. The CID stated that the Government Analyst had urged them to produce the aforementioned individuals before him, to test their DNA samples, as they had been identified as the suspects, who had visited the crime scene, at the initial instance after the incident. The CID informed the Court, that they had submitted a water bottle, a zip tie and a wire to the Government Analyst, which had been recovered from the motorcar used by the deceased and noted that the report compiled by the Government Analyst, had been received by them. Later, Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya instructed the Colombo JMO and the Government Analyst to preserve body specimens of the deceased businessman, if any such specimens had been obtained for testing or investigative purposes and not to destroy the body specimens, under any circumstance. This instruction was given to the Colombo JMO and the Government Analyst by the Court, having perused a request made to that effect, by President’s Counsel Anuja Premaratne, appearing on behalf of Schaffter’s family. The Magistrate then ordered the Director of the Colombo National Hospital (CNH), to submit all reports to Court, including the bed number when the deceased was admitted to the Accident Ward, following the incident on 15 December last year. She also ordered the Colombo JMO and the official attached to the SOCO Unit of the Borella Police Station, to submit to Court all photos and video footages at the time of the conduct of the initial post-mortem and the subsequent post-mortem on the deceased businessman. The case was convened via a motion. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Two soldiers remanded over death of woman
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, yesterday ordered two soldiers, attached to the Intelligence Unit of the Sri Lanka Army, who were arrested and produced before her by Borella Police, in connection with a woman being fatally shot in the Borella area on the night of 13 February, to be remanded till 21 February. The two suspects were identified as Lance Corporal Lahiru Kumara of the SL Army Intelligence Corp, a resident of Batapola and soldier Tharindu Kumara. The deceased was identified, as 25-year-old Melani Kanchana, a resident of Thalgahakumbura, Borella. Borella Police told the Magistrate that a witness had provided a statement to them, that a group of people from the shop owned by ‘Kalu Akka’ had gone to play a game called Keta Gaesima. Police said that as per the statement given by the witness, at that moment two individuals in civvies, had had assaulted a person who was playing and that while being assaulted, when asked who they were, they had stated that they were from the ‘Wilasitha’ shop. Borella Police told Magistrate Jayasuriya, that their probe into the incident had revealed that the two suspects had been deployed for duty in and around the Department of Government Printing. The prosecution then added that further inquiries into the incident, were still being conducted by them, with the help of the CCTV cameras, installed near the scene of the crime. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court, ordered the two suspects to be remanded, till the aforesaid date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: LG Polls Thrown into Doubt?
author: Author not found
Content: Following the Government Printer refusing to print ballot papers for postal voting, the Election Commission announced yesterday (14) that postal voting of the upcoming Local Government Elections was postponed indefinitely. This recent development raised concerns whether the LG Polls, which are scheduled to be held on 9 March, too will have to be postponed. Election Commissioner General Saman Sri Ratnayake, in a statement, said the decision to postpone postal voting was made as ballot papers for postal voting were not available due to reasons beyond the control of the commission.  Speaking to Ceylon Today, EC Chairman Nimal Punchihewa said if the Department of Government Printing fails to complete printing of ballot papers, the commission will have to take a final decision in regard to holding the LG Poll. The EC Chairman said the Government Printer has to abide by the recent circular issued by the Finance Ministry to limit expenditure. However, a stock of ballot papers has already been printed. If the printing of ballot papers can be completed within the next few days, they will be distributed immediately and postal voting will take place as scheduled, he added. Government Printer Gangani Liyanage refused to print ballot papers for postal voting until the due payments are made. The EC then informed political party secretaries yesterday (14), that it won’t be able to distribute ballot papers today (15), as originally planned, owing to the refusal of the Government Printer.  Postal voting for the Local Government Elections was scheduled to begin tomorrow at 1,116 centres. Postal voting was slated for 22, 23 and 24 February. By Methmalie Dissanayake and J.T. de Silva

title: Dealers pledge to recall vehicles with faulty air bags
author: Author not found
Content: All leading vehicle dealers pledged to recall the air bag models in motor vehicles that can be dangerous to passengers, Commissioner General of Motor Traffic Nishantha Weerasinghe said. A debate on the quality of air bags erupted following the tragic death of scientist, Dr. Vimukthi Jayaweera. The Commissioner General said a discussion to this effect had been held with representatives of motor vehicle importers. Weerasinghe added that during the discussion, motor vehicle importers had promised to look into the matter urgently. He added that he had underlined to motor vehicle importers the importance of producing superior quality air bags and to always install equipment which guarantees the safety of drivers and passengers. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: SLTWU organises ‘Variety Sale’
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Tamil Women’s Union (SLTWU) has organised a ‘Variety Sale’ of various products and services ranging from food items to clothes and accessories to mark Easter and the Sinhala and Tamil New Year on Saturday, 4 March from 9 a.m to 6 p.m at the Women’s International Club, Guildford Crescent, Colombo 7. The fundraising event is to help the community in various ways. It is also an initiative to encourage entrepreneurs to showcase their creativity in products and services. The SLTWU is 114 years old and home to ‘Kalalaya’ School of Dance and Music, which was founded in 1942.

title: Moragoda meets Dr. Mishra
author: Author not found
Content: Continuing his engagement with the key officials of the Government of India, the High Commissioner of Sri Lanka in New Delhi Milinda Moragoda met with the Principal Secretary to the Prime Minister of India Dr. Pramod Kumar Mishra at the Premier’s Office. The meeting between the Principal Secretary to the PM and the High Commissioner of Sri Lanka was held in a very cordial manner, and a range of issues pertaining to the bilateral relationship was discussed. HC Moragoda also followed up with Principal Secretary Mishra on the invitation that Prime Minister Narendra Modi has extended to President Ranil Wickremesinghe to visit New Delhi. Moragoda thanked Dr. Mishra for the support India has been extending to Sri Lanka in the context of the present economic crisis. The Principal Secretary to the Prime Minister, while recalling India’s historical and deep ties with Sri Lanka, stated that it was India’s duty to help its neighbour when it is faced with a crisis. Moragoda also stressed the vital role that India could play in Sri Lanka’s economic recovery phase through tourism. The discussion focused on the ways and means to enhance bilateral cooperation in the tourism sector, including at the State level, using the MoU signed between Sri Lanka and the State of Gujarat in 2009 when PM Narendra Modi was the Chief Minister of Gujarat and HC Moragoda was the Tourism Minister of Sri Lanka, as a template. During the past few weeks, Moragoda also met with several other key officials of the Government of India, including Finance Secretary T.V. Somanathan, Cabinet Secretary Rajiv Gauba and Chairman of the NITI Aayog Parameswaran Iyer. A Cabinet rank official, Dr. Mishra has been serving as the Principal Secretary to Prime Minister Narendra Modi since September 2019.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Special cultural event in Kuwait
author: Author not found
Content: A special cultural event to mark Sri Lanka’s 75th Independence Day was held in Kuwait on 8 February under the chairmanship of Kuwaiti Minister of Public Works and Minister of Electricity, Water, and Renewable Energy Amani Suleman Abdulwahab Bugamaz and Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Kuwait Kandeepan Balasubramaniam. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Kuwait organised this cultural event to enlighten diplomats from the State of Kuwait, officials from various ministries, and ambassadors about Sri Lanka’s cultural heritage. Participants expressed their gratitude for being invited to this colourful event. The event was held to improve friendship between the two countries, promote the tourism industry in Sri Lanka, attract foreign investors to the country, and create job openings in various fields.

title: Rural development will continue
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath emphasised that, despite the economic difficulties, the Government has prioritised the development of rural infrastructure. He emphasised that infrastructure development, particularly passenger transportation, has a positive impact on the rural economy. He also highlighted that despite the fact that the country’s rural roads have been properly developed, steps have been taken to reduce the remaining commuter difficulties on those rural roads. Speaking at the inauguration of a new bus from Ranawana village in Rambukkana Divisional Secretariat to Kegalle town, he said the Government has implemented numerous programmes to improve the rural people’s economy.

title: Japanese Ambassador plants Ruk sapling
author: Author not found
Content: In the presence of Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Ambassador of Japan Mizukoshi Hideaki planted a Ruk sapling at Sithawaka Wet Zone Botanic Garden to mark Sri Lanka’s 75th Independence anniversary and to commemorate 70th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Japan and Sri Lanka.  MP Yadamini Gunawardena, Japanese Embassy officials and Hiroyuki Shimotori, Director Shimokikaku co, Ltd, who established Japanese Language Center in Sithawaka, were also present.

title: Beach cleanup in Addalaichenai
author: Author not found
Content: A large-scale beach cleanup programme marking Sri Lanka’s 75th Independence Day was organised by members of the Addalaichenai Grand Mosque and Addalaichenai civil society groups, at Addalaichenai Beach. After the keynote address by Commander 241 Infantry Brigade, Colonel L.S.D.N. Pathirathna, the cleanup programme, supported by the Sri Lanka Army’s Akkaraipattu 241 Infantry Brigade, began at the beach park. A large number of volunteers from Walkers’ Union, trustees of the mosque, sports clubs, civil society groups, and influential persons in the area lent a helping hand. A large quantity of used plastic bottles and used plastic bags were collected and transported to landfill sites with the aid of Addalaichenai Pradeshiya Sabha tractors. Among the participants were Batticaloa High Court Judge N.M. Abdullah, Chief Trustee of Addalaichenai Grand Mosque N.M. Junaideen, Acting Akkaraipattu District Court Judge S.L.A. Rasheed and several other civil society group leaders. Secretary of the Ampara District Civil Society Group Dr. K.L. Nakfer thanked the volunteers for their valuable contributions and told them to keep up the good work. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: ADPC, USAID donate equipment to deploying troops
author: Author not found
Content: Director General, Disaster Management Centre (DMC), Major General (Rtd) Sudantha Ranasinghe handed over a set of state-of-the-art equipment on 12 February to the Disaster Response Training Centre in Gampola to be used by special military teams who are to leave for earthquake-affected Syria and Turkey to help in search and rescue operations. Assistant Director of Media and Public Relations, DMC, Janaka Handunpathiraja said on 13 February that the consignments had been donated by the Asian Disaster Preparedness Centre (ADPC) and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). He said with the support of the aforesaid agencies, the DMC has launched a training programme beginning 2021 to develop disaster response capabilities. “In line with the training programmes, the ADPC has also donated sophisticated training equipment worth Rs 17 million to the centre. The DMC has made arrangements to provide 448 items in four categories to be used by Sri Lankan troops while engaging in search and rescue operations in the affected countries,” Handunpathiraja added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Omani recruiting agents want SL to digitalise job sector
author: Author not found
Content: The heads of labour recruitment agencies in Oman requested Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara to take immediate steps to digitalise the foreign employment sector, in order to avoid the procedural delays in the recruitment of Sri Lankan workers for jobs in Oman. Nanayakkara, who is on a four-day official visit to Oman, responding to the request made by the heads of labour recruitment agencies, assured them that immediate action will be taken in this regards. The Minister met heads of labour recruitment agencies in Oman, to discuss matters related to the recruitment of workers from Sri Lanka for jobs in Oman. The heads of labour recruitment agencies pointed out to the Minister that some of them had to travel a long distance to come to the Embassy to get the approvals for the recruitment of workers, and a lot of time is wasted due to this. At the same time, due to the shortage of officials in the Embassy, they pointed out that they have to spend extra time in obtaining approvals. The Minister responding said that the best way to minimise such hassle was to digitalise the field of foreign employment and added that this will be done soon. In the meantime, it was also agreed to take necessary steps to recruit domestic workers only after conducting an interview through video technology. The problems that have arisen due to the bringing of female workers for domestic work in Oman, through tourist visas and the solutions that can be given to the problems faced by the representatives of the organisations that recruit workers in Oman, were also discussed at length.

title: Suspension of housing loans lifted
author: Author not found
Content: A housing week has been declared from 15 to 22 February to provide the next instalment of loans and grants to beneficiaries across the island. The temporary suspension of housing loans and grants has been lifted, according to Urban Development and Housing Minister Prasanna Ranatunga.  As a result, he advised the National Housing Development Authority (NHDA) authorities to take immediate action to complete the next instalment of these loans and grant programmes to  beneficiaries within a week from 15 to 22 February 2023. This decision was made recently at a meeting with District Managers of NHDA. Ranatunga advised NHDA officers not to begin new projects until the projects begun in 2021 and 2022 were completed. “When different governments came to power, they halted the previous government’s development work, claiming that it was a new concept that would affect the public,” the minister emphasised adding that he would begin new work after completing the old projects. “The NHDA implemented two loan and assistance projects between 2020 and 2022. A house for you – a future for the country and Mihindu Nivahana are two of them. The second, third, and fourth installments of these projects were temporarily suspended due to the last Covid-19 pandemic and the economic crisis. Measures were taken under the project A house for you – a future for the country to provide housing assistance for the construction of a house in each Grama Sevaka division,” he said. In addition, he highlighted that financial assistance was offered for 1885 houses and that the NHDA has allocated Rs 283 million to pay the remaining instalments, as well as Rs 9 million to provide the remaining allocation for 58 houses of the Mihidu Nivahana housing project. During the discussion, the Minister also suggested that officials launch a new housing assistance project for residents of the Northern and Eastern Provinces, as well as the plantation community.

title: Cabinet approves ban on single-use plastic products
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved banning the import, domestic manufacture, sale and local use of four plastic products with effect from 1 June. This is as recommended by the committee of experts to examine proposals regarding import, domestic production, sale and local use of seven single-use plastic/polythene products. They are single-use plastic drinking straws and stirrers, single-use plastic plates, cups (except yogurt cups), spoons, forks and knives, including yogurt spoons made of plastic, plastic garlands and string hopper moulds made of plastic.

title: YouTuber Sepal further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris yesterday (14) informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, that Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, had conveyed to him that if social media activist Sepal Amerasinghe, who had been remanded having defamed the sacred Sri Dalada Maligawa in Kandy, consents to abide by the conditions laid down by the Attorney General’s Department, the prosecution was willing to settle the case amicably. The SDSG made this submission to Court, after Defence Counsel Darshana Kuruppu, appearing for the suspect, told the Court, that his client was prepared to seek forgiveness in public from the Buddhists here and before the Chief Prelates, for his controversial remarks. Later, the Chief Magistrate, ordered the suspect to be further remanded, till 21 February. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: 111-year-old Excise Ordinance to be replaced
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved a proposal to enact a new Excise Act to replace a 111-year-old Excise Ordinance. Cabinet Spokesman, Minister Bandula Gunawardana said Cabinet approved President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s proposal to advise the Legal Draftsman on drafting an Excise Bill in his capacity as Finance Minister. The proposal was first made in Budget 2023, when the President presented it to Parliament. In November 2022, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said even licensed alcohol producers were evading excise taxes and on top of that the State lost revenue ldue to moonshine production. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Health professionals blame NMRA
author: Author not found
Content: The Alliance of Health Professionals (AHPs) blamed the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) for the current medicinal drug shortage prevailing in the country and alleged that a mafia operating within is purposely delaying the process. The AHP insisted that the NMRA should put a stop to obstacles in registering pharmaceuticals and suppliers and opt for a more practical method, in a short time, in order to minimise the impact of the current medicinal drug shortage in Sri Lanka. AHP President, Ravi Kumudesh noted that unregistered medicines are entering the market due to a faulty registration system, which does not facilitate the registering of the medicines. He also alleged that this arbitrary conduct of the MRA had paved the way for the Health Minister and various parties to import unregistered drugs at non-competitive prices. “Therefore, the Authority should take responsibility for violating the very purpose for which it was set up,” Kumudesh lashed out.  This situation has placed the State health system under the influence of the medicinal drug mafia. “The State health service is in a state of emergency,” Kumudesh pointed out accusing the NMRA of being unable to recognise it. Instead it has paved the way for a monopoly in the provision of medicines and health supplies. Indian credit support or new suppliers, who are willing to provide pharmaceuticals during the current economic crisis, are discouraged from entering the market by agents of certain pharmaceutical companies, which are hiding behind the NMRA. Instead of motivating new medicinal drug suppliers to readily step in, the NMRA’s main concern is on the pharmaceutical companies in its fancy list,” Kumudesh alleged. He claimed that this had led to the country being unable to import the required pharmaceutical utilising the Indian Credit Line. The AHP President alleged that avoiding, delaying, and seriously hampering the validation process of pharmaceutical supplies arriving from India, was a major cause of the current health crisis. Therefore, the medicinal drug crisis cannot be merely attributed to the economic crisis the island is facing, he added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Gammanpila claims QR system for fuel was his idea
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya Leader Udaya Gammanpila said the current implementation of a QR system, for fuel distribution, was an idea he had while serving as the Minister of Energy. He said former Finance Minister Basil Rajapaksa opposed the solutions and proposals he forwarded to avoid a fuel shortage by managing the demand and supply of fuel, but in the end, the incumbent Government was compelled to implement the solutions he proposed. Addressing the media yesterday (13) he said fuel queues were eliminated by a solution that he presented. “MP Rohitha Abeygunawardena said in Parliament that I was unable to eliminate fuel queues and that Minister Kanchana Wijesekera could. To avoid fuel queues, I proposed the same method the Romans used to eliminate wheat flour queues in the past. Despite the passage of time, there are only two solutions to this problem. That is, managing demand by raising prices or managing supply by rationing, as the Romans did in the past,” he said. Further, Gammanpila said he wrote to the Cabinet on 5 February 2021, stating that a cost-represented price system is required, and that a rationing system should be put in placed on 21 June 2021. He pointed out that raising prices manages demand, while rationing manages supply. “However, Basil, as Finance Minister at the time, opposed both those proposals. Finally, Minister Kanchana will solve this problem by implementing my suggestion. Demand management is achieved by raising the diesel price from Rs 121 to Rs 450. A 20-litre-per-car, 5-litre-per-three-wheelre, and 4-litre-per-motorcycle ration was implemented. Many people refer to it as the QR method. QR is simply a code that allows you to access the database where the ration is stored. Many businesses use QR codes to access their website. The Election Commission made the list of candidates running for office available via QR code. A rationing system was actually implemented. This QR code is required to gain access to the data bank in that ratio,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Government to release Rs 19B
author: Author not found
Content: A sum of Rs 19 billion will be released for several purposes, including payment of gratuity arrears to over 18,000 retired State sector employees, as per a proposal submitted to the Cabinet by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Apart from gratuity arrears, the Cabinet approved releasing funds for purchasing essential medicinal drugs, paddy and to address child malnutrition. The Cabinet granted approval to the President’s proposal as the economy of the country is slowly getting back on its feet, a senior Minister said.

title: GMOA hopeful of favourable response from President
author: Author not found
Content: Following the success of the protests and the rally held at Hyde Park last week the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) said they were hopeful of a favourable response from the President, with whom they have requested a discussion with regard to the enacted Inland Revenue Act of 2022. GMOA Media Committee Member, Dr. Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam said yesterday (13) that the government, which had been unwilling to introduce a single amendment to the Amended Inland Revenue Act, had later introduced minute changes which were concessional to those Professional grades, with non cash benefits following the massive rally of the professionals collective had at Hyde Park  He said his outfit was willing to wait it out this week hopeful that the President Ranil Wickramesinghe would give them a meeting. “We have asked for an amendment in the government’s tax policy decision which we hope would be given, failing which the Union would join with all the other professional trade unions next week. “If the government does not understand this language, then we are ready to talk to it in one it would understand then by collapsing all professional services, he warned.        By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Student drowns in swimming pool
author: Author not found
Content: A student drowned in the pool of Maharagama Navinna Municipality Stadium. Maharagama Police confirmed the victim as Didula Rashmika, a Grade 13 student, who lived in Heiyantuduwa, Mabima. According to Police, the student drowned while swimming with four other students. He was pronounced dead after being admitted to the Colombo South Teaching Hospital, Kalubowila. Police also confirmed that notices were posted asking people to come with a swimming coach if they wanted to swim in the pool. The deceased student’s post-mortem examination will take place at the Colombo South Teaching Hospital. Maharagama Police are conducting investigations. BY Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Bandula receives DMT probe report on Radella accident
author: Author not found
Content: The report of the special investigation, conducted by the Department of Motor Traffic (DMT), into the fatal accident in Radella on 20 January, was handed over to Minister of Transport Bandula Gunawardena. The investigation was on the accident which killed seven and injured 53, including schoolchildren, in Radella Nanu Oya. The observations related to the accident, the conditions of the vehicles involved in the accident, and many facts about the causes of the accident were revealed in this investigation conducted by an investigative panel of the DMT along with the Police. This report takes into account all of these facts, as well as the main causes of the accident and 16 recommendations to prevent similar accidents in the future. The report is to be presented to Parliament.

title: Passport office gets heated as system fails
author: Author not found
Content: A heated situation arose at the Department of Immigration and Emigration yesterday (13), when temporary disruptions had occurred in the issuance of passports, due to a system failure. As a result, issuing of passports had to be temporarily suspended islandwide. When the people, who had arrived to obtain services, started to protest, the Police was summoned to control the situation. According to the department, a technical fault in its internet services had caused the system failure. Following the incident yesterday (13), the department requested the people who booked appointments to obtain passports to refrain from coming on the day of appointment, and instead to come the following day. The department will be open on Saturday (18) to provide services to people who made appointments for Friday (17) and normal service are to resume on Monday (20).

title: National policy on coconut oil importation mooted
author: Author not found
Content: The All Ceylon Traditional Coconut Oil Manufacturers Association (ACTCOMA) has urged the Government to enact a national policy for the importation of coconut oil. Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando met representatives of the ACTCOMA, at the Ministry of Trade, to discuss the quality of coconut oil supplied to the local market. During the meeting, Fernando inquired about the market issues that local coconut oil producers are currently facing. “It is difficult for the traditional small and medium scale local coconut oil producers to compete with those coconut oil products due to low quality imported coconut oil being sold in the market at a low price,” ACTCOMA members claimed. As a precaution to ensure the quality of the coconut oil sold without packaging, Fernando directed Consumer Affairs Authority to take the necessary steps to identify the company that sold the coconut oil. At the moment, the market demand for coconut oil is 18,000 metric tonnes and despite the fact that local coconut oil producers have a capacity of 25,000, they only supply 8,000 metric tonnes to the market due to raw material scarcity. Members of the ACTCOMA said the tax breaks given to coconut oil importers are causing severe difficulties for local coconut oil producers. The Minister said he would take the next step in this regard after consulting with the Ministry of Finance. Furthermore, Ministry officials were directed to take the necessary steps to consult with the Sri Lanka Standards Institute in order to check the quality of coconut oil. The goal of this discussion is to protect consumers while also encouraging local coconut oil producers to provide high-quality products. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Decision on petition against power tariff hike on 17 Feb
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (13) stated the decision on whether or not the Petition, seeking an order to set aside the Cabinet decision to revise Electricity tariff, will be taken up for hearing will be declared on 17 February. This Petition, filed by the Centre for Environmental Justice and three others, including Electricity Consumers’ Association, was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Dhammika Ganepola and Sobhitha Rajakaruna. The Attorney General, making submissions yesterday (13), observed that the Ceylon Electricity Board does not have sufficient funds to provide uninterrupted power without increasing electricity tariff. Following submissions made by both parties, Court held that the decision on whether or not the Petition will be heard together with the decision on interim relief sought by the Petition, will be announced on 17 February. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Strike cancels 23 office train runs
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 23 office train journeys have been cancelled due to locomotive engineers’ strike yesterday (13). A discussion took place, at the office of the General Manager of Railways with the relevant trade union engaged in trade union action and the General Manager of Railways. The trade union then decided to call off their strike after discussions with authorities. Thousands of commuters travelling from Kalutara to Colombo and other areas were stranded after several trains were cancelled without notice and others were delayed yesterday morning. The commuters were inconvenienced due to the cancellation of several regular trains and a large number of them returned home instead of going to work. Some of the express trains were running late, so it was decided that the trains would stop at all stations. For several months, the authorities have been working to run the train from Kalutara South to Negombo at 7 a.m. to Maradana, but it was also cancelled yesterday. BY Prabhath Bulathsinhala – Agalawatte
