Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Gammanpila claims QR system for fuel was his idea
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya Leader Udaya Gammanpila said the current implementation of a QR system, for fuel distribution, was an idea he had while serving as the Minister of Energy. He said former Finance Minister Basil Rajapaksa opposed the solutions and proposals he forwarded to avoid a fuel shortage by managing the demand and supply of fuel, but in the end, the incumbent Government was compelled to implement the solutions he proposed. Addressing the media yesterday (13) he said fuel queues were eliminated by a solution that he presented. “MP Rohitha Abeygunawardena said in Parliament that I was unable to eliminate fuel queues and that Minister Kanchana Wijesekera could. To avoid fuel queues, I proposed the same method the Romans used to eliminate wheat flour queues in the past. Despite the passage of time, there are only two solutions to this problem. That is, managing demand by raising prices or managing supply by rationing, as the Romans did in the past,” he said. Further, Gammanpila said he wrote to the Cabinet on 5 February 2021, stating that a cost-represented price system is required, and that a rationing system should be put in placed on 21 June 2021. He pointed out that raising prices manages demand, while rationing manages supply. “However, Basil, as Finance Minister at the time, opposed both those proposals. Finally, Minister Kanchana will solve this problem by implementing my suggestion. Demand management is achieved by raising the diesel price from Rs 121 to Rs 450. A 20-litre-per-car, 5-litre-per-three-wheelre, and 4-litre-per-motorcycle ration was implemented. Many people refer to it as the QR method. QR is simply a code that allows you to access the database where the ration is stored. Many businesses use QR codes to access their website. The Election Commission made the list of candidates running for office available via QR code. A rationing system was actually implemented. This QR code is required to gain access to the data bank in that ratio,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Government to release Rs 19B
author: Author not found
Content: A sum of Rs 19 billion will be released for several purposes, including payment of gratuity arrears to over 18,000 retired State sector employees, as per a proposal submitted to the Cabinet by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Apart from gratuity arrears, the Cabinet approved releasing funds for purchasing essential medicinal drugs, paddy and to address child malnutrition. The Cabinet granted approval to the President’s proposal as the economy of the country is slowly getting back on its feet, a senior Minister said.

title: Jaffna, Tamil culture have nourished Sri Lankan culture
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said the policy of the Sri Lankan Government is based on reconciliation, development, and culture and that the Jaffna and Tamil culture have nourished Sri Lankan culture. He said this culture has roots in Sri Lankan soil and has connections to Tamil Nadu and Kerala cultures as well. He expressed these views at the vesting ceremony of the Jaffna Cultural Centre (JCC) in the people of Sri Lanka and called on everyone to join hands in brotherhood to rebuild this fallen nation. The JCC was completed with funds amounting to Rs 13,500 million provided by the Indian Government and the event was attended by the Union Minister of State for Information and Broadcasting Dr. L. Murugan. In his speech, the President emphasised the Government’s policy of reconciliation, development, and culture, and called for all citizens to come together in brotherhood to rebuild the country. “We have decided to celebrate our 75th Independence ceremony not only in Colombo, but also in Jaffna. We will commence the programme here at the JCC, which is a gift from Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. We are also discussing economic development projects in the Northern Province, a massive development project in the Trincomalee Port, and the energy sector. Furthermore, we appreciate the support extended by the Indian Government to Sri Lanka to overcome the debt trap during this economic crisis,” he said. Minister of Fisheries, Douglas Devananda, said the incumbent President Wickremesinghe has visited Jaffna twice in less than two months and has a good understanding of the problems faced by the people in the North. He has also outlined steps to be taken to solve these problems and has announced the implementation of the 13th Amendment. The President is seen as a solution to the economic crisis of 2022, and therefore, everyone should support him. The people of the North prefer to live as Sri Lankan Tamils. Indian State Minister L. Murugan expressed delight in being present at the inauguration of the cultural centre in Jaffna. The foundation stone for this centre was laid during the visit of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in March 2015, and its construction has now been completed. This cultural centre will play a significant role in promoting cultural and artistic activities in Jaffna. “During my recent visits to several provinces of Sri Lanka, I witnessed the support that India has given for the development of housing as well as infrastructure, education, health, and agriculture sectors. Among them are the Duraiappa Stadium and Thirukedeeswaram Kovil. In addition, when Sri Lanka faced a severe economic crisis in 2022, India provided USD 4 million in assistance. In addition, India provided the necessary financial guarantee for the restructuring of Sri Lanka’s debt to receive financial assistance from the International Monetary Fund. It should be noted here that Prime Minister Modi has an idaea to introduce a scholarship for 100 children from low-income families in the Northern Province, extending India’s assistance to Sri Lanka. India will be celebrating 100 years of Independence in 2047. India has already planned and implemented measures in this regard. I believe Sri Lanka has done the same. We believe that the journey will go in cooperation with both our countries,” he said.

title: CEJ DEMANDS DEEP JUNGLE FESTIVAL BE CANCELLED
author: Author not found
Content: The Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) urged to take immediate measures to cancel an event due to be held in Habarana, next to the Gal Oya forest reserve, on the basis that such an event would negatively impact the surrounding environment, while affecting the wildlife therein. “We have learned that an entity called Deep Jungle Entertainment (PVT) Ltd. has organised the ‘deep Jungle Music and Cultural Festival, under the patronage of certain Government authorities next to the Galoya forest Reserve, a well-known elephant corridor in Habarana from 17 to 18 February 2023,” the CEJ noted.  They added that the organisers have obtained support and permission from the President’s office, Prime Minister’s office, Ministry of Public Security, and other relevant authorities. However, the final conditional approval has been issued by the Department of Forest Conservation and the approval highlights the fact that the said location is adjacent to a Reserve Forest. The CEJ emphasised that 150- 200 elephants cross this elephant corridor daily, yet the the Department of Wildlife Conservation has given a letter stating the land does not come under its purview, while, the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Conservation is unaware about the said event. “Considering the fact that the area  is an active elephant habitat, the Forest Department has requested the organisers to maintain low noise levels. The Department has also warned about elephant movements on the bund of the Karandagaswewa reservoir and advised against staying on the bund of the tank specially during the night-time,” they said. They further observed that the Police circular No. 2031/2007, issued by the Inspector General of Police, fully prohibits the use of sound producing equipment from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m.  “As we know, the animal kingdom responds to noise very differently. Hearing ranges from very high frequency ultrasound (>20,000 Hz) echolocation in bats to very low frequency infrasound (<20 Hz) in elephants. In addition to that the forest is considered as a silent zone as any noise can disturb the wild animals,” they observed. The CEJ went onto to state, “we believe the proposed activities during the music festival such as electronic music and busy human gathering will exceed the noise level way above the permissible levels and the agencies which granted permission are not in a position to neutralise the discomfort on wild animals including elephants. Bright lighting will be harmful to wild animals including elephants. This area is known for elephant train accidents. There is a possibility of disturbed elephants being hit by trains or entering into the residential areas and damaging the properties of the local people.” They thereby demanded the relevant authorities to immediately cancel the approvals given and for the organisers to shift the event to another location. “We also demand the Inspector General of Police, Conservator General of Forest and Director General of Wildlife to adhere to the Police circular 2031/2007 and to the provisions of the Environment impact assessment, when conducting any project in the buffer zone of any Forest reserve and of any National reserve . Any failure to monitor and maintain the law of this country will be strictly dealt and legal action will be taken against those who are responsible for such violations and failures,” they said.

title: Jaffna Cultural Festival showcases vibrant Tamil culture
author: Author not found
Content: The Jaffna District Cultural Festival was held at the Jaffna Fort premises in celebration of Sri Lanka’s 75th National Independence Day. The event showcased the rich Tamil culture of the Northern Province and was attended by a large number of people from Jaffna and featured a massive musical concert. President Ranil Wickremesinghe was the Chief Guest at the event and was joined by several high-profile individuals, including Indian State Minister of Fisheries L. Murugan, Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda, the Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay, and the President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and the Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, other government officials and Chiefs of Security forces. The cultural festival was a vibrant display of the cultural heritage of the Northern Province, and the musical concert was a highlight of the event, featuring several South Indian artistes. The presence of such a diverse range of people, including government officials, dignitaries, and artistes, demonstrated the importance of this celebration of Sri Lanka’s Independence. In addition to the cultural festival, an Independence Commemorative Parade was held in the afternoon at the Jaffna Cultural Centre, bringing together all five districts of the Northern Province to present various dance elements. Schoolchildren from the Northern Province participated in the parade, which was a showcase of the cultural richness and diversity of the region. The Jaffna District Cultural Festival and the Independence Commemorative Parade were both well-received by the local community and were a testament to the significance of Sri Lanka’s 75th National Independence Day. These events will be remembered for years to come as a celebration of the country’s independence and the rich cultural heritage of the Northern Province.

title: Emirates launches humanitarian airbridge
author: Author not found
Content: In the wake of the devastating earthquakes in Turkey and Syria, Emirates is setting up an airbridge with the International Humanitarian City (IHC),to transport urgent relief supplies, medical items and equipment to support on-ground aid efforts and search and rescue activities in both countries. The first shipments are due to go out today on EK 121 and EK 117, consisting of high thermal blankets and family tents from UNHCR, followed by World Health Organisation (WHO) and World Food Programme (WFP) relief cargo of medical kits and shelter items, co-ordinated by the IHC in Dubai.  In the coming days, more consignments of blankets, tents, shelter kits, flash lights, water distribution ramps and trauma and emergency health kits will be transported on Emirates. Emirates SkyCargo plans to dedicate cargo space for around 100 tonnes of humanitarian relief goods over the course of the next two weeks across its daily flight operations to Istanbul. The critical emergency supplies carried on Emirates will then be delivered by local organisations to affected areas in southern Turkey and northern Syria, supporting on-ground responders and providing much needed aid to the hundreds of thousands of people impacted by the earthquakes.  HH Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum, Emirates’ Chairman and Chief Executive, said: “We stand with the Turkish and Syrian people and are working with experts like the International Humanitarian City to help provide urgent relief to those affected and displaced by the earthquakes, as well as support the complex recovery efforts on the ground. Emirates has extensive experience in supporting humanitarian relief efforts, and through its three daily flights to Istanbul will offer regular and consistent widebody capacity for relief items and medical supplies. Emirates also supports the UAE’s ongoing humanitarian efforts to support Turkey and Syria, and Dubai’s unique position as the world’s largest international aid logistics hub means that we can efficiently reach disaster stricken areas and the most vulnerable people as quickly as possible.” His Excellency Mohammed Ibrahim Al Shaibani, Chairman of the Supreme Committee for the Supervision of IHC: “The IHC remains committed to providing the people affected by the earthquakes with the humanitarian support and resources they need. We are taking urgent action by facilitating airlifts of vital medical supplies, shelter items and other relief goods from the UNHCR, World Health Organization (WHO) and World Food Programme (WFP) to address the pressing demand for aid in the affected regions.” The freight division of Emirates has a long-standing partnership with the IHC, enabling the airline to nimbly and quickly lead on numerous relief missions, deploying humanitarian supplies to communities around the world impacted by natural disasters, medical emergencies, global outbreaks and other crises. In 2020, the airline facilitated relief efforts to Lebanon in the aftermath of the Port of Beirut blasts. In 2021, Emirates set up a humanitarian airbridge between Dubai and India to transport urgent medical and relief items to support the country in containing the Covid-19 outbreak. Last year, the airline offered cargo capacity to organisations working with the IHC to transport critical equipment and supplies directly to five cities in Pakistan devastated by flooding.   Over the years, Emirates has also supported humanitarian flights in partnership with the Airbus Foundation, and since 2013, Emirates A380 ferry flights have transported over 120 tonnes of food and vital emergency equipment to those in need.

title: Switzerland Provides Funding To Improve Food Security
author: Author not found
Content: The United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) in Sri Lanka today acknowledged a recent contribution of CHF 800,000 (approximately LKR 292 million) from the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) at a special event held at the Embassy of Switzerland to Sri Lanka and the Maldives. The funding is being used to provide much-needed cash and other assistance to improve food security among rural farming communities affected by the country’s economic crisis. Through this funding, over 1,000 smallholder farmers across five drought-prone districts are being provided with LKR 50,000 each (approximately US$140) to access essential items, including food. The funding will also support recovery among communities grappling with the twin challenges of the economic and climate crises. Through a suite of assistance, which includes diversified sources of income and enhanced access to markets, WFP aims to improve the livelihoods of those most vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change. “Switzerland is supporting Sri Lanka in many ways during this difficult time. Farmers, their families and many people associated with the agricultural sector are currently facing enormous difficulties. I am grateful that we have developed a partnership with WFP to strengthen the resilience of Sri Lankan farmers. This will ultimately benefit the entire population,” said Ambassador of Switzerland to Sri Lanka and the Maldives Dr. Dominik Furgler. “Smallholder farmers form the backbone of our food systems but are among those hardest hit by the economic crisis,” said Abdur Rahim Siddiqui, Representative and Country Director of WFP Sri Lanka. “Their capacity to cope has been stretched to the limit, severely undermining their ability to withstand any future disasters such as floods and drought. This funding from Switzerland is timely and critical to assist these communities in meeting their immediate food needs while helping to restore food security in the long term.” Sri Lanka was ranked second among countries most affected by extreme weather events in the last 20 years, as per the Global Climate Risk Index 2019. As part of its efforts to strengthen food security, WFP works towards making food systems more robust and resilient to the effects of the climate crisis. The generous contribution from the Swiss Government enables WFP to sustain the positive outcomes of prior projects which strengthened the resilience of climate-vulnerable communities and promotes self-reliance among smallholders even in times of crisis.

title: Sri Lanka donates Tea to Türkiye
author: Author not found
Content: The Government, with the support of Ceylon Tea Exporters, donated a consignment of ‘Ceylon Tea’ on 10 February 2023, to the Ambassador of Türkiye in Colombo to be delivered to Türkiye earthquakes victims.  The consignment was handed over to Ambassador of Türkiye, Demet Şekercioğlu, by Director General for Emergency Response of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs O.L Ameer Ajwad at the Türkiye Embassy in Colombo.  The donation was coordinated by the Prime Minister’s Office, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the Sri Lanka Tea Board.  Foreign Ministry’s Director General for Europe Priyangika Dharmasena, Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tea Board Niraj De Mel and Director for Promotion at the Sri Lanka Tea Board Pavithri Peiris were also present at the event.

title: Amaraweera instructs ASMP to increase dry chilli production
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera advised officials of the Agriculture Sector Modernisation Project (ASMP) to take necessary steps to increase local dry chilli production by 25 per cent this year. ‘’Although the annual requirement of dry chilli in our country is 55,000 MT, 50,000 MT of it is imported from foreign countries,’’ he said, adding that thereby the production should be increased.  ASMP, which is a project implemented by the Ministry of Agriculture with foreign funds, has provided seeds, drip irrigation technology and modern technical equipment and knowledge to protect crops from insects to farmers free of charge.   Amaraweera stated that currently, 300 farmers in the Badulla District have cultivated 150 acres of chilli and ASMP has given each farmer Rs 1,000,000 in the form of non-reimbursable equipment and technical support for chilli cultivation. He instructed that youth groups, interested in chilli cultivation in the area, be selected and provided with the necessary financial support as well as technology and equipment for cultivation.

title: Cabinet nod for proposal to digitise education soon – Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said Cabinet approval to digitise education which is the foundation of educational transformation will be obtained in two weeks. He said discussions were underway to update the curriculum of all grades from Grade 6 to 13 and begin teaching Artificial Intelligence in Grade 8. According to the minister, artificial intelligence will be included as an optional subject or in the curriculum, and students will be able to study it alongside information technology. He was speaking at the awarding of prizes and certificates at the ICT competition, which was held for the second time in Colombo. “Also, since the future of the youth rests with the improvement of technology, opportunities for students to enter university should be systematically increased. Science and technology courses should be expanded in higher education and schools in rural areas should be provided with enough science and mathematics teachers to provide opportunities for this. The concept of school clusters will be based on  good resource management,” he said. Further, he said peer countries are now about ten years ahead of us in technology, and we cannot return to the twentieth century from the third decade of the twenty-first century, so we must move towards a mandatory education transformation process in the next five years. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Habaraduwa MOH collects Rs 587,000 in fines
author: Author not found
Content: The Habaraduwa MOH office collected fines totalling Rs 587,000 through fines after filing cases in Court against 13 hotels in Galle, that were operating in violation of health regulations. Health Inspectors of the Habaraduwa MOH filed cases against the hotels in Habaraduwa, Kathaluwa, and Talpe. Ice cream was found stored in freezers along with meat, hotel waste was disposed into drains, hotel employees did not have medical certificates, food was stored in such a way that it was exposed to flies, garbage was piled up irregularly, and toilets were left open to the kitchen. On the advice of Habaraduwa MOH Dr. Sundara Mudalige, PHI (Administrative) B.K.S. Jayasiri, PHIs Achintha Samarasinghe, Gayan Asanka Wismitha Haratasinghe, and Gayan Asanka Wismitha Haratasinghe, raids were conducted and cases were filed against the hotel owners. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Lankan among Türkiye earthquake victims
author: Author not found
Content: The body of a 64-year-old Sri Lankan woman, who was living in Türkiye and was reported missing after the earthquake, has been identified by her daughter, according to the Sri Lankan Embassy in Türkiye. Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Turkey, Hasanthi Dissanayake, earlier said 13 of the 14 Sri Lankans believed to be in earthquake-affected areas of Türkiye were safe and had been located. The deceased woman, who lived in a building that collapsed during the earthquake, was not present at the time of the incident and had not been contacted, according to Ambassador Dissanayake. The Ambassador also urged the public to share any information they may have on Sri Lankans living in Türkiye. A 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck southern Türkiye and northwest Syria in the early hours of 6 February while cold spells worsened the plight of victims. It was followed by a multitude of aftershocks and a second 7.5 magnitude quake. The death toll from the earthquake on both sides of the border in Türkiye and Syria is presently over 28,000 while over 86,000 have been evacuated from the earthquake affected area.

title: Rs 330M safety cover for NHDA employees
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the National Housing Development Authority (NHDA) Rajeev Sooriyaarachchi said a deposit of Rs 300 million has been made to ensure the safety of NHDA employees. He also said Rs 50 million will be allocated monthly for this deposit from the monthly recoveries. “The NHDA currently employs approximately 1,800 people. This programme will be implemented in accordance with Minister Prasanna Ranatunge’s instructions to ensure the safety of NHDA employees, especially during a crisis,” he said. The Chairman emphasised a pandemic, an economic recession or a lockdown may reoccur at any time and in such a scenario, this deposit will keep the institution running by paying employees’ salaries.

title: Agri Ministry urges tax on potato imports
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture Ministry Secretary Gunadasa Samarasinghe has written to the Secretary of the Ministry of Finance requesting a tax be imposed on imported potatoes. However, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said despite the letter, no action has been taken by Finance Ministry officials and that he will notify the President about this at today’s (13) Cabinet meeting. He said the Ministry of Agriculture has begun a programme to discourage importing potatoes during the local potato harvest to protect local potato farmers and local potato cultivation. “Every time the local potato harvest was in operation, farmers were forced to abandon local potato cultivation due to potato imports by every Government. It is the Government’s responsibility to protect farmers who grow potatoes in this country by investing large sums of money, and thus, despite sending this letter, officials from the Finance Ministry have taken no action,” he said. He was attending an event organised by the Agriculture Sector Modernisation Project, which began the harvesting of seed potatoes in the Boralanda area of Welimada on 11 February. He also said this step was taken to increase the production of seed potatoes needed to increase potato cultivation in Sri Lanka. “Under the Agriculture Sector Modernisation Project, the production of seed potatoes in Sri Lanka has been increased to nine million. Now about one hundred acres of seed potatoes were being cultivated in the Boralanda area. He advised that more land should come under potato cultivation,” he said. Amaraweera also said under the project free seed potato as well as modern technology, water supply systems, soil cover, and crop protection equipment for seed potato cultivation will be provided.

title: Only a Party with professionals can solve current crisis – Eran
author: Author not found
Content: No single person can solve the country’s problems, only a Party with educated professionals can, SJB MP Eran Wickramaratne said yesterday (12). Speaking to the media  from the Opposition Leader’s office in Colombo, he further said for the past 40 years the masses had been looking up to individuals to solve theirs and the country’s problems, but history has shown that these expectations have been brought to nought. He also said though many countries have managed the current economic crisis which is global in nature, the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) however has not been able to manage it because it does not have a proper management or action plan other than siphoning off public resources. “GoSL for over five months have been harping on a USD 2.9 billion IMF loan to tide over this crisis, but this loan is yet to see fruition. The country will never move forward without having proper international relations. He therefore urged the people to hand over power of the country or village to a party that has a team with experience that can deal with the international community,” Wickramaratne said. Speaking further, he said, Elections must be held from time to time and this time around it cannot be said that the people did not demand it, since it is stated in the Constitution or other laws to hold such periodic polls, it is anti-democratic to prevent Elections by giving lame excuses. The SJB MP also said the democratic framework of a country should be strengthened. He warned that if it is attacked, the people will take the law into their own hands. “It was reported that a Jaffna MP who held protests when the President visited Jaffna on 11 February was bailed out yesterday. These are unnecessary harassments against the people caused by the Police deprive the people of their democratic rights,” Wickramaratne said. The SJB MP said, “Left parties in the country have been disrupting education opportunities for decades. If you try to start a private university, it will be jeopardised at any cost by them.  GoSL does not have enough resources to grant higher education for all. So getting the assistance of the private sector to provide higher education was inevitable.” Wickramaratne added, a country’s problems are complex in nature. Therefore a team with experience and expertise is needed to solve such problems. Not only in the country’s governance or politics, but also in business, different experts are needed for different sectors. Can an uneducated person become a school teacher? Educated experts were needed in all fields to solve the country’s complex problems. Such experts are found only in the SJB, he said. (PA)

title: President directs paddy to be purchased at Rs 100
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed officials to purchase a kilogramme of paddy at a guaranteed price of Rs 100. The President further said the Northern Province and Jaffna District will be developed as a province capable of supplying food to the whole country. He was speaking yesterday (12) while attending the Northern Province harvesting ceremony at Paranthan in Jaffna. The President also inquired about the problems related to paddy cultivation from farmers of the Paranthan area and assured that immediate solutions will be provided to those problems. The President said the Government promptly provided required fertiliser to farmers. Therefore, we believe that there will be a surplus of paddy in the Maha Season. Accordingly, arrangements are being made for the Government to purchase a kilo of paddy at a guaranteed price of Rs 100. “Many people are currently experiencing financial difficulties. Even if yields increase, there is a segment of the population that lacks the financial means to purchase rice. Therefore, we are implementing a programme to provide 10 kilos of rice free of charge to 2 million families during March and April. Then by the Sinhala New Year season, they would have received 20 kilogramme of rice. Currently, approximately three metric tonnes of paddy is received per hectare. We require a minimum of 6 metric tons of rice per hectare. If possible, we hope to increase it to seven metric tonne,” he said. Speaking further he said the Government is working to provide the necessary facilities to achieve that target. More methods of purchasing and storing paddy will be developed in the future. We intend to build small and medium-sized rice mills. “We will be able to succeed in those activities in the next two years. We have planned to provide the necessary water facilities for this area. We are working to restore the Pooneryn tank. Meanwhile, the Iranamadu tank was now ready. We are working to transform the Jaffna district and the Northern Province into a province that is capable of producing enough food to feed the country once more. In addition to this, we hope to take steps to start the production of animal feed,” he said. Minister of Fisheries Douglas Devananda, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, former Member of Parliament Vijayakala Maheswaran, Chief of Defence Staff General Shavendra Silva, IGP, C D Wickramaratne and Northern Province State officials participated in this event. The President then visited the Pannam Kandi field, Kilinochchi and discussed the problems of farmers. A large number gathered to see the President. He engaged in a  friendly discourse with them and focused on children and their educational activities.

title: Star tortoise smuggling attempt thwarted
author: Author not found
Content: The Biodiversity Division of Sri Lanka Customs based on information seized 206 live Star tortoises when a smuggling attempt was thwarted. The tortoises were meant to be taken to Kuala Lumpur (Malaysia) by flight AK046 on 11 February 2023. The tortoises were seized at the Air Cargo Exports Terminal of the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake. The animals had been stuffed inside cloth sacks and then packed into six boxes describing as ‘Dried Sea Food’. Sri Lankan Star Tortoises (Geochelone elegans) is the same species that is found in India and Pakistan but has a specific geographic identity. It is one of the most beautiful tortoise species found in the world and due to this reason they are highly sought after, especially in the South East Asian countries. As a result, the species is threatened with extinction and included in the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List of species and also in the Appendix I of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). According to the Fauna and Flora Protection Ordinance (Section 40), attempts to export any mammal, bird, reptile, amphibian, fish, coral or invertebrate, eggs, feathers, or plumage of any bird, the horns, antlers, skin or hide of any mammal or reptile or any part of any mammal, bird, reptile, amphibian, fish, coral or invertebrate without the permission of the Director General of Wildlife Conservation Department is an offence and also simultaneously violates the Customs Ordinance (Chapter 235). Assistant Superintendents of Customs Prasad Ekanayake, Yashodha Kotuwegedara, KKMD Rasanga and MGD Tharaka involved in this seizure and further investigations conducted by the Biodiversity, Cultural and National Heritage Protection Division of Sri Lanka Customs.

title: MCPA Chief lambasts Health Officials
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa urged President Ranil Wickremesinghe to change the ‘most corrupt medical administration in the island’s history’. Lashing out, Dr. Sanjeewa yesterday (12) said successive Health Ministers, Secretaries and the Directors General Health Services (DGHS) had pushed the best health system into becoming the weakest health service in the world within a matter of two years. He accused Health Ministers, Health Secretaries and the DGHS’ as being responsible for the present state of affairs. Facts regarding corruption, fraud and irregularities in the Health Ministry continue to be revealed in Parliament, through audit reports, Economic Stabilisation Committee and Public Accounts Committee reports, but typically the President of the country has so far failed to take action by removing those responsible for this crisis and corruption, he said. As a result of not notifying the shortage of medicinal drugs beforehand, large sums of money is being wasted through middlemen, he alleged.  Continuing to keep the Minister and his officials in their present positions would be a decisive matter relating to the lives of citizens, he said.  Although the Health Minister and health authorities point to the economic crisis in the country as being responsible for the acute medicinal drug shortage and  increase in prices of medicines in the country, the budget allocation for the state health service remained unchanged regardless of the current economic crisis. The Department had responded to a query made by the Hospital Deputy Director  regarding the limitation of many medical services including kidney transplant and renal care services at the National Institute for Nephrology, Dialysis and Transplantation The prevailing medicinal drug shortage in the country has resulted in the Health Ministry’s decision to push back non-urgent surgeries.  The MCPA during a special discussion held with the Jathika Janabalawegaya discussed measures to be followed for the advancement of the health sector. Discussions revolved around the pharmaceutical crisis, increase in drug prices and the  corrupt political and bureaucratic transactions that have taken place in the health system for the last two years. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Providing funds for elections a Constitutional obligation – PAFFREL
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Finance has failed to provide the National Election Commission with the funds needed for the Local Government (LG) election, People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) Executive Director Rohana Hettiarachchi said. He said the Minister of Finance and the Secretary to the Finance Ministry are constitutionally obligated to provide the funds and that if this does not happen, legal action will be instituted against the competent authority. Speaking to the media, Hettiarachchi said they had been informed that the Ministry of Finance had failed to release the funds, which was regrettable. “If the Finance Minister and the Ministry Secretary do not release the funds, we are considering legal action against them,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Routine Surgical Operations Put on Hold
author: Author not found
Content: A shortage in required medicinal and anaesthetic drugs has pushed health authorities to prioritise essential surgeries and push back surgeries that could be delayed with counsel from the relevant consultants till the country gets sufficient supplies of medicinal drugs. Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella yesterday (12) advised hospital authorities to defer the date of surgeries that could be delayed with the advice from the relevant consultant. Rambulwella when contacted stressed that urgent and essential surgeries which were a matter of utmost priority were to be carried out as scheduled without any delay.  “In this way we could give urgent surgeries priority when allocating the required medicinal and anaesthesia drugs. It will take about two to three weeks to get ample drug stocks to the country,” he said. Medical authorities noted that routine surgeries such as hernia repair surgeries that could be delayed. Meanwhile, Chairman Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa said a situation has arisen where surgeries cannot be performed. As a result, he said, hospital directors have begun posting messages about the limitations of performing surgeries on their hospital WhatsApp groups rather than informing through formal letters. Meanwhile, JJB National Executive Member Nalinda Jayatissa said the health sector is an example of a corrupt environment where drugs are purchased with a commission in mind. He said the Minister of Health is directly aiding and abetting the ongoing corruption at the Ministry of Health. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: No land deeds for 92 families in Akmeemana
author: Author not found
Content: Approximately 92 families in Akmeemana, Galvalagodakanda are disappointed that the Government has yet to issue deeds for the lands on which they live. They point out that as a result of this situation, there are numerous difficulties in enrolling children in schools and obtaining bank loans. The villagers claim that politicians who visit the village during elections promise to give land deeds and repair the dilapidated road, but they have only made promises. They also claim that land deeds have not yet been issued; despite the fact that surveying has been done several times indicating that land deeds are to be issued. According to them, the road system leading to the village is also in poor condition, and even though the responsible authorities have been informed, the officers have turned a blind eye and deaf ear to their complaints. The villagers also claim that the National Housing Development Authority (NHDA) has provided housing loans ranging between Rs 300,000 andRs 500,000 for house construction. According to them, they were unable to repay their housing loan due to the Covid-19 pandemic and economic crisis. According to the villagers, some people must pay Rs 100 000 to Rs 150 000 as interest money in addition to the loan amount. They urged the NHDA to provide assistance. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Name JVP’s Foreign and Finance Ministers – Johnston
author: Author not found
Content: The SLPP MP and Former Minister Johnston Fernando while noting the JVP could not govern a country even if it won an election due to lack of capacity, challenged the Party to name who will hold Finance and Foreign Affairs Ministry portfolios in a future government. Addressing an election rally in Kegalle, Fernando said that some seemed to have been impressed by the massive numbers of participants at JVP rallies. He said, the JVP has 70,000 members who are taken from one rally to another so that they could show the numbers to impress others. “It is not a new phenomenon. They had been doing so for years. But when it comes to the final count of votes only their trick is exposed. Even if they win or lose they have a mechanism to bring people to their rallies. The JVP has created a Facebook wave to show that they are going to win the forthcoming local polls. Even in the last elections the JVP could only poll 42,000 votes. Suppose they would get their maximum this time, even then they would get only 120,000 to 130,000 votes from all over the country. With that they would not be able to get power,” he said. Speaking further Fernando noted that even if they win the election they cannot govern a country because they do not know how to do that and they do not have the capacity to do that. He said, JVP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake would not be able to work with the international community to get the necessary assistance to steer the country out of the present crisis. “He would not be able to secure the support of the international community to bring fuel. He does not have international connections. Basil Rajapaksa got 4.5 billion US dollars from India. Using that money we imported fuel. Anura cannot do that. He cannot even speak to Indian fishermen to get at least a litre of petrol from them. We challenge the JVP to name who would be the ministers of finance and foreign affairs under a government of theirs. They do not have persons with capacity to hold such positions. The JVP has always been duping the people. During the time of Sirimavo Bandaranaike in 1971 they got around 12,000 youth killed and in the 1987-88 period another 60,000 youth. Those who were born after 2000 do not know the real conduct of the JVP,” he said.

title: Grace period to hand over guns to Police
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Defence has declared a grace period from 6 February 2023 to 15 March 2023 for persons who possess guns without licence to hand over the guns to the Police according to the  Government Gazette No. 2318/02 of 6 February 2023. In a special statement from the Ministry, it said during the aforesaid period, all guns that are  without licence should be surrendered to the nearest Police Station.  “No prosecution will be initiated against persons who surrender such unlicensed guns during the period. At the termination of the period, islandwide operation will be conducted by the Police to apprehend the persons who possess guns without licence. The Government emphasises to all the persons who possess guns without licence to make use of this period to avoid arrest and prosecution,” the statement further said. Additional Secretary (Civil Defence and Development) D.M. Saman Dissanayake at the Ministry of Defence could be contacted (Telephone Number 011-2335792) for further details.

title: Land deeds, compensation to 197 families displaced in the North
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe gave land deeds and financial compensation to 197 families who were displaced in the North, along with cheques to the value of Rs 38,000 each. The lands were freed as part of a programme to return the lands used by the security forces, during the war against LTTE terrorism, to the original residents, as per the instructions of the President. Wickremesinghe presided over a ceremony at the Jaffna District Secretariat to handover the land deeds. During the ceremony, held on 11 February, the President awarded land deeds and financial compensation cheques to several recipients, who expressed their gratitude for being given back their lands after 33 years of displacement. The President was joined by Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda, the President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff, Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, President’s Coordinating Secretary to the Northern Province M. Ilangovan, former Parliamentarian Vijayakala Maheswaran, and other dignitaries. The resettlement programme and the awarding of land deeds and compensation to these families is a significant step towards helping them start a new life and rebuild their homes. The support of the Government and the presence of dignitaries at the event highlight the importance placed on this resettlement programme and its positive impact on the lives of these families, a spokesman said.

title: Navy springs into action to save whales beached in Kudawa
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy sprang into action on 11 February to save a pod of whales beached on Kudawa in Kalpitiya and guide them back to the ocean. The naval establishment SLNS Vijaya in the Northwestern Naval Command spotted about 14 whales stranded on Kudawa Beach this morning. Having quickly deployed to the scene to assess the situation and provide assistance, the Navy coordinated with the Department of Wildlife Conservation and residents of the area and successfully guided the whales back into the deeper waters of the ocean. Meanwhile, the Department of Wildlife Conservation confirmed that three whales have unfortunately died. The pod of whales is believed to be Short–Finned Pilot Whales.

title: International Day of Women and Girls in Science
author: Author not found
Content: Science Needs Women So Let Her STEM Did you know that globally women amount to only about a quarter of the workforce in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM), and that men vastly outnumber women majoring in most STEM fields in universities? The gender gaps are particularly high in some of the fastest-growing and highest-paid jobs such as IT and engineering. How serious is the underrepresentation of women in STEM in Sri Lanka? According to the University Grants Commission (UGC), in 2017, women accounted for nearly half – 49 percent – of undergraduate enrolments in STEM subjects in local universities. And yet, when examining the workforce, there are far fewer women working and leading in STEM. There is also a significant gendered divide within different STEM sectors, with much lower representation of women in fields like math, engineering and technology which are seen as ‘masculine’ or ‘male oriented’ fields, while more women in STEM pursue care-oriented fields such as health and biological sciences. Why are there fewer women in STEM fields? The underrepresentation of women in STEM is shaped by harmful gender stereotypes, norms and roles. These range from the idea that investment in women’s education is less important since women are primarily caregivers while men are breadwinners, to the belief that certain STEM fields are naturally more suited to the ‘male/ masculine’ mind and that women cannot equally understand or thrive in them. These biases and norms affect men and women in these sectors. Women often choose their fields of education and work based on how they perceive their abilities and roles in society. Men – particularly male family members, educators, and employers – allow these norms to guide their support, teaching, and recruitment.  These are major challenges to women’s equal entry into and engagement in STEM careers. In Sri Lanka, the multilayered crisis threatens to widen the gender gap in STEM fields. Building off of harmful gender norms and biases, economic hardship has affected girls’ access to education, with families choosing to educate their sons instead of daughters to cope with rising costs and poverty. Why do we need more women in STEM? As Sri Lanka navigates this economic crisis, addressing the gender gap in STEM fields is more crucial than ever. With an increasing number of jobs being digitalized, it is essential that women are not left behind in this transition and contribute to the development of a more equal and sustainable future economy. Women in Sri Lanka’s workforce predominantly belong to the low-skilled and informal workforce, and continue to be a minority in sectors like the tech industry, for example, which is one of the fastest-growing and highest-paying sectors worldwide. Closing the gender gap in STEM will ensure that women have access to more high-skilled employment and are meaningfully included in the economic growth that is driven by technology and innovation. At the same time, as these fields evolve and expand, it is increasingly imperative that the capabilities and perspectives of women are brought in to bring about innovative, inclusive and effective solutions to the complex societal challenges of today and to strengthen our collective performance on economic and development indicators. During the COVID-19 pandemic, for example, it was largely women in medical research who led the development of vaccines while also studying gendered impacts of COVID-19 on women’s bodies – a nuance which is too often excluded from scientific study. In a time of growing online violence, women in tech are leading the advocacy and work on developing safeguards and accountability systems to protect female users. As work on artificial intelligence (AI) expands, the technical contribution and oversight of women is vital to combat gender biases in AI algorithms. We cannot have products and innovation which include and reach out to all communities, genders, and consumer groups, unless they are equally driven by women. What are the necessary steps to close the gender gap in STEM in Sri Lanka? Closing the gender gap in STEM in Sri Lanka will require targeted and continued efforts in society, institutions, and the operational frameworks of STEM fields. As global societies, we must deconstruct harmful gender stereotypes and biases on the roles of women in society and their capacity to thrive in and expand STEM fields. But what does that mean? It means holistic efforts to recognize our own individual assumptions and biases about each gender,  and to address them in our daily life. It means reforming our educational structures and approaches. Our schools and universities must allow and encourage students to explore their interests regardless of their gender, and expand from current approaches to  – for example – encourage boys to explore domestic skills and the arts, and girls to explore mechanics and high-intensity sport. Our educational structures must celebrate those who have crossed gender lines, and pave the path for innovators, scientists, and artistes alike. Curricula across all levels of education must build an understanding of social issues along with critical thinking skills to recognize and deconstruct biases and discrimination. Academics must increasingly examine issues of science, technology, engineering and math through the lens of gender, in line with growing research that makes vital discoveries when adopting sex and gender disaggregated analysis. It means reforming the approach of media and the arts to present a broader view of individual capabilities, character, and potential, and counter discriminatory and misogynistic views, rather than reinforcing restrictive and biased gender norms.  It means breaking the barriers that keep and push women out of the STEM workforce and making tangible reforms towards more inclusive workplaces that allow women to thrive and lead in STEM. If the gender gap in STEM fields is to be sustainably redressed, our efforts must go beyond performative policies and translate into structural and equitable change including equal pay for equal work, equal paid family leave, childcare facilities and flexible work arrangements. These shifts in companies’ operating ethos have a tangible impact on closing gender gaps and retaining talent and skilled labour – a fact which has been established by multiple global and regional studies. The necessity of attracting and retaining women in STEM is increasingly recognized by leading actors in these fields. Giants in the technology sector including Google and Microsoft have programmes targeting the recruitment and upskilling of women in tech.  In some instances, international corporates, tech hubs, and governments have created collectives for more diverse and inclusive landscapes in technology. The future of STEM must belong to all of us. By closing the gender gap in STEM fields, we not only empower women and girls, but we also unleash a wealth of creativity and innovation as well as necessary inclusion and progress for society as a whole. It’s time to take action and break down the barriers that limit women’s contributions in STEM fields. On this year’s International Day of Women and Girls in Science let’s work together, challenge biases, and pave the way for a brighter and more equal future in the fields of science and innovation – for all.

title: Migrant worker remittances increase to USD 178.3 M
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said foreign remittances from Sri Lankan migrant workers have increased by 68.8 per cent, or USD 178.3 million, in January 2023 compared to January 2022 inflows. “This is a 68.8 per cent or USD 178.3 million increase compared to the inflows recorded in January 2022,” Nanayakkara added. In a Twitter message on 10 February, Nananyakkara said Sri Lankan migrant workers’ foreign remittances increased to USD 437.5 million in January 2023 from the USD 259.2 million reported in January 2022.  Meanwhile, Sri Lankan migrant workers’ foreign remittances were recorded as USD 475.6 million in December 2022. As per Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data, it is a 46 per cent (USD 150 million) increase compared to the inflows recorded in December 2021. Remittances in December also showed an improvement compared to the previous month, which was recorded as USD 384.4 million in November 2022. However, as per CBSL data, 2022 recorded the lowest yearly total of foreign worker remittances Sri Lanka has received in the last eight years, with a total of USD 3.78 billion. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: DMT compiles stats on vehicles with faulty air bags
author: Author not found
Content: Commissioner General of Motor Traffic Nishantha Anuruddha Weerasingha said they will gather information this week on which vehicles have air bags similar to the one that killed a scientist and how many of them are in the country. He added that two companies that have installed these types of faulty air bags have already recalled their vehicles and begun the air bag replacement process. When queried how many vehicles with faulty air bags have been identified, Weerasingha responded that they will compile figures this week. “With the fatal car accident, it was revealed that a piece of iron in the air bag hit his neck. In this connection, we found the categories of vehicles equipped with such air bags,” he said. A scientist from the Sri Lanka Institute of Nanotechnology (SLINTEC) was killed in a road accident in Kumbuka, Gonapola on 3 February. Police said the 37-year-old scientist, who was returning home in a luxury car, died after his vehicle collided with a concrete post of an unsecured roadblock. His car had toppled and he was killed when a metal shard of the air bag that activated on impact caused grievous injuries. Following this tragedy, local dealers of vehicles similar to that of the late scientist have recalled certain vehicle models for an air bag system upgrade. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Protest in Jaffna against Freedom Day celebrations
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held against the Independence Day celebrations held on Saturday (11) in Jaffna. It was organised by the Tamil National People’s Front (TNPF), led by Gajendrakumar Ponnambalan An Independence Day celebration was organised at Jaffna Cultural Centre, by the Fisheries Ministry, with the participation of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who arrived at Palaly International Airport.  Several Indian politicians, including L. Murugan and K. Annamalai, from South India, had arrived in Jaffna to participate in the Jaffna Cultural Center handing over ceremony. The protest was staged at 3.00 p.m. By T. Pratheepan – Jaffna

title: Sirisena curious why President wants to implement 13A
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Maithripala Sirisena said in Parliament yesterday (9), that he is curious as to why President Ranil Wickremesinghe is speaking about implementing the controversial 13th Amendment to the Constitution at a critical juncture like this. Sirisena likened Wickremesinghe’s attempt to holding a torch burning at both ends. “None of the former Presidents, such as J.R. Jayewardene who introduced the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, R. Premadasa, D.B. Wijetunge, Chandrika Bandaranaike, Mahinda Rajapaksa, or I ever attempted to implement the controversial amendment. It is not an easy task as Sinhala Buddhists, who are the majority in the country, are vehemently against it,” he pointed out. Speaking further, Sirisena said the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) is ready to extend its full support if an all-party Government is formed to rebuild the country. “We are the first party that recommended establishing an All-Party Government last year. The SLFP held discussions with former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and current President Ranil Wickremesinghe during the past one and a half years in a bid to establish an All-Party Government to develop the country after the Covid-19 pandemic occurred, he said. Sirisena said however due to the resistance from the incumbent Government, the formation of an All-Party Government never came through. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Kanchana claims PUCSL allowed tariff concession to apartments
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara, who is at loggerheads with Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), yesterday (9), alleged that the latter has granted a special electricity tariff concession to apartment complexes, than normal domestic consumers. The Minister said that electricity could be provided to normal domestic consumers at concessionary rates if this special relief granted to Housing Apartments was withdrawn. Speaking in Parliament, Wijesekara noted that the electricity tariff charged from apartment complexes are 50 per cent lesser than the tariffs charged from normal domestic housing units. He raised concerns as to why the PUCSL has allowed such special relief for apartment complexes. Speaking further, the Minister said he hopes that PUCSL would, as promised, give its approval for the proposed electricity tariff revision on 15 February. “The PUCSL promised the Cabinet and the National Council that it will amend the tariff proposals and give its approval on 15 February. We hope they will keep their word,” he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Only Ministers, MPs benefit from exclusion of non-cash benefits
author: Author not found
Content: Excluding non-cash benefits, when calculating income tax, only benefits Ministers and MPs who receive a wide range of non-cash benefits, MP Wasantha Yapabandara said in Parliament yesterday (9). Speaking on the circular, issued by the Inland Revenue Department, exempting employees from paying income tax on non-cash benefits, Yapabandara claimed this new instruction will not give any relief to State sector employees. “Ministers, MPs and Chairpersons of State institutions are receiving a wide range of non-cash benefits such as vehicle, fuel allowances, housing and medical benefits more than the basic salary. So, this new circular will be a huge benefit for Ministers and MPs because they get non-cash benefits higher than the basic salary,” he said. Yapabandara said he paid Rs 75,666 as tax last month from his allowances as an MP.  “It is not nice for Ministers and MPs to enjoy these exemptions while the general public is struggling to pay taxes. So, we have to provide true benefits to the general public,” he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Attempt to bring back women stranded in Oman hits snag
author: Author not found
Content: Attempts to bring back 59 women, who were stranded in Oman and are currently in ‘Suraksha’ safe houses toSri Lanka have been hindered due to several loopholes in the existing laws of the country, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said. Nanayakkara is currently on a four-day official visit to Oman with the objective of implementing maximum diplomatic measures to curb human trafficking and open up more job opportunities in Oman for trained professionals. He met the women staying in a safe house in Oman and inquired about the issues they had gone through after arriving in Oman. “There are 59 women in these safe houses. At the moment, there are false media reports about them. Therefore, I request the media not to report unverified information on the matter. The Sri Lankan Embassy in Oman operates under very limited facilities. There is a shortage of Embassy staff and the number of interpreters is not enough,” he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Sumanthiran says cannot accept devolution in unitary State
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK) MP M.A. Sumanthiran said both his party and people in North cannot accept the President’s statement on devolving power to the maximum within a Unitary State to resolve the ethnic matter in Sri Lanka. Sumanthiran made this remark in response to the Policy Statement delivered by President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the inauguration of the fourth sessions of the ninth Parliament on 8 February. He said though the President made several remarks on ethnic issue in the country they cannot accept the Policy Statement as it suggests devolving power within a Unitary State. “You cannot devolve power to the maximum by implementing the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. When the President contested for the Presidential Election in 2005, he used to speak about a Federal State. During the tenure of Good Governance Government, several attempts were made to devolve power. But, all those attempts were futile. The 13th Amendment is already in the Constitution. The President can enact it at any given time. If he fails to do so, we can say that he is violating the Constitution,” he said. By D.L. Jayakody
