title: ‘Branded kottu restaurants’ robbing customers – AICOA
author: Author not found
Content: Alleging that ‘branded kottu restaurants’ are robbing and exploiting the customers, by putting unreasonable prices on the product, the All Island Canteen Owners’ Association (AICOA) requested the Government to impose a Maximum Retail Price (MRP) on both kottu and wheat flour. AICOA Chairman Asela Sampath, addressing the media, said some of these branded kottu restaurants sell kottu at more than Rs 900-1,000. He noted that the price of a kilo of wheat flour has increased in the local market to a maximum of Rs 240. He demanded that the responsible authorities intervene immediately to stop the wheat flour mafia and lower the price to the extent that the people could bear. “The price of a kilo of wheat flour was Rs 193. Wheat flour had become the staple meal among the country’s poor and low-income families. Even though the price of wheat flour has increased, the prices of canteen products have not. We requested the main wheat flour importers to stop this fleecing of consumers. If not, we will have to intervene in the issue and reveal all the details about what they do,” he said. Therefore, the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) and Trade Ministry should intervene in this issue, he said. He further noted that with this sudden increase in price, there is suspicion that someone is getting commission. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Teacher in bribery net
author: Author not found
Content: The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) arrested a teacher, serving at the Maliyadeva School, Kurunegala, on charges of seeking a bribe of Rs 300,000 to enrol a student in the GCE Advanced Level Arts stream. The Bribery Commission took the suspect school teacher into custody on Wednesday (8), following information received that he sought the aforementioned sum as a bribe. According to Bribery Commission, the teacher has been serving as the head of the school’s Advanced Level Arts stream. The commission added that following initial inquiries the suspect will be produced before the Kurunegala Chief Magistrate’s Court. By Amith Maduranga Gamage

title: SC determines licensing Bill inconsistent
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court has determined that the Licensing of Shipping Agents, Freight Forwarders, Non-Vessel Operating Common Carriers and Container Operators (Amendment) Bill, as a whole, is inconsistent with Articles 12(1) and 148 of the Constitution, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena informed Parliament yesterday (9). The Bill was challenged in the Supreme Court in terms of Article 121(1) of the Constitution. The Speaker said the Supreme Court has determined that the Bill, as a whole, is inconsistent with Articles 12(1) and 148 of the Constitution and as such may be enacted only by the special majority required by Article 84(2) of the Constitution. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Katuriarachchi

title: Angry Suresh decides to quit all SJB positions
author: Author not found
Content: MP Vadivel Suresh who was agitated over Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa’s alleged bail out from a party rally organised by him in Madulsima yesterday (9), has decided to resign from all posts he held in Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB). Suresh said, Premadasa pledged to attend the rally in Madulsima yesterday (9), but he dodged the meeting at the last moment citing poor health conditions. Later, it was discovered he was addressing a rally in Welimada at the scheduled time for Madulsima rally, he alleged. “We prepared everything for the rally and the estate workers left their work for the day as well. When we were informed that the Opposition Leader had a sudden illness, everyone was sad and prayed for his speedy recovery. I personally apologised to the estate workers. Shortly after, however, I saw, on Facebook, Sajith speaking at a rally in Welimada at that very moment,” he said. Speaking further, Suresh said he was shocked to see Premadasa addressing another rally as he became a liar in people’s eyes. “At that very moment, I decided to resign from all the posts within the SJB,” he stressed. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Fowzie returns to Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: A.H.M Fowzie was sworn in as an MP of the 9th Parliament before Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena yesterday (9). After being sworn in before the Speaker, he signed the Member Roll kept in the presence of the Secretary General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake. Fowzie has been appointed to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Mujibur Rahuman of the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB). Rahuman resigned to contest as SJB mayoral candidate in Colombo at the upcoming Local Government election.  Born on 13 October 1937, Fowzie entered active politics in 1959. He was elected as the Deputy Mayor of Colombo in 1968 and was elected as the 16th Mayor of Colombo in 1973. Fowzi, who was elected to the Western Provincial Council in 1993, contested the 1994 general election and was elected to Parliament. He has also held many different ministerial portfolios. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Schaffter’s post-mortem reports contradictory
author: Author not found
Content: President’s Counsel Anuja Premaratne yesterday (9), informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, that the post-mortem report, compiled by JMO Ruhul Haq, into the death of Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Dinesh Schaffter last year, had been contradictory.  Accordingly, the Additional Magistrate stated that as per information conveyed to her by investigating officers that their probe into the death of the deceased has not been concluded as yet, she would be deferring her verdict on the Magisterial Inquest. As such, she mentioned that her decision on it will be delivered once the investigators submit all their reports to Court. Counsel Premaratne stated that as per the initial post-mortem report, it had been stipulated that the victim had died after being strangled. He said, however, the second report had said the deceased had died after being strangulated, as well as due to ingestion of cyanide in his system. He opined that the JMO report, which had been submitted to Court by the CID, had been sought from an individual, who had been suspended from practice for a period of eight months, by the Medical Council and hence it was contradictory. The PC told the Court that the initial post-mortem, conducted into the death of Dinesh Schaffter, had shown that there had been a few scratches on his face, while there had also been reddish marks on his neck, while similar marks had also been spotted on his fingers. Anuja Premaratne explained that thepost-mortem report, compiled on 16 December, had mentioned that the victim had died after being bound with zip ties and a wire around his neck. But, he pointed out that the subsequent post mortem report, conducted into the death of the deceased, had maintained that the latter, had died due to strangulation and ingestion of cyanide. He informed the Court, that though the post mortem report had mentioned that 150 ml of cyanide had been in the victim’s body, if such an amount had been ingested in a human, then that person’s body would invariably become pale, as per accepted medical science methods. Therefore, counsel argued that though the JMO had stated that the upper part of the victim’s body had blackened upon his death, the report compiled by the GA had observed that the amount of cyanide contained in the blood of the deceased, had been less than what had been mentioned in the JMO report and hence it is contradictory. Afterwards, Premaratne urged the Court, to defer its decision on the Magisterial Inquest into the death of Dinesh Schaffter, due primarily to the contradictory nature of the post-mortem reports that has been compiled and submitted to Court. The CID told Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya, that already 14 investigative teams had been deployed, to probe the death of the Janashakthi Insurance PLC Director and that they had already recorded statements from 20 individuals in this regard. They added that they had also inquired into 26 CCTV camera footages that had been installed, on the route that had been used by the deceased, for his final journey to the Cemetery. The CID stressed that from investigations carried out thus far, it had come to light that the deceased businessman, had been engaged in financial transactions with four other individuals, namely Brian Thomas, Elian Gunawardena, S. Uganathan and Deepthi Perera. They noted that investigations conducted had revealed that during such transactions, the victim had suffered massive financial losses and that most such losses had been incurred at the hands of Brian Thomas. The CID testifying further insisted that on the day of the death of the businessman, which was 15 December last year, perusal of telecommunication towers and analysis of mobile phone data, had revealed that Schaffter, had not been in conversation with any of the four aforementioned individuals or with any other person. They explained that data gathered from such smart phone systems, such as WhatsApp, IMO and VIBER had also been thoroughly analysed by them. Following the CID concluding testifying, the Additional Magistrate informed Court, that her final decision on the Magisterial Inquest into Schaffter’s death will be deferred to a later date, as the prosecution has still not concluded its probe into the case. She then instructed the CID, to expedite its probe into the case and submit all investigative reports to Court promptly. She fixed further hearing of testifying into the case to 8 March.    By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Order barring deducting income tax from Judges extended
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (9), extended the interim order issued preventing the collection of Advance Personal Income Tax (APIT) from Judges. This was when the Writ Application, filed by the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JASL), challenging the charging of APIT was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. The initial interim order was issued on 26 January and accordingly, the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) was ordered to refrain from collecting APIT tax from Judges until the case is supported. According to the Inland Revenue Act, employment income exceeding Rs 100,000 was taxed. Further, every employer was mandated to deduct APIT from payments made to employees upon exceeding the limit. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Kanchana claims PUCSL allowed tariff concession to apartments
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara, who is at loggerheads with Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), yesterday (9), alleged that the latter has granted a special electricity tariff concession to apartment complexes, than normal domestic consumers. The Minister said that electricity could be provided to normal domestic consumers at concessionary rates if this special relief granted to Housing Apartments was withdrawn. Speaking in Parliament, Wijesekara noted that the electricity tariff charged from apartment complexes are 50 per cent lesser than the tariffs charged from normal domestic housing units. He raised concerns as to why the PUCSL has allowed such special relief for apartment complexes. Speaking further, the Minister said he hopes that PUCSL would, as promised, give its approval for the proposed electricity tariff revision on 15 February. “The PUCSL promised the Cabinet and the National Council that it will amend the tariff proposals and give its approval on 15 February. We hope they will keep their word,” he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Indian State Minister to dedicate Jaffna Cultural Centre to Sri Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: Indian Union Minister of State for Information and Broadcasting, L. Murugan arrived at the Palaly International Airport, along with Bharathiya Janatha Party Tamil Nadu State President K. Annamalai yesterday (9), for a four-day visit, to dedicate the Jaffna Cultural Centre (JCC) to the people of Sri Lanka, which was completed with funding provided by the Indian Government. He will also attend many other events in the country during his official tour. President Ranil Wickremesinghe will join the Indian politician in dedicating the JCC to the people on 11 February. As mentioned in the MoU, India will continue to provide maintenance support to the (JCC) for duration of five years, the Indian Government said. The Fisheries Ministry has also planned to host a National Independence Day celebration on 11 February at the JCC.  In March 2015, Prime Minister Narendra Modi laid the groundwork for the Jaffna Cultural Centre. During his visit, Murugan will visit several locations that demonstrate the scope and breadth of the Indian Government’s people-centred development partnership in Sri Lanka. He will also meet leaders and stakeholders, according to a news statement from the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting. The JCC will be the symbol of improved relations between India and Sri Lanka, said the Indian Government. The JCC houses a museum, an auditorium with 11 floors and a modern theatre with a seating capacity for up to 600 people. A progress meeting regarding the President’s visit to Jaffna was held yesterday (9), at the Jaffna District Secretariat under the leadership of the Minister of Fisheries Douglas Devananda. Jaffna GA Ambalawanar Sivabalasundaran, Northern Province Chief Secretary Saman Bandulasena, President’s Additional Secretary-in-Charge of Northern Development, Security Forces Command Commander Jaffna District Deputy Inspector General of Police, representatives of the Tri Forces, divisional secretaries and heads of departments were present at the meeting. The JCC was not formally unveiled for over two years because there was a “conflict” on whether the Jaffna Municipal Council or the Central Government would run it. According to the Jaffna Municipal Council, the MoU said that the JCC should be operated by them and they have adequate funds to do so, however, the Sri Lankan Government stated that the Jaffna MC has no money and that the government will operate it. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: MAGISTRATE SAYS WARRANT NOT NEEDED TO ARREST DIANA
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (9) emphasised to the CID that a warrant will not be required for the arrest of State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage, if she has flouted Provisions contained in the Immigration and Emigration Act.  The Court issued this reminder to the CID, when a case, pertaining to a complaint, filed into the legality of the State Minister’s birth certificate, NIC and her passport, was called. Later the CID submitted a progress report on the case to the Chief Magistrate. Last month, the CID was ordered to obtain a report from the British High Commission in Colombo, on Gamage’s citizenship, and to conduct further investigations in this connection.  The relevant report was submitted to Court yesterday. Appearing on behalf of the petitioner Oshala Herath, President’s Counsel Rienzie Arsecularatne stressed that in the event an average person of a non-political background committed such an offence, prompt legal action would have been instituted against the said individual. However, no such haste is being seen in this case, owing to the fact that it concerns a State Minister. Accordingly, the next hearing of the case was fixed for 2 March, by the Court. The CID had informed the Court that they had noticed that Provisions contained in Section 175 of the Penal Code as well as the Section 45 (1) of the Immigrants and Emigrants Act No.20 of 1948 had been violated. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Asela B. Rekawa appointed MEPA Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Urban Development and Housing, Prasanna Ranatunga appointed Attorney-at-Law Asela B. Rekawa as Chairman of the Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) effective Tuesday (7). The appointment was approved by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Educated at S. Thomas’ College, Mt. Lavinia and graduated from the Sri Lanka Law College in 2000, Rekawa is an alumnus of the Bandaranaike Centre for International Studies and currently reading for his Masters in Criminal Justice Administration at the Open University of Colombo. He is a Life Member of the Sri Lanka Bar Association and a member of the International Bar Association, serving on its Committees for Pro Bono, Criminal Law and the Asia Pacific Regional Forum.

title: 13A will not resolve issues in North – Vigneswaran
author: Author not found
Content: MP C.V. Vigneswaran yesterday (8) said, during his tenure as Chief Minister of the Northern Province he realised that the national problem or the issues faced by the people of the North and East will not be resolved even if the 13th Amendment to the Constitution is fully implemented. He also said, in a unitary country, the Government will only implement the views of the majority, who are the Sinhalese, and that was why they urge a federal system. Speaking to the media yesterday (8), he also said, while the Government has made many promises, the issue is what actually happens when they try to deliver on those promises. “The Central Government has managed to put us in a position where we are unable to work. That is why we are requesting a federal system. However, it is preferable to fully implement the current situation via the 13th amendment. President Ranil Wickremesinghe admitted he had only fulfilled half the promises he made. Let us see how far he goes to fulfil them. His speech was good,” he said. (TR)

title: Favourability ratings of politicians remain negative
author: Author not found
Content: The latest Sri Lanka Opinion Tracker Survey (SLOTS) poll showed that net favourability ratings of all major party leaders remained negative through December 2022. The public’s negative perception of former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has changed little since his resignation, with his net favourability rating deeply negative and stuck at -72 as the year ended. President Ranil Wickremesinghe remains much less unpopular than his predecessor. But the boost in his favourability ratings after he took over the Presidency has dissipated, with his favourability rating falling back in November and December to end the year at -48. The ratings of both SJB Leader Sajith Premadasa and NPP/JVP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake continue to recover from the lows they and other politicians reached in mid-2022. Their net favourability is now substantially better than the President’s. But their ratings of -38 and -31 respectively in December, means that for every Sri Lankan who has a favourable view of them, there are another two who have a negative view. The SLOTS lead investigator is Dr Ravi Rannan-Eliya of the Institute of Health Policy (IHP), who has trained in public opinion polling at Harvard University and has conducted numerous surveys over three decades.

title: Monks clash with Police over 13A
author: Author not found
Content: A heated situation arose between the Police and the Buddhist Monks during a protest against the full implementation of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, which was held at Polduwa Junction near Parliament entry road yesterday. A large group of Buddhist monks started a protest march yesterday (8) near Parakumba Pirivena, Kotte, against the decision taken by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to implement the 13th Amendment. Police obstructed the protest march from proceeding after it had reached Polduwa Junction. Although Police interrupted the march, the monks continued to protest. The protest coincided with the beginning of the Fourth Session of the Ninth Parliament. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Galle Tourist Police initiate probe
author: Author not found
Content: An investigation has been launched by the Tourist Police in Galle into an incident where the driver of an app-based taxi service was verbally abused by a group of three-wheeler drivers in parks for transporting foreign tourists. A video recorded by two foreign tourists that went viral on social media recently, which showed a driver providing an app-based taxi service was being verbally abused by three-wheeler drivers in a park. The drivers at the park were seen warning the other driver who transported the tourists not to accept hires from tourists again in the area. The Tourist Police Division reported that no formal complaint has been lodged in this regard as yet, however, investigations have been launched as it involved foreign tourists.

title: Over Rs 1.3B credited to farmers’ accounts returned
author: Author not found
Content: Over Rs 1,300 million credited to farmers’ accounts have been returned as farmers have failed to give correct account details to the Department of Agrarian Development. According to the Department, steps were taken to distribute Rs 8 billion from the funds received by the Asian Development Bank to 1.2 million farming families in the form of Rs 10,000 for one hectare and Rs 20,000 for two hectares. Before crediting the money to farmer accounts, the Ministry of Agriculture and the Department of Agrarian Development informed farmers to check whether the account numbers given to the Agrarian Service Centres were correct, but some farmers have failed to do so. “As a result, Rs 1,300 million of the money directed to farmer accounts have been returned to the Department. Out of the Rs 8 billion, Rs. 6.5 billion has been credited to farmer accounts,” they said. Further, they added that steps will be taken to credit all the money to farmers’ accounts by the end of next week.  (FT)

title: NDCU mulls reinforcing Mosquito Control Act
author: Author not found
Content: With Dengue cases shooting up to nearly 11,000 by the fifth week of this year, the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) said it is looking at the possibility of amending the mosquito control laws to strengthen them further. Consultant Community Physician of NDCU,Dr. Anoja Dheerasinghe, when contacted, said the Unit was looking at amending the Mosquito Control Act No. 11 of 2007. “At present, legal action can be instituted against those who fail to follow the instructions given by Dengue control teams that visit premises for inspection. This is in regard to ridding their premises of mosquito breeding grounds. The Court can impose a fine on them.” She said there have been suggestions with regard to fines and amounts etc. but all this takes time and needs to go through the Legal Draftsman and receive Cabinet approval. Fielding questions, she said monsoonal rains impacted the Dengue caseload. From 1 January to 8 February there were 10,958 Dengue cases. Last month, there were 8,963 cases recorded while from 1 February till date there have been 1,995 Dengue cases diagnosed in the country. She said, however, that the Act cannot be used to impose spot fines on the public. But it was best for every individual to rid their surroundings of mosquito breeding places. She stressed on the need for anyone who develops a fever which lasts for over 24 hours to seek medical attention while pregnant women should seek immediate medical attention in case they develop a fever. Dr. Dheerasinghe advised the public to take only paracetamol to get the fever down. Ceylon Today learns that under the Western Province Declaration, the Ministry of Health had also instructed its Public Health Officers on imposing spot fines on individuals who fail to rid their premises of mosquito breeding sites. The declaration also allows legal action to be taken against such persons. Section 262 of the Penal Code also permitted spot fines to be imposed on such persons. Meanwhile, National Convener, Health Entomology Officers’ Association (HEOA), Disnaka Dissanayake said, however, that increasing fines will only burden the public further during the economic crisis. “Instead, policy should be formulated by a committee comprising all stakeholders engaged in Dengue control. The Medical Officer to the Public Health Inspector and the Health Entomology Officer should be included in that committee so as to form a proper long-term policy against Dengue. Further, the public should be made aware – they should be educated on the disease itself and the vector and its habits. There are people who still think that the Aedes aegypti mosquito breeds in water that flows in drains and unclean pools. On the contrary, they should be made aware that Dengue mosquitoes breed in clean water,” he said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Teen arrested for killing brother
author: Author not found
Content: A 14-year-old boy was arrested over killing his brother in Thekkawatta, Kalutara on 7 February. The Police Media Division said the boy attacked his elder brother with a sharp object following a dispute between the two siblings. At the time of the incident, their mother had left the house to visit her husband who was in hospital. Police commenced investigations based on a complaint lodged on the 118 Police Emergency Hotline. Preliminary investigations revealed the boy had used a ‘Manna’ knife to attack his brother. The deceased was a 26-year-old resident of Thekkawatta, Kalutara. Kalutara South Police are conducting further investigations into the killing. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Pregnant women’s nutrition allowance increased to Rs 4,500
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment Geetha Kumarasinghe said Rs 2000 which was given to pregnant women to obtain nutrition has been increased to Rs 4,500 with effect from last month. She was speaking following a recent meeting held with officials from institutions coming under her purview. Kumarasinghe added pregnant mothers whose monthly income was below Rs 50, 000 could get the new amount from Divisional Secretariats.

title: Leprosy Eradication Conference in Trinco
author: Author not found
Content: A regional conference on leprosy eradication was held at the Office of the Regional Director of Health Services, Trincomalee on 30 January. The conference was chaired by Provincial Director of Health Services, Dr. D.G.M. Costa. The conference was attended by officials attached to the RDHS, representatives from Alliance Development Trust (ADT), and interfaith leaders of the Trincomalee District. Several aspects pertaining to leprosy, including issues faced by leprosy patients were discussed at the conference. Participants also decided to utilise resources at the MOH offices efficiently in the future. The ADT was also lauded by government officials for its efforts in combating leprosy. Participants included Eastern Province Provincial Director of Health Services, Dr. D.G.M. Costa, Trincomalee Regional Director of Health Services, Dr. V. Premananth, Provincial Epidemiologist, Dr. S. Arulkumaran, Additional Government Agent of Trincomalee, Director Alliance Development Trust, Raghu Balachandran, Regional Manager – East, Alliance Development Trust, Jebasuthan Selvaretnam, and Regional Officer, Trincomalee District, Alliance Development Trust, P. Sivakumar.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Pregnant women’s nutrition allowance increased to Rs 4,500
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment Geetha Kumarasinghe said Rs 2000 which was given to pregnant women to obtain nutrition has been increased to Rs 4,500 with effect from last month. She was speaking following a recent meeting held with officials from institutions coming under her purview. Kumarasinghe added pregnant mothers whose monthly income was below Rs 50, 000 could get the new amount from Divisional Secretariats.

title: Leprosy Eradication Conference in Trinco
author: Author not found
Content: A regional conference on leprosy eradication was held at the Office of the Regional Director of Health Services, Trincomalee on 30 January. The conference was chaired by Provincial Director of Health Services, Dr. D.G.M. Costa. The conference was attended by officials attached to the RDHS, representatives from Alliance Development Trust (ADT), and interfaith leaders of the Trincomalee District. Several aspects pertaining to leprosy, including issues faced by leprosy patients were discussed at the conference. Participants also decided to utilise resources at the MOH offices efficiently in the future. The ADT was also lauded by government officials for its efforts in combating leprosy. Participants included Eastern Province Provincial Director of Health Services, Dr. D.G.M. Costa, Trincomalee Regional Director of Health Services, Dr. V. Premananth, Provincial Epidemiologist, Dr. S. Arulkumaran, Additional Government Agent of Trincomalee, Director Alliance Development Trust, Raghu Balachandran, Regional Manager – East, Alliance Development Trust, Jebasuthan Selvaretnam, and Regional Officer, Trincomalee District, Alliance Development Trust, P. Sivakumar.

title: India: The biggest friend of Sri Lanka – PM
author: Author not found
Content: Addressing the Tata Tiscon Dealer Convention 2023 on 7 February 2023 in Colombo, Dinesh Gunawardena, Prime Minister of Sri Lanka called on the Indian companies to invest further in Sri Lanka. Outlining the benefits of Indian investments in Sri Lanka,Sri Lanka highlighted that 90 per cent of components used by Lanka Ashok Leyland were indigenous. He also referred to India as the biggest friend of Sri Lanka in the time of crisis in his address. Speaking at the event, High Commissioner Gopal Baglay said that both the Government of India and Indian corporates are working to build relationships that are beneficial to the people within and beyond India, especially the neighbours, under Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s “Neighbourhood First” Policy. He added that the driving force behind this spirit of engagement was community-centered business practices and philosophy of Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam (world is one family). Referring to India and Sri Lanka as ‘civilisational twins’, the High Commissioner noted that both Governments are promoting people to people as well as business to business ties. He added that presence of numerous Indian business entities for the convention was the biggest vote of confidence not only in the relationship between the two countries but also in Sri Lanka’s potential.  Business and commercial linkages between the two countries are witnessing steady growth. India was the largest investor and also the biggest export destination for Sri Lanka in 2021. India continues to be the largest source of tourists as well. Indian companies in Sri Lanka actively support Sri Lanka’s economic recovery through increased economic activities, value addition of products, services, job creation for Sri Lankan nationals and direct assistance to the people of Sri Lanka through various CSR initiatives.

title: Rotary Italia Charity Car Rally on 12 February 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan in partnership with the Italian Car Enthusiasts Club (ICEC) will hold the inaugural Rotary Italia Charity Car Rally on 12 February 2023. We thank Hiran de Silva Director/CEO of Emergence Education Consultants (Pvt) Ltd coming forward as a Platinum Sponsor for this event. Emergence Education Consultants (Pvt) Ltd was established in May 2010 with the scope of providing consultancy service in education and career guidance to students who aspire to pursue higher studies overseas. With over 10+ years of experience in the industry, Emergence Education is now on its way to becoming a highly sought-after study abroad consultancy firm in Sri Lanka. Representing over 70 + reputed partner universities and colleges in Australia, Canada, the UK, Germany and New Zealand, Emergence Education is committed to deliver an excellent end-to-end service to students who dream of pursuing a world-recognized qualification in a leading university or college abroad. The expert team at Emergence Education adopts a holistic approach in advising students on the best higher education opportunities overseas. The comprehensive services provided by Emergence Education include: personalized guidance in selecting a university and a study program based on the interest, the careers in demand, academic and financial background of the student, assistance in obtaining scholarships, personalised visa guidance and career counselling. The Rotary Italia Charity Car Rally will kick off at 7 a.m. at the Excel World Car Park. The unique Charity Rally is organised as a charity event especially for fun loving car enthusiasts and for the Rotary Family of 3220. Entries are open to all cars of all makes and models. The participants of the rally can look forward to a fun-filled day of driving with camaraderie. This event is held with the objective of collecting funds to uplift two schools, Wethara Maha Vidyalaya and Olaboduwa Zoysa Maha Vidyalaya Gonapola in aid of construction of toilets and a computer lab. With each registration, a stationery pack will also be provided for a less fortunate child. These community development projects are initiated, monitored and managed by the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan. Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan (RCCM) President Dilini Hennayake said: “Our aim in organising this charity rally is to help build and empower our underprivileged communities.” We are helping to uplift two schools selected by us in Kesbewa area.  Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan has many projects that involve mainly less fortunate children of this country. Few projects that involve children are child friendly police station in Ragama, Two Hearts Project which help to fund children in the waiting list in LRH, Little Mind Strong Values which teach ethics and values to the children from songs, schools books project for caddies and minor staff children of Royal Colombo Golf Club and micro finance loans to 20 women in Trincomalee District. Italian Car Enthusiasts Club (ICEC) President Dayan Fernando said: “We are pleased to extend our partnership with the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan with their community development projects.” Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan is very happy to partner with Italian Car Enthusiasts Club (ICEC) for the first time and both clubs have worked hard to initiate the Rally for the first time. The platinum sponsor for the event is Emergence Education Consultant (Pvt) Ltd. Other partners for the event include Wheels Lanka, Wurth and Motormag Lanka.

title: People’s Leasing Offers Wadi’ah Gold Safekeeping Facility
author: Author not found
Content: People’s Leasing & Finance PLC (PLC) added PLC Wadi’ah Gold Safekeeping Facility to PLC product portfolio by opening up 3 units at Puttalam Al-Safa, Park Street Al-Safa and Kandy Al-Safa Branch Offices, a spokesman for PLC stated. Wadi’ah Gold Safekeeping Facility of PLC is an alternative to a traditional Gold Loan and a convenient solution for financially distressed people during their times of need. PLC Wadi’ah Gold Safekeeping Facility offers the customer the benefit of obtaining an Interest-Free loan for emergency cash requirements. The PLC Wadi’ah Gold Safekeeping Facility will be initially available at 75 Gold Loan operating branches island-wide and aims to make the facility available in the remaining ‘4 Islamic dedicated Branches’ by the end of February 2023 for customers’ convenience.

title: Court Clerk remanded till 16 February
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (8) ordered the Court Clerk who was arrested and produced before him by the CID, in connection with the case pertaining to the misplacement of gold items worth Rs 6.8 million, from the Court Productions Room of Court, to be remanded till 16 February. The suspect was identified as Mohammad Nashmi, who had served as the Caretaker of the Court Productions Room at the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court. The suspect was apprehended by the CID and then produced in Court yesterday. The CID prosecuting told Chief Magistrate Alwis, that at the time of the misplacement of the gold items, the suspect Court Clerk had functioned as the Caretaker of the Court Productions Room. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Cabinet decides to refrain from implementing recommendations
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam yesterday (8) informed the Court of Appeal that the Cabinet of Ministers has decided to refrain from implementing the recommendations of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) appointed to probe into political victimisation during the United National Front-led Government. This was when the Petitions filed by those including President Ranil Wickremesinghe, former CID Director Shani Abeysekara and JVP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake seeking an order quashing the recommendations made against them by the PCoI and the implementation of the recommendations was taken up. The Attorney General noted that while a Special Presidential Commission was appointed to look into the recommendations contained in the final report of the former Commission and to make suitable recommendation, the tenure of the Special Presidential Commission has expired and thereby the recommendations of the initial Commission is inoperative. Thereby the interim order issued staying the implementation of the recommendations of the PCoI on political victimisation was extended to 1 March. Former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa appointed a three-member Presidential Commission of Inquiry chaired by retired Supreme Court Judge Upali Abeyratne in January 2020 to inquire into political victimisation that had allegedly taken place between 2015 to 2019. While the final report of this Commission was submitted, a Special Presidential Commission was appointed to formulate a mechanism to implement the recommendations of the initial commission. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: CA reserves Order for 10 February
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (8) reserved the order on whether or not an interim order will be issued preventing the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) from imposing power cuts during the GCE Advanced Level Examination for 10 February. The Writ Application filed by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) seeking on order preventing power cuts during the A/L examination period was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. The Order so was reserved by the Court of Appeal after the conclusion of the case. It was stated in the Writ Application, that PUCSL did not recommend or approve power cuts during the A/L examination period and that such power cuts have heavily inconvenienced students. BY Faadhila Thaasim

title: Monkeys wreak havoc in Kokawewa
author: Author not found
Content: Owing to the presence of monkeys in Kokawewa, coming under the purview of the Galenbindunuwewa Divisional Secretariat, people are undergoing untold hardship on a daily basis, villagers of Kokawewa lamented. Villagers said these monkeys continue to destroy mangoes and king coconuts and added that some even tend to enter houses and steal pots containing rice and other food items. Hence, they said they have been forced to keep vigil around the clock to prevent monkeys from entering their residences and stealing their food and to protect their cultivations. They lamented that repeated complaints to Wildlife Officers fell on deaf ears. By Jayantha Diwulweva – Huruluwewa

title: Infant dies in three wheeler mishap
author: Author not found
Content: A nine-month-old infant died in a vehicle accident in Kurunegala on 7 February. The Police Media Division said a three-wheeler travelling from Yanthampalava towards Bamunugedera crashed into a utility truck when   the driver lost control of the vehicle. The driver and four other passengers in the three-wheeler who sustained injuries were admitted to the Kurunegala Hospital. However, a nine-month old child succumbed to injuries while receiving treatment at the hospital. Police said the passengers were residents of Bamunugedara, Kurunegala. Kurunegala Police are conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Compensation instalments in place
author: Author not found
Content: Action is in place to give the instalment of the compensation to fishermen in Negombo who were affected by the MV X-Press Pearl disaster, Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said. Devananda was responding to a question by fishermen during his recent visit to inspect development work  in the Negombo lagoon and the surrounding areas. He also said discussions are being held with relevant parties to provide fuel concessions to fishermen, affected following the increase in fuel prices. Representatives of fisheries societies in the area also brought to the Minister’s attention that the lagoon was being polluted due to waste water flowing from the Negombo Town. They also made a request to Devananda stressing the need to prepare a programme to purify the polluted lagoon. Fisheries Ministry Secretary Indu Ratnayake, Director General of Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Susantha Kahawatte and the Ministry officials had also been accompanied by Minister during the visit. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: JVP condoles with Turkiye earthquake affected
author: Author not found
Content: The JVP condoled with victims of the unprecedented earthquake in Turkiye which occurred on 6 February. The JVP’s international relations department said that as an organisation seeking solidarity and harmony among all people, they appreciate not only the people of Turkiye but many countries that have come forward to provide humanitarian emergency aid to the earthquake affected areas. While noting that as a people who were badly affected by the Indian Ocean tsunami in 2004, which caused the loss of more than 44,000 lives, they empathise with the tragedy and hardship the people of Turkiye were facing at this point and said the  JVP would not forget them for the  support and solidarity the latter extended during the tsunami tragedy. “We would like to extend our profound grief to the people of Turkiye and grieving families who lost their loved ones due to the unprecedented earthquake that hit your country. According to the latest news, more than 5100 deaths have been confirmed, but rescue teams fear the death toll may increase after more earthquakes rocked Turkiye and Syria.” “Many countries declaring to come to the assistance of the affected indicates the strong humanitarian bond that lies underneath various powerful forces that attempt to disrupt the humanitarian accord among the people. Further, while expressing condolences to grieving families, speedy recovery for the injured and expeditious normalcy in the regions, the JVP also said it wished all the strength and courage to the people of Turkiye to muster their forces to take on any catastrophe, whether natural or man made.” BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Teen arrested for killing brother
author: Author not found
Content: A 14-year-old boy was arrested over killing his brother in Thekkawatta, Kalutara on 7 February. The Police Media Division said the boy attacked his elder brother with a sharp object following a dispute between the two siblings. At the time of the incident, their mother had left the house to visit her husband who was in hospital. Police commenced investigations based on a complaint lodged on the 118 Police Emergency Hotline. Preliminary investigations revealed the boy had used a ‘Manna’ knife to attack his brother. The deceased was a 26-year-old resident of Thekkawatta, Kalutara. Kalutara South Police are conducting further investigations into the killing. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Cabinet nod for amending ETF Act
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approval was granted to amend Employees’ Trust Fund Act to provide health insurance, similar to the Agrahara health insurance, to private sector employees. Accordingly, the Legal Draftsman would be instructed to prepare a draft Bill to amend the Employees’ Trust Fund Act No. 46 of 1980. The Cabinet proposal, was presented by the President, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana revealed this yesterday (7) at the Cabinet media briefing. “The President, in his Budget 2023 speech, informed Parliament of the proposal to provide an insurance scheme, similar to Agrahara insurance, for both the  private and the public sector employees. This decision was taken to fulfil that promise,” he added.  “It is a known fact that Agrahara Insurance provides good health insurance to State sector employees. Our intention is to provide the same benefit to the private sector employees,” Gunwardena added. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: One Lankan reported missing, 13 others safe
author: Author not found
Content: One Sri Lankan was reported missing and 13 others were reported to be safe following devastating earthquakes in Türkiye, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said. Gunawardana, during yesterday’s (7), Cabinet media briefing, expressed condolences to people in Türkiye on behalf of the Government and the people of Sri Lanka. He said the Sri Lankan Ambassador in Türkiye had no information on the missing Sri Lankan who was in an earthquake-affected area. Meanwhile, the Sri Lankan Embassy in Türkiye has set up two emergency numbers to inquire about or provide information on Sri Lankans living in that country. The numbers are 00903124271032 and 009053445694998. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Students to get uniform material by 15 March
author: Author not found
Content: The task of distributing school uniform material will be completed by 15 March, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said. He said, the Chinese Government, which agreed to provide 70 per cent of the required uniform material, has already sent the first batch, and the remaining 30 per cent has been provided by local businessmen. The Chinese Government provided 8,862,990 metres of material as a grant, fulfilling 70 per cent of the school uniform material requirement for 2023. Acting Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Hu Wei officially handed over the stock to Education Minister Susil Premajayantha at the Colombo Port recently.

title: Govt spent only Rs 11M – PMD
author: Author not found
Content: The Government spent only Rs 11 million on the 75th National Independence Day celebrations and this figure is significantly less than past years, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. In a statement, the PMD said, false reports are being circulated about the cost of Independence Day celebrations this year and it is clearly another extension of the narrow political agenda that forced people to boycott the official State celebration of Independence due to the economic crisis. These forces even attempted to convince the people that even providing mobile toilet facilities during the Independence Day celebration was a mistake, the PMD said. “However, it should be emphasised that high-ranking foreign diplomats were invited to this celebration including Japanese State Minister for Foreign Affairs Takei Shunsuke, Bhutan’s Minister for Education and Skills Development Jai Bir Rai, Maldivian Foreign Minister Abdulla Shahid, Bangladeshi Foreign Minister Dr. A.K. Abdul Momen, Pakistan’s Minister of State for External Affairs Hina Rabbani Khar, Indian Minister of State for External Affairs V. Muraleedharan, Nepali Foreign Minister Dr. Bimala Rai Paudyal and Commonwealth Secretary-General Patricia Scotland. Further, around 3,200 dignitaries including ambassadors, high commissioners of foreign countries, as well as 6,670 armed forces personnel and the Police attended the ceremony. Also, these mobile toilet facilities were provided for the personnel engaged in rehearsals for the Independence celebration. In such a background, as a measure to provide proper health and safety measures for an event where thousands of people gather, it cannot be determined as an unnecessary expense for the provision of adequate mobile toilet facilities. It should also be noted that not paying adequate attention to such an essential aspect at an official state event where a large number of people gather, is a disgrace to the country.” The PMD further said the Education Ministry did not spend funds for the Independence Day celebrations.

title: Govt medical professionals stage 24-hour token strike
author: Author not found
Content: Government medical services will stage a 24-hour token strike from 8:00 a.m. today (8), in both State and private hospital clinics. However, essential medical services, such as Emergency Departments, Renal Hospitals and Units, and Children’s Hospitals and Units will continue uninterrupted. This action is taken to support the massive rally organised by over 40 trade unions against new tax scheme on the same day. Professional health services trade unions including Ayurvedic doctors and the Medical Faculty Teachers’ Union, will join engineers of the Ceylon Electricity Board, the Water Board, banking sector grade officers, Inland Revenue, Ports Authority, Government Joint Executives, and Airport Executives to stage a public rally. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam, said over 40 professionals’ trade unions including the above mentioned will gather at Hyde Park at 2:00 p.m. today (8) for a  rally against the new Inland Revenue Tax Act.   Dr. Ratnasingam said doctors in his outfit would carry out a token strike in State hospitals and the private sector against the Government’s oppressive tax policy. Only emergencies will be attended to during the strike while routine services will not be carried out for the day, he said. However, the union will exempt children’s hospitals and wards, women’s hospitals, Cancer Hospital and Unit, Tri-Forces hospitals, Renal Hospitals and Units. Dr. Ratnasingam said his outfit had met Central Committee Members and discussed at length the shortage of pharmaceuticals and the escalation of their prices, the Government’s rigidity and insensitivity towards proposals made by professional groups for the implementation of  a fair and transparent tax system, the damage caused to the country by the increasing brain drain as a result of the unfair tax system, the Government’s double standards in demanding sacrifices from the professionals and the public affected by the economic crisis while spending abundantly on the destructive and harmful matters such as the former President, Cabinet and Parliament as well as on the Independence Day ceremony. Expressing the dissatisfaction of union members, the GMOA Media Committee Member accused the Government of failing to prepare a recovery plan for the billions the country had lost through the large-scale fraud and corruption committed by government cronies. “It has failed to prepare a transparent programme to assess how that money was being utilised towards public betterment,” he said. Meanwhile the Government Dental Surgeons’ Association (GDSA) said it had been attempting to warn the Government of the detrimental and counterproductive impact the present new direct tax policy had on the country. “Even though we recognise the importance of taxes as a major source of income for the Government of Sri Lanka, as well as our need to pay reasonable and acceptable taxes in the form of direct and indirect taxes, the recent sudden dramatic increase in direct personal tax during the worst economic recession in Sri Lanka’s history is tangible on our members and all professionals,” GDSA General Secretary, Manjula Herath lamented.  “With the Government not responding favourably towards the GDSA’s demand, all grade dental surgeons will enter into a one-day token strike today (8) countrywide to force the Government to find an acceptable solution to this issue. All government dental surgeons will refrain from engaging in regular services and private channelling during this period,” he warned.  Dr. Herath said all emergency services will be maintained throughout the strike, while dental surgeons working in all maternity hospitals, children’s hospitals, and cancer hospitals will not participate in the strike. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Talks on to increase A/L answer script evaluation payments
author: Author not found
Content: Discussions are ongoing with the Finance Ministry over increasing the payment for GCE Advanced Level examination answer script evaluation and clearing the backlog of payments, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said. He said a Cabinet Paper was forwarded, by the Minister of Education, to increase the payments. It was approved, as a policy, by the Cabinet and payments would be made in consultation with the Secretary of the Ministry of Finance. Speaking further, Gunawardana said, if the exam results are delayed, it will have an impact on the children’s lives. Therefore, the results should be released as soon as possible in the best interests of the children. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: First container vessel MSC America arrives
author: Author not found
Content: MSC America, the first container vessel under the business promotion programme to attract new lines to the Port of Colombo (POC), called at the East Container Terminal (ECT) of the Port of Colombo yesterday (7). The latest programme to attract new shipping lines to the POC has been planned and implemented in collaboration with the Ministry of Ports and Shipping, Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA), Colombo International Container Terminals (CICT), South Asia Gateway Terminals (SAGT), Ceylon Association of Shipping Agents (CASA) and Sri Lanka Association of Vessel Owners (SLAVO) to effectively address strategic business promotions as a fruitful means to overcome the prevailing economic crisis. Attracting more new lines to the POC, increasing operational efficiency, expediting naval services, efficiency in logistics and warehouse management and container and cargo transportation are among the objectives. MSC America will be operated as a weekly caller to Colombo. On the first call, the vessel carried 2,300 TEUs to Colombo and is expected to carry 2,500 TEUs on a weekly basis. The vessel with a length of 334 m and a 7.5 m draft sails under the flag of Panama. The port rotation includes Singapore and South Africa. MSC is the largest global shipping line with a fleet of more than 775 TEU vessels for container transportation around the world. The shipping line that maintains long-term operations with the POC has a collaborative business relationship of more than 10 years with SLPA. Since 2015, it is the prime shipping line of the POC with an annual operational capacity of 2 million TEUs. It performs about 900 calls per annum at the POC. The deep draft vessels owned by MSC call at the CICT of the POC, whilst also calling at the SLPA-controlled JCT and ECT with more than 1 million TEUs per annum, becoming the main customer of the SLPA. According to MSC Lanka (Pvt) Ltd, the local agents for MSC shipping lines, another three new shipping lines under INGWE West Bound service, East Africa Express service and East Med Service will call at the POC this month. To mark MSC America’s first call at the POC, a special plaque exchange was held at the ECT of the SLPA between Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva and the Master of the vessel, Capt. Matlin Alexander. SLPA Chairman, Keith D. Bernard and several representatives of MSC Lanka (Pvt) Ltd also attended the occasion. Speaking at the occasion, Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva said, “With the deep draft of the East Container Terminal, there is ample potential for mega vessels to call at the port. The remaining development process of the terminal is expedited with an investment of Rs 5.9 billion. Today, a mega vessel of the MSC has contributed for container operations via the Port of Colombo. Similarly, four new services will be added to increase the capacity of the POC. That will increase our revenue. This has further strengthened the trust placed by the international shipping community in the Port of Colombo.”
