Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Students to get uniform material by 15 March
author: Author not found
Content: The task of distributing school uniform material will be completed by 15 March, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said. He said, the Chinese Government, which agreed to provide 70 per cent of the required uniform material, has already sent the first batch, and the remaining 30 per cent has been provided by local businessmen. The Chinese Government provided 8,862,990 metres of material as a grant, fulfilling 70 per cent of the school uniform material requirement for 2023. Acting Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Hu Wei officially handed over the stock to Education Minister Susil Premajayantha at the Colombo Port recently.

title: Govt spent only Rs 11M – PMD
author: Author not found
Content: The Government spent only Rs 11 million on the 75th National Independence Day celebrations and this figure is significantly less than past years, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. In a statement, the PMD said, false reports are being circulated about the cost of Independence Day celebrations this year and it is clearly another extension of the narrow political agenda that forced people to boycott the official State celebration of Independence due to the economic crisis. These forces even attempted to convince the people that even providing mobile toilet facilities during the Independence Day celebration was a mistake, the PMD said. “However, it should be emphasised that high-ranking foreign diplomats were invited to this celebration including Japanese State Minister for Foreign Affairs Takei Shunsuke, Bhutan’s Minister for Education and Skills Development Jai Bir Rai, Maldivian Foreign Minister Abdulla Shahid, Bangladeshi Foreign Minister Dr. A.K. Abdul Momen, Pakistan’s Minister of State for External Affairs Hina Rabbani Khar, Indian Minister of State for External Affairs V. Muraleedharan, Nepali Foreign Minister Dr. Bimala Rai Paudyal and Commonwealth Secretary-General Patricia Scotland. Further, around 3,200 dignitaries including ambassadors, high commissioners of foreign countries, as well as 6,670 armed forces personnel and the Police attended the ceremony. Also, these mobile toilet facilities were provided for the personnel engaged in rehearsals for the Independence celebration. In such a background, as a measure to provide proper health and safety measures for an event where thousands of people gather, it cannot be determined as an unnecessary expense for the provision of adequate mobile toilet facilities. It should also be noted that not paying adequate attention to such an essential aspect at an official state event where a large number of people gather, is a disgrace to the country.” The PMD further said the Education Ministry did not spend funds for the Independence Day celebrations.

title: Govt medical professionals stage 24-hour token strike
author: Author not found
Content: Government medical services will stage a 24-hour token strike from 8:00 a.m. today (8), in both State and private hospital clinics. However, essential medical services, such as Emergency Departments, Renal Hospitals and Units, and Children’s Hospitals and Units will continue uninterrupted. This action is taken to support the massive rally organised by over 40 trade unions against new tax scheme on the same day. Professional health services trade unions including Ayurvedic doctors and the Medical Faculty Teachers’ Union, will join engineers of the Ceylon Electricity Board, the Water Board, banking sector grade officers, Inland Revenue, Ports Authority, Government Joint Executives, and Airport Executives to stage a public rally. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam, said over 40 professionals’ trade unions including the above mentioned will gather at Hyde Park at 2:00 p.m. today (8) for a  rally against the new Inland Revenue Tax Act.   Dr. Ratnasingam said doctors in his outfit would carry out a token strike in State hospitals and the private sector against the Government’s oppressive tax policy. Only emergencies will be attended to during the strike while routine services will not be carried out for the day, he said. However, the union will exempt children’s hospitals and wards, women’s hospitals, Cancer Hospital and Unit, Tri-Forces hospitals, Renal Hospitals and Units. Dr. Ratnasingam said his outfit had met Central Committee Members and discussed at length the shortage of pharmaceuticals and the escalation of their prices, the Government’s rigidity and insensitivity towards proposals made by professional groups for the implementation of  a fair and transparent tax system, the damage caused to the country by the increasing brain drain as a result of the unfair tax system, the Government’s double standards in demanding sacrifices from the professionals and the public affected by the economic crisis while spending abundantly on the destructive and harmful matters such as the former President, Cabinet and Parliament as well as on the Independence Day ceremony. Expressing the dissatisfaction of union members, the GMOA Media Committee Member accused the Government of failing to prepare a recovery plan for the billions the country had lost through the large-scale fraud and corruption committed by government cronies. “It has failed to prepare a transparent programme to assess how that money was being utilised towards public betterment,” he said. Meanwhile the Government Dental Surgeons’ Association (GDSA) said it had been attempting to warn the Government of the detrimental and counterproductive impact the present new direct tax policy had on the country. “Even though we recognise the importance of taxes as a major source of income for the Government of Sri Lanka, as well as our need to pay reasonable and acceptable taxes in the form of direct and indirect taxes, the recent sudden dramatic increase in direct personal tax during the worst economic recession in Sri Lanka’s history is tangible on our members and all professionals,” GDSA General Secretary, Manjula Herath lamented.  “With the Government not responding favourably towards the GDSA’s demand, all grade dental surgeons will enter into a one-day token strike today (8) countrywide to force the Government to find an acceptable solution to this issue. All government dental surgeons will refrain from engaging in regular services and private channelling during this period,” he warned.  Dr. Herath said all emergency services will be maintained throughout the strike, while dental surgeons working in all maternity hospitals, children’s hospitals, and cancer hospitals will not participate in the strike. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Talks on to increase A/L answer script evaluation payments
author: Author not found
Content: Discussions are ongoing with the Finance Ministry over increasing the payment for GCE Advanced Level examination answer script evaluation and clearing the backlog of payments, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said. He said a Cabinet Paper was forwarded, by the Minister of Education, to increase the payments. It was approved, as a policy, by the Cabinet and payments would be made in consultation with the Secretary of the Ministry of Finance. Speaking further, Gunawardana said, if the exam results are delayed, it will have an impact on the children’s lives. Therefore, the results should be released as soon as possible in the best interests of the children. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: First container vessel MSC America arrives
author: Author not found
Content: MSC America, the first container vessel under the business promotion programme to attract new lines to the Port of Colombo (POC), called at the East Container Terminal (ECT) of the Port of Colombo yesterday (7). The latest programme to attract new shipping lines to the POC has been planned and implemented in collaboration with the Ministry of Ports and Shipping, Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA), Colombo International Container Terminals (CICT), South Asia Gateway Terminals (SAGT), Ceylon Association of Shipping Agents (CASA) and Sri Lanka Association of Vessel Owners (SLAVO) to effectively address strategic business promotions as a fruitful means to overcome the prevailing economic crisis. Attracting more new lines to the POC, increasing operational efficiency, expediting naval services, efficiency in logistics and warehouse management and container and cargo transportation are among the objectives. MSC America will be operated as a weekly caller to Colombo. On the first call, the vessel carried 2,300 TEUs to Colombo and is expected to carry 2,500 TEUs on a weekly basis. The vessel with a length of 334 m and a 7.5 m draft sails under the flag of Panama. The port rotation includes Singapore and South Africa. MSC is the largest global shipping line with a fleet of more than 775 TEU vessels for container transportation around the world. The shipping line that maintains long-term operations with the POC has a collaborative business relationship of more than 10 years with SLPA. Since 2015, it is the prime shipping line of the POC with an annual operational capacity of 2 million TEUs. It performs about 900 calls per annum at the POC. The deep draft vessels owned by MSC call at the CICT of the POC, whilst also calling at the SLPA-controlled JCT and ECT with more than 1 million TEUs per annum, becoming the main customer of the SLPA. According to MSC Lanka (Pvt) Ltd, the local agents for MSC shipping lines, another three new shipping lines under INGWE West Bound service, East Africa Express service and East Med Service will call at the POC this month. To mark MSC America’s first call at the POC, a special plaque exchange was held at the ECT of the SLPA between Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva and the Master of the vessel, Capt. Matlin Alexander. SLPA Chairman, Keith D. Bernard and several representatives of MSC Lanka (Pvt) Ltd also attended the occasion. Speaking at the occasion, Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva said, “With the deep draft of the East Container Terminal, there is ample potential for mega vessels to call at the port. The remaining development process of the terminal is expedited with an investment of Rs 5.9 billion. Today, a mega vessel of the MSC has contributed for container operations via the Port of Colombo. Similarly, four new services will be added to increase the capacity of the POC. That will increase our revenue. This has further strengthened the trust placed by the international shipping community in the Port of Colombo.”

title: Paris Club creditors provide financing assurances – PMD
author: Author not found
Content: The Paris Club creditors have provided financing assurances to support the International Monetary Fund (IMF) approval of the Extended Fund Facility for Sri Lanka. According to the President’s Media Division (PMD), the Paris Club members expressed their commitment to negotiate debt restructuring with Sri Lanka in accordance with the comparability of treatment principle with the goal of restoring debt sustainability. Saudi Arabia and India also expressed their support and commitment to provide financial assurances. The Paris Club members urged other official bilateral creditors, including China to do the same in line with IMF programme parameters, the PMD said. In a seven-point statement, the Paris Club said its members held a meeting on 25 January 2023, in the presence of representatives from Hungary, Saudi Arabia, the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development and India, as well as from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, to provide financing assurances to support the approval by the IMF Executive Board of the envisaged IMF programme for Sri Lanka, which would allow to restore the country’s macroeconomic stability. According to the statement, they examined the macroeconomic and financial situation of Sri Lanka, including its long-term debt sustainability, and the need for debt treatment by all bilateral creditors to both fill the financing gap and to ensure Sri Lanka’s debt sustainability in line with the proposed Extended Fund Facility. “We acknowledge that Sri Lankan authorities had the opportunity to present their economic and financial situation to its creditors, which underscored its need for debt treatment from all creditors. They also presented their reform programme that will be supported by an IMF arrangement requiring debt treatment to restore debt sustainability, as well as the prior actions already implemented. Paris Club members as well as Hungary, Saudi Arabia and India continue to look forward to working together along with all bilateral creditors and to engage with other key stakeholders to proceed with a comparable debt restructuring as soon as possible.” Shortly after the conclusion of a staff-level agreement between the Sri Lankan authorities and IMF staff on 1 September 2022, on a 48-month Extended Fund Facility arrangement, the Paris Club publicly stated its readiness to provide the necessary financing assurances in a timely manner and in coordination with other bilateral official creditors. To this end, the Paris Club has been engaging proactively with Sri Lankan authorities, the IMF, and Sri Lanka’s other official bilateral creditors, including by sharing its technical analysis to enhance the bilateral official creditors’ collective understanding of the need for debt treatment, the statement said.  “To support the implementation of the envisaged IMF supported programme and the Sri Lankan authorities’ efforts with other official bilateral creditors, Paris Club members, jointly with Hungary, expressed their full commitment to negotiate with Sri Lanka terms of a restructuring of their eligible claims, in accordance with the comparability of treatment principle among all bilateral creditors, and with the goal of restoring debt sustainability with due regard to targets and overall macroeconomic goals under the Extended Fund Facility. Saudi Arabia expressed its support for the process and acknowledged the importance to offer financing assurances in the near future. Members further expressed appreciation for the specific and credible financing assurances issued by India on 16 January 2023 and its coordination with the Paris Club. The Paris Club members as well as Hungary and Saudi Arabia urged other official bilateral creditors, including China, to do the same in line with IMF programme parameters as soon as possible. Paris Club members further noted the Sri Lankan authorities’ commitment to seek from all its commercial creditors and other official bilateral creditors a debt treatment on terms at least as favourable, and to hold all creditors in arrears until a comparable debt treatment is provided.” The Paris Club was formed in 1956. It is an informal group of official creditors whose role is to find coordinated and sustainable solutions to the payment difficulties experienced by borrower countries. A staff-level agreement was concluded between Sri Lankan authorities and the International Monetary Fund staff for a 48-month arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) on 2 September. Sri Lanka’s bilateral official creditors which are Paris Club members are Japan, France, Korea, Germany, the United States of America, Spain, the Netherlands, Russia, Sweden, Austria, Canada, the United Kingdom, Denmark, Belgium, and Australia. Non-Paris Club members include China, India, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Hungary, Iran, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.

title: Asirwatham  meets Luxembourg’s Foreign Affairs SG
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Belgium and Luxembourg and Head of Mission to the European Union Grace Asirwatham met Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs of Luxembourg Jean Olinger on 3 January, in Luxembourg.  During the meeting, Ambassador Asirwatham briefed the Secretary-General on the current political and economic situation in Sri Lanka and informed him of the measures taken and reforms being introduced to achieve sustained economic recovery and accelerated social and economic advancement in the country. Secretary-General Olinger commended Sri Lanka’s resolve to make a swift recovery from the unprecedented economic crisis and recommended that Sri Lanka explore the market opportunities for trade and tourism in Luxembourg to contribute to the economic recovery drive taking place in Sri Lanka. The discussion also focused on the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Sri Lanka and Luxembourg, and they agreed to expedite the pending bilateral arrangements for the mutual benefit of the two countries.  Secretary-General Olinger appreciated the Embassy’s decision to host a diplomatic reception in Luxembourg to commemorate the twin occasions, namely the 75th anniversary of Sri Lanka’s independence and the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations. He remarked that such an occasion would create awareness about Sri Lanka in Luxembourg and promote economic relations between the two countries.

title: Cabinet Decisions
author: Author not found
Content: Skill verification programme with ‘Takamol Company’ of Saudi Arabia A programme is being implemented by the Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission under the Ministry of Education and the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau in coordination with the relevant stakeholders and in consultation with the skill verification officials of foreign countries to standardise the qualifications of Sri Lankan skilled workers with foreign countries. It will allow migrant workers to take up overseas employment with higher value, respect and greater economic benefits. Thus, it has been proposed to enter into an agreement between Takamol Company, a Government-owned business services company under the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Development of Saudi Arabia, and the Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission of Sri Lanka. The draft agreement has received the clearance of the Attorney General and the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Education to sign the relevant agreement. Agreement between SLRC and Turkish Radio and Television Corporation In the second session of the Sri Lanka- Türkiye Joint Committee on Economic and Technical Cooperation held in 2021, it has been proposed to sign a cooperation agreement between the Sri Lanka Rupavahini Corporation and the Turkish Radio and Television Corporation with the aim of further strengthening trade, economic and technical cooperation between the two parties. The draft agreement has received the clearance of the Attorney General and the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Mass Media to sign the relevant agreement. MoU between SL and Maldives on Cultural Cooperation A cultural cooperation agreement has been proposed to be signed between Sri Lanka and Maldives. The draft agreement has received the clearance of the Attorney General and the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs to sign the relevant agreement. Colombo Port City Economic Commission Act No. 11 of 2021 The Colombo Port City (Offshore Company Registration) Order No. 1 of 2022 enacted under the Colombo Port City Economic Commission Act No. 11 of 2021 has been published in the Gazette Extraordinary bearing No. 2306/54 dated 17 November 2022. The proposal presented by President Ranil Wickremesinghe in his capacity as the Minister of Investment Promotion to present the said orders in Parliament for approval was approved by Cabinet. Submission of Welfare Benefits Act No. 24 of 2002 Regulations for payment of welfare benefits (section of eligible persons for receiving payments) as per the provisions No. 1 of 2022 subject to Section 27 of Welfare Benefits Act No. 24 of 2002 has been published in the Extraordinary Gazette Notification dated 20 October 2022. Further, consolidated welfare management systems regulations No. 2 of 2022 under Electronic Transaction Act No. 19 of 2006 has been published to prepare electronic reports and documents to perform tasks and activities of the Welfare Benefits Act No. 24 of 2002 and to maintain an information system related to the same by the Gazette Extraordinary dated 29 November 2022. Cabinet approved the resolution furnished by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies to submit the aforementioned regulations to Parliament for its concurrence. Amendment of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Act No. 2 of 1996 Approval was granted at the Cabinet meeting held on 21 December 2020 to increase the penalties for disturbances caused to authorised officers when implementing the provisions of the Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Act No. 2 of 1996 and to prepare a draft Bill to revise the said Act including the provisions for regulating illegal actions. Accordingly, clearance of the Attorney General was granted for the draft Bill.  Cabinet approved the proposal furnished by the Minister of Fisheries to publish the said draft Bill in the Government Gazette and to table the Bill in Parliament. Amendments to Partition Law Approval was granted at the Cabinet meeting held on 5 October 2021 to draft a Bill to amend the Partition Law including provisions applicable to present requirements. Clearance of the Attorney General has been granted for the draft Bill. Cabinet approved the proposal of the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms to publish the draft Bill in the Government Gazette and thereby submit to Parliament. Import and Export (Control) Act No. 1 of 1969 Cabinet approved the resolution furnished by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies to submit import control regulations, for payment methods No. 3 of 2023 which have been published by the Extraordinary Gazette Notification dated 19 January under the Import and Export (Control) Act No. 1 of 1969 to Parliament. Draft Bill of Finance  (Special Provisions) Act The requirement to introduce a draft Bill with the objective of managing funds owned by State establishments was tabled in Parliament by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies through a supplementary budget proposal in 2022. Cabinet approved the resolution submitted by the President to direct the Legal Draftsman to prepare a draft Bill to supervise the statutory funds systematically maintained by Ministries, Departments and other State institutions and to implement a programme. (TR)

title: Sri Lanka on the path to becoming a green economy – President
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka has the potential to transition to a green economy, especially by way of renewable energy, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said, addressing a high-level event on Strategies and Actions to Accelerate Sri Lanka’s Transition to a Green Growth Pathway, held at the Grand Ballroom, Hilton Colombo on Monday (6). He further said the Government prepared a National Adaptation Plan and National Environment Action Plan to ensure a green economy and a better world by 2050. The event was organised by the Ministry of Environment and the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI). A new Climate Change Act will be formulated while a new Environment Act will be drafted to replace the old one which will cover reforestation, forest cover and tree cover. He said Sri Lanka is to be the first country in the region to recognise some of its natural assets as living entities. The Knuckles Range, Horton Plains, Peak Wilderness, the Sinharaja Forest, the Mahaweli River, and Adam’s Bridge will thus be identified as living entities. The President welcomed the eighth Secretary-General of the United Nations and the President of the Assembly and Chair of the Council of the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) Ban Ki-moon for the signing of the Host Country Agreement with the Global Green Growth Institute. Hence, Ban Ki-moon will be associated with two historic agreements signed in Sri Lanka in which the first paved the way for reconciliation. “We are seriously concerned of the situation on climate change and the actions taken. What has happened so far is insufficient and the last conference of parties did not achieve the results that we desired. The low income countries and the middle income countries are striving for economic development while protecting living standards with insufficient funding. So, these countries are committed to a call for action by the developed countries to deliver their funding pledges by doubling their funding which is essential,” the President said. “I realise that some developed countries are experiencing a recession this year, but nevertheless the targets had not been met earlier. So, there has to be a full commitment of how we are going to meet the targets and what assistance is required. The other issue is the need for compensation for the developing countries where the emissions so far were not the responsibility of our countries. The third issue is how to address the loss and damages. This is not the issue of asking the developed countries to spend a lot of money for further development of the developing countries. Let us work out a sort of list, combine the money that is needed and then see how we are going to raise it. There has to be a contribution by them, as well as a contribution by us. But let’s agree on what we have to do.”

title: Foreman of private construction firm remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Horana Chief Magistrate Chandana Kalansuriya remanded, till 10 February, the foreman of a private construction company, who was produced in Court over the death of a young scientist. The suspect foreman was Dimuthu Lonesuhewa. He was produced in Court on charges of Reckless Endangerment. The deceased, 37-year-old Vimukthi Jayaweera, was a resident of Kumbuka East, Gonapola. He died when his vehicle collided with an unsecured roadblock on the Horana-Colombo main road. The roadblock was left behind by contractors working for a leading telecommunication company. The Traffic OIC of Moragahahena Police told Court the accident could have been averted if the contractor displayed warning signs on the road and followed safety protocols. By Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: PUCSL Writ fixed for support
author: Author not found
Content: The Writ Application, filed by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), seeking an order preventing the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) from imposing power cuts during the GCE Advanced Level examination period, was fixed for support on 8 February. This was when the Writ Application was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola yesterday (6). The two-Judge Bench further allowed the Petitioner to amend the Writ Application and ordered to make written submissions in regard to whether the members of the PUCSL have consented to proceed with the Petition today (7). It was stated in the Writ Application, that PUCSL did not recommend or approve power cuts during the A/L examination period and that such power cuts have heavily inconvenienced students. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Archbishop Gomis laid to rest
author: Author not found
Content: At a solemn funeral service held at St Lucia’s Cathedral Kotahena, where the late Emeritus Archbishop of the Colombo Archdiocese, Rev. Dr. Oswald Thomas Colman Gomis was laid to rest in the crypt within its premises.  In an emotional sermon rendered during Holy Mass yesterday (6), Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith said that present times called for the clergy to raise their voices and intervene for people, during their time of trouble, in a manner in which they would feel. They should speak in order to free them. They should be guided towards freeing themselves from being prisoners of cruel selfishness and power hunger, he said. “We should recollect what freedom we won despite celebrating 75 years of Independence,” he said observing that a change should be created within society by religious leaders. There is great need to allow law to be enacted as the law, while society should be cleansed of injustice and corruption,” Cardinal Ranjith said. However, in all this religious leaders should be at the forefront as they have the greatest responsibility towards the people, Cardinal Ranjith noted.             Apostolic Nunciature for the Diplomatic Mission of the Holy See,  Archbishop Brian Udaigwe, read the messages of condolence sent by Pope Francis and Cardinal Louis Antonio Gokim Tagle, Pro-Prefect of the Dicastery for Evangelisation. While Rector at St Aloysius William Evans Liyanarachchi announced the condolences for the Catholic Clergy in the Archdiocese of Colombo, the Chancellor of the Kelaniya University, the Kelaniya Rajamaha Viharaya, Kollupitiye Mahinda Sangarakkiitha Thera delivered the Buddhist Sermon.  Former Minister of Christian Affairs, John Amaratunga, read out the President’s message while, Spokesman for the Opposition Leader Kavinda Makalanda read out the Opposition Leader’s Message. Family member, P.A.T. Perera delivered the thanksgiving speech for the family members of the late Emeritus Archbishop of Colombo, Rev. Dr. Gomis. The Dr. Gomes’s last rites, which followed, were conducted by Apostolic Nunciature for the Diplomatic Mission of the Holy See and Rev. Dr. Harold Anthony Perera of the Bishop’s Conference. The late Rev. Dr. Gomis was interred in the crypt a midst floral tributes by the Catholic Clergy. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Case against Rajitha fixed for pre-trial conference
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (6) fixed 21 March, for the Pre-Trial Conference of the case against former Fisheries Minister Rajitha Senaratne and two others. Senaratne and two others, namely former Chairman of the Fisheries Corporation Upali Liyanage and its former Managing Director Neil Munasinghe, had been indicted on five counts before the High Court on 20 August 2020. The trio have been charged with causing a loss of revenue to the State over the lease of the Modera Fisheries Harbour to a private form from 1 August to 1 November nine years ago and for flouting Provisions contained in Sections of the Bribery Act via their actions. The Bribery Commission indicted Liyanage and Munasinghe, for aiding and abetting the activities of first accused Senaratne. The prosecution has also submitted 17 witnesses, along with 55 Court productions, to substantiate the charges filed against the three accused. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Laugfs gas up
author: Author not found
Content: Laugfs Gas announced that it had increased the price of its domestic LP gas with effect from midnight yesterday (6). Accordingly, the price of a Laugfs 12.5kg LP cylinder of gas has been increased by Rs 200 and the new price will be Rs 5,280. The price of a 5kg cylinder has been hiked by Rs 80 and the new price is Rs 2,112 while a 2kg cylinder has been increased by Rs 32 with the new price now Rs 845.

title: Spices bring in USD 455M profit
author: Author not found
Content: Development Director of the Department of Export Agriculture (DEA) Janaka Lindara said a profit of USD 455 million has been made by the country, via the export of spices and products last year. He explained the aforementioned profit had been gained through the export of 58,000 MT of spices such as cinnamon, pepper, cloves, nutmeg and coffee. Lindara revealed these details during a media briefing convened at the DEA premises in Peradeniya recently. According to him the highest revenue amounting to USD 217 million had been accrued through the export of 18,200 MT of cinnamon in 2022. He noted that the demand for quality spices from Sri Lanka has continued to increase in the international market. The revenue streams from exports should augur well for the recovery of the country’s economic crisis, he added. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: JJB pledges to make education a Fundamental Right
author: Author not found
Content: While pledging to make education a fundamental right of the people when the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) comes to power, its leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake said after that the people can go to Supreme Court to file a case against the  Government if there are no basic facilities in schools. Dissanayake noted that Government is responsible for the education of every child and it is not fair to differentiate education of students based on their economic levels. Speaking during a meeting with teachers in Matara recently, he stated that education must be made a right through the Constitution. The True Foundation of Singapore lies in its education and in Singapore 58 per cent of the children who enter to the grade one class leave as graduates, Dissanayake said. He added 20 per cent of the students are professional diploma holders in Singapore. However, only 38,000 children who enter the first grade enter universities in Sri Lanka and it is only 11 per cent. Therefore, improving the current education system is the main task of the JJB, Dissanayake said. He promised that a JJB Government would not allow a child who enters the first grade to drop out of school without educational competence or professional competence. Speaking further Dissanayake expressed his concern that in 2016/2017, 30,000 out of 330,000 students dropped out of schools before sitting the GCE Ordinary Level examination. He said that 84 per cent of the people who were remanded in 2019 were school drop outs.  “The burden of education placed on the people should be gradually reduced. The child, the teacher and the parents should together decide what line of study the child will take after grade eight. Every parent attempts to make their children an engineer or a doctor now. We need to change the social acceptance of our professions. Every profession should be given value and respect,” he added. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Handungoda released on bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (6), released on bail in two sureties of Rs 200,000 each, social media activist and political vlogger Darshana Handungoda, who was arrested at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake.  The Magistrate strictly warned the suspect not to make statements that could be a threat to the national security and could influence public tension, to which the suspect agreed. The case was then fixed for 17 May. He was arrested by Immigration and Emigration at the airport upon arriving in the country from Dubai.  Handungoda was arrested over the release of a video, allegedly promoting violence in front of Temple Trees, on social media on 9 May 2022. By Hansi Nanayakkara and Keerthi Mendis

title: Egg producers withdraw petition
author: Author not found
Content: The Petition filed by the Egg Producers’ Association, challenging the Extraordinary Gazette issued in August 2022 setting a maximum retail price (MRP) of eggs, was withdrawn by the Petitioner yesterday (6), on the basis that they are satisfied with the new MRP for eggs. This was following a request made by the Petitioner to Court of Appeal Judge K.A. Swarnadipathi. The Court of Appeal on 15 December 2022 issued an interim order suspending the Extraordinary Gazette until the final determination of the Petition. Additional Solicitor General Sumathi Dharmawardena, appearing on behalf of the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA), informed Court that due to the suspension of the Gazette, approximately over 25 million eggs have been sold at a higher price and thereby sought litigation cost. Court held that a decision pertaining to such request will be delivered on 30 March. According to the Extraordinary Gazette Notification, issued by the CAA Chairman, under the powers vested in him by Section 20 (5) of the Consumer Affairs Authority Act, No. 9 of 2003 on 19 August 2022, a maximum retail price of Rs 43 was set for white eggs and Rs 45 was set for brown/red eggs. The Gazette Notification prohibited manufacturers, producers, suppliers, distributors and traders from exceeding this price. A new Gazette Notification stipulating a new MRP for eggs was issued on 20 January according which a maximum retail price of Rs 44 was set for white eggs and Rs 46 was set for brown/red eggs. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Govt might opt for snap general election – Kiriella
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Lakshman Kiriella alleged that the Government might plan to dissolve Parliament and opt for a snap General Election within the next three months as the country’s economic crisis continues to worsen. He made this remark while taking part at an event held to declare open the party’s Kandy District Election Operations Office recently. The MP added that the Government is running scared of facing any kind of election as they are unable to face the wrath of the people. Also, there aren’t sufficient funds to conduct a poll, he added. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sri Lanka offers rescue services to quake hit Turkiye
author: Author not found
Content: Following a series of devastating earthquakes hitting Turkiye, Foreign Minister Ali Sabry yesterday (6), on the instructions of the President, offered rescue service assistance from Sri Lanka. More than 1,700 were confirmed dead in Turkiye and Syria after two large earthquakes, at the time this edition went to print. According to Sri Lanka Ambassador in Turkiye, Hasanthi Dissanayake, 13 Sri Lankans from the affected areas were found and are safe. Turkiye has raised the official death toll from the earthquakes to 1,121, Reuters reported, citing the country’s emergency AFAD disaster agency, bringing the combined total in Turkiye and Syria to over 1,700 confirmed dead. Syria’s health ministry said earlier that more than 326 people had been killed and 1,042 injured. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Assistance (OCHA) has put the death toll in the areas of north-west Syria, that the government does not control, at 255 killed and 811 injured. The first quake struck as people slept overnight and measured a magnitude 7.8, one of the most powerful quakes in the region in at least a century. It was felt as far away as Cyprus and Cairo. The European Mediterranean Seismological Centre (EMSC) said preliminary data showed the second large quake measured 7.7 magnitude, and was 67km (42 miles) north-east of Kahramanmaraş. In 1999, a tremor of similar magnitude to today’s quakes in Turkiye devastated Izmit killing more than 17,000. Turkiye’s president, Recep Tayyip, Erdoğan has described it as the worst disaster for the country since 1939, when an earthquake killed more than 32,000 people and injured more than 100,000. (With inputs from foreign news agencies)

title: Better days by this year’s Esala Perahara – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe and former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa attended inauguration of the Colombo Gangaramaya Temple Nawam Perahara on Sunday (5) night. The duo jointly placed the Karanduwa containing Sacred Relics on the elephant. Speaking on the occasion, President Wickremesinghe said, the country could experience economic respite by this year’s Esala Perahara season in August. “The Colombo Navam Perahara is held in conjunction with the 75th anniversary of Sri Lanka’s independence. This Navam Perahera and the Gangaramaya Temple are linked to the country’s freedom movement. It is worth noting that Venerable Hikkaduwe Sri Sumangala Nayaka Thera founded the Gangaramaya Temple,” the President said. “I don’t need to elaborate on the service rendered by him to this country. He assumed the reins of power and worked for the revival of Buddhism. He greatly assisted Migattuwatte Gunananda Thera during the Panadura Debate as well as to establish the Vidyodaya Piriwena. Col. Olcott established several major Buddhist schools, including Ananda Vidyalaya in Colombo. Through the Pirivena movement, Venerable Hikkaduwe Sri Sumangala Nayaka Thera also worked to create a new generation of followers.”

title: Massive Strike Tomorrow Against New Tax System
author: Author not found
Content: Massive trade union action has been planned, for tomorrow (8), by over 40 professional unions against the newly introduced tax system. Doctors would refrain from their private medical practice too. The doctors warned they would take their strike to the private sector tomorrow (8), demanding the Government amend the new Inland Revenue Act immediately.  Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam yesterday (6) said, his outfit would decide on their mode of trade union action during their meeting with the GMOA Branch Union Members. However, as of now it has been decided that all professional Health Service Trade Unions would resort to a strike both in the State and private sectors. “As to whether it would be a token strike for over 24 hours or four hours would be decided today (7),” he noted adding that doctors, Dental Surgeons, Medical Specialists, Medical Faculty Teachers (who are also doctors), Ayurvedic doctors and other health service professionals would join this strike. He said that professional trade unions in the health services would be joined by Bankers, Engineers, and sections of the Sri Lanka Administrative Services in their strike against the unjust tax policy of the government. There are over 40 professional trade unions in the Professional Trade Union Alliance (PTA) that would take part in a rally at Hyde Park tomorrow (8) against the new Inland Revenue Act.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: PUCSL Writ fixed for support
author: Author not found
Content: The Writ Application, filed by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), seeking an order preventing the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) from imposing power cuts during the GCE Advanced Level examination period, was fixed for support on 8 February. This was when the Writ Application was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola yesterday (6). The two-Judge Bench further allowed the Petitioner to amend the Writ Application and ordered to make written submissions in regard to whether the members of the PUCSL have consented to proceed with the Petition today (7). It was stated in the Writ Application, that PUCSL did not recommend or approve power cuts during the A/L examination period and that such power cuts have heavily inconvenienced students. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Archbishop Gomis laid to rest
author: Author not found
Content: At a solemn funeral service held at St Lucia’s Cathedral Kotahena, where the late Emeritus Archbishop of the Colombo Archdiocese, Rev. Dr. Oswald Thomas Colman Gomis was laid to rest in the crypt within its premises.  In an emotional sermon rendered during Holy Mass yesterday (6), Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith said that present times called for the clergy to raise their voices and intervene for people, during their time of trouble, in a manner in which they would feel. They should speak in order to free them. They should be guided towards freeing themselves from being prisoners of cruel selfishness and power hunger, he said. “We should recollect what freedom we won despite celebrating 75 years of Independence,” he said observing that a change should be created within society by religious leaders. There is great need to allow law to be enacted as the law, while society should be cleansed of injustice and corruption,” Cardinal Ranjith said. However, in all this religious leaders should be at the forefront as they have the greatest responsibility towards the people, Cardinal Ranjith noted.             Apostolic Nunciature for the Diplomatic Mission of the Holy See,  Archbishop Brian Udaigwe, read the messages of condolence sent by Pope Francis and Cardinal Louis Antonio Gokim Tagle, Pro-Prefect of the Dicastery for Evangelisation. While Rector at St Aloysius William Evans Liyanarachchi announced the condolences for the Catholic Clergy in the Archdiocese of Colombo, the Chancellor of the Kelaniya University, the Kelaniya Rajamaha Viharaya, Kollupitiye Mahinda Sangarakkiitha Thera delivered the Buddhist Sermon.  Former Minister of Christian Affairs, John Amaratunga, read out the President’s message while, Spokesman for the Opposition Leader Kavinda Makalanda read out the Opposition Leader’s Message. Family member, P.A.T. Perera delivered the thanksgiving speech for the family members of the late Emeritus Archbishop of Colombo, Rev. Dr. Gomis. The Dr. Gomes’s last rites, which followed, were conducted by Apostolic Nunciature for the Diplomatic Mission of the Holy See and Rev. Dr. Harold Anthony Perera of the Bishop’s Conference. The late Rev. Dr. Gomis was interred in the crypt a midst floral tributes by the Catholic Clergy. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Opposition attempting to gain political mileage
author: Author not found
Content: UNP MP Wajira Abeywardena claimed the Opposition is still acting for personal political gain without regard for the country or the people, who have been hard-hit by the economic crisis. “Many effective programmes are to be launched to rebuild the collapsed economy and restore normalcy. Many programmes launched last year have begun to pay off. Without a doubt, 2023 will be a watershed moment in Sri Lanka’s journey to become a developed nation,” MP Abeywardena said. MP Abeywardena was speaking to the media in Galle on 4 February evening in regard to the economic crisis and corrective measures needed to restore normalcy. “Not only the Government, but also people must act with dedication and make certain sacrifices to pave the way for a strong economy. 2022 was the worst year in our history. The youth fought for a system change. President Ranil Wickremesinghe always invited the Opposition and other political parties in Parliament to arrive at a national consensus,” Abeywardena said. He said UNP leaders initiated various development projects islandwide. “Governments led by the UNP laid the groundwork for infrastructure facilities needed to develop the country. The Accelerated Mahaweli Development Project and hydropower plants were among them.” Abeywardena added that without considering all these initiatives, the Opposition is gearing up for Local Government (LG) Polls. “This is the time to collaborate to rebuild the collapsed economy and to resolve burning issues of the people. The Opposition is fishing in troubled waters,” he said.  By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: No truth in FM hesitating to spend on polls rumours – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance, Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, said there is no truth in rumours that the Finance Ministry (FM) is hesitating to spend money for upcoming Local Government Election. However, it is the Finance Ministry’s responsibility to inform the Supreme Court of the country’s actual financial situation, he said. Speaking to the media on Sunday (5), the State Minister said as a responsible authority, the Secretary of Finance Ministry produced an affidavit to the Supreme Court indicating the current financial difficulties faced by Sri Lanka. “We do not want to use the Parliament to not release funds for the election. Such rumours are completely false. The Finance Ministry has no reason to be scared of holding an election. The concern here is the colossal amount of money that is needed to be spent for the election,” he stressed. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Protest demanding road repair
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was staged by the residents of Rattota demanding reconstruction of the badly dilapidated Rattota-Riverston road. They alleged that this road has been left to rack and ruin during the past four years. They observed that due to its present condition, many tourists visiting scenic locations in Mathale, Laggala and Rattota have been severely inconvenienced. Therefore, they urged the authorities to look into the present unstable condition of the road and carry out repairs without further delay. BY Mahesh Ruwan – Yatawatta

title: Thai Envoy opens ‘Art of Sri Lanka’
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Art of Sri Lanka’, an exhibition highlighting Sri Lanka’s pride, was held under the patronage of Poj Harnpol, Ambassador of Thailand to Sri Lanka, on 4 February at the J.D.A. Perera Gallery, University of Fine Arts in Colombo. As per President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s instructions, this exhibition was organised by veteran artist H. S. Sarath with the contribution of new and talented artists in conjunction with the anniversary celebration of the country’s independence. A large number of painters, of all ages from all over the country, including those involved in the ‘Aragalaya’, had submitted paintings for this art exhibition. This art exhibition, which commenced on 4 February, will be held till 10 February from 10.00 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. at the J.D.A. Perera Gallery, University of Fine Arts in Colombo 07.

title: Dilapidated road hampers tourism
author: Author not found
Content: The road leading up to several holiday resorts in Bentota, including the Prime Minister’s Bungalow, Senthara Club Paradise, a few tourist hotels and private inns is presently in a dilapidated condition. According to residents of the area even the public who utilise the nearby walking path for exercises are facing hardships as the road leading to it is currently not in a solid state. Residents said, at times of torrential rains the road becomes impassable and they stressed if this road is not repaired urgently it will dissuade scores of visitors, both local and foreign, from visiting Benthota which is a popular tourist destination. BY M. Meegahapala – Bentota

author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
