title: Ambassador-designate Jayaweera calls on the Lebanese FM
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador-designate of Sri Lanka to Lebanon, Kapila Jayaweera, paid a first courtesy call on the Minister of Foreign Affairs (FM) and Emigrants Abdullah Bou Habib at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Lebanon on 1 February 2023. Jayaweera conveyed greetings from President Wickremesinghe and the Government of Sri Lanka to the Government and People of Lebanon and briefed on the current resilience of the economy of Sri Lanka, the importance of maintaining strong bilateral relations and mutual partnership in international fora. He thanked the Government of Lebanon for facilitating the employment of Sri Lankans in Lebanon for several decades. The Foreign Minister warmly welcomed the Ambassador-designate and assured his full support to the Government of Sri Lanka and its people. He appreciated the contribution of the Sri Lankan community to Lebanon, and also extended felicitations for the 75th Anniversary of Independence Day of Sri Lanka. Following the meeting, Jayaweera called on the Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Ambassador Hani Chemaytelli, and discussed matters of bilateral interest. The Secretary-General appreciated the friendly relations that exist between Sri Lanka and Lebanon and assured his commitment to further strengthening cooperation between the two countries.

title: Devananda orders Peraliya fishery harbour development be completed
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda has instructed the Ceylon Fishery Harbour Corporation (CFHC) officials to take necessary action to complete the development works at Peraliya Fishery Harbour before Sinhala and Hindu New Year season. Devananda, who met the officials and fisher folk at Peraliya Fishery Harbour, during his recent inspection tour, pledged that every possible action has been taken to complete the ongoing development work. Devananda also expressed confidence that once the ongoing development work is completed facilities will be provided to a large number of fishing vessels, including more than 180 multi-day fishing trawlers, in Hikkaduwa, Dodanduwa and neighbouring areas off Galle. He said congestion prevailing in anchoring the vessels at Hikkaduwa and Dodanduwa fishery harbours can be prevented on a great scale subsequent to the development of Peraliya Fishery harbour. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: An HR strategy for achieving a debt -free Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka, despite its rich cultural heritage and natural resources, has been facing economic struggles in recent times, including a heavy debt load and a wide trade deficit. Despite efforts by the government to secure loans and implement austerity measures, the country remains mired in a debt crisis and continues to seek assistance from international organisations such as the IMF. A potential solution to boost GDP, from a human resource management perspective, is to invest in the development of the country’s workforce by re-skilling and upgrading the skills of current employees and ensuring that new workers possess the necessary qualifications for high-income jobs. One way to achieve this is by shifting the focus of education from traditional secondary education to tertiary-level education for students interested in pursuing it, and providing them with the knowledge and skills required to excel in high-income jobs. Furthermore, reducing the time spent on non-essential education such as GCE OL and AL and providing education that is more relevant to the workforce can also help to increase GDP. To combat corruption, it is crucial to implement measures such as increasing transparency and accountability in government, and enforcing anti-corruption laws and regulations. Instead of solely trying to eliminate corruption, investing in education and training programmes for the youth can equip them with the skills needed to succeed in the workforce and drive economic growth. The high failure rate at GCE O/L and low enrollment in higher education can lead to limited opportunities for young people, which can contribute to social unrest. To address this, the National Wage Policy should be reviewed, and the skill sets required for jobs in Sri Lanka should be identified and improved. Upskilling the workforce to meet the skill sets required for jobs in developed countries can help to increase productivity and innovation, and can also help to increase wages and improve living standards. Furthermore, renaming jobs to match similar names in the developed world can help to increase the recognition and value of those jobs. It is worth noting that many developed countries have abolished GCE O/L and GCE A/L and have only one exam for entering tertiary education, as it is more focused on the skills and knowledge required for specific jobs. This is a model worth considering for Sri Lanka. About the Author: Lalin I De Silva is a Former Senior Planter, Agricultural Adviser and Consultant, Former Secretary General, Ceylon Planters Society, Editor CPS Bulletin and Freelance Journalist By Lalin I de Silva

title: SL, Bhutan discuss education
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister, Dr. Susil Premajayantha met Bhutan’s Education Minister Jai Bir Rai, yesterday at the Education Ministry premises. An extensive discussion was held on the transformative educational reforms currently taking place in Sri Lanka. Dr. Premajayantha elaborated that Sri Lanka is focusing on upgrading the education administrative structure as a first step towards achieving rapid transformative educational goals. The discussion also focused on the educational processes in the SAARC countries and also on promoting higher education opportunities between Sri Lanka and Bhutan.

title: Promoted Judges sworn in
author: Author not found
Content: Justice K. P. Fernando, President of the Court of Appeal, took oaths as a Supreme Court Judge before President Ranil Wickremesinghe, yesterday morning (6), at the President’s House in Fort. Court of Appeal Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne took oath as the President of the Court of Appeal while High Court Judge M.A.R. Marikkar was also sworn in as a Judge of the Court of Appeal before President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, Commanders of the Tri-Forces and several other officials attended the event.

title: Unlawful assembly case against Mudalige et al fixed for 29 May
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (6) fixed 29 May to receive advice from the Attorney General, in connection with the case against 20 suspects, including Convener of Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Wasantha Mudalige and former Convener of the Inter University Bhikku Federation (IUBF) Ven. Rathkarawwe Jinarathana Thera. Twenty suspects have been charged, by Cinnamon Gardens Police, with staging a protest demonstration near the Lipton Roundabout while being members of an unlawful assembly, three years ago. The Chief Magistrate also lifted a bail condition, imposed on the suspects, which required them to report to the Police every month. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: French Envoy meets Navy Chief
author: Author not found
Content: The Ambassador of France to Sri Lanka, Jean-François Pactet met the Commander of the Navy Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera at the Navy Headquarters yesterday (6).  During the ensuing discussion, between them, Pactet and the Commander exchanged views on several matters of bilateral importance. Defence Attaché at the French Embassy in Colombo Commander Jean – Baptiste Trouche and Naval Assistant to the Commander of the Navy Commodore Kosala Warnakulasooriya were also present on this occasion. Signifying the importance of this occasion, the Commander of the Navy presented a memento to the French Ambassador.

title: 41 arrested in Facebook party raid
author: Author not found
Content: Panadura North Police arrested 41 persons, on 4 February, during a raid on a party, organised through Facebook. Police said the party was held at a hotel located in Horetuduwa. According to Police, eight men and two women were arrested with cannabis and 29 others, who were present, were also taken into custody.  Additionally, two others were arrested over a complaint lodged by a party goer claiming that she was sexually assaulted.  The suspects were aged between 20 and 40 years and were from Dehiwala, Galle, Kalagedihena, Balangoda, Rantapura, Mount Lavinia, Hettimulla, Colombo 15 and Kelaniya. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Goods worth Rs 5 billion languishing in Port warehouses
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva said about Rs 5 billion worth of goods, detained by Customs, were held up at the Port’s terminals and warehouses. He said about 89 containers imported into Sri Lanka and detained by Customs were stored in the Port’s terminals and warehouses for many years and hence it has not been possible to collect a levy for the containers. This was revealed at a discussion held at the Ministry of Ports recently under the patronage of Minister de Silva. “The Ports Authority has to face a huge financial loss and huge administrative issues due to space issues in warehouses and terminals, Port Authority officials pointed out. Among them were 12 containers of areca-nuts detained in 2015, 39 containers of basmati rice detained in 2019, 15 containers of tiles detained in 2020, five containers of auto spare parts detained in 2013, four textiles and stationery containers detained in 2019, 2020 and 2021 and four alcohol and ethanol containers,” he said. Officials pointed out that the Port Authority should charge a minimum of Rs 2,445 million as ground charges from these containers. In addition, it was revealed that around 40 cars and lorries, including two Benz and Range Rover cars detained since 2015 were languishing in the terminals. Meanwhile, Customs officials pointed out that there were delays in the Customs Ordinance. De Silva said Port and Customs officials should work together to amend the outdated Customs Ordinance to carry out an efficient clearance process according to the needs of the time. As the law does not permit the Ports Authority to recover moneys from Customs warehousing fees, the Minister instructed officials to remove the 89 containers including perishable goods within a week.

title: President opens ‘Path to Freedom’ exhibition at Colombo Museum
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘Path to Freedom’ exhibition, organised in view of the 75th National Independence Day, was opened yesterday (5) at the National Museum, Colombo under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The Department of National Museum, the Archaeological Department, and the Central Cultural Fund jointly organised the exhibition. The President was welcomed by Buddha Sasana, Religious, and Cultural Affairs Minister Vidura Wickramanayake. The President viewed the exhibits. The Director General of the National Archives Department, Dr. Nadira Rupasingha presented a collection of newspaper front pages reflecting unique moments in history relating to the freedom struggle between 1919-1972. Director General of the National Museums Department, Sanuja Kasturiarachchi presented four rare books reprinted courtesy UNESCO. A Gazette of the Central Province of Ceylon, Volume I & II, The Geology of Sri Lanka, Sigiri Graffiti Volume II and the Mahavamsa to the  President.  ‘Urumayaka Arumaya’, a collection of murals of the Kelani Vihara, Book of Buddha and bodhisattva, images of Ancient Sri Lanka, the book on Sathsathiya After the Enlightenment Based on Frescoes of the Kandyan Era, Ancient Ceylon Volume 26, Roots of Sri Lankan arts and History of the kingdom of Rohana was also introduced to the President by the Director General of the Department of Archaeology Professor Anura Manatunga. Meanwhile, the Director General of the Central Cultural Fund, Professor Gamini Ranasinghe also presented a to the President. President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Secretary to the Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Somaratne Vidanapathirana, and Buddhist Affairs Commissioner General Sunanda Kariyapperuma were present at the occasion. The Path to Freedom exhibition will be held at the Colombo Museum from 4 to 10 February from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President opens ‘Path to Freedom’ exhibition at Colombo Museum
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘Path to Freedom’ exhibition, organised in view of the 75th National Independence Day, was opened yesterday (5) at the National Museum, Colombo under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The Department of National Museum, the Archaeological Department, and the Central Cultural Fund jointly organised the exhibition. The President was welcomed by Buddha Sasana, Religious, and Cultural Affairs Minister Vidura Wickramanayake. The President viewed the exhibits. The Director General of the National Archives Department, Dr. Nadira Rupasingha presented a collection of newspaper front pages reflecting unique moments in history relating to the freedom struggle between 1919-1972. Director General of the National Museums Department, Sanuja Kasturiarachchi presented four rare books reprinted courtesy UNESCO. A Gazette of the Central Province of Ceylon, Volume I & II, The Geology of Sri Lanka, Sigiri Graffiti Volume II and the Mahavamsa to the  President.  ‘Urumayaka Arumaya’, a collection of murals of the Kelani Vihara, Book of Buddha and bodhisattva, images of Ancient Sri Lanka, the book on Sathsathiya After the Enlightenment Based on Frescoes of the Kandyan Era, Ancient Ceylon Volume 26, Roots of Sri Lankan arts and History of the kingdom of Rohana was also introduced to the President by the Director General of the Department of Archaeology Professor Anura Manatunga. Meanwhile, the Director General of the Central Cultural Fund, Professor Gamini Ranasinghe also presented a to the President. President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Secretary to the Ministry of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Somaratne Vidanapathirana, and Buddhist Affairs Commissioner General Sunanda Kariyapperuma were present at the occasion. The Path to Freedom exhibition will be held at the Colombo Museum from 4 to 10 February from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm.

title: Microfinance Trap Claims 225 Lives
author: Author not found
Content: The National Movement of Microfinance Loan Victims claimed 225 women opted to end their lives due to their inability to repay microfinance loans. Convener of the Movement, Nirosha Guruge said this was the official statistic, but it has been reported that some persons took their lives together with their children. She revealed these facts at a convention in Higurakgoda titled ‘Gewanna Ba; Kshudra Mulya Naya Ahosi Karanu’ (Can’t Pay; Do Away with microfinance loans). She also said the statement that microfinance loans would be cancelled was included in the Saubhagyaye Dekma policy because they requested it, and that it was limited to a single sentence. She said as far as they were concerned they had no obligation to the Government and will not settle the loans. She challenged the Government, stating that they will not settle the loans because they cannot and have no way to do so. “Our economic standing has deteriorated. We challenge the Government to do everything possible. We are proposing an outdated Law. A useless constitutional amendment has been proposed and we have been threatened with complaints against us. There are 3 million people against whom cases in this regard could be taken up. We are struggling to feed the children and serving prison sentences, this is no big deal for us,” she said. BY Anuradha Vishvanath – Anuradhapura

title: LCC requests USD 12.32M to pay for coal shipments
author: Author not found
Content: The Lanka Coal Company (LCC) has requested USD 12.32 million from the Minister of Power and Energy to pay for coal shipments. In a letter, LCC Chairman Shehan N. Sumanasekara, said the LCC had to make payments amounting to USD 12.32 million from 30 January to 3 February. He said LCC has made the 30 per cent payment for the 17th shipment due on 31 January. Further, the LCC was scheduled to make a 70 per cent payment on 2 February for the 12th shipment arriving in Puttalam with an original ETA by shipper reading as 6 February and a further 30 per cent advance payment for the 18th shipment on 3 February. “However, due to lack of funds at Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to meet these obligations, as stated in a mail by the CEB Finance Manager to LCC Finance Manager, we have requested CEB to make the required 70 per cent payment for the 12th shipment on 3 February and the 30 per cent advance payment of the 18th shipment was postponed to 6 February,” he said in the letter. “It is highly recommended we stick to the payment scheduleto have coal vessels arriving in Sri Lanka for uninterrupted power generation through the CEB Lakvijaya Coal Plant,” the LCC Chairman said.

title: Litro ups prices of domestic gas
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas Lanka yesterday (5) announced a price hike in domestic LP Gas. Speaking at a special media briefing held yesterday, Litro Chairman Muditha Peiris said the following price revisions will be effective from Sunday (5). The price of a 12.5 kg cylinder was increased by Rs 334 and the new price is Rs 4,743. A 5 kg cylinder was increased byRs 134 and the new price is Rs 1,904. A 2.3 kg cylinder was increased by Rs 61 and the new price is Rs 883.

title: OPEX Holdings MD found dead in Jakarta
author: Author not found
Content: Managing Director of OPEX holdings, billionaire businessman, 45-year-old Onesh Subasinghe was found dead under suspicious circumstances in an apartment in Jakarta, Indonesia. According to sources, the businessman was on a leisure trip in Jakarta along with his Brazilian wife, his four-year-old daughter and another Brazilian woman who was not identified as yet. Subasinghe was last in contact with his family in Colombo last Tuesday (2) and due to lack of contact thereafter, the family in Sri Lanka had contacted the apartment management and requested them to check up on Subasinghe. As the apartment management was unable to reach Subasinghe despite several attempts they had broken open the room door and the body of the deceased was found subsequently. When contacted, SL Ambassador in Jakarta, Dr. Jayanath Colombage said he got to know about the incident on 3 February from embassy staff. He also said CCTV footage showed Subasinghe’s wife, the daughter and the unidentified Brazilian leaving the apartment and had received information to the effect that they were Qatar-bound on their way to Doha. While noting that he had called for a report on the incident from Jakarta Police, Ambassador Colombage also said a brother and an uncle of the deceased businessman have already reached Indonesia following the incident. Family members who visited Jakarta after the incident have found that the trio had left the country on a Doha-bound flight on Tuesday, and their whereabouts are currently unknown.  Jakarta police is conducting investigations and it is suspected that the incident was a murder. The Foreign Ministry and Ambassador Colombage are also looking into what is a suspected murder. OPEX holdings website stated that Subasinghe held a Bachelor’s degree in Science from Cornell University, USA. His knowledge in investment, academics and experience brought meaningful gains to OPEX holdings. He was also known to take on business challenges which proved successful. OPEX is the first company in Sri Lanka to manufacture specialty liquid fertilizers for local and international markets, and has been the pioneer in the field of Integrated Nutrition Management in Sri Lanka.

title: Douglas N. Nanayakkara appointed PUCSL member
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies has appointed Douglas N. Nanayakkara as a member of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) following the resignation of two members last week. Secretary to the Treasury K. M. Mahinda Siriwardana in a letter to Nanayakkara stated that in terms of Section 3 (1) of the PUCSL Act No. 35 of 2002 of the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies has made the appointment with effect from 2 February 2023. It further stated that his term as a PUCSL member will conclude on 16 July 2024.

title: No politician truly serves country or people – Asgiri Mahanayake
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Prelate of the Asgiri Chapter, Most Ven. Warakagoda Gnanarathana Mahanayake Thera said every time an election approaches, the Government brings up an unnecessary issue and this time around it was the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. This was at a time when the majority of citizens were going hungry. He said no politician in this country truly serves the country or the people. While noting that there is no proper plan for anything in the country and that most politicians were only concerned about themselves, the Thera said priority should be given to resolving people’s current problems. The Thera was speaking when a group of members of the Union of Ministerial Secretaries visited him yesterday (5) to raise awareness about the setting up of a Product Promotion Regulatory Bureau in the country. According to Ajith Jayasundara, General Secretary of the Union, more than 150,000 economic development officers were getting monthly salaries without providing any service. Jayasundara said the Government pays more than Rs 6.75 million as monthly salaries to these development officers, which he noted was a crime. He said by setting up a Product Promotion Regulatory Bureau, young graduates will be able to contribute to development and enable the economy to gradually improve. Jayasundara said the draft will be sent to President Ranil Wickremesinghe soon and discussions will then commence. He also said the draft was prepared with the assistance of scholars and intellectuals. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Five SPs promoted SSPs
author: Author not found
Content: IGP C.D. Wickramaratne directed a group of Superintendents of Police (SP) to perform the duties as Senior Superintendents of Police (SSP) with immediate effect, due to the need for urgent duties. The Police Media Division noted that this directive has been given with the approval of the Secretary of Public Security Ministry and the Election Commission. Accordingly, SP S.H.D. Jay Chandrakumar was appointed SSP in the President’s Security Division (IV), SP M.R. Noordeenn was appointed SSP in the Special Bureau, SP Y. G.R.M. Rifad was appointed SSP in the Transport Division and SP K.B. Manatunga as SSP of the Child and Women Abuse Prevention Bureau. Additionally, SP M.H.K.S. de Silva Jayasekara was appointed SSP in the Prime Minister’s Security Division. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Our intention is to get all Opposition Forces together – Weerakkody
author: Author not found
Content: SLPP dissident MP Chandima Weerakkody appeared on the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) election platform in Galle recently. When Ceylon Today inquired from Weerakkody yesterday (5) about his showing up on the SJB platform on Saturday, he said he had no intention of getting SJB membership but would work towards forming ‘a grand opposition alliance’.  “I got on to the SJB stage as a part of the process to build a grand opposition alliance. Our intention is to get all opposition forces together, to build this country from the beginning. At the moment however, since the Government is reluctant to follow proper directions, we feel that it is the SJB that can resolve this issue for the people,” he said. He further said the SLPP does not consider him an SLPP member but that this did not affect him. “I was elected by the people and the purpose of my seat in Parliament is to serve them and I am answerable to them,” he said.  “Even at the Election, the SLPP leadership didn’t want people to vote for me. I don’t owe any explanation to those who obstructed my election campaign. I listen to the people who elected me. I go by the sentiments and expectations of the people who have elected me and trust me,” he added. “Our intention is to get all opposition forces under one umbrella,” Weerakkody further said. “All right-thinking people should get together to defeat the present Government. I got on to the SJB stage as a part of the process to build a grand opposition alliance,” he reiterated. He was seen on the SJB platform at a rally in Hiniduma in the Galle District. He however said, he would support Opposition Leader, Sajith Premadasa’s efforts to end starvation faced by the people. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: NEW PATH TO FULFIL NEEDS OF YOUTH ENVISAGED – PRESIDENT
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said the country was trapped in promises and endured slogans which finally resulted in the gradual collapse of the economy. The President said borrowings were increased to fulfil election pledges and agreed that slogans shouted at the protests were correct. He said money was borrowed more for consumption rather than for investment. He added that according to Buddhist philosophy loans should be taken for investment and not consumption.  While perpetuating Buddhism, actions he said were not in keeping with the Buddha’s teachings. Addressing the nation on the 75th Anniversary of Independence, he said the country has reached the point of destruction and there are those who want to keep perpetuating this wound forever, although he said it was not his wish. The President said, “After Independence we divided in terms of race, religion and region. The people were divided to the point of suspicion and animosity against each other. Various groups exploited this division to gain power and created further rifts among the people and instead of rejecting such groups, we gave power to these very same groups”. “In politics, lies were spread instead of the truth. Politicians who spoke the truth were rejected by the people. Those who pointed out the real situation of the country and sought related remedies were hardly given a place. Yet, those who satisfied people with their lies gained greater acceptance. We got trapped in a consensual political culture. Our characteristic was to depend on borrowed resources and we borrowed even more. We adopted the notion that, ‘The government is a spring of resources’. Many were of the view that the duty of the rulers was to distribute the various resources obtained from that spring, among the people. Accordingly, job opportunities were provided and various goods and equipment were also distributed.  Cash was also made available. In most instances, we did not vote on behalf of the country. Instead we voted for a candidate in order to get a job, to gain admission to a school for our children and to have a tender passed etc. We worked for political candidates expecting personal favours in return,” he said. He said “Most contested in the Election not for the sake of the country, but for personal power, for more perks and to earn a little more”. The President also said they were trapped in promises and endured slogans which finally resulted in the gradual collapse of the economy. “We borrowed increasingly to fulfil election pledges and he proved that the slogans shouted at the protests were correct. We borrowed more for consumption rather than for investment. However, according to the Buddhist philosophy one should take loans for investment purposes and not consumption.  While we are talking of Buddhism, our action is not in keeping with the Buddha’s teachings.” The President said there was only one way to overcome the crisis and achieve real economic and social freedom. “Youth who should work hard in different fields in this country are now standing in lengthy queues to obtain passports.  We need to change this situation too. To achieve this end we should modernise the economy and open it to the world. Corrupt political factionalism that deceived the people making them dependant and poor for ever should change.  This is the ‘system change’ that the youth of this country have been demanding for over a long period of time,” he said. The President said the Government has embarked on a new path of reform to fulfil the needs of youth and even though the decisions that have to be taken are painful, it has to be done in order to overcome the present morass..  “Hence, the basis and foundation for a strong new economy has already been formulated. We are successfully completing the difficult stage required to get support from the IMF. We expect to get their consent without delay. We cannot be satisfied just by strengthening the economy. The entire system needs to be changed. All areas of this political system, the Legislature, Parliament, Executive, State machinery, etc. should be modified to suit the modern era. For this system modification, we are proposing a number of orders to the Parliament,” he said. Speaking further he said immediate action needs to be taken in relation to the unique issues that the people in the North and East face. “A Cabinet subcommittee for this purpose has already been set up. I’m not attempting to treat the superficial condition with painkillers, but to treat the root cause of the malaise. It is challenging and difficult, but it’s our only option. I know that many of the decisions I have been compelled to take since assuming the presidency have been unpopular. We can become a developed country by 2048 if we work and move forward in a united and planned manner envisioning peace and reconciliation. There is the potential to become a developed country which is not begging from any other nation in the world. True freedom can be achieved and  it is possible,” he said.

title: Stepmother arrested for ill-treating 11-year-old girl
author: Author not found
Content: The Police Children and Women Bureau commenced investigations into a complaint lodged by an 11-year-old girl that her stepmother was ill treating her and she could not bear it anymore. The 11-year-old had lodged the complaint with the Horowapathana Police on 4 February. According to Police, the victim had trekked nearly four kilometres from her hometown to the Police Station to lodge the complaint. Police arrested the stepmother on the complaint and will institute legal action against her. Police said the mother of the victim had passed away five years ago and subsequently her father had re-married a woman who had a daughter from a previous marriage. The victim complained that her stepmother treated her own child with love and affection but was cruel and unkind to her. Unable to endure the torture anymore she had decided to lodge a complaint with the Police. Police added that the father of victim was severely warned to take care of his children and prevent such situations in the future.                                                 (NJ)

title: Higher education opportunities in Belarus
author: Author not found
Content: Providing higher education opportunities in Belarus to Sri Lankan students as well as implementing bilateral programmes to develop cooperation between the two countries for the advancement of higher education sector in Sri Lanka was discussed when Ambassador of Belarus, Andrei Rzheussky, who arrived in Sri Lanka from New Delhi, met Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha at the Ministry of Education. Premajayantha thanked the Belarusian Ambassador for the higher education opportunities and assistance provided by the State of Belarus to Sri Lanka. The Belarusian Ambassador then met with the heads of the Vocational Training Authority, the National Apprentice and Industrial Training Authority, the Skills Development Fund Ltd, the Sri Lanka Institute of Advanced Technical Education (SLIATE), the University of Moratuwa, and a private university. In addition, the Ambassador promised maximum support for skills development, technical education, training programmes, and exchange programmes in science and technology.

title: 50 handed over to President
author: Author not found
Content: Of the 500 buses to be given by the Indian Government  to uplift rural transport, 50 were handed over by Indian High Commissioner Gopal Baglay  to President Ranil Wickremesinghe  at the Presidential Secretariat premises yesterday (5).The President inspected two of the buses. The buses were given to coincide with the 75th Independence Day. The first fleet of 75 buses were handed over recently. Another 40 buses have been sent for registration. Hence 165 buses have already been given of the 500 buses that were pledged on Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardena’s request. The project is to be completed by March 2023.  President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed to direct the buses to SLTB bus depots islandwide to uplift rural transport across the country. Minister Gunawardena, State Minister of Transport Lasantha Alagiyawanna, State Minister of Investment Promotion Dilum Amunugama, MP Rajika Wickramasinghe, MP Muditha Prishanthi, First Secretary of Indian High Commission Irina Thakur, SLTB Chairman, Commissioner General of Motor Traffic, CEO of Lanka Ashok Leyland Umesh Gautam were present.

title: MILITARY MIGHT SHOWCASED AT INDEPENDENCE DAY PARADE
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka celebrated its 75th Independence Day with much fervour on a grand scale at Galle Face Green Colombo on 4 February 2023, under the theme ‘Namo Namo Matha – A step towards a century’. The Ceremony was held under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena. The National Anthem was sung by 105 students representing the School for the Blind- Ratmalana, Defence Services College- Colombo 2, D.S.Senanayaka College- Colombo 8, Buddhist Ladies College- Colombo 7, Musaeus College- Colombo 7, Muslim Ladies College- Colombo 4, Royal College- Colombo 7, Ramanathan Hindu College- Colombo 4, Zahira College- Colombo 10, Hindu College- Colombo 4, St. Anthony’s College- Wattala and St Bridget’s Convent- Colombo 7. Jayamangalagatha and Devo Wassathu Kaalena (blessings) were sung by 25 students representing Devi Balika Vidyalaya- Colombo 8, Visakha Vidyalaya- Colombo 4 and Sirimavo Bandaranayake Vidyalaya- Colombo07. The Armed Forces, Police, the Civil Defence Force and the National Cadet Corps Sri Lanka joined this year’s Independence Day Parade. The Army, Air Force, and Navy displayed their military might and manpower as well as modern military equipment was seen at the parade. Nearly, 6,385 soldiers and 390 armoured vehicles were on parade including s 3,284 Sri Lankan Army personnel and 170 armoured vehicles. Nearly 867 Navy personnel and 52 naval armoured vehicles took part in the parade. As for the Sri Lanka Air Force, 695  personnel and 109 Air force armoured vehicles, 336 Sri Lankan Police personnel, 220 Sri Lanka Police Special Task Force personnel, 437 Sri Lanka Civil Security Force personnel, 546 National Cadet Corps members, 21 armoured vehicles of retired military personnel and 29 armoured vehicles of Disabled personnel attended the Independence Day celebration. Meanwhile, many foreign diplomats including foreign Ministers, Ambassadors and delegations of foreign countries attended the Independence Day celebrations. Pix by Venura Chandramalitha and Anurudhdha Medhawattegedara by Nabiya Vaffoor

title: NAU Chief lambasts Agri Minister, Officials
author: Author not found
Content: President of the National Agrarian Unity (NAU) Anuradha Tennakoon said they are ready to file charges against the Agriculture Ministry over the consequences of the decisions taken by the present regime that dragged the country’s agro-sector to the streets. He said both the Minister of Agriculture and his officials have dragged the country’s farming community and the agriculture sector on to the streets because of their short-sighted policies. Tennakoon charged that farmers who had been involved in their profession had been forced to idle since 2021 due to the decision to ban the use of chemical and organic fertiliser.  He said the subject Minister along with his Ministry officials should be held directly accountable for the current parlous state of agriculture here. Tennakoon said even the relief granted to farmers by the World Bank had been pilfered by the Government with the knowledge of the Minister. BY Balasuriya – Galenbindunuwewa

title: Bus driver allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Nuwara Eliya Chief Magistrate Nalaka Edirisinghe released on bail, the driver of the bus who was involved in a traffic mishap, on the Nanu Oya-Radella road on 20 January. The driver, who had been in remand was enlarged on cash bail in Rs 25,000 and three sureties of Rs 300,000 each. The bus carrying a group of students from Thurstan College, Colombo, on an educational visit to Nuwara Eliya, had collided with a van and a three-wheeler travelling in the opposite direction on the Nanu Oya-Radella road. The driver of the bus was identified as 62-year-old I. Ghanarathana, a resident of Horana. Following the crash five members of the same family travelling in the van along with the drivers of the van and the three-wheeler had been killed on the spot while 53 persons travelling in the bus, including 41 students, were admitted to the Nuwara Eliya District Hospital with injuries. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: State sector told to reduce expenditure
author: Author not found
Content: A circular has been issued by the Ministry of Finance to State institutions to cut down a minimum of 6 per cent from the 2023 budgetary provisions. The National Budget Circular 01/2023 was issued to all Secretaries of Ministries, Provincial Councils, Heads of Departments, District Secretaries, Heads of State Corporations, Statutory Boards and State-owned companies. The aim of issuing the circular on using Government expenditure more sparingly and reducing unnecessary expenses as much as possible, is in order to reduce the adverse consequences that may arise due to the severe difficulties that have arisen in collecting the estimated gross Government revenue for this year. This circular has also informed that the revised cost estimates containing identified methods to reduce costs should be submitted to the National Budget Department before 28 February.

title: SJB member elected Mayor of Kurunegala
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) member Sumedha Arunashantha was elected as the Mayor of Kurunegala by a majority of four votes, in a vote that took place yesterday (2). The Kurunegala MC is controlled by the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP). The SJB members and SLPP member Gamini Peramunage voted in his favour.Arunashantha got ten votes while SLPP candidate Wijeyananda Wedisinha received six votes. SLPP Members Ranjith Jayawardene, Bandu Jayasekara and UNP Member Buddhika Ellepola refrained from voting. The post fell vacant when North Western Province Governor removed the former Mayor Thushara Sanjeewa Vitharana for failing to get the Council budget passed.

title: Paris Club to give SL financing assurances amid IMF debt talks – Sources
author: Author not found
Content: The Paris Club of creditor nations is ready to provide financing assurances to Sri Lanka, a key step needed to unlock a USD 2.9 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), two sources with direct knowledge of the matter have told Reuters. The informal group of bilateral lenders is set to “soon” announce its support to the crisis-hit nation on a debt overhaul, said one of the sources, who asked not to be named because talks are private. The Asian island nation, which is grappling with soaring inflation, a recession and currency depreciation, entered into a staff level agreement with the IMF last September. But, it needs financing assurances from key bilateral lenders before the fund’s executive board approves the programme. Sri Lanka’s public debt stood at 122% of GDP, of which 70% is denominated in foreign currency, according to data, in a country presentation, to investors in November. China and India, both non-Paris Club members, are the top bilateral lenders. “Paris Club assurance is not reliant on China,” said the source. Another source said the informal group is currently reaching out to other non-Paris Club members, besides China, on financing assurances, but did not provide any further details. India previously committed to help ease the debt burden of neighbour Sri Lanka as part of the IMF programme. While the IMF has not yet provided any guidance on where the lender stands regarding China’s assurances to Sri Lanka, a US official visiting Colombo said on Wednesday that Beijing has not done enough. “What China has offered so far is not enough. We need to see credible and specific assurances that they will meet the IMF standard of debt relief,” US Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs Victoria Nuland told reporters. The US is the largest IMF member. (Reuters)

title: Major strike on 8 Feb against APIT
author: Author not found
Content: Several trade union representatives, encompassing the nerve sectors of petroleum, electricity, ports, water and health yesterday (2) said they will take to the streets on 8 February opposing the imposition of the APIT tax. Convener of the Joint Ports Trade Union Collective Niroshana Gorakana said representatives of around 40 trade unions will go on strike on 8 February. Meanwhile, the Convener of CEB United Trade Union Alliance Ranjan Jayalal noted that they will also resort to similar trade union action on 8 February All the CEB employees will be summoned to Colombo to protest against the controversial tax scheme, he stressed. General Secretary of Petroleum General Employees’ Union Ashoka Ranwala also said they too will strike if the Government does not rescind its decision to amend the controversial tax imposed on the working class. By Anurada Herath

The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Liquor shops, bars closed from today
author: Author not found
Content: Additional Commissioner General of Income and Law Implementation of the Excise Department, Kapila Kumarasinghe said yesterday (2) that steps have been taken to close licensed liquor shops and bars islandwide from today (3). Kumarasinghe said at a time when Sri Lanka is celebrating its 75th Independence anniversary, he had taken this step to prevent any problems or untoward incident from taking place. He added that licensed liquor shops and bars must also be closed on Pasaloswaka Full Moon Poya Day which falls on 5 February.  Liquor shop keepers must abide by these regulations, if not legal action will be instituted against those who violate them, Kumarasinghe said. Business could resume as usual beginning Monday (6) Kumarasinghe added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Mahanayakes oppose implementation of 13A
author: Author not found
Content: The Mahanayake Theras of the three Nikayas urged President Ranil Wickremesinghe not to implement the 13th Amendment to the Constitution as it would create issues. In a letter addressed to the President, the Mahanayake Theras said all former leaders did not implement the 13th Amendment as they realised the possible issues such as unrest that could follow by doing so. Implementing 13th Amendment would create issues with regard to independence, territorial integrity and national security, they said. The Mahanayake Thera of Malwathu Chapter of the Siyam Nikaya, Most Ven. Thibbotuwawe Sri Siddhartha Sumangala Thera, Mahanayake Thera of Asgiri Chapter of the Siyam Nikaya Most Ven. Warakagoda Gnanarathana Thera, Mahanayake Thera of Amarapura Nikaya Most Ven. Dodampahala Chandasiri Thera and Mahanayake Thera of Ramanna Nikaya Most Ven. Makulewe Wimala Thera have signed the letter. They noted that devolving land and Police powers as well as transferring power to Provincial Councils to regulate ancient and historical places could lead to promoting separatism in the country. “It is true that as a country Sri Lanka has to face certain conditions set out by world powers when we are seeking global assistance to overcome the economic crisis. But we have to take steps to reject proposals that would endanger the territorial integrity and independence of the country,” they said.

title: NAU Chief lambasts Agri Minister, Officials
author: Author not found
Content: President of the National Agrarian Unity (NAU) Anuradha Tennakoon said they are ready to file charges against the Agriculture Ministry over the consequences of the decisions taken by the present regime that dragged the country’s agro-sector to the streets. He said both the Minister of Agriculture and his officials have dragged the country’s farming community and the agriculture sector on to the streets because of their short-sighted policies. Tennakoon charged that farmers who had been involved in their profession had been forced to idle since 2021 due to the decision to ban the use of chemical and organic fertiliser.  He said the subject Minister along with his Ministry officials should be held directly accountable for the current parlous state of agriculture here. Tennakoon said even the relief granted to farmers by the World Bank had been pilfered by the Government with the knowledge of the Minister. BY Balasuriya – Galenbindunuwewa

title: Bus driver allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Nuwara Eliya Chief Magistrate Nalaka Edirisinghe released on bail, the driver of the bus who was involved in a traffic mishap, on the Nanu Oya-Radella road on 20 January. The driver, who had been in remand was enlarged on cash bail in Rs 25,000 and three sureties of Rs 300,000 each. The bus carrying a group of students from Thurstan College, Colombo, on an educational visit to Nuwara Eliya, had collided with a van and a three-wheeler travelling in the opposite direction on the Nanu Oya-Radella road. The driver of the bus was identified as 62-year-old I. Ghanarathana, a resident of Horana. Following the crash five members of the same family travelling in the van along with the drivers of the van and the three-wheeler had been killed on the spot while 53 persons travelling in the bus, including 41 students, were admitted to the Nuwara Eliya District Hospital with injuries. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: State sector told to reduce expenditure
author: Author not found
Content: A circular has been issued by the Ministry of Finance to State institutions to cut down a minimum of 6 per cent from the 2023 budgetary provisions. The National Budget Circular 01/2023 was issued to all Secretaries of Ministries, Provincial Councils, Heads of Departments, District Secretaries, Heads of State Corporations, Statutory Boards and State-owned companies. The aim of issuing the circular on using Government expenditure more sparingly and reducing unnecessary expenses as much as possible, is in order to reduce the adverse consequences that may arise due to the severe difficulties that have arisen in collecting the estimated gross Government revenue for this year. This circular has also informed that the revised cost estimates containing identified methods to reduce costs should be submitted to the National Budget Department before 28 February.

title: SJB member elected Mayor of Kurunegala
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) member Sumedha Arunashantha was elected as the Mayor of Kurunegala by a majority of four votes, in a vote that took place yesterday (2). The Kurunegala MC is controlled by the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP). The SJB members and SLPP member Gamini Peramunage voted in his favour.Arunashantha got ten votes while SLPP candidate Wijeyananda Wedisinha received six votes. SLPP Members Ranjith Jayawardene, Bandu Jayasekara and UNP Member Buddhika Ellepola refrained from voting. The post fell vacant when North Western Province Governor removed the former Mayor Thushara Sanjeewa Vitharana for failing to get the Council budget passed.

title: Paris Club to give SL financing assurances amid IMF debt talks – Sources
author: Author not found
Content: The Paris Club of creditor nations is ready to provide financing assurances to Sri Lanka, a key step needed to unlock a USD 2.9 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), two sources with direct knowledge of the matter have told Reuters. The informal group of bilateral lenders is set to “soon” announce its support to the crisis-hit nation on a debt overhaul, said one of the sources, who asked not to be named because talks are private. The Asian island nation, which is grappling with soaring inflation, a recession and currency depreciation, entered into a staff level agreement with the IMF last September. But, it needs financing assurances from key bilateral lenders before the fund’s executive board approves the programme. Sri Lanka’s public debt stood at 122% of GDP, of which 70% is denominated in foreign currency, according to data, in a country presentation, to investors in November. China and India, both non-Paris Club members, are the top bilateral lenders. “Paris Club assurance is not reliant on China,” said the source. Another source said the informal group is currently reaching out to other non-Paris Club members, besides China, on financing assurances, but did not provide any further details. India previously committed to help ease the debt burden of neighbour Sri Lanka as part of the IMF programme. While the IMF has not yet provided any guidance on where the lender stands regarding China’s assurances to Sri Lanka, a US official visiting Colombo said on Wednesday that Beijing has not done enough. “What China has offered so far is not enough. We need to see credible and specific assurances that they will meet the IMF standard of debt relief,” US Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs Victoria Nuland told reporters. The US is the largest IMF member. (Reuters)

title: Major strike on 8 Feb against APIT
author: Author not found
Content: Several trade union representatives, encompassing the nerve sectors of petroleum, electricity, ports, water and health yesterday (2) said they will take to the streets on 8 February opposing the imposition of the APIT tax. Convener of the Joint Ports Trade Union Collective Niroshana Gorakana said representatives of around 40 trade unions will go on strike on 8 February. Meanwhile, the Convener of CEB United Trade Union Alliance Ranjan Jayalal noted that they will also resort to similar trade union action on 8 February All the CEB employees will be summoned to Colombo to protest against the controversial tax scheme, he stressed. General Secretary of Petroleum General Employees’ Union Ashoka Ranwala also said they too will strike if the Government does not rescind its decision to amend the controversial tax imposed on the working class. By Anurada Herath

title: Mass beach clean-up programme
author: Author not found
Content: A mass beach clean-up programme, organised by Clean Sri Lanka, Arugambay coinciding with the 75th Independence Day of Sri Lanka, was held in the Pottuvill coastal area on Wednesday (1). A distance of 15 kilometres was cleaned during the programme. The programme is supported by Coast Conservation Department, Youth Federation, Police, Arugambay Surf Forces, Medical Officer of Health, Pottuvl, Predeshya Saba, Pottuvill Divisional Secretariat, Office, Pottuvil Elephant Society, Make a difference-MAD project and Wishkey Point Resort. A large number of volunteers from these organisations engaged in the shramadana, in three groups in different spots and collected the waste, a large amount of used plastic bottles used plastic bags. Many foreign tourists also contributed to the programme. The President of Clean Sri Lanka, A. Muzammil thanked volunteers for their valuable contribution and appealed to them to continue this trend for a plastic free ocean. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara Correspondent

title: US secures deal on Philippines bases to complete arc around China
author: Author not found
Content: The US has secured access to four additional military bases in the Philippines – a key bit of real estate which would offer a front seat to monitor the Chinese in the South China Sea and around Taiwan. With the deal, Washington has stitched the gap in the arc of US alliances stretching from South Korea and Japan in the north to Australia in the south. The missing link had been the Philippines, which borders two of the biggest potential flashpoints – Taiwan and the South China Sea. The deal, which in part reverses the US’ departure from their former colony more than 30 years ago, is no small matter. “There is no contingency in the South China Sea that does not require access to the Philippines,” says Gregory B Poling, director of the Southeast Asia programme at the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. “The US is not looking for permanent bases. It’s about places, not bases.” The US already had limited access to five sites under the Enhanced Defence Cooperation Agreement (EDCA) – the new additions and expanded access, according to a statement from Washington, will “allow more rapid support for humanitarian and climate-related disasters in the Philippines, and respond to other shared challenges”, likely a veiled reference to countering China in the region. The statement came after US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin met Philippine President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr in Manila on Thursday. The US hasn’t said where the new bases are but three of them could be on Luzon, an island on the northern edge of the Philippines, the only large piece of land close to Taiwan – if you don’t count China. China criticised the agreement, saying “US actions escalate regional tension and undermine regional peace and stability”. “The United States, out of its self-interests and zero-sum game mentality, continues to step up military posture in this region,” its embassy said in a statement. These days the US is seeking access to places where “light and flexible” operations involving supplies and surveillance can be run as and when needed, rather than bases where large numbers of troops will be stationed. In other words, this is not a return to the 1980s, when the Philippines was home to 15,000 US troops and two of the largest American military bases in Asia, at Clark Field and nearby Subic Bay. (BBC)

title: Bomber used Police uniform as disguise
author: Author not found
Content: The man who attacked a mosque in the Pakistani city of Peshawar on Monday used a police uniform to gain access the area, police have said. The suicide bomber reportedly entered through the main gates of the secure zone where the mosque is located. Police Chief Moazzam Jah Ansari said they had CCTV footage revealing the man’s final movements, and were closing in on the “terror network” responsible. He also confirmed a head found at the site was the attacker’s. Monday’s blast – one of the deadliest attacks in Pakistan in years – took place at a 50-year-old mosque in a high-security police zone called Police Lines. At least 100 people were killed, of whom most were police officers. Officers failed to check the attacker as they assumed he was one of them, Ansari said. “I admit this was a security lapse. My men could not stop it. This is my fault.” He explained that police had been able to trace the bomber’s motorcycle journey before the attack using CCTV footage. As the man parked his motorcycle, he was “in a police uniform and was wearing a mask and a helmet”. After entering the compound, the attacker asked a constable where the mosque was. Ansari – who heads the force in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province – added that ball bearings had been found which were used in a suicide jacket. He said 10-12kg (22-26lb) of TNT explosives were used in the blast, which caused the mosque’s roof to collapse on the hundreds who were praying in the building. Police do not believe the man was a “lone wolf”, and have suggested there is an entire network behind him. A claim that the hard-line Islamist militant group Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) carried out Monday’s bombing was later denied by the group, which blamed it on the commander of a breakaway faction. In the past the TTP has refrained from claiming some attacks on mosques, schools or markets, preferring to cast its violence as a war with security forces and not against the Pakistani people. (BBC)

title: Inclement weather injures two, damages 157 houses
author: Author not found
Content: Inclement weather, experienced in various parts of the country, over the past three days, to yesterday, caused injuries to two persons, damaged 157 houses, impacted 168 families, comprising 578 persons, whilst also damaging 13 small and medium enterprises and the infrastructure of a building, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (2). The two injured were from Madampe in the Puttalam District. It also said that bad weather impacted one family, comprising seven persons, also in Madampe. In related developments, the DMC further said bad weather in Madampe damaged one small and medium enterprise (SME) and one critical infrastructure in the locality. In like news, the DMC said bad weather in the Kegalle District impacted one family, comprising four persons, whilst also damaging a house. In similar developments, it impacted a family comprising three and damaged a house in Ratnapura. Inclement weather also affected 85 families, comprising 278 persons in Trincomalee, whilst damaging 81 houses and 10 SMEs. Its impact in Polonnaruwa affected 52 families, comprising 194 persons whilst also damaging 52 houses. Inclement weather further impacted six families and 18 persons in Jaffna, whilst damaging three houses and two SMEs. In Kilinochchi it impacted five families, comprising 12 persons, damaged two houses and two SMEs. In Mullaitivu, 15 families, comprising 56 persons were affected and 15 houses were damaged. In Hambantota, one person and a house were impacted while in Kesbewa inclement weather impacted one family, comprising five persons, whilst also damaging a house, the DMC said. Meanwhile, the Met Department, in its Friday weather forecast, said the depression over the Southwest Bay of Bengal has entered through the east coast of Sri Lanka around early morning yesterday (2) and was moving across the country. Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in the Northern, Eastern and Uva Provinces. Showers or thundershowers will occur elsewhere during the afternoon or night, it said. Fairly heavy showers above 50mm are likely at some places in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, North-Western and Uva Provinces. Temporary localised strong winds and lightning will occur during thundershowers, the Met Department further said. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Mourners and protesters clash at Cardinal Pell’s funeral
author: Author not found
Content: At Cardinal George Pell’s funeral in Australia on Thursday, mourners muttered prayers and softly sung hymns but were at times drowned out by protesters condemning him to hell.  The Catholic cleric – who died last of surgery complications last month aged 81 – leaves a complicated legacy. Formerly one of the Pope’s top aides, he was Australia’s top-ranked Catholic. But his public image was tainted by unproven allegations he both concealed and committed child sexual abuse. Those allegations loomed large in Sydney on Thursday. At one point, police outside St Mary’s Cathedral intervened to separate angry mourners from chanting protesters. Earlier, one protester was arrested. Inside the church, where Cardinal Pell served as the city’s archbishop for over a decade, dignitaries including former Prime Ministers John Howard and Tony Abbott filled pews. Hundreds more gathered in a forecourt to watch the requiem Mass on big screens. Noticeably absent were Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and New South Wales Premier Dominic Perrottet – himself a devout Catholic. Both sent delegates. In a message read to the congregation, Pope Francis praised Cardinal Pell’s “dedication to the gospel and to the Church”, while Archbishop of Sydney Anthony Fisher lauded him as “giant of the Catholic Church in Australia” who had been wrongly demonised. Over six decades, Cardinal Pell rose to prominence in the Church as a strong supporter of traditional Catholic values. He took on the role of Vatican treasurer in 2014 but left in 2017, returning to Australia to face trial on child sexual abuse charges. He was convicted, then later acquitted on appeal.Many of Cardinal Pell’s supporters believe he was unfairly persecuted, and that his record on the issue of child sexual abuse is part of what made him great. Abbott, who spoke at the funeral, claimed Cardinal Pell had been the first Australian Catholic to sack child abusers and report them to police. Others pointed to the landmark – but controversial – compensation scheme he set up. “He was greatest man I’ve ever known,” Abbott said. (BBC)

title: Susil tells teaching hopefuls to keep away from tuition
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha told the graduates, who expect to become teachers, not to go for tuition classes to prepare for the recruitment examination. The Minister said, the broader education transformation process is not expected to produce a group of people who memorise everything they are taught, write answers to exam papers, attend tutoring classes, and prepare to take the teacher examinations. The minister highlighted this while attending the awards ceremony of the ‘National Level Information and Communication Champions-2021’ tournament held at the Ministry of Education, while commenting on an advertisement that tutoring classes will be held for the graduate teacher examination to be held in March. Noting that undergraduate students, who want to be teachers, should be able to immediately think and understand something and act on it, such as solving a simple math problem and answering a general question, he said a generation of children cannot be created by a group of teachers who seek help in tutoring classes even to appear for the teacher recruitment examination. He also said, as a result of such events, the need for a comprehensive education transformation process has been well established and that the selections examination, to be conducted by the Examination Department, for those who pass the relevant age limit and are expected to join the State service as development officers among graduates is not a difficult competitive examination. As a result, Premajayantha expects the candidates to show up at the exam hall on time and face the test with confidence, without participating in tutoring classes.  (TR)

title: CFC employees to get salary arrears soon
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (2), that arrangements have been made to pay salary arrears of employees working in the regional offices of the Ceylon Fisheries Corporation (CFC) in a few days. Minister Devananda lamented that due to the nonpayment of salaries to these employees for the past four months, they were facing many difficulties. Devananda and Fisheries State Minister Piyal Nishantha de Silva met CFC Trade Union (TU) representatives at Fisheries Ministry on 1 February to discuss the matter and to find a solution. Devananda added that during the discussion the TU representatives brought to their attention that the salaries of employees of CFC regional offices in Galle, Hambantota and Pesalai areas had not been paid for the past four months and the payment of Employees Provident Fund (EPF) and retirement gratuity has also been stopped as a result.  The Fisheries Minister said, it was pointed out during the discussion that due to this employees were facing severe economic difficulties and  as a result problems had arisen in running the organisation. State Minister de Silva said, the CFC and the Minster were discussing the matter  to find a solution and said that this was the first time such an incident had taken place where salaries have been delayed. He said, CFC was a well-run entity until the crisis situation sparked in the country. The State Minister added that he would work in collaboration with Minister to transform the CFC to a profit-making entity distributing fresh seafood to consumers at fair and affordable prices. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Probe launched into deaths of foreign sailors
author: Author not found
Content: The Galle Harbour Police have launched an investigation into the mid sea death of two crew members of a freighter which was sailing to India from Egypt. Police said, the victims were 41 and 53-year-old nationals of Ukraine. The ship has been anchored in Sri Lankan waters off the coast of Galle. Necessary arrangements have been made to bring the bodies ashore after getting the approval from the Galle Magistrate, according to Police. The post-mortem is to be performed at Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Assist SL in securing IMF bailout, push for 13A
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of Tamil Progressive Party (TPA), MP Mano Ganesan and many other Tamil speaking political party leaders such as Rauff Hakeem, M.A. Sumanthiran, D. Sithadthan, Gajan Ponnambalam and Rishad Bathiudeen, who held talks with visiting US Under Secretary of State Victoria Nuland said they had a unanimous stand that President Ranil Wickremesinghe should demonstrate his credibility by matching his words with deeds and urged the US to assist Sri Lanka to secure the IMF bailout. MP Ganesan elaborated that this is the President who has the benefit of the announced support of Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, Leader of prime ruling party Mahinda Rajapaksa, and the JVP Leader in implementing the 13A. All Tamil speaking parties agreed that President Wickremesinghe should conduct separate discussions with parties representing North and East Tamils, Hill Country Tamils and Muslims and convene an All Party Conference thereafter, they told the visiting US Under Secretary of State. He added that regarding addressing the issues, there shall be a step by step road map and US Under Secretary Nuland agreed to take these messages to President Wickremesinghe when discussing the economic crisis, ongoing US assistance to Sri Lankans, USD 240 million in new assistance last year alone, and the many ways both countries are working together toward an inclusive, prosperous and secure future for all Sri Lankans. On the meeting held with the Tamil politicians, US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung tweeted yesterday (1) that they held a positive meeting with parties on how the US can help Sri Lanka out of the economic crisis and to bring real-time reconciliation between communities with a genuine power-sharing agreement. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Catholic Church accuses Sirisena of ‘twisting’ SC verdict
author: Author not found
Content: The Catholic Church accused former President Maithripala Sirisena of ‘twisting’ the Supreme Court verdict in which the latter was ordered to pay a compensation for his responsibility for the Easter Sunday terror attacks in 2019, for his personal benefit. Spokesman for the Colombo Archbishop’s House, Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando yesterday (1) accused Sirisena of attempting to hoodwink people with false claims that he had to compensate those affected by the 2019 Easter Attacks due to the failure of officials appointed by him to carry out their duty rather than a fault of his own.   Fr. Fernando said the question was not about forgiving the former President for his apathy with regard to the 2019 Easter Attacks, but as to why he wants the Sri Lankan Catholics to forgive him when he has continued to maintain that he had not been at fault. Referring to Sirisena’s appeal for forgiveness from Sri Lanka’s Catholic Community on Tuesday (31) while announcing his intention to contest for 2024 Presidential Elections at a media briefing in Colombo, Fr. Fernando said Sirisena’s request was devoid of sincerity and were just empty words. “If one is asking to be forgiven then he or she has to accept the fault. The Supreme Court has noted that at the time of the bombing President Sirisena had held the portfolio as Defence Minister and been in charge of the Police, State Intelligence Service. It is against the principles of the Constitution to differentiate between the Police Department and State Intelligence which is what the former President did when he gave an affidavit stating the Inspector General of Police (IGP) and the Defence Secretary were bound to keep him informed regarding the security situation, and that the Director of State Intelligence was not bound by that duty.” The Court stated that the former President and the SIS Director had tended affidavits that gave out false distinctions that were artificial and had no legal or constitutional basis. The Supreme Court said Sirisena had violated human rights and that therefore he should pay compensation to those affected in the bombings. “It is not because of the officials he appointed but because as the Defence Minister, Maithripala Sirisena was bound to ensure the safety of the public by monitoring institutions which were under his purview,” the Spokesman for the Colombo Archbishop said, explaining the Supreme Court verdict. He said the Court had also noted that the former President’s abject failure had brought disastrous consequences to this country and not only destroyed lives and property, but also broken its whole fabric by paving the way for inter-communal crises and hatred amongst races. “Sirisena as an SLFP candidate has the right to contest the Presidential Elections again if the law did not hinder him. But while he held the post he failed in one of his primary duties of safeguarding the lives of his people,” Fr. Fernando said. The Church had no issues about forgiving him, but what it needs to know is who was behind the attacks and who else should take responsibility for the heinous crime. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
