title: Catholic Church accuses Sirisena of ‘twisting’ SC verdict
author: Author not found
Content: The Catholic Church accused former President Maithripala Sirisena of ‘twisting’ the Supreme Court verdict in which the latter was ordered to pay a compensation for his responsibility for the Easter Sunday terror attacks in 2019, for his personal benefit. Spokesman for the Colombo Archbishop’s House, Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando yesterday (1) accused Sirisena of attempting to hoodwink people with false claims that he had to compensate those affected by the 2019 Easter Attacks due to the failure of officials appointed by him to carry out their duty rather than a fault of his own.   Fr. Fernando said the question was not about forgiving the former President for his apathy with regard to the 2019 Easter Attacks, but as to why he wants the Sri Lankan Catholics to forgive him when he has continued to maintain that he had not been at fault. Referring to Sirisena’s appeal for forgiveness from Sri Lanka’s Catholic Community on Tuesday (31) while announcing his intention to contest for 2024 Presidential Elections at a media briefing in Colombo, Fr. Fernando said Sirisena’s request was devoid of sincerity and were just empty words. “If one is asking to be forgiven then he or she has to accept the fault. The Supreme Court has noted that at the time of the bombing President Sirisena had held the portfolio as Defence Minister and been in charge of the Police, State Intelligence Service. It is against the principles of the Constitution to differentiate between the Police Department and State Intelligence which is what the former President did when he gave an affidavit stating the Inspector General of Police (IGP) and the Defence Secretary were bound to keep him informed regarding the security situation, and that the Director of State Intelligence was not bound by that duty.” The Court stated that the former President and the SIS Director had tended affidavits that gave out false distinctions that were artificial and had no legal or constitutional basis. The Supreme Court said Sirisena had violated human rights and that therefore he should pay compensation to those affected in the bombings. “It is not because of the officials he appointed but because as the Defence Minister, Maithripala Sirisena was bound to ensure the safety of the public by monitoring institutions which were under his purview,” the Spokesman for the Colombo Archbishop said, explaining the Supreme Court verdict. He said the Court had also noted that the former President’s abject failure had brought disastrous consequences to this country and not only destroyed lives and property, but also broken its whole fabric by paving the way for inter-communal crises and hatred amongst races. “Sirisena as an SLFP candidate has the right to contest the Presidential Elections again if the law did not hinder him. But while he held the post he failed in one of his primary duties of safeguarding the lives of his people,” Fr. Fernando said. The Church had no issues about forgiving him, but what it needs to know is who was behind the attacks and who else should take responsibility for the heinous crime. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Catholic Church to boycott Independence Day celebrations
author: Author not found
Content: Neither the Cardinal, Bishops nor any representative from Sri Lanka’s Catholic Church would participate in the 75th Independence Day celebrations, on Saturday (4), as it is a ‘crime’ and waste of funds that is being committed against the citizens of Sri Lanka, Spokesman for the Archdiocese of Colombo, Rev. Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando stated. Addressing the media yesterday (1) at the Colombo Archbishop’s House, Fr. Fernando lambasted the Government over the colossal amount of public funds being spent for the Independence Day celebration. He noted that the Catholic Church opposed such waste at a time when the country’s economy is in a bad state. What should happen is all political parties, that have ruled this country for the past 75 years and shoved it towards this state of bankruptcy, should admit their mistakes publicly and ask the people for their forgiveness, he said. “Measures should be taken to bring all those responsible for robbing the country before the law and wrest all stolen money from them. What Independence can be celebrated spending Rs 200 million, when the country is unable to pay back the foreign loans that had been obtained, when, according to a report issued by the World Food Programme (WFP), 30 per cent of its population was suffering from hunger and 33.4 per cent children below the age of five years were suffering from malnutrition,” he queried. “According to the WFP 86 per cent families were able to obtain only food that had low nutritional value at a cheap price, he said noting that the Government was going begging for loans from country to country for funds to purchase food, fuel, pharmaceuticals and other essentials. The income of the majority population has plummeted while they were being distressed by the increasing cost of living. The Government on the other hand was only piling up direct and indirect taxes on the already suffering public,” he said. The Spokesman for the Colombo Archbishop’s House expressed the Church’s reservations on how the Government thought to celebrate 75 years of Independence when people were losing jobs, when small enterprises were collapsing, when the rule of law was being grossly violated and human rights were being desecrated without any qualms. People’s right to speech and to hold peaceful demonstrations were being violated by misusing Acts like the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). “To say the least the Government was unable to maintain 24 hour power supply at least for the sake of children sitting their GCE Advance Level Examinations during this period,” he lamented. Fr. Fernando accused the Government of spending such a colossal sum of money to celebrate Independence when it had come to a situation that it was unable to maintain the State health service with the provision of medicines and healthcare facilities thereby compromising the lives of patients. Fr. Fernando, who is also the Editor of the ‘Gnanartha Pradeepaya,’ the Catholic Publication, said that there was a question as to whether the citizens were able to proudly celebrate 75 years of Independence from the British rule  when it was doubtful as to whether “our people had a present and a future to talk about with pride.” By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Interim Order on retirement of doctors extended
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal extended the Interim Order staying the inclusion of medical specialists and medical doctors in the Cabinet decision, to reduce the compulsory retirement age from 63 to 60 years. This was when the Writ Application filed by 176 consultant specialist doctors, challenging the decision to reduce the compulsory retirement age of doctors to 60 years, was taken up before Court of Appeal Justices Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. The petitioners said that the decision of the Cabinet of Ministers, dated 17 October, has been made illegally and in complete violation of their legitimate expectation to continue in service at least until 63 years of age. The Petitioners’ position is that since 2017, as consultant specialist doctors, they have been guaranteed a defined compulsory age of retirement of 63 years, by both Cabinet Decisions as well as by the Amendment to the Minute on Pensions and therefore, that they were distinctly identified as a separate category, different and separate to that of other categories of public officers in general and that this status and legitimate expectation had been continuing for a period of 5 years, from 2017 up to 2022. They further stated that they have obtained their PGIM Board certification through a gruelling process over the years and that due cognisance had been taken of the important service that they dispense at the apex level of the public healthcare system and curative as well as the preventive segments of the patient care system, in the country. While the initial interim order was issued on 15 December, the Court of Appeal extended it until further notice. The Writ Application is due to be taken up on 28 and 29 March. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Explanation called from Milco Chair
author: Author not found
Content: The Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture called for an explanation from the Chairman of Milco (Pvt) Ltd in connection with the alleged sale of over 638 MT of milk powder, that was unsuitable for human consumption, for animal feed without calling for tenders. According to the Ministry of Agriculture, upon having been informed of the intention of Milco (Pvt) Ltd to sell the said milk powder, the Minister of Agriculture previously appointed a committee to look into the matter. The committee recommended that the relevant stock of milk powder should only be sold after calling tenders. The Ministry of Agriculture noted however that Milco (Pvt) Ltd had allegedly sold the milk powder to an individual at a price of Rs 100 million. Accordingly, the Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture called for an explanation for such sale ignoring the recommendations of the said committee. BY FaadhilaThassim

title: Halt 105 road development projects in Kaduwela MC
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission (EC) has informed the Kaduwela Mayor to halt 105 road development projects of Kaduwela Municipal Council, as the Commission sees those constructions as an attempt to promote municipal members misusing public funds. The EC has instructed the Mayor to recommence the projects worth about Rs 150 million after Local Government Elections conclude. As the date for LG Polls has been announced, the Kaduwela Mayor is advised to provide a list of roads that need to be repaired immediately and obtain approval of the EC. An independent investigation was conducted by the EC following a complaint of former Kaduwela Mayor G.H. Buddhadasa and a group of Kaduwela municipal members. They alleged that the present Mayor has obtained approval for funds to repair 100 roads in the area and this is a hindrance to hold an independent and fair election. By Amith Maduranga Gamageand Sugath Liyanage – Kaduwela

title: 102,545 tourist arrivals recorded in January – SLTDA
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) said 102,545 tourists arrived in the country in January 2023. The SLTDA said this is an increase of 20,218 tourists compared to the 82,327 tourist arrivals that were reported in January 2022. The highest number of tourists, 25,254 from Russia, 13,759 from India, and 8,483 from the United Kingdom arrived during this period. Germany, France, Canada, Australia, the United States, Maldives, and Israel are the remaining source markets for January.

title: PUCSL files Writ Application in Appellate Court
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) yesterday (1) filed a Writ Application before Court of Appeal seeking an order against the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), preventing power cuts during the Advanced Level Examination period. This is the second case filed against imposing power cuts during the A/L Examination period on the basis that it violates the rights of students. The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) previously filed a Contempt of Court case in Supreme Court against the Chairman of the Ceylon Electricity Board, Secretary to the Ministry of Power and Energy and the Chairman of the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, over the failure to supply continuous power during the G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination period. HRCSL observed that the said authorities have failed to abide by the settlement arrived at before the Commission with regard to the continuous supply of power during the A/L Examination 2022 from 23 January to 17 February 2023. CEB is, however, yet to take a decision on the continuous supply of power during the A/L Examination period. By Faadhila Thassim

title: LG Polls date gazetted
author: Author not found
Content: The notifications, pertaining to the holding of the Local Government Election on 9 March 2023, have been published in the Government Gazette. The Local Government notifications have been issued by the respective District Returning Officers for the LG bodies of each district, under Sub-section 38(1) (c) of the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance.  Accordingly, the election to those local authorities will be held on 9 March 2023 from 7.00 a.m. to 4.00 p.m. About 80,720 candidates will be contesting for 339 local government bodies at the election. The EC said these candidates belong to 58 registered political Parties and 329 Independent Groups.

title: 36,000 MT fertiliser shipment due in mid-February – Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: A fertiliser ship carrying 36,000 MT of manure is scheduled to reach the Colombo Port mid-February, Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said, instructing officials to commence the related procurement work immediately. Amaraweera instructed Ministry officials to allocate Rs 10 billion to purchase urea required for paddy and maize cultivation in the upcoming 2023 Yala Season. He said at present, the warehouses of Lanka Fertiliser Company and Colombo Commercial Fertiliser Company have 30,000 MT of urea and that arrangements have been made to purchase another 25,000 MT. The Ministry of Agriculture has planned to provide all three types of fertiliser essential for paddy cultivation; TSP, MOP and Urea without any shortage in the 2023 Yala Season. Arrangements have been made to provide TSP at the beginning of the Yala Season to all paddy farmers free of charge.

title: Wasantha Mudalige released on bail in three more cases
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (1) released Inter-University Students’ Federation (IUSF) convener Wasantha Mudalige on bail in three separate cases, including obstructing an ambulance, which had arrived to transport injured protesters on 9 July last year.  Strict bail conditions were imposed on Mudalige, who was released from prison after 167 days. The Magistrate released on bail in two sureties of Rs 200,000 each, pertaining to the lawsuit filed against him, for having violated orders of the Court. Magistrate Gamage, then sternly instructed the suspect, that upon his release on bail, he should not henceforth venture forth, to flout orders issued by the Court. The Fort Magistrate then ordered the suspect to appear before the Crimes Division of Fort Police at 10 a.m. on 7 February and provide a statement, related to a different case filed against him by the Police. Fort Police, stated that they need to record a statement from Mudalige, connected to the incident, where he had allegedly obstructed an ambulance, which had arrived to transport injured protesters, during the anti-Government riots on 9 July, 2022. Taking the request into consideration, the Magistrate issued the aforesaid order and warned that if the suspect continues to violate the bail conditions, the Court will rescind it and remand him till the conclusion of the case. Pic by Piyath Nikeshala By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: 77 Military Officers get Vishishta Seva Vibhushana medals
author: Author not found
Content: Seventy-seven military officers were honoured with Vishishta Seva Vibhushana medals by President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (1) at a ceremony held in Kandy. In addition to the 77 military officers, the President also presented the 75th Independence Celebration Commemorative Medals to 20 Tri-Forces personnel.

title: Prime Minister calls for ‘atrocities’ to be probed
author: Author not found
Content: An assessment should be conducted to determine the scale of atrocities committed against humanity by imperialists in Sri Lanka and the Government has a responsibility to take action in that regard, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said. He said this when Prof. C.M. Madduma Bandara presented a copy of his research volume titled, ‘FREEDOM STRUGGLES OF SRI LANKA; Lessons Learned and the Way Forward’ to Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the Prime Minister’s Office in Colombo recently. This book was completed on the occasion of the 200th Anniversary of the Great Rebellion against British colonial rule in Uva Wellassa in 1818 and shows how Sri Lanka, which had been an independent country for over 2,000 years, lost its independence due to oppression by imperialists. This book highlights a strong argument that compensation should be paid for the atrocities committed against humanity during that period. Speaking at this occasion, the Premier said it is the responsibility of the Government to take action in this regard. “The reports submitted by the Buddhist Commission and  Udarata Rural Rehabilitation Commission have presented the damage done to Sri Lanka by the imperialists and the Government has a responsibility to take action in that regard,” the Prime Minister said. Venerable Omalpe Sobitha Thera, Venerable Whitiyala Kavidhaja Thera, Yadamini Gunawardena MP, Prime Minister’s Secretary Anura Dissanayake, Navin Gunaratne, Lawyer Senaka Weeraratne, Renuka D. Nagodawithana, Kshamendra Thilakasiri, Dhawala Muthukudaarachchi and Gamika Gunawardena were also present at this occasion.

title: Part of X-Press Pearl wreck removed
author: Author not found
Content: The wreck of MV X-Press Pearl, which sank off the coast of Colombo North, at Dikkovita in 2021, after being completely destroyed by fire, has been split into two. One section is scheduled to be sent to the port of Singapore (Yard). However, State Minister of Urban Development Authority Arundika Fernando has instructed the wreck removing Chinese company, Shanghai Salvage, to fulfil all legal requirements including making a payment to the Port Customs first, before removing the vessel from Sri Lankan waters. The Chinese company had already removed the ship’s accommodation section and was about to sail to Singapore when the Minster announced that the removal company should do the needful.    The other part of the ship, which is still under water, would be removed as scheduled before March, said Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) Chair, Dharshani Lahandapura. MEPA had delegated the wreck removal and underwater debris removal projects to two separate companies, arranged by the ship owners. Shanghai Salvage removed the wreck, and Resolve Marine removed the underwater debris, last year. The wreck’s cut section is on the submersible barge. According to the MEPA Chairperson, ship breaking is prohibited in Sri Lanka under the Central Environmental Act, so the wreck must be relocated. She also said while the removal was taking place they did not notice any oil slicks or any other marine or environmental damages. The remaining parts of the ship would be removed before May this year, she added. The MEPA team presented its second interim report, to Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, in which it mentioned that a USD 6.5 billion compensation claim, as part of the recommendations made by marine experts, to vessel owners. However, Lahandapura stated that the final report for the environmental damage will be issued after the entire wreck has been removed and the damage caused during the removal as well as the condition of the water has been studied. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: New French Envoy calls on Public Security Minister
author: Author not found
Content: New French Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Jean-François Pactet, called on Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles at his Ministry premises yesterday (1) morning. During the meeting, the new French Envoy and Minister Alles exchanged views with regard to bilateral relations between the two nations. Pactet also assured Minister Alles of support from Paris to Colombo in the latter’s efforts to recover from its economic crisis. They had also discussed measures that should be taken to prevent Sri Lankans from unlawfully migrating to France. The Minister also sought support from the French diplomat to conduct a training programme for Police Officers.

title: Bureau set up on Buddha Sasana Minister’s instructions
author: Author not found
Content: On instructions of the Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs, measures have been taken to inaugurate a bureau towards the protection of cultural rights of differently-abled persons. Issuing a media release, the Ministry said following discussions by subject Minister Vidura Wickremanayake with representatives from the differently-abled community, a new bureau to cater to safeguarding of cultural rights of such individuals was opened yesterday (1). The new bureau has been set up on the 8th floor of Sethsiripaya in Battaramulla and will provide facilities to differently-abled persons to visit religious places in the country, tourist locations, support to nurture their artistic talents and promote their artistic creations etc.

title: President has no mandate to activate 13A – Weerasekera
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has no mandate to activate the vexed and controversial 13th Amendment to the Constitution, MP Rear Admiral Sarath Weerasekera stressed. He said this while meeting Mahanayake Thera of the Asgiriya Chapter, Most Venerable Warakagoda Sri Gnanarathana Thera along with a group of political representatives. The MP added that the 13th Amendment had been forced on Sri Lanka by India and that it was not desired by the people. He said, former Presidents Ranasinghe Premadasa, D.B. Wijetunga, Chandrika Kumaratunga and Mahinda Rajapaksa did not venture forth to activate it having understood its lasting repercussions to both the country and its people. Weerasekera warned that he will join hands with all patriotic and nationalist forces to prevent the President from activating the 13th Amendment even if they have to risk their lives. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Doctors give Govt one-week ultimatum
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors gave an ultimatum of one week to the Government to address the medicinal drug shortage and to amend the new tax policy. They vowed to initiate strong trade union action next week, with the support of over 40 trade unions, if their demands went unheeded.  They said they will watch and wait this week before resorting to stronger action next week if the Health Ministry fails to provide a lasting solution to the medicinal drug issue and if the Government does not amend the new Inland Revenue Act to come up with a more transparent and fair tax system. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe, when contacted yesterday (31), said over 40 professional Trade Unions, including doctors will give the Government and the Health Ministry a week to resolve the two major issues which jeopardised the State health service. Doctors in state hospitals concluded a ‘Black Protest Week’ last Friday (27 January). A letter was handed over to President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (31), requesting a meeting within the week to discuss the issue. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: LG Polls won’t be impacted – Punchihewa
author: Author not found
Content: The Constitutional Council’s decision to publish advertisements calling for applications to appoint new members to independent commissions will not affect the upcoming Local Government elections, Election Commission (EC) Chairman Nimal Punchihewa said yesterday (31). Punchihewa said this during a meeting held with editors and news directors on media guidelines during the election. The EC Chairman said after the 21st Amendment is passed, the tenure of independent commissions including the EC will lapse. “However, the 21st Amendment facilitated to continue the functions of the independent commissions without disruptions until new members are appointed.” “According to the reports we received after the Constitutional Council meeting, appointing members to the independent commissions will take at least 2-3 months, after publishing newspaper advertisements. Therefore, it will not affect the upcoming election. Even if new members are appointed to the EC, they can continue the work we have started with regard to the LG Polls,” Punchihewa said.  By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: PUCSL says no to retrospective tariff hike ‘unanimously’
author: Author not found
Content: The members of Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) unanimously decided not to implement Cabinet approved interim electricity tariff revision with retrospective effect. Chairman of PUCSL Janaka Ratnayake said this in a special message.  The Cabinet-approved electricity tariff hike was forwarded to the PUCSL, and the Commission later informed the Cabinet that they have sought Attorney General’s advice on the matter. Concerns were raised, however, about the PUCSL’s unanimous decisions, after three members of the PUCSL informed Ratnayake in writing of their decision to implement the electricity tariff hike. Kanchana Wijesekara, Minister of Power and Energy, also claimed that Ratnayake was acting arbitrarily and making decisions without consulting the other members.

title: Wasantha Mudalige released from PTA case
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (31) ordered the release of Inter-University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Convener Wasantha Mudalige, who was in remand custody on charges under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Announcing the release order, the Chief Magistrate mentioned that the suspect was not found to have committed any offence under the Provisions of the PTA. Chief Magistrate Alwis explained that though charges had been filed against the suspect, as per the Provisions in the PTA, none of those charges had been proved beyond a reasonable doubt via the evidence put forth in Court by the prosecution. He noted that the Court, had also taken cognizance of statements that had been made by various individuals, related to the incident. The Chief Magistrate mentioned, in his order, that though the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID) had put forth statements made by Piyumal Samarasinghe alias ‘Motivation Appachchi’, against the suspect, for having allegedly taken over a protest demonstration organised by Samarasinghe, the TID had failed to submit sufficient evidence in Court to prove it. He then remarked that the TID had also been unable to prove the evidence submitted to Court, via another witness Gemunu Wijeratne, who had maintained that groups such as the IUSF had been funded by global terrorist organisations. Chief Magistrate Alwis pointed out, that during the protest demonstration, a Police Inspector, named Wijeyamuni, had provided a statement to the Police, that he had been assaulted by the suspect concerned, but noted that evidence submitted, had proved otherwise. The Court stated that the Inspector had made up the statement to the Police, with the hidden intention of further incarcerating the suspect. The Court, in its release order, also observed that an ASP of the Police Department, Rodrigo had provided a statement to the Police, on 1 January this year, that the suspect had insulted him in front of the Police Department, but that the Court is not convinced with the authenticity or the transparency of the ASP’s statement. The Chief Magistrate opined in his release order, that the dubious and contradictory statements given to the Police, by some of their officers had clearly shown the intent of those officers, to create the impression that they had been physically accosted and verbally insulted by the suspect, while misusing the Provisions of the PTA, to imprison him. Furthermore, Chief Magistrate Alwis, remarked that though the Police had charged another suspect, with causing damage to public property and public places, to date no details had been submitted to him in that regard. Hence, the Chief Magistrate added that perusal of evidence produced before him, has convinced him that the TID had wilfully misused the Provisions of the PTA, to incarcerate the suspect via concocted statements by various Police Officers. Accordingly, the Court acquitted Wasantha Mudalige of the charges filed against him and released from the case. The IUSF Convener’s legal counsel had previously requested his release, on the grounds that there wasn’t any level of facts or evidence, to remand him under the Provisions of the PTA. However, as a few other cases, filed against the suspect before the said Court are yet pending, he was taken back to the Prison. Senior Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris prosecuted on behalf of the Attorney General’s Department, while a group of lawyers headed by President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, looked into the interests of the suspect. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Maithripala Launches 2024 Presidential Bid
author: Author not found
Content: After 1,382 days since the 2019 Easter Sunday bomb attacks that killed 269 innocent civilians and injured another 500, MP Maithripala Sirisena, who at the time of the attacks was the Executive President and the Commander-in-Chief of the Tri-Forces, apologised to the Catholic community of Sri Lanka yesterday (31 January), while announcing his candidature for 2024 Presidential Election.  Speaking to media at the SLFP Headquarters, Sirisena claimed the Catholic community does not hold a grudge against him. “I know that the Catholic community does not hold a grudge against me. I read the Bible when I was 15 years old. When I visit areas where majority of the residents are Catholics, I am always welcomed cordially by them,” he claimed. Sirisena publicly apologised to the Catholic community, including the victims and their family members, for the Easter Sunday bombings, which took place during his tenure as the President. Sirisena also claimed that the Supreme Court verdict clearly stated that he, as the then President, had not been informed of the intelligence information, on the Easter attacks by the responsible officials. However, the President should take the responsibility for any offences committed by any official appointed by him, he said. “I only have to pay compensations because of a mistake made by others. I was not informed of a possible terror attack on 21 April 2019. But, as the President at that time, I have to take the responsibility of the mistakes done by the officials who were under my purview,” he said. Mentioning the life of the Father of Modern South Africa Nelson Mandela, Sirisena said he has read the life story of Mandela, who was imprisoned for 27 years and won the Presidential election right after he was released from prison. “Likewise, I believe, I too can overcome all the conspiracies against me and I should say that I am not a man who will back down from anything. I will contest the next Presidential Election with the support of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP). I believe I could win the election with SLFP support,” Sirisena added. Moreover, Sirisena said that although he was ordered to pay a compensation of Rs 100 million, to the victims of the terror attack, he cannot afford it, as he only has one income, a monthly-based salary. However, he assured that he will pay it with the help of acquaintances. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Catholic Church rejects Maithri’s ‘apology’
author: Author not found
Content: There is no point in seeking forgiveness for the 2019 Easter Attacks before the media while announcing intentions of contesting the next Presidential Election, the Catholic Church emphasised yesterday (31 January), responding to former President Maithripala Sirisena, who called a media briefing at the SLFP Headquarters to announce his candidacy while extending an apology to Catholics. “Instead, former President Sirisena should resign from all current positions to come before the country’s Catholics and the entire nation to apologise for failing to prevent the tragedy and for compromising national security,” the Catholic Church urged.  Director of the Archdiocesan Mass Communication Centre, Fr. Jude Krishantha Fernando, responding to SLFP Leader Sirisena’s appeal for forgiveness from the Catholics in Sri Lanka, and his announcement that he will contest the next Presidential Election, said Sirisena should have stepped down as President on the very day of the Easter attacks and not apologise after a lapse of four years when announcing his intention to run for President. He alleged that the SLFP Leader was now struggling owing to the pressure he felt from the Supreme Court ruling and the resultant blow to his future political aspirations. “But if the SLFP Leader genuinely wants to be forgiven for the Easter Attacks, he should resign from all positions he holds now and have an audience with the Cardinal who is the Head of the Catholic Church of Sri Lanka and the Catholic Community to ask for clemency,” he said. Fr. Fernando said the former President should also seek pardon from the nation for risking the country’s security by failing to take action despite being informed of the 21 April 2019, Easter Sunday Attacks. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Cabinet did not discuss 13A
author: Author not found
Content: Implementing the 13th Amendment to the Constitution was not under discussion at the Cabinet meeting on Monday (30) and no proposal with regard to that was presented to the Cabinet either, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said. When queried, during the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (31), what the Government’s stance is on implementing the 13th Amendment, Gunawardana said no such decisions will be taken without first informing the public and the relevant authorities. “There will be intellectual discussions regarding the matter and they will be informed to the Cabinet. So, I can assure you that we did not receive such information or proposals this week,” he claimed. Implementing the 13th Amendment to the Constitution came to light when President Ranil Wickremesinghe said, during the All-Party Conference, that the 13th Amendment to the Constitution would be implemented accordingly or the Parliament should abolish it. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Doctors give Govt one-week ultimatum
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors gave an ultimatum of one week to the Government to address the medicinal drug shortage and to amend the new tax policy. They vowed to initiate strong trade union action next week, with the support of over 40 trade unions, if their demands went unheeded.  They said they will watch and wait this week before resorting to stronger action next week if the Health Ministry fails to provide a lasting solution to the medicinal drug issue and if the Government does not amend the new Inland Revenue Act to come up with a more transparent and fair tax system. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe, when contacted yesterday (31), said over 40 professional Trade Unions, including doctors will give the Government and the Health Ministry a week to resolve the two major issues which jeopardised the State health service. Doctors in state hospitals concluded a ‘Black Protest Week’ last Friday (27 January). A letter was handed over to President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (31), requesting a meeting within the week to discuss the issue. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: LG Polls won’t be impacted – Punchihewa
author: Author not found
Content: The Constitutional Council’s decision to publish advertisements calling for applications to appoint new members to independent commissions will not affect the upcoming Local Government elections, Election Commission (EC) Chairman Nimal Punchihewa said yesterday (31). Punchihewa said this during a meeting held with editors and news directors on media guidelines during the election. The EC Chairman said after the 21st Amendment is passed, the tenure of independent commissions including the EC will lapse. “However, the 21st Amendment facilitated to continue the functions of the independent commissions without disruptions until new members are appointed.” “According to the reports we received after the Constitutional Council meeting, appointing members to the independent commissions will take at least 2-3 months, after publishing newspaper advertisements. Therefore, it will not affect the upcoming election. Even if new members are appointed to the EC, they can continue the work we have started with regard to the LG Polls,” Punchihewa said.  By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Appointing new members to EC unlawful – Premadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said it is illegal to call for applications for Election Commission members when Local Government Elections have already been announced. Premadasa said this when launching the election campaign with Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Colombo mayoral candidate Mujibur Rahman and other candidates. “It was announced during the meeting of the Constitutional Council that calling for applications for the EC when an election has been called is unfitting,” he said.  “It is okay to call for applications for other independent commissions. But it should not be applied to the EC. It can be done after 9 March when the LG Polls conclude,” Premadasa said.  By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: EC yet to receive Charles’ resignation letter – Punchihewa
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission hasn’t received the resignation letter of its member P.S.M. Charles yet and the latter has even signed a recent gazette notification of the EC and handed it back to the Commission, Election Commission Chairman Nimal Punchihewa said. Speaking at a meeting with editors and news directors yesterday (31 January), Punchihewa said the resignation letter should be sent to the EC by Charles or someone who received it first. The Commission has not received such a letter, he said.  Charles did not attend the meeting with media editors yesterday (31). However, the EC Chairman said she had signed a recent gazette of the EC and sent it to the Commission.  By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: President calls for detailed report from Trade Minister
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has called for a detailed report from Trade Minister Nalin Fernando on the authorities who are allegedly obstructing the latter from executing the Cabinet decision to import eggs. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said Trade Minister Nalin Fernando informed Cabinet that certain Government authorities and institutions are objecting and obstructing egg imports. In response to Fernando’s claim, the President has requested that a report be prepared and presented at the next Cabinet meeting. Gunawardana queried as to why the authorities are objecting to egg imports from countries that have a history of exporting eggs to many nations. “The Sinhala and Tamil New Year is around the corner and the egg shortage that has been created now could worsen during the festive season. It is natural for egg prices to rise during the holiday season. Cabinet was of the opinion that eggs should be imported to alleviate the shortage,” he said. Speaking further, Gunawardana said India is a prominent exporter of eggs and that anyone objecting to egg imports should provide solid proof to support their claims. He underlined that imported eggs will be distributed to hospitals, bakeries, and schools for children’s lunch. He admitted that the scarcity of eggs and the high cost of eggs are major issues for families with school-aged and young children. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: India curbed social fallout by acting fast – Lankan envoy in Delhi
author: Author not found
Content: Lauding India’s financing assurances to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), backing Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring efforts, Lankan High Commissioner Milinda Moragoda said the social fallout of the economic crisis in the strategically located island nation would have been worse if India had not acted swiftly and that India’s support will minimise any trust deficit between the two countries. Speaking to TOI, Moragoda said no other country would have helped Sri Lanka the way India did and that Foreign Minister S Jaishankar’s recent visit to Colombo, his third in the past 12 months, marked the entry of the bilateral relationship into a new phase. It also marked, he said, the beginning of Lanka’s economic recovery. Jaishankar was in Colombo last month to express solidarity with Sri Lanka and he said during his visit India’s financing assurances to the IMF were meant to clear the way for Sri Lanka to move forward and in line also with India’s expectation that all bilateral creditors are dealt with equally. Sri Lanka is currently awaiting similar assurances from China and Japan, other major bilateral lenders. While Beijing has written to Sri Lanka offering a debt moratorium for two years and support for securing IMF’s proposed USD 2.9 billion bailout package, reports from Colombo suggest it’s not clear yet if the international lender, unlike in the case with India, is satisfied with China’s assurances. The timing was very important. India’s support overall and the fact that it took the lead can be hailed as an example of India’s ‘neighbourhood first’ policy. There would have been more social fallout of the crisis otherwise, said Moragoda, adding that India’s assurances are also in keeping with the requirements of Paris Club creditor nations which are helping Sri Lanka with debt restructuring. Protesters last year swarmed the residence of then President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, following acute food and fuel shortages in the country that resulted from Lanka’s debt crisis, leading finally to the exit of the Rajapaksas from power. Moragoda said Sri Lanka is looking to attract more investments from India through cooperation in areas like renewables, power grid connectivity, refineries, tourism, trade expansion and proposed divestments in telecom and insurance companies. Plans to turn Trincomalee into a petroleum hub and use rupee for trade settlement are also under consideration. Jaishankar had said in Colombo that India will encourage investments in core areas like energy, infrastructure and tourism. Significantly, Moragoda said India’s support will help address the trust deficit between the two countries, which has often been exacerbated by China’s ever-increasing footprints. “We went through some rough patches but what’s important is that we kept communication going. We were frank and candid. There will be ups and downs but what India did for us, no other country would have done.” India was the first country to provide financing assurances to the IMF as it sought proactive action by all creditors to help the nation of 22 million people. India and Sri Lanka are currently working to finalise dates for a visit by President Ranil Wickremesinghe soon. Jaishankar had delivered an invite to the president when he called on him during his visit. On Jaishankar’s call for implementation of the 13th Amendment, which seeks devolution of power to the Tamil minority, and early conduct of provincial elections, Moragoda said Wickremesinghe had been working to bring all parties together from the day he was sworn in. “Ìt’s complex in Sri Lanka. It’s difficult to speak in terms of timelines but the president is trying. This issue has been on the table for 75 years and the 13th Amendment has served as a framework for settlement. Right now, Sri Lanka is faced with a bigger crisis, an existential one, and it’s important everybody gets together,” he said. (Times Of India ) By SACHIN PARASHAR

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: The Education Ministry has settled payments to food suppliers who provide food to schoolchildren under the ‘Nutrition Programme’ for the months of November and December 2022. According to a Ministry statement, the total amount to be paid to provincial food suppliers for the months of November and December 2022 is Rs 2.4 billion. The money owed to these provinces had been credited to their accounts by 31 January 2023. Zonal Education Offices are already making payments to food suppliers. Accordingly, the Education Ministry has paid for Western Province, Central Province, Eastern Province, North Central Province, North Western Province, Northern Province, Sabaragamuwa Province, Southern Province and Uva Province in sums of 399,418,020, 269,900,000, 350,000,000, 256,000,000, 221,000,000, 164,050,718, 182,993,773, 335,356,317 and 225,470,000, respectively.  Popular

title: Rev. Fr. Nishantha Silva appointed Bishop of Badulla
author: Author not found
Content: Rev. Fr. Echchampulle Arachchige Jude Nishantha Silva was appointed as the Bishop of Badulla by Pope Francis, the Apostolic Nunciature in Sri Lanka announced. In a statement issued by the Apostolic Nunciature on Monday (30 January), it was stated that the new Bishop had been appointed by the Pope following the resignation of Bishop Julian Winston Fernando as the Bishop of Badulla for age limit in accordance with Section 1 of Canon 401 of the Code of Canon Law. The Apostolic Nunciature in Sri Lanka said Pope Francis had accepted Bishop Fernando’s resignation from the Pastoral Office of the Diocese of Badulla and appointed Fr. Nishantha Silva as his successor. The Colombo Archbishop’s House said Fr. Silva had served as the Judicial Vicar and Chancellor of the Diocese of Badulla and the Director of USCOD (Caritas).

title: Saemaul Undong Foundation pledges support
author: Author not found
Content: President of the Saemaul Undong Foundation Lee Seung-Jong called on Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the Republic of Korea Savitri Panabokke on 27 January at the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Seoul. During the meeting, Ambassador Panabokke discussed the success of present Saemaul projects in Sri Lanka and appreciated the contribution of the Saemaul Undong Foundation towards the development of the rural economy of the country. The Ambassador also discussed mechanisms to enhance future cooperation between Sri Lanka and the Saemaul Foundation. Director of Project Management Kwon Lyun Min, PR Team Leader of Saemaul Undong Foundation Esther Jounghyun Kim and Second Secretary of the Embassy Sachini Dias also participated in the meeting.

title: Ambassador-designate Colombage assumes duties in Indonesia
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador-designate to the Republic of Indonesia Admiral Professor Jayanath Colombage assumed duties at the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jakarta on 30 January. On arrival at the Embassy, Ambassador-designate Colombage was welcomed by the Embassy staff. His assumption was marked by a simple ceremony which commenced with the lighting of oil lamp by the Ambassador and other staff. Addressing the Embassy staff, the Ambassador-designate highlighted the importance of further strengthening bilateral relations with the Republic of Indonesia given its key achievements in economic, political and defence sectors. As the Chair of ASEAN for the year 2023, Indonesia plays a pivotal role and is an important partner for Sri Lanka to reach out to the entire region, he said. He emphasised that Indonesia and Sri Lanka are maritime neighbours and have the potential to develop collaborative mechanisms to ensure safety and security of maritime trade. Ambassador-designate Colombage was previously Secretary to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Director General of the Institute of National Security Studies in Sri Lanka. He has served the Sri Lanka Navy for a period of 36 years and was a former Commander of the Sri Lanka Navy. Ambassador-designate Colombage has been a guest lecturer in universities and training institutes in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, China, India, Japan and Pakistan. He holds a PhD from General Sir John Kotelawala University, Master of Science in Defence and Strategic Studies from Madras University and Master of Arts in International Studies from Kings College, London.

title: Nimal Siripala orders to open more visa counters
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva has ordered the officials at the Katunayake and Mattala airports to operate additional counters for the speedy issuance of visas. This is in view of the increase in the number of tourists arriving in the country with the start of the tourist season. It has been reported that at present, Russian tourists have to wait at the Mattala Airport for over four hours to obtain visas on entering Sri Lanka. This was revealed at a discussion on challenges faced in the tourism promotion sector and possible measurers to resolve them. The Minister instructed the Chairman of Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) (Private) Limited to immediately deploy additional staff in opening additional visa counters to assist Immigration Officers working in the airport. Several new airlines including Bulgarian and Israeli airlines have expressed interest in commencing passenger flight operations to Sri Lanka. In view of this new development, the Minister instructed the Secretaries of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation and the Ministry of Tourism to take immediate steps to obtain necessary approvals and to prepare the relevant Cabinet Paper. Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, Minister of Health Keheliya Rambukwella, Minister of Sports Roshan Ranasinghe and a number of officials also participated in the discussion held on 31 January at the auditorium of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation.

title: Sugarcane crushing to begin today
author: Author not found
Content: Manager of the Sewanagala Sugar Factory P.R. Priyantha said the process of crushing sugarcane for 2023 is slated to commence from today (1). But, he observed that at present there is an acute shortage of farmers to carry out harvesting of sugarcane at the factory. He said after the completion of harvesting of sugarcane for 2022, the factory had been shut for routine maintenance. Priyantha said the factory had only been reopened for the New Year on 20 January. According to him, 237,500 metric tonnes of sugarcane had been crushed last year while, he added, that they plan to crush 340,000 metric tonnes of sugarcane this year. But, he remarked that shortage of labourers for the harvesting of sugarcane could stall the process. By S. Kuttapitiya – Sewanagala

title: No. 5 Fighter Squadroan marks 32nd Anniversary today
author: Author not found
Content: The No. 5 Fighter Squadron, known as the ‘Black Drongos,’ celebrates its 32nd Anniversary of Glory today (1 February). No. 5 Fighter Squadron was formed with the arrival of four F-7BS fighters, one FT-7B trainer and two FT-5 trainers on 1 February 1991. Squadron Leader H.D. Abeywickrema was appointed as its first Commanding Officer. Air Force Commander, Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana was also a founder member of the No. 5 Fighter Squadron. Then Squadron Leader P. Gunasinghe, Flight Lieutenant S.K. Pathirana, Flight Lieutenant I.J.I. Wijetilleke and Flight Lieutenant S. Hendawitharane were the initial pilots in SLAF history to break the speed of sound and be considered the pioneers of the supersonic fighter age. The Squadron’s initial operations commenced from SLAF Base Katunayake, but were soon shifted to SLAF China Bay in 1994 to reduce response time and to act promptly for operational requirements during the war time. However, due to security concerns, it was later shifted back to its home base in Katunayake in 1996. To enhance the No. 5 Fighter Squadron’s Air Interdiction and specialised low-level strike capability, six Russian MiG-27 and one MiG-23UB trainer were inducted to the squadron in 2000. 2007 was a remarkable year for the SLAF and the No. 5 Fighter Squadron in terms of fleet enhancements. The modern F-7GS which is the advanced version of the F-7BS in relation to avionics, including an AI Radar, sophisticated weapons delivery system with air-to-air missile strike capability, and a user-friendly glass cockpit, was inducted. Much-needed and well-maintained SLAF air superiority over the nation was threatened with the emergence of the LTTE Air Wing, followed by the first airspace intrusion on 26 March 2007. The newly introduced F-7 ‘Air Guard’ fighters were called upon with expectations that they would live up to their literal reputation as the first supersonic interceptors with air-to-air strike capability. The squadron has been headed by ten Commanding Officers. Shouldering its responsibility as the cradle of fighter pilots, the squadron has produced over 25 pilots who were the front-line fighters to face the brutal enemy counterattacks, delivering tons of explosives to weaken the enemy’s morale to fight back in the prolonged Eelam Wars. No. 5 Squadron has contributed its effort promptly and effectively whenever it was called on with distinction and honour performing a multitude of Counter Air and Counter Surface Force Operations and conducting over 600 flying sorties during the humanitarian operations. The results of these efforts were clearly manifested in the nation’s ultimate victory over terrorism. No. 5 Fighter Squadron, which was also awarded the President’s Colours on 5 March 2021 for its valiant contribution, continues to render its service to the nation as the leading Air Defence platform guarding the skies of our motherland and will continue to prosper in the future with the latest updates and a highly trained crew.

title: SL more corrupt in 2022 – TI
author: Author not found
Content: The latest Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI) compiled by Transparency International (TI) showed that Sri Lanka’s score in the 2022 CPI stands at 36 out of 100, one point lower than the previous year. “Sri Lanka’s score in the 2022 CPI stands at 36 out of 100, one point lower than the previous year, which was 37, and two points lower than from 2020 – 2017 and 2014, where the CPI score remained stagnated at 38. Sri Lanka ranks at 101 in 2022, along with Panama, Albania, Kazakhstan, Serbia, Ecuador, Peru and Thailand,” TI said. The CPI scores 180 countries and territories around the world based on perceptions of public sector corruption. The scores reflect the views of experts and surveys from the business sector. The CPI is calculated using data from 13 external sources, including the World Bank, World Economic Forum, private risk and consulting companies and think tanks. The CPI uses a scale from 0 to 100, whereby 100 is considered very clean and 0 is considered highly corrupt. Over the past 10 years, Sri Lanka’s CPI score has remained relatively the same, from the highest being 40 in 2012 and the lowest being 36, which is the score this year and was the score in 2016. The top countries on the Index are Denmark (90), Finland (87) and New Zealand (87) while South Sudan (13), Syria (13) and Somalia (12) remain at the bottom of the CPI in 2022. Types of public sector corruption and related criteria captured in the CPI encompass bribery, diversion of public funds, and effective prosecution of corruption cases, adequate legal frameworks, and access to information, and legal protections for whistleblowers, journalists and investigators. Meanwhile, Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) said Sri Lanka too demonstrates the same lack of progress in terms of resisting corruption, coupled with suppression of civil society, culminating from a lack of political will to change the system, even amidst the crippling effects of kleptocracy on the country’s economy and on the quality of life of citizens. TISL urges the Government to recall how Sri Lankans of all walks of life came together in protest against those who were responsible for the bankruptcy of the nation, understanding the very close connection between corruption, poor governance, the country’s economy and their day-to-day lives. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) on which the Government is depending to resuscitate the fallen economy, also emphasised the need to reduce corruption vulnerabilities, by improving fiscal transparency, public financial management and a stronger anti-corruption legal framework. While the Government is in critical need to attract foreign investment, tourism and other income generation methods along with debt restructuring, foreign aid and other support from the international community to be able to secure the essentials for the people, it is paramount that the trust in the Government, the Legislature and the public sector be restored within and outside of Sri Lanka.  TISL also recalls the essential anti-corruption reforms that it urged the Government to implement to revive the economy, none of which stand implemented as at this day.

title: Govt cannot scrap Independence Day celebrations – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Expenses for the Independence Day celebrations come under traditional expenses and the Government cannot avoid commemorating the 75th National Independence Day because it is the day the nation demonstrates its dignity, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said.  He was responding to a query on why the Government is spending exorbitant sums on celebrations against a backdrop of the nation facing its worst economic crisis since Independence in 1948. In reference to the Republic Day celebrations of India in Sri Lanka, he said the Sri Lankan Government is doing the same thing as India in commemorating one of the most important days in Sri Lankan history. Gunawardana said no one can blame the Government for not bearing an expense that has been borne for many decades. “There are traditional expenses such as Parliament sessions, Court proceedings, and other nationally significant projects. These expenses cannot be reduced, but other expenses are being cut. The costs of this traditional celebration will be borne by citizens. This year marks the 75th Anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. Celebrating this day is important in strengthening ties with other countries,” he said. When queried about the expenses for the 75th National Independence Day at the Cabinet media briefing, Gunawardana said the expenses for the Independence Day celebrations is nothing compared to expenses for the rest of the year. By Thameenah Razeek

title: No power cuts today
author: Author not found
Content: After a tug-of-war with the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) and Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) over uninterrupted power supply during the on-going GCE Advanced Level examination 2022, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) yesterday (30) announced there will be no power outages today (31). Power was supplied without interruption on Monday (30) as well. This follows the Water Management Secretariat releasing adequate water to generate power without any interruptions on the two days, on the request made by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) on 29 February. A decision on supplying power without an interruption for the rest of the exam days will be taken on 1 February. The PUCSL requested the Water Management Secretariat to release adequate water from the reservoirs to generate sufficient hydro power for next couple of days. “The electricity demand in January 2023 dropped by 13% – 14% compared to the demand in the same period in 2022. CEB is currently saving 1.3GWh – 2GWh (estimated) per day by imposing power interruptions. The hydro dispatch in January 2023 is 20% -21% less than compared to the hydro dispatch in the same period in 2022 and therefore, Hydro Reservoirs has a total capacity of water at present which can generate 778GWh of electrical energy, which is 100GWh higher than the reservoir capacity had in the same period of year 2022,” PUCSL said on a statement. Based on the above, the Commission requested the Mahaweli Authority of Sri Lanka to allow CEB to use at least 2GWh per day more than the allocated water dispatch until 17 February 2023 for power generation.                                              (TR)

title: HRCSL files contempt case in SC over power cuts
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) yesterday (30) filed a Contempt of Court case before the Supreme Court against the Chairman of the Ceylon Electricity Board, Secretary to the Ministry of Power and Energy and the Chairman of the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, over the failure to supply continuous power during the GCE Advanced Level Examination period. HRCSL observed that the said authorities have failed to abide by the settlement arrived at before the Commission with regard to the continuous supply of power during the A/L examination 2022 from 23 January to 17 February 2023. They thereby said that the CEB Chairman is guilty of the offence of contempt under the provisions of the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 21 of 1996. The HRCSL said notwithstanding the settlement arrived by the above parties, to provide uninterrupted electricity for the A/L students, during the period of the examination, the CEB wilfully and maliciously disregarded the settlement and continued with the power cuts.  They added that the settlement was to prevent the power cut only during the period of the A/L examination while stating that the blatant disregard of the CEB to provide an uninterrupted electricity supply during the examination period is a gross violation of a child’s right to education.  The HRCSL said that having admitted before the Commission that there are meaningful ways to provide electricity, and settling on that basis, the CEB disregarded the assurance and proceeded with the power cut.  They said the unbecoming and outrageous behaviour of the State Officials of the CEB is an intentional affront to justice and contempt of the HRCSL. Thereby, HRCSL has signed a certificate of contempt and forwarded it to the Supreme Court and a case of Contempt of Court was also filed before the Supreme Court in this regard.                         (FT)

title: No job quotas for Sri Lankans in Türkiye – Foreign Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: Following the publication, on social media, of job postings for Sri Lankans in Türkiye, the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Ankara, Türkiye clarified that the Government of Türkiye has not provided any quota for the Government of Sri Lanka for the recruitment of employees from Sri Lanka. Recently, fake job agencies invited candidates to apply and meet them in Colombo. Due to the country’s financial crisis, there was an uncontrollable crowd of young people who had come to submit their documents in order to find employment in Türkiye. The Foreign Ministry said that the recruitment for employment opportunities in Türkiye is arranged by private recruiting agencies, registered at the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE), in collaboration with the private Turkish recruiting companies, which are registered in regional chambers of commerce Türkiye. Before recruitment is made, the Turkish recruitment companies are again registered at the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Ankara. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: PUCSL to discuss power tariff hike on 8 Feb
author: Author not found
Content: A consultative meeting would be held on 8 February in connection with the proposed electricity tariff hike, the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) said The PUCSL is in the process of determining the electricity tariff, based on the tariff proposal dated 5 January 2023, requesting a revision of electricity tariff. This consultative meeting is one of the steps in the tariff determining process. “As agreed at the meeting held at the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) recently, if any additional cost is required in providing an uninterrupted power supply until 17 February 2023, that cost will be recovered through the above tariff determination,” the PUCSL said.

title: Tamil Parties plan ‘Black Day’ on Independence Day
author: Author not found
Content: As the Government plans to spend Rs 200 million on the 75th Anniversary of Sri Lanka’s Independence, two Tamil political Parties along with Jaffna University students from the North and East plan to hold a Black Day and stage a protest hoisting black flags, to remind the Government that they have not worked on the process aimed at resolving the national question and meeting their demands that have been tabled. The Tamil National Alliance (TNA) faction of the Illankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK) has chosen to boycott the 75th Independence Day celebrations and stage its own protest in Kallady, Batticaloa. MPs M.A. Sumanthrian and Shanakiyan Rasamanickam of Batticaloa will lead this protest. Sumanthiran claimed that despite receiving an official invitation from the Government to attend the Independence Day celebration in Colombo, they chose to assemble in Kallady instead and raise a black flag when the Sri Lankan flag was raised in Colombo, said Rasamanickam. Meanwhile, Jaffna MP Selvam Adaikkalanathan stated that their split party, the ‘new TNA,’ will join the Jaffna University Students in their protest parade on 1 February and travel for four days in vehicles to reach the Eastern University of Batticaloa on 4 February. They intend to stop in various locations along their journey from the North to the East. Preparation is underway for the vehicle parade of the Jaffna University students to join the black day protest. Sumanthiran stated that they would declare 4 February as a ‘Black Day’ and launch a campaign to achieve true freedom. “Immediately after independence, it was transformed into a majority system under the guise of democracy. That is why other people in this country do not have freedom,” he explained. “The Sinhala Buddhists believed they had gained freedom. However, they now believe that they did not obtain freedom.” It is unclear whether Tamil National People’s Front (TNPF) Leader MP Gajendrakumar Ponnambalam and Leader of Tamil Makkal Kootani (TMK) MP C.V. Wigneswaran will also participate in the Black Day protest. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: 161 medicinal items in short supply at Ratnapura hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: About 161 medicinal items are in serious short supply at the Ratnapura Teaching Hospital (TH), as well as at hospitals that come under the purview of the Sabaragamuwa Provincial Council. This was revealed during the Ratnapura District Coordinating Committee meeting held recently. Director of the Ratnapura Teaching Hospital Dr. Anoj Rodrigo said the scarcity of vital medicinal items has also stalled crucial surgeries being carried out at the hospital as well. When MP W.D.J. Seneviratne inquired whether there is a drug shortage at the hospital, the Director of the Hospital confirmed the shortage of essential drugs. The Hospital Director stressed that a report to that effect was being submitted to the Ministry of Health via the Internet daily. BY L. Niroshana

title: CC to advertise for applications to join Independent Commissions
author: Author not found
Content: The Constitutional Council yesterday (30) decided to publish an advertisement in newspapers on 1 February 2023, calling for applications for membership of independent commissions (ICs). The draft format of the application would be published on the Official Parliament website. The deadline to submit applications is 15 February 2023. Meanwhile, the Constitutional Council considered the recommendation of the President to appoint K.P. Fernando, President of the Court of Appeal, as a Judge of the Supreme Court, to fill the vacancy created by Justice L.T.B. Dehideniya’s retirement. The Constitutional Council unanimously approved the recommendation. Furthermore, the nomination of N.B.P.D.S. Karunarathna, Judge of the Court of Appeal, to be appointed as the President of the Court of Appeal and the nomination of M.A.R. Marikkar, High Court Judge to be appointed as a Judge of the Court of Appeal, to fill the resultant vacancies were approved unanimously. The Constitutional Council met in Parliament yesterday (30) and the sitting was chaired by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, MPs Kariyawasam, other council members Dr. Prathap Ramanujam, Dr. Dilkushi Anula Wijesundere, Dr. Dinesha Samararatne was present at the meeting. MP Kabir Hashim had informed of his inability to attend this meeting due to unavoidable circumstances.

title: Abduction case against Hirunika on 28 February
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday, fixed the abduction case, against former MP Hirunika Premachandra, for 28 February, to fix dates for the trial. The former MP and seven of her aides, had been indicted, by the Attorney General, before High Court, with abducting Amila Priyantha, a youth serving in a textile shop at Colombo 9, on 21 December eight years ago, detaining him unlawfully and threatening him. The Judge gave this order, having considered a request made by the State Counsel, on behalf of the prosecution. However, Premachandra’s seven aides sentenced to two years RI suspended for 12 years, after they had pleaded guilty to the charges filed against them, on 24 November six years ago. But, the charges filed against the former UNP MP, were not dropped and continued, as she refused to plead guilty. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SJB demands AG indict Easter Attack mastermind
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) yesterday submitted a letter, to the Attorney General’s Department, requesting that indictments be filed against those who were ordered, by the Supreme Court recently, to pay compensation due to their failure to prevent the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. Several SJB MPs visited the Attorney General’s Department yesterday (30) and said the Supreme Court had ordered several persons to pay compensations to the victims of the terror attacks. “That verdict was given after hearing few Fundamental Rights petitions. There is a Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) report on the terror attacks too. In such a backdrop, we want to know why indictments have not been filed against any of them,” the SJB, in its letter, said. After handing over the letter, SJB MP Hector Appuhamy said if those in power are unable to serve justice even after several years have passed since the tragedy, they have no right to be in power. “The greatest issue for us is who the person truly responsible for the terror attack. It is clear that this person is hiding and he needs to be exposed. After that, he should be punished legally,” Appuhamy said. By Nabiya Vaffoor
