title: Race Course murder suspect further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: The suspect in the murder of a female university student, at Race Course Grounds recently, was further remanded until 13 February by Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis. When the case was called yesterday (30), the victim’s father testified during the Magisterial Inquest. He told the Court that the victim’s family had no knowledge about the relationship between the victim and the suspect. The Court then issued notice and instructed the Cinnamon Gardens Police, to summon the security guard on duty at the Race Course grounds, to testify at the next hearing. The Chief Magistrate also ordered the Police, to produce the suspect for a psychiatrist evaluation, at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH), Angoda and submit a medical report at the next hearing. The suspect was not produced in Court. The Prisons Department conveyed to Court that the suspect is currently being treated at the Prisons Psychiatry Hospital. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Provincial schools and hospitals to get rooftop solar
author: Author not found
Content: A programme is being implemented by the Provincial Councils and the Ministry of Health, to include all provincial schools and hospitals in a ‘Rooftop Solar Panel Programme’, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said. Wijesekara tweeted that under the Indian Government Credit Line of USD 100 million for renewable energy, 374 national schools, 25 State universities, 20 National Colleges of Education, eight Teacher Training Colleges, 20 Technical Colleges (VTA/NAITA), 25 District Secretariats, 331 Divisional Secretariats, 79 ITDLH centres of Education, 220 Tri Forces and Police Buildings, 824 Pirivenas, 5kv system each for 9,176 other religious institutes and other key Government buildings totalling 11,219 project locations, will be equipped with Roof Top Solar panels. Out of those places, a total of 827 have already been surveyed, the Minister said.

title: Five fishers detained by Myanmar Police
author: Author not found
Content: Myanmar Police have apprehended five fishermen from Dickwella, Trincomalee, and Weligama, together with their fishing vessel. They reportedly left the coasts for fishing on 29 December 2022, according to information. The five men are being held at the Botahtaung Township Police Station, according to the Mynmar Police. The families were informed on 23 January that these individuals had been arrested for trespassing on the Myanmar economic zone. These five fishermen had left in a single fishing trawler, which Myanmar Police had also detained in the Yangon River. W.G.L. Ruwan Kumara, R.R. Gamini, L.H.N. Karunasinghe, L.S.J. Nanayakkara, and M.M.R. Dinuka Dilshan are the five fishermen. They are all in their 50s. The vessel owner told Ceylon Today that he and several others will arrive in Colombo today to meet the Fisheries Minister, the Foreign Minister, and the Immigration Office to lodge a complaint about the incident and to assist in returning the fishermen and the fishing trawler to Sri Lanka. Several fishermen have previously ended up in Myanmar waters, and with the assistance of the Foreign Ministry, they have returned without their fishing vessels. When asked about the arrest of the five fishermen in Myanmar, the Foreign Ministry stated that they had sent all information to the Sri Lanka Embassy in Yangon.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: EC hits back at Govt Info DG
author: Author not found
Content: In response to Director General of Government Information Dinith Chinthaka Karunaratne’s claim that the Gazette Notification, to commence the Local Government Election process, has not been sent to the Government Printer as yet, the Election Commission (EC) stressed that the Director General lacks basic legal knowledge on holding an election. Karunaratne made this remark in a statement released to the media on Sunday (29). He said the Gazette Notification with the signatures of EC Chairman and members, had not been sent to the Government Printer so far. In a scathing statement, signed by the EC Secretary yesterday (30), the commission said it is hard to understand the intention behind Karunaratne’s statement as the notification with regard to holding the election is published by the Returning Officers under the Section 38 of the Local Government (Amendment) Act No 16 of 2017. “The election process was started on 4 January after the notification calling for nominations by the Returning Officers. The Director General has forgotten that fact. This is the normal process and this is what happened in previous elections. The signatures of the EC Chairman and the members are not needed for that. It seems the Director General lacked this basic legal knowledge when issuing the above statement,” the EC said. The relevant notice was handed over to the Government Printer on Monday (30) by the Returning Officers to publish it in the Government Gazette. “It is sad that the Director General of Government Information has made his post ‘lousy’ by issuing statements without having a proper knowledge,” the EC said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Authors, publishers complain to CID against PDF pirates
author: Author not found
Content: A collective of book publishers and authors lodged a complaint with CID yesterday (30) against illegal PDF distributors on internet. More than 400 authors and book publishers joined the cause that aimed to end the illegal PDF mafia, which became intense recently. They held a media briefing prior to lodging the complaint with the CID. This is the first time, in which book publishers and authors came together to fight against illegal PDFs of their books. Pic by Ganga Shinie Gamage (Social Media)

title: Vets strike against Govt interference
author: Author not found
Content: The Western Provincial Council Department of Animal Production and Health and veterinary hospitals island-wide were shut down yesterday (30), against what they termed as unnecessary interference by the Government in the Department of Animal Production and Health. As a result, people who brought their pets for treatment had been forced to turn back while being compelled to wait endlessly in the vain hope of the offices being reopened. The head of the Government Veterinary Officers’ Association Dr. Sisira Piyasiri said they were forced to resort to the strike due to the unwelcome interference by the government. He warned that if the government does not step aside allowing the department to function independently, they will resort to even more stringent trade union action. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: Arrangements made to hand over private lands -Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said on Sunday (29) that necessary arrangements have been made to hand over private lands to owners in the high security zone in the Valikamam North Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division in the Jaffna District. He said, the ceremony to release lands to owners will be chaired by him on 10 February at the Jaffna District Secretariat, and that nearly 1,200 acres of private land in the aforementioned area are under the control of Security Forces, with a portion of it to be handed over in this manner. Devananda added that President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who had been to Jaffna to take part in the Thai Pongal celebrations, had pledged that he will take necessary steps to release private land in the North gradually. “Following the visit of the President to Jaffna, a formal discussion with regard to this matter was held at the Jaffna District Secretariat between Presidential Secretariat officials and high-ranking officials in the district,” Minister Devananda said. Following the discussion, Presidential Secretariat officials visited to inspect lands which are under the control of Security Forces, the Department of Forest Conservation and the Department of Wildlife Conservation. Minister Devananda expressed confidence that a portion of land in the Valikamam North DS Division can be released before the 75th Independence Day celebrations to be held on 4 February. “The Government is committed to release the agricultural and residential lands in the aforesaid DS Division,” Minister Devananda added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Court typist complains Rs 40M misappropriated by Edu officers
author: Author not found
Content: A complaint has been lodged claiming that a sum of Rs 40 million, set aside to ensure nutrition for the students in the Hingurakgoda Education Zone, has been misappropriated by officers of Education Ministry and the Hingurakgoda Zonal Education Office. The complaint was lodged by a typist, attached to the Polonnaruwa Court, with the Polonnaruwa Special Crimes Detection Unit on 29 January. The complainant requested the Police to apprehend the suspects who had pocketed the aforementioned sum and to reimburse the stolen money to the State. She added that a separate complaint will also be lodged against the theft of money with the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL). BY Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: DEC vegetable wholesale prices drop but not retail
author: Author not found
Content: Traders at the Dambulla Economic Centre (DEC) stated that the wholesale price of several essential items, such as vegetables and fruits, had reduced markedly at the DEC by yesterday. However, these traders insisted that despite the reduction of the wholesale price the retail price of essentials had not declined. At the time of writing, the wholesale price of vegetables such as cabbage, pumpkin, capsicum, carrot, leeks and beetroot at DEC had come down drastically. These traders added that the consumers are unwilling to purchase essentials in large quantity unlike in the past due retail prices not changing. BY K. K. Ariyadasa – Dambulla

title: PM suggests appointing Hony. Consuls to promote ‘Destination Sri Lanka’
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said, the tourism industry is the one that can give the strongest help to the Sri Lankan economy and called on the stakeholders to take innovative steps for its growth. He said tourism can generate the vital foreign exchange for the country. Speaking at the golden jubilee of the Blue Oceanic Beach Hotel, of the Jetwing Hotels in Negombo, he stressed the need for the government to build a network of honorary consuls and representatives abroad to introduce and promote ‘Destination Sri Lanka’ in collaboration with the stakeholders of  the tourism industry and the hospitality sector. The services of honorary consuls will not incur any expenditure to Sri Lanka as there are many friends of Sri Lanka abroad who are willing to promote tourism. The Prime Minister said this kind of parallel honourary consul offices will help to promote Sri Lankan tourism faster as the officers of the diplomatic service are extremely busy exchanging communications in political capitals of the world on major bilateral issues. The Prime Minister also urged the hospitality industry to look into the possibility of creating entities capable of self generating energy, preferably renewable, and assured that the government would like to initiate a discussion on this issue with all relevant stakeholders. Premier Gunawardena also suggested that the finance sector and the Central Bank work together to introduce a system to facilitate foreign tourists to pay in preferred forms of electronic payment. “Just as much we encourage half a dozen international credit cards at the moment, it should further smoothen and popularise travellers coming from markets of Asian giants,” he said.    The Prime Minister praised the hotels that involved with communities to develop food production in the local area. “This is a great initiative and must be fully supported by the government. I am sure the Minister of Tourism, who is also the Minister for Land, will agree with me on broadening Government policy of the Food Security drive and provide more land for cultivation on short-term to the industry and the community living around their hot spots.”  “Our greatest wealth is our human resource. That’s what we must rightly invest in. Remember 50 years ago Herbert Cooray only created a family business, but it grew as he started to invest in young men and women, and it is all of you who have made it a world class brand today,” he said. Premier Gunawardena recalled the services rendered by the pioneer Jetwing Chairman, late Herbert Cooray, who faced challenges courageously and expanded the hotel group without running away as some others did in the face of drop of tourist arrivals. Former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga, Tourism Minister Harin Fernando, Parliamentarian Yadamini Gunawardena, Jetwing Chairman Hiran Cooray, late founder’s wife Menike Cooray and Directors Ruan Samarasimghe and Shiromal Cooray and top representatives of hospitality industry were present on this occasion.

Former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga, Tourism Minister Harin Fernando, Parliamentarian Yadamini Gunawardena, Jetwing Chairman Hiran Cooray, late founder’s wife Menike Cooray and Directors Ruan Samarasimghe and Shiromal Cooray and top representatives of hospitality industry were present on this occasion.

title: Ali Sabry thanks Saudi Arabia for support
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Minister Ali Sabry acknowledged the contribution of nearly SAR 1.5 billion, made by the Saudi Development Fund, in infrastructure and other developments in Sri Lanka and the solidarity shown in the IMF-supported debt restructuring programme. The Minister thanked his counterpart for hosting nearly 185,000 Sri Lankans and expressed his willingness to enhance the employment opportunities for Sri Lankans in skilled, semi-skilled and professional categories in the Kingdom. Minister Sabry invited Saudi investors to invest in Sri Lanka, especially in the Colombo Port City and the Renewable Energy sector.

title: Lankans abroad donate equipment to Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: A consignment of Medical equipment, valued at more than one million rupees, was handed over to the Akkaraipattu Base Hospital, by Ven. Rajawelle Subhuthi Thera recently. The donation was made by the welfare organisation of Sri Lankans living in the United Kingdom, Australia and Canada. The ceremony held with the participation of religious dignitaries, Akkaraipattu Mayor Ahamed Zacky Athaullah, members of the Hospital Committee and representatives of Civil Organisations, was presided over by the Chairman of Hospital CommitteeDr. M.A.M. Rakkeesthu. The medical equipment was handed over to the Hospital Superintendent Dr. M.H. Sanoofer by Ven. Rajawelle Subhuthi Thera, in the presence of medical professionals of the Hospital. Medical equipment was also donated to Addalaichenai District Hospital and Akkaraipattu MOH Office. Speaking at the gathering Ven. Rajawelle Subhuthi Thera said that the equipment was purchased with voluntary contributions and should be utilised with utmost care and with the sense of responsibility. He also stressed the importance of entering these items in the Inventory register. Ven. Thera thanked those who made a valuable contribution. The Secretary of the Committee Dr. U. L. Zainudeen delivered the vote of thanks. BY M. A. P. Deen – Ampara

title: Paddy farmers protest demanding certified price
author: Author not found
Content: Farmers, from 12 farmer unions, staged a protest demonstration last morning at Arachchikattuwa demanding a certified price for paddy. The protesting farmers said that presently the private sector has come forward to purchase their paddy harvest at Rs 55 to 60 per kg but they insisted that they were not content with the price offered. They added that a sum of Rs 110 is being incurred by them towards the production of a kilo of paddy and hence they urged the Government to impose a certified price while striving to purchase paddy from them. BY Prasad Purnimal – Chilaw

title: SL’s largest organic granular fertiliser factory opens
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s largest organic granular fertiliser manufacturing factory was opened in Pannala yesterday (30).  The Ministry of Agriculture stated that Hyosong OnB, a granular fertiliser manufacturing company, belonging to the Republic of Korea, manufactures 100 per cent environmentally-friendly organic granular fertiliser through this factory. This factory is fully equipped with high-tech equipment, and robotic technology has been used for the production of organic granular fertiliser. Further 1,800 MT of high quality organic granular fertiliser, required for Sri Lanka’s plantation industry, will be produced through this factory, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. South Korean Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Woongjin Jeong, emphasised that this project would further strengthen Sri Lanka-Korea friendly relations.

title: WHO TURNS LIGHT BACK ON ‘NEGLECTED TROPICAL DISEASES’
author: Author not found
Content: The World Health Organisations (WHO) called on countries and communities in the South-East Asia Region to mark this year’s ‘Neglected Tropical Diseases’ (NTDs) Day by  making bold, sustainable investments to help free the one billion people globally who were vulnerable to their devastating health, social and economic costs. “NTDs are a diverse group of 20 conditions that are mainly prevalent in tropical areas.” Globally, they affect more than one billion people, cost low- and middle-income countries billions of dollars every year, and perpetuate a cycle of poor educational outcomes and limited professional opportunities, mostly for impoverished communities, where they disproportionately affect women and children. The WHO South-East Asia Region accounts for the second highest NTD burden globally. At least one NTD is endemic to each of the Region’s 11 Member States, and more than 938 million people in the Region require interventions against NTDs. In 2021, the Region accounted for 59% of the global population requiring interventions against lymphatic filariasis (LF), 66.5% of new cases of leprosy, and 56% of children requiring regular de-worming against soil-transmitted helminthiases. Since 2014, WHO has supported countries of the Region to make rapid, equitable and sustained progress against NTDs in line with the Region’s Flagship Priority on eliminating NTDs and other diseases on the verge of elimination. In 2016 India was declared yaws-free. Maldives, Thailand and Sri Lanka have eliminated lymphatic filariasis (LF) as a public health problem. Bangladesh is currently being assessed for validation of elimination of LF as a public health problem, and Timor-Leste is now under post-treatment surveillance. Nepal and Myanmar have eliminated trachoma as a public health problem. All kala-azar-endemic implementation units in Bangladesh have now reached the elimination target, which India and Nepal are also close to achieving. India, Indonesia and Nepal continue to roll out triple drug therapy to accelerate action against LF, which Myanmar is also preparing to introduce. Between 2010 and 2020, the Region reduced the total number of people who require interventions against NTDs by a remarkable 20%. Across the Region, new challenges and opportunities have emerged. In 2021, WHO launched a global NTD road map that aims to ‘End the neglect’, setting a series of global targets and milestones to prevent, control, eliminate or eradicate NTDs, as well as cross-cutting targets that are aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals. In implementing the road map, the Region aims to accelerate momentum on its Flagship Priority, with a focus on several priorities. “On an array of NTDs – kala-azar, LF, trachoma and yaws – the Region has made tremendous, path-breaking progress. But where appropriate, countries should increasingly broaden their scope, for example by intensifying action to address snakebite envenoming – for which a new Regional action plan has now been launched – as well as dog-mediated rabies, dengue, schistosomiasis and other parasitic zoonoses such as taeniasis, echinococcosis and food-borne trematodiases.”

title: Wage hikes on the cards, if economy picks up – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said he hoped to give extra allowances to all State employees as a relief in the third quarter of 2023, if Sri Lanka’s income stabilises and continues to improve. He said, “As the state of our economy improves, wages should rise and earning should be boosted.” “Being a politician makes it tough to speak this truth. But I always reveal the truth, even if I win or lose. I request everyone to support Parliament to get out of this difficult situation for the people. The Paris Club including Japan has accepted and discussed our proposals together and also discussed them with India. The proposal has now been approved by China. With this situation, we receive foreign currency by February. Then, these issues can be resolved in a methodical manner. We need to build a new economy. The Anuradhapura kingdom had no debt. It was a powerful kingdom. In order to strengthen the economy, we must keep that in mind,” he said. Speaking further the President said the income earned on 25 January 2023 was Rs 145 billion and when all capital costs, such as wages, pensions, and welfare, are considered it amounts to Rs 143 billion. He said in addition, an additional Rs 355 billion is required to discharge the loan and in January, the Government spent a total of Rs 498 billion. “But we make Rs 145 billion annually. We can bounce back from this situation over time if a structured programme is put in place. In addition, there are other issues in 2022, including a Rs 794 billion loss in State institutions. This year, we don’t have the funds to pay for them. Therefore, we must make up for this loss. Everyone is currently being affected by the electricity bill issue,” he said. The President made this observation at the ceremeny where the Akta Pathra was presented to the new Atamasthanadhipathi, the Chief Sangha Nayaka of the Siam Maha Nikaya, Malwathu Chapter, Nuwara Kalaviya, Most Venerable Dr. Pallegama Hemarathana Nayaka Thera at the Jayasri Maha Bodhiya premises. “The IMF has informed us that we have to get tax revenue and that other countries will not provide tax revenue for our country. They pointed out that common people have the highest tax expenses in our country. In countries like Thailand, tariffs account for 2.8 per cent of government revenue. 30.1 per cent is obtained from income taxes. India receives 4.5 per cent from tariffs and 45.6 per cent from income tax. Our country receives 26.3 per cent from Customs duty and 17.7 per cent from income tax. Therefore, the IMF informed that when taxes are raised, income tax should be raised and that low-income earners will be inconvenienced due to the collection of taxes, I agree that we are all in a difficult situation. We have worked to provide a good harvest to farmers in the Maha season. All of us are bearing the pressure caused by the increase in the price of goods, transportation costs and oil.  We are unable to avoid this,” he said. He said his aim is to build a debt-free economy within the next five to ten years where people can live with a sense of pride and without having to bow their heads to anyone, as it was during the Anuradhapura era where the country maintained a strong and debt-free economy. The President also said if government revenue is stabilised marking progress in the economy, an extra allowance is expected to be granted to public servants in the third quarter of this year as a relief measure. Stating that he had a good understanding of the difficulties faced by the people, the President expressed confidence that with the expected economic progress expected to be achieved by 2024, relief to all, including salary increases could be provided. “Last April, we informed the world that we were not in a position to repay our debts. After assuming duties as the President, I made a request from the IMF about restructuring our debts. I notified them that the loans we had obtained were very high, and the country was not in a position to repay them. In order to be able to repay the loans, it was suggested to discuss with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and prepare a plan. Countries such as China, Japan and India, which gave us loans, told us to first discuss with the IMF and prepare a plan. Then it was informed that assistance that can be provided by those countries will be discussed. Therefore, we had to discuss with the IMF how to repay these loans. We cannot continue without this support. If we don’t get this support, our economy will collapse. Funds and foreign exchange in our country are not sufficient,” he said. Speaking further he said last year our economic growth rate was minus 11 per cent. This year, if we plan properly, we can make it minus 3.5 per cent. But, in the event there are global issues, it could even be minus 4 per cent. However, we expect to bring it down to minus 3.5 per cent.  “With this aim in focus, we expect to move the economy forward from 2024. We have received some aid due to the measures we took when we ran out of dollars. We are expected to receive more assistance in the future. Similarly, we will have an excess of paddy due to the success of the season this year with the provision of fertilizers. The country will revert to the state it was in May, June, and July of last year if we abandon this initiative. If that occurs, you will encounter another challenge. If that occurs, we won’t have any money left over for even three weeks to purchase medication,” he said. Speaking further he said the countries that provided us with loans advised that their revenue had also reduced and that it would be difficult to provide their support if their citizens could not bear the majority of the burden to deal with this problem. “Because they disclosed that the funding was obtained from taxes paid by their citizens. In 2019 our total revenue is 15 per cent of the gross domestic product. However, as a result of the tax reduction, the total income has decreased to 8.4 per cent of the gross domestic product by 2022. Those countries informed us if assistance is provided we should raise the total revenue to 15 per cent of the gross domestic product to the level of 2019. Accordingly, the current income should be increased by 75 per cent during the next three years. That is our challenge. That will require you to carry a heavy burden. However, we can go on. We are unable to refute the facts that they give,” he said. Explaining the situation further, he said he had 1500,000 files in 2019 that paid their income tax in full. Next, there were 122,000 files that pay VAT and Nation Development Taxes (NDT). “There were 1600,000 files in total. With the subsequent removal of these taxes, by December 2021, we had 400,000 income tax files. It had reduced from 1600,000 to 400,000. Accordingly, they questioned us on how could they give us the taxes they collected from their people when we reduce the collection of these taxes. It is that we have worked to bring about this state of taxation. Without this step, we cannot move forward,” the President said. Chief Incumbents of Three chapters and Anunayaka Theros, the Maha Sangha representing Atamasthana, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, former President Mahinda Rajapaksa and the Members of Parliament, Governor of North Central Province Mahipala Herath, Chief of President’s Staff and Senior Adviser on National Security Sagala Ratnayake, Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Ambassadors, Government officials, Commanders of Tri Forces and  Diyawadana Nilame of the historical Dalada Maliga, Mr Nilanga Dela Bandara and other guests attended the event.

title: Kanchana accuses HRCSL of violating human rights
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said he will take legal action against the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL), for violating the human rights of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) officials.  Wijesekara told the media yesterday (29) at the Energy Ministry that the time has come for the Constitution Council to make bold decisions about the Commissions because the HRCSL’s expiry date is approaching. He said one of the additional secretaries and an additional general manager from the CPC, as well as the financial manager of CEB, attended the meeting called by the HRCSL. He said these personnel informed Wijesekara in writing that they were influenced by the HRCSL and that these officials informed the HRCSL that all decisions must be approved by the board of directors. “The Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka and HRCSL have no authority to compel any institution to provide fuel on credit for 60 or 70 days. I am not sure if the HRCSL can persuade banks to lower their interest rates. In the future, the HRCSL will convene the CBSL and ask to change the tax policy because it is not in the best interests of humanity,” he said. Wijesekara pointed out that according to an affidavit, CPC officials have been threatened with jail terms by the HRCSL. “Such allegations are extremely serious. I was also told that the entire conversation had been recorded and that it would be useful when we went to court. I was also informed that when the first document was signed, it was torn down after mentioning in the document that it was signed under the approval of the board of directors. However, after signing the document, the official took a picture of it before tearing it down and shared it with the CPC Chairman. We have it as well,” he added. He said that it is good that the HRCSL has to go to court because the HRCSL officials cannot influence or direct the CPC or CEB to act according to their instructions. “The officials who attended the meeting claimed that the HRCSL officials’ actions on that day violated their human rights,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Govt preparing charge sheet on PUCSL Chair – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is preparing a charge sheet to sack Janaka Ratnayake from his position as Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) and it will be presented in Parliament soon. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said all parliamentarians from the ruling party agreed on the decision and the majority required is thus in place. Speaking to the media yesterday (29), Minister Wijesekera said Ratnayake made statements and decisions arbitrarily, putting the entire country in jeopardy. He claimed Ratnayake is to blame for the power outages, as he misled the other PUCSL members. He said there are enough provisions in Parliament to dismiss Ratnayake. “We are working within limited constraints. We are also collating a lot of information about Ratnayake. Before being appointed as PUCSL Chairman, Ratnayake asked former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa to appoint him as the Chairman of a leading private bank. Ratnayake’s name was sent to the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) to obtain an eligibility report, but CBSL later rejected it, stating that they cannot provide such a report, citing other reasons and criticisms,” he said. Wijesekera raised concerns about how the Constitutional Council in Parliament overlooked this information. He claimed that a select committee in Parliament had pointed out that Ratnayake wasn’t qualified to work at a state institution in 2012. He said he is working on the matter from a legal standpoint. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Traffic plan in place for 75th Independence Day rehearsals
author: Author not found
Content: Rehearsals for the 75th Independence Day, which will be held at Galle Face on 4 February, began on 28 January and a special traffic plan has been implemented on several roads in Galle Face and Colombo. Police Media Division stated that this special traffic plan will be implemented on 1, 2, 3 and 4 February from 5:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon. Vehicular movement will be restricted along Galle Face Middle Road, Galle Face Roundabout to NSA Roundabout and Chaithya Road, Colpetty Junction to the Galle Face Roundabout and the Colpetty Railway Station, St. Michaels’ Roundabout towards Galle Road, Rotunda Roundabout to Galle Road and Ceramic Junction to the NSA Roundabout. Additionally, vehicles will be restricted along York Street to Bank of Ceylon Mawatha, York Street to Chatham Street, York Street to MudaligeMawatha, York Street to Baron Jayathilake Mawatha, Khan Clock Tower Roundabout to the YMBA Roundabout, Ceynor Junction to OlcottMawatha and CTO Junction, CTO Junction to Lotus Road and Ceramic Junction. Also along, Gamini Roundabout to DR Wijewardena Mawatha, Slave Island Police Roundabout to Regal Junction, Macan Markar Mawatha to Baladaksha Mawatha and Galle Face, Bambalapitiya Junction along Galle Road to Colpetty, Marine Drive from the Bambalapitiya Railway Station, Thunmulla Junction to Bauddhaloka Mawatha and RA De Mel Road, Ananda Coomaraswamy Mawatha to Flower Road Junction and Liberty Roundabout and Liberty Roundabout to St. Michaels’ Roundabout. Police said residents along these roads can travel to respective areas on Police advice during the rehearsals and they also listed alternative roads for vehicles during the given period. Accordingly, alternate roads for buses and light vehicles and vehicles travelling along Galle Road to Fort and Pettah can turn right from the Bambalapitiya Junction through Bauddhaloka Mawatha, Thunmulla Junction, and Thurstan Road to reach Pettah. Vehicles can also turn right from the Colpetty Junction through the Liberty Roundabout and Dharmapala Mawatha to reach Pettah. Vehicles can use Olcott Mawatha, Technical College Junction, Sangaraja Mawatha, Panchikawatte Road, Maradana Bridge Junction, Gamini Roundabout to reach Fort, Pettah. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Three Election Commission members get death threats
author: Author not found
Content: Three members of the National Election Commission have received death threats via phone and investigations have revealed the threats were made from a foreign country, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa confirmed. He told the media yesterday (29) the CID has launched a special investigation into the phone calls based on complaints lodged by Election Commission members who received the death threats. SSP Thalduwa also said while the CID is investigating the case, it was found that the threats came from a single phone number from a specific address in Galle. However, during investigations it was found that the person at that address was not in Sri Lanka and was unaware of the incident. He emphasised that these phone calls were made from a foreign country, and CID has enlisted the help of the Telecommunications Regulatory Commission to conduct additional investigations. SSP Thalduwa pointed out that no suspects have being identified so far and concluded that according to the complaints received by the members of the Election Commission, arrangements have been made to provide armed security to the homes of the three members. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Strong charge needed to dismiss me – PUCSL Chair
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Janaka Ratnayake said sacking him requires not only a majority in Parliament but also a strong charge against him, which is nonexistent. He said he is eager to see what is on the charge sheet against him. He was responding to Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera’s claim that a charge sheet against him (Ratnayake) will be presented in Parliament, seeking his removal as PUCSL Chair. “I’m eagerly waiting to face the charge sheet which is said to have been prepared by Minister Kanchana Wijesekera. I do not have any charges filed against me unlike against Wijesekera,” he said. Meanwhile, Ratnayake chastised Wijesekera for intimidating the independent commission and refusing to work in accordance with the Commission’s decisions. He said he had not received any formal recommendation or letter from the Attorney General regarding the Cabinet-approved electricity tariff hike, and that once he does, he will take necessary action regarding the electricity tariff hike. Speaking to the media yesterday (29), he said Wijesekera is sharing a letter purportedly sent by the Attorney General with the members of the commission via WhatsApp and other informal channels. He pointed out that Wijesekera has no business to deal with the letter and questioned why the minister is so concerned about a letter that he (Ratnayake) should be receiving. “The document I am supposed to receive from the Attorney General is a formal business transaction between us two. Political parties or individuals are not permitted to intervene in this matter. This is an example of political intimidation of independent commissions. The National Council influences the Commission in one way while the Cabinet influences the Commission in another. PUCSL members are contacted 24 hours a day, seven days a week. This is a joke. We are not allowed to work independently,” he said. Wijesekera told the media yesterday (29) that Ratnayake had received an email from the Attorney General about the Cabinet-approved electricity tariff hike and challenged Ratnayake to act immediately if he does not have any hidden political agenda. However, Ratnayake refuted Wijesekera’s claims that he (Ratnayake) is preparing to enter politics on the National List from any party with the ‘Helicopter’ or ‘Telephone’ symbols in the upcoming Local Government Election. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Massive Seven-Hour Drug Raid in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: Following a seven-hour joint operation by the Police, STF and Sri Lanka Army, Navy and the Air Force, a total of 285 drug peddlers were arrested along with stocks of narcotics. Speaking to the media, Police Media Spokesman, SSP Nihal Thalduwa said the raids were mainly conducted to arrest drug traffickers under the direct supervision of Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. He said the raids were conducted according to a classified plan devised a few weeks ago and added that drones and helicopters were utilised for this purpose.  Accordingly, 33 from Nugegoda, 70 from Mount Lavinia, 23 from Kelaniya, four from Negombo, 13 from Gampaha, 24 from Colombo North, 30 from Colombo South, 10 from Colombo Central, 12 from Panadura, and four from Kalutara were taken into Police custody. SSP Thalduwa added that legal action will be taken against the suspects and said they plan to conduct more raids in the future.  He said the Police Narcotics Bureau and State Intelligence Service are working tirelessly to bring drug traffickers to justice. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Two arrested for filming near Parliament Complex
author: Author not found
Content: Thalangama Police arrested two persons for filming near the Parliament Complex yesterday (29). Police said the two suspects, who had approached Gate No. 1 and were making calls and videos about the Parliament Complex, were arrested. On interrogation, the suspects told Police they had come to film clips for a music video. According to Police, the two suspects are aged between 22 and 31 and are residents of Mahaiyawa in Kandy, and Vaiman Road in Jaffna. By Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Govt Printer yet to receive Gazette – DGI
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Government Information (DGI) confirmed yesterday (29) that the Gazette Notification to commence the Local Government Election process, with the signatures of the Chairman and other members of the Election Commission, has still not been sent to the Government Printer.

title: Only a new political force can restore shattered economy – Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: While acknowledging that the country’s foundation is fractured and weak, Jathika Jana Balawegaya Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake said his Party is ready to take on the challenge of building a strong foundation on which the country can be developed. He emphasised that the people’s objection is that the economy has been destroyed and all of the wealth of the public has been stolen, and that whoever brought the economy down cannot rebuild it. “In addition, a salary tax has been imposed, and those who wrecked the economy are writing books. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Competitive exam to recruit 26,000 grads in public service
author: Author not found
Content: Applications have been called for a competitive examination for the recruitment of 26,000 graduates in public service as teachers, with the primary goal of filling teacher vacancies in schools and recruiting a high-quality teacher to the classroom. Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha said these appointments are intended for graduates, including development officers, who joined the State service in 2018, 2019, and 2020, as well as all underemployed graduates who have applied for this position and are under 40. The Minister was speaking to the media after attending the 195th Pirivena Board of Education meeting held at the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic. Applicants have more than two weeks to submit their applications via http://applications.doenets.lk/exams. Applicants may apply for five years of service in their home province, a neighbouring province, or any province of their choice. “Based on the number of applications received, the Examinations Department is preparing to conduct a state-wide examination,” Premajayantha said, assuring that the exam will be held in March. In addition, he said the examination results will be issued at the provincial level, and interviews will be held at the provincial level for provincial schools and at the Ministry of Education level for national schools, and appointments will be made as trainees subject to a three-year probationary period, after which they will be absorbed into the teaching service. “Also, during this probationary period, the trainees should complete the National Institute of Education’s Postgraduate Diploma in Education and receive theoretical and practical formal teacher training from the institute’s centres across the country, with the ultimate goal of sending a high-quality teacher to the school classroom,” he said. Premajayantha also said after the results are confirmed in February, it is expected to provide teacher appointments for National College of Education diploma holders, to fill the teacher vacancies caused by the simultaneous retirement of a large number of teachers during the previous rainy season, and to balance the transfer of teachers.

title: Police warn Jaffna loan sharks
author: Author not found
Content: Senior DIG Northern Province Mahinda Gunaratne has warned that those who cause public nuisance and engage in violence in Jaffna will face immediate legal action. He was responding to legal action taken against persons on a video uploaded on social media where some individuals were being inhumanely attacked with wooden poles and iron bars in Jaffna. He said the attack was carried out on people to recover capital and interest from those who obtained loans at high-interest rates. Video footage was circulating on social media in the recent past of a gang operating in Jaffna attacking persons accompanying them to a land in Maruthanarmadam in Jaffna to recover their money with interest from victims who obtained loan from them at skyrocketing interest rate. However, stringent legal action will be taken against those causing disturbance to the public, the Senior DIG said. “I have directed every police unit in the North to investigate and take legal action against those who unlawfully beat and harass people. Five suspects who were arrested by the Jaffna District Police Crime Prevention team were remanded till 10 February. The public can lodge complaints at nearby police stations regarding such gangs operating in their areas. Those who have difficulty to do so can provide information to the Office of the Senior DIG. The doors of my office are open to accept complaints on a humanitarian basis and to take expeditious action on it,” Gunaratne added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Multi-level stakeholder engagement vital – NBRO Chief
author: Author not found
Content: Comprehensive, multi-level engagement of stakeholders ranging from high-level policymakers, government officials, and private sector organisations is required in the process of disaster preparedness, mitigation, and communication in disaster-prone areas, National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) Director General, Eng. (Dr.) Asiri Karunawardene said. Karunawardene said this while addressing the 12th Annual Research Symposium – 2022 of the NBRO themed ‘Building resilience amidst economic challenges’ held at the BMICH recently. He said the economic constraints further intensify these challenges. Financial constraints also negatively influence communities who are already vulnerable to disaster. In the recent past, the NBRO has extended its services to other technical agencies to address issues related to land development, regulating the construction and development and sustainable disaster mitigation, according to Karunawardene. “Apart from its key services, providing proper guidelines and consultancies to develop the land in disaster-prone areas, geological and geotechnical engineering services, measuring the structural condition of opulent buildings, quality control and standardisation of building materials and real-time assessment of urban air quality are among the key services that NBRO provides,” the Director General said. He said the NBRO has been vested with the duty of identifying and mitigating the landslide-prone locations and 27 early landslide warning centres are presently functioning under the purview of the NBRO and monitoring the situation, with 330 rain gauges installed in catchment areas. “We are jointly working with the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) to disseminate early warnings to persons in disaster-prone areas. We are able to issue accurate early warnings with the technical and financial assistance from Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA).  A mobile app was developed last year with the help of Japanese and JICA experts to notify the people in the landslide-prone areas of possible landslide occurrences. The NBRO will be able to disseminate the message in a timely fashion,” according to Karunawardene. Landslide mitigation work in Malabattawa area in Walapane in the Nuwara Eliya District and the mitigation work of Kadugannawa have already commenced. A landslide-prone location has been identified in Nallathanniya area in Hatton. The NBRO is looking to mitigate it as soon as possible. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President to decide on P.S.M. Charles’ resignation
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe is yet to decide whether to accept the resignation of P.S.M. Charles from the Election Commission. Charles had informed the President of her decision to resign from the Election Commission in writing on 25 January. According to Presidential Secretariat sources, the President is still contemplating whether or not to accept the resignation of Charles.

title: Speaker signs two Bills
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena signed the Regulation of Election Expenditure Bill and the Bureau of Rehabilitation Bill which were passed in Parliament recently. Accordingly, these bills come into force as the Bureau of Rehabilitation Act No. 2 of 2023 and the Regulation of Election Expenditure Act No. 3 of 2023.

title: President presents credentials to new Atamasthanadhipathi
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe presented Akta Pathra (Credentials) to the new Atamasthanadhipathi, Most Venerable Dr. Pallegama Hemarathana Nayake Thera at the Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi premises. ‘Vijinipatha’ was presented by Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena. Meanwhile, the President assured at the Anuradhapura Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi premises that the Bill to speed up the excavation work and preserve the Anuradhapura Maha Viharaya will be submitted to Parliament soon.

title: Rs 3.5B to expedite development of ECT
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva ordered the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) to provide Rs 3.5 billion to speed up development of the East Container Terminal (ECT). A special meeting was held recently under the chairmanship of De Silva to review construction work of the ECT and the Jaya Container Terminal Phase-05 (JCT-05). The Minister instructed SLPA officials to remove obstacles in the construction of the two Terminals and complete it within the allocated timeframe and facilitate the contractors to do so. According to this, the construction work of JCT-05 should be completed by the end of 2023 thus the problem in providing berthing facilities at the edge of the terminal for longer ships will be avoided, port authority officials pointed out. To speed up the work, the SLPA  has considered the request made by the contracting company to provide the money due to them immediately and legally certify bills and receive payments. The Minister instructed to pay USD 6.1 million and Rs 1 billion if the Companies have followed due procedure. The Minister said the remaining Rs 1.667 billion should be paid within three weeks thus expediting construction work. He advised officials to strengthen the cash reserve and give priority to development activities of the ECT terminal while spending funds.

title: COPE instructs to revisit egg pricing formula
author: Author not found
Content: Parliament watchdog, the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE), instructed the authorities to revisit the current pricing formula of eggs, considering the current cost of an egg. The COPE, which met on 25 January under chairmanship of Prof. Ranjith Bandara, held a four-point discussion as an extension of the Committee meeting held on 19 January 2023. The officials present said that they would revisit the pricing formula, taking into consideration all matters discussed at that Committee meeting. Accordingly, the Committee that looked into recommendations, to reasonably estimate the cost of production, for the purpose of setting a fair price for eggs in the market, held extensive discussion pertaining to the securing of the domestic poultry industry and scrutinising the egg shortage in the market. Also, attention paid to providing eggs to consumers at a fair price. The committee was of the view that the domestic poultry industry should be secured and the officials present agreed. It was revealed that domestic producers, representing the poultry industry, conveyed to the Committee that if the price of an egg can be kept at Rs 51 for a period of 1 ½ months until the poultry industry can be stabilised, the price of an egg can be reduced thereafter. The Committee was also of the view that whilst considering protecting the poultry industry, the respective authorities should also look at the context from the perspective of the consumer and act fairly by all parties. It was disclosed that there exists a temporary dearth of approximately three million eggs per day. The officials present stated that there is no precipitated process in the poultry industry as a solution to this.  Therefore, officials said that it has been agreed to import a limited number of eggs considering the consumer. Taking into consideration all factors presented before COPE, the Committee was of the view that all efforts must be made at a discussion to find a solution to the matter which is fair by the consumer. Accordingly, the Committee Chairman Prof. Ranjith Bandara instructed the respective officials to inform the public of the measures taken and to reassure that all parties are collectively working towards finding a practical solution to the matters of concern. MPs Nimal Lanza, Jagath Kumara Sumithraarachchi, Premnath C. Dolawatte, Madhura Withanage, Prof. Charitha Herath as well as high officials representing the Ministry of Trade, Commerce and Food Security, Ministry of Agriculture, Consumer Affairs Authority and other respective institutions were present at the meeting. (AK)

title: Police transfers and promotions effected
author: Author not found
Content: Subject to the approval of the National Police Commission, the Election Commission and the Secretary to the Ministry of Public Security, the Inspector General of Police (IGP) has made appointments and transfers of  Senior Superintendents of Police (SSP) to perform the duties of Deputy Inspectors General of Police (DIG) on the basis of urgent need. The Police Media Division yesterday (26), said that four SSPs were given appointments to the position of DIG, while six SSPs were transferred to other positions. Accordingly, SSP J.A.K. Jayasinghe was appointed from the position of OIC of Puttalam Division to perform the duties DIG-in-Charge of the Badulla District and SSP R. Gunasekara was appointed from the post of Director of the Legal Division to the post of DIG-in-Charge of Legal Division. Also, SSP I.B.T. Sugathapala was appointed from OIC of Batticaloa to the position of DIG-in-Charge of Kalutara and SSP O. Hevawitharana was appointed from Director of Human Rights to DIG-in-Charge of the Vanni Division. Additionally, four SSPs were transferred to several divisions as OICs and Directors, while two SPs were transferred as Directors. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Appellate Court quashes Pavithra’s decision
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (26) quashed former Minister of Health Pavithra Wanniaracchi’s decision to remove Prof. D.G. Harendra de Silva as President of the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) and four others as members of SLMC. This was when the Writ Petition, filed by Prof. Silva and the other members of the Council, challenging such removal, was taken before Court of Appeal Judges M. T. Mohamed Laffar and J.S.U.B. Karalliyadde. Court held that the Petitioners have been removed from their posts by Wanniaracchi only on the basis that they have been found guilty of certain allegations leveled against the SLMC. The Bench held that although the entire SLMC is responsible for the purported allegations, there is a question as to why only the said individuals were removed. Court thereby held that Wanniaracchi has acted in mala-fide, arbitrarily and capriciously revoking the appointments of the Petitioners of the SLMC and that the Petitioners were not heard before such removal. The Bench also held that the Minister did not adhere to the rule of natural justice. Thereby Court issued Writs of Certiorari to quash the decisions revoking the appointment of the Petitioners. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: School lunch project unlikely to continue in third school term – Stalin
author: Author not found
Content: It may not be able to continue the project of providing a nutritious lunch to needy schoolchildren, in the third school term, due to the failure to pay the suppliers for nearly four months, alleged Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin. The particular project was initially aimed at providing lunch to 1.1 million school children. Speaking to Ceylon Today, yesterday (26) Stalin alleged that as a result the children will be facing a severe risk of malnutrition and hunger when schools re-open for the next term. Stalin assured that the CTU will take immediate trade union action against the non payment to the suppliers, if the authorities failed to provide a solution immediately. He noted that CTU discussed this with the Education Minister who assured that he will look into it immediately. He also urged the government to make the overdue payments to suppliers. “The government launched the nutritional project, targeting 1.1 million school children. The programme was launched with the help of Samurdhi beneficiaries, who served as the primary food suppliers. It was introduced by the Education Ministry. The suppliers have incurred significant losses as a result of the government’s failure to make payments for nearly four months,” he added. Stalin noted that a Cabinet decision was taken on 23 October 2022, to increase the number of children, under this free lunch programme to two million, but with the existing difficulties it is likely that the programme may not continue in the next term. “We had a discussion in this regard with the Education Minister on Tuesday (24). But the minister claimed that the payments would be settled only after obtaining funds from the Treasury. The World Bank (WB) has already granted five billion rupees as a donation to implement the project. I wonder what happened to that donation?” Stalin said. He inquired what happened to the donations given by a number of countries and organisations, such as UNICEF, the World Food Organisation  and China, to implement the said project. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Godahewa, two others acquitted
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo High Court yesterday (26) acquitted Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Dr. Nalaka Godahewa and two others, who had been charged with misappropriation of State funds. Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja acquitted and released the three accused from the case on the grounds that the evidence submitted was not sufficient to prove them guilty. Godahewa was acquitted in the case filed against him on the alleged misappropriation of State funds to the tune of five million rupees belonging to the Securities Exchange Commission (SEC) during his tenure as the commission’s chairman. The other two accused in the case were former SEC Deputy Director General Dhammika Perera and Sports Director of Tharunyata Hetak organisation Ronnie Ibrahim. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: CEB warned of legal action if it goes back on agreement
author: Author not found
Content: Deepening the power cuts saga during GCE Advanced Level Examination 2022, the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) and Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) on Wednesday (25) warned the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) of legal consequences if CEB fails to adhere to the agreement. However, the CEB is still struggling to reach a decision as they have several ‘difficulties’. Despite the agreement by the relevant authorities, including CEB and PUCSL, that power cuts will not be imposed until 17 February, the date of conclusion of A/L examination, power cuts were reported Islandwide as usual. If the CEB fails to provide uninterrupted power supply during the GCE Advanced Level examination, legal action would be taken against the CEB according to the Section 48 of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act. The PUCSL said, it has not approved power cuts until 17 February. According to a letter, signed by PUCSL Chairman Janaka Ratnayake, sent to the Chairperson of HRCSL, the PUCSL has issued directives to the CEB to ensure uninterrupted power during the exams. Meanwhile, when asked about CEB’s decision on power outages during exam periods, Additional General Manager (Generation) Dhammika N. Navaratne stated that no decisions had been made on whether the agreement will be implemented. The HRCSL said, if the CEB fails to implement the agreement, it will file a case before the Supreme Court on the charges of contempt of the independent commissions. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: EC Chairman unaware of Charles’ resignation
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Election Commission Nimal Punchihewa said he is unaware that member of the Election Commission P.S.M. Charles, has tendered her resignation and has still not heard about it officially. The resignation was sent to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, said Charles. Punchihewa told Ceylon Today that there was no dispute and that he still does not know whether she has resigned or not but he ‘heard’ that the resignation was sent to the President.  The President’s Media Division (PMD) on Wednesday (25) night said Charles has resigned from the commission after submitting her resignation letter to the President. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Country saved USD 2.5B by restricting imports – Siyambalpitiya
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said Sri Lanka has been able to save USD 2.5 billion from the day imports of certain goods were restricted. Siyambalapitiya said this while speaking at the International Customs Day 2023 ceremony held at the Customs Headquarters, yesterday (26). The theme of this year’s International Customs Day is ‘Nurturing the next generation: Promoting a culture of knowledge-sharing and professional pride Customs’. He pointed out that due to these import restrictions, essentials such as fuel, medicines and fertiliser are being imported without creating any shortage. “The Finance Ministry expects that there would not another year compared to 2022 where the nation had to face severe economic difficulties. But the people have forgotten their sufferings,” Siyambalapitiya said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: ALL-PARTY CONFERENCE A FLOP?
author: Author not found
Content: The Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and Tamil Progressive Alliance (TPA) yesterday (26) boycotted the All-Party Conference (APC) that was convened by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The President’s Media Division (PMD) said the APC was convened in order to speak in depth on reconciliation. The SJB and the JJB said the APC is only a ‘mere talk show’ as the President has ignored several proposals made by them earlier. Newly formed Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya (People’s Freedom Alliance), also did not participate in the APC. The Prime Minister, the Speaker, former Presidents Mahinda Rajapaksa and Maithripala Sirisena were invited to the APC too. Meanwhile, TPA Leader Mano Ganesan stressed that President has not held talks on the issues related to Hill Country Tamils who are national minority in the country. Ganesan said that they have been repeatedly demanding of President Wickremesinghe to talk about the political aspirations of the hill country Tamil community in his stated attempt to find solution to the National Question. He said the President is holding talks on finding ways to resolve the Tamil questions but the rest of the Tamil political parties ‘don’t represent’ the hill country Tamils of Indian origin. The TPA Leader said further, “We have been repeatedly demanding of President Wickremesinghe to conduct talks with us and all the Hill Country Tamil political parties, on the political aspirations of the Hill Country Tamil community in his stated attempt to find solutions to the national question. We have specifically told him to nominate a high-powered committee, chaired by him to look into this subject. “But, apart from certain remarks made from public stages, President Wickremesinghe has not done anything officially in this regard”, Ganesan added.  While welcoming the President’s talks, with the Tamil parties of the North and East, to find solutions to the political and accountability issues faced by the northern and eastern Tamil brethren, he said they also wanted all stakeholders to understand the political aspirations of the Hill Country Tamil community beyond the ‘Plantation’ radius. And the national question of Sri Lanka is not North and East centric but national.  It is because the discussion is all about the National Question, why did not the TPA, as a party in the opposition, question President Wickremasinghe’s mandate to conduct talks with minority parties to address the national question, Ganesan queried. “We consider the national question as the most important subject on the tray and no head of State needs any mandate to address this particular subject.  We have even exchanged such positive views with North and East Tamil parties. Hence, the attitude of President Wickremasinghe towards us is disappointing.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
