title: Judge orders objections be submitted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Poornima Paranagama ordered Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and SJB General Secretary, MP Ranjith Madduma Bandara to submit, by 31 March, objections pertaining to the case filed by State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage, seeking an order preventing them from functioning in their respective posts. The District Court Judge gave this order having perused the petition filed by the State Minister. Gamage in her petition charged that as per the Samagi Jana Balawegaya constitution, no individual could lay claim to positions, while retaining membership of another political party. The State Minister has named Premadasa and Madduma Bandara as respondents in her petition. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Nimal thanks Japan for assisting debt restructure prog
author: Author not found
Content: A special discussion was held between Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva and the Ambassador of Japan to Sri Lanka Mizukoshi Hedeaki. The Minister expressed his gratitude to Japan for their assistance for the success of Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring programme. The discussion took place yesterday, at the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation. Japanese Ambassador Mizukoshi Hedeaki and Japan International Cooperation Agency’s (JAICA) Director for Sri Lanka Akimitsu Okubo assured that the construction of terminal 02 of the Bandaranaike International Airport would commence as soon as the IMF restructuring process was over. The Minister emphasised that the expectation of the government is to see it completed as a successful Japanese Project and no assistance of another party would be sought for that. A special delegation of the Embassy of Japan, a group of representatives from JAICA, Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra and Additional Secretary (Development) of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nayana Somarathna also attended the discussions.

title: An entertaining musical experience to mark India’s 74th Republic Day
author: Author not found
Content: On 24 January 2023, High Commission of India in Colombo organised a Rock Band concert- ‘Rhythm of Harmony’ to commemorate the 74th Republic Day of India falling on January 26, 2023. President Ranil Wickremesinghe graced the event as the Chief Guest. A renowned Rock band from India- UDX led by Inakhu Atoshe Ayeh, collaborated with a Sri Lankan band, Stigmata, led by Suresh De Silva, for this special event. Several Sri Lankan Ministers, Members of Parliament, members of the diplomatic corps, Indian diaspora and other dignitaries were present at the occasion.  UDX a seven-member band, which performed in Sri Lanka for the first time, hails from a province in the North-Eastern part of India, Nagaland, known for its musical talent. With the 75th Independence Day of Sri Lanka being commemorated on 4 February 2023, performance by artists from UDX and Stigmata together was a fitting tribute to the joint celebrations of the national days of India and Sri Lanka. The event reflected the close links between the two countries in the field of art and culture.  In the next few days, UDX will travel around the Island and give performances in Jaffna, Kandy and Hambantota.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Japanese Award for Agriculture Research
author: Author not found
Content: The Government of Japan has called for applications from Sri Lankan agricultural researchers for the ‘2023 Japan International Award for Young Agricultural Researchers (Japan Award),’ Japan’s Embassy in Sri Lanka said on Wednesday. ‘Japan Award’ aims to increase motivation among young researchers who are contributing to research and development in agriculture, forestry, fisheries and related industries in developing regions and show outstanding performance and research achievements that may lead to future innovation, it said. This award, firsts launched in 2007, is organised by Japan’s Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Research Council (AFFRC), the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF) and supported by Japan International Research Centre for Agricultural Sciences (JIRCAS). Candidates must be researchers who have the nationality of a developing country and/or territory, are under 40 years old as of 1 January 2023, belong to a non-Japanese research institute or a non-Japanese university, are engaged in research and development in agriculture, forestry, fisheries and related industries in developing regions. Those who have shown outstanding performance in research and development in agriculture, forestry, fisheries, or related industries for a developing region, and who show great promise, those who have shown outstanding achievements in research and development that will lead to future technological innovation in agriculture, forestry, fisheries or related industries for a developing region, and who show great promise are encouraged to apply, the Embassy said. Those who have applied for and missed the award in previous years are eligible to reapply, it added. Applications close on 19 May 2023. More information can be obtained from JIRCAS. (PA)

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: Well known social activist and a former official of Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), Ariyapala Edirisinghe, was unanimously elected as the new President of the Kulasevana Welfare Society at its 39th AGM, held at its office premises in Kottawa, Pannipitiya on Sunday (22). A retired officer from the Sri Lanka Army S.B. Katugaha was elected as the new Vice President of the Society while incumbent Secretary and a retired employee of Sri Lanka Customs, Ariyapala Gamage, was elected as its Secretary, for a second consecutive year. Wilson Hewage, formerly of the Road Development Authority (RDA), was elected by majority vote as the new Treasurer, while outgoing President D. Sirisena, formerly of the Sri Lanka Railways Department and outgoing Treasurer S. Hettige, a retired banker, were appointed as the new Patrons of the Society. The Kulasevana Welfare Society, established over four decades ago for community services, was the brainchild of one of Kottawa’s most prominent social service activists, the late T. W. K. Dissanayake. The newly constituted Committee members of the Kulasevana Welfare Society include: Ajith Alwis, Shantha Vithana, Ajith Kumara, D. L. Lionel, P. G. Amerasinghe, E. Madanayake, Subash Ranasinghe, G. P Sirimal, Priyantha Dahanayake, T. B. W. Delgahapitiya, Dhanapala Wanigasinghe and J. A. Karawita. Popular

title: Sri Lankan rulers have made people beggars
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that the Indian citizens are at the top of the major software companies and banks in the world, because Indian rulers had a great vision, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake claimed that Sri Lankan rulers have made the people beggars. He said that a big transformation should be made in the education sector in the country in order to go forward. Addressing a mammoth rally in Anuradhapura, on 25 January, Dissanayake said, if this country is to be rebuilt, the education sector should be updated to modern world standards. One of our teams, that has done various studies on education in Sri Lanka and has a deep understanding of the education in the world, is ready to take over the JJB’s proposed education reforms, he added. Dissanayake added that the economy has started to hit the people’s wages. The professional workforce is 15 per cent, and their wages are heavily taxed. Also, 500 top managers of banks have left this country. As of August, last year, about 500 doctors have left the country, he claimed. He went on to say that the ‘elites’ who have ruled this country for many decades are afraid of the transfer of power to the common people. Therefore, they have started setting up various traps to postpone the elections. Dissanayake said that President Ranil Wickremesinghe should understand that if the election is not held on 9 March, the people of this country will launch a stronger fight for their democratic rights. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: IRD prevented from collecting APIT from Judges
author: Author not found
Content: An interim order was issued by Court of Appeal yesterday (26), preventing the collection of Advance Personal Income Tax (APIT) from Judges. This was when the Writ Application, filed by the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JASL), challenging the charging of APIT was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. Accordingly, the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) was ordered to refrain from collecting PAYE tax from Judges until further notice. According to the Inland Revenue Act, employment income exceeding Rs 100,000 was taxed. Further, every employer was mandated to deduct APIT from payments made to employees upon exceeding the limit. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Probation Officers given JP posts
author: Author not found
Content: Probation Officers have been given Justice of Peace posts as a step to prevent child victims from being inconvenienced when giving affidavits.  Accordingly, the applications required for the appointment of Justice of the Peace for 325 Probation Officers working islandwide under the Department of Probation and Child Care Services were symbolically handed over to Secretary to the Ministry of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment Yamuna Perera. This step was taken by Justice Minister Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe on recommendation of Parliamentary Caucus for Children. The Provincial Commissioners including the Commissioner of Probation and Child Care Services met the members of the Parliamentary Caucus for Children on 2 December 2022. During the meeting, they pointed out that during the judicial process, child victims who are on probation are inconvenienced when referred to a third party to obtain affidavits. Thereafter, the Parliamentary Caucus for Children brought this proposal to the attention of the Minister of Justice. Justice Minister Rajapakshe, who attended the event to hand over the applications to the Ministry of Child Affairs, pointed out that the intervention of the Parliamentary Caucus for Children to solve a current issue is commendable. He said every possible step will be taken in this regard in the future as well. Rohini Kumari Wijerathna, Chairperson of the Caucus, said being able to provide solutions to this long-standing problem is a victory for the children of Sri Lanka. She pointed out that this occasion is an example of the Parliamentary committees’ intervention in a positive way to resolve the existing problems. Further, Wijerathna discussed the present issues regarding children at the provincial level with the ministry officials. There, instructions were given to promptly forward to the ministry the information including the issues and suggestions referred at the provincial level regarding ‘Child Protection’ and to take every possible step to avoid those problems. It was also further advised to inform the Caucus about its progress every six months. State Minister Diana Gamage, Deputy Co-Chairperson of the Parliamentary Caucus for Children Dr. Sudarshini Fernandopulle and MP Chandima Weerakkody were also present at this occasion. Also, Secretary of the Parliamentary Caucus for Children, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera, Secretary to the Ministry of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment Yamuna Perera, Additional Secretary Nilmini Herath, Commissioner of the Probation and Child Care Services Department, Namal Liyanage, and a group of officials from the Ministry of Child Affairs and Social Empowerment also participated in the event.

title: FRANCE DEPORTS ANOTHER 38 ILLEGAL MIGRANTS FROM REUNION
author: Author not found
Content: France on Wednesday (25), repatriated another 38 Sri Lankan migrants, who arrived illegally by boat on the French territory, Reunion Island, located on the Indian Ocean, on 14 January 2023, taking the total number of illegal Sri Lankan migrants deported to Sri Lanka thus far this month alone to 84, the French Embassy in Sri Lanka, in a statement, said yesterday (26). Previously 46 Sri Lankan migrants, who also arrived illegally on Reunion Island, were deported to Sri Lanka on 13 January, it said. Meanwhile, a French Embassy spokesperson told ‘Ceylon Today’ yesterday that several other allegedly illegal Sri Lankan migrants are still in Reunion. They had all arrived last month, the source said, adding that cases to deport them ‘too’ are still continuing. Meanwhile, the Embassy said France will continue to implement a policy of combating illegal immigration, while applying the humanitarian principles of rescue at sea for people in distress. Expulsions from Reunion will continue as necessary, in compliance with French law and international law. Smugglers mislead departing candidates about the opportunities that await them upon arrival and expose them, including sometimes children, to immense risks during the several months of the crossing on a fishing vessel barely 13 metres long, without any sanitary facilities, food and no ability to provide emergency care, it said. The fight against human trafficking and smugglers is a priority for France, which works closely with the countries of departure to increase its efficiency. “This Embassy emphasises in this respect the excellent operational cooperation that exists with Sri Lanka, in compliance with our respective legislations,” the Embassy said. (PA)

title: Korea to boost shrimp farming in SL
author: Author not found
Content: Korean Ambassador Santhush Woonjin Jeong, who met Minister of Fisheries Douglas Devananda at the latter’s Ministry yesterday (26),  recalled the recent commitment to invest around USD 1.2m bythe Ministry of Fisheries of Korea to help improve shrimp farming in Sri Lanka through the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation He stated that Korea is keen to boost shrimp farming in the island nation. They also discussed ways to promote exports, expand capacity-building and develop the fisheries industry in Sri Lanka. Both parties underscored the importance of strengthening the aquaculture sector in Sri Lanka and agreed to work closely together to deepen cooperation.                                         (SRM)

title: Japanese Embassy launches its Twitter account
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Japan in Sri Lanka has launched its official Twitter page, JapanEmb_SL and has requested the public to follow the Embassy of Japan in Sri Lanka on Twitter for updates on the activities of the Ambassador and other diplomats, as well as on events and other projects involving the Embassy. The Embassy of Japan will continue to share with you the most up to date information on both Facebook and Twitter, the Japanese Embassy said. (SRM)

title: Judge orders objections be submitted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Poornima Paranagama ordered Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and SJB General Secretary, MP Ranjith Madduma Bandara to submit, by 31 March, objections pertaining to the case filed by State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage, seeking an order preventing them from functioning in their respective posts. The District Court Judge gave this order having perused the petition filed by the State Minister. Gamage in her petition charged that as per the Samagi Jana Balawegaya constitution, no individual could lay claim to positions, while retaining membership of another political party. The State Minister has named Premadasa and Madduma Bandara as respondents in her petition. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Nimal thanks Japan for assisting debt restructure prog
author: Author not found
Content: A special discussion was held between Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva and the Ambassador of Japan to Sri Lanka Mizukoshi Hedeaki. The Minister expressed his gratitude to Japan for their assistance for the success of Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring programme. The discussion took place yesterday, at the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation. Japanese Ambassador Mizukoshi Hedeaki and Japan International Cooperation Agency’s (JAICA) Director for Sri Lanka Akimitsu Okubo assured that the construction of terminal 02 of the Bandaranaike International Airport would commence as soon as the IMF restructuring process was over. The Minister emphasised that the expectation of the government is to see it completed as a successful Japanese Project and no assistance of another party would be sought for that. A special delegation of the Embassy of Japan, a group of representatives from JAICA, Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra and Additional Secretary (Development) of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nayana Somarathna also attended the discussions.

title: India’s 74th Republic Day celebrations held in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: High Commission of India, Colombo celebrated India’s 74th Republic Day in Colombo on 26 January 2023. It may be recalled that it was on 26 January 1950 that the Indian Constitution – the world’s largest written Constitution – entered into force. The Preamble to the Constitution declares India to be a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic, Republic. This is the first Republic Day celebrations after India became the fifth largest economy in the world in September 2022. After paying tributes to the fallen heroes of the Indian Peace Keeping Force (IPKF), at the IPKF memorial, High Commissioner Gopal Baglay unfurled India’s national flag at India House – residence of High Commissioner of India – and inspected the Guard of Honour. The High Commissioner also read out excerpts of the Indian President’s Republic Day address. A special video message by Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka was also played on the occasion. The event featured songs by the Sri Lanka Navy band and a cultural programme organised by the High Commission’s cultural arm, Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre. Members of the Indian community attended the ceremony in several hundreds. A ceremonial reception was to be organised in the evening at India House. Several dignitaries from all walks of life in Sri Lanka were expected to attend this event. This year’s Republic Day celebrations take place less than two weeks after India became the first bilateral creditor of Sri Lanka to give written financing assurances to the IMF for an Extended Fund Facility programme. This support which is in line with Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ‘Neighbourhood First’ Policy is a continuation of the unprecedented USD 4 billion of economic, financial and humanitarian support given to the people of Sri Lanka in 2022. Further, this year’s Republic Day celebrations coincide with the commemoration of 75 years of Independence by both India and Sri Lanka. Also, the two friendly neighbours will celebrate the establishment of 75 years of diplomatic ties this year. Consulates General of India in Hambantota and Jaffna and the Assistant High Commission in Kandy also observed the 74th Republic Day of India by organising special events. (Pix by Sarath Kumara)

title: Pharma production to be boosted by 50% – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said his Ministry aimed at boosting Sri Lanka’s pharmaceuticals production by 50 per cent within the next few years. Minister Rambukwella who met German Ambassador to Sri Lanka Holger Seubert yesterday (25) briefed him of the country’s expectations for boosting its pharmaceutical production by 50 per cent during the next few years. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry said the Minister had noted that currently the local medicinal drug production was at 15 to 20 per cent and said that measures had been taken to increase it. He said steps had been taken focusing on the supply of medicines needed for the country. The necessary assistance would be given to investors, manufacturers, industrialists and all those involved in the pharmaceutical manufacturing industry to produce the medicinal drugs necessary for the country. The Spokesman said that Rambukwella had informed the Ambassador that agreements for projects and the purchasing pharmaceuticals had been produced had already been signed. He said that a large number of concessions would be given to these groups including tax exemptions and concessions for the importation of equipment. A total 12 investors had invested in factories for new projects. The media spokesman said that saline was already produced locally while many more drug generics would be produced in the future. “Minister Rambukwella said he hoped to enter into agreements with countries that supplied medicines to Sri Lanka,” he said adding that the time taken for the registration of drugs in Sri Lanka had been reduced. More attention would be given to expediting the process even more. Quoting the Minister the spokesman said that five or six more European countries were expected to participate in the supply of medicinal drugs. Minister Rambukwella pointed out that countries like India and Japan had already agreed to supply drugs while Indonesia had now joined the process. The Minister noted that there were currently 14 life-saving drugs in the country and that it was adequate for the next six months. He pointed out that his Ministry would be able to unravel the medicinal drug issue in the country within the next month. The Spokesman said that Minister Rambukwella had noted that Ministry officials were looking for long-term, short-term and medium-term solutions for the issue. (DJ)

title: Private plaint against former CBSL Governor withdrawn
author: Author not found
Content: A private plaint filed before Court against former Governor of the CBSL, Ajith Nivard Cabraal, was withdrawn before Colombo Fort Magistrate, Thilina Gamage, by the plaintiff yesterday (25). The plaintiff through the private plaint had charged that Cabraal, while serving as the head of CBSL, had misappropriated a sum of USD 6.5 million owed to Sri Lanka. Accordingly, the Fort Magistrate ordered to release the former CBSL Governor, from the lawsuit filed against him. The private plaint had been filed by Ven. Thiniyawela Palitha Thera of Nalandarama Temple, Nugegoda. Maithri Guneratne PC appearing for the plaintiff stated that due to a technical shortcoming, the private plaint filed by his client, would be withdrawn. He added that under the proviso of re-filing the lawsuit against the defendant, the petitioner was withdrawing his private plaint. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: A/L students cautioned against dengue
author: Author not found
Content: With the country reporting over 7,000 dengue cases by the third week of January 2023, the Association of Health Entomology Officers (AHEOs) urged students sitting the G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination – especially those in high risk areas to take precautions to prevent contracting the mosquito-borne disease while sitting for the examination.   National Organiser for the AHEOs Disnaka Dissanayake said yesterday (25),  the last 25 days of January this year had seen a total 7,115 dengue cases in the country.  A majority were reported from the Western Province, Kalmunai and Puttalam which have been identified as high risk areas.  He said the end of last year (2022) had seen a total of 76,688 dengue cases while in 2021 the total number had been 35,924.  “In comparison, the number of dengue cases had shown a sharp rise – more than two fold in 2022”, he said. The National Organiser said a comparatively high number of dengue cases at the beginning of this year indicates a possible risk of numbers exceeding those of last year. Dissanayake said Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara, Puttalam and Kalmunai had been identified as high risk areas.  “The public should be wary of the impending situation,” he said noting that students sitting the AL exam from these areas should pay close attention and take precautionary measures such as using a mosquito repellent when going to examination centres. He called for a systematic work plan to be prepared for dengue control by using entomology data. “New control methods should be used,” he said. The Entomology Officer said in addition, a systematic work plan should be made with survey data for dengue control. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 10 out of 33 coal shipments unloaded so far – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Power and Energy announced that 10 of the 33 coal shipments needed for Norochcholai had been unloaded so far. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said two shipments are expected this month, seven more scheduled in February, March and April 2023. However, he also pointed out that insufficient cash flow at the Ceylon Electricity Board and delays in financing has made it challenging to secure shipments on time and in delaying the process. Earlier this month, the power plant was shut down due to the coal shortage.

title: CC to call for applications from suitable candidates
author: Author not found
Content: The Constitutional Council decided to call for applications for several independent Commissions from interested and qualified individuals, through a newspaper advertisement. The Constitutional Council had its inaugural meeting yesterday (25) presided over by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Leader of the Opposition in Parliament Sajith Premadasa, Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, MP Sagara Kariyawasam, Dr. Prathap Ramanujam, Dr. Dilkushi Anula Wijesundere, Dr. Dinesha Samararatne were present at the meeting while MP Kabir Hashim informed of his inability to attend. The Secretary General of Parliament, Dhammika Dasanayake and Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary General, Kushani Rohanadeera were also present. The members discussed the future activities of the Council along with the mandate stipulated in the Constitution and other Laws. They discussed the constitution of the Commissions specified in Article 41B of the Constitution and agreed to call for applications from interested and qualified individuals, through a newspaper advertisement. Accordingly, a newspaper advertisement will be published calling for applications for the appointment as Members of the Election Commission, the Public Service Commission, the National Police Commission, the Audit Service Commission, the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka, the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption, the Finance Commission and the Delimitation Commission and the National Procurement Commission. A period of two (02) weeks from the date of advertisement will be given to furnish such applications. More details about the application process will be notified in the advertisement. The members unanimously agreed to discharge duties and functions of the Council in an independent, accountable and transparent manner.

title: Ampara JMO prevented from taking up post in Moneragala
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry’s failure to fill the vacancy of the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) of the District General Hospital Ampara, who is on transfer to the Moneragala District Hospital, has left Moneragala residents in a dilemma. Ceylon Today learns that the Moneragala District General Hospital was without a JMO for close to a year, while the Ministry’s failure to give the necessary posting to JMOs returning to the country after foreign training to the Ampara Hospital was preventing the Ampara JMO from taking up his post in Moneragala. The delay has jeopardised the services at the District General Hospital Moneragala.  Only when Ampara gets a replacement would the JMO be released. Until such time, services at the Moneragala District Hospital are crippled, hospital authorities lamented. Meanwhile, the Moneragala JMO had left the country for foreign training. Therefore, the Unit at the DGH Moneragala had only the services of two Medical Officers who were performing routine services. Sources said the Hospital and residents were in a quandary. It has resulted in patients and residents being inconvenienced.  They are unable to obtain special forensic reports or have post-mortems carried out by a Specialist JMO. Patients in need of JMO services and the dead have to be transferred to other hospitals that have a JMO. Therefore, Moneragala District General Hospital has to depend either on JMOs at the District General Hospital Ampara or Provincial General Hospital, Badulla. Several appeals had been made to the Health Ministry but to no avail, they alleged noting that even those JMOs returning after foreign training had used their influence to reverse them and get postings in Vavuniya and Nuwara Eliya, sources alleged.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  The University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA), which is holding a ‘Black week’ protest beginning Monday, 23 January, over the increase in tax deductions from their salaries, asserted that they have stopped attending any Government meetings and were attired in black and hoisted black flags throughout the campuses until Friday 27 January. They are expected to meet the University Grant Commission (UGC) one more time on 27 January and decide the FUTA course of action for next week on the outcome with the UGC. If the Government does not resort to a reasonable tax deduction that lecturers could bear, the next step would be to join Bank unions, CEB Engineers Union and the Government Medical Officers Association (GMOA), to protest against the blunt deduction, former FUTA President Prof. Aruna Kumara said. According to FUTA, there is a 36 per cent tax deduction and several senior lecturers have taken a salary package of a mere Rs 14,000 after taxation. They also estimate tax deductions ranging from Rs 50,000 to Rs 125,000, and the Government has not considered Bank loans for housing, vehicles, and leasing that lecturers have taken. In this regard, General Secretary FUTA Rohan Laksiri stated that the income tax policy under the Inland Revenue Act introduced in Sri Lanka in January has greatly affected them. “As good citizens of the country we are not opposed to tax being spent for the development of the country. However, the tax policy introduced this month is unfair and unethical. Due to this, many members of our association have suffered beyond measure.” Meanwhile, FUTA proposed to the Government alternative schemes to the State tax policy. But they did not receive a response. “We have informed the UGC Chairman, the Chairman of the Council of Vice-Chancellors and Governors of the Universities of Sri Lanka in writing but no action has been forthcoming so far,” Prof. Kumara said. He added that they are forced to commence trade union action to get their legal rights and seek the Government’s attention on the tax issue. FUTA met on 24 January before deciding that FUTA will not participate in any meeting in the universities till further notice. He said there are four types of additional allowances added to the pay and the gross pay is being taxed. He said the Research and Development allowance, medical allowance, cost of living allowance and another special allowance have been calculated as part of the gross pay and taxed. “We have given our proposal and a mechanism that is justifiable for tax reduction but none of them have been considered. This huge deduction is absurd,” he added. “Probationary lecturers, senior professors, and associate professors are seeing a reduction between Rs 50,000 to Rs 125,000 in their salaries and this unbearable,” he said.  Meanwhile, a silent protest organised by the University Teachers’ Union of University of Sri Jayewardenepura was held opposite the university premises, against the new tax scheme. Pic by Aminda Lakmal By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan Popular

title: Excise Duty Bill to be tabled soon – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said the draft of the new Excise Duty Bill will be tabled in Parliament to resolve many issues such as proceeds of drug trafficking and money laundering. The State Minister said the existing Bill should be amended according to present conditions. However, he said the Excise Duty Act, which was introduced in 1912, has now undergone over 1,200 amendments and has become complicated. He said the new Bill is in its final stage. A special discussion regarding the new Bill was held at the Ministry of Finance yesterday (25) and the meeting was chaired by the State Minister and Excise Commissioner General Saman Jayasinghe and others participated. (AK)

title: Gammanpila moots weekly, fortnightly salaries
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila suggested that the Government should follow a new system of paying salaries weekly or fortnightly, rather than monthly, to benefit both employees and employers. He said by using this method, both the employee and the employer will avoid being trapped in a debt trap. “It should be noted that in many countries around the world, salaries are now paid weekly or biweekly rather than monthly. The Minister said when monthly salaries are paid to State employees, not everyone will get their pay simultaneously. Payment of monthly salaries has become a serious challenge for private companies as well, in the face of this economic crisis,” he said. Further, he said the private sector pays workers by borrowing money on interest, while incomes had decreased due to taxes and costs have increased due to inflation. “As a result, it is no longer possible to spend the salary in the traditional manner. The salary disappears by the third week of the month. The crisis worsens when employees have to settle loans. At the end of the day, people will be trapped in debt. That is why we propose weekly salary payment instead of monthly salaries,” he said speaking at a media briefing yesterday (25). BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Gammanpila moots weekly, fortnightly salaries
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila suggested that the Government should follow a new system of paying salaries weekly or fortnightly, rather than monthly, to benefit both employees and employers. He said by using this method, both the employee and the employer will avoid being trapped in a debt trap. “It should be noted that in many countries around the world, salaries are now paid weekly or biweekly rather than monthly. The Minister said when monthly salaries are paid to State employees, not everyone will get their pay simultaneously. Payment of monthly salaries has become a serious challenge for private companies as well, in the face of this economic crisis,” he said. Further, he said the private sector pays workers by borrowing money on interest, while incomes had decreased due to taxes and costs have increased due to inflation. “As a result, it is no longer possible to spend the salary in the traditional manner. The salary disappears by the third week of the month. The crisis worsens when employees have to settle loans. At the end of the day, people will be trapped in debt. That is why we propose weekly salary payment instead of monthly salaries,” he said speaking at a media briefing yesterday (25). BY Thameenah Razeek

title: COPA questions need to spend colossal sums
author: Author not found
Content: Amid public outrage over the Government’s new tax policy, the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA), raised concerns about spending colossal amounts of money to make the Inland Revenue Department’s Revenue Administration Management Information System (RAMIS) operational after Rs 10 billion has already been spent to set it up. COPA Chairman Kabir Hashim questioned the need to spend more money to make the system operational. COPA pointed out that the Inland Revenue Department under the Ministry of Finance had launched the software system called RAMIS in 2014 to increase the efficiency of its tax revenue collection by investing about Rs 10 billion and information has been received that it is not functioning properly. The Auditor General said the Inland Revenue Department does not provide him with information about the service agreement and relevant payment details related to the above system. He further pointed out that the Inland Revenue Department refuses to provide particular information to the Auditor General according to the agreement, and that it is against the Constitution. Inland Revenue officials said there is a need to update this software system started in 2014 with the new Inland Revenue Act brought in 2017. They further pointed out that there is a problem in giving out the contractual information, according to the agreement with the Singaporean company that designed the above software system. Also, because it is a government to government agreement, the intervention of the Government will be appropriate for its future activities, IRD officials said. As there are issues in many areas of the RAMIS system, including procurement, COPA proposed to form two sub-committees to investigate the possibility of making this system operational in a way that will benefit the country. It is expected that the committee which is to be established jointly by the Attorney General’s Department under the leadership of the Finance Secretary will examine the legal conditions related to the RAMIS Agreement. The committee is to be established jointly with The University of Moratuwa, the Sri Lanka Information and Communication Technology Agency (ICTA), the Inland Revenue Department, and the Ministry of Finance to look into the possibility of updating the software system. It was also agreed to submit the reports containing the conclusions on the relevant matters to COPA within six weeks.

title: No Power Cuts During A/L Exams
author: Author not found
Content: The authorities reached an agreement not to impose power cuts until the conclusion of the G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination, which kicked off on 23 January, the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) said. Accordingly, there were no power cuts beginning yesterday (25) until 17 February. HRCSL summoned the Secretary to the Ministry of Power and Energy as well as the Chairman Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) for an inquiry yesterday (25) for failing to prevent power cuts during the examination. Summons were issued when  both authorities failed to respond to the HRCSL’s previous request of not imposing power cuts during the examination period as it violated the right to equality of the students. The meeting commenced at 10:30 a.m. yesterday (25). However, at the commencement the authorities could not reach a consensus. However, another meeting was called at 4.00 p.m. on the same day. Meanwhile, the Secretary of the Ministry of Power and Energy did not participate, instead the Additional Secretary attended the meeting.  During the meeting, the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) arrived at an agreement with the PUCSL to provide continuous fuel supply for electricity generation. PUCSL instructed the CEB to identify the cost required for power generation as a priority in the proposed tariff revision and the two parties agreed to pay the money within 60 days. The HRCSL recommended the Power and Energy Ministry to intervene and coordinate the decision. Meanwhile, addressing the media following the meeting, PUCSL Chairman Ratnayake said, the Bank of Ceylon (BOC) and People’s Bank (PB) have pledged to make the necessary provisions in their respective capacities. He also stated that they anticipate no power cuts until 17 February 2023. It is also recommended to provide power both during and after the examination. However, the Ministry of Power and Energy is yet to make an announcement on the agreement reached at the HRCSL. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Paddy crop yellowing due to nutrition deficiency
author: Author not found
Content: A report prepared by the Department of Agriculture showed that the major cause of crop yellowing is nutritional deficiencies, as farmers have failed to take steps to apply MOP fertiliser to paddy crops. The Agriculture Department submitted the report to Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera in regard to crop yellowing reported in paddy cultivation in the Maha Season. Amaraweera had previously instructed the Agriculture Department to conduct detailed observations and submit a report to the Ministry on crop yellowing and to make recommendations regarding the steps that can be taken to mitigate the issue. According to the Agriculture Department report, there are several key factors that have contributed to crop yellowing. They are phosphorus (P) deficiency, potassium (K) deficiency, both potassium and phosphorus (P and K) deficiency at the same time, root system damage by nematodes, rice thrift damage, brown moth infestation, salinity in paddy fields, and iron toxicity. Amaraweera advised that awareness programmes should be conducted for farmers to prevent crop yellowing, while adding that if necessary, the Agriculture Department should purchase insecticides.

title: Masked men steal ATM machine with Rs 8M
author: Author not found
Content: Four masked men stole an ATM machine with nearly Rs 8 million from a private Bank in Gampola, Police said.  According to Police, the group had dismantled and had stolen the ATM machine at around 12:40 a.m. yesterday (25). The group is said to have arrived in a van and had tied up the security officer at the Bank after which they had stolen the ATM machine.  Police found the van in the evening at Galaha Junction with the driver. The driver was arrested. The owner of the van was summoned to Gampola Police and he told the vehicle was rented through internet and it was provided with a driver to Galaha Junction on Wednesday (24) night. According to the driver’s statement, the group tied his hands and eyes and dropped him somewhere. After some time, the group left him with the vehicle. Since he was blindfolded, he did not see any of the suspects. The suspects have not been identified yet and Gampola Police have launched investigations to apprehend the group. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi and Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: e-voting ideal for LG polls – SJB
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balwegaya (SJB) proposed to introduce electronic voting (e-voting) system for the coming Local Government (LG) polls to cut down costs, and to address the current paper crisis in the country. Addressing the media, SJB MP Mayantha Dissanayake noted that introduction of an e-voting system for the LG polls would help cut down costs. “Introduction of an e-voting system would cut down costs and it will be a solution to the current paper crisis as well. It would be possible to get Indian assistance to introduce the e-voting system. It will be possible to do it in ten days,” Dissanayake said. Meanwhile, MP Harshana Rajakaruna who also participated at the press conference said there is a move to change the Election Commission members in order to postpone the LG Polls. “Postponement of the Polls will lead to terrible consequences as it would result in Sri Lanka losing its credibility with the international community. We have been told that the Foreign Employment Bureau had credited Rs 3 billion to the Treasury. These funds could be used for the LG polls,” Rajakaruna said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Youth to build clean green cities coinciding with National Independence Day celebrations
author: Author not found
Content: A clean green city building programme has been implemented coinciding with the 75th National Independence Day celebrations, entrusting youth to create a green Sri Lanka. The Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports, the National Youth Service Council, the Sri Lanka Youth Club Federation and the Youth Parliament, jointly implemented this programme titled, ‘National Youth Platform’ in keeping with President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s concept  to formally engage youth in the country’s development. Cleaning a selected city representing each Divisional Secretariat Division in Sri Lanka will be done in the initial phase. Accordingly, from 3 – 10 February, cleaning of selected cities will commence with the labour contribution of 50,000 youth from all 335 Divisional Secretariat Divisions covering the whole island. During the initial phase, contributions of provincial councils, urban councils, municipal councils and their affiliated institutions will be obtained and regional secretaries, Sri Lanka Police, health service offices and other community bases and voluntary organisations are also expected to contribute. The relevant city should be cleaned monthly, and it is expected to indirectly obtain the contribution of other youth organisations, university students, students of training centres, scouts, cadet groups and school environment activists in each division. United Nations Volunteers  will  also contribute towards the green city building programme.

title: No point in spending on LG Polls as Govt won’t change – Jeevan
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Water Supply and General Secretary of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress, Jeevan Thondaman said the upcoming Local Government election will not change the Government. Therefore the funds to be spent on the election should be used to combat the economic crisis as it would benefit the people. He said so on Tuesday (24) at a special discussion between the Election Commission and General Secretaries of several political parties and independent groups contesting the LG Polls. During the briefing, many issues were discussed including funding for the election and campaign. “By spending millions of rupees and holding local council elections, the Government will not change. The economic crisis will not be resolved. I have already announced my position in this regard. In the current situation, the people of the country have no idea about the elections. Next, many people have doubts about food security. There is a problem with sending children to school. Therefore, people’s interests should be given priority now. I am not against elections. However, there must be a suitable environment to conduct the election in a fair and just manner,” he added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sinhala, Tamil proficiency mandatory
author: Author not found
Content: The Finance Ministry has made its official language policy for promotions and increments mandatory for public service officers with retrospective effect from 1 July 2013. Finance Ministry Secretary K.M.M. Siriwardana in a circular dated 19 January and titled ‘Implementation of Official Language Policy and Payment of Incentives for Officers of Public Corporations, Statutory Bodies, State Banks and fully owned Government Companies’ also warned that  salary increments to be granted  will be suspended for officers who don’t satisfy the requirement of official language  competency in the ‘other’ official language vis-à-vis the period in question until they satisfy this requirement. According to Siriwardana, the official languages are Sinhala and Tamil. A public officer who has studied in the Sinhala medium will have to achieve competency in the Tamil language and vice versa as per the provisions of this circular. Proficiency tests in this connection will be conducted by the Official Languages Department (OLD). An officer will be tested for his proficiency in the other official language both orally and in his/her writing skills as well, the circular said. In this connection, a senior officer will have to attend a proficiency course lasting 200 hours, tertiary/secondary grade officers 150 hours and primary grade officers 100 hours, respectively. An officer will have to prove 80 per cent attendance as a condition to be considered as being competent in the official language in question. As a carrot, the Ministry has sanctioned an incentive payment of Rs 25,000 for those who obtain between 80-100 marks, Rs 20,000 for those who obtain between 65 to 79 marks and Rs 15,000 to those who obtain between 50-64 marks, respectively in such proficiency tests. “In addition to the above payment, a salary allowance, which, however is bereft of EPF and ETF benefits, shall also be paid to a successful officer who followed the official language course,” Siriwardana further said. He has however not quantified the value of this allowance. It’s mandatory that public officers be granted leave to attend such courses. OLD together with the National Language Education and Training Institute shall be responsible for conducting such courses. (PA)

title: Jaishankar promised legal action against Indian poachers–Douglas
author: Author not found
Content: Indian External Affairs Minister Dr. S. Jaishankar had pledged to ensure that legal action will be taken against the operators of Indian multiday fishing trawlers that encroach Sri Lankan territorial waters, Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said. Devananda said that the Indian External Affairs Minister, who had been on an official visit to Sri Lanka, met him at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta, Colombo and discussed various issues including the bilateral ties between the two countries as well as the upliftment of Sri Lankan fisheries. Devananda said that he also pointed out that marine environment and livelihood of local fishermen has been severely affected due to the encroachment of Indian multiday fishing trawlers and immediate action has to be taken with regard to this matter. “I brought to the attention of Jaishankar that former PM Mahinda Rajapaksa, who during his visit to India, handed over a set of proposals to Indian PM Narendra Modi, to be taken to resolve this issue. “The Indian PM also agreed to consider those proposals and to take necessary action,” Devananda said. The Fisheries Minister also urged the Indian Foreign Minister to take necessary action with regard to this matter as soon as possible. During the discussions Indian Foreign Minister said the Indian Government is always vigilant and holds discussions in order to take legal action. Many officials including Secretary to the Ministry of Fisheries Indu Ratnayake, Director General of the Fisheries Department Susantha Kahawatte and Director General of Fisheries Ministry (Technical) Dammika Ranathunga were present at the discussion. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: ‘Masjidul Amaan’ opened in Alim Nagar
author: Author not found
Content: A new mosque, ‘Masjidul Amaan,’ built in Akkaraipattu Alim Nagar by a young philanthropist, was opened to the public on Saturday in the presence of religious dignitaries, Ulamas, Maulavis, and distinguished persons of the area. An opening ceremony was held on Saturday under the patronage of President of the Jamiyyathul Ulama Akkaraipattu Branch, Al-Haj Moulavi M.M. Latheef (Bahjee).  Principal of the Akkaraipattu Ummudhartha Arabic College, Dr. M.I.M. Sitheeque (Al-Azharee) conducted a bayan at the new mosque. At the conclusion of the ceremony, philanthropist A.B. Manarul Hudha thanked the public for attending and thereafter hosted a lunch. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Pavithra assumes duties as Wildlife Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Newly appointed Minister of Wildlife and Forest Conservation Pavithra Wanniarachchi assumed duties yesterday (25). After assuming office, an initial introductory discussion about the Ministry was held at the auditorium of the Ministry with the participation of ministry officials. The Minister said animal rights should be protected and people’s problems should be resolved. She also said the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Conservation can generate a lot of revenue for Sri Lanka.

title: Ananda Palitha, Dhammika remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (24) remanded, till 26 January, United Trade Union Alliance Convener Ananda Palitha and Electricity Consumers’ Association Secretary, Sanjeewa Dhammika. The two were arrested by the Kollupitiya Police, for allegedly threatening two members of the Public Utilities Commission ofSri Lanka (PUCSL). Magistrate Gamage instructed the Police, to produce suspect Dhammika, before an identification parade while being adequately covered, at the next hearing date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Cabinet nod for South Asian Logistics Hub
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet approved implementing the South Asian Logistics Hub Programme as a public-private partnership project, between the China Merchant Port Company, Colombo International Container Terminals Company and Sri Lanka Ports Authority, based on the recommendations of the Cabinet-appointed negotiation committee. The proposal was presented by the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation. Colombo Port is the largest port in Sri Lanka as well as the main hub port in the South Asian region. One of the primary strategic objectives of the Port Authority’s National Port Master Plan is to turn Colombo Port into a service supply hub. Battenberg and Bloemendhal service delivery areas, belonging to Colombo South Port, have been identified as areas that can be developed under public-private partnership. The Colombo International Container Terminals Company has submitted a proposal to implement the first phase of the proposed project with an investment of USD 150 million and the proposal has been evaluated by a Cabinet-appointed negotiation committee.

title: Two gangs clash in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: Two violent gangs, operating in the North, clashed yesterday (24) afternoon, resulting in four gangsters being hospitalised. The clash erupted at Chunnakam junction in Jaffna and the two factions started attacking each other with swords, following an ‘accident’ in which two vehicles collided. Jaffna Police said the accident was a deliberate attempt to provoke the other group. A gang which came in one vehicle attacked the other group that came in a car, with swords. The injured persons are being treated at Jaffna Teaching Hospital and security had been strengthened at the location. A large number of Police and STF personnel were deployed in the area. The Jaffna District Police Crime Prevention Division was conducting further inquiries. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Douglas says SLN should go tough on Indian trawlers
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda has reiterated that the Sri Lanka Navy are not taking sufficient action to prevent poaching by Indian fishermen. The Minister requested the Navy to expedite measures to restrict the activities of Indian fishermen poaching in Sri Lankan waters, as well as to develop a safety structure in all fishing coastal areas. The Minister held a special discussion yesterday with the Navy and other stakeholders. He alleged that when hundreds of Indian trawlers are encroaching, the Navy’s action is insufficient The discussion was focused on completely curbing Indian fishermen entering Sri Lankan waters. The Minister also stated that some Tamil political groups, such as the Tamil National Alliance (TNA), are misusing the issue, causing a conflict between the two countries, which cannot be tolerated. Commenting on the occasion, the Navy assured that the naval operations were limited in the last months due to inclement weather and that the operations will be accelerated in the coming weeks. The officer further stated that there is a need to control all illicit fishing activities by local fishermen as well as their involvement in smuggling activities. As a result, it was also agreed to form advisorer committees in each district’s fisheries sector. It has also been decided to include senior officials of the Ministry of Fisheries, senior officials of the Navy and representatives of the Fishermen Federation in these committees. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Writ application filed against Cabinet approval
author: Author not found
Content: A Writ application was filed before the Court of Appeal yesterday (24) seeking a Writ of Certiorari, quashing the Cabinet Decision on revision of the electricity tariff. The Petitioners, including the Electricity and Renewable Energy Association, Electricity and Renewable Energy Consumers Association and the Centre for Environmental Justice, observed that the Cabinet of Ministers is not empowered to make a decision on the revision of electricity tariff as they could only make policy decisions in this regard. The Petitioners stated the proposed electricity tariffs approved by the Cabinet of Ministers had by passed the provisions of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act No.20 of 2009 (as amended) and the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 35 of 2002 and undermined the functions of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL). Further, they sought a Writ of Certiorari quashing the amended General Policy Guideline for the electricity industry approved by the Cabinet of Minister. The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), Chairman of CEB, the Cabinet of Ministers, the PUCSL, President Ranil Wickremesinghe in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies, Minister of Defence, Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment, Minister of Technology and the Attorney General were named as respondents to the Petition. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ajith Prasanna gets four years RI for contempt
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (24) sentenced Retired Major Ajith Prasanna to four years Rigorous Imprisonment over Contempt of Court charges. This was based on the Contempt of Court charges filed by the Attorney General, based on a statement made by Prasanna, at a Media briefing in 2020, in which he allegedly criticised a previous decision of the Supreme Court. The case was taken before Supreme Court Justices P. Padman Surasena, Gamini Amarasekara and S.Thurairaja and by a majority decision, Prasanna was held guilty of Contempt of Court. Court also imposed a fine of Rs 300,000. Further an additional six months imprisonment was imposed if Prasanna fails to pay the said fine. In the dissenting judgement, Supreme Court Justice Gamini Amarasekera opined that the imprisonment sentence should be reduced to two and a half years while agreeing on the rest of the facts of the majority decision. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: IMF assistance will be lost if taxes reduced – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet spokesman Minister Bandula Gunawardena yesterday (24) said the International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance will not be available if the Government’s new taxes are repealed or reduced. He noted that the IMF has informed that taxes should be levied on those who earn more than Rs 45,000 per month. However, the Government only imposed taxes on those who earn more than Rs 100,000 following a lengthy discussion. “If the country cannot reach an agreement with the IMF soon, it will be impossible to run the country effectively. We are also willing to listen to those who can offer better alternatives than going for IMF,” he said. He also said once the country’s economic crisis is resolved, a flexible tax policy will be implemented, but this is not the right time for that. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: INTEREST RATES CAN BE RELAXED WHEN IMF FUNDS ARRIVE – CBSL
author: Author not found
Content: The existing high interest rates would be reduced when Sri Lanka received the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), CBSL officials told the Committee on Public Finance (COPF). The COPF sitting was held on Monday (23). When questioned about the adverse effects of market contraction, due to the stifling interest rates, the Central Bank has acknowledged that those measures have been taken to limit growth in order to prevent the need for greater foreign exchange given the dwindling amount currently in the country.  The Central Bank went on to reiterate that with a cash infusion, via the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the IMF, interest rates can once again be relaxed and the market will once again have an opportunity to expand. COPF asked CBSL whether there is any possible alternative for Sri Lanka other than the IMF bailout. However, the CBSL officials said no other international financing/funding institute is willing to partner with Sri Lanka on its debt management unless they see an IMF partnership materialise first. With the ostensible debt treatment measures that an IMF programme accompanies, it reassures international agencies of Sri Lanka’s credibility to once more partner with the country for future ventures including debt management. The Central Bank has stressed that this is why it is imperative for Sri Lanka to lock in the bailout. The CBSL officials said they are confident of having an actual IMF first tranche disbursement within the first quarter of 2023. When questioned about the severe social implications of such steep mechanisms to adhere to IMF conditions, the CBSL said the IMF is wary about the social impact on vulnerable communities and has invoked certain safeguards such as expenditure ceilings to negate those effects. COPF Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva said regardless of allegiances, will be ready to stand by the reforms promulgated by the IMF and being executed by CBSL. State Minister Suren Raghavan, MPs Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Rauff Hakeem, Chandima Weerakkody, Harshana Rajakaruna, Vijitha Herath, Mayantha Dissanayake and Madhura Withanage were present at the committee meeting.
