However, the Government only imposed taxes on those who earn more than Rs 100,000 following a lengthy discussion. “If the country cannot reach an agreement with the IMF soon, it will be impossible to run the country effectively. We are also willing to listen to those who can offer better alternatives than going for IMF,” he said. He also said once the country’s economic crisis is resolved, a flexible tax policy will be implemented, but this is not the right time for that. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: INTEREST RATES CAN BE RELAXED WHEN IMF FUNDS ARRIVE – CBSL
author: Author not found
Content: The existing high interest rates would be reduced when Sri Lanka received the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), CBSL officials told the Committee on Public Finance (COPF). The COPF sitting was held on Monday (23). When questioned about the adverse effects of market contraction, due to the stifling interest rates, the Central Bank has acknowledged that those measures have been taken to limit growth in order to prevent the need for greater foreign exchange given the dwindling amount currently in the country.  The Central Bank went on to reiterate that with a cash infusion, via the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the IMF, interest rates can once again be relaxed and the market will once again have an opportunity to expand. COPF asked CBSL whether there is any possible alternative for Sri Lanka other than the IMF bailout. However, the CBSL officials said no other international financing/funding institute is willing to partner with Sri Lanka on its debt management unless they see an IMF partnership materialise first. With the ostensible debt treatment measures that an IMF programme accompanies, it reassures international agencies of Sri Lanka’s credibility to once more partner with the country for future ventures including debt management. The Central Bank has stressed that this is why it is imperative for Sri Lanka to lock in the bailout. The CBSL officials said they are confident of having an actual IMF first tranche disbursement within the first quarter of 2023. When questioned about the severe social implications of such steep mechanisms to adhere to IMF conditions, the CBSL said the IMF is wary about the social impact on vulnerable communities and has invoked certain safeguards such as expenditure ceilings to negate those effects. COPF Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva said regardless of allegiances, will be ready to stand by the reforms promulgated by the IMF and being executed by CBSL. State Minister Suren Raghavan, MPs Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Rauff Hakeem, Chandima Weerakkody, Harshana Rajakaruna, Vijitha Herath, Mayantha Dissanayake and Madhura Withanage were present at the committee meeting.

title: EC tells Party reps to limit Polls expenses
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission informed the political Party representatives that it would be suitable to spend an amount between Rs 15 and 20 per voter in the upcoming Local Government Election. The EC convened a meeting yesterday (24) morning with the representatives of all political parties and independent groups contesting in LG Polls. Also, the EC said, after the Speaker signed the recently passed Election Expenditure Bill, the commission will announce the guidelines for expenditure in LG Poll officially. The commission advised the party representatives to limit their election expenditure. Furthermore, it was informed that there is no urgency to gazette the election date and it would be enough to issue the Gazette Notification a week prior to the scheduled date of the LG Poll. BY J.T. de Silva

title: HRCSL summons Power Ministry Secy, PUCSL Chair
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has summoned the Secretary to the Ministry of Power and Energy and the Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) for an inquiry over the failure to prevent the implementation of power cuts during the GCE Advanced Level examination period. The inquiry will take place today at 10:30 a.m. at the HRCSL premises. In a statement, the HRCSL has raised concerns over non-responsiveness of the two, with regard to previous statements of the commission, about ensuring uninterrupted power supply during the exam period. The HRCSL previously said the right to equality of the students, who began sitting for GCE Advanced Level examination yesterday (23), had been violated by the hours-long power cuts during the examination period. The commission said it has written to the Secretary of the Ministry of Power and Energy and the Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), to instruct the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to refrain from implementing power cuts at any time during the examination period.

title: Police withdraw charges against lawyers
author: Author not found
Content: Keselwatta Police yesterday sought approval from Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis, to withdraw a complaint against a group of lawyers, who staged a protest in front of the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court on 18 January. The complaint was filed in connection with the violation of Provisions contained in Sections of the Police, Elections and the National Thoroughfares Acts, over the alleged intervention in the activities of the Judiciary by the Attorney General. The Chief Magistrate acceded to the request and ordered that Court proceedings, in this connection be concluded. Keselwatta Police informed Chief Magistrate Alwis on 20 January that around 50 lawyers, serving at the Court, along with a group of individuals purporting to be from the ‘Aragalaya’ movement, staged a protest in front of the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court, on 18 January. The Police added that the actions of the protesters had flouted Provisions contained in Sections of each of the aforementioned Acts. However, Police said that as they had not identified any offences committed by the protesters they sought the Court’s approval, to withdraw the complaint. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Two Deacons to be ordained Priests by Bishop Valence Mendis
author: Author not found
Content: At 10.00 a.m. on 28 January, at St. Mary’s Church Bolawalana, Bishop of Chilaw and Kandy, The Most Rev. Valence Mendis will raise to the Priesthood two Deacons, namely Rev. Deacon Janith Lakmal, S.J. and Rev. Deacon Chamika Nipun, S.J. Rev. Deacon Janith Lakmal, S.J. Mallawa Arachchige Don Janith Lakmal Perera, born on 4 March 1989, is the second child of Manel Jacintha Fernando and the late Annesley Shantha Perera of Talawila. Blessed with two brothers and a sister, Janith Lakmal grew up in the neighbourhood of St Anne’s shrine, Talawila. Inspired by his early association with this shrine of pilgrimage, he grew up with a passionate desire for religious activities. He received his primary education at St Anne’s Maha Vidyalaya, Talawila and secondary education at St Xavier’s College, Marawila The life journey of young Janith Lakmal took a decisive turn directed by the life stories of the Jesuits and especially that of Saint Ignatius of Loyola. Driven by the desire to serve as a Jesuit, in September 2008, he entered the Jesuit Pre-novitiate at Akkarapanaha, Negombo, where he received his initial religious formation. Having made up his mind to follow the Jesuit way, he entered the Jesuit Novitiate, ‘Daham Sihila’ at Dalugama, Kelaniya on 20 June 2009 and pronounced his first religious vows on 21 June 2011. In 2012, he began his degree studies in English Literature, Journalism and Economics at St. Aloysius University College in Mangalore, India and obtained his degree. He completed his post-graduation in Philosophy in ‘Satya Nilayam’ having obtained his MA degree from the University of Chennai, India. He then, returned to Sri Lanka and immersed himself in activities to gain experience working with people, a period known as Regency in Jesuit terminology. The next stage was his theological studies, an absolute requirement for priesthood, he was sent to the Gregorian University, Rome in 2019. On 19 April 2022, he was ordained a Deacon by Luis Cardinal Antonio Tagle in Rome. After completing the theological studies, he returned to Sri Lanka and started his diaconate ministry at the Jaffna Cathedral inserting himself in the life of the parish in order to gain pastoral experience and also to master the Tamil language. Later, he continued his services at St. Joseph’s Church, Wennappuwa too. Rev. Deacon Chamika Nipun, S.J. Chamika Nipun, born in Negombo on 27 November 1988, is the eldest child of Rohan Neumal and Carmen Abeywardena. He belongs to the parish of Our Lady of Lourdes, Raddolugama, where he learned the rudiments of the Catholic faith and deepened his commitment to his religious beliefs. As a growing up young man, he held in high honour his faith commitment and offered a good part of his precious time to parish activities, such as teaching religion to children and to other similar activities. He pursued his studies in Wesley College, Colombo. As he completed his studies at Wesley College and stood at the cross roads of life, to decide on a course of action, to face his future, he decided to offer himself to serve as a Jesuit. In order to pursue this newly discovered venture, he joined the Jesuit Pre-novitiate at Akkarapanaha, Negombo in September 2008 and discovered that the Lord, he longed to serve, was calling him to be a member of his company. Having discovered where his future should be, he entered the ‘Daham Sihila’ Jesuit Novitiate at Dalugama, Kelaniya and pronounced his first vows on 21 June 2011 committing himself to continue his chosen life as a Jesuit. In 2012, he was sent to St Aloysius University College, Mangalore in India where he studied mathematics, physics and computer science and obtained his B.Sc., degree. Then, he was asked to complete his post-graduation in philosophy at the University of Chennai, India for two years. In 2015, he returned to Sri Lanka to follow ‘Regency’, the next stage of his formation. He entered the Gregorian University in Rome in 2019 to begin his theological studies. On 19 April 2022, Luis Cardinal Antonio Tagle ordained him a Deacon in Rome. He returned to his motherland and exercised his diaconate responsibilities at the Madurankuliya Parish while making every effort to master the Tamil language. The new priests, Rev. Chamika Nipun will celebrate his first Mass on 29 January at Our Lady of Lourdes Church, Raddolugama and Rev. Janith Lakmal will celebrate his first Mass on February 5 at St. Anne’s Shrine, Talawila. By Chinthaka De Mel

title: Trickle-Down Economics in Davos
author: Author not found
Content: The billionaires, bankers, politicians – and the high-price sex workers who cater to them – have gone home. The World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos is over for another year. More than 1,040 private jets flew in and out of airports serving the Swiss mountain resort during the week of the WEF, producing four times as much CO2 pollution from private jets in an average week. As the plutocrats and politicians flew home in luxury from their Swiss jaunt, they might have had time to cast a glance at a new report published to coincide with the gathering in Davos. Survival of the Richest, by Oxfam, makes enlightening reading. It shows that extreme wealth and extreme poverty have increased simultaneously for the first time in 25 years. “While ordinary people are making daily sacrifices on essentials like food, the super-rich have outdone even their wildest dreams. Just two years in, this decade is shaping up to be the best yet for billionaires – a roaring ‘20s boom for the world’s richest,” said Gabriela Bucher, Executive Director of Oxfam International. “It’s time we demolish the convenient myth that tax cuts for the richest result in their wealth somehow ‘trickling down’ to everyone else. Forty years of tax cuts for the super-rich have shown that a rising tide doesn’t lift all ships – just the superyachts.” Billionaires have seen extraordinary increases in their wealth. During the pandemic and cost-of-living crisis years since 2020, US$ 26 trillion (63 per cent) of all new wealth was captured by the richest ‘1 per cent’, while US$ 16 trillion (37 per cent) went to the rest of the world put together. A billionaire gained roughly US$ 1.7 million for every US$ 1 of new global wealth earned by a person in the bottom 90 per cent. Billionaire fortunes have increased by US$ 2.7 billion a day. Billionaire wealth surged in 2022 with rapidly rising food and energy profits. The report shows that 95 food and energy corporations have more than doubled their profits in 2022. They made US$ 306 billion in windfall profits and paid out US$ 257 billion (84 per cent) of that to rich shareholders. The Walton dynasty, which owns half of Walmart, received US$ 8.5 billion over the last year. Indian billionaire Gautam Adani, owner of major energy corporations, has seen this wealth soar by US$ 42 billion (46 per cent) in 2022 alone. Excess corporate profits have driven at least half of inflation in Australia, the US and the UK. At the same time, at least 1.7 billion workers now live in countries where inflation is outpacing wages, and over 820 million people are going hungry. Women and girls often eat least and last and makeup nearly 60 per cent of the world’s hungry population. The World Bank says we are likely seeing the biggest increase in global inequality and poverty since WW2. Entire countries are facing bankruptcy, with the poorest countries now spending four times more repaying debts to rich creditors than on healthcare. Three-quarters of the world’s governments, including Sri Lanka, are planning austerity-driven public sector spending cuts. Decades of tax cuts for the richest and corporations have fuelled inequality, with the poorest people in many countries paying higher tax rates than billionaires. But at least some trickle-down wealth is helping the sex workers who flocked to Davos. Nearly 3,000 conference delegates were in town for the five-day jamboree, the first in the post-pandemic era, said to provide a US$ 100 million boost to the local economy. Prostitution is legal in Switzerland, with sex workers expected to pay taxes. And trade was booming in Davos. Take Liana, who dresses in business attire so she doesn’t stand out among the executives. She told Bild she regularly sees an American who visits Switzerland multiple times a year and is among the WEF attendees. Liana charges around €700 (US$ 760) for an hour and €2,300 (US$ 2,500) for the whole night, plus travel expenses. The manager of one escort service in Aargau, 100 miles away from Davos, says she was flooded with bookings. She told 20 Minuten: “Some also book escorts for themselves and their employees to party in the hotel suite.” Salome Balthus, a sex worker and writer, posted on Twitter: “Date in Switzerland during #WEF means looking at the gun muzzles of security guards in the hotel corridor at 2 a.m. – and then sharing the giveaway chocolates from the restaurant with them and gossiping about the rich… #Davos #WEF.” I bet she has some stories to tell. By Michael Gregson

title: Colombo Uni Leos’ ‘Sahurda Yatra 4.0’ to begin soon
author: Author not found
Content: Under the theme ‘Finding Extraordinary People among People,’ the Colombo University Leo Club (Leo District 306-C1) is organising the ‘Sahurda Yatra 4.0’ project for the benefit of people with disabilities and special needs. The first of three phases of this project, a career guidance and encouragement programme, for the benefit of students with disabilities studying at the University of Colombo, under the banner of ‘Friendship Dialogue’, was held on 18 November 2022 at the Colombo University campus. It was a great success.This time, the second phase of the project, ‘Sahurda Manudama’, is based on the theme of ‘bringing smiles to little hearts’, and includes a physical fitness programme as well as arts and crafts for children with special needs, to showcase their talents at the Kindelpitiya ‘Diri Daru Piyasa’ Development Centre. An exhibition was held on 20 and 21 December 2022. A physical therapy and occupational therapy programme was implemented as part of this, to improve the physical fitness of children with special needs and an art and craft exhibition was organised to help them discover their hidden talents. The third phase of this project, ‘Sahurda Saviya’, will begin soon.

title: SL Ambassador-designate to Ethiopia assumes duties
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador-designate of Sri Lanka to the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, K.K. Theshantha Kumarasiri assumed duties at the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Addis Ababa on 18 January. Addressing Embassy staff on assuming duties, the Ambassador-designate said there was a renewed focus on expanding Sri Lanka’s relations with African countries. In this regard, Ethiopia is an important partner both from a political and economic perspective as well as reaching out to other African countries given its central role as the headquarters of the African Union. Kumarasiri counts 20 years in the Sri Lanka Foreign Service, having served in Sri Lankan Embassy in Brazil, South Korea, France and Permanent Delegation of Sri Lanka to UNESCO in Paris. He is a graduate of the University of Kelaniya and has a Masters in Human Rights and Democratisation from the University of Colombo.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Over 200 schools to receive USD 2.3M food security funding from Australia
author: Author not found
Content: Over 200 schools will receive funding from Australia, via the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO), to build entrepreneurial school gardens in the North, Central and Uva Provinces, to support nutritional security among children, the UN office in Colombo said. The entrepreneurial school gardens programme, implemented as part of a project funded by the Australian Government, totalling over USD 2.3 million, is aimed at improving the food and nutritional security of groups most affected by the ongoing economic crisis, particularly women and children. The programme features a discovery-based learning approach for over 100,000 secondary school students, from grades 8 – 12, where they will be educated on the capacity to transform their school gardens into sources of nutritious produce, that will facilitate diverse and healthy eating habits and encourage students to apply entrepreneurial thinking in agriculture. 505 school teachers from the three provinces were also trained on the discovery-based learning methodology as part of the programme to improve skills in food security, nutrition, agriculture and entrepreneurship. The Agriculture club in each school will be empowered to operate as a core programme partner that will oversee the coordination and navigation of the programme alongside school officials. It will also oversee the sale of harvests from the gardens and will be linked to sales points including private sector organisations, parents of students, local markets, or the national school meal programme via FAO, to ensure the harvests of the gardens generate an income – thereby ensuring the sustainability of the gardens beyond the project period. Australia’s High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Paul Stephens said, “School gardening has the potential to both improve children’s health and support learning. Involving students in school gardening and teaching them about the benefits of nutrition can have a lasting impact. This programme is helping to highlight the value of growing food for household food security.”  “We are appreciative of this generous assistance from the people of Australia, which has enabled this sustainable school-to-home knowledge transfer approach to strengthen food security among school children,” said FAO Representative in Sri Lanka, Vimlendra Sharan adding, “School gardens offer rich environments for children to engage in active learning. The knowledge will be transferred through students to their family members and by extension, to the communities, prompting an attitudinal change on food consumption habits and new agricultural concepts.” FAO will work closely with the Ministry of Education, Department of Agriculture, Ministry of Health and the Chief Secretariat of Uva, Central and Northern Provinces, to educate children and faculty on eco-friendly agricultural practices and nutrition. (SRM)

title: Former Jaffna Mayor petitions SC against new Mayor
author: Author not found
Content: Former Jaffna Mayor Viswalingam Manivannan filed a petition, in the Jaffna High Court yesterday (24), against New Mayor Arnold Emmanuel, who has been re-elected as Mayor. Emmanuel was announced as the Mayor of Jaffna and he assumed duties last Saturday (21). His name was proposed and seconded on Friday. For several weeks, there has been a tussle over the Jaffna Municipal Council election, in which Mannivannan stepped down after failing to pass the 2023 budget. However, he has been running a re-election campaign, which the Illanaki Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK) has opposed. He was alleged to have appealed the Governor of the Northern Province to reinstate him but the ITAK has said he is not eligible after he stepped down. However, both Arnold and Manivannan are MC members and eligible to stand at the elections, noted C.V. K. Sivanganam who was the former PC Chairman. He said the appointment of Arnold is ‘debatable’ as there is little confusion but he noted that Arnold’s name was proposed and seconded. On the appointment of Emmanuel as the Mayor, the former Mayor Manivannan has said Emanuel was defeated earlier. Manivannan replaced him for two years but stepped down before the second reading for the Budget a few weeks back.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: THREE REMANDED OVER THEFT OF TEXTBOOKS
author: Author not found
Content: Trincomalee Chief Magistrate I.P. Razak yesterday (24) remanded, till 31 January, a past pupil of a leading school in Kantale and two other suspects, who were charged with the theft of about 600 school textbooks. The past pupil is a resident of Trincomalee while the other two suspects, who had purchased the textbooks from him, are residents of Kaththankudy and Anuradhapura. It was revealed in Court that the suspects had broken and entered into the school storeroom and robbed the textbooks. BY W.M. Wickremasinghe – Kantale

title: Maligawila temple traders hit hard
author: Author not found
Content: Traders at the Maligawila Temple premises expressed their agitation over being hit hard due to the drastic reduction in the number of devotees visiting the sacred site. They said only a small number of traders are presently engaged in business but due to the lack devotees visiting the sacred temple they have not been able to make sufficient sales. A trade centre consisting of 105 stalls was constructed by the Ministry of Housing and Construction via the finances from the Sevana Fund 23 years ago. But, the traders claimed that due to the steep decline in devotees and pilgrims, they are currently facing difficulty in earning a living. They urged the Government to look into their predicament. BY Nadun Gunathileka – Bibila

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  The Sri Lanka High Commission in Singapore, together with the Sri Lankan community there, celebrated the Thai Pongal festival for the third consecutive year in a colourful ceremony at the High Commission premises on Thursday (19).  Decorative motifs, popularly known as “’Kolams’ among the Tamil community, were drawn on the floor adding a traditional cultural look to the event.  Vice Chairman of the Sri Senpaga Vinayagar Temple in Singapore K. Selvakrishnan and President Jayaseelan Karthijesu, and Secretary-General of the Singapore-Ceylon Tamils Association  S. Koban were present as special guests. Chief Priest of the Sri Senpaga Vinayagar Temple in Singapore, Sri Sabesan Kurukkal, conducted the special pooja and Hindu religious observances.  Welcoming those present, High Commissioner Sashikala Premawardhane emphasised the importance of the Thai Pongal Festival and introduced it as the most treasured religious and cultural festival celebrated by the Tamil Community across the globe. She added that festival pays tribute to the sun by offering the first harvest as a token of gratitude. She said that the Thai Pongal festival has become an integral part of the national culture and this year’s ‘Thai Pongal’ is a celebration with added significance, considering the bumper harvest of the current ‘Maha’ Season, from which the entire nation will benefit.  The High Commissioner quoted from the Thai Pongal message of President Ranil Wickeremesinghe, which highlighted that the Pongal festival this year is opportune to signify the Government’s endeavours, to build a self-sufficient country by ensuring food security and nutrition for all, and reviving Sri Lanka as the Granary of the East, as established by our forefathers. The High Commissioner added that the Singapore -Sri Lanka relationship is underpinned by shared cultural values and strong people to people linkages. She recalled the invaluable assistance extended throughout the Covid 19 pandemic by the Government of Singapore through Temasek Foundation International, other charitable organisations and the Singapore community to support Sri Lanka’s healthcare response to the pandemic. High Commissioner Premawardhane added that the High Commission is also hoping to join hands with the Tamil Community in Singapore to assist in initiating some special projects for which the preliminary discussion has been held with the Governor of the Northern Province of Sri Lanka during his recent visit to Singapore. The High Commissioner acknowledged the extensive contributions made by the Sri Lankan Tamil community towards the development of Singapore, stating that the community was a proud reflection of the country, its diversity and its talent. The Senpaga Vinayagar temple in Singapore was built in the 1850s for which the Ceylonese Tamils are credited with pioneering the building of the first structures of the temple. The High Commissioner appreciated the important role played by the Singapore-Ceylon Tamils Association in the maintenance and management of the temple.  The religious rituals ended with the offering of Pongal to Lord Ganesha and other gods. Traditional sweetmeats, including Pongal and Ceylon Tea were served at the conclusion of the event. Popular

title: Twins from 30 countries to arrive in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Twins Organization will hold Twin Miss World and also the most handsome twin couple 2023, at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute Colombo. This event is endorsed by the Ministry of Tourism and also the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau. This event will also carry a meaningful purpose, as it mainly targets the economic growth of the country by covering several areas such as social, economic, culture and tourism. This will be a wonderful opportunity to promote Sri Lanka as an important Tourism destination, renowned for its warm hospitality and iconic tourism attractions, Sri Lanka Tourism said. The grand finale of this event is scheduled to be held on 28 May 2023 in Sri Lanka, while the first round of selecting the Sri Lankan contestants will be held on 22 February 2023. Around 30 countries are scheduled to be represented at this event, and a large number of foreign visitors and their media representatives are also scheduled to arrive for the event. It should be also noted with great pride that the basic concept of this event belongs to the two founders of the Sri Lanka Twins Organisation By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: President plans to export poultry and eggs
author: Author not found
Content: While raids are being conducted to find if eggs are being sold at prices in excess of the stipulated price, the President intends to turn the poultry and egg industry into an export industry, Senior Adviser to the President on Food Security Dr. Suren Batagoda informed stakeholders. He informed this during a discussion held at the President’s Media Centre yesterday morning (23). Dr. Batagoda said therefore all those involved in the industry should work collectively for the advancement of the industry. The matter was discussed at length during a discussion on the issues related to the chicken and egg industry during the meeting.  The shortage of animal feed, rising prices of raw materials, fuel crisis, transport issues, foreign exchange issues for importing animal feed etc. and the available solutions to address these issues were focussed on during the discussion. Those involved in the poultry and egg production industry and officials of related line institutions participated in this meeting. Dr. Batagoda pointed out that most of the issues related to the industry could be solved by way of coming to a collective agreement among all the stakeholders and by determining the prices of egg and poultry products accordingly. The Chairman of the Egg Trade Association, the Chairman of the Restaurant Owners Association, the Chairman of the All Ceylon Egg Production Association and the Chairman of the National Farmer Association Board also presented issues affecting the industry as well as probable solutions to them. The willingness to reach a collective agreement, for the advancement of the poultry and egg industry, was a special feature of the discussion while the intervention made by the President’s Office for the security of the industry was also appreciated. Agriculture Ministry Secretary Gunadasa Samarasinghe, Trade, Commerce and Food Security Ministry Secretary A.M.P.M.B. Atapattu and officials of line institutions participated in the discussion.

title: Constitutional Council to meet tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: The Constitutional Council will meet tomorrow (25) at 9:30 a.m., Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadheera said. The President appointed non-members of Parliament as members of the Constitutional Council based on the nominations submitted by the Speaker with the agreement of the Speaker, the Prime Minister and the Opposition Leader in Parliament. Accordingly, Dr. Pratap Ramanujam, Dr. Dilkushi Anula Wijesundere, and Dr. Weligama Vidana Arachchige Dinesha Samararatne have been appointed. Dr. Ramanujam has served as a Member of the Public Service Commission and has also served as the Secretary to several Ministries for over a decade. Dr. Wijesundere is a doctor by profession. Dr. Samararatne is a law academic and works as a Senior Lecturer at the University of Colombo.

title: Health workers stage token strike
author: Author not found
Content: The Joint Health Workers’ Union (JHWU) staged a token strike yesterday (23), making 11 demands, including the increase of transport allowances to suit price inflation and overcome the existing drug shortage. JHWU General Secretary, Ven. Tampitiye Sugathananda Thera said the protesting hospital assistants had also demanded the reduction of the interest rate levied for bank loans. He said the Government should also take immediate action to overcome the shortage of hospital assistants. The strike was staged from 8:00 a.m. to noon. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 81 bird species in SL threatened with extinction
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s Biodiversity Secretariat said 81 of the country’s bird species are threatened with extinction. Director of the Biodiversity Secretariat under the Ministry of Environment R.H.M.P. Abeykoon said Sri Lanka is a biodiversity hotspot with 435 species of birds, and this has been found during a nationwide survey on the Red Data Book of 2022. The birds are faced with the threat of extinction owing to the damage caused to their habitats by humans, she said. The Red Data Book is a public document recording endangered and rare species of plants, animals, fungi as well as some local subspecies that are present in a particular region. (Xinhua)

title: Coalition Parties will be consulted – Sagala
author: Author not found
Content: Opinions of the coalition Parties that submitted nominations under UNP’s ‘Elephant’ symbol will have to be sought to decide who the UNP mayoral candidate for Colombo Municipal Council will be, UNP National Organiser Sagala Ratnayake said. Ratnayake’s remark comes in contradiction of the Statement made by former Colombo Mayor Rosy Senanayake that the UNP has proposed her name as the mayoral candidate for the MC. Ratnayake said a strong team of candidates from both UNP and coalition parties are ready to contest for the Colombo MC and Senanayake is also part of the team. He said Senanayake is an experienced politician and led the MC for an extended period. However, when deciding the mayoral candidate, opinions of the coalition parties will also be considered, Ratnayake added. By Amith Maduranga Gamage

title: Govt doctors threaten to lodge WHO complaint
author: Author not found
Content: State hospital doctors warned they will lodge a complaint with the World Health Organization (WHO) against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella and his officials at the Health Ministry during the course of this week against the inefficiency and weak management of the prevailing pharmaceutical crisis in Sri Lanka. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe yesterday (23) accused Rambukwella and the Ministry officials for failing to take timely action in resolving a medicinal crisis which has been persisting for close to one year due to their inefficiency and feeble management skills. According to the Union’s discussions with the Treasury recently, the Health Ministry has findings which it can use to put an end to the medicinal drug issue. Dr. Wijesinghe lamented that there was no desired outcome despite funds from the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the Indian Credit Line being made available for it. There is no guarantee that the issue will be resolved by May this year despite the Health Minister’s public reassurance owing to the snail pace at which even the Indian Credit Line was being put to use. He lamented that the shortage of drugs in the State health service could lead to the death of some of its patients – especially from amongst those who suffer from chronic diseases. They receive drugs to last them only for two weeks due to the drug shortage while the price of medicinal drugs in the private sector was high, so patients only took the drugs that were given by their clinics. The GMOA Media Committee Member said with the increased charges in private sector hospitals, patients who used to take medicine from the private sector hospitals have also turned to the government service. Meanwhile, the GMOA commenced its Black Protest Week yesterday (23) from the National Hospital, Colombo with the signing of a petition against the drug shortage in the State health service and the new Inland Revenue Act. The outfit’s Media Committee Member, Dr. Wijesinghe said they hoped to create public awareness among patients and relatives who came to the NHSL mostly against the medicinal drug issue. He said the Union hoped to gather at least one million signatures for the petition which will be submitted to President Ranil Wickremesinghe next month. The Black Protest Week is being observed in islandwide State hospitals where the petition was also being signed. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Govt short of Rs 480B this month – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: In the backdrop of projected drop of income of Sri Lanka Customs and Excise Department by Rs 10 billion this month, the Government is struggling to earn Rs 480 billion for its expenditure. In a statement issued by State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, total expenditure of the Government in January is estimated at Rs 625 billion and expected revenue in January is only Rs 145 billion. Addressing the concerns of delaying salaries of public sector employees in January, Siyambalapitiya said salaries of non-executive public sector employees will be paid on the 25th of every month as usual. He said salaries of executive-level public sector employees will be paid on the same day or with a day’s delay. Siyambalapitiya emphasised that out of the Rs 93 billion needed to pay State employee salaries, Rs 87 billion has already been allocated. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Power cuts violate rights of GCE A/L students – HRCSL
author: Author not found
Content: The right to equality of the students, who began sitting for GCE Advanced Level examination yesterday (23), has been violated by the hours-long power cuts during the examination period, the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) noted yesterday (23). In a statement, the commission said it has written to the Secretary of the Ministry of Power and Energy and the Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), to instruct the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to refrain from implementing power cuts at any time during the examination period. The commission Stated that this will enable the students preparing for the examination to exercise their right to education unobstructed. Accordingly, the HRCSL requested the relevant authorities to deliver uninterrupted power supply during the period of the Advanced Level Examinations, from 23 January 2023 to 17 February 2023. (AK)

title: Twins from 30 countries to arrive in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Twins Organization will hold Twin Miss World and also the most handsome twin couple 2023, at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute Colombo. This event is endorsed by the Ministry of Tourism and also the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau. This event will also carry a meaningful purpose, as it mainly targets the economic growth of the country by covering several areas such as social, economic, culture and tourism. This will be a wonderful opportunity to promote Sri Lanka as an important Tourism destination, renowned for its warm hospitality and iconic tourism attractions, Sri Lanka Tourism said. The grand finale of this event is scheduled to be held on 28 May 2023 in Sri Lanka, while the first round of selecting the Sri Lankan contestants will be held on 22 February 2023. Around 30 countries are scheduled to be represented at this event, and a large number of foreign visitors and their media representatives are also scheduled to arrive for the event. It should be also noted with great pride that the basic concept of this event belongs to the two founders of the Sri Lanka Twins Organisation By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: President plans to export poultry and eggs
author: Author not found
Content: While raids are being conducted to find if eggs are being sold at prices in excess of the stipulated price, the President intends to turn the poultry and egg industry into an export industry, Senior Adviser to the President on Food Security Dr. Suren Batagoda informed stakeholders. He informed this during a discussion held at the President’s Media Centre yesterday morning (23). Dr. Batagoda said therefore all those involved in the industry should work collectively for the advancement of the industry. The matter was discussed at length during a discussion on the issues related to the chicken and egg industry during the meeting.  The shortage of animal feed, rising prices of raw materials, fuel crisis, transport issues, foreign exchange issues for importing animal feed etc. and the available solutions to address these issues were focussed on during the discussion. Those involved in the poultry and egg production industry and officials of related line institutions participated in this meeting. Dr. Batagoda pointed out that most of the issues related to the industry could be solved by way of coming to a collective agreement among all the stakeholders and by determining the prices of egg and poultry products accordingly. The Chairman of the Egg Trade Association, the Chairman of the Restaurant Owners Association, the Chairman of the All Ceylon Egg Production Association and the Chairman of the National Farmer Association Board also presented issues affecting the industry as well as probable solutions to them. The willingness to reach a collective agreement, for the advancement of the poultry and egg industry, was a special feature of the discussion while the intervention made by the President’s Office for the security of the industry was also appreciated. Agriculture Ministry Secretary Gunadasa Samarasinghe, Trade, Commerce and Food Security Ministry Secretary A.M.P.M.B. Atapattu and officials of line institutions participated in the discussion.

title: Constitutional Council to meet tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: The Constitutional Council will meet tomorrow (25) at 9:30 a.m., Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadheera said. The President appointed non-members of Parliament as members of the Constitutional Council based on the nominations submitted by the Speaker with the agreement of the Speaker, the Prime Minister and the Opposition Leader in Parliament. Accordingly, Dr. Pratap Ramanujam, Dr. Dilkushi Anula Wijesundere, and Dr. Weligama Vidana Arachchige Dinesha Samararatne have been appointed. Dr. Ramanujam has served as a Member of the Public Service Commission and has also served as the Secretary to several Ministries for over a decade. Dr. Wijesundere is a doctor by profession. Dr. Samararatne is a law academic and works as a Senior Lecturer at the University of Colombo.

title: Health workers stage token strike
author: Author not found
Content: The Joint Health Workers’ Union (JHWU) staged a token strike yesterday (23), making 11 demands, including the increase of transport allowances to suit price inflation and overcome the existing drug shortage. JHWU General Secretary, Ven. Tampitiye Sugathananda Thera said the protesting hospital assistants had also demanded the reduction of the interest rate levied for bank loans. He said the Government should also take immediate action to overcome the shortage of hospital assistants. The strike was staged from 8:00 a.m. to noon. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: NPP to present economic policy framework today
author: Author not found
Content: A National Economic Forum, organised by the National People’s Power (NPP) will be held at Galadari Hotel today (24) at 5:30 p.m.  Over 500 corporate leaders representing all sectors, including university academics, researchers and foreign investors will attend the forum. The NPP will present their economic policy framework at this high-level meeting, and they hope to engage with entrepreneurs with a view to shape a business-friendly production economy in Sri Lanka. NPP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake will address the forum.

title: Three antique thieves arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Three suspects were arrested for possessing antiques, suspected to be taken from a treasure, Police said. The suspects were arrested based on information received by the Panadura Central Anti-Corruption Unit on 22 January, near a hotel car park in Kalutara. Investigations showed the main suspect is a retired soldier. He had retired due to medical reasons. The main suspect is a 34-year-old resident of Moragahakanda and the other two suspects are residents of Gandara and Kaluwamodara, aged 36 and 42. On interrogation, it came to light that the suspects planned to sell the antiques for Rs 30 million. Kalutara North Police and Panadura Central Anti-Corruption Unit are conducting investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: 800,000 litres of spirits languish at sugar factory
author: Author not found
Content: Around 800,000 litres of spirits had piled up at a distillery of Pelwatte Sugar Factory as buyers have failed to purchase the stocks, a Pelawatta Sugar Factory official said. He said at present around 800,000 litres of spirits had piled up at its distillery and warned that if buyers fail to purchase the stocks, the production of spirits will have to be halted. A litre of spirits is being sold at Rs 1,200. Chairman of Lanka Sugar Company, Retired Major General Sarada Samarakoon said this situation had arisen due to the increase in prices of products made out of spirits via the hike in recent taxes and the failure of prospective buyers to renew their licences. However, he said they will be able to sell the stocks of spirits at the distillery in the coming weeks. By Nadun Gunathileke – Bibile

title: Farmers want polls money paid to them as compensation
author: Author not found
Content: The funds set aside for the conduct of the 2023 LG Polls, should be paid to farmers, as compensation, over the loss of the paddy harvest in several Provinces due to the presence of a bacterial fungus, a group of farmers from the Mahaweli B Zone in Sewanapitiya said. They warned that all farmers in the Mahaweli B Zone will boycott the upcoming Polls if the Government ignores their request for compensation. They made this comment at a media conference at Nelumwewa in the afternoon of 23 January. The farmers alleged that due to the spread of a bacterial fungus, around 50 per cent of the paddy harvest could be seriously affected. They maintained that if the Government fails to provide adequate compensation to farmers over their losses, they will not leave any room for political representatives to visit their villages ahead of the upcoming election. BY Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: Govt to spend Rs 122M
author: Author not found
Content: Rs 122 million will be spent to distribute the diesel consignment which was donated by China, Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said. According to the Minister, the Department of Agrarian Development has commenced the distribution of 6.8 million litres of diesel donated by China to farmers for paddy harvesting. Amaraweera said the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) will undertake the distribution of the diesel stock and it is expected to spend Rs 122 million for the task. Also, steps have been taken to provide diesel free of charge to paddy farmers who cultivate between half an acre to two and a half acres, he added.

title: Geetha attends Congress for Women of Influence in Iran
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe participated in the First International Congress for Women of Influence held in Tehran, Iran, on 20 January. She left the country on 18 January, following an invitation of Iran’s Vice President of Women and Family Affairs Ensieh Khazali. The First International Congress for Women of Influence was held in Tehran on 20 January with female guests including wives of heads of state, ministers, vice presidents, and parliamentarians from Burkina Faso, Kyrgyzstan, Serbia, Guinea, Niger, Nigeria, Sri Lanka, Syria, Turkmenistan, and Armenia. According to Iran, the event aimed to appreciate women of influence, support and help them grow, and promote their creativity and ideas.

title: Unattended wastewater system polluting Mattegoda HS
author: Author not found
Content: Owing to failure to carry out proper maintenance work on the wastewater system, connected to 1,200 houses, at the Mattegoda Housing Scheme, the wastewater that is released from the houses had begun to pollute the environment while paving the way for various health hazards. According to the residents, this unpleasant situation had arisen over the past five months. As a result of this issue, the residents living near to the Housing Complex had started to sell off their houses due to their inability to reside in the area because to the unbearable stench emanating, while a pre-school that had been operated for years had also been forced to be shut down and a young girl had fallen victim to dengue. If the Government fails to address this situation urgently and resolve it the day will not be far when they would have to face the wrath of the public ahead of the upcoming LG Polls, the residents stressed. BY Hashan Pushpika – Pannipitiya

title: What’s the point in imposing taxes when people can’t pay? – Ravi K
author: Author not found
Content: Former Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake said the Government envisioning earning Rs 100 billion from the PAYE tax is impractical and senseless and asked; “What’s the point of having such tax expectation when people can’t actually pay?” Karunanayake addressing the media in Colombo further said; “Today, a person who starts a small and medium business has to pay 30 per cent interest rate. When they allocate 40 per cent for salaries, having electricity tariff increased by 80 per cent, water tariff increased by 40 per cent, their tax which was 14 per cent earlier increased to 30 per cent, what is left for a business?” “In 2019, Rs 19 billion was earned from PAYE tax while Rs 24 billion in 2020 and Rs 32 billion in 2021 were earned. Now it is estimated to be Rs 100 billion in 2023. If you know from the beginning that this is not achievable, there is no point in enforcing such a tax. If a white person comes and says to increase this from 10 to 25 per cent, our Government officials should have the courage to say that this cannot be done. “How much pressure does it put on an ordinary working person? Although his income has increased, his ability to pay or purchasing power has decreased rapidly due to inflation and taxes. “Therefore, I request the Government to please reconsider the PAYE tax.” This is not a practical tax, even though the whites say so. You can think about this afresh. Today, there are 14 million EPF tax files. If put Rs 250 per month in each of these files, you can earn Rs 42 billion in a year. Also, there are 3 million active tax files. If you get Rs 750 every month from a file, you can find Rs 27 billion in a year. There are 100,000 tax files of high level people who earn Rs 3-4 million monthly. If you impose a tax of Rs 75,000 a month, you will get Rs 90 billion in a year. When these things are added, you will get Rs 157 billion. There are 8 million in the private sector. They don’t get a cent from this tax. Does the public service contribute to the development of the country? I say these things because I have love for this country.” The former Finance Minister also said the proposals of the International Monetary Fund should be implemented only while safeguarding local values and insisted that the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) should think creatively and find sources of income without pressuring the people. Karunanayake also blamed the Central Bank stating it lacks practical knowledge. “I find this as a major problem and point my finger at the Government also for watching silently. This crisis is not something that happened overnight.  We can only come out from this only by thinking differently when proceeding. These people are talking about an independent administration. Didn’t we go through 74 years of independent administration? Where has it gone now? Is the country bankrupt today because of the governments? No. The financial control is with the Central Bank.” He also alleged that today’s administration has in some way destroyed the creativity of Government officials. It is ridiculous to say that inflation will not be caused by devaluing the Rupee. Devaluing rupee is a proof of inflation, he added.

title: Treasury must release funds for Election – Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that the Election was approved by Parliament, Jathika Jana Balawegaya Leader MP Anura Dissanayake added that if the Treasury Secretary refuses to provide funds for Elections, he faces a three-year jail term. He said President Ranil Wickremesinghe is trying to postpone the Local Government Election and the Government was using various ruses such as power outages and the lack of medicinal drugs as being the reasons to delay Elections. Dissanayake recently told a gathering in Maligawatte that the Government does not want to increase Treasury funds as it would compel the Government to hold an Election. As a result, they continue to deplete Treasury funds to continue staying in power, he said. “The Election costs only Rs 8 billion. The sugar tax scandal alone costs the country Rs 15 million. We could have held two Elections with this money. If you have brought this country to a point where even Elections cannot be held, you must leave,” Dissanayake said. Speaking further Dissanayake said the public wanted thievery to be brought to a halt and that the culprits who stole from the country should be punished. Only the Jathika Jana Balawegaya is capable of fulfilling this wish of the common people, he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: KANCHANA URGES LEGAL ACTION AGAINST PUCSL CHAIR
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera will hand over a letter to President Ranil Wickremesinghe urging him to take legal action against Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Chairman Janaka Ratnayake, if he made an arbitrary decision regarding the Cabinet-approved electricity tariff hike. He said all commissions are subject to the President’s supervision, and that he, as Minister of Power and Energy, will request that the President take legal action against the PUCSL Chairman. He stressed that he hopes Ratnayake will set aside his political agenda in the coming days to avoid further jeopardising the country and putting the public in a precarious position. “The Government is the main victim of the Cabinet-proposed electricity tariff hike because the election is around the corner. Thus, the Government has no hidden agenda in increasing the electricity tariff. Postponing or failing to act on the Cabinet-approved electricity tariff hike will only put the country in a bind,” he said. Further, Wijesekera highlighted that the National Council convened under the patronage of the Speaker, and with the participation of the Prime Minister, political representatives, and relevant institutions. He said only at that meeting did they realise that the PUCSL’s statements were made by one person and not by the Commission as a whole. “There are four members in the Commission and three of them have informed that the Cabinet decision on electricity tariff hike should be implemented as soon as possible. Therefore, we anticipate receiving written approval for the electricity tariff hike on Monday (23). We noticed that the PUCSL Chairman was speaking arbitrarily without seeking input from other members,” he added. By Thameenah Razeek
