title: Reduce electricity use
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) urged public institutions, private institutions, and electricity consumers to reduce electricity consumption during the GCE Advanced Level Examination. They said reducing electricity consumption could be accomplished by not using air conditioners and other methods, particularly during peak hours. During the examination period, the Commission hoped all parties will cooperate in managing electricity demand and enabling the necessary electricity supply. In a statement issued yesterday, the Commission said they expect the Government and the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to work together to implement the Commission’s proposal by assisting the examination department so that students sitting the examination could do so with ease.  “The Commissioner General of Examinations informed the PUCSL that candidates will be inconvenienced by power cuts during the examination schedule and at night. In response, the PUCSL advised the CEB to avoid power cuts to enable the Advanced Level Examination to be held successfully. The CEB has informed the Commission that it has implemented the recommendations,” they stated. The statement went on to say that it is the responsibility of both the Government and the CEB to coordinate and permit the examination to be held without a hassle since approximately 350,000 students were sitting the examination. “It is the CEB’s responsibility to work with relevant parties to provide electricity for the successful and trouble-free conduct of the high-level entrance examination, which is of national importance and determines the future of the country’s next generation,” it said.

title: India first to support IMF assistance for SL
author: Author not found
Content: On Monday, India became the first country to hand over its letter of support for financing and debt restructuring of Sri Lanka to the International Monetary Fund in a sign of its continued support for the island nation’s economic recovery. In 2022, India provided USD 4.5 billion in assistance to Colombo to tide over its dire economic situation. While China is expected to hand over its letter of support to the IMF on Sunday, New Delhi handed over its support letter to IMF on 16 January, four days before External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar landed in Colombo to meet Sri Lanka’s political leadership on 20 January. During his meetings with Sri Lankan leaders including President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Jaishankar made it clear that India stands with its neighbour at a time of need and is prepared to go the extra mile if the need arises. The minister said his visit to Sri Lanka was a demonstration of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Neighbourhood First Policy. In the letter of support to the IMF, addressed to IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva, India’s Finance Ministry acknowledged Sri Lanka’s deeply unsustainable debt situation, the country’s engagement with creditors to restore debt sustainability, and confirmed its strong support to Colombo’s prospective Extended Fund Facility supported programme. New Delhi has made it clear that it is committed to supporting Sri Lanka with financing/debt relief consistent with restoring that country’s public debt sustainability under the IMF supported programme and ensuring that the programme is fully financed as projected by the Bretton Woods Institution. The Modi Government has conveyed that this financing/debt relief will be provided by the Export Import Bank of India. Despite the fact that Sri Lanka’s economic crisis is partly due to white elephant infrastructure port and airport projects financed by high interest loans from Chinese banks, India has come out first in supporting Colombo, which is battling both economic and political turmoil. In its letter to the IMF, India has conveyed that it is committed to continuing negotiations with the Sri Lankan Government along with the Paris Club on a medium- to long-term debt restructuring through maturity extension and interest rate reduction or any other financial instrument that can deliver similar debt relief. The financing-cum-debt relief provided by Exim Bank of India will be consistent with restoring debt sustainability under the IMF supported programme. The Modi Government has been told that the IMF’s debt sustainability assessment will be underpinned by programme targets of reducing the ratio of Sri Lankan public debt to GDP to below 95 per cent by 2032 (from 130 per cent in 2022), the central government’s annual gross financing needs below 13 per cent of GDP on average in 2027-2032 period, and the Sri Lankan Government’s annual foreign currency debt service below 4.5 per cent of GDP in every year during the above time frame. The other target is to close the external financing gap of the island nation. India has made it clear to IMF that Sri Lankan authorities are expected to seek equitable debt treatment from all commercial creditors as well as official bilateral creditors, apart from adequate financing contributions from the multilateral development banks. Supporting IMF efforts on the above, India has conveyed its readiness to have in-depth talks with the Sri Lankan Government, IMF and the Paris Club so that debt relief and finances are finalised for the beleaguered island nation in coming weeks. (The Hindustan Times)

title: Special transport plan during A/L exam
author: Author not found
Content: The National Transport Commission (NTC) has issued a special transport plan to facilitate students sitting the G.C.E Advanced Level examination.  NTC Director General Commander (Rtd) Dr. Nilan Miranda told a media briefing yesterday (22) that  the Sisusariya Deepawyaptha service project run by the NTC will come into operation in keeping with the special transport plan. “We have 1,617 buses assigned to the Sisusariya Deepawyaptha service project. We informed the Road Passenger Transport Authority Director General and Chairman of the Sri Lanka Transport Board that even if there is one student who requires transportation, please continue the transport service,” he added.  Miranda further assured bus owners and drivers that NTC will make sure that relief payment to buses that operate will be paid to ensure that examiners and parents of students sitting the examination will be provided transport. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Uni academics will not participate in GCE A/L evaluation process – FUTA
author: Author not found
Content: The Federation of University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA) informed that university academics will not participate in the GCE Advanced Level Examination evaluation process this year, in a bid to convey a clear and unequivocal message to the Government to stop the destruction of this country through the proposed ‘pernicious taxation’. In a statement, FUTA cited that they were forced to make this decision because the regime is unwilling to negotiate with us or address their demands; this means that the Government should bear full responsibility for any repercussions that may arise.  “Our decision to boycott the GCE (AL) evaluation was not made lightly, but it shows how far we are willing to go to defend our rights and ensure that the country is on the right path to recovery. In doing so, we are not only safeguarding our economic rights and livelihoods, but also protecting the future of our students, who stand to be adversely affected by a sudden change in the evaluation process,” they said. Speaking further FUTA said therefore, they have instructed its members to withdraw their participation in the GCE Advanced Level 2023 Evaluation Process.  “While we are aware that this choice may raise serious concerns in the public, we are confident that the Government will be forced to see the light as a result of our awareness-raising and public agitation on the iniquitous and catastrophic tax law, revoking its worst provisions and revising on the basis of enlightened principles, so that we may take part in the examination and evaluation process without interruption. Moreover, even if the evaluation process were to be delayed, we are aware that no new students will be admitted to the state university system at present due to an acute lack of funding. Consequently, at this crucial juncture it is crucial that we keep up the fight for fair living standards for the populace and sufficient funding for our educational system,” he said.

title: Nematode infestation affects 11,000 acres of paddy
author: Author not found
Content: According to the Lunugamwehera Farmer Organisations, the Bathalagoda Research Institute has informed them that nematode infestation has affected approximately 11,000 of the 25,000 acres cultivated under the Lunugamwehera project. They stressed that they were advised to abandon the crop because they were unable to save it from nematode infestation. After informing the research institute in Bathalegoda, the Kiridiwela Joint Farmers Organisation Chairman, S. Jaliagoda said a delegation came to Bathalegoda to inspect the fields advised them because the paddy crop that had not been harvested for two months on the left bank of  Lunugamwehera was being destroyed by the infestation. According to Samitha Chaturanga, President of the Farmers’ Organization,of the 25,000 acres of paddy, 11,000 acres was infected and that the disease had the potential to spread to the remaining 25,000 acres by the next season. The farmers claimed that organic fertiliser and organic liquid fertiliser distributed last season were of poor quality, and that the salinity of the paddy fields had increased, creating an ideal environment for nematodes. They also claimed that farmers who did not use the government-supplied organic fertiliser and liquid fertilizer escaped the nematode infestation. BY Amila Sampath Sri – Tissamaharama

title: 2022 GCE A/L exam starts today
author: Author not found
Content: The 2022 G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination will begin today (23) and will last 22 days, ending on 17 February. Commissioner General of Examinations Amith Jasundara said the total number of applicants for the examination is 331,709, with 53,513 applying privately. He highlighted that there are 2,200 examination centres throughout the country, as well as 317 coordinating examination centres. Apart from these examination centres, there is one at the Magazine Prison, one in Ratmalana, one in Tangalle for the differently-abled, and another at Apeksha Hospital Maharagama. He said security to conduct the examination has been discussed with the Defence Ministry and the Three Forces. Jasundara said security for the examination including transportation of examination papers will be carried out under strict security. He had requested the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and Lanka Electricity Co. (Pvt) Ltd. (LECO) to provide uninterrupted power supply during the examination period. “We received a positive response in this regard. We believe there will be a continuous power supply from 23 January to 17 January,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Kurunegala Mayor removed
author: Author not found
Content: Kurunegala Mayor Thushara Sanjeewa Vitharana has been removed from his post through an Extraordinary Gazette Notification, due to his inability to pass the budget of the Municipal Council. The relevant Gazette was issued by the Governor of the North Western Province. The Gazette notification cited that the removal was done by  virtue of powers vested under Section 326 (1) of Municipal Council Ordinance Chapter 252 to be read with Section 2 of Provincial Council (Incidental Provisions) Act, No. 12 of 1989, in the North Western Province 21 January, 2023. Governor of North Western Province Admiral of the Fleet Wasantha Karannagoda ordered that the powers, activities, execution of performance of the position of the Mayor shall be entrusted to the Deputy Mayor since the post of Mayor of Kurunegala Municipal Council is vacant, in terms of Section 14 (6) of the Municipal Council Ordinance, Chapter 252 as per the Local Government Election (Amendment) Act, No. 22 of 2012 with effect from 31 December 2022. He said until the vacancy is filled, as the budget document for the year 2023 has not been passed at the Council which was presented by the Mayor of the Municipal Council Kurunegala belonging to the North Western Province in terms of Section 215(a) of the Municipal Council Ordinance Act, 252, as amended by Section 7 of the Local Authorities (Special Provisions) Act, No. 21 of 2012 and/or since the budget had not been compiled or enforced in terms of Municipal Budget Compilation and Enforcement Orders 2020 published by the Governor in the North Western Province by the Extraordinary Gazette No. 2199/15 of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka and dated 29 October 2020.

title: Bus driver remanded till 1 Feb
author: Author not found
Content: The 62-year-old driver of the bus involved in the Nanu Oya fatal accident who was arrested by Police was remanded until 1 February by the Nuwara Eliya Magistrate, Police said. Seven died following a fatal collision involving the bus, a van and a three-wheeler, which occurred on the Nuwara Eliya-Thalawakele Road, on Saturday (21). Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said the bus had toppled down a precipice of about 45 metres following the accident. The bus which was en route to Colombo had been transporting a group of students of Thurstan College Colombo who were on an educational trip to Nuwara Eliya. At least 41 students, three teachers and three parents were inside the bus at the time of the accident. SSP Thalduwa said 53 injured persons are currently receiving treatment at the Nuwara Eliya Hospital while seven had died. The driver of the three-wheeler and six passengers of the van were among the dead. The deceased were identified as 8, 12, 13, 26, 26 and 27-year-old residents of Nanu Oya. Nanu Oya Police are conducting investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Garments, SL’s top export earner after 14 years
author: Author not found
Content: Remittances, hit by an overvalued rupee, for the first time after 14 years fell from its pedestal position of being Sri Lanka’s (SL’s) number one foreign exchange (FX) earner, last year (2022), unseated by garments, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data from Friday (22 January) showed. While remittances earnings last year fell by 31 per cent year-on-year (YoY) to USD 3,789.5 million, on the other hand garments exports, Sri Lanka’s second largest FX earner after remittances for 14 years, from 2009 to 2021, saw exports, in the first 11 months of last year alone increase… by 11.6 per cent YoY to USD 5,470.5 million, easily unseating remittances, to become Sri Lanka’s top FX earner last year. Further, garment export earnings of USD 5,470.5 million in the first 11 months of last year, compared to remittances earnings of USD 3,789.5 million for the totality of last year, is an increase of 30.73 per cent (USD 1,681 million), CBSL’s latest data showed, thereby becoming Sri Lanka’s top FX source last year. Meanwhile, Sri Lanka’s last month’s (December 2022) merchandise export statistics, including garments exports, has not been released by CBSL as yet. However, once such data is released, that will boost Sri Lanka’s garments earnings for the totality of last year further. Prior to last year, garments exports were Sri Lanka’s top FX earner for 23 consecutive years from 1986 to 2008, before being unseated by remittances in 2009, impacted by Sri Lanka losing its GSP+ duty free facility in its exports to the EU for alleged war crimes in its war against the LTTE. GSP+ was however restored in 2017. The EU, after the USA, is Sri Lanka’s second largest export market led by garments, Sri Lanka’s top merchandise export. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Kerawalapitiya Plant will operate on requirement
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) Additional General Manager (Generation) Dhammika N. Navaratne said the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation has increased Naphtha prices from Rs 164 per litre to Rs 220 per litre from 11 January midnight.   However, he said depending on the system requirement, Kerawalapitiya Combined Cycle Power Plant (KCCP) will operate in the coming week. “There is Naptha for today in CEB tanks and further there is Naphtha in the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation tanks for today and tomorrow. Naphtha will be available when required. However, KCCP was stopped because Lakvijaya unit 1 was made available,” he said.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Bangladesh Envoy meets Commander Northern Naval Area
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commissioner of Bangladesh to Sri Lanka, Tareq Md Ariful Islam met the Commander Northern Naval Area, Rear Admiral Aruna Tennekoon at the Command Headquarters recently. During this discussion, they exchanged views on several matters of bilateral importance. Defence Adviser at the Bangladesh High Commission in Colombo, Commodore Md Shafiul Bari was also present. The discussions drew to a close with an exchange of mementos, symbolising goodwill and cooperation.

title: Ratnapura war veteran’s family gets house through ‘Api Wenuwen Api’ project
author: Author not found
Content: A new house constructed utilising the Defence Ministry’s ‘Api Wenuwen Api’ funds was vested in a war veteran’s family recently during a brief ceremony in Alupola, Wewalwatta in Ratnapura. The Defence Secretary was the chief guest at the event. The family of Lance Corporal W Dharmarathna, a war hero who sacrificed his life for his motherland received financial aid from the ‘Api Wenuwen Api’ fund and labour assistance from the Sri Lanka Army’s 4 Engineer Service Regiment troop to complete the partially built house. The Defence Secretary symbolically handed over the keys of the house to Lance Corporal Dharmarathna’s wife, A. P. Chamila and son Thimira Nimesh Daluwaththa amidst religious observances  by the Maha Sangha. Lance Corporal Dharmarathna of 6 Sri Lanka National Guard had succumbed to injuries following a terrorist attack at Vavuniya Kovil Puliyankulam in 2001. The dream of completing the partially-built house of the family became a reality under the ‘Api Wenuwen Api’ fund. Tri Forces members and families are given complete and partial grants under the ‘Api Wenuwen Api’ initiative to construct their houses or to complete partially built houses while the labour support is provided by the military. The Maha Sangha, Defence Ministry Additional Secretary – Administration Gamini Mahagamage, Deputy Chief of Staff Maj. Gen. Senarath Yapa, Military Liaison Officer of the Defence Ministry Maj. Gen. Dinesh Nanayakkara, Centre Commandants of Army’s Gamunu Regiment and Sri Lanka National Guard, Defence Ministry’s Senior Assistant Secretary – Administration, senior military officers and family members of the beneficiary were also present at the occasion.

title: FR petition against Cabraal’s appointment dismissed
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights (FR) petition filed against the appointment of Ajith Nivard Cabraal, as the former Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), was dismissed by the Supreme Court on Thursday. This was when the Petition was taken before Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya and Supreme Court Justices Yasantha Kodagoda and Mahinda Samayawardena. The petition was filed by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) General Secretary Ranjith Maddumabandara. The case was dismissed on the basis that the lawyer appearing on behalf of the Petitioner requested to withdraw the petition. Former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, Former Minister of Finance Basil Rajapaksa the Central Bank Monetary Board, and Former Secretary to the President Dr. P.B. Jayasundara were named as respondents to the Petition. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: UAE to take stern action against scammers
author: Author not found
Content: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) Human Resources Minister Dr. Abdulrahman Abdulmannan Al Awar assured Labour and Foreign Employment Minister Manusha Nanayakkara that his country will take stern action against those who bring foreign workers into the country through illegal means. Nanayakkara said the UAE has decided to take stern action against those who facilitate illegal immigration into their country. The decision was announced during Nanayakkara’s official visit to the UAE. Nanayakkara explained to the UAE Minister about difficulties faced by Sri Lankans who come in search of jobs to UAE on visit visas as a result of various scams by individuals and organised groups. He also explained that efforts are taken to make the public aware of the perils of seeking foreign employment opportunities through a visit visa. The UAE Minister responded positively to the request made by Nanayakkara to provide more job opportunities in UAE for skilled workers from Sri Lanka. The joint technical committee that was set up in 2021 between the two countries will continue to discuss technical details on how to prevent human trafficking through visit visas to the UAE. He said a programme will be implemented by mapping the qualification framework of the two countries that will recognise the qualifications of Sri Lankan migrant workers. Minister Nanayakkara explained that 35,572 Sri Lankan workers obtained employment opportunities through the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment last year which accounts for 11.4% of the total departures in Sri Lanka. This is a 27 per cent increase in 2022 compared to 2021. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Power cuts to continue during A/L Exam
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) has informed the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) that power cuts will have to be imposed even during the 2022 G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination, scheduled to begin today (23). This statement was made in response to PUCSL’s announcement in which they assured that no power interruptions will be imposed after 7:00 p.m. during the 2022 G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination. CEB said such relief cannot be provided amid the ongoing crisis, owing to the high costs incurred for electricity generation, and the lack of funds. Meanwhile, PUCSL has approved a two-hour and 20-minute power cut for today (23). Thus, power will be cut for one hour during the day and one hour and 20 minutes at night for Groups A-L and Groups P-W. The power cut schedule is being announced in response to PUCSL’s decision not to impose power cuts after 7:00 p.m. during the 2022 G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination, as requested by the Department of Examinations. The CEB later informed PUCSL that such an agreement could not be reached due to the high costs of electricity generation and a lack of funds. In light of this, they said power cuts will have to be imposed even during the examination period.

title: Burkina Faso demands departure of French troops
author: Author not found
Content: Burkina Faso’s military government has ordered French troops stationed in the West African country to leave within a month. The decision, announced by the official Agence d’Information du Burkina (AIB) on Saturday, is the latest sign of deteriorating relations between France and its former colony since a second military coup in September of last year. The AIB said the military government on Wednesday suspended a 2018 military accord that allowed the presence of French troops in the country. There was no immediate comment from Paris. A source close to the Burkinabe military told the AFP news agency that Ouagadougou was not severing relations with France and that the “notification only concerns military cooperation agreements”. France has some 400 special forces soldiers stationed in Burkina Faso, which is battling groups affiliated with al-Qaeda and ISIL (ISIS). The West African nation is one of the world’s poorest countries and the conflict there, which had spread across the Sahel from Mali over the past decade, has killed thousands of civilians.

title: Booker Prize winner in town
author: Author not found
Content: Booker prize winner, Shehan Karunatilaka, will be reading extracts from his award winning novel The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida together with Ashok Ferrey at the British Council, Colombo on Saturday (28 January), the British Council tweeted.

title: PRESIDENT INSTRUCTS TO IMPLEMENT YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
author: Author not found
Content: In conjunction with the 75th Independence Day, under the theme, ‘National Youth Platform’, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has instructed to implement a youth-led development project, covering the entire island, to make Sri Lanka a developed country by the 100th Independence Celebration (2048) through youth ideas, skills and interventions. A discussion regarding this programme was held at the Presidential Secretariat under the patronage of the President. During this discussion, the plans related to the development of the major cities in each district, as tourist cities, formulated by the lecturers and students of all the universities, were presented to the President. Accordingly, the Jaffna and Vavuniya University, focusing on the Jaffna District and the Kelaniya University and Rajarata University presented tourism plans related to the Anuradhapura District. The Ruhuna University, Sabaragamuwa University and Sir John Kotelawala Defence University jointly submitted plans for the Galle Districts and the Colombo University, Sri Jayawardenepura University, University of Fine Arts and the Moratuwa University jointly submitted their plans for the Colombo District. Peradeniya, Wayamba and Uva Wellassa Universities jointly presented the plans related to the Kandy District while the Eastern and South Eastern Universities presented the plans for the Batticaloa District. Expressing his appreciation for all the plans that were submitted, the President said that private-sector financial assistance could also be sought to support this programme. Pointing out that it is a very good trend for the university community to contribute to the development of the country, Wickremesinghe appreciated the university community’s involvement in these projects and commended their contribution. Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, Chairman of the University Grants Commission Dr Sampath Amaratunga, Secretary to the Ministry of Finance Mahinda Siriwardena, University Vice Chancellors and officers of line institutions joined this discussion through online technology.

title: Work in unison for country’s future – – Abeywardena
author: Author not found
Content: UNP MP Vajira Abeywardena said yesterday (22) that the time has come for everyone who loves the country to band together and work in unison for the sake of the country’s future, rather than seeking personal political mileage. He said that the stigma associated with Sri Lanka in the international arena was gradually dissipating, including friendly nations looking positively and beginning to extend a helping hand to resolve the country’s current economic crisis. While expressing confidence that all issues, including the current economic crisis, can be resolved through national policy, Abeywardena stated that now was not the time to stir in troubled waters. He said that UNP has submitted nomination papers to contest nine local government bodies in the Galle District excluding the Elpitiya Pradeshiya Sabha. Abeywardena also claimed that wrong economic policies had caused total collapse and the Government led by President Ranil Wickremesinghe has been vested with the responsibility of fixing it and putting the economy back on track. “The economic crisis and every other issue must be fixed or resolved. If the country is to be brought on top, the Sinhalese, Tamils and Muslims in this country must unite and work under a common agenda,” Abeywardena added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: PS chair, driver to stay in remand
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis further remanded, till 31 January, Mawanellla Pradeshiya Sabha (PS) Chairman Samantha Steven and his driver, who have been charged with seeking a bribe of two million rupees. The driver was identified as Hasitha Thillakaratne. The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) informed Chief Magistrate Alwis that their sleuths had apprehended the two suspects on 13 January, when they had solicited the said bribe, based on a complaint lodged with them. Upon being arrested the two suspects, were produced before the Mawanella Chief Magistrate’s Court and were ordered to be remanded till yesterday. The CIABOC produced the two suspects before the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court yesterday. The prosecution informed the Court, that the two suspects had demanded the aforementioned bribe from a complainant, to approve parts of a building construction within the Mawanella town. They added that the suspects had been nabbed, while they were about to receive the bribe, at the top floor of the Seetha Restaurant in the town. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Parliament to be prorogued soon
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe will prorogue Parliament within the next couple of days, a highly placed Government source said. Accordingly, the Third Session of the Ninth Parliament will end by next week. The Gazette Notification in this regard will also be issued early next week. Meanwhile, the Fourth Session of the Ninth Parliament will commence on 1 February.

title: India’s FM visits SL denoting stronger ties
author: Author not found
Content: India’s Foreign Minister arrived in Colombo yesterday (19) following his country’s backing of Sri Lanka for a USD 2.9 billion International Monetary Fund (IMF) loan, leaving China as the island’s last remaining major creditor, which has yet to agree to the debt restructuring plan. India has told global lender IMF that it strongly supports Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring plan, with Colombo owing around USD 1 billion to its nearest neighbour. But Sri Lanka requires the backing of both China and India – its biggest bilateral lenders – to reach a final agreement with the IMF on the loan that is essential to help the country of nearly 22 million people emerge from its worst financial crisis in seven decades. During his two-day visit, his third to Sri Lanka since 2021 Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar will look to strengthen India’s ties with its debt-ridden neighbour and sign several key deals. The two countries are also expected to sign a Memorandum of Understanding for a renewable power project covering three islands in Sri Lanka’s north during Jaishankar’s visit, two sources at Sri Lanka’s power and energy ministry said. The project stoked controversy last year as it was initially awarded to a Chinese company before India stepped in to secure it. Jaishankar will meet Sri Lanka’s president this morning (20). He will also hold discussions with Sri Lanka’s Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, according to a statement from India’s Foreign Ministry. (Reuters)

title: All religions should adapt to modern world – President
author: Author not found
Content: All religions should guide their respective communities to modernity and adapt to the modern world, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said yesterday (19). Addressing the All Ceylon Jamiyyathul Ulama (ACJU) Centenary celebrations, the President invited the Muslim Community to join hands with the Social Justice Commission to find solutions to the issues faced by the Muslim Community. He urged all communities to unite as true Sri Lankans as the country celebrates its 75th Anniversary of Independence this year. Wickremesinghe emphasised that despite the various religions having different beliefs, no religion promotes hatred. He pointed out that the past 75 years was spent with the various communities fighting each other and appealed to all Sri Lankans to cast aside all differences and unite as citizens of one Sri Lanka as the country celebrates its 75th Anniversary of Independence.  “We are facing our 75th year after most of our time has been spent fighting each other. I think now is the time for reconciliation, and coexistence. And, so we have now started by talking to the Tamils, the Sri Lankan Tamils, to look at what their issues are and how we can move towards reconciliation. The first step has been taken and we are meeting the party leaders again. We have made a lot of progress in the discussions.” Speaking further, the President noted that he want to have a discussion with the Muslim community about the problems they face. “What are the issues you (Muslim community) have gone through? A good example is the Digana riots in 2018. We have to talk about it and we have to talk about Easter Sunday attacks in 2019 as well. All those incidents are needed to be discussed and we have to talk about who and what created those situations. The issues that the Muslims in Colombo face are quite different from the issues that are faced by Muslims in the southeast of Sri Lanka, or the Mannar Muslims. So let us discuss those. There are so many issues. I think it is time for a genuine discussion,” he added. A commemorative stamp which was issued for the 100th anniversary of the ACJU was presented to the President along with a memento. Religious dignitaries, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, Former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga, High Commissioners and Ambassadors, The President’s Chief of Staff and Senior Advisor to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake, Honorable Members of Parliament, Secretary of Ministry of Defence General Kamal Gunaratne (Retd), Chief of Defence Staff General Shavendra Silva and many other Opposition and ruling party politicians were present at the occasion. Pic By Venura Chandramalitha BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Minor staff surrounds Dr Bellana’s office
author: Author not found
Content: A highly charged situation arose outside the National Hospital, when minor employees, who had allegedly taken umbrage over comments made by Deputy Director, Dr. Rukshan Bellana, surrounded his office demanding his removal. They accused Dr. Bellana, who is also the President of the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF), of repeatedly accusing the Colombo NHSL minor employees of being addicted to marijuana and dangerous substances such as ice, claiming that they had even resorted to steal from patients coming to the hospital for treatment. The protesters had surrounded his office area, while some had surged into the hospital and the corridor outside his office, chanting slogans and surrounding it forcing him to remain within. Protesters demanded that disciplinary action be taken against the GMOF President. Minor employees alleged that Dr. Bellana was unable to fulfil his duty, as an administrator, to find solutions to the issue rather than going around giving voice cuts to the media and antagonise the staff.  However Dr. Bellana, when contacted, said that attendants had been offended by his revelation and that disciplinary action should be taken against them. Meanwhile, President of the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP), Ravi Kumudesh said that action should be taken to introduce a globally accepted method of testing for 16 types of dangerous substances. “We have written to the President, the Health Minister and the Minister of Law and Order requesting that like the breath analyser tests, this particular method of testing the urine for dangerous substances, be also introduced. It helps identify even the extent of the period during which the substance abuse has been taking place. This situation does not just prevail at the National Hospital and the Health Ministry but is there in every walk of life and it should be addressed with care, he said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Pavithra, Thondaman promoted as Ministers
author: Author not found
Content: MPs Pavithra Wanniarachchi and Jeevan Thondaman were sworn in as Cabinet Ministers, before President Ranil Wickremesinghe, at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (19). Wanniarachchi took oath as the Cabinet Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation while Thondaman took oath as the Minister of the Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development. Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake was also present at the occasion. Also, several new Cabinet appointments would be made in the coming days and MPs Wajira Abeywardena and Duminda Dissanayake will most likely receive portfolios. Ceylon Today learns that apart from Abeywardena and Dissanayake, eight MPs from the SLPP will also be given ministerial portfolios. Accordingly, new ministers would be appointed to Ports, Highways, Sports, Transport, Power, Mass Media, Investment Promotions and Industries. Also, several ministers would be removed from the Cabinet. Meanwhile, Mahinda Amaraweera stepped down as the Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation on the same day. While Amaraweera held both portfolios of Minister of Agriculture and Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, he noted that there is no need for one Minister to hold two Ministerial portfolios. He added that the Minister of Agriculture portfolio in itself covers a wide area and that he would continue in such portfolio. In a letter to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Amaraweera informed of his resignation and stated this step was taken to pave way for the appointment of new Ministers if required. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: CID probes death threats to Polls Commissioners
author: Author not found
Content: The CID has commenced an investigation into death threats received by two members of the Election Commission (EC), Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena informed Parliament yesterday (19). Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa alleged that two members of the Election Commission had received death threats over the Local Government Elections. He said the two commissioners have lodged a complaint with the Police in this regard. Speaking during the debate on the Regulation of Election Expenditure Bill in Parliament yesterday (19), Premadasa said debates on elections are being held in this kind of an environment. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena later informed Parliament that the Police had launched investigations into the complaint on the same night. Gunawardena noted that Police protection is being provided to the two commissioners who received death threats. He requested the MPs to not support such absurd acts and added that double standards should be rejected. Meanwhile, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said EC Members K.P.P. Pathirana and S.B. Divaratne have lodged complaints at two Police stations over the threats. According to the complaints, a person introducing himself as a ‘leader of the military wing of the Aragalaya’ threatened them demanding not to hold the LG election and to resign from their posts. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi and Mithun Jayawardena

title: EXTREMELY DIFFICULT TO FUND ELECTION
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, Mahinda Siriwardana, informed the Supreme Court that the Treasury will find it extremely challenging to find additional resources for an election, as only Rs 18 billion per month is left for Government expenses. The Secretary, in an affidavit submitted in connection with the Petition filed by Colonel (Retired), W.M.R. Wijesundara, seeking an order suspending the holding of the Local Government Elections in March 2023, said in 2022, average monthly expenditure on salaries, based on the Government cashflow, was around Rs 90 billion, monthly pensions and Samurdhi payments amounted to around Rs 28 billion and other recurrent expenditure, including medical supplies, fertiliser and others amounted to Rs 28 billion, totalling to Rs 145 billion per month. Compared to this, monthly Government revenue was Rs 163 billion based on the 2022 cashflow, he said adding that thereby on average, only Rs 18 billion per month was left from the revenue collection for all the expenses of the government. It was noted that there was other expenditure, including interest payments of around Rs 114 billion, capital expenditure of around Rs 31 billion and debt repayments of around Rs 169 billion per month in 2022. Consequently, there was an average cash deficit of aroundRs 296 billion per month. He added that since the country has been locked out of global capital markets since early 2020, the Government was unable to obtain foreign financing from the international markets to finance the cash deficit. It was also stated that it is only after IMF approves Sri Lanka’s contemplated EFF programme that the country will be able to access even limited foreign financing, adding that in the absence of foreign financing for the budget, the Government must manage its expenditure obligation through available tax and non-tax revenue and market borrowings which are very limited and expensive. Siriwardana noted that in such backdrop, expenditure for an election would add further pressure on an already stressed public finance system and noted that the Government is in the process of implementing a range of critical economic reforms, adding that if such move is disrupted at this stage, it could result in potentially disastrous consequences for the economic and social fabric of the country. He said long standing issues in the fiscal sector have been key factors behind the economic crisis adding that foreign financing options as well as domestic financing channels have also been exhausted. It was further noted that extreme care is necessary in deciding on the priority areas of expenditure, given the critical cashflow position and the need for managing mandatory and essential expenditure. It was also stated that any slippage would add to the already stressed fiscal position and would in turn burden the public. Siriwardana observed that the Government’s daily cashflow management has become extremely challenging in 2023 as well and even the regular payment of the public sector salaries on time has been challenging. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Veteran filmmaker Sumithra Peries passes away
author: Author not found
Content: Veteran film producer, director Dr. Sumitra Peries passed away at the age of  88 years yesterday (19) morning, while receiving treatment at a private hospital in Colombo. Dr. Peries began her career as an assistant director and an editor, having extensively studied cinema in Europe. She went on to becomeSri Lanka’s first female filmmaker as well as a key figure in bringing women’s stories to Sri Lankan Cinema, with a career spanning over 10 films, contributing as a director, filmmaker and screenwriter. Some of her best known works are Gehenu Lamai, Ganga Addara and Yahaluvo. Dr. Peries was born Sumitra Gunawardena on 24 March 1935, in the village of Payagala and later raised in her paternal hometown, Avissawella. Sumitra also served as Sri Lanka’s ambassador to France and Spain from 1996 to 1999 and was later appointed as the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the United Nations by Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunge during her presidency. The Late Lester James Peries who was considered as the father of Sri Lankan cinema was her husband.

title: Bathiudeen’s appeal fixed for support
author: Author not found
Content: The appeal filed by MP Rishad Bathiudeen, against the Court of Appeal Order directing him to bear the entire cost to carry out a tree planting programme at the Wilpattu Forest Reserve, was fixed for support on 17 March by the Supreme Court yesterday (19). This was when the appeal was taken before Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya and Supreme Court Justices Yasantha Kodagoda and Mahinda Samayawardena. In September 2022, Supreme Court Justice Arjuna Obeysekera declined to hear the appeal filed by Bathiudeen and it was thereby re-fixed for support yesterday (19), by a Bench excluding Justice Obeysekera. The appeal was so filed by Bathiudeen in connection with the decision of the Court of Appeal, pertaining to the case filed by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ), against the illegal clearing of forest land in the Wilpattu Forest Reserve area. When the case filed by CEJ was taken up, the Court ordered the Conservator General of the Forest Conservation Department to take steps to implement a tree planting programme in the forest reserve area and any area similar to the reserve, if illegal clearing had been done. Further, the Court issued an order for Bathiudeen to bear the entire cost of the tree planting programme and directed the Conservator General of Forests to calculate the cost of the tree planting programme. Bathiudeen later submitted an appeal to the Supreme Court, against the said decision of the Court of Appeal and when the appeal was initially taken up, the Court emphasised that the hearing of the appeal does not stand in the way of the execution of the Appellate Court order. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Election of Jaffna Mayor put off
author: Author not found
Content: The vote scheduled for yesterday (19), at the Jaffna Municipal Council, to elect an Interim Mayor, was postponed due to a lack of quorum. Some members MC accused the Local Government Commissioner of postponing the election. The 20 members of the MC stated that they will take legal action against the Local Government Commissioner for postponing the election. They have accused the Northern Province Local Government Commissioner of acting unfairly in the selection of the Interim Mayor for the Municipal Council. The meeting for the election of the Interim Mayor was held yesterday at 10.00 a.m. but was cancelled due to a lack of quorum. The 20 members, who participated in the meeting, have sent a letter to the Northern Province Local Government Commissioner, claiming that the postponement was improper.  In the letter, they stated that under section 66(a) of the Local Authorities Elections (Amendment) Act No. 22 of 2012, they express their objection to the improper postponement of the Jaffna Municipal Council Mayoral election and the meeting convened by them as per the letter dated 9 January. By the time the meeting started, there were 24 people present. They said “since 24 members were present for the meeting, it should have been held as there was a quorum.  They said after Emmanuel Arnold’s name was proposed for the post of mayor, in the absence of any other proposals,  Arnold was chosen as the Mayor. At this point, four members of the council walked out, objecting to the proposal. “At that time, against the legal provisions, you announced that you were adjourning the meeting. An objection was immediately registered by us in the council as an unfair notification. However, ignoring our request, you adjourned the meeting and left the council hall,” they said in the letter. They further said that although the required quorum was present at the time of commencement of the meeting, as there was no other proposal for election, and no member raised any objection over the absence of quorum due to the withdrawal of four members, they had considered it appropriate to unanimously declare Emmanuel, as the Speaker of the Council as proposed. But after informing the official, he failed to rectify his mistake in this regard, and thereby they would be forced to take legal action, they said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Complaint to be filed with CID over fake liquor stickers
author: Author not found
Content: A complaint will be filed with the CID over forged labels being pasted on bottles of liquor, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. Siyambalapitiya said he received the initial report, of the Commissioner General of Excise, regarding the forged labels pasted on the bottles and legal actions would be taken accordingly. Speaking to the Media yesterday (19), at the Ministry of Finance, Siyambalapitiya said that they have decided to check some of the labels, attached to the bottles, to see if the digital indication on those labels has been done properly. Also, a report would be called for of a forensic test from a related foreign institution within a week. In addition to this, a specific inspection team is being deployed in the Excise Department to regularly check on the proper functioning of this sticker and the receipt of proper income, he added. “We believe that it will be rectified soon and government revenue will be properly collected and on the other hand, the customer will be protected,” he further said. (AK)

title: SC extends Order preventing acceptance of nominations for Kalmunai MC
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (19) extended the interim injunction prohibiting the acceptance of nominations for the Kalmunai Municipal Council, at the upcoming Local Government (LG) Election, until the final determination of the Petition filed in this connection. This was when the Fundamental Rights Petition, filed against accepting nominations for the Kalmunai Municipal Council, for the LG Election, was taken up before Supreme Court Justices Vijith Malalgoda, Yasantha Kodagoda and Mahinda Samayawardena. While an interim injunction, prohibiting accepting of nominations for the Kalmunai Municipal Council until yesterday (19), was issued on Tuesday (17), it was extended until the final determination of the Petition. The petitioner noted that excluding Sainthamaruthu from the Gazette notification, issued calling for nominations for the LG Election and including it under the Kalmunai Municipal Council, violates the fundamental rights of people guaranteed by the Constitution. Court also ordered to re-issue notice to the respondents, including the Chairman of the Election Commission and its members. Further hearing of the case was fixed for 24 March. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: X-Press Pearl disaster doubled air pollution – NBRO
author: Author not found
Content: Air pollution increased two-fold due to the X-Press Pearl disaster, State-owned National Business Research Organisation (NBRO) said on Tuesday (17). NBRO, in its 2021 Annual Report, uploaded to the Parliament website on Tuesday, said that air quality dispersion model software was run to assess the ground level concentration of pollutants generated by the fire. “This modelling indicated that the contribution made by the X-Press Pearl fire increased the ambient pollutant levels resulting in the release of a total of between 8,000 to 13,000 metric tons of air pollutants to the atmosphere, depending on the amount of burnt mass caused, due to this incident. However, when the X-Press Pearl Disaster struck, Sri Lanka was in a Covid-19 lockdown scenario, said NBRO. As such the predicted levels of air pollution were well within the standard levels of pollution, since the ambient air pollutant levels during those days were very low due to the Covid-19 lockdown scenario, it added. Referring further to the X-Press Pearl disaster, NBRO, in their 2021 Annual Report, said that it conducted a comprehensive study on air quality in affected areas. “Once a ship is on fire, most of the chemicals and other materials stored in the vessel decompose and release smoke containing chemical vapour to the atmosphere, as ‘criteria air pollutants’ such as Carbon Monoxide are generated due to the combustion products depending on the composition of such materials.  Therefore, these fires may release hazardous pollutants such as dioxins, furans and other organic pollutants, heavy metals, and in addition, greenhouse gases such as Carbon Dioxide to the atmosphere depending on the nature of the burning materials and flame temperature. Released air pollutants then disperse into surrounding areas depending on the metrological conditions,” said NBRO. “As per the observations made during this particular fire, generated air pollutants dispersed as a plume to the inland areas when prevailing wind was from the West and South-West. The results of measurements taken indicated high pollution levels in areas close to the ship whereas significant levels were not recorded in other areas identified earlier as critical. The continuous monitoring data indicated that some peak pollution levels exceeding national standard levels existed only for a few hours with and due to the changing meteorological conditions,” it added. (PA)

title: Parliament to be prorogued soon
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe will prorogue Parliament within the next couple of days, a highly placed Government source said. Accordingly, the Third Session of the Ninth Parliament will end by next week. The Gazette Notification in this regard will also be issued early next week. Meanwhile, the Fourth Session of the Ninth Parliament will commence on 1 February.

title: India’s FM visits SL denoting stronger ties
author: Author not found
Content: India’s Foreign Minister arrived in Colombo yesterday (19) following his country’s backing of Sri Lanka for a USD 2.9 billion International Monetary Fund (IMF) loan, leaving China as the island’s last remaining major creditor, which has yet to agree to the debt restructuring plan. India has told global lender IMF that it strongly supports Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring plan, with Colombo owing around USD 1 billion to its nearest neighbour. But Sri Lanka requires the backing of both China and India – its biggest bilateral lenders – to reach a final agreement with the IMF on the loan that is essential to help the country of nearly 22 million people emerge from its worst financial crisis in seven decades. During his two-day visit, his third to Sri Lanka since 2021 Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar will look to strengthen India’s ties with its debt-ridden neighbour and sign several key deals. The two countries are also expected to sign a Memorandum of Understanding for a renewable power project covering three islands in Sri Lanka’s north during Jaishankar’s visit, two sources at Sri Lanka’s power and energy ministry said. The project stoked controversy last year as it was initially awarded to a Chinese company before India stepped in to secure it. Jaishankar will meet Sri Lanka’s president this morning (20). He will also hold discussions with Sri Lanka’s Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, according to a statement from India’s Foreign Ministry. (Reuters)

title: Free milk powder to 70,000 low-income families
author: Author not found
Content: In support of the government’s ‘National Combined Mechanism for Food Security and Nutrition’, Fonterra will provide free milk powder to 70,000 low-income families. Joining the ‘National Combined Mechanism for Food Security and Nutrition’ programme, set up under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Fonterra Brands Lanka Company has donated milk powder worth Rs174 million to 70,000 low-income families experiencing financial hardship. The donation was made symbolically at the President’s Office on Tuesday (17) with the participation of New Zealand High Commissioner Michael Appleton and a group of New Zealand representatives. Speaking at the occasion, Chairman and Adviser of the Presidential Committee on National Food Security Dr. Suren Batagoda said, “The Vision of the food security programme of the government is to ensure that every citizen has access to nutrition. This initiative is aimed at bridging this gap with the most vulnerable families.” The milk powder was delivered to the 70,000 vulnerable families across the country, identified by the task force and delivered via the District Secretariats. President’s Chief of Staff and the Senior Adviser on National Security Sagala Ratnayake, Vidya Sivaraja – MD SEA & SA, Consumer and Food Service Global Markets, Judith Swales – CEO, Global Markets, General Shavendra Silva – Chief of Defence Staff and several other officials, attended this event.

title: Three including hotel owner arrested for theft
author: Author not found
Content: An owner of a hotel located in Unawatuna was arrested along with his son and the accountant of the hotel, for robbing foreign currency worth six million rupees from a guest who was residing at the hotel recently. The arrest was made by the Unawatuna Tourist Police on 18 January following a complaint by the foreigner.  According to the Police, four persons had robbed USD 10,100, Rubel 195,000 and Euro 200 worth cash from a safety deposit box, which was placed inside the guest’s room. Additionally, the suspects had wiped the CCTV footages from the system. However, Police arrested three suspects with over Rs 1 million.  The arrested suspects were identified as 35-year-old, 37-year-old and 60-year-old residents of Unawatuna and Bogahagoda. Unawatuna Tourist Police are conducting further investigations to arrest the fourth suspect, who had fled the scene. Police said he was identified as the manager of the hotel.  BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi
