title: G.S. Withanage new CAASL Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka (CAASL) G.S. Withanage, has been appointed as the Chairman of the CAASL with immediate effect, succeeding Upul Dharmadasa, a graduate of the University of Certified Travel Agents in Massachusetts, USA, who served as the Chairman for the last three years. Withanage is the eighth Chairman of the CAASL and a past pupil of Ananda College. Former CAASL Chairman Dharmadasa had completed his tenure, but many CAASL officials were of the view that the Aviation Minister did not consult industry stakeholders and CAASL employees about replacing the former Chairman. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: NYC another step in President’s visionary programme for youth – PM
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said that the National Youth Corps (NYC) is one part of a visionary programme implemented by President Ranil Wickremesinghe when he was Prime Minister to create young people with ability and personality. The Prime Minister also said  the programme is aimed at producing national leaders is commendable. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena was addressing the National Youth Corps annual art festival and awards ceremony ‘Paurshabhimana’ held at the BMICH in Colombo on Tuesday (17). Gunawardena further said, “Almost three decades have passed since the formation of the Youth Corps for the future of the nation. The President did a lot of work to provide this space for youth at the time he was Minister of Youth Services”. The Youth Service Council plays a major role in guiding youth who do not pursue a higher university education. “We know that the Youth Corps shoulders a big responsibility in this task. The greatest contribution of the Youth Corps to the country is the unity of youth. Organisations such as the Youth Corps can make the biggest contribution to the challenge of building the country in the future. The Youth Corps has all the facilities to help youth in their potential. This enables us to develop the skills of our youth and create citizens who can take charge of the future,” he said. President’s Chief of Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security, Sagala Ratnayake, said, “When Channa Gunathilaka and I started this work, we did not have a National Youth Corps. The primary responsibility was to take the necessary steps to implement the concept of the President, who was the Prime Minister at the time. Its primary need was to raise a generation of young people with a good personality, skills suitable for the times, able to give good leadership, able to overcome future challenges, ready for the job market, and equipped with positive attitudes.”

title: Don’t use Bill to put off elections – Polls Watchdogs
author: Author not found
Content: The collective of election monitoring organisations expressed several concerns over the Regulation of Election Expenditure Bill and warned it shouldn’t be used to put off scheduled Local Government polls. The Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL), in a statement emphasised that “a law that seeks to regulate election campaign financing should prevent undue influence of donors over candidates, parties and independent groups, create a level playing field for all candidates including new entrants and underrepresented groups and reduce excessive and illegal spending on elections including by means such as the misuse of public funds and vote-buying. “To be effective, the law should also provide for a robust monitoring and enforcement mechanism by both the authorities and citizens.  “However, the Bill that was gazetted on 29 November 2022, is woefully inadequate to serve these purposes. The Bill bans campaign contributions from certain parties such as foreign governments, corporate bodies registered outside Sri Lanka, companies with foreign shareholding and anonymous donors. However, it does not impose any limit on how much funding a candidate, party or independent group can receive from any source, allowing space for undue influence,” the statement said. “Furthermore, the Bill foresees the designation of an authorised amount as the spending limit for a candidate at each election, which amount has not been considered with sufficient detail. It also does not set out an adequate monitoring mechanism. It does not prevent spending by political parties and third parties, on candidates. As such, the proposed spending limit will only defeat the purpose of introducing this law.  “The proposed procedure to enforce spending limits is also inadequate. The Bill only provides that candidates should submit audited accounts to the Election Commission of Sri Lanka (ECSL), who will notify the public of their availability for perusal. An effective law would require maintenance and disclosure of all accounts of candidates, parties or independent groups to the ECSL, and would also make such information digitally accessible to the public, enabling easy scrutiny, and an opportunity to digitally identify irregularities.” While re-emphasising the critical need for election campaign finances regulation in Sri Lanka, the collective of election monitoring organisations called upon the government to close the aforementioned loopholes in the Bill and to engage in a consultative process with the public, without rushing its passage in Parliament. “A weak regulatory system can lead to a further deterioration of people’s trust in politics and the legitimacy of the electoral process, and will not achieve the objectives of introducing such a law,” they said.  The collective further reiterated that the introduction of a campaign financing law should in no instance be used as a reason to delay the holding of the LG election.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Many criminals, including drug abusers and illicit alcohol dealers in the villages, who were earlier involved in SLPP politics, have now become the main JVP activists, Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Thushara Indunil Amarasena alleged.  Addressing the media, Amarasena said, this is the ground reality. “Even though the JVP praised itself as the most suitable party to be given the power to rule Sri Lanka, it is the same old thugs who are coming back with a new label.”  “Sajith Premadasa is a leader who spends his personal money to provide necessities to the needy. We are a party that does not want a giant party headquarters spending millions of rupees collected from the people who support us. We are not wearing branded clothes and shoes like them,” he stressed. The JVP has huge fixed deposits and its leaders provided education to their children abroad. They are doing a political business, he alleged. By Nabiya Vaffoor Popular

title: Rotaract Alumni extends helping hand to USJ cleaning staff
author: Author not found
Content: The Rotaract Club of University Alumni, was founded on 25 August 2014, by a group of 20 enthusiastic and driven former Rotaractors from the Universities of Colombo, Peradeniya, Kelaniya, and Sri Jayewardenepura who wished to further hone their leadership skills and plan projects as young leaders that will make a difference locally and globally while working with another 10 new members who were not affiliated with the RI Movement at the time. The Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan sponsors the club, which presently has over 100 members and is steadily expanding. The community service project  ‘Tribute’ honours cleaning staff members at area universities who go above and beyond to ensure everyone’s safety, not just of university students. The project goals are to support the University of Sri Jayewardenepura’s cleaning staff in this challenging situation. In addition, as alumni Rotaractors, we want to support them during this economic crisis and the aftermath of the Covid pandemic. Community Service Avenue of the Rotaract Club of University Alumni is in charge of organising these types of CSR projects (RACUALU). It is one of the Rotaract Club of University Alumni’s key initiatives. Under this avenue, we practice corporate social responsibility (CSR). The ‘Tribute’ project turned out to be a resounding success. This project took place at the University of Sri Jayewardenepura on 31 December 2022, from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. The University of Sri Jayewardenepura has a cleaning staff cadre of sixty persons. Dry ration packs were distributed to them. Last but not least, we must not forget our sponsors. They extended their maximum support to make this project a success. The sponsors are: Link Natural, Unilever, Ceylon Biscuits Limited, Elephant House Cream Soda, Ceylon Today newspaper and Norfolk Foods. The official media partner of the Tribute project is Ceylon Today. Ceylontoday.lk is the website of the Ceylon Today newspaper which catapulted into the national print media industry of SriLanka on 18 November 2011, with full-fledged Sunday Editions as well as five dailies, the first-ever English newspaper to do so. As a sponsor, they publish ‘Tribute’ articles in their newspaper. The official beverage partner of the ‘Tribute’ project is Elephant House Cream Soda. With a very unique ‘clear but not quite’ colour and a flavour that is syrupy yet refreshing, Elephant House Cream Soda is all about experiencing joy and togetherness, enabling shared experiences among our youth hailing from diverse backgrounds and all corners of the island. As a sponsor, they provide bottles of cream soda for the cleaning staff of the University of Sri Jayewardenepura. The official food partner of the ‘Tribute’ project is Norfolk. Since its inception in 1994, Norfolk Foods for over two decades has delighted the taste buds of people around the world. Founded as a British-Sri Lankan joint venture, Norfolk Foods has been at the forefront of bringing innovative quality value-added meat, poultry, fish and vegetarian products to consumers. As a sponsor, they provide per pack fish rolls and chicken nuggets. The official silver partner of the ‘Tribute’ project is Ceylon Biscuits Limited (CBL). Since their inception, they have been committed to making delicious food of the highest quality for every family to enjoy through brands that stand for caring, quality, innovation and integrity. As a sponsor, they provide CBL Samaayu Karapincha Herbal Porridge, Samaposha Packets and CBL Noodles. The official gold partner of the ‘Tribute’ project is Unilever Lanka. Unilever employs over 140,000 staff and has over 400 trusted consumer brands spread worldwide. Unilever is sailing an amazing journey to make sustainable living commonplace. As a sponsor, they provide packets of Sunlight. The official platinum partner of the ‘Tribute’ project is Link Natural. The company Link Natural established in 1982, is driven by a challenging and inspiring corporate philosophy, namely that of providing an innovative range of herbal products for its consumers. These include safe and effective healthcare products, Ayurvedic pharmaceuticals as well as personal care and wellness products. As a sponsor, they provide Samahan SP Balm, Sudantha toothpaste, Swastha Amurtha packs and Sudantha toothbrushes. Further, the cleaning staff of the University of Sri Jayewardenepura expressed their heartiest gratitude to us for bringing new hope to their lives and making their lives easier. Finally, thank you to everyone, who extended a helping hand to make this project a reality. Special thanks goes to our beloved sponsors. Also, we can’t forget the Executive Board of the Rotaract Club of University Alumni, the Board of Directors of Rotaract Club of University Alumni and the members of our club who actively extended their support to make this project a success. The ‘Tribute’ project concluded successfully on 31 December 2022 at the University premises.

title: Pakistan to host Engineering and Healthcare Show in Feb
author: Author not found
Content: After a resounding success in the first edition of Engineering and Healthcare Show, in February 2022, the Trade Development Authority of Pakistan (TDAP) and Ministry of Commerce, Government of Pakistan are organising the second edition from 23 to 25 February 2023, at the Expo Centre, Lahore. This mega trade exhibition will target over 400 business delegates from Sri Lanka, and Gulf countries, Afghanistan, China, Central Asian Republics and African countries. Over 200 exhibitors from Pakistan are expected to showcase their products in the following sectors: Construction Materials, Minerals and Marble, Agriculture Machinery, Fans, Electrical Machinery and Home Appliances, Mobile Phones, Plastic and its products, Paints and Chemicals, Pharmaceuticals, Surgical Instruments, Musical Instruments, Sports Goods, Autoparts, Cutlery and Products, Cookware, Steel and Iron, Gems and Jewellery, Furniture, Mattresses, Rubber and Rubber Products, Packaging, Stationery, Paperboard, Handicrafts and Safety Equipment. Pakistan and Sri Lanka are important trading partners and have entered into a bilateral Free Trade Agreement (FTA) since 2005. The FTA has provided duty concessions on a wide range of imports/exports between the two countries, which makes bilateral trade more cost effective. The Engineering and Healthcare Show 2023 would provide an excellent platform to explore trade and investment opportunities between Pakistan and Sri Lanka in over 20 sectors. The visiting delegates would have an opportunity to hold B2B meetings, with special assistance of assigned product officers of TDAP, with a wide range of Pakistani exhibitors showcasing high quality products. The Trade Development Authority of Pakistan, Ministry of Commerce and High Commission of Pakistan in Colombo look forward to active participation at this mega event by Sri Lankans. For further details, please visit the events’ website at ehcs.tdap.gov.pk and/or email the Commercial Wing of the High Commission at [email protected] and [email protected], for any further queries.

title: India tells IMF it supports SL’s debt restructuring plan – Source
author: Author not found
Content: India has informed the International Monetary Fund (IMF) it will support Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring plan, a source with direct knowledge of the matter said, as the island nation races to secure a USD 2.9 billion bailout from the global lender. The country is facing its worst economic crisis since independence from Britain in 1948, and policymakers have been grappling with multiple challenges over the past year including a shortage of dollars, runaway inflation and a steep recession. “India has written to the IMF,” the source told Reuters, asking not to be named because they are not authorised to speak to the media. A spokesperson for India’s Finance Ministry declined to comment. Sri Lanka’s Finance Ministry did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Sri Lanka requires the backing of China and India – its biggest bilateral lenders – to reach a final agreement with the IMF on the USD 2.9 billion loan that is essential to put its battered economy back on track. “We are working to get our economy onto the right path,” President Ranil Wickremesinghe told Parliament on Tuesday. “We now have to get India and China’s agreement on debt restructuring. These discussions are continuing and so far they have been successful.” The two Asian giants, which have jostled for influence over Sri Lanka for decades, are also the island nation’s biggest trading partners, accounting for about USD 5 billion each in bilateral trade in 2021. Sri Lanka owes India around USD 1 billion that will come under the debt restructuring plan, the source said. New Delhi separately provided Sri Lanka with about USD 4 billion in rapid assistance between January and July last year, including credit lines, a currency swap arrangement and deferred import payments. Sri Lanka owed Chinese lenders USD 7.4 billion – nearly a fifth of its public external debt – by the end of last year, according to calculations by the China Africa Research Initiative (CARI). Japan is Sri Lanka’s third significant bilateral lender, and Colombo needs prior financing agreements with all three countries to seek IMF board approval for a four-year programme with the lender. “We are hopeful of finalising support from the IMF in the first quarter of 2023,” Sri Lanka’s cabinet spokesperson, Bandula Gunawardana, told reporters on Tuesday. Sri Lanka has to secure prior financing assurances from creditors, put its heavy debt burden on a sustainable path and increase public revenue before the global lender will disburse the funds, the IMF has said. The IMF has stressed the importance of joint talks involving three of Sri Lanka’s main bilateral creditors – China, Japan and India. Sri Lanka’s cabinet said on Tuesday that it would cut its recurrent budget expenditure by 6% in 2023 and had approved a proposal to delay salaries of some public employees to manage public finances. (Reuters)

title: Dr. Jaishankar arrives today
author: Author not found
Content: India’s Minister of External Affairs, Dr. S. Jaishankar will arrive in Sri Lanka today (19) amid assumptions that India would support Sri Lanka’s USD 2.9 billion International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout package efforts and also give its Extended Fund Facility (EFF). According to sources, the financing/debt relief will be provided by Export-Import Bank of India. Dr. Jaishankar scheduled to have official discussions with Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry and pay courtesy calls on President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena and other dignitaries. Foreign Ministry in Colombo said that the External Affairs Minister Dr. S. Jaishankar will be accompanied by Joint Secretary (IOR) Puneet Agrawal, Director Sandeep Kumar Bayyappu, Deputy Secretary (Sri Lanka) Nidhi Choudhary and Deputy Secretary Raghoo Puri from the Ministry of External Affairs, India. India has stressed to the IMF officials that Sri Lankan authorities are expected to seek equitable debt treatments from all commercial creditors and other official bilateral creditors, as well as adequate financing contributions from the multilateral development banks and that they stand ready to support IMF’s efforts on these. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Election Expenditure Bill to be debated today
author: Author not found
Content: The Regulation of Election Expenditure Bill will be taken up for debate today (19), Secretary-General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake said. This was decided at the Committee on Parliamentary Business meeting held yesterday (18). The meeting was chaired by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana. The debate will be held today (19) from 10:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. On Tuesday (17), the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms decided to postpone the second reading debate of the Regulation of Election Expenditure Bill by one month on request of the MPs present at the meeting. However, a meeting was held between President Ranil Wickremesinghe and party leaders with regard to the Bill. The Speaker also participated in the meeting. Government MPs and SLFP Leader Maithripala Sirisena and SLMC Leader Rauff Hakeem were present. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, JJB Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake and Prof. G.L. Peiris did not participate. During the meeting, the Opposition MPs were told that the Bill will be debated today (19), even if they disagree with it.  By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Karturiarachchi

title: LG polls will be conducted as scheduled
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Commission (EC) yesterday (18) gave an undertaking to the Supreme Court that the Local Government (LG) Election will be conducted in accordance with the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance. President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, on behalf of the EC, observed that the steps taken in regard to the LG Election, thus far, will continue after the nominations process as well. This was when the Petitions filed by a group of MPs, seeking an interim order to be issued to the Election Commission, for steps to be taken to hold the Local Government election in March 2023 was taken up . Meanwhile, the Secretary to the Treasury sought permission to file an affidavit objecting holding of the LG Election, containing information with regard to the funds for the holding Election. The petitions were filed by MPs Dayasiri Jayasekara, Lakshman Kiriella, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, M.A. Sumanthiran, Ranjith Madduma Bandara and G.L. Pieris. The Petitioners state that the respective four-year terms of such Local Authorities, or more precisely, the four-year term of office of each Member of such Local Authority, was to stand expired by operation of Law, in terms of the provisions of the respective Laws governing such Local Authorities, in or about March 2023. They said however, acting in terms of the powers vested in him by the relevant Laws governing such Local Authorities, the then Minister in charge of the subject of Local Authorities, by Orders published in Government Gazette Extraordinary bearing No.2262/8 dated 10-01-2022, extended the said term until 19 March 2023. The Petitioners note that it is not permissible in Law, for the Minister, to order any further extensions of the said term, and accordingly, the new term of office of duly elected Members to each such Local Authority shall commence on 20 March 2023. They further state that accordingly, it was incumbent for the Election Commission to take steps in terms of the provisions of the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance No.53 of 1946, as amended, to conduct elections in respect of each such Local Authority – the term of office of the Members, adding however that it has been neglected to date. They said thereby that an irreparable loss will be caused to the people and to the petitioners by an indefinite postponement beyond 30 March 2023. Among other relief, they prayed Court to grant and issue an interim order, directing the Election Commission to take steps to publish the notices of intention to hold elections to all Local Authorities and set in motion, the election process for the said Local Authorities. The case was re-fixed for 10 February. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: MEPA Chair to be removed?
author: Author not found
Content: Chairperson of the Marine Environment Protection Authority (MEPA) Dharshani Lahandapura will be removed from the post with immediate effect, as per the request by State Minister of Urban Development and Housing, Arundika Fernando and the approval of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. In a letter dated 9 January 2023, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake informed the Secretary of the Ministry of Ubran Development and Housing that the President has approved Fernando’s request to remove Lahandapura and appoint Attorney-at-Law Asela Rekawa to the post with immediate effect. It was last week Lahandapura and the team at the MEPA and 40 other marine scientists and experts compiled the second interim report on the X-Press Pearl disaster report that was submitted to State Minister Fernando. She also said the wreck would be removed soon. One of the recommendations found in the report was to claim a compensation of USD6.5 billion. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Wild animals destroyed over 200M coconuts in 2022
author: Author not found
Content: Over 200 million coconuts have been destroyed by toque macaque, monkeys and giant squirrels in 2022, a study conducted by the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute revealed. According to the study, in January to June of 2022, coconut plantations have suffered the most crop damage by wildlife. While in the first six months in 2022, 93 million coconuts have been destroyed by toque monkeys, monkeys and Giant Squirrels, by the end of 2022, the situation has aggravated and the damage has increased to 180 to 200 million coconuts.  Accordingly, the amount of hectares affected by coconut crop damage in 21 districts is 57,815 hectares. In the first six month of 2022, most coconut damage was recorded in Kurunegala, Puttalam, Ratnapura, Kegalle, and Moneragala.  Minister of Agriculture, Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Mahinda Amaraweera has appointed a committee headed by the Secretaries of the two Ministries and the Director Generals of Wildlife and Forest Conservation to obtain suggestions from interested parties in regard to measures that should be taken to mitigate the damage caused to crops by wild animals. Accordingly, the Ministry of Agriculture has started extensive discussions with the participation of all parties regarding the measures to be taken to prevent crop damage caused by wild animals.

title: China responds to US Envoy Chung’s ‘China a spoiler’ remarks
author: Author not found
Content: China, the United States of America’s power rival, rebuked American Ambassador in Colombo Julie Chung’s recent remarks to the BBC that ‘China is a spoiler’ in Sri Lanka’s attempt to obtain the International Monetary Fund (IMF) facility to support its ailing economy.    Chinese Embassy in its official media release on Tuesday (17) lamented, “China, China, China is our US colleague starts chanting this infamous mantra and blaming China as a spoiler to the Islands negotiation with the IMF during her recent interview on Sri Lanka debt Issue.” Further, Beijing noted that before the US Envoy’s baseless accusing and lecturing, their US colleague should have at least asked herself, who is the single largest shareholder of the IMF with veto power over major policy decisions? Who is keeping printing US dollars with more than USD 3 trillion in 2020 alone and who are those private creditors owning 40 per cent of Sri Lanka’s total external debt stock with the highest interest rates and who sued Sri Lanka in its Federal Court immediately after the Island’s default? The outrageous remarks came after the US Envoy in her recent BBC interview, stated that China is a “spoiler” as it keeps delaying in debt restructuring for Sri Lanka. The BBC highlighted that Chinese loans stand at USD 7 billion while Indian loans stand at USD 1 billion. The Chinese Embassy also highlighted that the  public may also like to k know how the US has walked the talk to help Sri Lanka people when they have already received 1,000MT of rice 9,000 litres of diesel, Rs. 5 billion worth of medicines and three million fabric meters of school uniform material gifted by China. Beijing also questioned the US as to what are the political preconditions of US Aid while being assured by China’s ‘no strings attached’ commitment and practice.  The Dragons further noted that it was hypocrisy at its finest for the US Colleague to play the blame game instead of self-examination. “Why didn’t the US take decisive actions in the IMF for a more comfortable solution for Sri Lanka or extend a grant to the island with the rocket amount of USD dollars they print every year, instead of sowing discord between China and Sri Lanka.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: AG will not appear for former SI Chief
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General’s Department yesterday (18) informed Colombo Additional District Judge Mahesha de Silva that the Attorney General will not appear on behalf of former Chief of State Intelligence SDIG Nilantha Jayawardena, who has been named as a defendant in the 108 cases filed demanding compensation for the victims of the Easter Sunday attacks. The cases were filed on behalf of the victims against those who failed to prevent the Easter Sunday attacks even after having received intelligence information. The plaintiffs demanded compensation ranging from Rs 10 million upwards, depending on the nature of the damage caused. SDIG Jayawardena, former President Maithripala Sirisena, former Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, former Defence Secretary Hemasiri Fernando, former Inspector General of Police Pujith Jayasundara, former Chief of National Intelligence Sisira Mendis and the Attorney General were named as respondents in these cases. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: GMOA to stage ‘Black Protest Week’ starting Monday
author: Author not found
Content: Kicking off with a massive protest in Colombo in collaboration with several professional categories affected by the New Inland Revenue Act coming into effect tomorrow (20), the Government Medical Officers Association (GMOA) Secretary Dr. Haritha Aluthge warned that medical professionals serving in countrywide State-run hospitals would stage a ‘Black Protest Week’ starting Monday (23). Dr. Aluthge said yesterday (18) that they hoped to coerce the Government to amend the Inland Revenue Act and resolve the medicinal drug crisis without further delay. He said the union’s Central Committee which had met had unanimously decided to stage a ‘Black Protest Week,’ He said the union said it would commence the signing of the public petition to be delivered to the President demanding sustainable solutions to the drug crisis which has held the country in its grip for over a year. Dr. Aluthge said the Union also hoped to create awareness with regard to the crisis and the collapse of the free health service among religious leaders, social activists and the general public. With the consensus of all trade unions of professional service categories would be created to form a broader front through which his outfit would agitate against the unjust tax issue. The GMOA Secretary warned that his union was prepared to intensify its trade union action and resort to more stringent measures if the Government failed to give solutions to the two most pressing issues at the moment.  (DJ)

title: Rehabilitation Bill passed by 17 votes
author: Author not found
Content: The Rehabilitation Bill was passed in Parliament yesterday (18). The Second Reading of the Bill was passed by a majority of 17 votes, 23 votes were in favour while six were against. The Third Reading of the Bill was passed with amendments. Participating in the Second Reading, Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe rejected allegations levelled against the Government that the  Rehabilitation Bill was an attempt to suppress Aragalaya activists and other opponents.  Rajapakshe pointed out that there was public opinion that the Bill was brought against Aragalaya activists because of the word ‘misguided individuals’ which is included in the Bill. While noting that it was brought at a time when there was an Aragalaya in the country, Minister Rajapakshe highlighted that it is not an act to suppress the people and that the Rehabilitation Bill draft was many years old. Speaking further, Rajapakshe said the Bill has been restricted to rehabilitation of drug addicts. Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Ali Sabry claimed the Act on Rehabilitation was brought with a good purpose and added that at the time it was introduced  an Argalaya had not even been heard when the Bill was introduced. While pointing out that other countries identify addiction to drugs as a medical problem, Minister Ali Sabry said misguided individuals need rehabilitation instead of imprisonment. He added in Sri Lanka drug traffickers escape while the Courts are filled with sprats. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Medical practitioners accused the Government of attempting to privatise the State health service under the guise of finding solutions to the country’s economic crisis. Media committee member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam said that although State service doctors were not completely averse to re-introducing paying wards they were concerned as to whether the Government aimed at slowly but gradually privatising the free health service into a another money earner for the State. The initial aim according to President Wickremesinghe’s 2023 Budget proposals was to re-introduce the paying ward system at national and base hospitals during the first phase. He said that the system was already available at National Hospital, Colombo.    There were suggestions to say that private wards would be introduced at Teaching Hospital, Kalubowila and Base Hospital Panadura during the first stage.  The membership had expressed its concern as to the effects such a move would have on the free health service. Therefore, it should be made in consultation and arriving at a consensus with all stakeholders in free health care. The GMOA Media Committee Member said that currently Sri Jayewardenepura General Hospital was semi government where patients had to meet the cost of the service provided while government doctors and medical practitioners who had left government service served at the hospital.  He added that several other services provided initially by the State including transport and electricity were partially privatised.     By Dilanthi Jayamanne   Popular

title: Magistrate orders psychiatric report
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (18) ordered to produce the suspect arrested in connection with the stabbing of a 24-year-old undergraduate, before a specialist psychiatrist at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) and to produce the reports to Court. Court also ordered to remand the suspect until 30 January. The suspect, 24-year-old Pasindu Chaturanga de Silva is a resident of Wellampitiya. Cinnamon Gardens Police informed Court that further investigations into the incident will be conducted. Counsel who appeared for the suspect stated that the suspect has been suffering from a certain mental disorder since 2017 and was receiving treatment. The Magistrate thereby ordered to call for a psychiatric report on the suspect and ordered him to be remanded until 30 January. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: 253m high Bungee jumping platform at Lotus Tower under installation
author: Author not found
Content: The world’s highest platform for bungee jumping, at 253 metres, from the commercial building of the Lotus Tower is under construction. It is speculated that the Japanese company ‘Go Bungee’ Japan-based in Singapore which has invested in this recreational activity is also aiming to make it the highest length of bungee jumping in the world. The Japanese firm that will open an office at the Lotus Tower hopes to start the recreational activity and attract bungee jumpers from all over the world. According to Ceylon Today sources, the Company also hopes to expand bungee jumping possible from an earmarked height to a further higher point on the Lotus Tower. Currently, the highest commercial bungee jump facility (building) is 232.82 metres which is located on the Macau Tower, in Macau, China. According to sources, the Lotus Tower Company would be sharing 20% of the profit from the Bungee Jumping which would be over USD 500 per jump. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Decision on removing President as defendant on 1 March
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional District Judge Mahesha de Silva yesterday (18) said the decision on whether President Ranil Wickremesinghe will be removed as a defendant in the 108 cases filed, claiming compensation for the victims of the Easter Sunday attacks, will be delivered on 1 March. While Wickremesinghe was named as the second defendant in the compensation cases, the lawyer appearing on his behalf previously requested Wickremesinghe’s name to be removed on the basis that he is entitled to Presidential immunity under the provisions of Article 35(1) of the Constitution. Written submissions were made to this effect yesterday (18). Accordingly, the relevant decision will be delivered on 1 March. BY Hansi Nanayakkara
