title: Jaffna Mayor to be elected today
author: Author not found
Content: Following several rounds of discussions, the selection of a new Mayor for Jaffna Municipal Council (JMC) will take place today (19), and the sitting will be chaired by Commissioner of Department of Local Government, Northern Province S. Pranavanathan. The Mayor seat had become vacant following the resignation of Jaffna Mayor Viswalingam Manivannan after the Budget for 2023 was defeated. When contacted Jaffna Mayor Manivannan said, he had no any intention of contesting for the post again, despite news in this connection circulating on social media. He said, Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) member Solomon Syril was expected to contest for the post  and added that it is understood that former Jaffna Mayor Immanuel Arnold will contest for the post on the TNA ticket. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: YouTuber Sepal further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday further remanded, till 31 January, YouTuber Sepal Amarasinghe, who has been charged with defaming the Sri Dalada Maligawa, Kandy. Announcing his decision, the Chief Magistrate stated that if the suspect wishes to seek bail, he could file an application to that effect, with the Colombo High Court. Amarasinghe was arrested by CID on 5 January, after making several controversial statements about the much-revered Sri Dalada Maligawa. The YouTuber’s claims led to chaotic uproar amongst Sri Lanka’s predominantly Buddhist society, the CID prosecuting stated, while the Director General of Department of Archaeology also asserted that the slanderous statements in question made by the suspect, were a grave wrongdoing. The Chief Prelates of the Malwatta and Asgiriya Chapters had also informed the CID, that they are ready to provide statements pertaining to the matter, the prosecution informed the Court. Investigations had also revealed that Amarasinghe had received funds from persons overseas, regarding which the CID are conducting further probes under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act and the Convention on the Suppression of Terrorist Financing Act. The CID initiated investigations into the statements made by Amarasinghe, after IGP C.D. Wickramaratne received written complaints in this regard, which lead to Amarasinghe’s arrest. The Chief Prelates of Malwatta and Asgiriya Chapters, Most Ven. Thibbatuwawe Sri Siddhartha Sumangala Thera and Most Ven. Warakagoda Sri Gnanarathana Thera also wrote to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, raising concerns about the most insulting statements made by Amarasinghe and urged the Government to take necessary measures to nip the matter in the bud. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Foreign Secretary Wijewardane meets UK FCDO Under-Secretary
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Secretary Aruni Wijewardane and Permanent Under-Secretary of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) of the United Kingdom Sir Philip Barton held discussions at the Foreign Ministry in Colombo on Tuesday, 17 January. The constructive bilateral engagement takes place in the 75th year of UK-SL diplomatic relations. Foreign Secretary Wijewardane briefed the UK Permanent Under-Secretary on present developments in the country and the Government’s plans for 2023 as a year of socio-economic stabilisation, reconciliation and recovery. Permanent Under-Secretary Barton encouraged Sri Lanka’s efforts and reiterated the support of the UK in this regard. In view of the priority placed by Sri Lanka on economic recovery and growth, the Foreign Secretary highlighted the significance of Sri Lanka’s economic partnership with the UK, under the Developing Countries Trading Scheme (DCTS) which provides duty-free access to the UK market, as well as in other sectors such as enhancing the UK’s contribution to Sri Lanka’s tourism and skilled labour migration. The two parties appreciated the potential to further expand trade and investment ties, including reaction to climate change objectives, and in achieving Sri Lanka’s target of 70 per cent renewable energy by 2030. Both parties reiterated their mutual interest to initiate a Sri Lanka-UK Dialogue in the first quarter of 2023, with a view to elevate the existing multifaceted engagement and to work towards achieving tangible results through a result-oriented approach on several areas of mutually beneficial cooperation. Foreign Secretary Wijewardane and Permanent Under-Secretary of the FCDO appreciated the vibrant people-to-people ties emanating from the significant community of Sri Lankan heritage in the UK. Foreign Secretary Wijewardane apprised the Permanent Under-Secretary on the Government’s intent to further engage with the overseas Sri Lankan community to better harness their synergies for mutual benefit. It was agreed to commemorate the 75th anniversary of UK-Sri Lanka diplomatic relations this year in a manner reflective of the long-standing relations in a forward-looking and result-oriented manner. In an exchange of views on regional and international developments, Foreign Secretary Wijewardane briefed the Permanent Under-Secretary on Sri Lanka’s policy priorities in Indian Ocean engagement, as well as the country’s assumption of the Chair of the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) this year. During the visit, the UK Permanent Under-Secretary called on Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe and the President’s Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka. Sir Philip Barton was accompanied by British High Commissioner Sarah Hulton and officials of the British High Commission and the UK FCDO. Senior officials of the Foreign Ministry also participated in the meeting.

title: AdiVasi community to participate in 75th Independence Day celebrations
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of the AdiVaasi (Vedda) community Uruwarige Vanniyala Aththo assured Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena that the community will participate in the 75th Independence Day ceremony. “As per the invitation of the Prime Minister all leaders of the Vedda community will participate in the Independence Day ceremony” he said when community leaders met the Prime Minister in Parliament. Uruwarige Vanniyala Aththo said the community is honoured to accept the invitation extended by the Prime Minister, on behalf of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. During the meeting he handed over a document listing out various problems faced by indigenous groups living in the Uva, Eastern, North-Central and other provinces in the country. He urged Parliament to intervene to pass a bill to protect the rights of the indigenous community who are facing various problems. The problem of microfinance loans faced by women in their community was also discussed during the meeting. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena instructed the State Minister Ashoka Priyantha to find appropriate measures to solve the problems faced by them.   The Premier said he would look into measures that could be taken in this regard through the committees in Parliament.    Uruwarige Vanniyala Aththo, Rathugala regional leader Danigala Bandalage Sudu Banda, Pollabedda regional leader Thala Bandalage Gunawardena, Henanigala regional leader Thala Warige Guna Bandia, Wakere regional leader Nallathambi Velayudhan, Muthur regional leader Nagaratnam Vardhan, N.  Kanakaratnam, A. Sree Selvam, indigenous leaders and members were present at the discussions. Chief organiser of the ruling party, Minister Prasanna Ranatunga, State Minister of Home Affairs Ashoka Priyantha, Lionel Guruge, Lalinda Wickramaratne and M. Pradeepan of the Centre for Policy Alternative (CPA) were also present.

title: Will it be Rosy or Faiszer for CMC Mayor?
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Mayor Rosy Senanayake has expressed willingness to contest for her post again in the coming Local Government polls to be held soon. Sirikotha sources said, a final decision in connection with the appointment of candidates for the CMC is yet to be decided. UNP General Secretary Palitha Range Bandara said the process to finalise candidates for the post of Mayor for the CMC will be taken in a couple of days. Even though discussions were underway in this regard Mayor Senanayake’s position was not decided, sources said. At the same time UNP is exploring the possibilities of fielding Faiszer Musthapha, who left the SLFP, for the post of Colombo Mayor on the UNP ticket, Range Bandara added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Opposition Leader slams double speak of some MPs
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa vowed that although some ‘VIP Socialists’ are trolling him for distributing buses to needy schools, he would not stop providing the service to children of the country. Premadasa alleged those so-called VIP socialists visit rural villages and speak about the proletariat and socialism while their children were receiving quality  education in foreign countries. “It is true that Sri Lanka has free education, however, all children were not getting equal opportunities and equal facilities”, he said. “This is why the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) launched the ‘Sakwala’ programme to provide certain facilities to needy schools. We even provided buses to schools where ‘VIP socialists’ were educated. That is why they are so angry with us and call me a ‘busman.’ I’m not afraid of them,” he said. Premadasa also challenged his opponents to do their bit for the development of the country without mocking others’ attempts. He further said the Government was afraid of the Election. “They say there is no money to pay salaries and hold Elections. But have enough money for Independence Day celebrations,” he added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Deputy Speaker denies owning cannabis cultivation
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse denied media reports that the STF recently arrested a person for maintaining a cannabis farm on a plot of land owned by him (Rajapakse) and said he has taken legal action against those that published the “fake news.” He also said he requested relevant authorities to investigate as to why an STF Officer told the media that the land in question belonged to him. Raising a privilege matter in Parliament yesterday (17), Rajapakse stressed he does not own any land in Hambantota District except in Ambalantota Divisional Secretariat where he lives. “Those who published this news did not contact me to get my side of the story. I have already taken legal action against several newspapers, demanding compensation of Rs 500 million for damage caused to my reputation,” he said.   By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: National Academy on Animal Conservation to be set up
author: Author not found
Content: The Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera is to submit a Cabinet Paper to establish a National Academy on Animal Conservation and Zoological Garden Management for both local and foreign students. The required human resource for the Academy will be facilitated by the Department of National Zoological Gardens, Amaraweera said. ‘’Currently, there are over 800 staff including animal caretakers, veterinarians, elephant caretakers, aquarium attendants at the Department of National Zoological Gardens, but there is no specialised institute for further training. In the past, groups of foreign students from China, Australia, Spain, Netherlands, India, Latvia, Czechoslovakia, Pakistan, Malaysia and Great Britain visited Sri Lanka to receive training in wildlife conservation and zoo management,’’ he said adding thereby the Academy will be able to facilitate such students and could also be a means of generating foreign income.

title: Farmers in Ampara urge Government to return paddy lands taken over
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting was mooted by President Ranil Wickremsinghe to enable farmers to get their traditional paddy lands back so that they could engage in paddy cultivation and help the national food drive.  Meanwhile, farmers allege that many sections of land in the Ampara District were taken over by Government Departments and the Forces during the LTTE days when these lands were in terrorist areas and now farmers were not in a position to visit their original lands and bring it under the plough. The meeting organised by the Ampara District Alliance for Lands Rights (ADALR) was held at the Auditorium of the Mango Garden Akkaraipattu and was attended by farmers from various parts of the District.  Presiding over the meeting the Executive Director of the Human Evaluation Organisation, K. Nihal Ahamed detailed the purpose of the meeting and that what was expected from the meeting. MP for Digamadulla District, S.M.M. Musharraf, who welcomed the move said ADALR has been playing an important role and collecting details of lands acquired by the Forces and some Departments of the district. He said evry aspect should be carefully analysed and assessed as this was a sensitive area. Director – Programme and Operations – Law and Society Trust (LST), Sandun Thuulgala and Women Rights and Social Activist Sarala Emmanuel participated as resource persons. Three teams made their observations at the presentation. BY M. A. P. Deen –Ampara

title: CEB’s generation profits pass Rs 7.5B in only 15 days
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Electricity Board’s (CEB’s) generation profits passed the Rs 7.5 billion mark (Rs 7.52 billion) in a mere 15 consecutive days to Tuesday (17 January) aided by CEB’s 75 per cent tariff hike effective from 9 August 2022 according to the authorities, CEB data from yesterday showed. CEB statistics showed that Sri Lanka consumed a total of 37.10 gigawatt hours (GWh) of electricity on Tuesday. CEB’s average tariff rate of Rs 29.14 per kilowatt hour (kWh), which the above calculations are based on, are as per Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera’s recent statement, coupled with CEB’s tariff costs found in Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, which is the latest of such data available in the public domain. Wijesekera was not contactable to find out CEB’s latest generation cost/s and transmission and distribution losses data, respectively. In related developments, the Cabinet’s last Monday’s (9 January) decision to hike electricity tariffs further by an undisclosed percentage with retrospective effect from 1 January is also not taken into consideration, because, ipso facto, such details are unknown. Meanwhile, according to CBSL, CEB’s average tariff rate in 2021 was Rs 16.37 per electricity unit (one kWh of electricity energy), a 78.01 per cent (Rs 12.77) hike since. An 8.72 per cent transmission and distribution loss as per 2021 cost estimates as computed by the CEB is also taken into consideration in the above computation. In like developments, the breakdown of the 37.10 GWh of electricity generated on Tuesday comprised 12.97 GWh of CEB coal, 11.79 GWh of CEB hydroelectricity, 7.736 GWh of CEB fuel/thermal oil, 5.97 GWh from renewable energy (RE) other than CEB hydroelectricity and 2.18 GWh from independent power producers’ (IPP) private sector (PS) fuel oil, respectively. According to the CBSL, the cheapest electricity generation cost to the CEB in 2021 was CEB hydroelectricity at Rs 1.67 a unit of electricity, followed by CEB coal (Rs 10.68), ‘other RE’ (Rs 16.22), IPP/ PS fuel oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB fuel oil (Rs 32.03), respectively.  The main driver of CEB hydroelectricity is the Mahaweli which generated 7.16 GWh of electricity on Tuesday and which contributed to 17.62 per cent of total electricity generation and 60.73 per cent of total CEB hydroelectricity generation on that day. Mahaweli is led by Victoria, Randenigala, Rantambe and Kotmale built during the J.R. Jayewardene era after obtaining both grant and concessional aid from the West. On Tuesday, cheap and clean RE such as electricity generated by the Mahaweli provided 43.70 per cent (17.76 GWh) of Sri Lanka’s total electricity needs via the CEB, while the balance 56.30 per cent (22.88 GWh) of electricity generated was from the dirty and imported fossil fuels consisting of coal and fuel oil, respectively. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: YouTuber Sepal further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday further remanded, till 31 January, YouTuber Sepal Amarasinghe, who has been charged with defaming the Sri Dalada Maligawa, Kandy. Announcing his decision, the Chief Magistrate stated that if the suspect wishes to seek bail, he could file an application to that effect, with the Colombo High Court. Amarasinghe was arrested by CID on 5 January, after making several controversial statements about the much-revered Sri Dalada Maligawa. The YouTuber’s claims led to chaotic uproar amongst Sri Lanka’s predominantly Buddhist society, the CID prosecuting stated, while the Director General of Department of Archaeology also asserted that the slanderous statements in question made by the suspect, were a grave wrongdoing. The Chief Prelates of the Malwatta and Asgiriya Chapters had also informed the CID, that they are ready to provide statements pertaining to the matter, the prosecution informed the Court. Investigations had also revealed that Amarasinghe had received funds from persons overseas, regarding which the CID are conducting further probes under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act and the Convention on the Suppression of Terrorist Financing Act. The CID initiated investigations into the statements made by Amarasinghe, after IGP C.D. Wickramaratne received written complaints in this regard, which lead to Amarasinghe’s arrest. The Chief Prelates of Malwatta and Asgiriya Chapters, Most Ven. Thibbatuwawe Sri Siddhartha Sumangala Thera and Most Ven. Warakagoda Sri Gnanarathana Thera also wrote to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, raising concerns about the most insulting statements made by Amarasinghe and urged the Government to take necessary measures to nip the matter in the bud. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: COUNTRY WILL RETURN TO LONG QUEUES – DR. WEERASINGHE
author: Author not found
Content: The country returning to long queues that prevailed for more than six months last year is inevitable if the existing economic mechanism is interrupted or disturbed in any way, Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe warned yesterday (17). Responding to questions posed by journalists during a televised discussion Rata kothanada? (Where does the country stand?) on the country’s economic and financial situation aired by all TV channels last night, Dr. Weerasinghe emphasised the need to bring in foreign exchange in some way. “If the country gets enough foreign exchange, the economy will be stable. So far, what we have done is manage the limited amount of foreign exchange and spend it only on essential items. “The primary requirement now is how to manage the amount of foreign exchange required to fulfil basic needs. So far, we have been able to manage it without obtaining any additional foreign loans.” Fielding further questions, the CBSL Governor said: “When I assumed the post of Central Bank Governor, the economy of this country had collapsed. The Treasury was at great risk. Even then, we saw that if the economy had continued as it is, the country was heading for a big economic crisis. At that time, our effort was to address the situation in some way without taking such a risk. In short, an economy heading towards inevitable collapse is now stabilising. However, people are still experiencing the effects of the economic crisis. It is because the economy contracted that there were some difficulties. A recent contraction of negative 7.5 means that economic activity is 7.5 per cent lower than the last year and inflation is high. Accordingly, it is evident that the economy has contracted and there has been some impact on the economy. Yet, despite some contraction, the economy that was heading towards collapse has now been stabilised. One of the main reasons for economic contraction is the lack of foreign exchange in the country. The economy began contracting by a negative 1.5 per cent in the first quarter of 2022. Thereafter, the situation continued to worsen, but now it has reached a stable level. The best example is to look at the economy’s contraction for the first time in history before Covid in 2001. You might remember that it was from minus 1.5. There was a similar crisis then, especially, the foreign exchange deficit. At that time, the economy was stabilised by obtaining foreign exchange assistance from the International Monetary Fund. When there was no economic system in the country, for example, there were huge fuel and gas queues from March to July. If that situation continued, the country’s economy would have crashed. That would have created a situation where no one would have been able to engage in any local industry or export.” Meanwhile, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe, expressing views during the same programme, said it would be possible to obtain the approval of the Executive Board of Directors of the International Monetary Fund before the end of the first quarter of this year. Further, due to the assurance that Sri Lanka will follow a globally acceptable financial policy with other countries, the State Minister also pointed out that the possibility exists for obtaining other bilateral and multilateral loans and money. In response to a question raised by a journalist regarding the financial assistance proposed to be received from the International Monetary Fund, the State Minister said: “Small groups who do not understand the intervention of the International Monetary Fund are talking about the USD 2.9 billion received over four years from this extended loan amount. But this matter does not stop there. So far, many of the groups that are talking about this are groups that have not contributed to the programme carried out by the Government and the programme carried out by the Central Bank and the Ministry of Finance.  Similarly, some groups believe that the foreign exchange crisis in the country should be resolved, but there are a handful who say that the people should be allowed to suffer in this manner without resolving it. No one can go against the decisions taken by the Government regarding the International Monetary Fund. I saw different groups, different institutions, and different people expressing their personal opinion on this matter. However, now we have reached the final stage. There is a division in the Government regarding whether or not to seek assistance from the International Monetary Fund. One group said they should get the support of the International Monetary Fund, while another group discussed the management of the country’s economy through a local mechanism without seeking the support of the IMF. However, by March 2022, the Government decided to seek the assistance of the International Monetary Fund and get their Extended Fund Facility to find the necessary solutions to the crisis in the country. Based on the situation we are in today, loan repayment has been suspended. We are known as a country that cannot repay debts. Therefore, we must achieve debt sustainability. The intervention of the International Monetary Fund is very important in this situation. If we look at the USD 2.9 billion, this is between USD 4-5 billion. It is not only the International Monetary Fund that intervenes here. With the confidence we get, in the guarantee that is given, based on the assurance that the necessary reforms will be carried out in the country and we follow a financial policy that is acceptable to other countries globally, we will have the ability to get other bilateral and multilateral dues and possible funds. Notably, the IMF is gaining confidence in Sri Lanka. Today’s rating agencies have rated the economy at a very low level. As a result, we are unable to obtain more funds and get financial support. That is why the President said if we look at the past 7-8 months, no institution or country has provided any kind of financial support to Sri Lanka apart from urgent humanitarian assistance. We are managing our foreign exchange locally on the policies adopted by the Treasury. The rating agencies will consider the country’s economic situation more positively based on the confidence in us internationally. Similarly, when implementing our financial policies, we look positively at the method of implementing these policies. Hence, the International Monetary Fund certification is very important for us to achieve debt sustainability. The IMF’s assurance is very important for us to achieve debt sustainability. Therefore, we have discussed this with all bilateral creditors. Three rounds of negotiations have been held and we hope that we will be able to get the approval of the Executive Board of the International Monetary Fund before the end of this quarter after receiving the necessary financial certifications. Therefore, the country’s economic stability that we have experienced so far to some extent is not the complete stability that the Government is hoping for. We all should pay attention to this situation while we work. I believe that where the Parliament is considered, the ruling party members as well as the other members too have the same responsibility. Hence, when expressing their views, it is very important to express their opinions in a manner that does not interfere with this positive programme because all citizens get the dividends of these programmes. Similarly, if the country cannot be stabilized, everyone will have to face the repercussions. Therefore, if any group interrupts the approval process of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to stabilise the economy of the country, the economic situation in the country would become more serious than the situation in March 2022, and it would require a comparatively longer period to recover. Therefore, no one should underestimate this programme and its benefits should not be limited just to USD 2.9 billion. By now, related countries and institutions have commenced discussions with us with their assurance to extend financial support as well as other support to us. Therefore, we believe that with the assurance we receive at the end of the first quarter, we would be able to bring our economy to the expected level of stability by the end of this year.”  Responding to a journalist, who queried if it wasn’t the public who will have to bear the financial burden of an election, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said during the last two years a massive movement created by democracy was shattered due to economic issues. “The President, who was elected with 6.9 million votes, had to resign due to the struggle of the people who could not bear the economic pressure. As a result, the Cabinet was rendered inactive. If the struggle had continued, the Parliament would have been inoperative. We still have the problem of whether this is a suitable year for an election. We are still in an economic crisis where some sectors are still in decline. In some sectors, the decline of the economy is slowing down. Under such a situation, should we go for a so-called democratic election soon? It has been estimated that Rs 12 billion would be spent on the election. At present, the expenditure of the country has increased to 300 if the income is 100. We have had to find the deficit by way of loans or printing money. If the election is held, the inflation rate would rise. If the funds for an election were taken out of the tax revenue, it would affect the poor. In such a situation, if we find the money for a Local Government Election by printing money, it will be a world record. Democracy is important and I am saying it as a representative of the Treasury. But, I ask the public if this is the right time for an election. This is a time when the country’s democracy is being turned upside down by the country’s economic issues.” Another journalist asked Finance Ministry Secretary Mahinda Siriwardana about the budgetary allocation on the Local Government Election and the financial capability of the Treasury to pay the salaries of public employees and pensions and grant subsidies in the future. Siriwardana responded: “In general, we have problems in day-to-day financial management. Essential payments such as government employee salaries, pensions and subsidies have to be made. We have to proceed with those payments. Rs 3 billion is required to pay government employee salaries while Rs 27.5 billion is needed for pensions. The Government has to bear Rs 11 billion for other allowances. Rs 10 billion is spent monthly on medicines alone. In such a situation, only Rs 10 billion would be spared from the income and hence we are in the grips of an economic crisis. The amount we get from foreign loans is very limited. During 2020 and 2022, there has been an outflow of foreign currency from the country. If the interest rate in the banking system remains high, it is difficult for the public to carry out their daily activities. In addition, the country is experiencing a USD crisis. Rs 3 billion should be given to the State Pharmaceuticals Corporation or there would be a shortage of medicine in the country.”

title: PM contradicts Hapuhinna
author: Author not found
Content: Public Administration Ministry Secretary Neel Hapuhinna appears to be in hot water for sending a controversial letter to District Secretaries, ordering them not to accept LG Polls deposits, with Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, who is also the Public Administration Minister, vouching in Parliament that the Cabinet never took any decision to halt accepting deposits. In response to a question raised by Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake, the PM said the Cabinet did not take such a decision last week and if someone claims so, it is completely false. Dissanayake said it was the Cabinet Secretary who informed both the Election Commission and the Public Administration Ministry Secretary. “If what the PM says is true, someone like the Cabinet Secretary spreading such false claims is very serious situation,” Dissanayake pointed out. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, who also joined the discussion, said Gunawardena also should take the responsibility for the chaos created after Hapuninna’s controversial letter. Gunawardena then said, as the Public Administration Minister, he never instructed to send such a directive. “The Secretary withdrew the letter on the same day. There are instances in the past where ministry secretaries sent letters and withdrew them on the same day,” he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: China strongly opposes Dalai Lama’s planned visit to SL
author: Author not found
Content: In the wake of a group of high-ranking Sri Lankan Buddhist Monks, who were on a pilgrimage to Bodh Gaya recently, seeking His Holiness Dalai Lama’s visit to Sri Lanka, Chinese Embassy Chargé d’affaires Hu Wei visited Kandy recently and called on the Mahanayake Thera of the Malwathu Chapter, Most Venerable Thibbatuwawe Sri Siddhartha Sumangala Thera to stress that the Government and people of China including in the Tibet Autonomous Region strongly oppose any foreign country to receive the Dalai Lama in any name. The Chinese Envoy claimed that the 14th Dalai Lama is absolutely not a “simple monk” as he self-claimed, but the head of the feudal serfdom and the theocracy in Tibet prior to 1951 and a political exile disguised as a religious figure that has long been engaging in anti-China separatist activities and attempting to split Tibet from China. The Embassy said at the visit on 11 January, Wei had a friendly conversation about the millennia-close exchanges between the two peoples and Buddhist communities of the two countries, as well as China’s firm support to all walks of life in Sri Lanka to fight against the Covid-19 pandemic and the economic crisis. The issue of the 14th Dalai Lama’s intention to visit Sri Lanka was also discussed The Embassy added that by smashing the lies of the Dalai Lama group; the Chinese Chargé d’affaires briefed the Mahanayake Thera that in the Dalai Lama era, about 1 million people were serfs accounting for 95 per cent of Tibet’s population. Its GDP was only 129 million RMB and the Life Expectancy was only 35.5 years (in 1951). Under the leadership of the Communist Party of China, the Tibetan people are now enjoying a prosperous economy with a GDP of RMB 210 billion (31 billion USD) and the GDP per capita of USD 8,000 (twice of Sri Lanka and 4 times of India where he resides now), the longevity of 72.19 years on average and freedom of religion with 46,000 monks and nuns in over 1,700 temples in Tibet. According to Indian news agency ANI, Waskaduwe Mahindawansa Mahanayaka Thera, Sri Sambuddha Sasanodaya Sangha Sabha stated in an interview, “India helped His Holiness Dalai Lama, and today we know thousands of tourists are at Bodh Gaya because of His Holiness.” “These days, Bodh Gaya is really cold, and people typically don’t come, but they come because of His Holiness,” he added. “Bodh Gaya benefits in a variety of ways. Is Tibet gaining anything? We should ponder about this part also.” The high-ranking monk wished the Dalai Lama would visit Sri Lanka and assist in overcoming the country’s present economic difficulties. “As His Holiness has been to Bodh Gaya, I believe. If he visits Sri Lanka, tens of thousands of tourists will visit, boosting the economy because we are in a slump. And, if His Holiness visits Sri Lanka, many tourists will flock here, as they did to Bodh Gaya. We will be blessed, and the economy will benefit as well,” he explained. The meeting with the Dalai Lama apparently impressed Makulewe Wimala Mahanayaka Thera, Mahanayaka Thera of Ramanna Maha Nikaya, who said “We were delighted to meet His Holiness the Dalai Lama, a spiritual leader. We have a grasp on spiritual activity. As a result, Mahasangha from Sri Lanka is pleased to witness what His Holiness is accomplishing.” Ven. Muruddeniya Dhammarathana Thera of the Asgiriya Chapter further said they are overjoyed because Bodh Gaya is like our motherland because Lord Buddha attained enlightenment there and they love that location.  However, We emphasised that China and Sri Lanka have been firmly supporting each other on issues concerning each other’s core interests, including the Tibet-related issue. Both sides, especially the Buddhist communities, must prevent a sneaky visit of the Dalai Lama to the island to promote “Tibetan independence” and safeguard the China-Sri Lanka historical relations from being damaged. The Chinese Embassy said Most Venerable Malwathu Mahanayaka Thera highly appraised the close friendship between Sri Lanka and China dating from Ven. Faxian Thera’s visit the island 1,600 years ago, and Chinas continued support to Sri Lanka since the latter’s independence, particularly during former PM Sirimavo Bandaranaike’s time. In the last three years of fighting against the Covid-19 and economic crisis, China has been assisting us greatly with PPEs, vaccines, rice, diesel etc., which is fully appreciated by the Sri Lanka people including the Maha Sangha. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Rs 200M ‘investment for the future’ – President
author: Author not found
Content: Amid strong criticism against spending Rs 200 million for the 75th Independence Day celebrations, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said the celebration is an investment for the future. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (17), the President said he understands that there is criticism against Independence Day celebrations. “We have planned a programme to provide two million low-income families with 10 kg of rice per month during March and April. I would be happier if we could give them more. As we celebrate our 75th Independence Day, we will not allow our people to starve. We will invest the funds required to feed them. Some people criticise the expenditure of the Government on the independence celebration. But, we need to provide such relief to the people,” he said. He also said Sri Lanka will have to spend another Rs 10 billion within the next few years for the 25-year development plan. “It has been 75 years since we gained independence and we are taking measures to create several institutions by the time we reach our 100th year of independence to bring about the required reforms in the country. Thus, we are working to establish an institution to study about the history of the country. One of the biggest accusations against us is that we have forgotten our history. We are establishing an economic and trade institution similar to those in many different countries. In addition, for the first time in our country, we are setting up an institution for women and gender. Measures will also be taken to establish a university for training the officials on Government and State Policies. We should establish an agricultural technology university if we need our agriculture to be modernised. We also plan to establish a University on Climate Change to which foreign countries have already expressed their willingness to assist. We also hope to establish a sports university to train this country’s athletes to international standards. We need funds for these activities. These may cost more than Rs 10 billion. We do not spend money at once on these projects. Our 75th independence celebration does not end there. We are implementing these programmes for the future,” he said. Speaking further, the President said the Government plans to pass several new laws; National Commission for Women Act, the Gender Equality Act, and the Women’s Empowerment Act. “When these three acts are passed, ours will become the country in South Asia that has taken the highest measures for the safety of women. We would also pass the Climate Change Act, Forest Replantation and Tree Cover Act etc. In addition, with the passage of the Living Entity Act, we would get the rightful ownership of the Mahaweli River, Sinharaja Forest, Sri Pada Site, Horton Plains, Knuckles and Adam’s Bridge etc. The country would become one with the best environmental laws in the region with the passage of the laws for marine resources exploration and management and the Muthurajawela (Conservation) Act,” he said. Moreover, he said a Social Justice Commission Act will be introduced as well. “In addition to these programmes, allocations should be made to establish 75 urban forests this year and the National Youth Platform project programmes. We will also take measures to implement a 1,996 housing project for low-income families in Colombo and Gampaha Districts. Despite the present economic crisis in the country, we are working hard to provide relief to the people. On this 75th independence anniversary, I propose to the Opposition to change the existing political system. Let’s work together to provide relief to the people. If we could achieve such progress with these limited resources, I urge everyone to work together for the future of the country,” the President said.  By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SDSG wants case transferred to Colombo Chief Magistrate
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris yesterday (17) insisted, when the case pertaining to the IUSF Convenor and the University Bikkhu Federation Convenor was called before Colombo Additional Magistrate Tharanga Mahawatta, to transfer the case to be heard before the Colombo Chief Magistrate, citing alleged prejudice.   The case pertaining to IUSF Convener, Wasantha Mudalige and University Bhikku Federation Convener, Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera was taken up for the first time before Colombo Additional Magistrate Mahawatta yesterday and Senior Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris appeared for Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam. The two suspects Mudalige and the IUBF Convener, Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, were produced at the official chamber of the Colombo Chief Magistrate on 17 and 22 November, last year. When it was convened at the two aforementioned dates, SDSG Peiris stated that four officers attached to the TID, had submitted affidavits to the IGP, related to statements delivered by the Additional Magistrate and pertaining to her actions. He pointed out that as per the affidavits submitted to the IGP, the latter had made a request, to hand over the complaints against the Additional Magistrate, to the JSC. The SDSG mentioned that as per the affidavits submitted, after the suspects had been produced at the official chamber of the Chief Magistrate, the Additional Magistrate had maintained that as per the Provisions of the PTA, the suspects cannot be enlarged on bail. SDSG Peiris stated that the Additional Magistrate had claimed, as her hands were tied due to Provisions contained in the PTA, that she had advised officials to facilitate Ayurveda medicine for the suspect monk and provide him with a certain milk powder brand. According to SDSG Peiris, the Additional Magistrate had sent Rs 10,000 via a Court Officer, to be given to the suspect monk. At that stage, the Additional Magistrate advised the prosecution, to submit the affidavits filed by the Police Officers. SDSG Peiris then insisted that it would be prejudicial to the trial, if it were to be called before the Additional Magistrate concerned and urged the Court, to transfer it to be heard before the Colombo Chief Magistrate. Thereafter Saliya Pieris, PC, representing the defence, strongly opposed the request made by the prosecution. He added that if the AG wishes a trial to be transferred from one Court to another, then it should be carried out as per Provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act. He remarked that the actions of the prosecution would not bode well for the judicial community in this country. Saliya Pieris explained that the prosecution’s actions could also be best described, as an attempt made to intimidate the Judiciary and also as an affront to it. Addressing the Court thereafter, Additional Magistrate Mahawatta noted that though she had made certain remarks directed at the suspect monk purely on humanitarian grounds, all comments she had made on that date had been uttered in front of TID officers. However, she maintained that the TID officers had in their affidavits, included remarks which had not been uttered by her, on that date. She said it was obvious to her that certain people had attempted to create a rift between her and the Police and that she would not condone such actions. Thereafter, Additional Magistrate and Defence Counsel Saliya Pieris, inquired from the prosecution, whether any complaints had been lodged before the Judicial Services Commission (JSC), related to the affidavits. Responding, SDSG Dileepa Peiris observed that the Attorney General’s Department was looking to submit the complaints concerning the affidavits, to the JSC shortly. Considering the submissions, Additional Magistrate Tharanga Mahawatta, ordered future trial proceedings, to be convened before Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis. Thus, the trial was convened before the said Chief Magistrate and at the outset, Defence Counsel Saliya Pieris, PC urged the Court to issue an order for his client to be enlarged on bail. The Court then ordered both the prosecution and the defence, to file written submissions pertaining to the trial on 24 January and ordered the suspect IUSF Convener, to be further remanded till 31 January.  Following this, Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis stated that his decision on whether to enlarge Mudalige on bail or not, will be delivered on 31 January. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Electricity tariff hike ‘unlawful’ – Ratnayake
author: Author not found
Content: If the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) does any tariff revision, it would be a violation of Section 30 of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act as it has failed to implement steps instructed by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) 10 years ago to determine ‘reasonable cost’ related to tariff changes, the PUCSL said. As a result of CEB’s failure to implement those proposals, calculating reasonable cost to pass to consumer in the recent tariff hike is impossible. Therefore, if the CEB increases the electricity tariff, it would be a violation of Section 30 of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act. PUCSL Chairman Janaka Ratnayake in a letter to Cabinet Secretary W.M.D.J. Fernando with regard to the recent proposal to raise electricity tariffs in 2023 said the CEB was instructed to perform the five conditions since 2013 to determine the reasonableness of cost reflective tariff. Those conditions were establishment of Bulk Supply Transactions Account, execution of Power Purchase Agreements between CEB Generation plants and Transmission Licensee, execution of Power Sales Agreements between Transmission Licensee and Distribution Licensees, transparency in Merit Order Dispatch and independent dispatch audit and long-term fuel supply agreements. Ratnayake said the consumer tariff determining methodology is possible under the tariff methodology and a cost reflective tariff is a legal requirement under Section 30 of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act, which the Commission has to adhere to. However, the Act only allows passing reasonable costs to the consumers. He said in the letter that the determination of the reasonableness of the costs is a function of the Commission under Section 30 of the Act, and in this regard, the Commission has directed CEB to perform the following conditions since 2013 to determine the reasonableness of costs. “However, CEB has not taken action for 10 long years to adhere those requirements and it is impossible to judge the reasonableness of the costs submitted by the CEB. Therefore, CEB shall complete these requirements before any tariff revision. Otherwise, it is a violation of the law as well as it is grossly unfair by the consumer,” it said. Therefore, the PUCSL has directed the CEB to complete these requirements before any tariff revision, citing otherwise, it is a violation of the law as well as it is grossly unfair by the consumer.

title: State sector executives to get salaries after due date
author: Author not found
Content: Taking the current financial crisis into consideration, the Cabinet of Ministers has decided to delay the salaries of the executive grade officers in the State sector, while ensuring salaries of non-executive staff are paid on the usual salary date. Accordingly, the monthly salaries of executive officers in the State sector will be paid after some days from the exact salary date. It was revealed that this was due to the implementation of new revenue proposals of the government that is now underway for the year 2023 and since a considerable time would be needed for collecting the income generated from that, government expenditure has to be managed for the next few months from January to cater to the government’s financial inflow.

title: India to back debt restructuring plan
author: Author not found
Content: India, which provided financial, economic, and humanitarian assistance totalling nearly USD 4 billion last year alone, has informed the International Monetary Fund (IMF) that they “will support Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring plan,” which has been a stumbling block in Sri Lanka’s pursuit of the IMF’s USD 2.9 billion loan facility at a time when Sri Lanka is hard-hit financially. Bloomberg reported yesterday (17) that India formally notified that it would support Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring plan and also quoted President Ranil Wickremesinghe as saying that Sri Lanka’s debt negotiations with China and India are “successful.” The three major donor countries, China, Japan, and India, were requested to restructure their loans, a pre-condition tabled by the IMF to obtain the bailout package. India’s support for Sri Lanka’s IMF facility comes as India’s Minister of External Affairs, Dr. S. Jaishankar, plans to visit Sri Lanka on 19 January, where he will meet stakeholders and discuss debt restructuring. Last week, President Wickremesinghe endorsed his visit. Japan said some months ago that it will proceed with other development projects, but that Sri Lanka must first obtain an IMF loan. Japan stated in August that it is critical for the Sri Lankan Government to collaborate with the IMF and the Paris Club to improve the country’s economic and financial position while maintaining openness. Japan also stated that it will continue to think about how to respond to this scenario while keeping a careful eye on such trends and the situation in Sri Lanka, as well as talking with Sri Lanka and other donors and international organisations. China’s Communist Party (CPC) Vice Minister and Head of the CPC International Department Chen Zhou, who was in Sri Lanka a few days ago, told Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, “Sri Lanka is a very special friend of China, and we are considering how we could assist Sri Lanka to get over the current crisis,” and he had assured the Prime Minister, “You will have some good news soon.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: CPC suspends operations at 54 filling stations
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) has taken action against 54 filling stations between 1 and 17 January, for failing to adhere to guidelines of implementing the QR code system for fuel sales. According to a spokesman for the Ministry of Power and Energy, operations at 28 filling stations had been suspended from 1 January to 16 January. However, the suspension was lifted thereafter. The CPC once again suspended fuel distribution and operations at 26 filling stations, which is the highest number in a day so far, yesterday (17), for failing to follow guidelines. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera, on 16 January, directed CPC officers to temporarily halt operations at fuel stations that do not use the QR system. A progress review meeting was held with CPC and CPSTL officials to discuss fuel ordering and distribution. The immediate recovery of Rs 105 billion owed to CPC by CEB for an uninterrupted fuel supply and the continuation of refinery operations was also discussed. The Ministry will release petrol, diesel, and clear a Murban crude oil shipment today (18). A 40,000 MT diesel shipment will be released today after the ministry makes the required payment. Meanwhile, a 94,000 MT Murban crude oil shipment will be released today after the ministry makes the payment, and a 35,300 MT petrol shipment will be cleared today. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Two gruesome murders in one day
author: Author not found
Content: Two cold blooded murders were reported in Colombo and Kandy yesterday (17). The body of a female student of the University of Colombo was found at the Race Course Ground in Colombo 7 near the scoreboard at the ground, yesterday morning. The 23-year-old victim was a third-year student at Science Faculty of University of Colombo. She died due to excessive bleeding caused by deep cut wounds around her neck. The Police arrested a male student of the same faculty of the university in Wellampitiya, along with the murder weapon. Cinnamon Gardens Police have launched an investigation. Meanwhile, a security guard of a leading boys’ school in Kandy was found dead inside a room at the school’s sports complex yesterday (17). An investigation into the death was launched based on a complaint received by the Kandy Police. Police said the victim was found with his hands tied and mouth gagged. The victim is a 27-year-old resident of Hanwella. Kandy Police are conducting investigations to determine the cause of death. By Hashan Pushpika – Pannipitiya and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Sirisena insists on FR laws being amended
author: Author not found
Content: A seemingly distressed former President Maithripala Sirisena, who was ordered by the Supreme Court to pay Rs 100 million in compensation for the victims of the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks, insisted in Parliament yesterday (17) on the need to amend laws pertaining to hearing Fundamental Rights petitions in the Supreme Court enabling respondents too to be given a chance to have their voice heard. Making a statement in the House, Sirisena blamed the officials under him, at that time, for not carrying out their responsibilities properly and said he is being penalised for others’ crimes. “Some claim I was fined by the Supreme Court. But this is not a fine, but compensation. I only have to pay this because the officials who were under my purview, at that time, did not carry out their responsibilities properly, not because of a fault of mine,” he claimed. However, since he is economically incapable of paying Rs. 100 million he will seek assistance from his friends and well-wishers and somehow compensate the victims, he added. Speaking further, Sirisena said the Supreme Court verdict clearly stated that he, as the then President, had not been informed about the intelligence information on the Easter Attacks by the responsible officials. The SC also observed that the President should take the responsibility for any offences committed by any official appointed by him and that he had to pay compensation only on that basis, he claimed. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Tangalle DS officials in hot water
author: Author not found
Content: Officials of Tangalle Divisional Secretariat are in hot water after publishing a notice to use death certificate applications when applying for birth certificates. This was after a photograph of the controversial notice went viral on social media yesterday (17). When Ceylon Today inquired about this from Tangalle Divisional Secretariat, an official said the decision was taken as the stock of paper at the office had run out. “Many Divisional Secretariats are facing similar problems owing to a paper shortage and this was a temporary solution. We informed the Registrar General’s Department as well,” the official said. However, speaking to Ceylon Today, the Assistant Registrar General (Southern Province) denied that he gave approval to use death certificate applications when applying for birth certificates. Registrar General P.S.B. Abeywardena said this controversy occurred only due to an arbitrary decision taken by the Tangalle Divisional Secretariat. “There are enough birth certificate applications at the Registrar General’s Department and the officials have to place orders when their stocks run low. The department has printed 400,000 applications for birth certificates. An investigation will be launched into this incident,” he said. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: PM contradicts Hapuhinna
author: Author not found
Content: Public Administration Ministry Secretary Neel Hapuhinna appears to be in hot water for sending a controversial letter to District Secretaries, ordering them not to accept LG Polls deposits, with Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, who is also the Public Administration Minister, vouching in Parliament that the Cabinet never took any decision to halt accepting deposits. In response to a question raised by Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake, the PM said the Cabinet did not take such a decision last week and if someone claims so, it is completely false. Dissanayake said it was the Cabinet Secretary who informed both the Election Commission and the Public Administration Ministry Secretary. “If what the PM says is true, someone like the Cabinet Secretary spreading such false claims is very serious situation,” Dissanayake pointed out. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, who also joined the discussion, said Gunawardena also should take the responsibility for the chaos created after Hapuninna’s controversial letter. Gunawardena then said, as the Public Administration Minister, he never instructed to send such a directive. “The Secretary withdrew the letter on the same day. There are instances in the past where ministry secretaries sent letters and withdrew them on the same day,” he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: China strongly opposes Dalai Lama’s planned visit to SL
author: Author not found
Content: In the wake of a group of high-ranking Sri Lankan Buddhist Monks, who were on a pilgrimage to Bodh Gaya recently, seeking His Holiness Dalai Lama’s visit to Sri Lanka, Chinese Embassy Chargé d’affaires Hu Wei visited Kandy recently and called on the Mahanayake Thera of the Malwathu Chapter, Most Venerable Thibbatuwawe Sri Siddhartha Sumangala Thera to stress that the Government and people of China including in the Tibet Autonomous Region strongly oppose any foreign country to receive the Dalai Lama in any name. The Chinese Envoy claimed that the 14th Dalai Lama is absolutely not a “simple monk” as he self-claimed, but the head of the feudal serfdom and the theocracy in Tibet prior to 1951 and a political exile disguised as a religious figure that has long been engaging in anti-China separatist activities and attempting to split Tibet from China. The Embassy said at the visit on 11 January, Wei had a friendly conversation about the millennia-close exchanges between the two peoples and Buddhist communities of the two countries, as well as China’s firm support to all walks of life in Sri Lanka to fight against the Covid-19 pandemic and the economic crisis. The issue of the 14th Dalai Lama’s intention to visit Sri Lanka was also discussed The Embassy added that by smashing the lies of the Dalai Lama group; the Chinese Chargé d’affaires briefed the Mahanayake Thera that in the Dalai Lama era, about 1 million people were serfs accounting for 95 per cent of Tibet’s population. Its GDP was only 129 million RMB and the Life Expectancy was only 35.5 years (in 1951). Under the leadership of the Communist Party of China, the Tibetan people are now enjoying a prosperous economy with a GDP of RMB 210 billion (31 billion USD) and the GDP per capita of USD 8,000 (twice of Sri Lanka and 4 times of India where he resides now), the longevity of 72.19 years on average and freedom of religion with 46,000 monks and nuns in over 1,700 temples in Tibet. According to Indian news agency ANI, Waskaduwe Mahindawansa Mahanayaka Thera, Sri Sambuddha Sasanodaya Sangha Sabha stated in an interview, “India helped His Holiness Dalai Lama, and today we know thousands of tourists are at Bodh Gaya because of His Holiness.” “These days, Bodh Gaya is really cold, and people typically don’t come, but they come because of His Holiness,” he added. “Bodh Gaya benefits in a variety of ways. Is Tibet gaining anything? We should ponder about this part also.” The high-ranking monk wished the Dalai Lama would visit Sri Lanka and assist in overcoming the country’s present economic difficulties. “As His Holiness has been to Bodh Gaya, I believe. If he visits Sri Lanka, tens of thousands of tourists will visit, boosting the economy because we are in a slump. And, if His Holiness visits Sri Lanka, many tourists will flock here, as they did to Bodh Gaya. We will be blessed, and the economy will benefit as well,” he explained. The meeting with the Dalai Lama apparently impressed Makulewe Wimala Mahanayaka Thera, Mahanayaka Thera of Ramanna Maha Nikaya, who said “We were delighted to meet His Holiness the Dalai Lama, a spiritual leader. We have a grasp on spiritual activity. As a result, Mahasangha from Sri Lanka is pleased to witness what His Holiness is accomplishing.” Ven. Muruddeniya Dhammarathana Thera of the Asgiriya Chapter further said they are overjoyed because Bodh Gaya is like our motherland because Lord Buddha attained enlightenment there and they love that location.  However, We emphasised that China and Sri Lanka have been firmly supporting each other on issues concerning each other’s core interests, including the Tibet-related issue. Both sides, especially the Buddhist communities, must prevent a sneaky visit of the Dalai Lama to the island to promote “Tibetan independence” and safeguard the China-Sri Lanka historical relations from being damaged. The Chinese Embassy said Most Venerable Malwathu Mahanayaka Thera highly appraised the close friendship between Sri Lanka and China dating from Ven. Faxian Thera’s visit the island 1,600 years ago, and Chinas continued support to Sri Lanka since the latter’s independence, particularly during former PM Sirimavo Bandaranaike’s time. In the last three years of fighting against the Covid-19 and economic crisis, China has been assisting us greatly with PPEs, vaccines, rice, diesel etc., which is fully appreciated by the Sri Lanka people including the Maha Sangha. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Cabinet green lights Truth and Reconciliation mechanism
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers gave its approval for necessary action to be taken to implement a truth and reconciliation concept mechanism. The joint Cabinet paper was submitted by the President, Prime Minister, Minister of Fisheries, Minister of Education, Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, Minister of Urban Development and Housing and the Minister of Foreign Affairs. The requirement of an independent local mechanism, to search for the truth, as a meaningful way to take forward the peace achieved after ending the 30-year conflict and to secure it, is apparent. Sri Lanka has established several independent investigation commissions to seek reconciliation after the conflict and therefore the accomplishment all the recommendations of those commissions is vital.

title: Rs 5B needed for 14 days – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: The Government must find Rs 5 billion to ensure uninterrupted power supply during the G.C.E. Advanced Level Examination, which begins on 23 January, and will last for 14 days. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera informed Cabinet about the costs of providing uninterrupted power during this period. Speaking at the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (17), Gunawardana, quoting Wijesekera, said Rs 357 million will be required per day to provide uninterrupted power supply. “Wijesekera said he will make sure children have continuous electricity supply on the days of the examination. However, he said the CEB will need to find Rs 357 million per day for 14 days, totalling Rs 5 billion.” By Thameenah Razeek

title: Motorcycle gunmen take another life
author: Author not found
Content: An individual was shot dead by two unidentified gunmen who arrived on a motorcycle in Peliyagoda yesterday (17). Police said the shooting had taken place when the victim was in his house in Peliyagoda. According to Police, the victim, who was injured in the shooting, was pronounced dead on admission to the Colombo National Hospital. Investigations showed that the victim was released from prison a few weeks ago and has several murder cases pending against him. Peliyagoda Police are conducting investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Debt structuring talks with India, China successful
author: Author not found
Content: Discussions with India and China with regard to debt structuring are successful at present, President Ranil Wickremesinghe informed Parliament yesterday (17). The President, who attended yesterday’s Parliamentary sitting, made a statement on progress of debt restructuring, 75th Independence Day celebrations and future plans of the Government. “At present, we are working to get our economy on the right track. Now we have to get India and China to consent to this debt restructuring. We are continuing discussions in that regard and I am pleased to announce that the discussions are successful at present. However, we would not get the income we expect at once,” he said. The President said the priority of the Government is paying salaries and pensions. “We should also provide the Samurdhi. Similarly, two more new programmes on social welfare will be implemented and we have to provide money for that too. We have been accused of not providing money for medicines,” he further said. “The problem is Sri Lanka is due Rs 50 billion for medicines we bought for the last few years. Nevertheless, we will allocate Rs 30-40 billion to purchase medicine this year,” the President added. By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: BROKER, TWO GRAMA NILADHARIS ARRESTED
author: Author not found
Content: A broker and two Grama Niladharis were arrested by the Colombo Crime Division (CCD) in connection with a kidney transplant racket run at a private hospital in Borella. The Police Media Division said the CCD had launched an investigation after several complaints were received by the Borella Police Station regarding a kidney transplant racket run at a private hospital in Borella promising large sums of money to low-income persons. During investigations, a 32-year-old resident of Colombo 13, who was operating as a key broker in this racket was arrested on 16 January at Armour Street. In addition, two Grama Niladharis of Kolonnawa and Sri Jayewardenepura Kotte were arrested for aiding and abetting the racket by providing forged documents. The suspects, both aged 59, are residents of Rajagiriya and Kaduwela. The Colombo Crime Division is conducting investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi
