We have been accused of not providing money for medicines,” he further said. “The problem is Sri Lanka is due Rs 50 billion for medicines we bought for the last few years. Nevertheless, we will allocate Rs 30-40 billion to purchase medicine this year,” the President added. By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: BROKER, TWO GRAMA NILADHARIS ARRESTED
author: Author not found
Content: A broker and two Grama Niladharis were arrested by the Colombo Crime Division (CCD) in connection with a kidney transplant racket run at a private hospital in Borella. The Police Media Division said the CCD had launched an investigation after several complaints were received by the Borella Police Station regarding a kidney transplant racket run at a private hospital in Borella promising large sums of money to low-income persons. During investigations, a 32-year-old resident of Colombo 13, who was operating as a key broker in this racket was arrested on 16 January at Armour Street. In addition, two Grama Niladharis of Kolonnawa and Sri Jayewardenepura Kotte were arrested for aiding and abetting the racket by providing forged documents. The suspects, both aged 59, are residents of Rajagiriya and Kaduwela. The Colombo Crime Division is conducting investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Contributory pension scheme on the cards – PM
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is considering introducing a contributory pension scheme for State sector employees who were recruited to the service after 2016, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said in Parliament. In response to a question raised in Parliament by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Eran Wickramaratne, Gunawardena said the Good Governance Government also considered introducing such a pension scheme, but they had not taken any steps with regard to this when the new Government was elected. It has been proposed by the Interim Budget 2022 to introduce a Contributory Pension Scheme Bill for this purpose. This should be introduced this year and we are taking necessary steps, the PM said. By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Three protesters arrested at IUSF protest
author: Author not found
Content: Three protesters were arrested by Kollupitiya and Cinnamon Gardens Police during a protest organised by the Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) in Colombo on Monday (16). A restraining order was issued by the Colombo Chief Magistrate preventing the protesters from entering the Galle Face Green and Hospital Square from Lipton Circus, Police said. Tear gas and water cannons were fired to disperse the protesters who obstructed the traffic and the public. Two of the protesters were arrested by the Colombo South Crime Division and were handed over to Kollupitiya Police Station while the other protester was arrested by the Cinnamon Gardens Police. They are 52, 62 and 43-year-old residents of Pepiliyana, Pugoda and Yakkala. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Rs 16B needed to hold LG Polls – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said, at least Rs 16 billion is needed to hold Local Government Elections. He was speaking at the Cabinet media briefing held yesterday (17). When queried how the Government will bear the expenses of an election at a time when managing public expenditure is problematic, and whether money will have to be printed for this purpose, Gunawardana said it is not possible to print money for an election. “The Treasury Secretary said he will provide funds in instalments to hold the election. If the election is announced, we are ready to face it,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Cabinet slashes 6% of recurrent expenditure
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet decided to freeze 6 per cent of the recurrent expenditure from the Government expenditure estimations approved for the year 2023. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said it was decided to suspend 5 per cent of the recurrent expenditure in the Government expenditure estimations for the year 2023 at the Cabinet meeting held on 9 January so that sufficient financial provisions can be ensured for the control of government expenditure within the existing limited financial space as well as the finances for essential and priority activities. Speaking at the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday, he said expected actions to be taken by the General Treasury for implementing those decisions were submitted to Cabinet by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies. Thus, Cabinet decided to withhold 6 per cent from the recurrent provisions in approved government expenditure estimations instead of 5 per cent from the recurrent expenditure decided at the discussion and allocate a portion equal to 1 per cent of that to the Ministry of Health as additional provisions to purchase essential medicines. By Thameenah Razeek

title: VRS for redundant employees – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman, Minister Bandula Gunawardana yesterday (17) said, he has informed all secretaries heading the ministries under his purview to implement a voluntary retirement scheme for all institutions coming under respective ministries with redundant employees. He said this was suggested as part of public sector restructuring process. Gunawardana was responding to a question posed by the media on whether Government institutions are being restructured. He also said several institutions have been notified that those will be merged and that institutions with no specific role will be nullified. “For example, the Road Development Authority oversees four additional companies. They requested that they be merged into one company. Such actions are ongoing, but take time. Because, according to the law, it must be done in such a way that the potential loss to those employees is minimised. It is planned,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Travel ban on Cabraal extended
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawela yesterday (17) further extended, until 16 February, the foreign travel ban imposed on the former Central Bank Governor Ajith Nivard Cabraal. The order was delivered when a private plaint filed by former Governor of the Southern Province Rajith Keerthi Tennakoon, was called before Additional Magistrate Kekunawala last morning. The plaintiff has alleged that during his tenure as the Central Bank Governor from 2006 to 2015, Cabraal had paid a sum of USD 6.5 million to Pakistani-American political donor Imaad Zuberi, without the approval of Cabinet of Ministers and thereby is responsible for criminal breach of trust and criminal abuse of funds. According to the plaintiff, the former Governor of the CBSL, had flouted Provisions contained in Sections 388, 386 and 392 of the Penal Code, as well as the Provisions contained in Section 55 (1) of the Registered Stock and Securities Ordinance No. 7 of 1937, via his actions. He also charged Cabraal with causing a loss of USD 500 million to the Government, through sovereign bonds due on 18 January 2022, while serving as the CBSL Governor. According to the plaintiff, the Sri Lankan Government had incurred a loss of Rs 10 billion, through the appointing of close relatives to positions and through the release of confidential information on Treasury bills and bond issues, during his tenure as the Governor of the CBSL. When the case was convened, the Attorney raised preliminary objections, to which the Defence Counsels, were ordered to file written submissions when the case is next heard on the said date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: FUTA to hand over petition against new tax reforms today
author: Author not found
Content: A petition signed by over 3,000 university lecturers against newly introduced tax reforms, will be handed over to the Presidential Secretariat at 1.00 p.m. today (18). The Federation of University Teachers’ Association (FUTA) said this petition was signed opposing the tax in response to the significant increase in taxes by the current Government. Accordingly, over 3,000 university lecturers have signed this petition and it has the support of numerous economic experts and civil society organisations. FUTA said the tax increase is not only unnecessary, but also harmful to the economy and could have lasting effects. “Therefore, we urge that the government reconsider its decision and look into alternate methods of revenue generation that are more just, more equitable and less harmful to our economy,” the FUTA said.

title: SJB, SLFP hand in deposits for Anuradhapura District
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), on 16 January, tendered their deposits for Local Government Election in the Anuradhapura District.  After handing in the SJB deposits, former MPs P. Harrison and Chandrani Bandara addressed the media. Harrison said, the SJB would receive a landslide victory at the LG elections therefore the party does not need to go into an alliance with anybody. According to Bandara, those who were elected from Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) at the last LG election are now requesting the SJB to give them the opportunity to contest the upcoming Poll on the SJB ticket. “This is because they are now ashamed to go to the villages and request for votes. Everyone knows what ‘Pohottuwa’ did to the country. Although, there is a party called NPP, everyone knows that it is another face of the JVP. So, people know who they are and how they destroyed the country in the past. The only party that people can vote for without hesitation is SJB,” she said. Meanwhile, after handing in the SLFP deposits, former MP Weerakumara Dissanayake said, everyone should vote for the SLFP as it is the only reliable party for the people to vote. “Unlike others, the SLFP served the people in this country for 70 years. We have the capability to develop the villages. The SLFP, under the hand symbol, will contest all the LG authorities in the country,” Dissanayake said.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Delegation of investors led by UAE Royalty visits PCC
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation of investors from the United Arab Emirates, led by His Royal Highness Sheikh Mohammed Bin Maktoum Bin JumaAl Maktoum, visited Port City Colombo on the 14 January. Discussions were held between the members of the delegation, representatives from the Colombo Port City Economic Commission (CPCEC) and Port City Colombo (PCC) with a view to attracting foreign direct investments to the project. The delegation was given a comprehensive overview of Port City Colombo’s development and plans for the future, which the delegation commended, followed by a tour of PCC Marina. Port City Colombo is a large-scale development project covering an area of 269 hectares of reclaimed land. It aims to serve as a new economic hub for the country, offering a range of commercial and residential opportunities. The project is expected to bring significant economic benefits to Sri Lanka, including job creation and increased foreign investment.

title: Connectivity between State institutions needed – Withanage
author: Author not found
Content: When dealing with increasing the rank of Sri Lanka’s Ease of Doing Business Index, an interconnection should be maintained between related State institutions, MP Madhura Withanage said. He made this remark recently (12), when the Parliament Select Committee, appointed to study the practical problems and difficulties that have arisen in relation to enhancing the rank in the Ease of Doing Business Index in Sri Lanka, met in Parliament. Officials representing eight Presidential Task Forces, established under the Office of the President’s Secretariat for Business Facilitation in Sri Lanka, were present for the committee meeting and they pointed out the concerns and suggestions related to raising the Index of Ease of Doing Business in their respective fields by way of presentations. Matters mainly related to the financial sector and land and property registration were discussed. The committee was of the opinion that the efficiency of the work can be increased by using online technology in the related fields. Furthermore, there was a lengthy discussion about the support that the Central Bank of Sri Lanka can provide in terms of starting new businesses and encouraging entrepreneurs. MPs Mohamad Muzammil, Sanjeeva Edirimanna, Lalith Varna Kumara were present at the Committee meeting.

title: New SL Envoy to Venezuela presents credentials
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the Republic of Cuba, Lakshitha Pradeep Ratnayake, who is concurrently accredited as Ambassador to the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, presented Letters of Credence to Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro at the Presidential House in Caracas on 10 January. During a brief conversation following the ceremony, the Venezuelan President warmly welcomed the new Ambassador and extended his wishes for the latter’s successful tenure of office as the Sri Lankan Ambassador to Venezuela. President Maduro emphasised the need to boost relations between the two countries to face global political and economic challenges in the future. He also expressed that his country is keen to open avenues for Sri Lankans to explore investment opportunities in the fields of petroleum, natural gas, and gold. Ambassador Ratnayake conveyed the good wishes of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. He assured the Venezuelan President that he will explore all avenues to establish close economic relations and expand the level of bilateral cooperation, especially in the areas of international relations, healthcare, ICT, agriculture and maritime cooperation for the mutual benefit of the two countries. During the visit, Ambassador Ratnayake held meetings with Venezuelan Vice Minister for Asia, the Middle East, and Oceania Capaya Rodríguez and Venezuelan Vice Minister for Multilateral Affairs and Integration Rubén Darío Molina. Ambassador Ratnayake has worked at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs since 1998, and was the Director General of Asset Management and Development, Ministry of Foreign Affairs prior to his appointment in Havana.

title: CPA Secy Gen Twigg meets Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary General of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) Stephen Twigg, who arrived in the island on 10 January, met Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana recently. He also met Leader of the House Minister Susil Premajayantha. A separate discussion was also held with MP Yadamini Gunawardena and State Minister Dr. Suren Raghavan. During the discussions, Twigg laid special emphasis on the CPA Parliamentary Academy, which was initiated as a central learning hub for Commonwealth Parliamentarians and parliamentary officials and stated that the purpose of the said initiation has been extended to anyone who wishes to learn about Parliaments and key thematic topics. He elaborated on the importance of extending women representation in Parliaments across the Commonwealth Parliaments. Twigg, accompanied by Emily Davies, Head of Strategy and Engagement of the CPA, also met Secretary General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadheera and Assistant Secretary General of Parliament Tikiri Jayathilaka for a cordial discussion followed by a special tour around Parliament. The CPA Secretary General also met senior officials of Parliament staff and discussed future opportunities and areas of improvements.

title: PPCP calls for report on Dr. Sanjeewa’s suspension
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Petitions Committee of Parliament (PPCP) has called for a report, from the Health Ministry, regarding the suspension of Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa, President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), who was serving at the Ministry. In a letter to Dr. Sanjeewa, the Public Petitions Committee said it had decided to call for a report from the Health Ministry, following receiving approval from the Speaker, regarding the suspension of his duties prior to proceeding with an investigation into the incident. The decision to call for the report had been taken after SJB MP Rohini Kumari Wijeratne submitted Dr. Sanjeewa’s petition to the Speaker. Dr. Sanjeewa, in several separate media briefings, revealed accounts of the fast sagging nutrition levels of the country due to the economic crisis, the losses incurred by the Health Ministry due to emergency purchasing due to the country’s drug shortage and the large number of lives which could have been saved if proper scientific methods had been followed when handing the pandemic. Meanwhile, the International Human Rights Commission and International Refugee Organisations had also expressed concern regarding Dr. Sanjeewa’s suspension. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Navy apprehends narcotics carrying trawlers
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy apprehended 10 suspects and two local fishing trawlers, which were suspected to have smuggled narcotics into the island. The suspects and the fishing trawlers were escorted to the Port of Colombo yesterday (16). The arrests were made based on information revealed by a group on local fishing trawler, which was held during a special operation carried out by the Navy in waters west of Beruwala on 5 January. The same operation also led to the seizing of nearly 23.5 kg (including packages) of heroin smuggled by those suspects.  In order to curb illegal activities, including the smuggling of drugs via sea routes, Sri Lanka Navy conducts regular patrols and operations in the coastal and beach areas of the island. According to a coordinated operation carried out by the Navy together with other intelligence services, it has been revealed that a number of local multi-day fishing trawlers are involved in the smuggling of drugs into Sri Lanka. During the arrests made by SLNS Wickrama II on 5 January off Beruwala, 22 packages of heroin weighing 23kg and 235g (including packages) were seized from the suspicious trawler (Reg. No. IMUL–A –1610–MTR Kingfisher – 6). Along with the consignment of narcotics, five suspects and the drug-carrying trawler were also taken into custody. Based on information revealed by the suspects apprehended in that operation, two more local multi-day fishing trawlers (Reg. No. IMUL–A–1888–MTR Kingfisher – 8 and IMUL–A–2029–MTR Kingfisher – 3), suspected of smuggling drugs to Sri Lanka were intercepted off the western coast by SLNS Gajabahu on 7 and 8 January. During interrogation, the suspects aboard those trawlers admitted that they had thrown the stocks of narcotics overboard due to the presence of the Navy. The interrogation also revealed that drug traffickers have developed a new strategy in which they remove inside components of the multi-day fishing trawlers’ Radar Domes and conceal drugs within. The two fishing trawlers brought ashore are currently being inspected. Meanwhile, the fishing trawlers and 10 suspects will be handed over to the Police Narcotic Bureau for onward legal proceedings.

title: Police use tear gas, water cannon to disperse IUSF protest
author: Author not found
Content: Tear gas and water cannons were fired to disperse the protest organised by Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) at St Anthony’s Road, Kollupitiya yesterday (16). The protest was orginsed demanding the release of IUSF Convener Wasantha Mudalige. A restraining order was issued by the Colombo Chief Magistrate preventing the protestors from entering the Galle Face Green in Colombo from Lipton Circus via Union Place. Owing to firing of tear gas and water cannon, Duplication Road in Kollupitiya had to be shut to motorists for some time. (Pix by Kelum Chamara)

title: Wildlife Dept earns Rs 1.4B
author: Author not found
Content: The Wildlife Department earned a revenue of Rs 1.4 billion by November 2022 and majority of that was through licence fees. Also, the department earned an amount of Rs 7.7 million in 2022 through filing lawsuits against various individuals for damage to forest and wildlife. This was revealed in a discussion held by Minister of Agriculture, Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera with the Department of Wildlife. During the discussion, Amaraweera advised the department officials to start programmes to attract foreign tourists to the Yala, Wilpattu and Wasgamuwa National Parks. The Minister also mentioned that since foreign tourists are returning to the country, measures should be taken to open additional ticket counters so they can visit national parks without delays.

title: Govt should widen current tax net
author: Author not found
Content: If the Government conducts random checks to see if the owners of luxury vehicles, houses and apartments are paying their taxes properly, the tax net could be easily expanded, the Association of Medical Specialists (AMS) said. AMS President and General Secretary, Drs Lakkumar Fernando and R. Gnanasekeram yesterday (16) said the apathy and the snail pace action of authorities to widen the tax net and the Inland Revenue Department’s over- dependence on compliant tax payers, has caused loss of valuable tax income to the State. “There was a time in the past where vehicles were even checked for car radio licences, but the current practices are deliberately designed to protect the very rich who have power and political connections,” the duo alleged. They urged all tax payers, both PAYE and otherwise, to demand that the Government enact and strictly enforce regulations to obtain appropriate taxes on non-cash benefits from all without sparing its favourites. “The Government should widen the current tax net, creating a level playing field for all. If the Government delays this process, it will not only lose a large amount of tax money, but it will also force a considerable number of skilled professionals and entrepreneurs to leave the country in frustration,” they warned. Increasing tax rates was inevitable due to the unprecedented deterioration of the country’s economy.  The Government raised the income and other taxes to improve the State revenue, which has failed to reach the desired levels while adversely affecting the entire economy of the country. The AMS alleged that certain influential persons, who were entitled to a wide variety of ‘non-cash benefits’ would not pay the correct amount of taxes due to deficiencies in the regulations which governed tax collection. “Non-cash benefits include provision of a vehicle or in some cases several vehicles, driver, a certain quota of fuel in litres per each vehicle, domestic aides and an official residence, all provided at the expense of the employer.” The duo pointed out. In the case of those who receive remuneration from the State, all ‘non-cash benefits’ were funded by tax payers, they pointed out. Drs. LakKumar and Gnanasekeram noted that it was important to accurately calculate the tax one has to pay for all non-cash benefits they enjoyed, on the pretext of ‘entitlement’, in fairness to other tax payers. It’s also important that calculation of “’non-cash benefits’ should strictly be based on current market rates and values to avoid under taxation, the duo added. (DJ)

title: Kite festival held in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: The annual kite festival in Jaffna, with gigantic kites decorating the skies, was held on Sunday (15). The festival was held at the Valvettithurai beach as part of the Thai Pongal celebrations, organised by the Valvettithurai Udayasooriyan Sports Club and the Vigneshwara Committee. The youths flew a variety of extraordinary kites that elaborated their culture, leaving the people awestruck at seeing their creations flying high in the sky. (SRM)

title: Cabinet gives go ahead to provide 10kg of rice
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet approved President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s proposal to provide 10kg of rice per month to two million low income families, including Samurdhi beneficiaries, for a period of two months, the President’s Media Division said yesterday (16). The Government will purchase 61,600 MT of paddy to meet the requirement of 40,000 MT of rice. This programme is proposed to be implemented by District Secretaries and Divisional Secretaries, with the assistance of small and medium-scale paddy mills. Under the District Secretaries and Divisional Secretaries, rice will be distributed among the identified Samurdhi beneficiaries, including low-income earners using the existing system and the Ministry of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment will coordinate the District Secretaries and issue necessary instructions to them. The total estimated cost for this programme is eight billion rupees, which includes Rs 6.2 billion for paddy purchase, Rs 290 million for rice drying, Rs 590 million as milling charges, Rs 200 million for packing costs, Rs 160 million as additional payment to mill owners and Rs 600 million for transportation. However, the programme’s estimated cost will vary depending on market fluctuations, and a budget provision of around Rs 10 billion will be allocated to be used if the need arises. According to data from the Departments of Agriculture and Agrarian Development, the land extent used for paddy cultivation, in the 2022/2023 Maha season, is approximately 732,201 hectares, and the expected yield is 3.3 million MT, while approximately 2.2 million MT of rice can be produced.  Given the country’s monthly rice requirement of approximately 210,000 MT, it has been observed that the next Maha season may see a paddy surplus. As a result, in order to protect both the paddy farmer and the consumer, the government must intervene in the purchase of a specific amount of paddy during the 2022/23 season. Furthermore, due to the country’s extremely difficult economic situation, it is necessary to protect low-income groups of society from the negative effects of the crisis by assisting them in maintaining a good nutritional level. This group consists of approximately two million families, including Samurdhi beneficiaries, the PMD said.

title: SLPP confident of winning LG polls
author: Author not found
Content: Based on the public response thus far, there is no doubt that Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) will win the Local Government authorities that it is contesting at the upcoming Local Government (LG) Election, SLPP General Secretary Sagara Kariyawasam said. He added that although several false protests were prompted by certain sectors, the support for SLPP from the public has been unaffected while stating that several false accusations have also been levelled against the Party and leaders. ‘’For instance, several allegations were levelled against the heads of SLPP in regard to the Easter Sunday attacks but the apex Court in its verdict decided who were in fact responsible for the attacks,” he said. The nominations list for the Local Government (LG) Election is currently being drafted, he said adding that all necessary steps to face the Election have also successfully been adopted. Meanwhile, when queried about newly formed Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya (Free People’s Alliance), Kariyawasam said is not a threat to SLPP in the upcoming election. He claimed that this alliance has been formed by a group of individuals who previously represented SLPP and robbed public votes for their personal agendas.  “The fact that the alliance does not have a leader is clear evidence that the primary motive of those in the alliance is leadership,” he said questioning on how an alliance without even a leader could head a country. A new coalition titled Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya (Free People’s Alliance) formed by the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), together with several other political parties and the Group of Independent MPs in Parliament, was launched on 11 January to contest the upcoming Local Government Election. The SLFP, Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya, and the group of independent MPs in Parliament are the members of the new coalition. The symbol is the helicopter. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Seven Int’l HR Groups condemn Mudalige’s detention
author: Author not found
Content: Seven international human rights watchdogs yesterday (16) demanded the Government to immediately end the arbitrary detention of Wasantha Mudalige, a student activist who was arrested on 18 August 2022. The Amnesty International, the Asian Forum for Human Rights and Development (FORUM-ASIA), CIVICUS, Frontline Defenders, the Human Rights Watch, the International Working Group on Sri Lanka and the Sri Lanka Campaign for Peace and Justice said that, since 21 August 2022, Mudalige was held in detention for 90 days on orders signed by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), a draconian law that the government had long promised to repeal. They also pointed out that the Sri Lankan authorities should immediately impose a moratorium on the use of the PTA, and promptly repeal it. The authorities should immediately review the detention of anyone held under the PTA, ensuring adequate access to fair bail hearings. They should also release all protesters facing charges that do not meet international standards. A hearing on Mudalige’s bail application has been scheduled for 17 January 2023 at the Hulftsdorp Magistrate’s Court. Under the PTA, the Court does not usually grant bail if the Attorney General’s Department, acting on the Government’s behalf, opposes it. The Sri Lankan Government detained Mudalige as part of its crackdown since an economic crisis in 2022 sparked largely peaceful protests demanding governance reform and action against alleged official corruption. The government responded by giving sweeping powers to the Police and Military, which used unnecessary and excessive force to break up demonstrations and arrest hundreds of people, including many students. Many of those detained have since been released on bail. However, the authorities have used extraordinary powers, under the PTA, to keep Mudalige in detention despite having produced no evidence of any involvement in terrorism. As convenor of the Inter University Students’ Federation, he had taken a prominent part in the protests. For much of the time he has been held in solitary confinement and poor conditions, which can violate the prohibition on torture or other ill-treatment under international human rights law. In December 2022, Mudalige required hospital treatment for breathing difficulties. His family and his lawyer have expressed concern for his safety and his health in detention. On 4 October, the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka issued a notice calling for the Police to ensure Mudalige’s safety in custody. The PTA allows for up to a year of detention without charge on the orders of the Defence Minister, who is currently President Wickremesinghe. Since it was introduced as a ‘temporary’ measure in 1979, the law has been used particularly to target members of the Tamil and Muslim communities and to stifle dissenting voices including journalists and human rights defenders. The United Nations and human rights groups have repeatedly documented that the PTA has been used to enable prolonged arbitrary detention and torture or other ill-treatment.  On 18 August 2022, the authorities arrested Mudalige along with 19 other people during a protest in Colombo, which the Police violently disrupted using excessive force. Two others arrested that day were also detained under the PTA, but both have since been released without charge. Hundreds of people arrested, under ordinary criminal legislation, for offenses allegedly committed during the 2022 protests, such as damage to public property, have also been released on bail. (SRM)

title: Country will be divided if 13A fully enacted – Wimal
author: Author not found
Content: In response to President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s recent pledge in Jaffna, that the 13th Amendment to the Constitution would be fully enacted, National Freedom Front (NFF) Leader Wimal Weerawansa said if Wickremesinghe wants to start over from 2002, when the UNP formed the Government, he should seek a fresh mandate through a Presidential Election. In a letter to the President, Weerawansa said if the pledge was fulfilled, the country would be divided within a short period. He alleged that although the President called for an all-party conference, to discuss solutions to the problems in Northern Province, it seems that he acts in a biased manner towards a certain political party. Wickremesinghe tried to enact federalism twice, but failed. Now he trying to implement his agreements which he failed implement in the past through the all party conference, Weerawansa alleged. “In those two occasions, you (the President) had a mandate from people. But this time, you have no such mandate. Therefore, we cannot agree with your attempts to continue what you tried to do in the past under the guise of an all party conference,” he said. Furthermore, Weerawansa alleged that Wickremesinghe tried to deceive the majority Sinhala Buddhists as the people of the country have become helpless due to the economic crisis, he added. (MD)

title: Maithri abandons helicopter
author: Author not found
Content: Five days after forming a new alliance called the Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya (Free People’s Alliance) to contest the upcoming Local Government election, the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) announced yesterday (16) that the Party decided to go it alone, due to a few unfortunate and sad incidents such as the demise of former Governor Reginald Cooray. This was revealed by former MP Weerakumara Dissanayake after placing the deposits for Anuradhapura District. Dissanayake said former Governor, the Late Reginald Cooray died due to threats, stress and pressure placed on him during the nomination process for the election. “That is very sad. We had to go through few sad situations like that. Therefore, the SLFP Central Committee decided to contest for the election as a single party under the hand symbol. The SLFP agreed to form this alliance with genuine intentions. But it seems some people have taken it as our weakness. The secretary post of the new alliance belongs to them. Some people even tried a conspiracy to destroy the SLFP. They demanded 50% and 60% for them in the nomination list and at the end we unanimously decided to give them the entire 100% and to go it alone at the polls. That is the best solution,” he said. Speaking further, Dissanayake said everyone should vote for the SLFP as it is the only reliable party for the people to vote. “Unlike others, the SLFP served the people in this country for 70 years. We have the capability to develop the villages. The SLFP, under the hand symbol, will contest all the LG authorities in the country,” He said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Jaishankar’s visit aimed at supporting Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: India’s Minister of External Affairs Dr. S. Jaishankar will be visiting Sri Lanka this week to meet stakeholders and discuss debt restructuring, Indian media reported. President Ranil Wickremesinghe last week said Dr. Jaishankar will visit the country on 19 January and Sri Lanka will continue to have debt restructuring talks with India. A report in The Hindu quoted sources in the Indian Government saying that Jaishankar’s visit will focus on “supporting Sri Lanka” in its economic crisis. “India is expected to give a positive response to Sri Lanka’s requirements, in keeping with India’s support last year as well,” the report quoted a source as saying. Sources also said that the talks in the field of energy security, food security, currency swap arrangements as well as talks about restructuring Sri Lanka’s debt are underway. The Hindu report also said that during Jaishankar’s visit, talks are likely on two possible Memorandums of understanding (MoUs) — on the Trincomalee development project and the long-pending plan for a cross-strait transmission line that would enable access for Sri Lanka to India’s plans for an energy grid along with other countries including Nepal, Bhutan and Bangladesh. Jaishankar’s visit holds special significance as it is the first such meeting after the new government in Sri Lanka was formed six months ago. Apart from assisting Colombo with its current economic difficulties being a priority, the Indian foreign minister’s visit to the island nation would also include a comprehensive review of bilateral ties.

title: ‘China Will Soon Have Good News for SL’
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena reminded China’s Communist Party (CPC) Vice Minister  and Head of the CPC International Department  Chen Zhou, that Sri Lanka is looking  forward to China’s support in restructuring its debt, as recommended by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), to obtain the USD 2.9 billion bailout, and further strengthen its economy in the near future, to which, Zhou had responded to the Prime Minister saying,  “You will have some good news soon”. Minister Zhou, who arrived in Sri Lanka on 14 January, briefed the audience at Hotel Shangri-La, on the Communist Party’s 20th National Congress. Prior to meeting the Prime Minister yesterday (16) afternoon, Minister Zhou met major political party leaders, members, China’s friendship associations, scholars and local and international media in the morning at Shangri-La Colombo, in the midst of Sri Lanka seeking a financial bailout from the IMF, which is critical for Sri Lanka but lagging since donor countries, including China, are yet to restructure the loans given to Sri Lanka. On 14 January, Zhou and delegation also paid a visit to President and Leader of the United National Party Ranil Wickremesinghe and delivered a letter from General Secretary of the CPC Central Committee and President of China Xi Jinping. They had a cordial and fruitful discussion about how to strengthen bilateral, pragmatic cooperation and party-to-party exchanges between Sri Lanka and China. President Wickremesinghe stated, during the meeting, “We look forward to China’s support in restructuring Sri Lanka’s debt at the moment and our economy in the near future.” The Prime Minister’s office quoted Zhou as saying, “Sri Lanka is a very special friend of China and we are considering how we could assist Sri Lanka to get over the current crisis,” and he had assured the Prime Minister, “You will have some good news soon”. During the meeting, Chen held a detailed discussion on how to enhance Sri Lanka-China bilateral pragmatic cooperation and party-to-party exchanges between the CPC and progressive political parties in Sri Lanka like Mahajana Eksath Peramuna (MEP). Minister Zhou also donated 1,000 solar power generators to Sri Lanka, which were donated by China’s Communist Party, the Chinese Embassy tweeted. On 15 January, Zhou met former President and Leader of the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna Party MP Mahinda Rajapaksa and some of his party associates. They had a broad discussion about promoting the friendship between China and Sri Lanka, as well as bilateral cooperation and party-to-party exchanges. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Cumaraswamy marks 50 years of dedicated service in Laundry and Dry-cleaning industry
author: Author not found
Content: Amaranath Cumaraswamy completes 50 Years, this year, of continued service in the laundry and dry-cleaning field in Sri Lanka. He started his career 50 years ago (1973) in the Laundry Department at the first five-star hotel in Sri Lanka, the Ceylon Inter-Continental Hotel. Here he had the opportunity to work in the first fully-automated professional laundry and dry cleaning plant in Sri Lanka. Trained under Xavier Salhani, an Italian who was the director for Laundry and dry cleaning for Asian pacific for Inter-Continental Hotel. He was trained in all aspects connected with professional laundry and dry cleaning work. In 1974 he won the first ‘Employee of the month’ award for his outstanding Service in the hotel laundry section. In 1976 he was transferred to Riyadh Inter-Continental Hotel in Saudi Arabia and in 1978 he joined the Ramada Hotel Chain as laundry manager and served for 12 years in Abu Dhabi, Jabel Dhanna and Dubai. In 1988 he returned to Sri Lanka and joined the then Ramada Renaissance Hotel Colombo (Present Cinnamon Lakeside) as Laundry manager There he was responsible for opening of the Drive-in Laundry Counter, Creases and pleats, and today it is the best professional laundry and dry cleaning service outlet in town. After a long stint in the industry, at both local and international hotels, he retired in 2008 in 2009 he joined Sri Lankan Catering as Management Consultant for Laundry and dry cleaning. This was an opportunity for him to share his vast knowledge and experience in opening the laundry and dry cleaning facility at Sri Lanka Catering at Katunayake. The Laundry Service, named Aero clean, was equipped with the best state- of -the- art branded Laundry and dry cleaning equipment in the world to provide laundry and dry cleaned linen and garments at their best and processed approximately 10,000 kg of linen per day. This facility provides direct employment to 85 people, most of them school-leavers who were trained by him in this field. The 24—hour operation provided its services to Sri Lanka Airlines and other international airlines. He also opened a laundry outlet provide laundry and dry cleaning service for outside customers. After completing his consultancy agreement with Sri Lankan Catering in 2012, he joined the Sri Lanka Institute of Tourism and Hotel Management, formerly known as Ceylon Hotel School, as Laundry Manager/ Lecturer, with the opening of the well equipped and fully- automated laundry and dry-cleaning facility at SLITHM, the one and only Laundry & Dry-cleaning training centre in Sri Lanka. For the first time in Sri lanka SLITHM has introduced a three- month management level theory and practical course in professional laundry and dry cleaning operations. The future prospects of the laundry in Sri Lanka look bright and this sector has reached a formal role in providing a professional service for individuals as well as corporate. There is a huge potential for growth in the laundry industry in Sri Lanka and with the present boom in the tourism industry has fuelled growth further. The students who successfully completed the Laundry Course have already found employment in five- star hotels in Colombo and Overseas. The main aim of the course is to train more youngest to take up job opportunities is the field. Since there are lots of job opportunities in Sri Lanka and abroad for skilled laundry staff. This year there will be a few more five-star hotels opening Sri Lanka and SLITHM will be able to provide professionally- trained laundry personnel to take up positions in these new hotels. This specialised course is only conducted by SLITHM and it is envisaged to provide trained personnel to work in five-star hotels, catering services, hospital and commercial laundry and dry cleaning plants in Sri Lanka and abroad.  Cumaraswamy is very optimistic about the future of laundry operations in the county and would like to see more youngsters taking up jobs in this field. A member of the International Fabricare Institute of the USA, he has trained over 400 staff in this field. Some of them are working as laundry managers In Sri Lanka, the Middle East and the Maldives in five-star hotel chains and commercial laundries. Those who wish to follow a career path in this fieled now have an opportunity to make use of the specialised course provided by SLITHM in laundry and dry cleaning operations and be sure of a job opportunity in this booming industry in Sri Lanka and abroad. This Industry needs some recognition in order to stimulate interest of country’s youth to join this industry as there is a proven -career path.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: China and the Sovereign-Debt Bomb
author: Author not found
Content: International capital flows have long been a major source of economic growth. Savings in higher-income countries have financed high-yielding investments in low-income countries, generating benefits for all. After World War II, capital flows under the Marshall Plan drove the rapid reconstruction of Europe, and after those countries recovered, they extended their own foreign aid and other official financial flows to the developing world. Private financing also increased substantially; by the 1990s, it accounted for over half of total capital flows to developing countries. Some of these flows led to spectacular results. South Korea was one of the poorest countries in the world in the 1950s, with a savings rate of only 3% of GDP. But after implementing major policy reforms, it was able to avail itself of large capital inflows to finance investments with very high rates of return. It has since become an advanced economy. High savings and investment rates mean it has no difficulty servicing its debt. But not all low-income countries have pursued macroeconomic and other policies that are conducive to growth. Many have borrowed to cover balance-of-payments deficits and other problems, depleting their foreign-exchange reserves and jeopardising their access to private capital markets. For decades, the international community addressed these problems through the International Monetary Fund and an informal arrangement among official (government) creditors known as the Paris Club. When an indebted country ran into trouble, the IMF stepped in to provide short-term financing and recommend policy reforms designed to put the economy back on a sustainable growth path. Once the Fund and the debtor-country government had agreed on a reform programme, the Paris Club creditors could negotiate a reduction of the existing official bilateral debt to make it sustainable. Implicit in this process was that private creditors also must agree to a similar ‘haircut.’ Otherwise, the IMF’s bailout funds would end up being used to service the country’s debts to the private sector, rather than for restoring economic activity. Although this system for managing crises was far from perfect, it generally worked. But the situation has changed markedly in the past two decades, during which China has become a major lender to developing countries. As of 2022, the world’s 74 lowest-income countries had debt-service obligations totalling USD 35 billion, with  USD 13.1 billion – 37% – owed to China. According to a May 2021 Peterson Institute for International Economics policy brief, China accounts for over 50% of all debt owed by poor countries to official creditors. China’s emergence as a leading creditor has created problems, not least because it has refused an invitation to join the Paris Club. While Paris Club members share information about the sums owed to them, China does not. Nor has it been willing to participate meaningfully in multilateral debt-restructuring arrangements. Instead, it has operated as a black box, attaching nondisclosure agreements to many of its loans, and funnelling credit through a wide range of agencies. In 2020, the G20 – which includes China – agreed on a Common Framework for addressing debt distress in developing countries. But there has been little additional progress since then. This month, Ghana became only the fourth country to apply for support under the facility. Meanwhile, the number of countries facing serious debt-servicing issues has continued to grow. Zambia and Sri Lanka have already defaulted on their loans, and their economies are in deep recession. While Sri Lanka – along with Malawi – has tentatively accepted the terms of a new IMF programme, the agreement cannot be signed (or the funds disbursed) until the debt is made sustainable. But when the existing debt level is unsustainable, the IMF cannot approve the loan without all significant creditors agreeing to a restructuring. The resulting paralysis has put many other poor countries in danger. Tunisia cannot meet its budget without international bond financing. Ghana, already struggling under a heavy debt load, was forced in November to issue a six-month treasury bill with a ruinous 36% interest rate. Pakistan, after being devastated by floods last summer, has foreign-exchange reserves equal to only a month’s imports – well below a level deemed safe. And these are just a few of the countries with debt levels that are, or are likely to become, unsustainable. Without international help, these highly-indebted countries will be confronted with ongoing shortages of electricity, fuel, and other essentials (as we saw in Sri Lanka last year), leading to economic stagnation or decline. As more countries fall into this trap, humanitarian crises and sharp increases in poverty will follow. It is in everyone’s interest to find ways to ensure debt restructuring, along with the necessary economic policy reforms, for countries in dire need. A renewed push on this issue could produce an agreement between China and other creditor countries to the benefit of all. The most promising route, given the IMF’s crucial role in supporting macroeconomic policy reforms, would be to grant the Fund greater authority to deem debt unsustainable. Failure to get ahead of the developing world’s looming debt crises would represent a moral failure, and would also greatly dampen world economic growth, as it would induce greater pressure for protection in advanced countries and spur greater resistance to reforms in developing countries. The result would be prolonged stagnation and depression in debt-ridden economies, with huge humanitarian costs. Anne O. Krueger, a former World Bank chief economist and former first deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, is Senior Research Professor of International Economics at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies and Senior Fellow at the Center for International Development at Stanford University. (Project Syndicate) By Anne O. Krueger

title: Can humanity’s new giant leap into space succeed?
author: Author not found
Content: There is a new order emerging in space – a race between America and China. But with the demands of space exploration, even these great superpowers won’t be able to do it alone. Hugely technically challenging and costly goals have been touted, not least the aim of people living and working on other worlds, possibly within 10 years – but in a divided world where international goodwill is scarce, are they realistic? Nasa’s return to the Moon has begun with its Artemis programme. The first of three missions has been successfully launched. This uncrewed flight tested that the rockets and technology worked. The second mission will take humans further in space than they have ever gone before and the third launch will put astronauts on the Moon for a week, where they will carry out experiments. The long-term goal is to use the Moon as a jumping off point to get to Mars. But the programme is estimated to cost USD 93 billion (£ 76 billion), a heavy price tag for the American taxpayer, who is already feeling the economic squeeze. In a report to Congress last year, the US Auditor General’s office warned of an ‘unrealistic -development schedule’ and likely overruns, adding that Nasa needed to make cost estimates “more reliable and transparent”. Yet, although Nasa will get less overall funding than it asked for in 2023, Congress, at the moment, still supports its human space exploration ventures. China has achieved its own fully-operational space station, Tiangong, in orbit on schedule. The Chinese space programme has launched probes to the Moon and Mars. It plans to establish an unmanned research station on the Moon by 2025 and then land astronauts on its surface by 2030. Putting an astronaut on the Moon has been done before but the next step, to Mars, is much more difficult. It is 250 times further away than the Moon and there is no spacecraft currently capable of sending humans to the red planet. Even if scientists can find a safe way to launch a fuel-heavy rocket and land it on a planet with such a thin atmosphere, there is the further challenge of returning the astronauts safely home after months in space. Historically, superpowers have jostled for supremacy above the Earth. America and Russia vied for dominance in the 1950s and 1960s. The Russians put the first man in orbit. The Americans landed a man and planted their flag on the Moon a few years later. In the 1970s a golden era of cooperation was forged, culminating in the construction of the International Space Station (ISS), which began in 1998. Along with 13 other partner nations, the two superpowers built what is now the largest structure in space. It is not owned by any one nation, and each depends on the other to operate. It was a symbol of what humanity could achieve if nations put aside their differences and worked together. But the reality was somewhat different. Notably America prevented China from becoming a partner in the ISS, so the Chinese went their own way. More recently, within weeks of the invasion of Ukraine, nations stopped working with Russia. Two joint Moon missions between the European Space Agency (ESA) and Russia have been cancelled, as has a joint Mars Rover project to search for signs of life on the red planet. Yet scratch the surface and collaboration continues on the ISS, where Western countries have to work with Russia to maintain it in orbit. Americans and Europeans even still train in the centre of Moscow at Russia’s Space HQ, Star City. But what happens once the ISS comes to the end of its lifetime in 2030? Juliana Suess, a space policy analyst at the Royal United Services Institute think tank in London says Russia has much less to offer partner nations than it once did because its technology is outdated. She raises the possibility that the first nation into space could be the first one out. “If the Russians haven’t figured out an alternative by the time the ISS is decommissioned or develops its own space station, which given the current circumstances and sanctions is quite unlikely, it might not have any human spaceflight,” she says. Russia’s plight comes at a time when China’s space programme is advancing rapidly. In the last 10 years it has launched more than 200 rockets, even though America’s spending on space still makes China’s look small. China is mindful that partnerships offer technical know-how and money. It has invited other nations prohibited from access to the ISS to join them and has made a call for proposals for scientific experiments. Seventy-two countries now have their own space programmes because they can’t afford to be left behind in what has become a new space race. The billionaire spacefarers Space is a vital part of our everyday lives. We depend on satellites for weather forecasts, communications, bank transitions, not to mention valuable surveillance tools for nation States. And it’s getting busy out there. In 2021, about 5,000 satellites were launched. Going back 20 years, about 800 were launched annually. Space is an expensive and technically difficult business. No one country can do it alone. New partnerships are being forged, notably with the new brash billionaires on the block. Elon Musk’s company, SpaceX, is already taking passengers into orbit. The billionaire entrepreneur is bringing down costs with a reusable rocket. Not to be outdone, Amazon’s Jeff Bezos wants to build a commercial orbiting station, called Orbital Reef. Helen Sharman, who was the UK’s first astronaut, on a mission to the Soviet Space Station Mir in 1991, believes that current international rivalries could be put in the shade by the pragmatism of the private sector. “It really is going to be commercialisation that brings companies together worldwide,” she told the BBC. “We don’t care where they are registered, what matters is what they do for the benefit of the world.” (BBC)

title: MOE SAYS WON’T ISSUE LETTERS TO ADMIT STUDENTS TO A/L CLASSES
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education (MoE) yesterday (16) announced that it will not issue letters to admit students to GCE Advanced Level (A/L) from the GCE Ordinary Level (O/L) according to subject streams. In a statement, the ministry said schools have been given permission, through circulars, to admit students for A/L classes. The Zonal Education Director of respective area can assist the students to find schools, where the relevant stream is available, in their residential area. Furthermore, a new circular for admission of children to intermediate classes (except 1-6) would be issued in 2023 and notifications will be issued to those who wish to apply by 27 March, when the first school term commenced. Until then, the Ministry will not issue letters admitting students to national schools for intermediate classes.

title: Tickets to be issued to Tourists
author: Author not found
Content: In order to boost tourism, the Ministry of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs has decided to issue tickets to witness the sunrise and sunset from the top of Sigiriya. This programme was launched last Saturday (14). Tickets will be issued from 5.30 a.m. and the tourists can observe the environment from the top of Sigiriya until 9.00 p.m. Subject Minister Vidura Wickremanayake said this type of programmes would be expanded to other tourist destinations too.

title: UPP to go it alone at LG polls
author: Author not found
Content: The United People’s Party (UPP) will contest the upcoming Local Government election, as a single party and several ‘aragalayites’ will be nominated to contest on the UPP ticket. A press conference was held yesterday (16) with regard of the UPP’s participation in the 2023 Local Government elections. According to UPP Propaganda Secretary Chaminda Gunasinghe, the party expects to present a new vision and programme to overcome the difficult situation the country has been placed in due to 74 years of wrong political decisions, bureaucracy, and inefficiency. This would be a solution-oriented political movement that goes beyond mere criticism, he said. He said citizens who want to join this political movement are welcome to join the party and contest upcoming elections. A prominent face in the Aragalaya, Akila Viraj Konara, who is contesting the Maharagama Urban Council poll, told the media that clinging onto ‘Aragalaya’ forever is useless and it is time to do some real work to ensure the country’s economic stability. Konara said he is currently involved in a project related to digital economy and the main reason for joining the UPP to enter politics is the freedom given by the party to pursue such projects. Meanwhile, addressing the same media briefing, another member of the party, Mashi Senanayake, said the representation of women in the Sri Lanka Parliament is very low and in order to discuss women’s issues, more women should enter politics. “The LG election is the only election in Sri Lanka where a specific quota is set aside for the representation of women. Therefore, women are invited to join the UPP and change the current situation in the country,” she said. Another member of the UPP Chatura Rajapaksa also highlighted that while this LG Poll is referred to as a ‘small election’ it is as important just like a general election in the current political climate. So candidates of any party in this election must present a specific programme on their plans for LG Authorities, he noted. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Sahwa Arabic College triple ceremony held
author: Author not found
Content: The triple ceremony of Sinna Palamunai, of the Sahwa Arabic College, in the Addalaichenai DS Division, was held on a grand scale at the Akkaraipattu Athaullah Arangam, in the presence of religious dignitaries and educationists. The ceremony to mark the 3rd Convocation, honorary awards to those who contributed invaluable services to the Arabic College in various ways and  the Pearl Jubilee, was chaired by the President of the Board of Directors of Sharia Studies, of the Sahwa Institute, As-Sheikh M.H.M. Ithrees and was attended by the Chancellor of the South Eastern University of Sri Lanka, President’s Counsel Faisz Musthapha as Chief Guest. SLMC Leader Rauff Hakeem, ACMC Leader and MP Rishard Badiudeen, and the General Secretary of the All Ceylon Jemmiyathul Ulama As-Sheikh Arkam Nooramith were the guests of honours. In his address Chancellor Faisz Musthapha congratulated those who graduated from the Sahwa Arabic College upon the completion of strenuous seven-year programme. He also thanked the College Staff, headed by As-Sheikh I.L.M. Hashim, for their contributions. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Student dies after falling from bus
author: Author not found
Content: A schoolchild died after falling from a moving SLTB on 15 January, according to the Nawa Kurunduwatta Police. The child, Hasitha Devindra, was a student of Anuruddha Kumara National School in Nawalapitiya. He was returning home in an SLTB bus in the afternoon of 15 January, after attending a tuition class in the Nawalapitiya town. While trying to get off the bus, he fell and hit a mound of earth, near the main road, sustaining serious injuries. According to the Police, he died on the spot. The Police suspect that when the student attempted to get down from the front of the bus before it stopped, he had fallen. The bus driver was arrested and will be produced in the Gampola Magistrate’s Court. The body of the deceased student was being kept at the Nawalapitiya District General Hospital for the Post Mortem. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Lankan arrested at BIA attempting to smuggle gold
author: Author not found
Content: Customs officials arrested a 30-year-old Sri Lankan on 14 January at the BIA when she attempted to smuggle a stock of gold into the country. Customs Director (Legal) and Spokesman Sudaththa Silva said the woman was arrested following information received by the Customs intelligence officials attached to the Customs Revenue Monitoring Division with the support of Indian Revenue Intelligence wing. According to Customs intelligence information, the woman flew from Dubai via Chennai and reached the BIA at 1.45 am 14 January, Silva said. While checking this woman’s luggage thoroughly, Customs officers found the gold was concealed inside the travelling bags, he said. “24, rings, and bangles of 24 carat gold bars and eight containing liquid gold were found among the smuggled gold,” Silva said.  The gold jewellery was found silver-plated and designed to look like Bank cards to evade Customs officials, the spokesman said. The total weight of the gold was 4 kg and 892g and the market value was estimated to be in the range of at Rs 111.55 million.  The eight capsules were found to contain 2.222g of gold powder prepared as liquid. The value of the gold contained in the capsules is still being calculated.  Customs Officials are conducting further investigations.  Customs investigation is scheduled to take place at the conclusion of the Revenue Monitoring Division investigations.  BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: 68 killed in Nepal plane crash
author: Author not found
Content: Dozens of people have been killed after a plane with 72 people on board crashed near an airport in central Nepal. The Yeti Airlines flight from Kathmandu to the tourist town of Pokhara crashed on landing before catching fire. Videos posted on social media show an aircraft flying low over a populated area before banking sharply. At least 68 people are confirmed to have died, officials said. Several critically injured survivors were taken to hospital, unconfirmed reports said. Local resident Deeveta Kal told the BBC how she rushed to the crash site after seeing the aircraft plunge from the sky shortly after 11:00 a.m. local time (05:15 GMT). “By the time I was there the crash site was already crowded. There was huge smoke coming from the flames of the plane. And then helicopters came over in no time,” she said. “The pilot tried his best to not hit civilisation or any home,” Deevta Kal added. “There was a small space right beside the Seti River and the flight hit the ground in that small space.” The flight set out with 68 passengers on board, including at least 15 foreign nationals, and four crew members. According to flight tracking website Flightradar24, the 15-year-old twin-engine ATR 72 stopped transmitting position data at 05:05 GMT and the last signal from the aircraft was received at 05:12. Hundreds of Nepalese soldiers are involved in the operation at the crash site in the gorge of the Seti, just one and a half kilometres from the airport. Video taken where the plane came down showed thick billowing black smoke and burning debris. “We expect to recover more bodies,” an army spokesman told Reuters, saying the plane “has broken into pieces.” Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal called an emergency meeting of his cabinet and urged state agencies to work on rescue operations. A panel to investigate the cause of the crash has been set up. Of the passengers, 53 are said to be Nepalese. There were five Indian, four Russians and two Koreans on the plane. There was also one passenger each from Ireland, Australia, Argentina and France among others. Aviation accidents are not uncommon in Nepal, often due to its remote runways and sudden weather changes that can make for hazardous conditions. A Tara Air plane crashed in May 2022 in the northern Nepalese district of Mustang, killing 22 people. In early 2018, 51 people were killed when a US-Bangla flight travelling from Dhaka in Bangladesh caught fire as it landed in Kathmandu. The European Union has banned Nepalese airlines from its airspace over concerns about training and maintenance standards in the country’s aviation industry. (BBC)

title: Govt loses Rs 60B annually – Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Many liquor bottles with fake safety stickers were found in liquor stores throughout the island during the raids. They were found during liquor store raids in Tambuttegama, Talawa, Nelubewa, and Kahatagasdilliya. Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe stated that the Government loses approximately Rs 60 billion per year due to fraud involving alcohol safety stickers. In a statement, the Excise Department cited that it has found fake safety stickers and does not provide correct data in the computer system that has been installed. According to the Excise Department’s announcement, the traffickers’ goal is to make a large profit by selling substandard alcohol to the public while defrauding the Government of taxes that should be paid. Meanwhile, during a recent debate in Parliament, Rajapakshe revealed that the company selected to print the safety stickers in Sri Lanka was the world’s most corrupt in this regard. He also said the Indian company was accused of fraud and irregularities involving safety stickers in many countries around the world. He told Parliament that if the company legally gives the government ten million stickers, it illegally gives the private sector twenty million stickers. In addition, the Minister of Justice stated that the government loses approximately Rs 60 billion per year due to fraud involving alcohol safety stickers. In addition, a mobile application has been introduced to verify the accuracy of the sticker affixed to the alcohol consumed. The ‘EXCISE TAX STAMP VALIDATOR’ mobile phone application can be downloaded on the phone, and the accuracy of the security sticker can be checked, as well as information regarding fake stickers can be given to the Excise Department by calling the number 1913.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
