title: INS ‘Delhi’ arrives at port of Trincomalee
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian Naval Ship (INS) ‘Delhi’ arrived at the Port of Trincomalee on a formal visit yesterday. The visiting ship was welcomed by the Sri Lanka Navy in compliance with naval traditions. INS ‘Delhi’ is a 163.2m long Destroyer manned by a crew of 390 and the ship is commanded by Captain Shiraz Husain Azad. In the meantime, the Commanding Officer of INS is scheduled to call on Commander Eastern Naval Area and Commandant Volunteer Naval Force, Rear Admiral Dammika Kumara on 16th January at the Eastern Naval Command Headquarters. During the ship’s stay, the crew will take part in several programmes organised by the Sri Lanka Navy, with a view to promoting cooperation and goodwill between two navies. They are also expected to go on a sightseeing excursion in Trincomalee. On the other hand, Sri Lanka Navy personnel will engage in a training visit onboard INS ‘Delhi’. Concluding the visit, INS ‘Delhi’ will depart the island on 17 January 2023.

title: Chaos in Jaffna on Thai Pongal Day
author: Author not found
Content: Jaffna was in chaos on Thai Pongal Day yesterday (15) as protesters demanded an explanation for what happened to the missing persons and demanded their return as President Ranil Wickremesinghe arrived in Jaffna, heavily guarded by the Police, Special Task Force (STF), and Commandos to partake in the Pongal celebrations organised by government officials including Minister of Fisheries Douglas Devananda. The protest was held by the Families of the Disappeared and the University Students of Jaffna as President Wickremesinghe arrived in at the Palaly International Airport for the celebrations at about 3 pm. President delivered his speech at the Dhurkadevi Mani Mandapam, later on. President Wickremesinghe was driven to the city of Jaffna from the Airport heavily guarded to the Sivan Kovil in Nallur for Pongal rituals, the people who had already planned the protests, marched through the streets of Jaffna. The President was greeted with a red carpet by Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda. He also drew a golden shawl over his shoulders, as is customary among Tamils. “Ranil – Don’t bribe us, we want our loved ones back” and “We don’t want your Pongal; we want our land back” were some of the banners held by the protesters in Jaffna who were dispersed by water cannons. A scuffle broke out between the police and university students in the Nallur, Sivan Kovil at Aarasadi area too following which the riot police and the STF were mobilised in the area to stop the students from coming. The police presence in the area with water cannons and tear gas canisters added to the tension. Despite that, they remained protesting and tried to remove the heavily guarded barricades by the police and the STF. The protesters most being women members of the Families of the Missing Persons and the Jaffna University students, called the president to give them back their relatives who disappeared during the war. Meanwhile, the security forces have obstructed a bus taking the Tamil families of the disappeared from Mullaitivu to Jaffna to join a large-scale protest as Sri Lankan President Ranil Wickremesinghe visits the district for Thai Pongal. Women were seen pleading to the riot police to return their missing relatives showing their photos and demanding they meet the president in the mani mandapam. Recently, the President guaranteed the Tamil polity that he would find a solution to the ethnic issue before the 4 February Independence Day. Still, the north-east Tamils have maintained that the government had fooled them and had not settled the burning national question.  Pix by T Pratheepan        By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan and T. Pratheepan (Jaff. Corr)

title: ‘Seethawaka Odyssey’ on maiden journey
author: Author not found
Content: The weekend special tourist train service, ‘Seethawaka Odyssey,’ which was added to the operation in an effort to boost tourism, began operations yesterday (15) from Colombo Fort Railway Station. The special tourist train will run from Colombo Fort to the Waga Railway Station on the Kelani Valley railway line. It left Colombo Fort Railway Station around 7 a.m. yesterday, with a return from Waga Railway Station scheduled for this afternoon. The inaugural journey of Seethawaka Odyssey was attended by a number of groups, including Minister of Transport Bandula Gunawardene. Passengers on the ‘Seethawaka Odyssey’ will be able to see waterfalls such as the Ranmudu Ella, Kumari Ella, and Goraka Ella, as well as other tourist attractions such as the Seethawaka Wet Zone Botanic Gardens.

title: President visits Sri Naga Viharaya in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is in Jaffna to participate in the National Thai Pongal Festival, visited the Sri Naga Viharaya in Jaffna yesterday (15) and engaged in religious ceremonies. The President also met Venerable Meegahajandure Sirivimala Nayaka Thera of the Jaffna Sri Naga Viharaya and inquired about his well-being. The Thera congratulated the President and chanted Seth Pirith. Dr. M. Morgan, Chairman of the ‘Buddhist-Hindu Religious Forum,’ welcomed the President. Meanwhile, President Wickremesinghe met Reverend Sri Somasundaram, Nallai Adeena Ashramadipati and received blessings from him. The President also visited Jaffna Bishop, Right Reverend Dr. Justin Gnanapragasam and engaged in a brief discussion. The event was attended by Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda, State Minister Dr. Suren Raghavan, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Army Commander Lt. Gen. Vikum Liyanage, and several other officials.

title: President pledges full implementation of 13A
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe while noting he is working to establish a social justice commission to solve the problems of people belonging to all ethnicities, as he joined national Thai Pongal celebrations in Jaffna, pledged the full implementation of the 13 Amendment to the Constitution. Speaking at Durga Hall in Jaffna where festivities took place, the President further said to build a country where all races live together and achieve economic prosperity all must return to the ‘Sri Lankan’ identity envisioned by D.S. Senanayake 75 years ago. President Wickremesinghe also announced that he will make a special statement in February on the Government’s measures to bring about reconciliation and said that he will call a meeting of the party leaders next week to seek their views and opinions on the matter. Amongst many other pledges the President also assured expediting the work of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission to provide relief to the families of the disappeared. “This country needs reconciliation. As a result of 30 years of war and insurgencies our country has been divided by divisive, racist, sectarian and bankrupt politics.  We must return to the Sri Lankan identity that was created by D.S. Senanayake since we all have to live in one country and build the economy,” he added. These issues cannot be resolved by putting them aside and postponing them. The solution should be told to the country and the Parliament. We can’t keep playing Pandu when it comes to these issues. That is why Parliament’s views are first sought, he explained. “We have discussed a number of issues. It is necessary to provide relief to the relatives of the missing persons, to find the truth, to find out what happened. Also, the work of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission will be expedited to find out about this.  “Three weeks ago I asked the Army Commander what his opinion is about the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. He said it is an absolute necessity to establish the commission as it could be the only way to answer the allegations against the three forces. No one has so far voiced any objection to this Commission. “Instead of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, we are bringing a new law. Some say that this bill would be used against those in the North. There’s no such ulterior motive and we will use this to create stability in the country. Next is the land issue. Today we are discussing the issues related to the Wildlife Department. We are also discussing the return of land in Jaffna. During the war, the army maintained about 30,000 acres under its control because it wanted to protect these areas. Today, only 3,000 acres remain under the security forces. The army has expressed its willingness to hand over another part of it. We are discussing about it,” he added

title: India in a relative bright spot, must leverage exports, says IMF official
author: Author not found
Content: India is in a relative ‘bright spot’ in the world economy, but needs to leverage its existing strength in services exports and extend it to job-rich manufacturing exports, a top official at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Friday. “India is a relative bright spot in the world economy today, growing at rates significantly,” IMF Deputy Managing Director Antoinette Sayeh said at an event in New Delhi. India is in a relative ‘bright spot’ in the world economy, but needs to leverage its existing strength in services exports and extend it to job-rich manufacturing exports, a top official at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Friday. “India is a relative bright spot in the world economy today, growing at rates significantly,” IMF Deputy MD Antoinette Sayeh said at an event in New Delhi. Macroeconomic policies are responding to the significant headwinds, with fiscal policy measures supporting vulnerable groups and monetary policy addressing persistently high inflation India’s headline inflation moderated to an 11-month low 5.88% in November from 6.77% the month before. The Reserve Bank of India’s monetary policy committee has increased the policy repo rate by 225 basis points since May last year to reign in inflation (The Economic Times)

title: Minister orders procurement process be expedited
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva instructed officials to expedite the procurement process to set up electronic gate facilities at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA). The Minister instructed officials of the Airport and Aviation (Sri Lanka) (Private) Limited at a discussion held at the Ministry auditorium recently.  Instructions were given to set up two electronic gates at the Arrivals Terminal and two at the Departures Terminal under Phase I of the project. “Although the Project was initiated in 2017, it had not been implemented due to various reasons. I instruct officials to expedite obtaining required approvals according to the procurement process and reinstate the project immediately, with less expenditure and in a more advantageous manner to the country,” the Minister said. It was also revealed at the discussions that the financial provisions for the project will be allocated by the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and that the process will take around one year.  The Minister emphasised that until IOM funds are finalised, as an urgent requirement utilise funds from the  Airport and Aviation (Sri Lanka) (Private) Limited according to tender procedure. “I urge to obtain assistance of the IOM for modernisation projects of the port sector as well and a joint committee to  be appointed for this purpose. Under that committee, priority should be extended to obtain the scan machine that should be available very soon   at the Kankesanthurai (KKS) Port. Technical assistance of the IOM should also be obtained for operations and other activities of the port with enhanced productivity,” the Minister said. The requirement for two scan machines for security scanning of metal and other material for the passenger ferry service between KKS and India to be launched  in the near future was emphasised.

title: Réunion Island repatriates 46 Sri Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: The Réunion Island of France repatriated 46 Sri Lankan nationals to Sri Lanka by air on the evening of 13 January 2023. Reportedly, the group of Sri Lankans was apprehended as they were attempting to migrate to the Réunion Island illegally by sea. The suspects set out aboard a multiday fishing trawler (IMUL – A- 0559 CHW) from Negombo on 2 December 2022. The group of individuals comprises 43 males including the crew of the multiday fishing vessel, two females and one boy. They were apprehended as they were attempting to illegally enter the Réunion Island of France on 24 December 2022. They have been identified as residents of Jaffna, Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu, Mannar, Batticaloa, Chilaw and Negombo, from 13 to 53 years of age. Meanwhile, the group of individuals will be handed over to the CID for legal action.  The human smuggling ring operated in the Dehiwala area and charged from Rs 200,000 to Rs 4,500,000 for a single person. Smugglers orchestrate these unlawful acts to make a fast buck, by defrauding innocent people. Therefore, the Navy urges the public not to fall victim to such ploys and waste their hard-earned money. The French government does not entertain the illegal entry of people to the Réunion Island and such people will be immediately repatriated on being apprehended, the Navy said.

title: TFA of Bankers celebrates 25th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: Trade Finance Association of Bankers (TFAB) held their 25th Anniversary Celebrations along with the Annual Inter-Bank Trade Quiz and Social at the Grand Ball Room, Hilton Hotel Colombo in grandeur on 3 December 2022 with Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe, Governor, Central Bank of Sri Lanka as the Chief Guest. Several CEOs and members of the corporate management of Commercial Banks, senior bankers attached to trade departments of banks, members of TFAB along with the senior Government Officers connected to import and export trade graced the occasion. Consequent to the inaugural address by Lawrian Somanader, President TFAB, the Guest of Honour for the evening, Matthieu Andrieu, Head of Corporate Banking of M/s. Finastra who were the Chief sponsors for the celebrations, addressed the audience. In his speech he shared valuable insights, market trends and Covid-19 impact on the global economy. He also reiterated the importance of embracing  Fintech solutions to Trade Finance banking needs and  being delighted in  partnering  the TFAB celebration. Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe delivered the keynote speech where he emphasised that the most important part in international trade for bankers is to give proper advice to their customers and our ability to provide professional advice depends on our ability to predict, forecast and read the situation and render the correct advice to the client. As part of the anniversary celebrations the Association, re-launched its web site www.tfab.lk with a better look and feel with additional resources. The association also launched its Anniversary volume titled “Navigating International Trade Through Economic Turbulence” First copy of the volume was presented by Eranda Weerakoon, Chairman of the Editorial Committee to the chief guest. Thereafter the Chief Guest presented copies of the volume to each of the writers who contributed articles to the Anniversary volume. The Chief Guest, Governor, Central Bank of Sri Lanka presented mementoes to the Past Presidents in recognition of their contribution to the Association and to the international trade finance community at large. The 25th Anniversary Celebrations were flagged off with the annual Inter-Bank Trade Quiz which has been the premier event of the Association and is designed to test and share the knowledge in International Trade Finance among the trade practitioners. The quiz competition consisted of five rounds, with topics ranging from sports and current affairs to trade finance. Following the completion of each round, the respective winner for that round was also announced. To entertain the rest of the audience, they were also quizzed on a few questions whilst the competition took place.  This year too the Quiz was keenly contested with 27 teams competing for the coveted Trophy was won by Seylan Bank, while  Peoples Bank and the Commercial Bank of Ceylon won the  1st and 2nd Runners-up titles respectively. The Trade round was won by Bank of Ceylon. The organising committee for the 25th Anniversary celebrations of the association wishes to convey a special thank you to their sponsors for their generosity and contribution especially during difficult times. The Fellowship, Dinner and Social saw the bankers handling trade across commercial banks in Sri Lanka networking to improve connectivity among them, the spokesman said.

Content: Trade Finance Association of Bankers (TFAB) held their 25th Anniversary Celebrations along with the Annual Inter-Bank Trade Quiz and Social at the Grand Ball Room, Hilton Hotel Colombo in grandeur on 3 December 2022 with Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe, Governor, Central Bank of Sri Lanka as the Chief Guest. Several CEOs and members of the corporate management of Commercial Banks, senior bankers attached to trade departments of banks, members of TFAB along with the senior Government Officers connected to import and export trade graced the occasion. Consequent to the inaugural address by Lawrian Somanader, President TFAB, the Guest of Honour for the evening, Matthieu Andrieu, Head of Corporate Banking of M/s. Finastra who were the Chief sponsors for the celebrations, addressed the audience. In his speech he shared valuable insights, market trends and Covid-19 impact on the global economy. He also reiterated the importance of embracing  Fintech solutions to Trade Finance banking needs and  being delighted in  partnering  the TFAB celebration. Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe delivered the keynote speech where he emphasised that the most important part in international trade for bankers is to give proper advice to their customers and our ability to provide professional advice depends on our ability to predict, forecast and read the situation and render the correct advice to the client. As part of the anniversary celebrations the Association, re-launched its web site www.tfab.lk with a better look and feel with additional resources. The association also launched its Anniversary volume titled “Navigating International Trade Through Economic Turbulence” First copy of the volume was presented by Eranda Weerakoon, Chairman of the Editorial Committee to the chief guest. Thereafter the Chief Guest presented copies of the volume to each of the writers who contributed articles to the Anniversary volume. The Chief Guest, Governor, Central Bank of Sri Lanka presented mementoes to the Past Presidents in recognition of their contribution to the Association and to the international trade finance community at large. The 25th Anniversary Celebrations were flagged off with the annual Inter-Bank Trade Quiz which has been the premier event of the Association and is designed to test and share the knowledge in International Trade Finance among the trade practitioners. The quiz competition consisted of five rounds, with topics ranging from sports and current affairs to trade finance. Following the completion of each round, the respective winner for that round was also announced. To entertain the rest of the audience, they were also quizzed on a few questions whilst the competition took place.  This year too the Quiz was keenly contested with 27 teams competing for the coveted Trophy was won by Seylan Bank, while  Peoples Bank and the Commercial Bank of Ceylon won the  1st and 2nd Runners-up titles respectively. The Trade round was won by Bank of Ceylon. The organising committee for the 25th Anniversary celebrations of the association wishes to convey a special thank you to their sponsors for their generosity and contribution especially during difficult times. The Fellowship, Dinner and Social saw the bankers handling trade across commercial banks in Sri Lanka networking to improve connectivity among them, the spokesman said.

title: Ethimale Police OIC interdicted
author: Author not found
Content: The Officer-in-Charge (OIC) of the Ethimale Police Station, who was arrested for allegedly aiding and abetting Moneragala SSP Sisira Kumara was interdicted yesterday (15), Police said. Moneragala SSP Sisira Kumara was recently arrested by the Special Task Force (STF) who found over 650 Ganja plants at his official residence on 8 January and was interdicted by the IGP with immediate effect on 13 January. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said a Police Constable who worked as the driver for the main suspect and a Police Sergeant who worked at the official residence of the main suspect were also taken into STF custody. Additionally, one individual from Moneragala and two others from Moratuwa were also taken into custody, on suspicions of aiding and abetting the SSP. A ground-scanning device was also taken into custody during the raid conducted on 8 January. SSP Thalduwa added that the Criminal Investigation Department has taken over the investigation on the IGP’s orders. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: China expects to be paid back – IMF Chief
author: Author not found
Content: Problems that China has in restructuring debt owed to it by countries like Sri Lanka is that they expect to be paid back because it is a developing country, IMF Managing Director (MD) Kristalina Georgieva said on Thursday (12 January). The IMF, in an upload on its website the following day Friday (13 January), further quoting Georgieva warned that if countries like Sri Lanka are not provided with debt restructuring, it will be very difficult for those countries to provide basic services to the poor. Georgieva made these comments when she was interviewed by IMF’s Communications Director Julie Kozack, the IMF website further said. IMF Headquarters is located in Washington, D.C. The IMF Managing Director further said China is becoming a very significant source of lending and also bears responsibility to support countries when they’re faced with inability to service that debt. To quote more excerpts from the interview, Question: One of the issues the US and others are saying is that China, with a portion of the debt, of course, countries have to China. I was wondering if you’ve seen any particular progress on that front, that China would be more willing to take a haircut in some of these situations? Answer: We have engaged with the Chinese authorities, working on two very important issues: One, coordination among Chinese agencies that would allow all sources of debt to China to be part of the discussion for a solution. And this has been a long process and it is still continuing. China does not have the tradition of that coordination that exists in more mature lenders. China has many agencies and entities involved. The second area we have engaged with China is at the country level, to define a pathway for debt resolution of Chad, Zambia, also, we are discussing Sri Lanka, Suriname, to help China understand both the whole issue of debt sustainability and what can be a pathway for their contribution. When we were in China last month, we asked to have a meeting with the two key agencies, the China’s Finance Ministry and the People’s Bank of China; as well as with the large lenders in China, Exim Bank and China Development Bank. They came for this meeting and we had a very constructive and frank discussion on these issues. What is the biggest problem internally, domestically for China? It is the notion, and is actually very broadly shared by many officials and citizens in China, that China is still a developing country and therefore China will try to offer support to all developing countries genuinely with the objective to help, but also, they expect to be paid back because it is a developing country. So a haircut in the Chinese context is politically very difficult, but they understood, after many interactions that there are ways in which they can reach the equivalency of a haircut by stretching maturities, reducing or eliminating interest rates, payments and the Paris Club in their own engagement with China, so that there might be a way to reach the same objective in a way that in terms of reducing the burden of debt. Now, of course, it is much better if debt reduction is done upfront, not to that reprofiling, but to as you said, haircut. So, we of course, continue to discuss with China, the value for China as a lender to have their exposure to countries defined in a way that is rational and then the countries can actually service that debt. For countries that are suffering under tremendous burden of debt, they cannot possibly serve, that translates into reducing social services for their own people. And that is not the choice they should be faced with. (PA)

title: Working with a single policy- the need of the hour- President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised the need to work within one policy framework while facing economic difficulties the country is confronted with. The President made these observations during a meeting with trade union representatives at the President’s Office held recently. Government, semi-government and private sector trade union leaders and representatives participated in the meeting which was presided over by the President and the Prime Minister to discuss measures that could be taken to find solutions to the economic and financial crisis in the country. Stating that the country’s economy is expected to improve after the first quarter of this year, the President expressed his confidence in achieving better economic progress in 2024. The President pointed out that not only the public sector but the private sector should also be strengthened to provide relief to the people while continuing with the development programmes of the country. He further said he is aware of the hardships the people are going through today and added that he would somehow provide relief to the public. The President also pointed out that measures have been taken to provide rice to about two million families who are not entitled to Samurdhi benefits during March and April.  “Additionally, we have one more problem. In the Global sphere, the economic growth in Europe and America is now slowing down. Under such a situation, our export market may drop by next year and we have to develop our tourism industry”, he said. “We would be able to increase the Inland Revenue by the end of this year. Then some relief could be given to the people. However, before that, the country’s economy should be strengthened where not only the public sector but the private sector as well. Otherwise, there would be a gap. First, we need to find out what relief could be given to the people. We have made allocations to provide rice to about two million families, in March and April, who are not entitled to Samurdhi benefits,” the President said. Speaking further he also noted that working people and small-scale entrepreneurs were facing the most difficulties.  He said problems have arisen in both public and private banks as well. “We must protect the banking system and when they are not protected, small-scale entrepreneurs borrowing from such banks could collapse. What is the next step then? How should the economy be managed from 2024? The export economy should be strengthened by protecting the competitiveness of businesses. Similarly, concessions should be given to the working people. I suggest that not only the public sector but also private businesses, marketing boards, trade unions, farmers, and all should discuss lengthily and at least reach a framework of a social agreement on how we can advance this economic programme,” he said.  Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said due to the measures taken by the Government in the last few months, the economic situation of the country is changing to some extent. “To strengthen the situation in the future, we need to cooperate and improve products and services. It is on that basis that we can raise our heads as a country and the participation of working people in that endeavour is of paramount importance,” he said.

title: Drunk driver arrested for assaulting Police officer
author: Author not found
Content: An individual was arrested yesterday (15) for driving under the influence of alcohol, obstructing Police duty and assaulting a Police officer. According to the Police Media Division, the suspects vehicle was stopped by Police at Hungama Junction for inspection. However, the suspect used derogatory language on the officers and fled the scene. Police pursued the car and arrested the driver after determining that he was under the influence of alcohol. The vehicle was also taken into Police custody. Police said the suspect had acted violently and even attacked a policeman while they were travelling to the Police Station. The injured policeman was admitted to Ranna Hospital for treatments. The suspect was identified as 37-year-old resident of Pallegama, Hungama. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Voice of Global South Summit held virtually
author: Author not found
Content: India hosted a two-day Voice of Global South Summit virtually on 12-13 January 2023. With ten sessions in total, the Summit saw the participation of Leaders and Ministers from 125 countries of the Global South including Sri Lanka. Under the theme ‘Unity of Voice, Unity of Purpose’, this one of a kind Summit focused on priorities, perspectives and concerns of the developing world. The Summit was particularly relevant as the world passes through a difficult period marked by challenges to health, food security, and affordable access to energy, climate finance and technologies, and economic growth.  Prime Minister Narendra Modi presided over the Inaugural Leaders’ Session on 12 January 2023. This was followed by eight Ministerial-level thematic segments dedicated to addressing the most pressing concerns of the developing world. The Summit wrapped up on 13 January 2023 with a Concluding Leaders’ Session also hosted by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.  President attended the Concluding Leaders’ session. In his remarks, the President of Sri Lanka focused on economic issues of the developing world. He said that India was in the best position to act as a bridge between the developing countries which are facing a debt crisis and the G20.   The Indian Premier announced a number of initiatives at the Concluding Leaders’ Session such as,  Aarogya Maitri,  Global South Centre of Excellence,  Global South Science and Technology Initiative, Global South Young Diplomats’ Forum and Global South Scholarships.  State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe attended the Finance Ministers’ Session on 12 January 2023. In this session, Ministers exchanged views on financing the development needs of the Global South, achieving financial inclusion, implementation of digital public goods in the financial sector, and development partnerships that are outcome-oriented and financially sustainable.  Participating countries recognised with appreciation that the Summit produced fruitful conversations and charted a new path through an action oriented agenda that strives to address their priorities and challenges. They underscored the agenda and quest for solutions to global challenges must include the voices of its biggest stakeholders, the Global South, a spokesman said.

title: EC should not run to AG – Polls watchdog
author: Author not found
Content: Some election watchdogs said the Election Commission (EC) should not go behind the Attorney General at every turn seeking his support in their bid to conduct polls. National Coordinator of Centre for Monitoring Election Violence (CMEV) Manjula Gajanayake alleged that it is a misconception that is being spread by the Government that the EC has to be at the mercy of the Attorney General to conduct elections. He mentioned that in order to maintain the independence of Commissions, the EC should be devoid of the clout or influence wielded by the Attorney General. Gajanayake added that though as per the Code of Ethics for State institutions they should consult the Attorney General regarding legal matters, Independent Commissions should not undertake such a course at any time. By Bingun Menaka Gamage

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Reginald Cooray’s widow requests Post-mortem
author: Author not found
Content: Chandrika Priyangani Coooray, widow of the Late Reginald Cooray had requested the Coroner of the Kalutara Teaching Hospital, S.A. Kumasaru, to conduct a Post-mortem on her late husband’s remains. The former Chief Minister of Western Province passed away aged 75 at dawn on Friday (13). His widow made this request to the Coroner during the Post-mortem. Testifying at the Post-mortem Cooray’s Private Secretary J.M. Somasiri had claimed that Cooray had suddenly fallen ill following a heated exchange of words with four individuals including SLPP National List MP Gevindu Kumaratunga. Afterwards the Coroner ordered a Post-mortem on the remains of the deceased to be carried out under the supervision of JMO of the Kalutara Teaching Hospital, Sriyantha Amararatne. BY Hashan Pushpika – Pannipitiya

title: Ex-President Sirisena Ordered to Pay Rs 100M In Compensation
author: Author not found
Content: In a momentous decision, the Supreme Court yesterday (12), ordered former President Maithripala Sirisena to pay a sum of Rs 100 million as compensation for victims of the Easter Sunday Attacks and families of the deceased, for the failure to prevent the attacks even after having received intelligence information. The Supreme Court also ordered former Inspector General of Police Pujith Jayasundara and former Head of State Intelligence SDIG Nilantha Jayawardena to pay a sum of Rs 75 million each, former Secretary to the Ministry of Defence, Hemasiri Fernando, to pay a sum of Rs 50 million and former Chief of National Intelligence Sisira Mendis to pay a sum of Rs 10 million as compensation to the victims of the Easter Sunday attacks. The order was made when 12 petitions, filed against those responsible for the Easter Sunday attacks, were taken up before a Supreme Court Bench comprising Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya and Justices Buwaneka Aluwihare, L.T.B. Dehideniya, Murdu N.B. Fernando, S. Thurairaja, A.H.M.D. Nawaz and A.L. Shiran Gooneratne. Whilst Sirisena, Jayasundara, Jayawardena, Fernando and Mendis were named as respondents to the Petitions, Court held that their failure to prevent the Easter Sunday attacks in 2019 despite having received intelligence information has infringed the fundamental rights enshrined under Article 12(1) and 14(1)(e) of the Constitution. The above sums were ordered to be paid out of the personal funds of the respondents. These payments have to be made to a Victim Fund, to be set up at the Office for Reparations and maintained in an escrow. Court held that it was Sirisena’s obligation to have had a constant vigil over his ministerial functions, as National Security was his portfolio and he should have exercised his supervision over his Departmental Heads, regardless of personal predilections for particular officers. It was also stated that Sirisena could not be relieved from his constitutional obligation of ensuring the national security of the country. Court also held that Jayawardena and Jayasundara were both aware of the potential threats by the mastermind of the Easter Sunday attacks Zaharan Hashim, his cohorts and the NTJ, long prior to the Easter Sunday attacks. With regard to Mendis, Court held that he fell short of his primary duty of sharing intelligence and he omitted to ensure that the intelligence received on 4 April 2019 was disseminated to other intelligence agencies, for instance Director of Military Intelligence. Further, with regard to Fernando, Court held that although Fernando chaired the Weekly Intelligence Coordinating Conference on 9 April 2019, he did not take any initiative to open a discussion on this vital piece of intelligence and has thereby failed in his duty as the supervisory authority of the State Intelligence Service. Court further ordered the Office for Reparation to investigate into the underpayment and non-payment of compensation to victims and families of the deceased and for accurate information by way of a motion to be submitted to Courts within three months from the date of the judgment. The Attorney General was also directed to liaise with the Office for Reparation and notify the Court of same. The Bench further ordered that disciplinary action be taken against SDIG Jayawardena. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: ‘Born Again’ cult possibly taking over SLC – probe committee
author: Author not found
Content: Special attention must be paid to the possibility of Sri Lanka men’s cricket team being subjected to the influence of religious cult, ‘Born Again’, as there are clear signs of that happening, recommended the five-member committee appointed to probe various allegations against Sri Lanka men’s cricket team, which had taken place during December 2022 Australia tour. This recommendation was made by the committee after obtaining statements from several Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) officials and team members. The report said cricketer Bhanuka Rajapaksa, who was a Buddhist, has become a follower of the Born Again cult. A Born Again Pastor named Terry had met cricketer Chamika Karunaratne and preached about the importance of the cult. According to the report, there are several SLC officials and national team players who are followers of Born Again. The report also says, controversial Pastor Jerome Fernando, who introduces himself as a Prophet, takes various steps to increase the number of followers of his cult. At the same time, it was observed that some cricketers hesitated to provide statements to the committee due to fear of jeopardising their careers, the report claimed. Furthermore, the report shed light on many alleged financial misappropriations that occurred during the said tour. The SLC has spent more than Rs 25 million on air tickets for 16 officers. Also, more than USD 100,000 has been spent as additional expenses. It is also revealed that SLC Chief Operating Officer Jerome Jayaratne’s visa and air tickets had been sponsored by the Sri Lanka Cricket and he had also been provided a per diem of USD 7,000 for 10 days. However, he has done nothing related to the tour as an SLC official. Although Jayaratne engage in promotional activities, the committee said there is no need for him to go overseas as it can simply done by e-mails. Jayaratne launched a promotional campaign for the men’s T20 World Cup in 2022 and his duty was terminated during the tournament. Jayaratne went Australia on26 October 2022 and returned to the country on 8 or 9 November 2022. He had spent the days in the house of his sister, the report said. Moreover, the committee recommended to grant permission for the cricketers’ spouses to accompany them on tours, for it would help in ensuring their mental health and stop the cricketers from going outside their hotels at night. BY Bingun Menaka Gamage and Mithun Jayawardena

title: SLBFE staff surround GM’s office demanding bonus
author: Author not found
Content: The staff of the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) yesterday (12) surrounded the office of the General Manager, demanding the annual bonus.  It is said, the annual bonus had not been approved by the Treasury. The staff demanded the annual bonus claiming that several loss-making State institutions had paid the bonus to their employees. Meanwhile, commenting on the issue, Labour and Foreign Employment Minister Manusha Nanayakkara said, it was temporarily resolved after discussions with the employees. Nanayakkara, who is in Anuradhapura, said a final decision with regard to the issue will be taken following the consultation of the Ministry of Finance. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Qatar Charity announces USD 11.7M in humanitarian aid
author: Author not found
Content: Qatar Charity, the main charitable arm of the Qatar Government, announced a USD 11.7 million, in humanitarian assistance toSri Lanka, on 11 January, after the country lifted the ban imposed on the organisation following the 2019 Easter Sunday terror attacks. The announcement was made at the reopening ceremony of its country office in Colombo. This comes as a goodwill gesture in the wake of the Sri Lankan Government revoking the ban on the charity. Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry was present at the event. “At the launch of the country office today, Qatar Charity announced humanitarian aid worth USD 11.7 million for the year 2023. This will be allocated to identified areas as per the State’s requirements. Thank you, Qatar Charity for stepping up to support the vulnerable,” Minister Ali Sabry tweeted following the reopening ceremony. Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera met officials of the Qatar Charity on 29 June 2022 and informed them of the Defence Ministry’s decision to lift the ban on the charity.     “Met the officials of the Qatar Charity. Conveyed the message that the Defence Ministry has informed the Attorney General its decision to lift the ban on the fund which was imposed in 2019,” Wijesekera tweeted at the time. Qatar Charity was accused of funding terrorism following the 21 April 2019, Easter Attacks, shortly after which the CID froze the organisation’s accounts in Sri Lanka. The charges have since been dropped. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: ‘Sex for fare’ taxi driver granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: The Police Women and Children’s Bureau (PWCB) had arrested a three-wheeler driver, who had sought sexual favours from a French woman, instead of his cab fare. According to Police, the incident had taken place on 2 January in Colombo 3. Police added that after the hire, the 35-year-old French woman had sought to pay her three-wheeler fare via a bank card but the suspect had declined it and instead had invited her to engage in oral sex with him. The irate foreigner had chased away the suspect and two days after the unpleasant incident had lodged a complaint with the PWCB. The PWCB, acting promptly, had nabbed the suspect, a 28-year-old resident of Akurana, and had produced him in Court after which he had been enlarged on bail. BY Inoka Udayangani – Battaramulla

title: Kelanitissa Plant might shut down today
author: Author not found
Content: The Kelanitissa Power Station (KPS) might shut down today (13), as the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) does not have funds to purchase naphtha from the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC), said CEB Chairman Nalinda Ilangakoon. He said the plant had enough naphtha to run until today (13) morning and that the petroleum corporation is willing to give naphtha in exchange for cash. He also stated that the Electricity Board is negotiating with the authorities to find funds to pay the CPC for the naphtha required to run the plant. The naphtha will be delivered if they can send some money this afternoon or so. The KPS generates approximately 165 MW for the national grid. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Renewable energy plant owners left in the lurch
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) has put the owners of renewable energy (RE) power plants into jeopardy as the CEB has failed to pay them about Rs 40 billion, placing them in difficult situations with banks, CEB General Manager Eng. Rohan Seneviratne claimed. He claimed that of the Rs 40 billion, nearly Rs 3 billion must be paid to the owners of roof top solar panels. Seneviratne told the media yesterday (12), that if the CEB cannot pay this Rs 40 billion, no person will make any future investments in renewable energy projects. Seneviratne also pointed out that CEB does not have the necessary funds to make the payments. Explaining the process that the CEB has planned for paying the owners of renewable energy plants, he said they hope to pay the owners as soon as they have a proper income from the increased electricity tariff and proposed loans from banks. He also said unless the Rs 40 billion in arrears are paid, no renewable energy investors will invest in renewable energy plants.  “We hope to address these issues and add at least 2,500 MW to the national grid in the coming years,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: EC to get funds in instalments
author: Author not found
Content: Treasury Officials have informed the Election Commission (EC) that funds for the upcoming Local Government Election can only be released in instalments. This was conveyed to the EC, when Treasury officials met EC members on Wednesday (11) morning. Furthermore, it is not possible to determine an exact time period in which they could release funds through instalments as well, the Treasury had told the EC. The Treasury had reportedly informed the EC that welfare expenditure would have to be slashed to make funds available for polls.

title: Adarsha granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (12) enlarged on bail Adarsha Karandana, who is said to be the girlfriend of former Adviser to the President on Parliamentary Affairs, Ashu Marasinghe. Bail was set at two sureties of Rs 500,000 each. The CID had arrested and produced Adarsha in Court, in connection with a complaint lodged by Marasinghe, who had alleged that K.G. Wageesha Adarsha had threatened to post his nude photos on the Internet and demanded a sum of Rs 100 million, to refrain from doing so. The Chief Magistrate stated that the plaintiff had not produced sufficient submissions, to warrant the rejection of bail and ordered the accused to be released on bail. He mentioned that the probe into the incident had been conducted expeditiously within a span of 15-days, after the complaint had been lodged. He noted that during that period, it had not come to his notice, that the suspect had in any manner tampered with either the evidence into the case or interfered with witnesses and hence he was ordering her to be enlarged on bail. The CID said that thus far, they had conducted a swift probe into the incident, while recording statements from witnesses. They said that the suspect had to date not given them any clear information, with regard to her permanent address. The CID pointed out, that if the suspect were to be enlarged on bail at this stage of the probe, she could avoid future Court proceedings and that she could also tamper with evidence. Hence, the CID requested the Court, to issue an order for her imprisonment. However, the Counsel appearing for the suspect informed Chief Magistrate Alwis, that his client had previously submitted an anticipatory bail application to him, in light of her imminent arrest by the CID. He then said, barely 24 hours after the Court, had dismissed his client’s anticipatory bail application, the prosecution had arrested his client. The Counsel for the suspect opined that his client has had no pre-conceived notions of absconding Court and urged the Court, to issue an order for her release, under any suitable bail condition. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court released the suspect on bail and fixed further proceedings of the case to 23 March. The CID has filed a lawsuit at the said Court, against the suspect, on charges of flouting Provisions contained in Sections 373, 374 and 43 of the Penal Code as well as violation of Provisions contained in Section 2 of the Obscene Publications Amended Act, via her actions and on the charge of demanding the aforementioned ransom from Ashu Marasinghe. By Hansi Nanayakkara

Bail was set at two sureties of Rs 500,000 each. The CID had arrested and produced Adarsha in Court, in connection with a complaint lodged by Marasinghe, who had alleged that K.G. Wageesha Adarsha had threatened to post his nude photos on the Internet and demanded a sum of Rs 100 million, to refrain from doing so. The Chief Magistrate stated that the plaintiff had not produced sufficient submissions, to warrant the rejection of bail and ordered the accused to be released on bail. He mentioned that the probe into the incident had been conducted expeditiously within a span of 15-days, after the complaint had been lodged. He noted that during that period, it had not come to his notice, that the suspect had in any manner tampered with either the evidence into the case or interfered with witnesses and hence he was ordering her to be enlarged on bail. The CID said that thus far, they had conducted a swift probe into the incident, while recording statements from witnesses. They said that the suspect had to date not given them any clear information, with regard to her permanent address. The CID pointed out, that if the suspect were to be enlarged on bail at this stage of the probe, she could avoid future Court proceedings and that she could also tamper with evidence. Hence, the CID requested the Court, to issue an order for her imprisonment. However, the Counsel appearing for the suspect informed Chief Magistrate Alwis, that his client had previously submitted an anticipatory bail application to him, in light of her imminent arrest by the CID. He then said, barely 24 hours after the Court, had dismissed his client’s anticipatory bail application, the prosecution had arrested his client. The Counsel for the suspect opined that his client has had no pre-conceived notions of absconding Court and urged the Court, to issue an order for her release, under any suitable bail condition. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court released the suspect on bail and fixed further proceedings of the case to 23 March. The CID has filed a lawsuit at the said Court, against the suspect, on charges of flouting Provisions contained in Sections 373, 374 and 43 of the Penal Code as well as violation of Provisions contained in Section 2 of the Obscene Publications Amended Act, via her actions and on the charge of demanding the aforementioned ransom from Ashu Marasinghe. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: No. 3 Maritime Squadron celebrates 4th anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: The No. 3 Maritime Squadron proudly celebrated its 4th anniversary on Wednesday (11) after the re-establishment of the Squadron at SLAF Academy China Bay. Being one of the initial flying formations in Air Force antiquity, No. 3 Squadron was originally inaugurated in 1965 at Air Force Base China Bay and history of the Squadron indicates that in December 1971, it was refurbished as a fully-fledged operational flying formation and renamed as No. 3 Maritime Squadron, headed by Commanding Officer, Squadron Leader Noor Rahim under the guidance of then Commander of the Air Force, Air Vice Marshal P.H. Mendis. The Squadron logo featured the ‘Red-wattled Lapwing (Kirala),’ to indicate the role of the Squadron of providing early warning. Initially, the Squadron inventory comprised de Havilland Dove aircraft and it was entrusted with dawn to dusk reconnaissance patrols of the Eastern Coast from Point Pedro to Galle as a deterrent to possible Arms smuggling, a need felt during the 1971 insurgency. The Squadron shifted to SLAF Base Katunayake with the addition of the Cessna 337 aircraft and again relocated to SLAF Base China Bay in 1988 to conduct surveillance operations against the LTTE. Present Air Force Commander, Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana was a pioneer aviator in No. 3 Maritime Squadron who logged numerous flying hours, conducting surveillance, MEDIVAC and other operational missions over this period. However, No. 3 Maritime Squadron became non-operational in 1993 due to depletion of its fleet, yet the need of a dedicated maritime surveillance squadron remained unquenched over the period of nearly 25 years. The Squadron was re-established at SLAF Academy China Bay on 11 January 2019, fulfilling the need of an operational flying formation entrusted with maritime/ land surveillance and HADR operations and equipped with Y-12 and B-200 aircraft. Wing Commander Vidura Premasinghe (Rtd) was the first Commanding Officer after the re-establishment and since then the Squadron is on 24×7 operational readiness to conduct surveillance, HADR and other flying commitments and has expanded its operations with the induction of the newest addition of SLAF, the Dornier 228 aircraft from Indian Navy. At the present average of three sorties per week, this Squadron covers about 50,000 km2 islandwide. The Squadron is now equipped with a Beechcraft King Air B-200 aircraft and Do-228. The No. 3 Maritime Squadron undertakes maritime, ground surveillance and reconnaissance missions to safeguard the sovereignty of our motherland.

title: Govt urged to look into welfare of Lankans working abroad
author: Author not found
Content: The Social Welfare Organisation of Ampara District (SWOAD) urged the Government to look into the welfare of Sri Lankan citizens employed overseas and have been not paid their salaries and other privileges, thus depriving the country of much needed dollars.  SWOAD Programme Officer K. Lathan presided over the media briefing at their Conference Hall in Akkaraipattu recently.  Addressing the journalists, Managing Director V. Paramasingam, detailed the purpose of the meeting and sought the assistance of journalists to solve the outstanding problems faced by immigrants. Local Journalists representing electronic and Print Media were present at this media briefing.  Continuing Paramasingam  said that he has been receiving complaints that immigrants who are employed in foreign countries, especially in Middle East, are facing hardship without even their basic needs. Though they set out with full of hope and expectation, they have been cheated and even their fundamental rights are being denied. He also charged the employers don’t take any interest in their welfare. Those who were employed during Covid-19 were severely affected and they were even deprived of their basic rights.  Paramasingam said that some employees who returned from foreign countries met him and related their woes. A few who went abroad and returned to the country were also at the media briefing to relate their stories. By M.A. P. Deen – Ampara

title: 100% sales at T Bill auction
author: Author not found
Content: Wednesday’s (12) administered, weekly Treasury (T) Bill auction saw Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) selling all of the offered tenures for the second consecutive market week, whilst ensuring that the weighted average yields (WAYs) fell for the fifth consecutive market week. Consequently, CBSL sold all the Rs 88,000 million T Bills offered at Wednesday’s auction, allowing for a 100 per cent subscription for each of the tenures offered. Subsequently, CBSL sold all of the 91,182 and 364-day tenures offered at Wednesday’s auction, with their splits being Rs 50,000 million, Rs 20,000 million and Rs 18,000 million, respectively. The WAYs fetched for the 91, 182 and 364-day tenures at Wednesday’s auction were 31.15 per cent, 31.37 per cent and 29.04 per cent, down 86 basis points (bps), 65 bps and 12 bps each, Week-on-Week (WoW), respectively. The fact that the WAY of the 364-day maturity being smaller than both the 91 and 182 day maturities for the twentieth consecutive market week to Wednesday and that of only the 91-day maturity for the twenty first consecutive market week to Wednesday is an indication that the market expects yield pressure to last only in the short term. In related developments, CBSL on behalf of the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL), will have to repay to the market, a total of Rs 82,152 million maturities, corresponding to the relevant 91, 182 and 364-day repayments by today (13). However, maturing T Bills held by CBSL, and which also have to be repaid by today are unknown as CBSL the steward of GoSL debt has not revealed their value. In addition, CBSL, by a previous placement, sold Rs 788 million worth of T Bills of both 182 and 364-day maturities, of which the 364-day maturity repayment is also due by today. However, CBSL has failed to give the related maturity splits of the above Rs 788 million T Bill sale. Usually, investments in T Bills are risk-free, because if GoSL is unable to repay such debt, generally, CBSL is mandated to print demand-pull inflationary money and repay such creditors. Domestically, issuing of T Bills is a key instrument used by GoSL to raise money locally. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Construction sector problems discussed
author: Author not found
Content: The National Council Sub Committee took for discussion the concerns faced by the construction industry in the wake of the economic crisis. The Sub Committee discussion, held on Wednesday (11), included identifying the short and medium-term programmes related to economic stabilisation of the construction industry in the face of the economic crisis. Representatives of several parties, representing the public and private sectors, related to the construction industry in Sri Lanka, participated in this committee and their opinions were obtained on the issues that exist in the said field. The representatives present indicated that there are approximately 650,000 direct and 700,000 indirect jobs related to the construction industry. But, they pointed out that the construction sector has collapsed at present and because of this, workers have faced a crisis. Furthermore, these parties said that it has become difficult to sell constructions such as apartments and offices, that are currently being built. Also, the parties present pointed out that there are a large number of people who find it difficult to paying the bank loans due to the government not making payments for part of the constructions that have been built so far. It was also revealed that due to the economic crisis, there has been a tendency for people associated with the construction industry to leave the country. The Chair of the sub-committee said that if solutions that require money, solutions that do not require money and legal solutions are not identified and implemented separately, the country’s engineering sector will suffer a major collapse. He said that he is hoping to submit to the Parliament and the Government proposals on the matter as soon as possible.

title: Coast Guard conserves 1,743 sea turtle eggs
author: Author not found
Content: The collective efforts of Sri Lanka Coast Guard (SLCG) personnel attached to the life-saving posts at Mirissa, Hikkaduwa, Unawatuna, Wellawatta, Mount Lavinia and Panadura, recovered 1,743 numbers of sea turtle eggs from places close to their natural habitat during the eight-day period from 1 to 7 January, SLCG said. The recovered eggs are being conserved at the locations near respective life-saving posts. Under the Coast Guard Turtle Conservation Project (CGTCP), every effort has been made to conserve turtle eggs in or around their natural habitat to ensure protection since sea turtles are becoming a vulnerable species to extinction, SLCG said. To date, SLCG has conserved 1,624 turtle eggs and released 125 sea turtle hatchlings into the sea, it added. (PA)

title: Japan Automobile Industry to open up for Sri Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: A high-level Japanese delegation met Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment, Manusha Nanayakkara on Wednesday (11) and agreed to support the setting up of a Vocational Training Centre (VTC) targeting the Automobile Industry to train youth for employment in Japan’s automotive industry. Those who successfully complete training at the centre will be qualified for immediate work opportunities in Japan thus creating more employment options for Sri Lankans. They said they were ready to hire more Sri Lankan workers to fulfil the labour demand in Japan. They also said that due to the close cultural and religious relations between Japan and Sri Lanka, they are willing to hire more Sri Lankan workers. Minister Nanayakkara said he has made plans for Sri Lanka to become number one among labour supplying countries to Japan. This assurance was given when a Japanese delegation including FUJIMARU Satoshi, State Minister of Cabinet Office of Japan and Yamamoto Kozo, former Minister of State for Overcoming Population Decline and Promotion of Local Economy Revitalisation met Minister Nanayakkara at his Ministry. The VTC will be a joint venture between the public and private sectors. The Minister also agreed to support the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau(SLFEB) in this effort. There is a need to recruit 6.5 million workers from foreign countries for jobs in Japan in the next few years, and views were exchanged at length regarding how Sri Lankan workers could contribute to meet that labour demand. The high-level Japanese delegation assured to give priority to Sri Lankan workers under the Specified Skilled Worker (SSW) system which gives foreign nationals more opportunities to work in Japan. The discussion also focused on employment opportunities in Japan in the care giving sector as such opportunities for foreign nationals were growing due to the increase in the elderly population in Japan. The Minister said he had obtained Cabinet appproval to include Japanese language learning in the school curriculum, and that the National Institute of Education is currently working to implement the proposal. He said that with the intervention of the SLFEB, 5,000 people were being trained in the Japanese language. The Minister also said 17,000 have faced the Japanese language proficiency examination held recently.  The Minister thanked Japan for opening up three fields where workers are recruited to Japan under the SSW programme, and requested that job opportunities in the other fields be opened to Sri Lanka as soon as possible. During his visit to Japan, the Minister explained to the Japanese representatives about the agreements reached to develop Gojo City and Galle City as sister cities and about the ‘Visit Galle’ project to attract more Japanese tourists to Sri Lanka. (SRM)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sumanthiran urges all Tamils to support political struggle in SL
author: Author not found
Content: At the celebration of the ‘Non-Resident Tamil Day’ in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, Tamil National Alliance MP M.A. Sumanthiran urged all Tamil leaders from around the world, including Tamil Nadu Chief Minister M. K. Stalin, to support the Sri Lankan Tamils’ political struggle and achieve fruitful results this year. Sumanthiran said yesterday (12), at a mega conference attended by all leaders of Tamil communities around the world and over 500 representatives from various international Tamil organizations, that whenever there is trouble faced by the Sri Lankan Tamils, Tamil Nadu will stand by them. He appreciated the recent cargo, meant for the Tamils of Sri Lanka, sent in three ships and said that gesture will not be forgotten. Leader of Tamil Progressive Party MP Mano Ganesan was also present.  The conference also discussed the history of non-resident Tamils and research on the Tamil language. The political struggle in Sri Lanka is nothing new and does not need to be repeated, Sumanthiran said, urging all Tamils to speak up in order to find a lasting solution to the ethnic problem and Tamil concerns in Sri Lanka. “If something happens to the Sri Lankan Tamils, Tamil Nadu, which is just over 20 kilometres away, has questioned it and we have our brothers in Tamil Nadu to rely on,” Sumanthiran said. He thanked Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Stalin and presented him with a ‘Yarl’ music instrument as a token of his undying friendship and support that is pure and genuine.  He stated that the political struggle for Tamil rights would continue, and recalled how the struggle also reached a point of taking up arms. Regardless of how it ended, he said, the political struggle continues and they have not given up. “Our uniqueness is preserved, and Tamils will continue to speak out and fight for their rights, and we believe we can succeed,” he said. Even senior M. K. Karunanidhi and the current Tamil Nadu government has given us immense hope, he stated.   He also stated that the talks they had with Sri Lanka’s incumbent President, prior to his arrival in Tamil Nadu, were fruitless. “We want the government to do what they had promised the Tamil people. We have given them a week to give us a response but while all of this is going on, the support from Tamil Nadu has given us hope of achieving our political ambitions, and we urge the Government of Tamil Nadu, as well as all other Tamil leaders and Tamil voices, to continue to support us in our struggle,” Sumanthiran said. “Your support is hugely needed and for 25 years or so the struggle continues and we want it to be fulfilled, hopefully to resolve it this year,” he added.  MP Ganesan added that his participation at the event, when the upcountry Tamils will mark 200 years since arrival from Tamil Nadu, was a great opportunity.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: STF raids ganja plantation close to MRIA
author: Author not found
Content: The STF arrested a suspect for having a ganja cultivation in a 10-acre plot, which had been rented from Deputy Speaker SLPP MP Ajith Rajapaksa. Following a tip-off, officers of the Kataragama STF Camp carried out the raid. Police said the land is situated adjacent to the Mattala Airport. Police handed over the suspect, who is a resident of Sooriyaweva, to the Kataragama Police. BY Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: State sector nurses to protest today
author: Author not found
Content: State service nurses will stage a series of protests today  (12) in major hospitals countrywide demanding the Government to step down as it was merely heaping taxes and tariffs and was unable to provide solutions to long-standing issues including increased interests rates on bank loans and the massive drug shortage the country was facing. General Secretary of the All Ceylon Nurses’ Union (ACNU), S.B. Mediwatta yesterday (11) warned that nurses including those serving at the National Hospitals Colombo and Kandy and Karapitiya would protest the from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. demanding the Government to either find solutions or step down as it was not able to give solutions to the drug shortage in State hospitals and other issues. Nurses worked closely with in-ward patients and patients complained to them when they do not get their medicine or are unable to undergo required laboratory tests. The issue has been growing since last year and the Government has been unable to find any long-term solution, they said. The protests are also against the unjust manner in which the State and private banks had increased interest rates on loans as a result of the Central Bank’s lending rates. Mediwatta said it had severely impacted nurses who had taken loans from Banks and were unable to meet their loan payments as a result of  increased rates. Their wages were not upped at the rate that Banks have increased interest rates for loan payments. Nurses wages’ have not increased parallel to the new hike in electricity bills, he lamented. The ACNU General Secretary said on 5 July 2021,  the Government pledged to amend a Circular and award Grade promotions to 14,000 nurses. They have to serve for five years to be promoted from Class Three to Class Two and seven years to be promoted to Class One. But due to shortcomings in the Circular even after a lapse of one year and five months the Health Ministry has been dragging its feet regarding the promotions. He said nurses would be able to get increments with the promotions that were long due.  Madewatta lashing out said the State was not doing anything to fill cadre requirements in hospitals. Nursing posts were left vacant due to retirement and the increasing tendency of nurses leaving the country to serve abroad. He accused the Health Ministry of violating circular 2/19/2019 issued in 2003 by the then Health Secretary. Payments were made according to this Circular till recently. But now there were attempts to violate that Circular and reduce payments.     By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SC upholds High Court ruling in bribery case
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (11) affirmed the conviction of Chief-of-Staff of former President Maithripala Sirisena Kusumdasa Mahanama and former Chairman of the State Timber Corporation (STC) Chairman, Piyadasa Dissanayake by the Colombo High Court Trial on several charges under the Bribery Act. Mahanama and Dissanayake were indicted by the Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) before the High Court of the Colombo The Complainant K.P. Nagarajah, an Indian National was involved in the Sugar Industry and acted as a representative/ shareholder to a foreign investor who was interested in purchasing the State-owned Kanthale Sugar Factory. The evidence led before the High Court at Bar revealed (that the Complainant had observed an inordinate delay in implementing the unsolicited proposal to purchase the Kanthale Sugar Factory when the matter had been approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. Since the Complainant was not happy with the progress made, he brought it to the notice of an official in the Prime Minister’s Officer and the matter had referred to the CIABOC by an Additional Secretary to the Prime Minister’s Officer. The Complainant Nagarajah had appeared before the Investigation Unit of CIABOC on a telephone message received by the said division. During the same period, the complainant had a few meetings with the two accused and it was the position of the witness that the accused had solicited a sum of Rs 20 million as an advance in order to finalise matters pending at that time. Thereby, the aggregate sentence imposed 20 years Rigorous Imprisonment with a fine of Rs 65000 and compensation of Rs 20 million in terms of section 26 of the Bribery Act for Mahanama and 12 years Rigorous Imprisonment with a fine ofRs 55,000 for Dissanayake. Being aggrieved by the said conviction and the sentence imposed on them by the High Court at Bar, both Accused Appellants had preferred two appeals to the Supreme Court. Amongst the arguments put forth by appellants was that they were deprived of a fair trial. Thereby, the Bench yesterday (11), concluded that the investigative technique adopted by the CIABOC does not amount to an entrapment and that the Appellants have not been deprived of a fair trial and upheld the decision of the High Court. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya launched
author: Author not found
Content: A new coalition titled Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya (People’s Freedom Alliance) formed by the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), together with several other political parties and the Group of Independent MPs in Parliament, was launched yesterday (11), to contest the upcoming Local Government Election. The SLFP, Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya, and the group of independent MPs in Parliament are the members of the new coalition. The symbol is the helicopter. The SLFP-chaired by former President Maithripala Sirisena, independent SLPP MPs Dullus Alahapperuma, Prof. G.L. Peiris, including the Freedom People’s Alliance, the Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya headed by MP Wimal Weerawansa, and independent MPs Anura Priyadharshana Yapa and Sudharshani Fernandopulle alongside other independent MPs participated in the event. The event was held at SLFP headquarters in Colombo.

title: BASL slams attempt to ‘interfere’ in LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) in reference to the controversial letter issued to the District Secretaries (DSs), ordering them not to accept deposits from candidates for the upcoming Local Government Election, raised concerns on attempts by the Government to interfere in the exercise of franchise by the people at the election. BASL observed that the said letter from the Secretary, Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government which has now been withdrawn, could result in the nomination process to the local authorities being brought to a standstill, thus effectively overturning the decision of the Returning Officers and the Elections Commission to receive nominations and thereafter to conduct elections in the Local Authorities. “The Supreme Court has held in the case of Waruna Karunathilake and another vs Dayananda Dissanayake that the exercise of the franchise by the people is a fundamental right which must be protected. Fundamental rights and franchise are two important aspects of the sovereignty of the people of Sri Lanka which is inalienable,” BASL said.
