title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 300 train cancellations in 11 days
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the worsening staff shortage at the Sri Lanka Railways, nearly 300 train journeys have been cancelled in the last 11 days, Ceylon Today learns. Many train journeys have been cancelled on a regular basis since the beginning of 2023, and the Department has informed the relevant staff in writing as official cancellations. Yesterday (11), railway trade unions, quoting the Sri Lanka Railways announced  42 train journeys, including office trains, have been cancelled until further notice. It was said there are 20 journeys on the main route, four on the Puttalam route, two on the Kelani Valley route, and 16 on the coastal route. However, Sri Lanka Railways (SLR) later announced that there would be no cancellations.

title: STF raids ganja plantation close to MRIA
author: Author not found
Content: The STF arrested a suspect for having a ganja cultivation in a 10-acre plot, which had been rented from Deputy Speaker SLPP MP Ajith Rajapaksa. Following a tip-off, officers of the Kataragama STF Camp carried out the raid. Police said the land is situated adjacent to the Mattala Airport. Police handed over the suspect, who is a resident of Sooriyaweva, to the Kataragama Police. BY Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: State sector nurses to protest today
author: Author not found
Content: State service nurses will stage a series of protests today  (12) in major hospitals countrywide demanding the Government to step down as it was merely heaping taxes and tariffs and was unable to provide solutions to long-standing issues including increased interests rates on bank loans and the massive drug shortage the country was facing. General Secretary of the All Ceylon Nurses’ Union (ACNU), S.B. Mediwatta yesterday (11) warned that nurses including those serving at the National Hospitals Colombo and Kandy and Karapitiya would protest the from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. demanding the Government to either find solutions or step down as it was not able to give solutions to the drug shortage in State hospitals and other issues. Nurses worked closely with in-ward patients and patients complained to them when they do not get their medicine or are unable to undergo required laboratory tests. The issue has been growing since last year and the Government has been unable to find any long-term solution, they said. The protests are also against the unjust manner in which the State and private banks had increased interest rates on loans as a result of the Central Bank’s lending rates. Mediwatta said it had severely impacted nurses who had taken loans from Banks and were unable to meet their loan payments as a result of  increased rates. Their wages were not upped at the rate that Banks have increased interest rates for loan payments. Nurses wages’ have not increased parallel to the new hike in electricity bills, he lamented. The ACNU General Secretary said on 5 July 2021,  the Government pledged to amend a Circular and award Grade promotions to 14,000 nurses. They have to serve for five years to be promoted from Class Three to Class Two and seven years to be promoted to Class One. But due to shortcomings in the Circular even after a lapse of one year and five months the Health Ministry has been dragging its feet regarding the promotions. He said nurses would be able to get increments with the promotions that were long due.  Madewatta lashing out said the State was not doing anything to fill cadre requirements in hospitals. Nursing posts were left vacant due to retirement and the increasing tendency of nurses leaving the country to serve abroad. He accused the Health Ministry of violating circular 2/19/2019 issued in 2003 by the then Health Secretary. Payments were made according to this Circular till recently. But now there were attempts to violate that Circular and reduce payments.     By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SC upholds High Court ruling in bribery case
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (11) affirmed the conviction of Chief-of-Staff of former President Maithripala Sirisena Kusumdasa Mahanama and former Chairman of the State Timber Corporation (STC) Chairman, Piyadasa Dissanayake by the Colombo High Court Trial on several charges under the Bribery Act. Mahanama and Dissanayake were indicted by the Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) before the High Court of the Colombo The Complainant K.P. Nagarajah, an Indian National was involved in the Sugar Industry and acted as a representative/ shareholder to a foreign investor who was interested in purchasing the State-owned Kanthale Sugar Factory. The evidence led before the High Court at Bar revealed (that the Complainant had observed an inordinate delay in implementing the unsolicited proposal to purchase the Kanthale Sugar Factory when the matter had been approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. Since the Complainant was not happy with the progress made, he brought it to the notice of an official in the Prime Minister’s Officer and the matter had referred to the CIABOC by an Additional Secretary to the Prime Minister’s Officer. The Complainant Nagarajah had appeared before the Investigation Unit of CIABOC on a telephone message received by the said division. During the same period, the complainant had a few meetings with the two accused and it was the position of the witness that the accused had solicited a sum of Rs 20 million as an advance in order to finalise matters pending at that time. Thereby, the aggregate sentence imposed 20 years Rigorous Imprisonment with a fine of Rs 65000 and compensation of Rs 20 million in terms of section 26 of the Bribery Act for Mahanama and 12 years Rigorous Imprisonment with a fine ofRs 55,000 for Dissanayake. Being aggrieved by the said conviction and the sentence imposed on them by the High Court at Bar, both Accused Appellants had preferred two appeals to the Supreme Court. Amongst the arguments put forth by appellants was that they were deprived of a fair trial. Thereby, the Bench yesterday (11), concluded that the investigative technique adopted by the CIABOC does not amount to an entrapment and that the Appellants have not been deprived of a fair trial and upheld the decision of the High Court. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya launched
author: Author not found
Content: A new coalition titled Nidahas Janatha Sandhanaya (People’s Freedom Alliance) formed by the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), together with several other political parties and the Group of Independent MPs in Parliament, was launched yesterday (11), to contest the upcoming Local Government Election. The SLFP, Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya, and the group of independent MPs in Parliament are the members of the new coalition. The symbol is the helicopter. The SLFP-chaired by former President Maithripala Sirisena, independent SLPP MPs Dullus Alahapperuma, Prof. G.L. Peiris, including the Freedom People’s Alliance, the Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya headed by MP Wimal Weerawansa, and independent MPs Anura Priyadharshana Yapa and Sudharshani Fernandopulle alongside other independent MPs participated in the event. The event was held at SLFP headquarters in Colombo.

author: Author not found

Fundamental rights and franchise are two important aspects of the sovereignty of the people of Sri Lanka which is inalienable,” BASL said. They added that any unlawful attempt to interfere with the exercise of the franchise and any attempt to prevent people from exercising their sovereign right to choose their representatives at whatever level of Government will be a blatant attack on the Rule of Law and Democracy in Sri Lanka and that such move will have far-reaching consequences.  It was further noted that previous attempts by different administrations over the years to interfere with the franchise of the people has resulted in disastrous consequences for the country and its people. “The BASL is firmly of the view that the Election Commission should be allowed to exercise its powers mandated under the Constitution and the law without interference. (FT)

title: Adarsha arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Adarsha Karandana, who accused the President’s former adviser Prof. Ashu Marasinghe of bestiality, was arrested by the Police Computer Crimes Division, yesterday (11). Together with former PM Hirunika Premachandra, Karandana accused Prof. Marasinghe of sexually abusing her pet dog, disclosing a video footage and several photos, during a media briefing held on 23 December 2022. Following their media briefing, Marasinghe filed a complaint at the CID stating that the video was doctored. He also sent Letters of Demand (LoD) to Premachandra and Karadana over the incident. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Amend ‘unfair’ Inland Revenue Act
author: Author not found
Content: Handing over a petition with 15,000 signatures from doctors to the Additional Secretary to the President, urging President Ranil Wickremesinghe to amend the new Inland Revenue Act enacted this month, medical officers warned they will resort to further stringent trade union measures if no action was taken to make those amendments.  Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam when contacted yesterday (11) said they had declared a “black week” from 23 January to step up their protests against the new Inland Revenue Act which will force doctors to pay two months’ salary as taxes if measures were not taken to amend it. Accordingly, they will only receive 10 months wages under such circumstances. He said awareness will be created amongst the public, religious leaders, and Parliamentarians as to the unfairness of the Act. The union will also take measures to include other professional groups from the medical service, engineers, the Federation of University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA), CEB Unions, Registered Medical Officers’ Union and some Sri Lanka Administrative Service (SLAS) officers also affected by the new Act.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President promised to address concerns – TNA
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has assured the Tamil National Alliance (TNA) that he will discuss the issue of private land being occupied by the State in the North and East when he visits Jaffna on 15 January. The TNA, which met President Wickremesinghe on 10 January evening at the Presidential Secretariat, claimed that the meeting did not result in any positive developments. However, the President promised that he will address some of the TNA’s concerns within a week. Following the meeting, TNA Spokesman M.A. Sumanthiran told the media that they discussed the urgent issues that needed to be addressed, including the missing persons and the pursuit of justice for their families, those who had been arrested under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), as well as the Tamils’ land that the State had taken over. The MP claimed that no progress had been made despite the Government’s repeated assurances that it will take necessary action. “On the PTA detainees, the President said they will inform them of how many could be released.” On the truth-finding mission for the missing, the Government has informed the TNA that an office will be set up through a legal mechanism, and that the legal draft will be shown to the TNA. Similarly, they will be shown the legal draft on the PTA. Sumanthiran said during the discussion about the devolution of power as in the Constitution to be implemented, they highlighted the clauses that could be implemented immediately. “We were not given a clear message on the subject,” he said. Sumanthiran further said the Government will inform them on the concerns raised within a week. The TNA in reply said they will meet for the next round of talks after the one-week deadline has passed. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Dr. Ruchitha Perera appointed to Board of Directors of CIM, UK
author: Author not found
Content: Dr. Ruchitha Perera, FCIM, Chartered Marketer (UK) has been elected to the Board of Directors of The Chartered Institute of Marketing, UK for a three-year term beginning December 2022. The appointment was announced at the Annual General Meeting held recently, at Moor Hall, United Kingdom. The Board of Directors consists of ten members, of which, eight represent the UK and Europe and two represent the rest of the world. Ruchitha was elected as per the electoral results from a ballot of all voting members of CIM worldwide. The Board is required to uphold CIM’s constitution and is responsible for the overall governance of CIM and its affairs. The Board is also answerable to CIM members for the activities and functions undertaken to uplift the standards of marketing as a profession globally. Ruchitha is an enthusiastic marketer with a career spanning 30 years, delivering marketing education, business coaching and training. He has also provided leadership to global organisations representing brands such as Acer, IBM, and HP. As an inspirational business coach, specialising in marketing, sustainability, and digital transformation, he has displayed a thorough understanding of marketing trends, driving organisational value through global coaching assignments. In addition to facilitating CIM modules, Ruchitha has also aided both master’s and doctoral programmes internationally. He has guided many professionals and organisations enabling them to be future-ready. Furthermore, he takes pride in motivating the next generation of entrepreneurs to embrace innovative marketing through local and international mentoring programs. Ruchitha plans to enhance stakeholder value, create fusion and cordial relationships within and beyond the marketing fraternity by positioning CIM as the global mark of professional marketing. CIM is the world’s leading professional body for marketing and has been operating in Sri Lanka for more than 25 years, specialising in supporting people to achieve internationally recognised professional marketing qualifications. In December 2018, CIM opened a new office in Colombo, which had business development as its primary focus. Business volume has increased by 50% with a sharp 67% increase in professional members and a 40% increase in students by November 2021 and April 2022, respectively. Unfortunately, the economic challenges in Sri Lanka have temporarily hampered aspirations of further growth but a doubling of regional social media followers is a clear indication that the organisations positioning has improved. During COVID restrictions, CIM Sri Lanka held regular webinars to ensure members were still able to connect with CIM’s community of marketers and had access to the insight necessary to progress their careers. To support members during the current economic turmoil, CIM will be providing a full schedule of CPD events to ensure that members remain up to date with their professional development. CIM Sri Lanka and the Maldives is headed by Onalie Dissanayake supported by staff and a team of experienced volunteers.

title: ‘Spot’ unchanged at Rs 364/372
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘benchmark,’ albeit administered market ‘spot,’ remained unchanged for the eleventh consecutive market day at Rs 364/372 to the US dollar yesterday, while the value of the administered, albeit benchmark market ‘spot’ a year ago closed unchanged for the eighty fifth consecutive market day at Rs 202/203 to the dollar in two-way quotes, thus weakened by 80.20-83.25 per cent (Rs 162-169), Year-on-Year (YoY), thereby causing cost-push inflationary pressure, as Sri Lanka is an import-dependent economy. Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) maintained the official, but administered benchmark ‘spot’ unchanged at  Rs 362.24 to the dollar yesterday, while a year ago the official ‘spot’ was artificially strengthened by Rs 0.95 (0.47 per cent) to Rs 200.95 to the dollar. YoY as at yesterday, the official, administered ‘spot’ has been devalued by 80.26 per cent (Rs 161.29).  The band in which the guided market ‘spot’ may currently operate is fixed at +/- three per cent of the officially administered ‘spot’ value, where the latter is applicable for transactions involving the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL), CBSL and/or between the GoSL and/or CBSL. Sources further said trades in the administered market ‘spot’ (Rs 364/372) yesterday were mainly restricted to ‘bank-client’ outright trades, while the interbank foreign exchange (FX) market was however dominated by swaps, which were outside the domain of the FX market for this purpose. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and of its foreign reserves also deals in ‘spot.’ By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Kanchana meets US delegation
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera met visiting US National Security Council Senior Director for South Asia, Rear Admiral Eileen Laubacher, US Ambassador Hanaa Singer-Hamdy, and a US delegation yesterday (11). They discussed Government plans on energy sector reforms, renewable energy, challenges faced, and financial and technical assistance.

title: SJB goes to Court over not accepting deposits for LG Elections
author: Author not found
Content: General Secretary of the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), Ranjith Madduma Bandara filed a Writ Application before the Supreme Court yesterday (11), seeking a Writ of Certiorari quashing the decision to not accept deposits from Local Government Election candidates until further notice. Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government, Commissioner General of Elections, Chairman of the Election Commission, Attorney General and 81 others including the Cabinet of Ministers were named as respondents to the application. Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Neel Hapuhinna issued a letter on Tuesday (10) to the District Secretaries (DSs), ordering them not to accept deposits from candidates for the upcoming Local Government Election. Hapuhinna said, the directive was issued to the District Secretaries, as per the decision taken by the Cabinet on Monday (9) Bandara in his Petition observed that the respondents are bound by Sections 28, 29, and 30 of the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance No.53 of 1946 (as amended) to accept nomination papers and deposits from the Local Government Election candidates which are being duly submitted as per the provisions of the said Ordinance. The petitioner stated that SJB is in the process of depositing the monies in order to be eligible to contest all the local authorities in the country and will be restrained in doing so in the event Divisional Secretaries comply with the directive of Cabinet. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: US keen to strengthen ties with SL – R Adm Laubacher
author: Author not found
Content: The United States values Sri Lanka’s partnership and is keen to further strengthen ties between the two countries through a broad array of partnerships, Senior Director for South Asia, US National Security Council, Rear Admiral Eileen Laubacher said. Laubacher said this when she met President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (11) at the Presidential Secretariat. During the meeting, Laubacher expressed her government’s appreciation for the recovery efforts undertaken by President Wickremesinghe in regard to the economic crisis in the country. President Wickremesinghe outlined the Government’s economic plans including the economic reforms being undertaken. The President also discussed maritime matters, including increased efforts by the Government to crack down on drug smugglers.

title: Nominations for BASL President, Secretary handed over
author: Author not found
Content: Nominations to appoint a new President and Secretary to the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) for 2023/2024 were handed over yesterday (11). Attorney-at-Law Kaushalya Nawaratne submitted nominations for the post of BASL President, while Attorney-at-Law Isuru Balapatabendi submitted nominations for the post of Secretary. Whilst only two nominations have been submitted for the two posts, Nawaratne and Balapatabendi will be elected uncontested. The official appointment will be announced today (12).The incumbent President of  BASL is Saliya Pieris PC while the Secretary is Balapatabendi. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Legal reforms to protect plantation workers’ rights – Manusha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara said special legal measures will be taken to protect plantation workers’ rights. Nanayakkara said this during a discussion with plantation trade union representatives held at the ministry premises. The meeting was held to discuss about the series of programmes that will be implemented to mark 200 years since plantation workers came to Sri Lanka. To resolve numerous problems, Nanayakkara instructed to bring special laws relevant to plantation workers’ rights and to include them when new labour laws are drafted this year relevant to the budget proposals. “Plantation workers are not presently considered as public sector or private sector employees and are not covered by Wage Control Boards. These new laws will give plantation workers protection when it comes to employment related issues. The plantation unions raised issues regarding the fact that the letters sent by the Department of Labour are only in Sinhala language to workers and because of that they are facing difficulties.” Nanayakkara added that all letters sent by the Labour Department should also be sent in Tamil. MPs Jeevan Thondaman, Vadivel Suresh, Secretary of the Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment R.P.A. Wimalaweera, and Labour Commissioner Prabath Chandrakeerthi were also present. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Josephian inter-house drama competition
author: Author not found
Content: The Inter-House Drama Competition of St.Joseph’s College organised by the English Literary Association in collaboration with the Cold Theatre 7, will be held on 15 January 2023 commencing at 5.00 p.m. at the Lionel Wendt Theatre.  St.Joseph’s College has a proven track record for academic success, sports and spiritual uplift. With regard to co-curricular activities, we believe that it is our duty to continuously focus on these areas to give students a holistic education. Drama is one such activity. Many skills are developed by involving in drama such as Programme Creativity, Communication, Problem solving, Accountability, Collaboration, Perseverence, Time management and focus to name a few. Drama also improves social skills including empathy and improves emotional balance, broadens perspectives and critical thinking, builds self-confidence and assists risk taking and encourages team work and co-operation. In my opinion, drama encourages students to think and act creatively, thus developing critical thinking and problem solving skills that can be applied in all areas of learning. Through drama, children are encouraged to take responsible roles and make choices, to participate and guide their own learning. Drama nourishes the imagination. Drama also teaches patience and commitment. Communication is one of the main objectives of drama. Like all the Arts, drama enables students to communicate and understand others. Drama the in school curriculum can develop students ‘ artistic and creative dispositions. It can also enable students to generate new knowledge and skills that are transferable to a variety of artistic, social and work related contexts. We believe that drama is a powerful tool for learning and ‘Whole-Person development’. We want to empower students to use Drama to: Examples of these positive attitudes are: Perseverence, Commitment, Care for others and Respect for fair play. In my opinion, “Drama is an important tool for preparing our young Josephians to live and work in this world that is increasingly Team oriented” rather than hierarchical. Also, Drama can help to build responsible global citizens. That is our ultimate goal and vision. Rev. Fr. Ranjith Andradi, Rector of St. Joseph’s College wished Master Niven Nanayakkara, President of the English Literary Association and his team members success  and is confident that they will regain the Championship this year too. He is also thankful to the teacher-in-charge Sonali Perera andKevin Cruze,  director of Cold Theartre 7 for developing the young Josephians to perform on stage better, besides developing their personalities to become multi-talented students and be of benefit to society. The Chief Guest will be Cinema, Stage Drama and television personality, Wilson Gunaratne. St.Joseph’s College which has imparted knowledge to its highest and broadest sense and produced a galaxy of Josephians, grow from strength to strength”. By Maruthai Ravindhiran

title: Johnston confident of SLPP winning LG Polls
author: Author not found
Content: Former Minister and Kurunegala District SLPP leader Johnston Fernando said that his party was confident of winning the forthcoming local council polls. After placing the SLPP deposits for the Kurunegala District MP Fernando said, “We are confident that as a party we will emerge victorious at the upcoming election. The intelligent people of this country are with us.” Before placing the deposits we participated in religious observances at the Bauddhaloka Vihara in Kurunegala and received the blessings of the Maha Sangha. We are already ahead in this campaign. Some parties are not even ready with their nomination lists. They are not even ready for the elections but demand an elections. This shows their duplicity. The media asks us whether we have problems in working with Ranil Wickremesinghe. How could that be a problem? It is we who elected him the President. He is our president, so why it would be a problem for us to work with him? Sajith Premadasa and others did not come forward when the post and responsibility were offered to them. Only Ranil Wickremesinghe accepted the challenge. Asked to comment on the SLPP’s standpoint over the Central Bank bond scam, the former minister said: “We have not reversed our position. We still demand that punishments must be meted out to those who are responsible for the Bond Scam. “Our leader is President Mahinda Rajapaksa. We have not changed that,” he said.

title: SL inks MoU with French expert, KSAPA
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Plantation Industries signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with KSAPA, a French expert in the rubber industry, for capacity-building of rubber smallholders in Sri Lanka. The MoU between the Ministry of Plantation Industries and KSAPA was finalised with KSAPA Managing Director, Raphael Hara signing it at the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Paris in the presence of Chargé d’affaires and Diplomatic Staff of the Embassy, Deputy Head of Unit, Direct Financing, Ministry of Economics and Finance in France Elise Bengo and Program Manager at KSAPA Ariedn Covo on 5 January. Secretary to the Ministry of Plantation Industries Janaka Dharmakeerthi signed the MoU on 16 December 2022 on behalf of Sri Lanka. The focus of this MoU is to ensure the designing and execution of ‘Rubber Improvement of Value Chain & Embedded Smallholders Resilience (RIVER) Project’ to implement capacity-building activities in the Moneragala District targeting farmer communities that mainly focus on rubber production. This project is expected to strengthen the capacity of around 6,000 rubber smallholders within the Moneragala Rubber Development Project Region with a special focus on the Badalkumbura and Medagama areas. The project intends to harness digital technologies and hands-on technical training to improve rural rubber smallholder farmers’ knowledge, performance, livelihoods, social outlook as well as environmental impacts. The project will be mainly funded by the FASEP grant of the French Ministry of Economy, Finance and Recovery. Additional funds will be provided by the Michelin Group of France as a foreign grant. The project will be designed and implemented by KSAPA, a French public liability company possessing the relevant expertise. Messrs Camso Loadstar in Sri Lanka, which is a subsidiary of the Michelin Group, will also contribute to the operational activities of the project. (SRM)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Kanchana meets US delegation
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera met visiting US National Security Council Senior Director for South Asia, Rear Admiral Eileen Laubacher, US Ambassador Hanaa Singer-Hamdy, and a US delegation yesterday (11). They discussed Government plans on energy sector reforms, renewable energy, challenges faced, and financial and technical assistance.

title: SJB goes to Court over not accepting deposits for LG Elections
author: Author not found
Content: General Secretary of the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), Ranjith Madduma Bandara filed a Writ Application before the Supreme Court yesterday (11), seeking a Writ of Certiorari quashing the decision to not accept deposits from Local Government Election candidates until further notice. Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils, and Local Government, Commissioner General of Elections, Chairman of the Election Commission, Attorney General and 81 others including the Cabinet of Ministers were named as respondents to the application. Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Neel Hapuhinna issued a letter on Tuesday (10) to the District Secretaries (DSs), ordering them not to accept deposits from candidates for the upcoming Local Government Election. Hapuhinna said, the directive was issued to the District Secretaries, as per the decision taken by the Cabinet on Monday (9) Bandara in his Petition observed that the respondents are bound by Sections 28, 29, and 30 of the Local Authorities Elections Ordinance No.53 of 1946 (as amended) to accept nomination papers and deposits from the Local Government Election candidates which are being duly submitted as per the provisions of the said Ordinance. The petitioner stated that SJB is in the process of depositing the monies in order to be eligible to contest all the local authorities in the country and will be restrained in doing so in the event Divisional Secretaries comply with the directive of Cabinet. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: President presents 25-year plan to Cabinet
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe informed Cabinet that seven institutions, 11 new laws and three mega projects will be implemented within the next 25 years. The proposed seven institutions are Institution on History, Institute of Economy and Trade, Institute of Women and Gender, University of Government and Government Policies, University of Agricultural Technology, University of Climatic Change and University of Sports. The new laws are National Commission on Women’s Act, Gender Equality Act, Women Empowerment Act, Child Protection Act, Act on Climatic Change, Commission on Social Equality Act, Reforestation and Forest Cover Act, Live Entities Act; River Mahaweli, Sinharaja, Sri Pada Conserve/ Solitary Peak, Horton Plains, Knuckles, Adam’s Bridge, Laws for oceanic resources expedition and management (Specific economic zone/ within EEZ), Muthurajawela (Conservation) Act and Protection Act of Differently Abled Persons. Implementation of new projects includes 75 urban forests, 1,996 houses in Colombo for low-income families, and projects and programmes on national youth platform. By Thameenah Razeek

author: Author not found
Content: The committee appointed to prepare a new Bill, to replace the PTA, handed over its report to Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe.  The new Bill is titled National Security Bill. Kulasena, Senior Assistant Secretary of the Ministry of Justice Hiranya Perera and several senior officials participated in the handing over. BY Amra Liyakath

title: Sepal Amarasinghe further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (10) further remanded YouTuber Sepal Amarasinghe, until 17 January. Amarasinghe was remanded until yesterday on 6 January, over the recent controversial and derogatory statements, he made about the ‘Sri Dalada Maligawa’. DSG Dileepa Peiris, prosecuting, stated that thanks to the denigrating remarks made by the suspect, connected to Sri Dalada Maligawa it has paved the way for vicious personal attacks on the Internet. Hence, he stressed that if such vicious personal attacks could also come to be embraced by the civilians as well, it could then lead to an unprecedented crisis, it would be only apt to issue an order for the continued incarceration of the suspect. Taking the submissions into consideration, Chief Magistrate Alwis ordered remanded the suspect till the conclusion of the on-going probe into the case. Amarasinghe was arrested in Bellanwila by the CID on 5 January, after the public complaints division of the CID commenced a probe into the matter. Investigations into the matter commenced, when the IGP C. D. Wickramaratne received several written complaints in this regard. Meanwhile, the Chief Prelates of Malwatta and Asgiriya Chapters, Most Ven. Thibbatuwawe Sri Siddhartha SumangalaThera and Most Ven. Warakagoda Sri GnanarathanaThera also wrote to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, raising concerns about the insulting statements made by Amarasinghe and urged the Government to take necessary measures to nip the matter in the bud.Justice Minister Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe also vowed legal action against Amarasinghe, stressing that the religious harmony in the country cannot be allowed to be disrupted. Pursuant to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) Act, No. 56 of 2007, propagating war or advocating national, racial, or religious hatred that constitutes incitement to discrimination, hostility or violence is a punishable offense with rigorous imprisonment for a term not exceeding 10 years. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Removing the wreck could impact marine life – Experts
author: Author not found
Content: The report of the experts’ committee appointed to probe damages caused by the fire that broke out on the MV X-Press Pearl vessel has pointed out that if the shipwreck is removed, there is a risk that the remains could be released to the sea and affect marine life. The report was handed over to Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe yesterday (10). The committee comprised over 40 experts in relevant fields. They further pointed out that measures taken to compensate for damages should be done in accordance with international laws. The report will be handed over to the Attorney General as the next step. In the immediate aftermath of the X-Press Pearl incident, this multi-institutional Stakeholder Consultation Committee (hereinafter referred to as ‘the Committee’) headed by the then Minister of Justice Ali Sabry was appointed. The Committee conducted its first meeting or sitting on 7 June 2021, and had been thereafter conducting periodic meetings, in situ as well as virtually, and was disbanded with the resignation of the Cabinet of Ministers in April 2022. Moreover, the incumbent Minister of Justice had recommenced the convening of the committee meetings. By Faadhila Thassim and Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Public Admin Ministry withdraws controversial letter
author: Author not found
Content: In an interesting turn of events, Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Neel Hapuhinna withdrew a controversial letter, within few hours of issuing it, to the District Secretaries (DSs), ordering them not to accept deposits from candidates for the upcoming Local Government Election. Hapuhinna, in the letter said the directive was issued to the District Secretaries, as per the decision taken by the Cabinet on Monday (9). However, the Secretary withdrew the letter, which was issued yesterday (10) morning, on the evening of the same day. The Election Commission (EC), issuing a Gazette in December last year announced respective District Secretaries or Government Agents have been appointed as Returning Officers while Deputy Commissioners or Assistant Commissioners of Elections have been named Assistant Returning Officers of respective districts. Ceylon Today learns that a letter, in this regard, has been sent to EC Chairman Nimal Punchihewa by the Office of the Cabinet of Ministers on the same day (10) too. However, in a letter to the District Returning Officers, on the same day, the EC noted that it is the responsibility of the District Secretaries to accept the deposits from candidates. Meanwhile, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, making a special statement over the controversy, said this is another desperate attempt to postpone the LG Poll. “The Government should stop these ‘palace conspiracies.’ This is a violation of the Constitution of the country. How can the Cabinet takes these types of decisions arbitrarily? This is illegal,” Premadasa stressed. Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake, also questioned under which power the Cabinet and the Secretary to the Ministry Public Administration issued such directives to the EC and the District Secretaries. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ITAK quits, ‘new’ TNA in the offing
author: Author not found
Content: In the backdrop of Tamils of the North and East calling all Tamil political parties to join hands and find a solution to the ethnic question, Ilankai Thamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK), the main constituent of the Tamil National Alliance (TNA) walked out of the Alliance while People’s Liberation Organisation of Tamil Eelam (PLOTE), Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization (TELO), Eelam People’s Revolutionary Liberation Front  (EPRLF), Tamil Makkal Kootani (TMK), Tamil National Party and Jananayaka Porali Katchi formed by rehabilitated former LTTE cadres are set to join hands as the ‘new’ Tamil National Alliance. As these political alliances continue to hold talks to arrive at a final stance, ITAK members such as MP R. Sampanthan, Mavai Senathirajah, MP M.A. Sumanthiran and MP Charles Nirmalanathan have decided to walk out of the Alliance and agreed to contest independently in the future, according to MP Selvam Adaikalanathan, ITAK member representing the TELO from the Vanni District who has decided to quit the alliance. MP Adaikalanathan said the ITAK wanted to part ways and that his party along with the rest are forming the TNA and will register the party after the Local Government Elections, as they cannot register now. He told Ceylon Today that the TNA was not a registered party and this is the first time they will register as a political party. He pointed out this is not for the LG Polls, but in the future this set of Tamil political parties will be called the TNA. Meanwhile, Leader of Tamil Makkal Kootani, MP C.V. Wigneswaran has announced that his party will contest together with former TNA member and former Jaffna Mayor Manivannan’s team in the Local Government Elections. The announcement regarding the alliance was made after a meeting between them. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: PUCSL allowed to propose ‘better’ amendments – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), Janaka Ratnayake, said the commission needs at least 50 days to act on the Cabinet-approved electricity tariff. He noted that he received the proposal to amend the Electricity Bill on 9 January. Addressing the media yesterday (10), he said the proposal of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) was received by the commission on Monday (9) and the PUCSL was informed to consult with the relevant parties and submit amendments if there is any by 15 February. “We have no objections to that. The issue for us is that we only received this proposal on 9 January. This procedure typically takes 45-50 days. However, we see in the second paragraph of the Cabinet paper that this tariff hike will be effective as an interim measure from 1 January 2023. There is no system in place to change the Electricity Bill in such a way that it affects the past,” he said. Meanwhile, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said the PUCSL has now been given the opportunity to consult with other authorities and come up with better amendments to the Minister of Power and Energy’s Cabinet-approved electricity tariff hike. Speaking at the weekly Cabinet media briefing, he said the electricity tariff hike will take effect from 1 January. According to him, Cabinet has been advised to make the new electricity tariff revision effective 1 January, in consultation with the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and PUCSL. “If the PUCSL proposes new amendments, they will be applied and the required calculations will be done from the next month onwards by the CEB. This means that if the PUCSL states that a tariff reduction is possible, the reduction will begin the following month,” he explained. Cabinet considered the proposal submitted by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stability and National Policies and the Minister of Power and Energy regarding the electricity tariff revision. It was further observed by Cabinet that the Treasury is not able to provide the necessary funds for the CEB and therefore there is no other option but to revise the existing electricity tariffs to ensure a continuous electricity supply in the country while minimising the impact on electricity consumers as much as possible. By Thameenah Razeek

title: President orders to slash 5% of Ministry expenditure
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has instructed to slash 5 per cent of the estimated expenditure allocated under Budget 2023 to all Ministries as a precautionary measure, as the Treasury is facing an acute shortage of funds. According to Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana, who cited the President, the income from taxes paid by the public will be depleted in the months of January, February, and March 2023, impacting the Treasury. Gunawardana, speaking at the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (10) said the payment of Samurdhi allowances to all low-income families is likely to be delayed by nearly two weeks. “The payments of State sector employees’ salaries and welfare expenses such as the Samurdhi allowances have proved difficult for the months of January, February and March. The potential income that could be earned through taxes in the first few months of 2023 has been reduced greatly due to the economic crisis,” he said. Further, he said despite a significant decrease in Government revenue for the months of January, February, and March, essential payments must still be made. He also said the Treasury does not have enough funds to cover day-to-day expenses such as government employee salaries, pensions, interest on government loans, and welfare expenses. “Thus, we will be prioritising the payment of the salaries of public servants and pensions. Because of the financial crisis, Cabinet was also told to cut 5 per cent from all proposals submitted by ministries for the 2023 Budget,” Gunawardena said. He said to pay salaries or the interest on loans, the Government used to print money previously. However, he stressed that this is no longer an option, and that the decision to cut 5 per cent from spending will be unpopular. He said Samurdhi allowances will be paid, but a delay is anticipated. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Adarsha’s anticipatory bail plea dismissed
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis yesterday (10) dismissed the anticipatory bail application filed by Adarsha Karandana, who prayed the Court to issue an order preventing her arrest by the CID, in connection with a complaint lodged against her by President’s former adviser on Parliamentary Affairs, Ashu Marasinghe. Announcing his decision, the Chief Magistrate stated that in his view it would not be apt for him to grant the request made by the applicant and hence, noted that he was rejecting it. The Counsel for the applicant had informed the Court that Marasinghe had lodged a complaint against his client on 24 November last year. The Counsel had informed the Court that via his complaint Marasinghe had charged that his client (G. Wageesha Adarsha) had, during a media conference held on 22 October last year, cast aspersions on Marasinghe’s character related to a pet dog being raised at Marasinghe’s house. Adarsha’s Counsel had informed the Court that if his client is arrested in this regard, it could pose a threat to her life and therefore he urged the Court to issue an order for her release on bail before her imminent arrest. Marasinghe’s Counsel told Chief Magistrate Alwis, that if the applicant is ordered to be released on bail it would hinder the on-going probe into the case and he requested the Court to dismiss the anticipatory bail application filed by the applicant. One of the respondents to the anticipatory bail application, the CID, too was present in Court and stated that as the suspect has failed to support the on-going probe into the case, if she is granted bail it could hamper the inquiry. Hence, the CID requested the Court to not enlarge the suspect on bail. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Chief Magistrate mentioned that as it was unsuitable at this time to grant the anticipatory bail, to the applicant, he was rejecting it. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Devananda identifies obstacles to implement 13A
author: Author not found
Content: In a letter to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Leader of the Eelam People’s Democratic Party (EPDP), Douglas Devananda, submitted a detailed memorandum identifying the shortfalls and the impediments that stand in the way of full implementation of the 13A and proposed a three-stage solution. The three stages are: Stage I – Through Executive and Administrative Actions retaking of the functions wrongfully taken over by the Centre over a span of more than 30 years as well as the taking over of functions wrongfully withheld by the Centre. This could be done through Executive and Administrative means and Stage II – Amending Certain Acts of Parliament: Amending certain provisions of the Provincial Councils Act No. 42 of 1987 and provisions of certain Acts, mainly that were enacted prior to the passing of the 13th Amendment, to be in line with the spirit embodied in the provisions of the 13th Amendment. Stage III – Amendment to the Constitution: Necessary Constitutional Amendment to remove the ambiguity in certain provisions of the 13th Amendment and to make clearly defined allocation of subjects, and limits on the exercise of legislative, executive, judicial and fiscal powers by the different layers of government. Emphasising the significance of the 13A, he noted in the letter dated 5 January, that in the Provincial Council Elections held in the Eastern Province twice and the Northern Province once, except for the elections held for the first time for the merged North-East Province in 1988, all political parties participated and the people voted overwhelmingly with enthusiasm. “It demonstrates their willingness to accept the system. People in the remaining provinces are also accustomed to the system, and there is no opposition to its continuation.” He said implementing the 13A in full is the step forward to resolve the political aspirations of the Tamils and his Party has been consistent in this stand for a long period of time. The Indo-Lanka Agreement and the 13th Amendment to the Constitution are the outcomes of the longstanding struggle of the Tamils for a power-sharing mechanism in the areas of their habitation, he underlined. “More than three decades of our experience with the Provincial Councils system is that unless the obstacles and bottlenecks, due to constitutional ambiguity which stand in the way of full implementation of the 13th Amendment are removed, effective implementation of the 13th Amendment is not possible,” he further said. “It is a widely accepted axiom that the essence of the law lies in its spirit. Even the limited extent of devolution envisaged by the 13A has been difficult to realise, with a glaring disparity between what is provided in the text of the Constitution and how those provisions are implemented. Implementing the 13A in a meaningful manner devoid of constant central intrusion into its realm of functions is crucial if it is to serve as a means of dealing with diversity and pluralism within a united country. In the absence of clearly defined allocation of subjects, and limits on the exercise of legislative, executive, judicial and fiscal powers by the different layers of government, particularly between the Centre and the Provincial Councils, implementing the 13A in full would be a futile exercise,” he added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SCHAFFTER’S BROTHER TESTIFIES BEHIND CLOSED DOORS
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (10) ordered the hearing of evidence, into the magisterial inquest into the death of Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Dinesh Schaffter, to be convened in the official chamber of the Colombo Chief Magistrate for a second day. This followed a request made by the family of the deceased. When the hearing of evidence into Schaffter’s death was convened in Open Court, the family of the deceased urged the Additional Magistrate, to conduct it at the Official Chamber of the Chief Magistrate and the request was granted. Hence, it was held at the Chief Magistrate’s Chamber sans the presence of the media. The magisterial inquest commenced at around 12.30 p.m. and lasted for around one hour. During the hearing yesterday, Ramesh Schaffter, a sibling of the deceased, testified. Afterwards further recording of evidence was deferred to 13 January, by the Additional Magistrate. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Cabinet Decisions
author: Author not found
Content: Sustainable development of energy sector A Cabinet sub-committee was appointed under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister at the Cabinet meeting held on 30 August, to identify the policies and strategies to be followed for the sustainable development of the energy sector and to make appropriate recommendations to the Cabinet of Ministers and to provide necessary guidance and monitoring for the efficient implementation of the decisions reached by Cabinet based on those recommendations. After conducting several meetings with relevant stakeholders, professionals and experts the said sub-committee has submitted its report and Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Prime Minister for the implementation of the road map which includes the recommendations and milestones related to the energy sector included in the report. Community-based tourism development project Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Tourism to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding between the Korea Tourism Organisation and Tourism Development Board of Sri Lanka for the  implementation of a community-based tourism development project focusing on the Central and North-Eastern regions of Sri Lanka under a financial grant from the Korea Tourism Organisation. The Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority has proposed the implementation of a “community-based tourism development project” under the sponsorship of the Korean Tourism Organisation focusing on the Kutchiveli tourism development areas owned by the Authority. A delegation of the Korea Tourism Organisation has conducted a feasibility study on the relevant project proposal. South Korea has agreed to provide financial assistance amounting to 2.172 billion South Korean won for the implementation of the proposed project. As the first phase, it has been agreed to provide a grant of 400 million won for the preparation of the overall plan of the relevant tourism development project, the preparation of the training programme and the implementation of a pilot project. Export-oriented oil refinery in Hambantota Cabinet approved the proposal tabled by the Minister of Power and Energy for declarations of intent to select an appropriate investor to set up an oil refinery in the proximity of Hambantota and to call for detailed proposals from investors who meet fundamental qualifications. It has been recognised that high potential exists to set up an export-oriented oil refinery and related products processing centre in Hambantota. Numerous parties and foreign investors are interested in this investment opportunity. Revisions to national policy on management of chemical substances Cabinet approved the resolution tabled by the Minister of Environment to implement the national policy on the management of chemicals that has been prepared by discussing with all the stakeholders including the relevant major State institutions and Non-Government organisations, paying attention to chemical substances management to act according to the international conventions signed by Sri Lanka. According to the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), approximately 350,000 chemicals are in the market worldwide. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), approximately 2 million individuals die due to being exposed to chemicals. Whereas, it is confirmed that people experience various ailments due to failure to manage chemicals properly. Considering the negative impact caused to the environment and human health, when utilising chemicals, “proper management of hazardous chemicals in an environmental and human-friendly manner” has been recognised as a matter that should be attended to, with global priority in the Agenda 21 of the UN. Purchasing hydrophobic foldable extreme contact lenses International competitive bids have been called for in regard to this procurement. In terms of the recommendations of the standing procurement committee appointed by Cabinet, the Minister of Health proposed to award the relevant contract to ‘M/s Vision Solutions Lanka (Pvt) Ltd.’ and Cabinet approval was granted. Sri Rahularama Purana Viharastha Samanera Bikku College The Draft Bill on Sri Rahularama Purana Viharastha Samanera Attitude Development Bikku College (Incorporated) Balapitiya has been submitted to Parliament by MP Gayantha Karunatilleka as a private resolution. The Draft Bill has been formally prepared by the Legal Draftsman and the clearance of the Attorney General has been granted to the same. Cabinet approved the resolution tabled by the Minister of Education for submission of a report to Parliament recommending the relevant Draft Bill as per Provision 52 (6) of the Parliamentary Standing Orders.

title: All five ATM scam suspects remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Baddegama Chief Magistrate M. P. G. Fernando yesterday (10) remanded, till 23 January, the five suspects, including the IP of the Meegahathenna Police, who were charged with siphoning nearly Rs 10 million from several ATMs, belonging to State banks in the Southern Province. The five suspects include the IP of the Meegahathenna Police, two Bulgarians, a Canadian and a Sri Lankan, according to Police. The foreign duo, were arrested by the Computer Crime Investigation Division of the CID, while they were staying at a luxury apartment complex in Colombo 5. Upon searching the apartment complex, officers seized various equipment used by them to carry out the scam, including laptops, cell phones and walkie-talkies. Meanwhile, the OIC of the Administration Division of the Meegahathenna Police was also arrested in Amugoda, Pitigala, on suspicion of aiding and abetting the suspects. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Devananda identifies obstacles to implement 13A
author: Author not found
Content: In a letter to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Leader of the Eelam People’s Democratic Party (EPDP), Douglas Devananda, submitted a detailed memorandum identifying the shortfalls and the impediments that stand in the way of full implementation of the 13A and proposed a three-stage solution. The three stages are: Stage I – Through Executive and Administrative Actions retaking of the functions wrongfully taken over by the Centre over a span of more than 30 years as well as the taking over of functions wrongfully withheld by the Centre. This could be done through Executive and Administrative means and Stage II – Amending Certain Acts of Parliament: Amending certain provisions of the Provincial Councils Act No. 42 of 1987 and provisions of certain Acts, mainly that were enacted prior to the passing of the 13th Amendment, to be in line with the spirit embodied in the provisions of the 13th Amendment. Stage III – Amendment to the Constitution: Necessary Constitutional Amendment to remove the ambiguity in certain provisions of the 13th Amendment and to make clearly defined allocation of subjects, and limits on the exercise of legislative, executive, judicial and fiscal powers by the different layers of government. Emphasising the significance of the 13A, he noted in the letter dated 5 January, that in the Provincial Council Elections held in the Eastern Province twice and the Northern Province once, except for the elections held for the first time for the merged North-East Province in 1988, all political parties participated and the people voted overwhelmingly with enthusiasm. “It demonstrates their willingness to accept the system. People in the remaining provinces are also accustomed to the system, and there is no opposition to its continuation.” He said implementing the 13A in full is the step forward to resolve the political aspirations of the Tamils and his Party has been consistent in this stand for a long period of time. The Indo-Lanka Agreement and the 13th Amendment to the Constitution are the outcomes of the longstanding struggle of the Tamils for a power-sharing mechanism in the areas of their habitation, he underlined. “More than three decades of our experience with the Provincial Councils system is that unless the obstacles and bottlenecks, due to constitutional ambiguity which stand in the way of full implementation of the 13th Amendment are removed, effective implementation of the 13th Amendment is not possible,” he further said. “It is a widely accepted axiom that the essence of the law lies in its spirit. Even the limited extent of devolution envisaged by the 13A has been difficult to realise, with a glaring disparity between what is provided in the text of the Constitution and how those provisions are implemented. Implementing the 13A in a meaningful manner devoid of constant central intrusion into its realm of functions is crucial if it is to serve as a means of dealing with diversity and pluralism within a united country. In the absence of clearly defined allocation of subjects, and limits on the exercise of legislative, executive, judicial and fiscal powers by the different layers of government, particularly between the Centre and the Provincial Councils, implementing the 13A in full would be a futile exercise,” he added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SCHAFFTER’S BROTHER TESTIFIES BEHIND CLOSED DOORS
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (10) ordered the hearing of evidence, into the magisterial inquest into the death of Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC Dinesh Schaffter, to be convened in the official chamber of the Colombo Chief Magistrate for a second day. This followed a request made by the family of the deceased. When the hearing of evidence into Schaffter’s death was convened in Open Court, the family of the deceased urged the Additional Magistrate, to conduct it at the Official Chamber of the Chief Magistrate and the request was granted. Hence, it was held at the Chief Magistrate’s Chamber sans the presence of the media. The magisterial inquest commenced at around 12.30 p.m. and lasted for around one hour. During the hearing yesterday, Ramesh Schaffter, a sibling of the deceased, testified. Afterwards further recording of evidence was deferred to 13 January, by the Additional Magistrate. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: COPF unhappy over actions of CPCEC officials
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Finance (COPF) expressed its displeasure over the operations of the Colombo Port City Economic Commission (CPCEC), as its senior officials did not appear before the committee and failed to provide proper notice of absence. Therefore, the Secretary to the Commission was instructed by the Committee on Public Finance to submit in writing a reasonable explanation as to why high officials of the Commission are not present before the committee when they had been summoned before the Committee on Public Finance on 21 December 2022. Whilst emphasising on the importance of the Port City, project for the purpose of generating investments and the work done thus far, the COPF, chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva, unanimously expressed dissatisfaction and advised the officials present that a better sense of responsibility needs to be exercised as professionals handling such project of importance.

title: Petition against sugar scam fixed for support
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights Petition filed by Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) Politburo member Sunil Handunnetti, against those responsible for the 2020 sugar scam, was fixed for support by the Supreme Court yesterday (9). Accordingly, the Petition, filed seeking an order for the recovery of Rs 15.9 billion from those responsible for the sugar scam, was fixed to be taken up on 6 May. The former Secretary to the President P.B. Jayasundera, former Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, S.R. Attygalle, former Sathosa Chairman Nushad Perera, former Wilma Chairman Sajath Mausoon, former Consumer Affairs Authority Chairman Shantha Dissanayake and the Attorney General were named as respondents to the Petition. The Petitioner observed that the Fundamental Rights of the public has been violated by the respondents, due to the sugar scam, which had caused a loss to the Government. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Trouble for those feeding wild jumbos
author: Author not found
Content: Director General of the Department of Wildlife Conservation (DWC) Chandana Sooriyabandara instructed wildlife officials to arrest and take legal action against people who feed wild elephants and those who behave in a manner that harms wild elephants. This follows instructions, given by Minister of Agriculture, Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera, to commence a short-term programme to provide solutions to the increase in accidents, on the Buttala-Kataragama road, due to wild elephant attacks. Officers and vehicles of the Yala Forest Site Office were deployed to drive the wild elephants on the Buttala – Kataragama road back into the forest and to prevent accidents. Sooriyabandara said that the DWC has decided to continue to implement this programme. According to the DWC, the damage caused by wild elephants has increased as those travelling on this road feed the wild elephants, and as the elephants are used to getting food from the vehicles it often results in mauling.  Sooriyabandara added that due to the deployment of mobile vehicles on the Buttala-Kataragama road, wild elephants have stopped coming to the road, and incidents of damage to vehicles have not been reported during such time. (FT)

title: Govt to import 200,000 hatching eggs
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to address the shortage of mother hens needed for egg production, the Ministry of Agriculture and the Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation have decided to import 200,000 hatching eggs. It has been said the current monthly egg production in the country has decreased to 30 million, due to a lack of animal feed as well as a reduction in the annual import of mother hens from 80,000 to 40,000. Although 80,000 hens were imported each year, the number dropped to 40,000 in the previous year, affecting egg and poultry meat production. As a result, importing mother hens may cause egg production to be delayed by 11 months. As an alternative, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera has advised the Ministry of Agriculture’s Livestock Development to take steps to import 200,000 hatching eggs. The Department of Animal Production and Health has already prepared the necessary basic activities and the procedure for obtaining mother birds from imported bred eggs will be implemented using the Livestock Development Board’s two hatcheries located at the Miriswatta and Marawila farms. The importation of hatched eggs has now been transferred to the National Livestock Development Board and private sector institutions, with the Livestock Development Division of the Ministry of Agriculture and the Department of Animal Production and Health providing the necessary facilities. “Although we have been self-sufficient through egg and poultry production in the past, with the ban on chemical fertiliser in 2021, the lack of fodder has severely affected the decline in animal production due to the drop in maize production to 40 per cent. Our country’s annual egg requirement is approximately 2,990 million. The monthly egg requirement is between 249 and 250 million. However, it has now dropped to 30 million. If these bred eggs are imported before the end of February, the production of eggs in this country can be brought to a high level by next May and June,” the officials in charge of the Livestock Development Division pointed out.

title: Moneragala SSP arrested with ganja plants
author: Author not found
Content: Moneragala SSP Sisira Kumara was arrested by the Police Special Task Force (STF) for having over 650 Ganja plants at his official residence. Police Media Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said a Police Constable, who worked as the driver, and a Police Sergeant, who worked at the official residence of the SSP Kumara, were also taken into STF custody. Additionally, one individual from Moneragala and two individuals from Moratuwa were also taken into custody on suspicions of aiding and abetting the incident. SSP Thalduwa added a metal detector was also taken into custody during the raid conducted on 8 January. He added that the Criminal Investigation Department has taken over the investigation. He noted that disciplinary actions will also be taken against the suspects in the future. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Institutions barred from paying employees’ PAYE
author: Author not found
Content: Payment of the PAYE Tax of State and Semi-Government sector employees, from the funds of the respective institutions, will be prohibited and a circular in that connection will be issued within this week, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said yesterday (9). Issuing a statement, Siyambalapitiya said the PAYE Tax was introduced for employees of State and semi-Government institutions who earn an income surpassing a specified level. “It is reported recently that some institutions are planning to use the institution’s funds to pay the PAYE Tax of employees. Therefore, a decision was taken to prevent the payment of PAYE Tax for State and semi-Government employees via the institutions’ funds,” he said. (AK)

title: IP among five arrested over ATM scam
author: Author not found
Content: An Inspector attached to the Meegahatenna Police, was arrested in connection with the stealing of over Rs 100 million from three ATMs in Southern Province, the Computer Crimes Division attached to the CID said. Apart from the Inspector, two foreigners and two locals were also apprehended on charges of stealing from ATM machines from three State-run banks. Police stated that two suspects were foreign nationals, One a Canadian and the other Bulgarian. It was observed that both were well versed in computer technology. The Police added that the two suspect foreigners were arrested at the Havelock City Housing Complex, in Colombo 5, while the Inspector had been arrested at Amugoda in the Pitigala Police Division. Two other suspects were rounded up from Elpitiya and Negombo. Police stated that besides the suspects they also seized laptops used in the thefts, various keys used for breaking into the ATMs walkie-talkies, mobile phones along with a few ATM cards and cash amounting to Rs 150,000. The suspects robbed the cash from ATMs belonging to a State banks situated at Karapitiya, Hikkaduwa and Baddegama. BY Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo and Sumith Premathilaka – Pothupitiya

title: CID to grill Minister’s Coordinating Secy
author: Author not found
Content: The CID is preparing to interrogate the Coordinating Secretary to a Cabinet Minister, in connection with the theft of the artefact known as ‘Sandagala’ from Kundasale recently, Ceylon Today learns. Accordingly, a Police team had visited a building construction site owned by the Coordinating Secretary, at Aruppala in Kandy yesterday, but the latter had not been there. Inquiries conducted into the theft to date had revealed that the backhoe used to remove the 1,000 kg artefact had belonged to the firm owned by the Coordinating Secretary. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy
