title: THOSE CALLING FOR CHANGE MUST PREPARE FOR LG POLLS – RASAMANICKAM
author: Author not found
Content: ITAK Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam yesterday (4) called upon everyone who fought for change in to prepare for the Local Government (LG) Polls expected to be held in March this year. Rasamanickam yesterday (4) met the National Delimitation Commission led by former Election Commission Chairman Mahinda Deshapriya including Jayalath R. V. Dissanayake, W. M. M. R. Adikari, K. Thavalingam and I. A. Hameed in relation to the proposed LG polls and the progress of demarcation activities. Rasamanickam made this open invitation to everyone who fought for change while commenting to the media following the meeting with committee members. He said that those who fought for change had got the opportunity now and everyone must make use of it. Rasamanickam accused that the Government of taking forward certain mechanisms to reduce the number of wards and that some ruling members were supporting to this move. The number of wards in the Batticaloa District must be increased instead of reducing the number of wards, he said. “We reiterated this matter during the meeting with committee members,” Rasamanickam added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: JICA celebrates 40 y ears in SL
author: Author not found
Content: Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), the official overseas development agency of the Japanese Government celebrated its 40th year of establishment of the JICA Sri Lanka (SL) Office in Colombo on 15 December 2022, JICA said yesterday.  The event took place at its Colombo office with the participation of the staff, ex-staff members of JICA Alumni Association and their families, it said. As part of the event, the staff with the longest outstanding service was recognised and appreciated for their dedication at JICA Sri Lanka. JICA will continue to support Sri Lanka towards the economic and social development of the country and look forward to celebrate many more years of a relationship with Sri Lanka assuring its assistance towards overcoming the development challenges the country is currently facing, said JICA. Japan’s development assistance in the form of technical cooperation has been provided to Sri Lanka since 1954 and JICA was established in Japan in the year 1974, it added. Since then, JICA as a development partner continues to support the Government of Sri Lanka to implement a range of projects across priority sectors, intensifying the overall growth of Sri Lanka, JICA said. In 1982, JICA Sri Lanka Office was established and among the many commendable joint interventions are infrastructure development for quality growth, rural development for inclusive growth and Social infrastructure development for vulnerability reduction. In 2008, new JICA began operations after the merger with the Overseas Economic Cooperation Operations Department of the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC). JICA assists and supports developing countries as the executing agency of Japanese Official Development Assistance (ODA). The vision of JICA “Leading the World with Trust” has steered resolution of issues of developing countries by using the most suitable tools of various assistance methods and a combined regional-country-and issue-oriented approach, said JICA. JICA’s Chief Representative to Sri Lanka Tetsuya Yamada was present at this occasion. (PA)

title: Locally produced fertiliser for tea, vegetables
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Commercial Fertiliser Company introduced a special mixed fertiliser for tea and vegetables under the programme to provide fertiliser for farming activities implemented by the Government. Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera stated that farmers had raised concerns on the failure to provide fertiliser for tea, vegetables and potatoes. He added that he instructed the Ceylon Fertiliser Company Limited and Colombo Commercial Fertiliser Limited to produce two types of special fertiliser within a week, one for potato cultivation and the other for tea cultivation. The Colombo Commercial Fertiliser Company has produced 800 MT of this fertiliser. (FT)

title: No 10 fighter Squadron celebrates 27th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: No 10 fighter Squadron celebrates its 27th Anniversary under its present Commanding Officer Wing Commander Prabath Wijekoon and is under a transformation with the fleet up gradation to C12 version, which will expand its limits further with the performance enhancement through highly sophisticated avionics package, navigation and weapon systems. With these new additions the Squadron would render its service to the nation in the future as the leading fighter of SLAF defending national air space. With the endowing effort and commitment of its professional crew under the guidance of its Commanding Officer, the No 10 Fighter Squadron will continue to thrive in future keeping the Sri Lanka Air Force ensign flying high. The No 10 Fighter Squadrons was founded on 5 January 1996 with the induction of six new graceful tailless delta Kfir C2s based at SLAF Katunayake under the command of Squadron Leader Priyantha Gunasinghe. The Squadron was reinforced in  2000 with the arrival of another nine Kfir C2s and C7s enhancing the fleet up to fifteen fighters. The Kfir was developed by Israel as a multirole all weather day night fighter, which satisfied almost all the fighter capabilities of SLAF’s through Battlefield Air Strike, Air Interception, Air Interdiction, Maritime Air strikes with precision and deadly force. At the outset, the No 10 Fighter Squadron was strengthened with four pilots, four engineering officers and seventy technicians, who were trained by Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) and instructor pilots from Israel Air Force. The present Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana was first Officer Commanding Operations and succeeded as the second Commanding Officer from 7th of June 2000. First batch of pilots included Wing Commander Janaka Wijayathilake (Retd) and Group Captain Sajeewa Hendawitharana (Retd). Kfir was the first aircraft to be inducted to SLAF with a Head Up Display (HUD) and a sophisticated Weapons Delivery and Navigation System (WDNS). In addition to the bombload of 5.4 tons, the Kfir has two 30mm cannon guns inbuilt to suppliment its firepower. The Kfir with its formidable firepower and precision targeting was responsible for neutralizing the greatest number of LTTE strongholds, ammunition dumps, fuel depots, troop concentrations, maritime elements and artillery gun positions effectively reducing the LTTE attrition for ground troops to advance on ground. Since its inception, the Squadron has logged more than 2,800 operational flying hours and has delivered over 3,500 tons of weapons precisely over confirmed enemy targets. Further, with the instigation of precision guided munitions (PGM) Kfirs contributed its effort promptly and effectively, whenever it was called upon with distinction and honour. The results of these efforts were clearly manifested in the nation’s ultimate victory over terrorism in 2009. On 8 March 2009 President Mahinda Rajapaksa recognized the contribution of the squadron by awarding Presidents’ Colours to No 10 Fighter Squadron for its unique and enduring action to eliminate the terrorism, which pestered the Island nation for over three decades.

title: FAO, Fisheries Ministry launch modified multi-day fishing vessel
author: Author not found
Content: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and the Fisheries Ministry launched a modified multiday fishing vessel at an event in Colombo to improve the quality of fish and reduce post-harvest loss in the fisheries sector, FAO said yesterday. The modified vessel was made by the Government of Sri Lanka owned Cey-Nor Foundation Ltd. Studies by the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) indicate that the fish quality loss in some harbours is at 60 – 70 percent, FAO further said. Some of the issues contributing to these losses include the lack of an adequate cooling system in multi-day fishing vessels that use weeks-old ice to maintain low temperatures and the captured harvest not being handled or stored properly by fishers, which reduces the quality of the overall harvest and damage the bottom layer of stored fish, it said.  To address this issue, FAO, together with the Ministry and NARA, modified the design of a multi-day fishing vessel as a pilot project to introduce new boat designs that provide an economically viable solution to minimize the quality loss of fish harvests. By reducing the existing post-harvest losses, the investment for the proposed new design can be recovered within 3.5 years, said FAO.  The modified multi-day vessel features a pilot coolant system in fish holds and storage as well as a modified fish holding facility to minimize the physical damage to fish due to overload. The modified vessel was launched at an event in Colombo under the auspices of Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda, State Minister Piyal Nishantha de Silva and FAO Assistant Representative for Sri Lanka Nalin Munasinghe. The pilot will be experimented for a month before being available in the market. Fish products are an important source of animal protein for Sri Lanka and the sector contributes about 1.1 percent to Sri Lanka’s GDP, added FAO.  (PA)

title: ‘Royal Enfield Motor Cycle Tour Series 2023’ in Negombo
author: Author not found
Content: The flagging off of the first ‘Royal Enfield Motor Cycle Tour Series 2023’ organised by Vintage Rides will take place on 8 January 2023 in Negombo. Connaissance de Ceylan is the local partner for the groups. Vintage Rides specialises in organising biking tours across the globe offering unforgettable human and  authentic motorcycle experiences. Connaissance De Ceylan   has been working with Vintage Rides for over 10 years promoting biking tours in Sri Lanka, with a new concept 10-day circuit tour and six groups have confirmed participation. The flag off ceremony for the first group will be held over the weekend with over 14 French participants.  (SRM)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Veterinarian remanded for bribery
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Prasanna Alwis remanded, till 17 January, a veterinarian, who charged with soliciting a bribe. The suspect veterinarian had been charged with seeking a bribe of Rs 26,000, to facilitate the registration of 30 head of cattle owned by a complainant. The suspect veterinarian was identified as Balasingham Mayura, attached to the Veterinary Office situated at Karadiyakaru. The Bribery Commission told Magistrate Alwis that the suspect had been nabbed by their sleuths on 22 December last year, when he had sought the aforementioned bribe from a complainant. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: PETITION FILED AGAINST HOLDING LG POLLS
author: Author not found
Content: A Writ Petition was filed before the Supreme Court seeking an order suspending the holding of the Local Government Elections in March 2023. The Petition was filed by Colonel (Retired), W.M.R. Wijesundara on Monday (2). The Chairman of the Election Commission and its members, Secretary of the Ministry of Finance and the Attorney General were among the respondents named in the Petition. The Petitioner observed that based on information received from the Election Commission, it costs over Rs 10 billion to hold the Local Government Elections, and that the funds will be released depending on the State income and the ability to borrow, adding that holding an election amidst an economic crisis could be catastrophic. It was further noted in the Petition that due to the inability of obtaining bilateral and multilateral loans, if money will be printed for such purpose, it would only result in further inflation and there could be a further economic downturn. Previously two petitions were filed in Supreme Court, by a group of MPs calling for an interim order to be issued to the Election Commission for steps to be taken to hold the Local Government Election in March 2023. The petitions were filed by MPs Dayasiri Jayasekara, Lakshman Kiriella, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, M.A. Sumanthiran, Ranjith Madduma Bandara and G.L. Peiris, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Sandun Gamage. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Transport Ministry recalls retired Railway staff
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Transport decided to recall several retired Railway employees, after over 10 train journeys were cancelled yesterday (3) for the fourth consecutive day. These appointments will be on contract basis. Several train journeys had to be cancelled following the retirement of hundreds of Railway employees, leaving commuters stranded. The Sri Lanka Station Masters’ Union (SLSMU) said 18 train journeys were cancelled yesterday (3). However, the Transport Ministry said the actual number of cancellations was 14. Meanwhile, the SLSMU said 44 Station Masters will be appointed today (4) at the Maga Neguma office in Battaramulla under the patronage of Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardana. The union said train cancellations will not be resolved by these appointments, as there is a shortage of locomotive drivers, controllers, cabin men, and train assistants. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Govt questions reliability of Intelligence services
author: Author not found
Content: The Government questioned the credibility and efficiency of the Sri Lankan Intelligence network after notorious underworld gangster Mohamed Najim Mohamed Imran, alias ‘Kanjipani Imran’ fled to India, days after he was released on bail. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana told the media yesterday (3), that concerns about the conduct of Intelligence Officers were raised after the Easter Sunday Attacks in 2019 as well, and that the shortcomings identified in the Intelligence service in the country are being addressed in several phases. Tamil Nadu Intelligence has sounded an alert to senior Police Officers across the State to mount vigil along the coastal districts and look for Imran and his associate who landed along the Ramanathapuram district coast on 25 December 2022. Kanjipani Imran, wanted for various offences, including murders and criminal intimidation, was arrested in Dubai in 2019 and deported to Sri Lanka. He was in judicial custody till a local Court granted him bail on payment of two sureties, in Rs 5 million. The intelligence services had a specific input from central intelligence agencies and reliable sources that Imran was planning to enter India after his release on bail. The information was that he left the Court in disguise and moved to Talaimannar from where his associates were making arrangements for his infiltration into India. “Imran is a drug kingpin with strong connections with heroin and cocaine suppliers based out of Afghanistan and Pakistan. He is facing several cases in Sri Lanka. On information that Imran would attend a birthday function in Dubai, a special team arrested him there in 2019. His gang is actively involved in big-time smuggling of drugs across maritime boundary lines,” a senior Police Officer told The Hindu recently. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Cabinet greenlights egg imports
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved a proposal tabled by Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando to import eggs if the need arises. This is in a bid to prevent an egg shortage and control rising egg prices in the country. Cabinet Spokesman, Minister Bandula Gunawardana said the decision was made after the Food Policy Committee briefed Cabinet on the present egg shortage and high prices. However, he said imports are only temporary. Concurrently, the All Ceylon Egg Producers’ Association warned importing eggs would jeopardise the local industry and local producers would step away from the industry as a result. Meanwhile, All Ceylon Bakery Owners’ Association (ACBOA) President N.K. Jayawardena urged the Government to grant them permission to import eggs, as bakers were facing serious problems in running their business due to the high prices of eggs in the local market. He insisted they can provide eggs at a price between Rs 30 and Rs 35 if his association is allowed to import eggs from India and Pakistan. He also said bakery owners have to raise the prices of all bakery products except bread as the price of eggs has risen to around Rs 70. Speaking further, he said the hoodwinking drama of selling eggs brought in lorries at Rs 55 should be halted and added that the Government can allow egg imports at the stroke of a pen. By Thameenah Razeek

title: President calls for reports from SriLankan, CPC
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe called for reports from the Chairmen of SriLankan Airlines (SLA) and Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) on payment of bonuses at a time when both institutions were running at a loss. The President made this directive after a report revealed that these two institutions have violated existing circulars and paid bonuses to their employees. According to the report, the CPC has paid two months’ salary as bonus while SriLankan Airlines has paid Rs 100,000 to each employee. The said report revealed even though the Finance Ministry issued clear instructions through a circular, the bonuses have been paid to CPC employees claiming that the corporation earns profits due to fuel price hikes. To do this calculation, total debts of the CPC had been deliberately omitted. It is revealed that Rs 1.2 billion has been paid to 4,200 CPC employees as bonuses. Some high-ranking CPC officials had been paid Rs 1 million in bonuses. Meanwhile, SriLankan Airlines had spent Rs 580 million on bonuses for its 5,800 employees. These payments were made claiming that a Supreme Court ruling has permitted to pay bonuses as 13th month salary.

title: Govt vets warn of possible bird flu outbreak
author: Author not found
Content: With Cabinet greenlighting egg imports, the Government Veterinary Surgeons’ Association (GVSA) raised concerns on the possible threat of avian flu entering the country. They, therefore, called for the authorities to streamline the import process and not allow importers to act in an ad hoc manner owing to the possibility of avian flu entering the country. GVSA President, Dr. Sisira Piyasiri yesterday (3) said they had worked in collaboration with animal research and investigation institutions for a lengthy period to prevent avian influenza (AI) from entering the country. “Unregulated egg imports could lead to a serious crisis as we run the risk of inviting a dangerous disease like avian influenza,” he warned.  It would also seriously affect the local egg production and poultry industry. At present, Sri Lanka enjoys the recognition of being identified as a country without AI enhancing its abilities of exporting chicken. Also, a large number of jobs which are depending on the egg industry would also be lost as a result of this decision, he said. Informed Veterinary sources said, Sri Lanka was the only Asian country which did not have AI while the disease was endemic in countries like India, Pakistan, Nepal and Bangladesh. Meanwhile, Chairman of the All Ceylon Chicken Producers’ Association (ACCPA), Ajith Gunasekara said his outfit did not believe that the decision to import eggs at this juncture was timely. Sri Lanka has always been self-sufficient in egg production. And measures were being taken by producers to enhance their production despite the crises facing them at present, he claimed. Therefore, this move by the Government would only hinder the effort being made by the ACCPA and the All Ceylon Egg Producers’ Association (ACEPA) to increase egg production while encouraging those who had abandoned the industry to rejoin and commence production. “Also, there is a serious question as to whether the local egg prices would be able to compete with the cost of imported eggs owing to the high production costs.” Gunasekara warned that this latest move would only discourage egg producers even further from either continuing or rejoining the industry. “Though the Minister of Trade thinks that it is his duty to import eggs even and reduce the cost, the truth is that the local cost of an egg could only be reduced by shrinking production costs and removing the hold which intermediate wholesale dealers have on it,” he said. Egg production in Sri Lanka was affected by the pandemic in 2020, the fertiliser issue, and the present forex crisis. At present, a price of an egg has been raised to between Rs 60-70 in the market, greatly inconveniencing consumers. Sri Lanka first imported eggs in 2010 and the imported stock had to be destroyed as it was unfit for consumption.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Four suspects granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera yesterday (3) ordered four suspects who were arrested and produced before him, on charges of assaulting the Executive Director of the Maga Neguma Head Office in Peliyagoda, to be enlarged on bail. He ordered the first and fourth suspects to be released on two sureties in Rs 300,000 each, while the second and third suspects were ordered to be granted bail in Rs 300,000 each. The four suspects released on bail were, K. Sudarshana Kumara, a resident of Beliatta, Sunil Shantha, also a resident of Beliatta, Ajith Pathmakumara, a resident of Panadura and Thushara Chamara, a resident of Pugoda. The four suspects were arrested by Peliyagoda Police, in connection with the incident and produced in Court. One of the suspects is reportedly the President of drivers’ association of the Maga Neguma project and another is a committee member of the same association. Meanwhile, the attack was described as an act of terror by the Government. Speaking at the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (3), Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said the CID has been told to investigate the incident. Gunawardana claimed that an organised group dressed as the institution’s staff refused to hoist the National Flag at an event organised on Monday (2). He further said, the Chairman and Executive Director of the Maga Neguma Road Construction Equipment Company were not permitted to engage in any customs to celebrate the New Year as well. “The attack occurred during an event held to commence work in the New Year. During the incident, milk rice and other objects were hurled at the officials,” he said. By Hansi Nanayakkara, Thameenah Razeek and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  The Chairman of the Elections Commission (EC) had conveyed that if the Government fails to release the requisite funds, it will be impossible to press ahead with the conduct of the 2023 Local Government Polls, Member of the Lawyers’ Union, attached to the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), Attorney Sunil Watagala claimed. He said the JJB had recently held a round of discussions with officials from the EC. When inquired about the financial situation regarding the staging of the said Polls, the EC officers had informed them that the Government was yet to release the necessary monies for it, he said and added, as the President has not even mentioned setting aside the funds for the conduct of the LG Polls during his budget speech last year, it was clear that the hidden aim of this regime is to defer its conduct as much as possible. According to Watagala, the EC Chairman had not expressed his optimism thus far of being able to go ahead with the staging of the forthcoming election for want of the necessary funds. By Anurada Herath Popular

title: Govt won’t even have money to buy paddy – Finance Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: If an emergency election is held this year, the Government will not even have money to buy paddy in the upcoming ‘Maha Season,’ a top Finance Ministry official warned. According to Finance Ministry reports, if paddy cannot be purchased, there is a risk of the rice market collapsing again. It was also said in this situation, only the private sector will be able to buy rice and farmers will be in a desperate situation, resulting in a rapid price drop. The official also said 800,000 hectares of paddy harvest is expected during the Maha Season, while the Government is expected to purchase three million metric tonnes of paddy from the harvest. It was also said, a sum ofRs 2 billion will have to be spent for the purchase and if an election is held, it will not be possible to use the above sum to purchase rice. Rice harvests, which had dwindled after the ban on chemical fertiliser, have increased rapidly this time, and the Government aims to make the country self-sufficient in rice in the presence of a surplus of rice. The official also claimed if a large sum has to be spent suddenly for an election, the agriculture industry will collapse and the country will return to its previous predicament. The Election Commission has requested Rs 12 billion for the election and the Finance Ministry is of the opinion that the amount may increase.

The official also said 800,000 hectares of paddy harvest is expected during the Maha Season, while the Government is expected to purchase three million metric tonnes of paddy from the harvest. It was also said, a sum ofRs 2 billion will have to be spent for the purchase and if an election is held, it will not be possible to use the above sum to purchase rice. Rice harvests, which had dwindled after the ban on chemical fertiliser, have increased rapidly this time, and the Government aims to make the country self-sufficient in rice in the presence of a surplus of rice. The official also claimed if a large sum has to be spent suddenly for an election, the agriculture industry will collapse and the country will return to its previous predicament. The Election Commission has requested Rs 12 billion for the election and the Finance Ministry is of the opinion that the amount may increase.

title: Cabinet nod to sign quarantine protocol
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approval has been granted to sign the Protocol on Inspection, Quarantine, and Veterinary Hygiene Requirements of Marine Fisheries Aquatic Products to be exported from Sri Lanka to China. This was signed between the Customs Administration of China and the Ministry of Fisheries of Sri Lanka to provide the necessary support and encouragement for the export of aquatic products to China. The General Administration of Customs of China has approved the export of 33 Sri Lankan food products to China. Among them, 29 are aquatic products and 38 Sri Lankan companies registered in China are working as exporters of these products. (TR)

title: Three arrested for attack on ICU head
author: Author not found
Content: Police at the Badulla Provincial General Hospital, yesterday (3) said, they arrested three persons for attacking the head of the hospital’s Intensive Care Unit (ICU), Dr. Palitha Rajapaksa and some staff members, following a complaint lodged with them in this connection. They said that the suspects were handed over to Badulla Police for legal action, adding that the doctor and the staff had been attacked over an issue where an under-aged child, who had attempted to commit suicide, died immediately after being admitted to hospital, due to the delay bringing the victim to hospital on time. The disgruntled people had created chaos in the hospital and eventually had attacked Doctor Rajapaksa. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: HOLDING ELECTION NOW WILL LEAD TO BIGGER DISASTER – WAJIRA
author: Author not found
Content: If an election is held at this critical juncture, the country would face a greater disaster, than ever before, as more than Rs 20 billion will be required for it. This will also affect the tourism industry UNP Chairman Wajira Abeywardena claimed. Addressing the media at Sirikotha yesterday (3), Abeywardena said, such a large sum of money can be made use to provide relief and concessions to the crisis affected people. He said, holding Local Government elections will not change the Government. President Ranil Wickremesinghe has promised the youth he would bring about a system change. In this backdrop, the Opposition demands an election for its own petty politics, he alleged. He said that the people of this country must act prudently with regard to LG polls expected to be held after March. After the election, salaries will have to be paid to 8,000 LG members. If this happens at a time when the arrival of tourists is gradually rising, the entire tourism sector will be badly affected, he claimed. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Identified State enterprises to come under one umbrella
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers granted approval for the establishment of a mother company, affiliated to the Treasury and to register the identified State Enterprises under the government’s planned restructuring process as subsidiaries of that company. The proposal was made by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stability and National Policies. The proposal aims to make necessary arrangements to establish a parent company affiliated to the Treasury with 100 per cent equity ownership by the Secretary of the Treasury. Addressing the weekly Cabinet briefing yesterday (3), Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Guanwardena said this step is also to make arrangements to register the State Enterprises, identified for restructuring, as subsidiaries of the said parent company in order to accelerate the State-owned enterprises restructuring programme. The resolution for the restructuring of State enterprises was presented to the Parliament by the President, in the interim budget of 2022, as well as in the budget presented for 2023. Accordingly, the State Enterprises Restructuring Unit has already been established under the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies to facilitate the restructuring process of State Enterprises. Some of the entities targeted for restructuring are State-owned companies of which the government is the majority shareholder. Some State-owned enterprises operate as corporations. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Devananda vows to improve fishers’ living standards
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda vowed to improve the living and economic conditions of saltwater and freshwater fishermen while making the fishery industry a top foreign income earner. Devananda said, there is no point in talking about stale matters. “It is better to focus on tomorrow’s challenges and rebuild the economy in the New Year,” he said. He said, every effort would be made to provide fishermen with sophisticated technology and improve sanitation facilities and security systems at fishery harbours. Minister Devananda added that he has instructed Ceylon Fishery Harbours Corporation (CFHC) officials to take necessary steps to improve facilities in Tangalle, Kudawella, Suduwella and Puranawella fishery harbours on the Southern Coast. “Most of the fishery harbours on the Southern Coast are very busy and close attention must be paid to sanitation facilities and security systems of those harbours. Many persons use these harbours in the morning hours daily and sanitation facilities must be provided to them while addressing lighting systems at harbour premises,” Devananda added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Suspect in kidney racket case remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (3) remanded, till 17 January, a suspect who has been identified at an identification parade in connection with a kidney racket. The suspect has been charged with deceiving people from poverty stricken families under the pretext of providing them with money and selling their kidneys to both local and foreigners in the process. The main suspect in the racket, who was arrested by the CCD, identified as 41-year-old Mohammad Bazeer Mohammad Rajabdeen, alias Bai, was thus remanded by the Court. Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya stated that she was dismissing the bail application filed on behalf of the suspect, as granting bail to him would hamper the ongoing probe into the case, as it has not yet concluded. The CCD prosecuting, told the Court that the suspect had been produced before an identification parade yesterday and that during the parade the suspect had been identified by four of the witnesses. They added that the on-going probe into the incident had revealed that there were a few more suspects involved in the racket. The prosecution pointed out, that out of those suspects, the addresses mentioned in  three suspects’ NICs had been different. They explained that when inquired further, it had come to light that the Grama Niladhari Officers had also been aware of the changes in the addresses mentioned in their NICs. The CCD informed the Additional Magistrate, that to further expedite the probe they had also recorded statements from the Grama Niladhari officers concerned. They noted that out of the suspects identified to date, one had gone overseas on 27 November last year. The prosecution opined that the suspect, who had left the country, was yet to return home and insisted that they will be shortly seeking an order from the Court regarding the suspect. Meanwhile, the Counsel appearing for the suspect, urged Additional Magistrate Jayasuriya, to issue an order for the release of his client on any suitable bail condition. Taking the submissions into perusal, the Court ordered the suspect, to be remanded till the aforesaid date, as the probe into the case was yet proceeding. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Cabinet gives go ahead
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet gave permission to appoint a committee, headed by a Senior Additional Secretary to the President, to prepare and submit a policy and required guidelines to divest lands in regard to divestiture of crown lands. This report will be included in the amendments that should be introduced by studying all rules and prevailing regulations. Currently, powers to the divestiture of lands, under the Mahaveli Development Scheme, are reserved with the Director General of the Sri Lanka Mahaweli Development Authority, while the powers to divest lands, under the Land Reform Commission, is reserved by that Commission. Since the objectives under the Accelerated Mahaweli Development Scheme, as well as the Land Reform Commission, have been accomplished by now, there should be an appropriate procedure to perform all the fundamental activities applicable to divestiture of all crown lands including the divestiture of crown lands under the purview of the above two institutions by the Divisional Secretaries.

title: Market ‘spot’ unchanged at Rs 364/372
author: Author not found
Content: Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) kept the official, but administered benchmark ‘spot’  unchanged at Rs 363.11 to the US dollar for the second consecutive market day to yesterday, while a year ago too the official ‘spot’ was kept unchanged for the second consecutive market day at Rs 200.43 to the dollar. Nonetheless, Year-on-Year (YoY) as at yesterday, the official, administered ‘spot’ has been devalued by 81.17 per cent (Rs 162.68). Meanwhile, the ‘benchmark,’ albeit administered market ‘spot,’ remained unchanged for the sixth consecutive market day at Rs 364/372 to the dollar yesterday, while the value of the administered, albeit benchmark market ‘spot’ a year ago closed unchanged for the seventy ninth consecutive market day at Rs 202/203 to the dollar in two-way quotes, thus weakened by 80.20-83.25 per cent (Rs 162-169),YoY, thereby causing cost-push inflationary pressure, as Sri Lanka is an import-dependent economy.  The band in which the guided market ‘spot’ may currently operate is fixed at +/- three per cent of the officially administered ‘spot’ value, where the latter is applicable for transactions involving the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL), CBSL and/or between the GoSL and/or CBSL. Sources further said trades in the administered market ‘spot’ (Rs 364/372) yesterday were mainly restricted to ‘bank-client’ outright trades, while the interbank foreign exchange (FX) market was however dominated by swaps, which were outside the domain of the FX market for this purpose. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and of its foreign reserves also deals in ‘spot.’ By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Student found dead in college hostel
author: Author not found
Content: A student from a technical college located in Diyagama, Homagama was found dead under mysterious circumstances inside the college hostel on 2 January. The deceased is a 25-year-old second-year student and a resident of Katupotha. According to Police, the student returned to the college after holidays on 1 January. Police said two friends of the student had found him inside the hostel room when they went to find out why he didn’t attend lectures throughout the day. The friends informed campus administration that the student was unresponsive, after which he was admitted to the Homagama Hospital. Sadly, the student was pronounced dead on admission on Monday (2). The cause of death is yet to be determined, and the post-mortem will be conducted at the Homagama Hospital. Kahathuduwa Police are conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Kalugala farmers allege AGSC tainted with corruption
author: Author not found
Content: A group of farmers from the Kalugala village alleged that the Adiyagala Govijana Service Centre (AGSC) is tainted with corruption. The farmers said there were many irregularities when distributing free fertiliser during the Maha Season. They further said the AGSC has failed to supply sufficient stocks of fertiliser to farmers for the requisite money that had been deposited by them. Thus, they urged authorities to intervene and resolve these issues. By Prasanga Ekanayake – Madatugama

title: CEB makes Rs 484M generation profit
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) ended last year by making a generation profit of Rs 484 million on Monday 2 January 2023 alone, aided by CEB’s 75 per cent tariff hike effected since 9 August 2022, CEB data from yesterday showed. CEB statistics also showed that Sri Lanka consumed a total of 34.22 gigawatt hours (GWh) of electricity on Monday. CEB’s average tariff rate of Rs 16.37 per kilowatt hour (kWh), which the above calculations are based on, are as per Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, which is the latest of such data available in the public domain. An 8.72 per cent transmission and distribution loss as per last year’s cost estimates as computed by the CEB is also taken into consideration in the above computation. Meanwhile, the breakdown of the 34.22 GWh of electricity generated on Monday comprised 12.95 GWh of CEB coal, 11.83 GWh of CEB hydroelectricity, 3.94 GWh of CEB fuel/thermal oil, 2.88 GWh from renewable energy (RE) other than CEB  hydroelectricity and 2.62 GWh from independent power producers’ (IPP’)/ private sector fuel oil, respectively. According to the CBSL, the cheapest electricity  generation cost to the CEB last year was CEB hydroelectricity at Rs 1.67 a unit of electricity (one kWh of electricity), followed by CEB coal (Rs 10.68), ‘other RE’ (Rs 16.22), IPP fuel oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB fuel oil (Rs 32.03), respectively.  The main driver of CEB hydroelectricity is the Mahaweli which generated 7.53 GWh of electricity on Monday and which contributed to 22 per cent of total electricity generation and 51.19 per cent of total CEB hydroelectricity on that day. Mahaweli is led by Victoria, Randenigala, Rantambe and Kotmale built during the J.R. Jayewardene era after obtaining both grant and concessional aid from the West. On Monday, cheap and clean renewable energy (RE) such as electricity generated by the Mahaweli provided 42.99 per cent (14.71 GWh) of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs via the CEB, while the balance 57.01 per cent (19.51 GWh) of electricity generated was from the dirty and imported fossil fuels consisting of coal and fuel oil, respectively. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Wildlife Officers find carcass of 6-foot crocodile
author: Author not found
Content: Wildlife Officers in Kantale found the carcass of a 6-foot crocodile at the children’s park in Peraru village last morning (3). The officers said the crocodile had sustained several injuries and suspect poachers were after its head. Residents said the crocodile had been known to roam around the children’s park and added that the animal may have entered the park from a nearby canal. Wildlife Officers have launched an investigation to arrest the poachers. By W.M. Wickremasinghe – Kantale

title: 12 Indian fishers granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Magistrate of Point Pedro P. Krishanthan, on 2 January, ordered 12 Indian fishermen who were remanded on charges of illegal entry to Jaffna waters and engaging in illegal fishing, to be enlarged on strict bail conditions. The 12 Indian fishermen had been arrested by Navy Officers on 22 December 2022 and after they were handed over to Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Ministry officials they were produced in Court and remanded till 1 January 2023. The suspects pleaded guilty to the charges and they were then imposed with a three-year prison term suspended for a period of 10 years by the Point Pedro Chief Magistrate. They were also warned by the Court not to enter Northern waters henceforth. By Sashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: Snowflakes spotted in N’ Eliya
author: Author not found
Content: Snowflakes had been spotted near several places within the limits of the Nuwara Eliya MC and in areas such as Ambepola and Pattipola last morning (3). According to sources, for several years during Christmas and the New Year Nuwara Eliya and nearby areas had been witnessing these snowflakes. They added that it had been spotted in locations such as Nuwara Eliya Race Course, Nuwara Eliya Golf Course, in and around several tea estates, as well as in and around villages such as Meepilimana and Pattipola. Sources said the temperature in areas around the Nuwara Eliya MC limits had fallen to -5 Celsius at dawn yesterday (3). By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: No Mobile Phone Use During Work Hours
author: Author not found
Content: Claiming that public sector employees, in some offices, have increased their social media usage during working hours, Public Administration Ministry Secretary Neel Bandara Hapuhinna asserted that tough action would be taken against public officials using mobile phones during office hours. Public sector employees started the work for the New Year yesterday (2), amidst cancellation of at least 15 office trains. They took oaths kicking off official work for the New Year, pledging that they will work to make the State sector efficient. Addressing the ceremony, held at the Ministry of Public Administration, to mark the beginning of the New Year yesterday (2), Hapuhinna said he had seen, in some places, public officers surfing social media like Facebook and WhatsApp just after they start work for the day, without caring about the people who come to obtain services from public offices. Therefore, a possibility of issuing a circular on using mobile phones, during office hours, would be considered, Hapuhinna said adding that employees in certain private sector offices have to place their mobile phones in a locker when starting work and they could only get the phones back when leaving the offices. “I would not hesitate to take such decisions, if there is a need for that,” he noted. Meanwhile, addressing the same occasion Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said the country needs efficient projects to uplift the conditions of villages. “The Government has already launched programme on that. To make it a success, your support is much needed,” the Prime Minister said.

title: CID allowed to have Schaffter’s DNA tested
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya allowed the CID to obtain DNA testing through the Government Analyst on the Late Dinesh Schaffter’s blood samples, nails, body parts and some spot evidence. The Additional Magistrate made this instruction following a request made by the CID yesterday (2). The CID told the Court that as the investigation into the death of Dinesh Schaffter is on-going, the reports of the Government Analyst are needed for further investigations. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Kelaniya Uni students’ union president arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The President of the Kelaniya University Students’ Union and another student member were arrested when they visited the Thalangama Police to record a statement yesterday (2).  The duo was arrested on charges of damaging public property during a protest in front of the Education Ministry on 10 June 2022. Police said, the two had come down to the Thalangama Police station to give statements. However, they were arrested on charge of damaging a gate and obstructing Police. The arrested students are Union president Kelum Mudannayake and member, Harshana Wijesiri. They are to be produced before the Kaduwela Magistrate’s Court today (3). BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Application challenging Gazette on Law exam dismissed
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal dismissed the Writ Application challenging the Gazette issued to conduct Sri Lanka Law College examinations in the English medium. This was when the Writ Application, filed by a student of Sri Lanka Law College, was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobhitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. The substantive relief sought by the Petitioner was for a Writ of Certiorari to quash the Extraordinary Gazette Notification No. 2208/13, by which a rule, among others, has been made by the Council of Legal Education to conduct all study courses of Sri Lanka Law College in the English medium and to hold examinations gradually from year 2022 in English medium as reflected in its Rule 28A. The Application was however dismissed on the basis that the Petitioner has waited even until this examination was partly concluded to file this Application and in order to justify his delay, the Petitioner has tendered a medical treatment book for treatment taken for a shoulder pain. The judges held that evidence cannot be accepted to justify the delay of the Petitioner to come to Court adding thereby that the petitioner is guilty of laches. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Amaraweera challenges Prof Piyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera challenged the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Vice President, Prof. Rohana Lakshman Piyadasa, to garner at least 1,000 votes at the upcoming local governments election. Amaraweera said if Prof. Piyadasa can do it, he will resign from his ministerial portfolio. “Prof. Piyadasa does not know politics and is making baseless remarks that denigrates his professorship,” Amaraweera said. “Local government elections are also approaching. I would like to encourage that professor to run for office and if possible, garner 1,000 votes. Currently, 1,200 of our members serve in local government bodies. However, if the elections are held, the SLFP will be unable to secure at least 200 votes from each area. Today, most of the SLFP members are with us,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Important to assess performances of politicians, officials – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Measuring the performance of students alone is insufficient and measuring the performance of officials and politicians is also an important factor in a country’s development, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said. After a record number of people in the public sector, including officials in responsible administrative positions, retired at the end of 2022, new officials took office yesterday to fill those vacancies. Addressing Education Ministry officials yesterday (2), Premajayantha said the change in the existing system, which is the wish of the majority of the people, should be accomplished through a revolutionary education transformation process, overcoming problems from the previous year as well as new challenges such as climate change. “Right now, the world has to face the challenge of being exposed to general climate change in a negative way and the extreme cold weather situation that many countries are currently facing has changed, and we have to face the opposite climate change in the future. That transformation, which should not be limited to personnel transfers, should be a practical one, beginning with the administrative structure itself, with changes at a level we can afford, it should be carried out continuously while other educational activities, such as examinations, are held,” he said. Further, he said it is important to focus on achieving the sustainable development goals of providing quality education to all, promoting student attendance, and instilling confidence in students and parents about the quality of the teacher who enters the classroom. “When the year 2024 begins, everyone should work differently from the existing system and with dedication inculcate the benefits to the future generations, so that we can look back and be happy in the year 2023,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: JJB will not nominate Party jumpers – Tilvin
author: Author not found
Content: JVP General Secretary Tilvin Silva says when finalising the JJB nominations list, for the upcoming Local Government elections, they will not accommodate any politician who has a history of ditching political Parties for personal gain. He said if the Election Commission presses ahead with holding the LG Polls, the JJB will field candidates who are willing to serve the nation voluntarily and whose track record is unquestionable. Silva also described the upcoming election as one which could indicate which party is capable of understanding the heartbeat of the citizens and would serve the public without fear or favour. The JVP General Secretary also warned that if the Government plots to unduly delay the election, his party will mount a decisive protest by taking to the streets with the public.  By Anurada Herath

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Cabinet puts off considering proposal to hike power tariff
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers postponed the  consideration of the Electricity Tariff hike proposal submitted to the Cabinet yesterday. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said it has been postponed for one week for consideration, and that it will be taken up at the next Cabinet meeting. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara presented the Cabinet paper. Addressing the media last week, he noted that power tariffs will be raised by 60 to 65 per cent in January 2023. The cost is determined by the average rainfall. However, this is the second time in the last six months that the electricity tariff will be increased. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: New driving licence with QR code
author: Author not found
Content: New driving licence, embossed with QR Code, will be issued to those who are renewing their licences from the beginning of this year, Commissioner of Department of Motor Traffic Kusalani de Silva said. She said the QR Code embossed licence has many advantages. One of them is the authorities can easily verify the details of the cardholder by scanning the QR Code with a mobile phone and there will be no risk of duplication. Many traffic offences can be prevented with this system while easily bringing the traffic offenders before the law without wasting time or resources, de Silva added. Meanwhile, the programme to issue driving licence to those who are hearing impaired will commence after March this year. The pilot project of issuing driving licences for those with hearing issues was inaugurated in the Gampaha District in November last year (2022). Under this pilot projects licences were issued to 75 persons who have hearing problem. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: CID allowed to have Schaffter’s DNA tested
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya allowed the CID to obtain DNA testing through the Government Analyst on the Late Dinesh Schaffter’s blood samples, nails, body parts and some spot evidence. The Additional Magistrate made this instruction following a request made by the CID yesterday (2). The CID told the Court that as the investigation into the death of Dinesh Schaffter is on-going, the reports of the Government Analyst are needed for further investigations. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Kelaniya Uni students’ union president arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The President of the Kelaniya University Students’ Union and another student member were arrested when they visited the Thalangama Police to record a statement yesterday (2).  The duo was arrested on charges of damaging public property during a protest in front of the Education Ministry on 10 June 2022. Police said, the two had come down to the Thalangama Police station to give statements. However, they were arrested on charge of damaging a gate and obstructing Police. The arrested students are Union president Kelum Mudannayake and member, Harshana Wijesiri. They are to be produced before the Kaduwela Magistrate’s Court today (3). BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Application challenging Gazette on Law exam dismissed
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal dismissed the Writ Application challenging the Gazette issued to conduct Sri Lanka Law College examinations in the English medium. This was when the Writ Application, filed by a student of Sri Lanka Law College, was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobhitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. The substantive relief sought by the Petitioner was for a Writ of Certiorari to quash the Extraordinary Gazette Notification No. 2208/13, by which a rule, among others, has been made by the Council of Legal Education to conduct all study courses of Sri Lanka Law College in the English medium and to hold examinations gradually from year 2022 in English medium as reflected in its Rule 28A. The Application was however dismissed on the basis that the Petitioner has waited even until this examination was partly concluded to file this Application and in order to justify his delay, the Petitioner has tendered a medical treatment book for treatment taken for a shoulder pain. The judges held that evidence cannot be accepted to justify the delay of the Petitioner to come to Court adding thereby that the petitioner is guilty of laches. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Amaraweera challenges Prof Piyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera challenged the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Vice President, Prof. Rohana Lakshman Piyadasa, to garner at least 1,000 votes at the upcoming local governments election. Amaraweera said if Prof. Piyadasa can do it, he will resign from his ministerial portfolio. “Prof. Piyadasa does not know politics and is making baseless remarks that denigrates his professorship,” Amaraweera said. “Local government elections are also approaching. I would like to encourage that professor to run for office and if possible, garner 1,000 votes. Currently, 1,200 of our members serve in local government bodies. However, if the elections are held, the SLFP will be unable to secure at least 200 votes from each area. Today, most of the SLFP members are with us,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Important to assess performances of politicians, officials – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Measuring the performance of students alone is insufficient and measuring the performance of officials and politicians is also an important factor in a country’s development, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said. After a record number of people in the public sector, including officials in responsible administrative positions, retired at the end of 2022, new officials took office yesterday to fill those vacancies. Addressing Education Ministry officials yesterday (2), Premajayantha said the change in the existing system, which is the wish of the majority of the people, should be accomplished through a revolutionary education transformation process, overcoming problems from the previous year as well as new challenges such as climate change. “Right now, the world has to face the challenge of being exposed to general climate change in a negative way and the extreme cold weather situation that many countries are currently facing has changed, and we have to face the opposite climate change in the future. That transformation, which should not be limited to personnel transfers, should be a practical one, beginning with the administrative structure itself, with changes at a level we can afford, it should be carried out continuously while other educational activities, such as examinations, are held,” he said. Further, he said it is important to focus on achieving the sustainable development goals of providing quality education to all, promoting student attendance, and instilling confidence in students and parents about the quality of the teacher who enters the classroom. “When the year 2024 begins, everyone should work differently from the existing system and with dedication inculcate the benefits to the future generations, so that we can look back and be happy in the year 2023,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Parliament staff take oath
author: Author not found
Content: Addressing the Parliament staff, for the year 2023, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse said yesterday (2), “During a time when we have to face more challenges than ever, as employees of one of the highest institutions of the country, you should begin this new year with an undertaking to responsibly fulfil the expectations of the people.” The Deputy Speaker made this remark at the public service event of Parliament for the year 2023.  Rajapakse pointed out that after overcoming the challenge of Covid-19, the nation had to face the economic crisis and accordingly, the public servants have a huge responsibility in order to overcome the existing difficulties. He also pointed out that Government employees have a great responsibility towards the people in a more challenging environment given the situation where a large number of public servants are retiring at once. The Deputy Speaker hoisted the National Flag, at the main steps in front of the Parliament Building. A two-minute silence was observed afterwards to commemorate all those who sacrificed their lives for the country, including war heroes. Thereafter, the Parliament Staff proceeded to take the Oath of public service for the year. Addressing the staff, Kushani Rohanadeera, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary General of Parliament, stated that to save the country from the existing difficulties, “we must work with maximum efficiency even in a challenging environment.” She emphasised that many new committees are to be established in Parliament and accordingly, “in a background where recruitments and financial allocations are limited, we should work as one family with more commitment.” She also expressed her gratitude for the contribution of the Parliament staff towards the smooth running of Parliamentary Affairs during the Covid-19 challenge. Tikiri K. Jayathilake, Assistant Secretary General of Parliament, department heads, Parliament staff and affiliated staff were present at the event.

title: BoC commences operations for New Year – 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Bank of Ceylon wished all its customers, stakeholders and Sri Lankans a Very Happy New Year as it commenced work for the ‘New Year-2023’. The main event took place in a simple manner, at its Head office in Colombo, with a multi-religious ceremony to invoke blessings on the Staff of the Bank, all its customers including expatriates and all Sri Lankans in general. The ceremony was held with the patronage of the bank’s Chairman Kanchana Ratwatte and General Manager K.E.D. Sumanasiri. Customers, well wishers, members of the Corporate and Executive Management and other bank officials also participated. The staff of Bank of Ceylon also renewed the annual oath, taken by public servants, before commencing new year operations. Parallel to the main event all BOC branches commenced duty after multi-religious activities with the participation of respective customers.

title: Badulla Hospital Docs, staff protest assault
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors and staff attached to the Badulla Provincial Hospital engaged in a protest yesterday to express their strong disapproval over the 1 January attack on some of the hospital staff, by an unidentified group. According to sources from the hospital, a 17-year-old girl, who had hung herself, had been brought to the hospital for treatment at around 5.30 p.m. The Assistant Secretary of the GMOA Dr. Palitha Rajapaksa stated that when his officers had tried to explain the matters to the relatives of the girl, an unidentified group, that had forcibly entered the hospital premises, had proceeded to assault some of the staff. He urged the authorities to conduct an impartial probe into the assault, prosecute those responsible for the dastardly act and ensure protection for the hospital staff. BY Nishantha Abeygunawardene – Badulla
