title: Palmyrah Toddy exported to France, UK
author: Author not found
Content: The first Palmyrah Toddy shipment was sent to France, on 29 November 2022, by a Palmyrah Development Board registered exporter, under the observation of Palmyrah Development Board and Palmyrah Research Institute. The order value was USD 45,000. Another Palmyrah Toddy shipment was sent to the UK on 14 December 2022 by another Palmyrah Development Board registered exporter, under the observation of Palmyrah Research Institute.

title: Immediately disburse SLTB annual bonus – ACTWU
author: Author not found
Content: The All Ceylon Transport Workers’ Union (ACTWU) has requested the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) to take immediate steps to disburse the annual bonus to SLTB employees before 31 December, claiming that SLTB employees are disillusioned. In a statement, ACTWU said, SLTB employees had high hopes of getting the annual bonus. “You have stated to the media that annual bonus will not be given to loss-making institutions. SLTB is not a profit and loss-making entity. The only purpose of SLTB is to provide great service to the people,” the union said. “A sum of Rs 13,500 was given to SLTB employees in 2020. The SLTB has been put in a loss-making situation not by its employees, but by politicians of successive governments,” they said. “Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa caused a loss of Rs 420,000 by using SLTB busses for political activities. Through operations of the City Bus service, SLTB recorded another loss of Rs 85,000,” the ACTWU said.

title: Minister urges special fertiliser for tea, potato
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera, instructed the Ceylon Fertiliser Company Limited and Colombo Commercial Fertiliser Limited to produce two types of special fertilisers within a week, one for potato cultivation and the other for tea cultivation. The production of a special fertiliser for potato and vegetable cultivation was assigned to the Ceylon Fertiliser Company and the production of special fertiliser for tea cultivation was assigned to the Colombo Commercial Fertiliser Company. Amaraweera instructed the Ministry Secretary, Gunadasa Samarasinghe, to give the necessary approvals for the production of these two fertilisers. The Heads of the companies stated that they already have the urea, MOP and other ingredients required for the production of the special fertilisers.

title: IMF’s tax-free threshold more cognisant of poor
author: Author not found
Content: IMF’s tax-free threshold in its personal income tax (PIT) proposals for Sri Lanka appears to be more cognisant of the poor than President and Finance Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe’s PIT rates, as spelt out in his recent Budget 2023 proposals, which was passed by Parliament earlier this month. As per Wickremesinghe’s ‘Budget 2023,’ the PIT tax-free annual income threshold is a mere Rs 499,999.99, whereas the IMF, in an upload made on its Sri Lanka website on Friday recommends that the PIT tax-free threshold should be “upped” by Rs 100,000 (Rs 100,001) to Rs 600,000. As per Wickremesinghe’s Budget 2023, the new PIT rates effective from April will be a six per cent tax rate on the first Rs 500,000 accruals (monthly income of Rs 41,667 in the 12 months beginning in April 2022 and ending on 31 March 2023), where the annual tax-free threshold will be Rs 499,999.99. A further 12 per cent tax rate on the next Rs 500,000 annual income, 18 per cent on the next Rs 500,000, 24 per cent on the next Rs 500,000 income slab, 30 per cent on the following slab and a flat rate of 36 per cent in the balance, respectively. On the other hand, the IMF recommendation, uploaded on its Sri Lanka website on Friday suggests that PIT increases should be in the form of an annual tax-free allowance up to Rs 600,000. Between Rs 600,001 and Rs 1.2 million (next Rs 600,000) a 10 per cent PIT, next Rs 600,000, 20 per cent and for the balance a flat rate of 30 per cent, respectively, it said. “Based on Sri Lanka’s household income distribution, we estimate that this hypothetical marginal PIT rate schedule would be strongly progressive, imposing an estimated 82 per cent of the tax burden on households in the top 10 per cent of the income distribution, and none on those in the bottom 60 per cent,” IMF said. “Based on Sri Lanka’s relative revenue performance, we estimate that adopting a marginal PIT rate schedule broadly in line with those of its comparators would raise PIT revenue by an additional 0.2 per cent points of GDP, up from its 2020 level of 0.3 per cent of GDP,” it added. The above IMF recommendations are found on a study titled ‘Sri Lanka: Selected Issues’ dated 11 November, but released on its website only on Friday (23). By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Illegal construction cause of floods – Kandy Mayor
author: Author not found
Content: Illegal constructions were the main cause of the recent floods in Kandy City, said Kandy Mayor Kesara Senanayake. He said steps will be immediately taken to remove all buildings that are blocking the waterways and that if this is not done, the city will be destroyed soon. He was speaking during a discussion on the Kandy disaster situation, at the Kandy District Secretariat yesterday (26). He also noted that removals will be conducted regardless of the impact when it comes to removing unauthorised constructions. Senanayake noted that no matter how much rain falls in Kandy, such destruction has never occurred, and that some politicians should be held directly responsible for this destruction. He emphasised that there are many unauthorised constructions in Kandy, and as a result, many avenues to drain the water are blocked. The mayor also pointed out that, as a result of the floods caused by unauthorised constructions, the city council is being held accountable by those who carried out the unauthorised constructions. According to the Disaster Management Centre, 1,630 people, belonging to 322 families, in the Kandy district have been affected by the heavy rains. A total of 98 houses have been damaged. Two siblings died when their house was completely destroyed by a landslide. Five persons were injured in the incident. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Sri Lanka is finally back on the holiday map – Daily Mail
author: Author not found
Content: Mary Wales of the Daily Mail has urged British tourists to visit Sri Lanka as the nation is providing great holiday packages at low costs.  According to Mary Wales, seldom has so little money been spent by so few to gain so much luxury as Sri Lanka now offers. Full article: “With the British Government now giving a green light for travel to the country, tourists are being offered unprecedented bargains following the almost total tourism shutdown earlier in the year due to fears about riots and food shortages. Those fears appear to have been over-stated and short-lived. I have just spent two weeks in Sri Lanka, a country I have always loved and was amazed by what I found. As one tourist chief put it: “This is the only country in the world which deals with revolutionary anger through flowers, friendliness and good nature.” Indeed, the friendliness is perhaps even more evident than before the corrupt government began to destroy the economy. What’s more, Sri Lankans are delighted Britain has its first British Asian Prime Minister. “We hope Rishi comes here and that he sends us more tourists,” said the manager of Lakshmi Jewels, a boutique in Galle, the delightful former Portuguese Fort town 40 miles west of Tangalle. It’s certainly easier to come here compared with India, where UK citizens now need three weeks and must turn up in person at a consulate to get a tourist visa. To enter Sri Lanka, you get your digital visa in 36 hours. Go now and you’ll find many hotels are near empty, most running at 10 per cent occupancy, but bookings are slowly rising. The most luxurious hotel in the south of Sri Lanka, the Peace Haven Anantara, near Tangalle, heroically kept on its 340 staff including sushi and Italian chefs. Peacocks still parade on its lawns and giant monitor lizards soak up the sun. You can bag a room here for around £239 a night in January and February. Tangalle’s glorious beaches are deserted. Small bars offer grilled lobster for £15. It is an incredible bargain time for Western travellers. The cost of a shirt being tailored at Numesh Tailors is £3; a pair of linen trousers at Sanu Fashion costs £9. Fresh papayas and pineapples are offered as complimentary desserts. But there’s no question that many hotels and shops are struggling. Some guest houses have closed. In Galle, there is a trail of motley backpackers with only a few higher-spenders hitting the shops or the somewhat eccentric maritime museum. The hunger for tourists is intense even in this laidback seaside town. Delicious curry and a Lion beer is just £10 at The Spice Chest restaurant. The Amangalle, the chic boutique-chain hotel with its white-uniformed staff, has dropped rates by as much as 30 per cent off its peak time prices. Jenny Hope, a retired teacher from Sheffield is a rare British middle-class traveller, enjoying her £40-a-night room at the Parawa guest hotel. ‘I can get a thali meal for £8 and a ten minute tuk-tuk taxi for £1. It is safer and sunnier than any town I can name in Yorkshire,’ she says. Sri Lanka always offers unlimited sunshine and friendliness. And there’s wildlife, too. After two days of spa and sand at the Peace Haven hotel, we headed to Yala national game park on the south-east coast hugging the Indian Ocean, near Hambantota. To seek the rare indigenous leopards is like visiting Kipling’s Jungle Book with its dense green terrain, waterholes where elephants, wild boars and peacocks cool down, and trees where monkeys chatter and swing. And, at the moment leopards outnumber tourists. Before flying back from the capital, Colombo, we stayed a night at The Wallawwa Hotel, just 15 minutes from the airport. This peaceful country house is the perfect antidote to airport hell. Rooms are going for £180 per night, which is a little bit more than pre-pandemic because taxes have risen due the economic crisis, but it’s still lower than in comparable hotels in places such as Mauritius. Sri Lanka needs tourism like never before. Its people are suffering. The good news is that the Foreign Office no longer advises against visiting this beautiful country and Sri Lanka has dropped all its Covid-19 restrictions for arrivals from overseas. My advice is to get there sooner rather than later.”

title: Police seek AG’s advice on prosecuting blackmailer
author: Author not found
Content: Police have sought instructions from the Attorney General, on filing charges over last year’s suicide of 16-year-old, as it has been revealed that the youth was pushed to suicide by a person who was blackmailing him. Police revealed that the student died by suicide in his home, after a person threatened to kill his relatives and demanded money and pre-paid phone cards from him. SSP Samantha Vedage said victim named Ashen Isuru Wickramaarachchi, who was a resident of Gungumuwa, died by suicide on 11 October 2021. After the parents complained that the victim had no reason to take his life, a lengthy investigation was launched by the Police, using modern technology. During the investigation, a person who impersonated a young girl had communicated with the victim via mobile phone, and obtained his personal pictures. The suspect then demanded money and pre-paid phone cards from the victim. It has been discovered from the statements obtained from the father of the deceased, the student had given the money to the suspect after stealing his father’s money, which was earned by selling betel nuts. Police also found many scratched prepaid cards hidden in the student’s room. If you or someone you know needs mental health assistance dial 1926: the hotline of the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) By Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: SJB-led alliance will sweep LG polls – Kiriella
author: Author not found
Content: A Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB)-led alliance will record a landslide victory at the upcoming Local Government polls, said SJB MP Lakshman Kiriella. Addressing the media recently, Kiriella noted that the SJB has no intention of accepting any politician, alliance or political party that has helped the Rajapaksa family to destroy this country, to contest the upcoming election, even if they try.  “The Samagi Bala Sandhanaya (SBS), comprising the Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC) Jathika Hela Urumaya (JHU), the Tamil Progressive Alliance (TPA) and members of the SLPP, who sit as an independent group in Parliament, is the most powerful political alliance at the moment. No political party or political alliance in the country can doubt the SBS in respect of the confidence among voters, ability, power and popularity,” Kiriella stressed. He invited the political opponents of the alliance, who inquire from the SJB about their programme to save the country from the current crisis, to go through the 20-point strategic plan announced by Premadasa in Parliament in early October. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Four arrested over attack on social media activist
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Crimes Division (CCD), yesterday (26) arrested four persons over the stabbing of social media activist Dilan Senanayake on 14 December. The CCD said that four persons were arrested in connection with the incident of assaulting and injuring Dilan Senanayake with a sharp weapon. It was revealed that he was inside his photography studio on Pagoda Road, Nugegoda, when he was attacked and the attackers had fled after the attack. Police investigations revealed that the attackers came and left in a three-wheeler. Police said that the persons involved in the attack were arrested while hiding in a house in Dematagoda and Maligawatta area. They claimed that the investigation revealed that a personal dispute had led to the attack. The four suspects are to be produced in Court. By Bimal Jayasinghe (Colombo)

title: Floods destroy CP Edu Dept equipment
author: Author not found
Content: Computer equipment and property worth tens of thousands of rupees, as well as audit reports, personal files of education administrative officers and a stock of exam model question papers, were destroyed as a result of the inundation of the Central Province Department of Education. According to Provincial Director of Education, Amarasiri Piyadasa, a batch of model question papers, prepared by the Central Province Department of Education in Kandy, for students taking the GCE Advanced Level Examination, which were to be sent to schools, had been destroyed. Approximately 50 computers in the office were damaged. A number of audit reports have also been reportedly destroyed by flood waters. The water also destroyed a stock of school equipment, including exercise books worth thousands of rupees that had been received as UNICEF aid to be distributed to schools. Two vehicles from the Advanced Technological Institute of Kandy, as well as numerous items, including students’ certificates, were under water. State Minister Dilum Amunugama visited the flood-damaged Railway Department, Education Department, and Advanced Technological Institute in Kandy yesterday (26) and stated that he would seek the assistance of the Archives Department to restore the essential files damaged by the water. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: INDIAN CREDIT LINE TO BUY INDELIBLE INK
author: Author not found
Content: Indelible ink will be imported using the Indian credit line, for the Local Government election, which is expected to be held in March 2023, Election Commissioner General Saman Sri Rathnayake said. He said the ink stocks currently available at the Election Commission (EC) will not be sufficient for the upcoming election. Also, samples of the ink stock have been sent to the Government Analyst to determine whether it is safe to use next year, he added. Speaking further, Rathnayake said to use the ink in an efficient manner, a single line would be drawn on the fingernail of the voter without applying the ink on the whole fingernail. He said as every voter has an NIC, the possibility of election fraud taking place is minimal. However, according to the Local Government Election Act, it is mandatory to apply ink on the fingernail. Therefore, indelible ink is necessary to hold the election, he noted. BY J.T. de Silva

title: Fuel consumption drops by half
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) said the fuel demand in the year 2022 has seen a reduction by 50 per cent. The demand for petrol and diesel was around 4,000 metric tons per month in the first half of last year, but it has now dropped to 2,000 metric tons. During the months of March to July, daily diesel consumption decreased from 6,496 to 2,299 metric tons. The consumption of petrol has decreased from 3,764 to 1,226 metric tons. The economic crisis, a significant decrease in fuel consumption, the issuance of fuel only through the QR system, and consumers’ failure to maintain fuel reserves, have all contributed to a drop in fuel demand.

title: Russia’s Red Wings to begin charter flights to SL
author: Author not found
Content: Red Wings Airlines, a Russian regional leisure airline, based in Moscow, will start charter flight operations to Sri Lanka’s Mattala Airport, twice a week from 28 December, the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Moscow said yesterday (26). In a statement, the Embassy said this is the third Russian Airline operating direct flights to Sri Lanka. According to the commercial director of the Airline I.V. Tretiakov, the first few flights are fully booked and that it is supported as well by the Russian top tour operators working in partnership with the Red Wings Airline. Red Wings Airline planes are expected to switch to the regular flights as soon as the accreditation is granted by the Sri Lanka Civil Aviation Authority and gradually increase the number of flights. “Given that the Russian Federation could be regarded as an important tourist traffic source to Sri Lanka at this trying time, this Embassy is of the view that this flight resumption will be of vital importance to Sri Lankan tourism industry. We cordially solicit Russian tourists to choose to visit Sri Lanka while enjoying the convenience of direct flight experience,” the Embassy further said.

title: Gota leaves for USA
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his wife Ioma left for the United States of America via Dubai yesterday (26). They were accompanied by their son Daminda Manoj, daughter-in-law and granddaughter. The group boarded Emirates flight EK-649 at 2.55 a.m. at Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) via the VIP lounge. There are no direct flights from Katunayake Airport to the United States of America. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Entire society to blame for drug menace – Akila
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Assistant Leader and former Education Minister Akila Viraj Kariyawasam claimed that the entire society, including politicians, is responsible for the drug mafia, operating in the proximities of schools in various places of the country, targeting schoolchildren. He said that it was clear that various businesses and organisations are operating in the distribution and the sale of Crystal Methamphetamine (Ice) targeting schoolchildren. Politicians, MPs and the public must pay attention to curb this situation and to protect the children who are to take over this country one day, he said. “We see how certain political figures are upset and suspect that this drug mafia is taking place at political level. Because of this, we have seen how the country’s treasured children are being led to great destruction,” Kariyawasam said. It is a compulsory duty to come forward to protect the children of this country from this great danger without shedding crocodile tears, before the media. “When the police were asked about moonshine distillation and sale, they told us certain political elements interfere with that. If they opposed it they would be transferred because certain politicians are making money from it,” Kariyawasam said. There won’t be any benefit by speaking in Parliament and making comments via media in this connection. Police have a great responsibility to curb the drug mafia operating in the country, he added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: NATA, NDDCB condemn legalising cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka cannot be developed by legalising cannabis, National Authority on Tobacco and Alcohol (NATA) Chairman Dr. Samadhi Rajapaksa said. NATA and National Dangerous Drugs Control Board (NDDCB) condemned the proposal to legalise cannabis, for export purposes, claiming that no country in the world has developed by exporting cannabis and pointed out that Sri Lanka could not either export or import any part of cannabis or refined product of cannabis according to the three agreements. Addressing the media, Dr. Rajapaksa said that the claim that it was only for export purposes is just to hoodwink the people. “This tag ‘only for export purposes’ will go away soon. There will be people smoking cannabis in every junction. I challenge anyone to prove with example if there is any country in the world which has earned dollars and developed by exporting cannabis as refined oil or as a medicine,” he said. Meanwhile, NDDCB Chairman Sakya Nanayakkara said Sri Lanka has not passed any laws on exporting cannabis. He said Sri Lanka has entered into three international agreements with regard to drugs and that Sri Lanka could not either export or import any part of cannabis or refined product of cannabis according to the three agreements. (NV)

title: Illegal construction cause of floods – Kandy Mayor
author: Author not found
Content: Illegal constructions were the main cause of the recent floods in Kandy City, said Kandy Mayor Kesara Senanayake. He said steps will be immediately taken to remove all buildings that are blocking the waterways and that if this is not done, the city will be destroyed soon. He was speaking during a discussion on the Kandy disaster situation, at the Kandy District Secretariat yesterday (26). He also noted that removals will be conducted regardless of the impact when it comes to removing unauthorised constructions. Senanayake noted that no matter how much rain falls in Kandy, such destruction has never occurred, and that some politicians should be held directly responsible for this destruction. He emphasised that there are many unauthorised constructions in Kandy, and as a result, many avenues to drain the water are blocked. The mayor also pointed out that, as a result of the floods caused by unauthorised constructions, the city council is being held accountable by those who carried out the unauthorised constructions. According to the Disaster Management Centre, 1,630 people, belonging to 322 families, in the Kandy district have been affected by the heavy rains. A total of 98 houses have been damaged. Two siblings died when their house was completely destroyed by a landslide. Five persons were injured in the incident. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Sri Lanka is finally back on the holiday map – Daily Mail
author: Author not found
Content: Mary Wales of the Daily Mail has urged British tourists to visit Sri Lanka as the nation is providing great holiday packages at low costs.  According to Mary Wales, seldom has so little money been spent by so few to gain so much luxury as Sri Lanka now offers. Full article: “With the British Government now giving a green light for travel to the country, tourists are being offered unprecedented bargains following the almost total tourism shutdown earlier in the year due to fears about riots and food shortages. Those fears appear to have been over-stated and short-lived. I have just spent two weeks in Sri Lanka, a country I have always loved and was amazed by what I found. As one tourist chief put it: “This is the only country in the world which deals with revolutionary anger through flowers, friendliness and good nature.” Indeed, the friendliness is perhaps even more evident than before the corrupt government began to destroy the economy. What’s more, Sri Lankans are delighted Britain has its first British Asian Prime Minister. “We hope Rishi comes here and that he sends us more tourists,” said the manager of Lakshmi Jewels, a boutique in Galle, the delightful former Portuguese Fort town 40 miles west of Tangalle. It’s certainly easier to come here compared with India, where UK citizens now need three weeks and must turn up in person at a consulate to get a tourist visa. To enter Sri Lanka, you get your digital visa in 36 hours. Go now and you’ll find many hotels are near empty, most running at 10 per cent occupancy, but bookings are slowly rising. The most luxurious hotel in the south of Sri Lanka, the Peace Haven Anantara, near Tangalle, heroically kept on its 340 staff including sushi and Italian chefs. Peacocks still parade on its lawns and giant monitor lizards soak up the sun. You can bag a room here for around £239 a night in January and February. Tangalle’s glorious beaches are deserted. Small bars offer grilled lobster for £15. It is an incredible bargain time for Western travellers. The cost of a shirt being tailored at Numesh Tailors is £3; a pair of linen trousers at Sanu Fashion costs £9. Fresh papayas and pineapples are offered as complimentary desserts. But there’s no question that many hotels and shops are struggling. Some guest houses have closed. In Galle, there is a trail of motley backpackers with only a few higher-spenders hitting the shops or the somewhat eccentric maritime museum. The hunger for tourists is intense even in this laidback seaside town. Delicious curry and a Lion beer is just £10 at The Spice Chest restaurant. The Amangalle, the chic boutique-chain hotel with its white-uniformed staff, has dropped rates by as much as 30 per cent off its peak time prices. Jenny Hope, a retired teacher from Sheffield is a rare British middle-class traveller, enjoying her £40-a-night room at the Parawa guest hotel. ‘I can get a thali meal for £8 and a ten minute tuk-tuk taxi for £1. It is safer and sunnier than any town I can name in Yorkshire,’ she says. Sri Lanka always offers unlimited sunshine and friendliness. And there’s wildlife, too. After two days of spa and sand at the Peace Haven hotel, we headed to Yala national game park on the south-east coast hugging the Indian Ocean, near Hambantota. To seek the rare indigenous leopards is like visiting Kipling’s Jungle Book with its dense green terrain, waterholes where elephants, wild boars and peacocks cool down, and trees where monkeys chatter and swing. And, at the moment leopards outnumber tourists. Before flying back from the capital, Colombo, we stayed a night at The Wallawwa Hotel, just 15 minutes from the airport. This peaceful country house is the perfect antidote to airport hell. Rooms are going for £180 per night, which is a little bit more than pre-pandemic because taxes have risen due the economic crisis, but it’s still lower than in comparable hotels in places such as Mauritius. Sri Lanka needs tourism like never before. Its people are suffering. The good news is that the Foreign Office no longer advises against visiting this beautiful country and Sri Lanka has dropped all its Covid-19 restrictions for arrivals from overseas. My advice is to get there sooner rather than later.”

title: Amaraweera says 3,559 litres of fuel provided for Maha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said 3,559 bowsers provided fuel from September to 11 December for Maha season cultivation. In a statement issued yesterday (26), Ministry of Agriculture said in order to make rice cultivation successful in the 2022/23 season, the fuel distribution activities had been very successful as per the instructions given by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to provide diesel and kerosene to the farmers without any shortage or inconvenience. “The proposal presented by Minister Amaraweera, to provide fuel in the Maha season without any shortage was approved by the Cabinet of Ministers led by the President. Accordingly, for the distribution of fuel, the Petroleum Corporation and the Ministry of Agriculture appointed one officer each to coordinate these activities. Due to this, there were no reports that there had been any shortage of fuel or any difficulty for the farmers to get fuel from filling stations for their Maha season cultivation activities, which started last September,” the Ministry said. Among the facts revealed in the discussion about the progress of fuel distribution for the cultivation activities in the Maha season, the required 6,600 litres of fuel had been provided to the farmers through 3,559 bowers from last September to the second week of December. Accordingly, fuel has been supplied by 866 bowsers in September, 1587 bowsers in October, 1004 bowsers in November and 102 bowsers by 11 December. Apart from this, 151 bowsers of 6,600 litres of kerosene had also been provided to the farmers for cultivation purposes. Accordingly, 16 bowsers in October, 111 bowsers in November, and 24 bowsers in December had been given to the farmers. Amaraweera said that although there is an economic crisis in the country, the Government has taken steps to provide the necessary facilities to the farmers despite the difficulties in order to make this season a success. He also emphasised that although a large number of people criticised the Government, when there were some problems in providing fuel for cultivation in the last Yala season, it is a pity that nobody, not even farmer organisations, appreciate the measures taken regarding the provision of fuel and fertilisers without any delay or shortage.

title: Two-thirds employed in informal sector – IMF
author: Author not found
Content: Informal employment contributed to two-thirds of total employment in Sri Lanka, the IMF, in a publication titled ‘Sri Lanka: Selected Issues’ said. In 2019, about 5.5 million (67 per cent), from a total 8.2 million employed in Sri Lanka, were considered informal, it added. These workers are neither subject to national labour legislations and income tax nor entitled to social protection and employment benefits. They are not registered with the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) and Employment Provident Fund (EPF), do not have formal financial accounts, do not have EPF accounts, or such establishments do not have 10 or more employees. An important feature of informal employment in Sri Lanka is that a significant share of workers (0.8 million, nine per cent of total employment or 22 per cent of formal sector employment) have informal contractual relationships while working in formal enterprises, the IMF said. “They work in the formal sector but without contribution to social security programmes,” it added. Informal workers also receive less protection from labour regulations due to gaps in labour legislation and weak law enforcement in the informal sector. Although Sri Lankan labour laws seek to protect all workers, some components of the law exclude informal workers. For example, provisions of the Termination of Employment of Workmen Act (TEWA) and the Payment of Gratuity Act generally apply to enterprises with 15 or more workers. Thus, workers engaged in smaller, informal establishments lack protection and compensation against sudden dismissals by an employer, like in the case of Covid-19, the IMF publication said.  Informal workers also have limited protection since the unemployment and retirement benefits in Sri Lanka rely on payment by the employer at the end of the contract, it said. Workers in informal establishments are also vulnerable due to limited enforcement of labour laws due to their lack of visibility, the IMF said. IMF recommendations to uplift the lot of the informally employed, included immediate mobilising revenue to provide adequate fiscal space to support the poor and vulnerable groups whilst remaining the top priority, this could be complemented by broadening the coverage of social service net (SSN) programmes to include the informal sector and improve targeting, allowing for support to be intensified during a crisis such as Covid-19. Meanwhile, over the medium-term, policies should focus on facilitating a gradual transition from the informal to formal sector to increase productivity, employment protection, and Government revenues. These include investing in human capital, improving business and investment climate, simplifying registrations and regulations for new businesses, simplifying tax payments, reforming labour market and laws, and improving access to finance, the IMF recommended. By Paneetha Ameresekere

Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. title: Shereff’s 201st hoisting of Mosque flag marked
author: Author not found
Content: A Grand ceremony marking Nagoor Aandakai  Tharha Shereff’s 201st Hoisting of  the flag,  of the  Grand Kalmunai Beach Mosque (Kadatkaraippalli), was held at Kadatkariappalli Grounds in the presence of thousands of Muslim devotees after Asar Prayers at 4.30 p.m. on Saturday (24).  The ceremony, held under the patronage of the Chief Trustee of the Kalmunai Town Jummah Mosque Dr.S.M. Abdul Azees, was attended by  Kalmunai  Mayor A.M. Rakkeeb, Deputy Mayor  Rahmath Munsoor, Muslim religious dignitaries, Moulavies and Ulamas. The holy flags were brought from the Kalmunai Town Mohideen Jummah Mosque to the Beach Mosque in  grand procession flanked  by Ulamas, Member of the Pakkeer Jamaath,  headed by the President Prof. Pakker Jahufar.  the flags were hoisted at the Nagoor Aandakai Tharha Minar.  The programme will go on daily with religious preaching’s by reputed Ulamas,  Pakkeerbawas ‘raathibs’ continuously for  12 days and the ceremony will   conclude on 4 January  2023 with lowering of the flag and Grand Kanthootri (Feast). BY M. A. P. Deen- Ampara

title: Sajith sets example – Imran
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Trincomalee District MP M. Imran yesterday (26) said that Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa set an example to others by donating Rs 3.9 million worth of medical equipment to the Trincomalee District General Hospital under the SJB’s’Breathe’ health promotion programme. Imran said it was the 54th phase of SJB’s health promotion programme. Those who came to power, claiming that they would develop Sri Lanka to the level of Singapore, are unable to come out of their homes as they have deceived the people by giving false promises. The speeches made by them during their election campaigns and propaganda were humorous, Imran said. “At a time when the people of this country have been severely impacted by the prevailing economic crisis, the Opposition is extending a helping hand to the crisis impacted people at a greater level than the Government, taking the real situation into consideration.” “On the concept of Opposition Leader Premadasa, the SJB has launched a programme titled ‘Sakwala’ (Universe) to fulfill the educational needs and other fundamental needs of children taking into consideration that it is the bounden duty of their representative in Parliament and the Government as well.  So far buses worth Rs 106.2 million have been donated by the SJB to 48 schools across the country. Rs 17.8 million worth of telecommunication equipment has been donated by the SJB to 22 schools across the country while donating Rs 229.2 million worth of essential medical equipment to hospitals in the country including the Northern and Eastern Provinces,” Imran added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Inclement weather wreaks havoc
author: Author not found
Content: The prevailing inclement weather conditions have wreaked havoc, in several districts across the country, claiming the lives of two persons, causing injury to seven and affecting a total number of 387 families comprising 1,675 persons, Disaster Management Centre (DMC) sources said yesterday (26). The deaths had occurred in the Akurana Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division in the Kandy District due to cutting failure, according to the DMC sources.  They added that the among the affected Districts were Matale, Kandy, Ampara and Badulla and the highest number 231 families, comprising 1,016 persons had been affected in the Gangawata Korale DS Division, in the Kandy District, due to heavy rains and cutting failure. A total number of 33 families, comprising 130 persons had been affected in Akurana DS Division alone. “A total of 109 houses had been partially damaged and  one was completely damaged in the Akurana DS Division. The highest number of 35 and 27 partially damaged houses had been reported from the Akurana and Poojapitiya DS Divisions in the Kandy District,” the DMC sources said.  Meanwhile Senior Scientist, Early Landslide Early Warning Centre (LEWC), of National Building Research Organisation (NBRO), Dr. K. P. G. Wasantha Senadeera said along with the prevailing inclement weather conditions the NBRO has declared five districts in the Central Hill Country to be vulnerable areas for landslide. “On the basis of rainfall received to particular areas, level one yellow and level two amber landslide early warning alerts have been issued to those districts. Kandy, Kegalle, Kurunegala, Matale and Nuwara-Eliya Districts are among them,” Dr. Senadeera said. He said that level one yellow (watch) landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Ganga Ihala Korale, Udadumbara, Udunuwara, Pathadumbara and Pathahewaheta DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kandy District, Galigamuwa and Rambukkana DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Matale and Yatawara DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matale District and Kotmale DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Nuwara Eliya District. Level two, amber (watch) landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Mawanella DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Rideegama DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Kurunegala District and Pallepola, Ukuwela, Laggala, Pallegama, Rattota and Naula DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Matale District, according to Dr. Senadeera. He said that the people living in other hilly areas receiving heavy rainfall have been instructed to be vigilant and to exercise caution over possible landslides,  cutting failure and subsidence. They have been instructed to take precautionary measures if they found any landslide signs such as slanting of trees, telephone and light posts or emerging of sudden springs or muddy water from the underground or highlands, cracks on walls or floors of buildings or sudden cracks on the ground in the surrounding and neighbouring areas. If the situation gets worse they have been asked to evacuate to safe places after informing the nearby Police Station and the DMC District office in this connection, Dr. Senadeera added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: All LG bodies to be dissolved by 5-10 Jan
author: Author not found
Content: SLPP MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage said all Local Government bodies in the country will be dissolved between 5 and 10 January, and elections will be held subsequently, as per the powers vested with the Election Commission of Sri Lanka (EC). He made this remark at a public meeting in Bavvagama, Nawalapitiya. He added that Local Government bodies would be dissolved and nominations would be accepted within 14 days. According to Aluthgamage, the JVP has accepted his challenge to win one division in the Nawalapitiya Constituency at the Local Government election, and as a result, the JVP is holding daily meetings in Nawalapitiya. He also stated that he is not afraid of elections because he has done much development work in the area. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Commemorating 2004 Tsunami victims
author: Author not found
Content: In commemoration of the 2004 Tsunami disaster, 26 December was designated as ‘National Safety Day,’ and commemorative events were held throughout the island. Yesterday (26) marked the 18th anniversary of the Tsunami disaster inSri Lanka and many special programmes had been organised to remember the victims. (Pix BY C. D. H. Hewage (Watawala), K. L. Suraweer (Kandy), Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage (Vavuniya), Janak Hettiarachchi (Wadduwa), Sumith Ranawaka (Pothupitiya), Kamal Wijehewa (Galle), Farhan Nizamdin (Galle), N. G. Liyanage (Ahangama) and G. I. Roshan (Wellawaya))

title: Trio arrested over attack on Police
author: Author not found
Content: Three suspects were arrested, by the Wattala Police, for obstructing the duties of Police on 25 December. Police said, a group of individuals, who were travelling in a three-wheeler near the Hendala Junction, Wattala were stopped by two Policemen due to their inappropriate behaviour. The driver and two passengers, were allegedly under the influence of liquor and when two Police officers attempted to arrest the driver, the passengers had attacked them and fled. However, after the two police officers informed the Wattala Police about the incident, another team of Police officers later arrested the three suspects along with the three-wheeler. The arrested suspects were identified as 25, 29 and  30-year-old residents of Wattala, Mabola. The two Police officers were admitted to the Colombo North General Hospital, Ragama. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: GFLOCK chair speaks to Mahamaya BV students
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of GFLOCK Clothing Sri Lanka, Ranil Villaddarage, made a speech to students of Mahamaya Balika Vidyalaya, Kandy, on the topic, ‘A person who works for the country with positive thinking’, in the auditorium of the school recently. On this occasion, the principal of the School Sasikala Senadheera, astronomer Anura C. Perera and a group of female students participated.

title: Two remanded over Eppawala child kidnapping
author: Author not found
Content: The two suspects, who were arrested over the abduction of the nine-year-old boy from Eppawala, were remanded until 4 January 2023 after being produced before the Thambuttegama Magistrate on 24 December. A nine-year-old boy from Eppawala, who was reported missing several days ago, was found with his kidnapper, a 45-year-old employed as a welding mechanic in the area. Police said they were found at Johnston Estate in Rikillagaskada on 24 December. Eppawala Police arrested the suspect and his associate who was the resident of the house in Rikillagaskada. Police also seized the main suspect’s three-wheeler. They were brought down to Eppawala Police Station on Saturday (24) for further questioning, during which the boy revealed that he had gone with the man voluntarily as his father was trying to ordain him into monkhood. The child was reported missing at around 8:30 p.m. on Monday (19) and was believed to be in the custody of the suspect based on the information received by the Police. Police investigations showed that the suspect had picked up the child from his family home in Kirologama, Getadiwula claiming that he is dropping the child off at a tuition class, like he usually does. However, the child had not returned home that night and the parents lodged a complaint with the Eppawala Police Station. It was revealed that after the suspect dropped the child at home, the child had gone to the suspect’s house alone later that night. As the child didn’t like to return home, the suspect had taken the child with him. The suspect had reportedly stayed over at close relative’s houses in Ukuwela and Naula on and after 20 December and had left those places with the child to Rikillagaskada. Police were able to arrest the suspect after conducting lengthy investigations. The boy is presently being examined at the Anuradhapura Hospital under Police protection. Eppawala Police are conducting further investigations. Pix By Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: NBRO issues landslide warnings in five districts
author: Author not found
Content: The National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has issued landslide early warnings for several areas in five districts.  The early warnings have been issued for several Divisional Secretariat Divisions in the districts of Kandy, Kegalle, Kurunegala, Matale and Nuwara Eliya. Since the rainfall within the past 24 hours has exceeded 100 mm, the people living in the below mentioned areas are requested to remain on alert on the possibility of landslides, slope failures, rock falls, cutting failures, and ground subsidence, being ready to evacuate to a safe location if the need arises.  Warning Level 2 Alert (Amber) was issued to Mawanella in Kegalle District, Rideegama in Kurunegala District, Pallepola, Ukuwela, Laggala Pallegama, Rattota and Naula in Matale District. Warning Level 1 watch (Yellow) issued to Ududumbara, Udunuwara, Pathadumbara, Pathahewaheta and Ganga Ihala Korale in Kandy District, Galigamuwa and Rambukkana in Kegalle District. Meanwhile, showery and windy conditions are expected to worsen across most parts of the island following a depression in the Southwest Bay of Bengal, according to the Meteorology Department. It is likely to move to the western sea area of Sri Lanka by today (26). There could be showers in the Northern, Eastern, North Central and North Western Provinces. Hence, heavy showers exceeding 100 mm could be expected in some places. Several spells of showers will occur elsewhere. Strong gusty winds between 40-50 kmph are expected to blow at times over the Northern, Eastern, North-Western, Western, and Sabaragamuwa provinces. The public are advised to take adequate precautionary measures to safeguard themselves from damage caused by gusty winds and lightning during thundershowers. (NV)

title: AIRPORTS SHOW BIG LOSSES
author: Author not found
Content: The Mattala International Airport has incurred a net loss of Rs 4.44 billion and the Colombo International Airport at Ratmalana had made a loss of Rs 461 million in 2021, with the Jaffna International Airport and the Batticaloa Airport recording absolutely no income, a recent annual report by the Auditor General revealed. This was revealed in an audit, of the performance of those airports, conducted by the Auditor General’s Department. According to the report, the capital expenditure of Rs 36,564 million, spent for the construction of Mattala International Airport, was not used effectively. The Treasury paid a sum of Rs 1,708 million as loan interest from 2010 to March 2015 for the loan of USD 190 million, obtained for that construction. The report also shows that Airport and Aviation Services Limited paid a sum of Rs 3,532 million from April 2015 to March 2022. According to the report, the loan balance was USD 109 million as of 31 December 2021. Although the Mattala International Airport’s expected annual passenger capacity is around one million, the total number of passengers who have used the airport in the last five years is 91,747, according to the Auditor General’s report. According to the report, only 2,396 flights have been operated in the last five years. It cited that the Mattala International Airport operations resulted in a net loss of 4,440 million rupees in 2021, and a cumulative net loss of 20,590 million rupees from 2017 to 2021. Meanwhile, the report reveals that the Colombo International Airport Ratmalana has continuously incurred losses through its operations, with a cumulative loss of Rs 1,693.66 million from 2017 to 2021 and a loss of Rs 461.08 million for 2021. According to the report, only 13 planes were handled at the airport each year in 2020 and 2021, with 60 passengers handled in 2020 and 28 in 2021. Although the Jaffna International Airport opened to passengers in October 2019, the Auditor General’s report shows that it has been losing money for the past three years. Administrative expenses of Rs 40.74 million were incurred in 2021, but no income was generated. Meanwhile, according to the Auditor General’s annual report, the Batticaloa Airport has not earned any revenue in the last five years and has spent Rs 74.64 million on administrative expenses. BY Amila Abeyrathne

title: 260 OICs transferred
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 260 Officers-in-Charge (OIC) have been transferred, the Police Media Division said.  Among that group are 50 Police Inspectors and 210 Chief Inspectors. Among these transfers, some Chief Inspectors of Police and Inspectors of Police who worked as OICs have been deployed for general duties. The Secretary of the Ministry of Public Security has ordered the appointment and transfer of the posts of OICs in accordance with the delegation of powers carried out by the Public Service Commission through Special Gazette Notification No. 2202/04 dated 30 November 2020. By Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Kandy Railway station flooded
author: Author not found
Content: The trains scheduled to run from Badulla to Colombo Fort at 10.15 a.m. and to Nanu Oya from Colombo Fort at 12.40 p.m. yesterday (25) were cancelled due to inclement weather conditions, according to the Department of Railways. The Kandy railway station, its surrounding areas were completely flooded, causing major problems for the officials working there. It was also reported that the railway track near the Gelioya station had been flooded and that train traffic had to be halted as a result. The water that had submerged the Kandy railway station due to the rain had receded by yesterday afternoon and railway employees had begun cleaning the station.

title: SL to observe two-minute silence
author: Author not found
Content: A two-minute silence will be observed islandwide in memory of all those who died in the 2004 tsunami and other natural disasters in Sri Lanka today (26) on National Safety Day, from 9:25 to 9:27 a.m. Meanwhile, a multi-faith memorial event will be held this morning at Akmeemana Kurunduwatta, near the tsunami memorial statue, to mark the 18th anniversary of the tsunami. This event is organised by the Akmeemana Pradeshiya Sabha. Minister of Plantation Industries, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, will preside over the tsunami commemoration. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Prasanna orders official to solve people’s problems
author: Author not found
Content: Urban Development and Housing Minister Prasanna Ranatunga advised the Gampaha District Secretary to hold a series of meetings to solve the problems in villages before 31 January 2023. He also said all Divisional Secretaries and other State officials in the Gampaha District should be present. The minister also highlighted that Government officials should announce how the people, who would be assisted through Samurdhi and other projects, were chosen. He was speaking at the Gampaha District Coordination Committee meeting, at the Gampaha District Secretariat. The minister also highlighted that receiving the assistance of Government officials was not happening. He also noted that politicians are chastised for the mistakes of Government officials. “Some Government projects are unknown to people’s representatives. However, people yell at public officials. As a result, at the regional coordination meetings in Gampaha and Minuwangoda, I directed that a series of meetings with divisional officials be held as soon as possible. In those meetings, the officials should explain how they chose the officials to distribute goods in the food and Samuddhi programmes.  This programme should be implemented in the district of Gampaha. As a result, the Governor should attend the regional coordination committee meeting and discuss people’s problems with the regional secretary and government officials, as well as work to find solutions to them. “This programme should be implemented by January,” he said.

title: Wildlife Ministry posts record revenue of Rs 6.6B
author: Author not found
Content: All four agencies falling under the Wildlife and Forest Conservation Ministry have earned record revenue of Rs 6.6 billion by October 2022, Minister of Agriculture, Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera said at a recent progress review meeting. The Wildlife Conservation Department earned Rs 1,291.08 million, the National Zoological Department earned Rs 414.2 million, the Forestry Department earned Rs 672 million, and the State Timber Corporation earned Rs 4,316 million. Amaraweera thanked all the staff for their efforts put into increasing revenue despite a massive setback caused in past years due to the Easter Sunday Attacks and the Covid-19 pandemic. The Minister also advised officials of the State Timber Corporation, Sri Lanka’s sole State timber supplier to begin new projects to increase income by capitalising on the ban imposed on importing timber and furniture to Sri Lanka with import restrictions put in place by the Government. The minister also encouraged officials to achieve the revenue target of Rs 5,000 million next year. In addition, the National Zoological Department has made plans to implement many programmes aimed at increasing local and foreign tourist attractions beginning next year, with the construction of new animal sanctuaries in Pinnawala and Ridiyagama.  (NV)

title: ETF Regulations amended
author: Author not found
Content: The Employees’ Trust Fund Regulations 1981, published in Government Gazette No. 125, dated 23 January 1981 have been amended. The following new regulations are hereby inserted immediately after regulation 3(1)(b) shall have effect as 3.(1)(c) and (d) of the Regulations: (c) Where any employer having in his employment a minimum of fifteen employees shall, from 1 February 2023, make such contributions electronically through a computer system or a mobile electronic device. (d) It shall be the duty of every employer having in his employment a minimum of fifteen employees to furnish returns monthly to the Board by electronic means. This direction shall come into effect from 1 February 2023.

title: Avoid bathing in rivers, waterfalls, sea
author: Author not found
Content: The Police requested the public to avoid bathing in rivers, waterfalls, reservoirs, and the sea due to the prevailing weather conditions. Speaking during a media briefing recently, Police Spokesman, SSP Nihal Thalduwa requested the public to be cautious and take precaution when engaging in activities or trips near rivers and waterfalls during the holiday and festive season. He requested to adhere to instructions given by lifeguards and Community Police Officers who are on duty near waterfalls, lakes, rivers, and beaches.  He said several drowning cases in hotel swimming pools were reported recently. Therefore, the public is requested to avoid consuming alcohol when going for a swim. “The public is requested to avoid drinking alcohol and bathing in the above mentioned places as much as possible, and especially to avoid sending children and elderly to those places,” he added. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: 44-year-old arrested with ‘Kush’
author: Author not found
Content: The STF, Customs officials, and the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) arrested a 44-year-old man who came to the Colombo Central Mail Exchange to collect a parcel containing over 1 kg of ‘Kush,’ a banned drug sent from the US. According to the STF, the drugs were concealed in a parcel labelled as toys. The parcel contained 1.3 kg of Kush, worth over Rs 20 million on the black market. The suspect, a Colombo 14 resident, was handed over to the PNB for investigation. A team of officers including Inspector B.S.H. Peiris of the Special Raid Unit conducted the raid. By Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Five arrested for illegal sand mining in Panadura
author: Author not found
Content: The Panadura Walana Anti-Corruption Unit said five people were arrested for illegally mining sand in the Kelani Ganga in the Hanwella Yaka Bamma area. Six boats, five and a half cubes of sand, and a large amount of sand mining equipment were seized when the suspects were arrested. According to Police, the raid was conducted based on information received by the OIC of the Panadura Walana Central Anti-Corruption Unit, that there was a great danger to the Hanwella Bridge in the Colombo and Gampaha districts, and that they were illegally forming groups and mining sand, causing significant environmental damage. According to an officer involved in the raid, when the Police arrived at the location the miners had been tipped off, so they had to proceed with caution. By Bimal Jayasinghe

title: New Navy Chief visits Anuradhapura sacred sites
author: Author not found
Content: Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera paid homage to the Atamasthana and several other places of worship in Anuradhapura on 24 December. This was his maiden tour to Anuradhapura, after taking office as the 25th Commander of the Sri Lanka Navy. The Navy Commander was accompanied by Mala Lamahewa, President of the Navy Seva Vanitha Unit. The Navy Commander first paid homage to sacred Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi in Anuradhapura and called on Atamasthanadipathi, Chief Sanghanayake of ‘Nuwara Kalaviya,’ Most Venerable Pallegama Sirisumana Rathanapala Hemarathana Nayake Thera and received blessings for future endeavours of the Navy. Subsequently, he visited Lankaramaya, Ruwanweliseya, Jethawanaramaya, Isurumuniya, Abayagiriya, Thuparamaya, Mirisawetiya as well as Sandahiru Seya and paid homage in pious sentiments. In addition, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera called on the Chief Incumbent of Lankaramaya and Chief Adhikarana Sanghanayake of North and North- Central Provinces Ven. Ralapanawe Dhammajoti Thera, Chief Incumbent of Ruwanweliseya and Chancellor of Rajarata University, Panditha Ven. Ethalawetunuwave Gnanathilaka Maha Nayake Thera, Viharadhikari of Jethawanaramaya, Ven. Ihalahalmillewe Rathanapala Nayake Thera, Chief Incumbent of Isurumuniya Raja Maha Viharaya and Chief Adhikarana Sanghanayake of ‘Nuwara Kalaviya,’ Ven. Matawa Sri Sangharakkitha Thera, Chief Incumbent of Abhayagiri Raja Maha Viharaya and Senior Lecturer of Bhiksu University of Sri Lanka, Rajakeeya Panditha Ven. Kallanchiye Rathanasiri Thera, Chief Incumbent of Thuparamaya, Ven. Kahalle Ganendra Nayake Thera and Chief Incumbent of Mirisawetiya, Ven. Welihene Sobitha Nayake Thera and received their blessings. Giving their wise counsel to the Navy Commander, the members of Maha Sangha heaped praise on the Sri Lanka Navy, which has been engaged in wide-ranging responsibilities for the defence of the nation and prosperity of the country. They showered the blessings of the Noble Triple Gem on the Navy Commander and all naval personnel, wishing them strength to realise the aspirations of the nation. President of Naval Buddhist Association and Director General Engineering, Rear Admiral Ravi Ranasinghe, Commander North-Central Naval Area, Rear Admiral Prasad Kariyapperuma, and a group of naval personnel from Navy Headquarters and North-Central Naval Command were present on these occasions.

title: Poultry, livestock struck by lightning
author: Author not found
Content: An animal shed in Eravur was set ablaze by lightning at 2:30 a.m. yesterday (25). Ismail Anwar, a labourer, built a shed in his backyard and raised goats, chickens, and ducks. Lightning and thundershowers were reported in the Batticaloa District on Saturday evening. Anwar’s 9 goats, 8 hens, 4 chickens, and 3 ducks were killed in the blaze. This two-floor shed housed goats on the upper floor and chickens, hens, and ducks on the lower floor. By T.L. Jawfer – Batticaloa

title: Seminar to mark 126th birthday of Prof. Paranavitana
author: Author not found
Content: A special seminar will be held to mark the 126th birthday of the first Archaeological Commissioner of Sri Lanka today (26) at 2:30 p.m. at the Postgraduate Institute of Archaeology of the University of Kelaniya, located at Bauddhaloka Mawatha, Colombo 7. The Chairman of this seminar is Director of Postgraduate Institute of Archaeology, Prof. Gamini Adikari. The event is organised by the Prof. Senarath Paranavitana Foundation in collaboration with the Department of Archaeology, Muslim Archives Department, and Central Cultural Fund. The resource persons for the seminar are Prof. J.B. Disanayake, Prof. Chandima Wijebandara, Prof. Gamini Adikari and Sirisaman Wijetunge, Secretary of the Prof. Senarath Paranavitana Foundation. This seminar will be compeered by Wasana Sirimalwaththa of Department of Archaeology. (NV)

title: Land, buildings under Mahara PS to be taken over
author: Author not found
Content: Chairperson of the Mahara Pradeshiya Sabha, Sudima Chandani, said the land and buildings under their administration will be taken over. Kirikitta-West, Kirikitta-East, Neelammahara-North, Neelammahara-South, Uruwala-East, Uruwala-West, Batepola, Sivuralumulla, Kahatana, Aramangoda-North, Henegama, Atikehelgalle, Puakpitiya, Warapalana, Ambagaspitiya, Yongammulla, Kadumulla, Pasgammana, Butpitiya-Uthura, Birkuttutu, Kinigama, and Bagalgoda are located in the 22 village service domains. The Chairperson said a majority of buildings on these lands have been built or are being built with public funds from the Mahara Pradeshiya Sabha. Chandani added that she had submitted a proposal to the council to take over these lands and buildings, which had been approved. By K. Duminda (Biyagama) and Udara Madhushanka (Kadawatha)

title: Distribution of dry rations at Abhayagiri Vihara
author: Author not found
Content: Arrangements have been made to distribute 50,000 parcels of dry rations among needy families by the China Buddhist Association and Faxian Charity Trust with the participation of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena and Acting Chinese Ambassador Hu Wei in the presence of Atamasthanadhipathi Ven. Pallegama Hemaratana Thera, Chief Incumbent Abhayagiri Temple Ven. Dr. Kallanchiye Rathanasiri Thera on 27 December at 1:30 pm at the Abhayagiri premises in Anuradhapura. The event is organised by the Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka and the China-Sri Lanka Buddhist Friendship Association.

title: heavy rains wreak havoc in several areas of country
author: Author not found
Content: Severe floods caused by heavy rains in the last 48 hours damaged a section of the Kundasale, Arangala, and Banduraya road. This road was repaired about two years ago. It is impassable at present. Meanwhile, the Polonnaruwa Parakrama Samudra has begun to overflow due to heavy rain, according to the Disaster Management Centre. Due to the downpour in Pallepola area since 24 December, the paddy fields of the Katukenda Kinigama area were inundated after the Pallepola Oya overflowed. As the main road from Matale to Galewela is flooded, traffic has been disrupted, and light vehicles are forced to use alternative routes. Pix By Pallepola J. Pathmasiri, Anuradha Vishwanath and Priyantha Polwatte (Ukuwela)
