Ralapanawe Dhammajoti Thera, Chief Incumbent of Ruwanweliseya and Chancellor of Rajarata University, Panditha Ven. Ethalawetunuwave Gnanathilaka Maha Nayake Thera, Viharadhikari of Jethawanaramaya, Ven. Ihalahalmillewe Rathanapala Nayake Thera, Chief Incumbent of Isurumuniya Raja Maha Viharaya and Chief Adhikarana Sanghanayake of ‘Nuwara Kalaviya,’ Ven. Matawa Sri Sangharakkitha Thera, Chief Incumbent of Abhayagiri Raja Maha Viharaya and Senior Lecturer of Bhiksu University of Sri Lanka, Rajakeeya Panditha Ven. Kallanchiye Rathanasiri Thera, Chief Incumbent of Thuparamaya, Ven. Kahalle Ganendra Nayake Thera and Chief Incumbent of Mirisawetiya, Ven. Welihene Sobitha Nayake Thera and received their blessings. Giving their wise counsel to the Navy Commander, the members of Maha Sangha heaped praise on the Sri Lanka Navy, which has been engaged in wide-ranging responsibilities for the defence of the nation and prosperity of the country. They showered the blessings of the Noble Triple Gem on the Navy Commander and all naval personnel, wishing them strength to realise the aspirations of the nation. President of Naval Buddhist Association and Director General Engineering, Rear Admiral Ravi Ranasinghe, Commander North-Central Naval Area, Rear Admiral Prasad Kariyapperuma, and a group of naval personnel from Navy Headquarters and North-Central Naval Command were present on these occasions.

title: Poultry, livestock struck by lightning
author: Author not found
Content: An animal shed in Eravur was set ablaze by lightning at 2:30 a.m. yesterday (25). Ismail Anwar, a labourer, built a shed in his backyard and raised goats, chickens, and ducks. Lightning and thundershowers were reported in the Batticaloa District on Saturday evening. Anwar’s 9 goats, 8 hens, 4 chickens, and 3 ducks were killed in the blaze. This two-floor shed housed goats on the upper floor and chickens, hens, and ducks on the lower floor. By T.L. Jawfer – Batticaloa

title: Seminar to mark 126th birthday of Prof. Paranavitana
author: Author not found
Content: A special seminar will be held to mark the 126th birthday of the first Archaeological Commissioner of Sri Lanka today (26) at 2:30 p.m. at the Postgraduate Institute of Archaeology of the University of Kelaniya, located at Bauddhaloka Mawatha, Colombo 7. The Chairman of this seminar is Director of Postgraduate Institute of Archaeology, Prof. Gamini Adikari. The event is organised by the Prof. Senarath Paranavitana Foundation in collaboration with the Department of Archaeology, Muslim Archives Department, and Central Cultural Fund. The resource persons for the seminar are Prof. J.B. Disanayake, Prof. Chandima Wijebandara, Prof. Gamini Adikari and Sirisaman Wijetunge, Secretary of the Prof. Senarath Paranavitana Foundation. This seminar will be compeered by Wasana Sirimalwaththa of Department of Archaeology. (NV)

title: Land, buildings under Mahara PS to be taken over
author: Author not found
Content: Chairperson of the Mahara Pradeshiya Sabha, Sudima Chandani, said the land and buildings under their administration will be taken over. Kirikitta-West, Kirikitta-East, Neelammahara-North, Neelammahara-South, Uruwala-East, Uruwala-West, Batepola, Sivuralumulla, Kahatana, Aramangoda-North, Henegama, Atikehelgalle, Puakpitiya, Warapalana, Ambagaspitiya, Yongammulla, Kadumulla, Pasgammana, Butpitiya-Uthura, Birkuttutu, Kinigama, and Bagalgoda are located in the 22 village service domains. The Chairperson said a majority of buildings on these lands have been built or are being built with public funds from the Mahara Pradeshiya Sabha. Chandani added that she had submitted a proposal to the council to take over these lands and buildings, which had been approved. By K. Duminda (Biyagama) and Udara Madhushanka (Kadawatha)

title: Distribution of dry rations at Abhayagiri Vihara
author: Author not found
Content: Arrangements have been made to distribute 50,000 parcels of dry rations among needy families by the China Buddhist Association and Faxian Charity Trust with the participation of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena and Acting Chinese Ambassador Hu Wei in the presence of Atamasthanadhipathi Ven. Pallegama Hemaratana Thera, Chief Incumbent Abhayagiri Temple Ven. Dr. Kallanchiye Rathanasiri Thera on 27 December at 1:30 pm at the Abhayagiri premises in Anuradhapura. The event is organised by the Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka and the China-Sri Lanka Buddhist Friendship Association.

title: Rotary and UNICEF hand over Rs 47M worth of medicines to Health Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: The Rotary International President Jennifer Jones and the UNICEF Representative to Sri Lanka, Christian Skoog, handed over LKR 47 million worth of medicines, under the Lifeline project, to the Minister of Health, Keheliya Rambukwella, to help the delivery of health services at a time the country is facing shortages due to the economic crisis. The medicines valued at USD 130,000 (approx. 47 million LKR) were urgently procured by UNICEF with funds raised by Rotary’s global network and alumni through the online donation platform https://lifelinesrilanka.rotary.unicef.org.au “We are happy to present the first consignment of the medicines to the Ministry of Health so that the people of Sri Lanka can be served,” said Jennifer Jones. “Rotary will continue to find ways of supporting the country which is very special. Your country has such wonderful people with smiling faces all the time. We must make sure to save that smile in the future,” she said. This consignment of medicines will support various types of treatment including for women during childbirth, pain management, and hypertension. “The protracted nature of the crisis is stretching vital social services such as healthcare and education. UNICEF is using its procurement and logistics expertise and leveraging its partnerships to deliver lifesaving supplies to families,” said Christian Skoog, UNICEF Representative in Sri Lanka. “Despite some improvements in the economic situation in Sri Lanka, the needs of the most vulnerable children and families remain acute, and we are seeking the support of multiple stakeholders to help sustain and scale up our assistance,” he said. The former President of Rotary International, K.R. Ravindran, and the Rotary Sri Lanka Governor Pubudu de Soyza were also present at the event. Explaining the initiative, past Rotary International President Ravindran said “As 80 per cent of our medical supplies are imported, with foreign currency reserves running out because of the economic crisis, essential medicines are not available, and our healthcare system is close to collapse. Lives are in peril, surgeries are being postponed and children and pregnant women are most at risk. This is the reality, and we must accept it and then find ways to help Sri Lanka. I am glad that the Global president is present to hand over the stocks to the Government of Sri Lanka.” In August this year, Rotary International and UNICEF partnered to raise funds to support the delivery of life-saving medicines, clean drinking water, education materials, and other critical supplies to children and families impacted by the economic crisis across the country.

title: HRCSL discusses difficulties faced by differently-abled
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) convened a meeting, with officials of Public and Private Banks, to discuss the issues faced by persons with disabilities and dwarfs while engaging in physical transactions at Banks. The Bank Officials representing the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) and 12 other Public and Private Banks were present at the meeting. Attention was focused on the New Customer Charter, issued in July 2022 by the CBSL, based on the HRCSL’s recommendations given in 2021, which provides guidelines for Banks in assisting their customers. Bank Officials stated that they are in the process of implementing those guidelines and they affirmed that they will take necessary action without undue delay. Positive comments were received during the discussion and Banks suggested the use of Digital Banking Facilities (Online Banking) by customers including people with disabilities and dwarfs, which is more convenient for everyone. If they lack knowledge of Digital Banking Facilities, Bank officials agreed to contribute voluntary assistance to conduct capacity-building programmes with the support of HRCSL.The meeting was convened under the patronage of HRCSL Chairperson Justice Rohini Marasinghe, on 20 December 2022. (SRM)

title: STATE OFFICIALS ACTING LIKE RUSSIANS AND UKRAINIANS – PRESIDENT
author: Author not found
Content: Instead of solving problems of the general public, State officials are acting like Ukrainians and Russians who are fighting, said President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (22). He was speaking at the Nuwara Eliya District Development Committee meeting held at the Nuwara Eliya District Secretariat. The President pointed out that about 50 per cent of the people’s problems, presented to him, can be solved by officials and it is not necessary for a President or a Minister to come from Colombo to solve those problems. He also said that Government institutions should be committed to providing maximum public service in a well-coordinated manner. He said Government officials should fulfil their responsibilities properly without engaging in tug-of-war when serving the people.

title: Tourists engaging in business to be dealt with
author: Author not found
Content: Labour and Foreign Employment Minister Manusha Nanayakkara said the Labour and Foreign Employment Ministry will take immediate action against tourists engaged in businesses without permission. He mentioned this while participating in the recently held Galle District Coordination Committee meeting. Nanayakkara told the officials that foreign tourists, coming to Sri Lanka from various countries, on tourist visas are engaged in various businesses without any registration or licence and to take immediate action in this regard. “This group is engaged in businesses from selling various goods to selling drugs, and they return to their countries, with foreign currency that should have been ours. This does not bring any benefit to the economy of this country. Owing to this situation, locals engaged in business in tourist areas, including Galle, are in a lot of trouble,” Nanayakkara further said. He added that even after complaining about this, the Police sometimes get confused about the measures that need to be taken to stop this. He added it would be convenient if an order could be given stating how such complaints should be dealt with. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Tardiness of Lankan Minister irks S.Korean delegates
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation from the renowned South Korea Disaster Relief Foundation (SKDRF) was irked when they were kept waiting by State Minister for Social Empowerment, Anupa Pasqual, at an event on 21 December. SKDRF President Cho Sung Lea reprimanded the top invitee, Pasqual, over his late arrival saying that if this delay had occurred in Korea, the person would have been investigated and possibly removed from the position because he would not have been deemed suitable for the position. It happened when the Minister arrived about 30 minute late and the SKDRF President began his lecture by pointing out Pasqual’s delay and irresponsibility. In the video going viral, Lea chastised the Minister by saying when anyone engages in a job, he must be honest. When the boss is around the worker tends to be working but when he leaves, the worker starts to idle. If the promises are not kept, I will not continue working with them said Lea. “What is a lie? When the meeting is at 9 a.m. and if the person concern arrives at 9.30 a.m., it’s a lie. He assured he will come and he did not and his assurance was a lie. Why should I meet a person like that? There is an English saying “don’t let a man who lies even build a toilet for you.  “if someone lies the English people  cut connections with him completely.  If one cannot work properly even for a minute, he is done. In Sri Lanka, lying is like eating rice every day. Lying is common and a regular thing here. Despite my saying, it seems so simple to break promises for Sri Lankans. As Sri Lankans you should be ashamed to hear a foreigner saying this. It has become part of your tradition in Sri Lanka. This has to change and it is an important point. We must be honest and reasonable.  If you have given a responsibly take it up and work on it 100 per cent. When a task is given to you, do it with responsibility. We must be accountable for the work we undertake. The point is that here no one takes the responsibility for the given task. The reason is you have managed to accept it as normal and reasonable.  If I am given a task I will sacrifice my life to complete it with honesty,” he added. He also pointed out Sri Lankans employed in Korea are asked to leave if they idle. If the workers are known to be lazy and idling they lose popularity and the demand to be employed there. “Without doing the work properly, but asking for a pay, does not work. We also should be reasonable. If a person lies to a Korean, that’s the end. There is no pointing in continuing our talks.  The business with him comes to an end. For the last 10 days we have been engaged in a workshop and there should not be a delay of even five minutes. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: GoSL and India must recognise their contribution – Mano
author: Author not found
Content: In the light of Indian Origin Hill Country Tamils marking 200 years since their arrival in Sri Lanka from South India next year, Leader of Tamil Progressive Alliance (TPA) MP Mano Ganesan, urged President Ranil Wickremesinghe and his administration to add administrative measures, such as constitutionally authorised affirmative action, to the evaluation Cabinet memo, in order to make up for lost ground regarding the rights to land, housing, employment, education, and health of the Hill Country Tamils. President Wickremesinghe arrived in Nuwara Eliya Yesterday (22), and spoke on the solutions to the land problems of Nuwara Eliya people and said he would want to resolve it before 4 February, Independence Day. On the same lines, he also spoke about a cable car project between Pattipola-Boralanda for tourists to see the World’s End. President Wickremesinghe instructed officials during the Nuwara Eliya District Development Committee meeting, held yesterday, to commence construction of a cable car project. Ganesan continued to remind the Government of its stance on the Hill Country Tamils. He further noted that the Government of Sri Lanka has officially decided to evaluate and then recognise the contribution of Indian Origin Hill Country Tamil community to the national economy over the last 200 years since their arrival in 1823.  He said that the TPA, as the major community party, welcomed the Cabinet Memo of President Wickremesinghe. “Next year, 2023, is going to be the 200th anniversary of the arrival of the first generation of Hill Country Tamils of most recent Indian origin, now a Sri Lankan community, to Ceylon. MP Ganesan said further, “realisation of the Sri Lankan State on the need to support the underprivileged Hill Country Tamil community makes us happy, but the economic crisis may not be conducive to provide all livelihood subsidies and other infrastructure allocations needed by these people.  To this, he added that it is a wakeup call and that goes to India also. “Governments of the Indian Union and the State of Tamil Nadu should consider providing monetary assistance and expertise to the Sri Lankan Government to design and conduct affirmative action programmes in the plantations.”  He pointed out that the most underprivileged segments in India are looked after with special reservations, with constitutional provisions.  “It is the vision of Dr. Ambedkar and C.N. Arignar Annadurai towards the marginalised people in India under the concept of Social Justice. We request India to extend the same to our people through the Government of Sri Lanka,” Ganesan said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Govt scared to hold elections – Gammanpila
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is hesitating to hold elections on time because they are alarmed by the people’s reactions over increased direct taxes, possible long-hour power outages and the delay in obtaining International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance, said Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader Udaya Gammanpila. Addressing a media briefing, Gammanpila said the increased direct and indirect taxes will come into effect on 1 January 2023, and people will feel the real pressure due to the increased taxes after that. Holding an election when the people are angry would be fatal for the Government, he pointed out. “According to the election law, the Election Commission should announce the local government elections before 9 January 2023. The Election Commission is as interested in holding the election as the Government is in not holding the election,” he explained and added, “We (Sri Lanka) were the first to announce that the IMF facility would be available after March. It is expected that one billion US dollars would be received from the Asian Development Bank and USD two billion from the issuance of Bonds, in addition to the IMF loan. The Government hoped to use the funds to purchase fuel and medicine, thereby alleviating the shortages. It was hoped that the money would be used to stabilise the rupee and lower the cost of goods. They hoped to go to the elections as heroes, but they failed big time.” He went on to say that the Government knows that when none of these things can be done on time, if it has to face an election in the midst of a power outage, a medicine shortage, rising commodity prices, and an increasing tax burden, it will be fatal blow to them. “But, no matter how hard the Government tries, we promise the people that we will not allow the Government to deprive the people of their right to vote,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Handunnetti demands probe
author: Author not found
Content: Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) Politburo member Sunil Handunnetti demanded an immediate investigation to determine why the former Third Secretary of the Sri Lankan Embassy in Oman, who is a suspect in the Oman sex trafficking incident, was not sent back toSri Lanka, following clear instructions of top officials to do so, months ago. Addressing a media briefing, Handunnetti said it is very unfortunate that the incident is forgotten now. Then Chairman of the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE), General Mahinda Hathurusingha, had informed the Minister about this individual and sent a letter, on 28 January, through the Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs demanding that the suspect return to Sri Lanka, he said. Handunnetti added that this order was made based on the complaints received from the employees about the activities of this person, the reports of the investigations conducted by the internal audit department and the investigation reports of the CID. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Injured trio of dolphins washed ashore
author: Author not found
Content: Three injured dolphins were washed ashore on the Panadura beach, in the afternoon of 21 December and were later returned to the sea by local residents, Panadura South Police said. These dolphins are said to have washed ashore behind a major tourist hotel in Panadura, and they were severely injured. Panadura South Police were then notified by local residents. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: STF finds hand phones at Boossa Prison
author: Author not found
Content: The STF, during a search operation, discovered six mobile phones that had been concealed in the ceiling of the Jailors Rest Room at the High Security Remand Prison in Boossa, Galle. According to the STF, they recovered those items, following a detailed search conducted at the prison premises. They added that besides the mobile phones, mobile phone chargers, power banks, cables and wires were also seized during the operation. The seized items were handed over to the STF Head Office in Colombo. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: 5,000 youths jailed over drug offences in 2021
author: Author not found
Content: Some 5,000 youths, aged between 16 and 22, were arrested and imprisoned for drug offences in 2021, Prison Spokesman Chandana Ekanayake said. Speaking to Ceylon Today, he said, in 2021, the number of students in GCE Ordinary Level and Advanced Level classes, who were imprisoned due to drug use, had increased in comparison to 2015. He also noted that in 2015, there were 2,600 youths imprisoned for drug use. He also claimed that there has been a significant increase in the age group of between 16 and 22 years old. However, speaking on a television programme, Ekanayake said nearly 600 youths, who did not attend school, were imprisoned for drug-related offences in 2015, and that figure had fallen fall to 190 by 2021. “However, the number of students, imprisoned for using drugs, enrolling in GCE Ordinary Level and Advanced Level classes, has increased. It was around 2,000 in 2015, and by 2021, the number had risen to 5,000,” he noted. Further, he noted that it demonstrates an increase in the number of 16 and 17-year-old educated youths, which is not a good thing. “Also, more people over the age of 34 were imprisoned for drug-related offences in 2015. When all of these factors are considered, there is an increase in the number of young people who are addicted to drugs. Also, 22 graduates have been imprisoned in 2020 for drug use,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: N’Eliya people’s land issues to be solved
author: Author not found
Content: All the land licences given to the plantation companies will be cancelled and steps will be taken to provide the land needed by the people before Independence Day next year, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said yesterday (22). The President revealed this at the Nuwara Eliya District Development Committee meeting held at the Nuwara Eliya District Secretariat. The President instructed the officers to formulate a joint report, engaging all Government agencies, on the resolution of land problems in the Nuwara Eliya District, before 4 February 2023, adding that if such a report is not submitted, he would take necessary action in this regard.

title: Two arrested in attempt to sell sword
author: Author not found
Content: Two individuals, who had attempted to sell a sword, claiming that it belongs to the reign of King Walagamba, have been apprehended by Walana Anti Vice Squad. Police said the weight of the sword was 750g and that it is 23 inches long while it has a depiction of a dragon embossed on the handle. Police added that they conducted a raid following a tip off received that the two suspects were scouring for a buyer to sell the sword, which was allegedly dug out from a forest reservation at Mahiyangana. The STF stated that the suspects planned to sell the sword for four million rupees. They said that having masqueraded as buyers, a group of Police officers had gone to Mahiyangana and arrested the two suspects aged 23 and who are residents of Bandarawela. The Police are due to call for a report from the Archaeological Department on the sword. By Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: CID records statements from Schaffter brothers
author: Author not found
Content: The CID made arrangements yesterday (22) to record statements from the brothers of Janashakthi Life Insurance Co. Non-Executive Director Dinesh Schaffter, who was murdered recently. The brothers were summoned to CID office in Kirulapone, Polhengoda where their statements were recorded. They were informed that they would be summoned again if necessary. According to CID sources, the statements recorded from Schaffter’s wife and the statements given by the brothers will be compared. At the moment, statements from 60 people have been recorded. Many details about phone records are being revealed, but because doing so would jeopardise the investigation, the details could not be revealed, sources said. BY Keerthi Mendis

title: Seven remanded over narcotics possession
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera yesterday (22) remanded, till 3 January 2023, seven suspects, who were charged with trafficking and possession of 200 kg of ‘ICE’. The suspects were arrested and the stock of ‘Ice’ was seized in a special coordinated operation, conducted recently, by the SL Navy, the Police Narcotic Bureau (PNB) and the State Intelligence Service (SIS), off the Southern coastal belt, after which they had been handed over to the PNB sleuths. The PNB, prosecuting, requested Additional Magistrate Perera to remand the suspects as their investigations were continuing. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Re-skilling migrant returnees
author: Author not found
Content: In response to strengthening the socioeconomic resilience of returning migrant workers, the International Labour Organization (ILO) has identified the maritime sector as having the potential to generate ample employment opportunities for the returnees and aspirant migrant workers, Japan’s Embassy in Sri Lanka said in a statement yesterday. In this connection, the Mahapola Port and Maritime Academy supported by the Government of Japan (GoJ), with the facilitation of the ILO and the National Union of Seafarers of Sri Lanka (NUSS), successfully conducted the graduation ceremony for 22 trainees who completed the Training Course on Maritime and Seamanship on Tuesday (20). The training covered all routine operational activities, such as hands on experience to operate deck-rated machinery and equipment and to assist the deck officer on watch and watch-keeping duties, among others, it said. Speaking at the certificate awarding ceremony, Hideaki Mizukoshi said, “I am pleased to see that Japan’s assistance can be of help to migrant returnees to obtain new employment and ‘skill-up opportunities’. Through the project, the Government of Japan also aims to strengthen the returnees’ practical skills and encourage their entrepreneurship.” ILO Country Director for Sri Lanka and the Maldives Simrin Singh also spoke. This programme has been initiated through the ILO’s ‘Socioeconomic Reintegration of Sri Lankan Migrant Workers Project’ with the support of the people of Japan, the statement concluded. (PA)

title: Paddy cultivators to get 6.98M litres of fuel
author: Author not found
Content: As per a request made by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, 6.98 million litres of fuel, provided to Sri Lanka by the Chinese Government, will be distributed to farmers engaged in paddy cultivation, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said.  The Chinese Government provided a total of 10.06 million litres of fuel, therefore, the balance will be allocated for the fisheries sector, he said. The fuel distribution will be done through the filling stations belonging to the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, selected from the respective Districts, Amaraweera noted. He said the fuel required for rice cultivation has been provided to farmers, Island wide, without any shortcoming. Meanwhile, a total of 851,043 hectares of paddy land is expected to be cultivated for the 2022/23 Maha season, the Ministry of Agriculture stated. (FT)

title: Eight spl trains for season
author: Author not found
Content: Eight Special trains will be operated during the festive season, said Sri Lanka Railways Deputy General Manager A.D.G. Seneviratne. The special trains will be operational beginning today (23), according to him. Furthermore, he said three special trains will run from Colombo Fort to Badulla, with three more trains running from Badulla to Colombo Fort. Meanwhile, he said, a special train will run from Colombo Fort to Kankesanturai and another from Kankesanturai to Colombo Fort.

title: Country’s leaders should be ashamed to go begging – Cardinal
author: Author not found
Content: The leaders of the country should be ashamed to travel the world and beg for food and drink from foreign nations, whilst living in such a beautiful country like Sri Lanka, Archbishop of Colombo Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith observed.   “The appalling deeds of our country’s leaders have led to this crisis situation,” he charged when addressing the gathering at Holy Cross College, Kalutara, during a carol service themed ‘A Birth of Hope’. He accused Sri Lanka’s leaders of seeking assistance from foreign countries to obtain food and drink like beggars. What is the attitude of this country’s leaders which makes them go begging like this? It is their blameworthy actions that led to this sorry situation in Sri Lanka, the Cardinal claimed.  Cardinal Ranjith said, it is not possible to celebrate Christmas with joy when a majority people in the country were hungry. The United Nations has said that 6.1 million people in Sri Lanka skipped at least one meal due to poverty. Therefore, with Sri Lanka going through such a vulnerable situation, how can the Christian community celebrate and enjoy Christmas this year, he said. Christmas is not all about crackers, food, drink, decorations. What is given is more important than what is received at Christmas, he added.  Ten children with special talents from low-income families in Kalutara were given the necessary facilities to study in the school, and a special financial donation was made to twenty poor families in ten villages of Kalutara. The concert was conducted by the Principal Prasad Niranjan Fernando and the Deputy Principal Ranmal Sevanda. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: December 26 a public holiday
author: Author not found
Content: As Christmas falls on a Sunday this year, Monday (26), has been declared a public holiday. Accordingly, the Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government Dinesh Gunawardena has instructed the Secretary to the Ministry to take necessary steps to declare 26 December a holiday. (FT)

title: Special programme for COPA members
author: Author not found
Content: A special awareness programme to support the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) regarding the further expansion of the evaluation process in the public sector was held in Parliament recently, with the participation of COPA members. Officials of Sri Lanka Evaluation Association (SLEA) briefed committee members on this programme. COPA Chairman Kabir Hashim chaired the event. It was also discussed regarding the completion of the National Evaluation draft bill and implementation of the recommendations of the Parliamentary Select Committee. Also, facts were presented about the possibility of establishing an Evaluation Unit when setting up a Budget Office in Parliament. The need to speed up the preparation of a National Evaluation Policy was also emphasised during the programme. Emphasising the need for a formal national evaluation process, the COPA Chairman said this programme is a preliminary discussion and that he expects to discuss this broadly in the future and take necessary steps expeditiously. State Ministers Prasanna Ranaweera, Kader Masthan, MPs Sudarshani Fernandopulle, Major Pradeep Udugoda, Wasantha Yapabandara, Sahan Pradeep Vithana, Dr. Charitha Herath, and Dr. Harini Amarasuriya were present at the discussion.

title: 125 new jeeps handed over to Police
author: Author not found
Content: As the first phase of the initiative to provide 500 jeeps to the Police, under the Indian credit line, 125 new jeeps were handed over to the Police yesterday (22) at the Ministry of Public Security. Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka Gopal Bagley symbolically handed over the jeeps to Public Security Minister Tiran Alles. Speaking at the occasion, Minister Alles said it is a special day for the Police and the programme will be a solution to the shortage of vehicles for duty in some Police stations. These new jeeps are essential for the Police to combat theft and drug trafficking, and the Police have not been able to procure vehicles for the past 3 years, he said. Minister Alles added that this project was a success due to the close ties with the Indian High Commissioner in Sri Lanka. Indian High Commissioner Gopal Bagley said his government is delighted to give these jeeps to Sri Lanka Police to maintain law and order, democracy, and stability in the country. (AK)

title: Christmas Tree made of Vegetable plants
author: Author not found
Content: With the aim of popularising agricultural crops and gardening among the people, a Christmas tree made of vegetable plants, for this Christmas, has been created at the roundabout near Galle Face, close to the Presidential Secretariat. This Christmas tree, which is about 30 feet tall, consists of about 2,000 pots of natural vegetable plants. Many types of plants like kankun, red tampala, spinach, brinjal, cabbage, okra, dangoa, chilies and many other plants have been used to decorate this Christmas tree. Softlogic Life Insurance PLC, which created this tree, said that the purpose of this special Christmas tree is to direct the people, who have been away from gardening due to the various obstacles faced by the country, towards gardening. The organisers said that if it was possible to create a Christmas tree from such vegetable plants in the midst of obstacles such as the prevailing temperature in the city of Colombo and the salty wind in this area, it is not impossible for the people to maintain a garden in their backyard with minimal obstacles. Softlogic Life Insurance PLC, which is exhibiting this Christmas tree, said that after the exhibition period, the plants will be distributed among the people and to a school in Borella. (AK)

title: Navy seize Indian trawler with 12 fishers
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy conducted a special operation, on Wednesday (21) morning, to turn away Indian trawlers poaching in Sri Lankan waters. The operation led to the seizing of an Indian trawler with 12 Indian nationals found poaching in Sri Lankan waters northeast of Veththalakerni. Thus far in 2022, the Navy has seized 36 Indian poaching trawlers and held 264 Indian fishermen who been handed over to the relevant authorities for legal action. Sri Lanka Navy continues to conduct regular patrols and operations in Sri Lankan waters, to curb illegal fishing practices of foreign fishing trawlers. In a similar operation, the Northern Naval Command deployed a Fast Attack Craft of the fourth Fast Attack Flotilla to chase away a cluster of Indian trawlers, after having spotted that they were engaging in illegal fishing in Sri Lankan waters northeast of Veththalakerni this morning. (NV)

title: Health Ministry to Charter SLAF planes
author: Author not found
Content: A memorandum of understanding (MoU) was entered into between the Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) and the Health Ministry, for the latter to charter the former’s aircraft for the purpose of airlifting the bodies of deceased persons, in respect of organ retrievals for the purpose of organ transplant, the SLAF said on Wednesday (22). The MoU was signed at SLAF Headquarters in Colombo between SLAF Commander Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana and Health Ministry Secretary Janaka Sri Chandraguptha. SLAF in this connection will have in readiness its C-130, AN-32, MA-60, Y-12, MI-17, Bell-412, Bell-212 and Bell-206 aircraft. Also present at this occasion were SLAF Director Air Operations, Air Vice Marshal Bandhu Edirisinghe, Director Legal, Air Commodore Sureka Dias, Staff Officer Operations I of Directorate of Air Operations Group Captain Dinesh Kasagala, Legal Officer Procurement Wing Commander Harshani Katugampola, Additional Health Ministry Secretary (Medical Services) Dr. Sunil De Alwis, Director Medical Services Dr. Ayanthi Karunarathne, Senior Registrar (Medical Services), Dr. Avanthi Rupasinghe and Chief Legal Officer, A.R. Ahamed. (PA)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sajith Calls for Education Revolution
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa claimed that there should be a revolution in the education system as the usual parroting system has proved to be a failure. Addressing the Sakwala education programme, where a bus was donated to the Thopawawa National School on Wednesday (21), Premadasa noted that there has been a massive collapse in the education system and the country cannot go forwardwith it.  “In order to win the world, digital, computer and English language education is a must.  An education system that provides solutions to the modern problems and creates an education system centred on the international standards of the  labour market must be created,” he added. Premadasa claimed that few people with outdated mentality laughed when it was said that English should be mandatory.  “Learning something new is important for a country that is moving towards modernisation. Even though some parties may lose their votes if this happens, this will develop the education of our country. Many generations will benefit from that,” he added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Herath, Wedaarachchi meet Fisheries Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Vijitha Herath and SJB MP Dilip Wedaarachchi recently joined Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda and State Minister Piyal Nishantha for a discussion to resolve teething issues that plague the country’s canned fish industry. This discussion had taken place at the Fisheries Ministry on 21 December and during the meeting representatives from the Canned Fish Importers’ Association (CFIA) had highlighted problems which continue to stymie the industry. During the meeting, the subject Minister had assured CFIA officials that the issues pointed out by them will be looked into by his Ministry and steps will be taken to popularise canned fish among the public expeditiously. Devananda had also assured that steps will be taken to prevent low quality canned fish from flooding the market and urged the Opposition MPs to support the Government in these efforts. SJB MP Wedaarachchi discussed various issues faced by fishermen due to the steep rise in the price of kerosene and urged the Minister to provide relief.

title: WFP welcomes USAID Regional Programme Officer
author: Author not found
Content: The World Food Programme (WFP) in Sri Lanka welcomed Dustin Shiau, Senior Regional Programme Officer of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)’s Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance (BHA), on a visit to Sri Lanka. He met food-insecure communities and heard first-hand accounts of the difficulties they are facing and how USAID and WFP support has helped provide regular meals for their families. During his visit, Shiau met communities from Mullaitivu in the North, who are among those worst affected by the economic crisis – including pregnant and breastfeeding mothers and people with disabilities – to better understand their nutritional needs. This year, the US has provided a record total USD 20 million (approximately Rs 7.3 billion) to support WFP’s response to the economic crisis in Sri Lanka. Of that, USAID’s most recent contribution of USD 13 million (approximately Rs 4.7 billion) is providing cash assistance and food rations to families hard-hit by the economic crisis across the country. USAID also donated funds to WFP to help feed children enrolled in the national school meal programme. “The United States of America is a significant contributor to WFP’s emergency operation in Sri Lanka and the single largest donor to WFP globally,” said Abdur Rahim Siddiqui, WFP Sri Lanka’s Representative and Country Director. “We are immensely grateful for the contribution from USAID’s Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance which has enabled us to swiftly expand our emergency operation, so we can help more people access regular, nutritious meals. We welcome Shiau’s visit to Sri Lanka where he has witnessed how valuable USAID’s contribution is to food-insecure communities.” According to the latest WFP surveys, seven out of 10 households are adopting negative coping strategies – such as limiting portion sizes or skipping meals altogether – to deal with high food prices and reduced incomes. The US funding comes at a critical time to help safeguard these communities and prevent them from adopting potentially damaging coping strategies. USAID’s long-time support to WFP and the Government of Sri Lanka includes disaster risk reduction initiatives related to floods and landslides. During his visit, Shiau participated in a live demonstration of a mapping exercise in Moratuwa – an area susceptible to weather-related natural disasters – to understand the process by which authorities use Geographic Information System (GIS) software to identify where the most vulnerable communities may be hardest-hit during an emergency. With support from donors like the US, WFP is rapidly scaling up its emergency operation – which commenced in June – with plans to provide food and nutrition assistance to 3.4 million people. WFP has so far reached over one million people with cash, food and vouchers and through the national school meal programme.

title: CP Facing Shortage of Doctors
author: Author not found
Content: Central Province Governor Lalith U. Gamage said the Province is presently facing a shortage of around 100 qualified doctors. He stated that between 300 and 500 doctors had recently left the country to ply their trade abroad. He bemoaned the fact that certain medical practitioners, who received free education from this country and having qualified in their profession, now tend to cater to the needs of foreigners rather than their own people. Gamage described such doctors as being indebted to their country of birth. He made these comments during an event held at the Rajawella Junior School recently. BY D. Wanniarachchi – Menikhinna

title: Estate youth obtains Degree
author: Author not found
Content: A youth from the Glaxo Tea Estate in Nanu Oya has managed to receive a University Degree, thus proving to all and sundry that if there is a will there is also a way. Sources said that around 600 families continue to dwell at the Glaxo Estate and recently a welcoming ceremony was held for the youth who had obtained his degree from the University of Colombo. He had received his degree for political science and social studies. The 25-year-old youth is Narayanan Punniyaselvan and he had received his initial education from the now defunct Glaxo Tamil MV. However, Punniyaselvan had not shown much inclination towards his studies initially but upon making up his mind to pursue higher studies he had got through the GCE Ordinary Level examination with flying colours. Afterwards, he had followed the arts stream in the Advanced Level class having enrolled with the Navalar Tamil MV and subsequently qualified to enter the Colombo University. Punniyaselvan’s parents are underprivileged but they have taken great pains to provide for his education and he had repaid their faith in him by becoming the first youth from the Glaxo Estate to pursue University studies. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: PM and Indian Envoy hail SLTC link with IIT, Madras
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena and Indian High Commissioner Gopal Baglay jointly witnessed the establishment of partnership linkage between the Sri Lanka Technological Campus (SLTC) Research University and the Indian Institute of Technology – Madras (IITM) in an inclusive partnership for academic, research and resource exchange. During their visit to the SLTC in Padukka, on Wednesday, they joined a zoom meeting between the SLTC Campus and IIT, Madras in which Higher Education State Minister Dr Suren Raghavan and SLTC Chairman Deshamanya Ajith Zoysa, as well as lecturers and students participated, while Founder President/CEO of SLTC Dr Ranjith Rubasinghe welcomed them from Australia, where he is currently on an official visit. The SLTC Research University and the IIT, Madras entered into a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to further their contribution towards education and research along with widening provision for staff and student exchange programmes. The lecturers and students of SLTC demonstrated, to the Prime Minister and the High Commissioner, how they could use the state-of-art technological tools such as cloud application systems for the students to link to four stations simultaneously and interact with lecturers and students and work on their own initiatives. Two students explained their latest project to convert discarded cooking oil into diesel to run motor vehicles. They explained this innovative method could be used commercially and would save at least a small portion of the foreign exchange spent on fuel imports. The academics of SLTC expressed confidence that the partnership with IIT Madras would provide provision for intellectual opportunities for the participants of both countries, enriching research and academic fields. MP Yadamini Gunawardena said the areas of collaboration include finding solutions for traffic management and participation in NASA supported programmes. Dr. Nanda Gunawardane, Director/International Affairs at SLTC, said that the Campus is currently working on a broad programme to train youths with high IT skills for potential employment in Japan. It is expected to enter into an agreement with Japanese industrial groups to ensure employment for Sri Lankan youths skilled in IT and the Japanese Language. “There are over 10,000 employment opportunities available,” he said.

title: Ban on cattle transport lifted
author: Author not found
Content: The ban on transport of cattle and goats, on imposed when many head of cattle died in the North and East, has been lifted with immediate effect, said Director General of the Department of Animal Production and Health, Dr K.  Kothalawala. According to the President’s Media Division (PMD), the ban was lifted after lab tests revealed that the animals died of shock caused by extreme cold weather on 8 and 9 December. She said laboratory tests confirmed that the deaths were not due to an epidemic but due to extreme weather.

title: SCATS delegation meets Aussie HC
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation from the Sri Lankan Study Centre for the Advancement of Technology and Social Welfare, SCATS Australia and SCATS Sri Lanka met Australian High Commissioner Paul Stephens at the Australian High Commission in Colombo and discussed the shared experience between the two countries in economic, technological and social fields. Gamini Perera OAM, the Founder President of SCATS Australia explained the 30-year journey of service and Kanaka Herath, State Minister of Technology and Adviser to SCATS Sri Lanka emphasised the importance of Transferring Technology and innovation through SCATS. The High Commissioner was impressed and highlighted the importance of having strong relationships between the two countries and also exploring ways to assist Sri Lanka in the field of Education, Technology and Economic growth. President of the Sri Lanka branch, Lionel Nawagamuwa and Secretary Dr. P.N. Meegaswatte addressed the meeting and Daya Lankapura, Media Adviser and Upali Liyadapitiya, coordinating Secretary   of the SCATS Sri Lanka, also attended the discussion.

title: Police initiate awareness programme
author: Author not found
Content: Dimbulapatana Police implemented a programme on Wednesday (21) to inspect school bags of children attending schools in Kotagala and nearby upcountry areas to curb the rapid spread of drugs such as ‘Ice’ among children. Besides inspecting schoolbags, Police also initiated a programme to educate students on the pitfalls of the use of drugs and how to prevent them from falling victim to such vices. Police also advised students against carrying ‘unnecessary items’ to school and to inform principals and teachers if any unknown persons attempt to lure them into various vices. BY Chandrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: Bourse enjoys largest NFI after 1,255 Days
author: Author not found
Content: The stock market (bourse) enjoyed its largest net foreign inflow (NFI) in secondary market trading on a single day, after 1,255 days, on Wednesday with a figure of Rs 2.90 billion, bourse’s data showed. A figure higher than this was recorded on 15 July 2019 with a value of Rs 8.72 billion, records showed. Consequently NFIs in secondary market trading hit a new record of Rs 28.5 billion on Wednesday. NFIs were once more led by Expolanka,  the bourse’s largest capitalised stock,  with virtually continuous buying into it by its largest shareholder , the Japanese controlled SG Holdings Ltd.,  with this stock contributing to more than 75 per cent of the day’s turnover with Rs 3.65 billion, on a total turnover of Rs 4.62 billion. Prior to Wednesday, the last time bourse’s daily turnover crossed the four billion-rupee mark was 19 calendar days ago, where on 2 December it made a total turnover of Rs 4.01 billion. Wednesday was also the seventh consecutive market day that the bourse enjoyed NFIs. Prior to Wednesday, the last time the bourse enjoyed NFIs for at least seven consecutive market days was 12 calendar days ago, from 29 November to 9 December, where the bourse enjoyed NFIs for eight consecutive market days.  Nonetheless, scarred by overall uncertainty and almost record high double digit inflation, the bourse fell for the fifth consecutive market day to Wednesday, with the ASPI declining by 1.04 per cent over its Tuesday’s close to finish at 8,420.26 points and the S&P SL 20 Index by 1.51 per cent to 2,653.84 points on a share volume (SV) of 68.44 million on Wednesday. Meanwhile, prior to Wednesday, the last time the bourse fell for at least five consecutive market days was 30 calendar days ago, where for six consecutive market days from  14 November to 21 November, it continuously fell. Further, prior to Wednesday, a lower figure than this the ASPI hit was 22 calendar days ago on 29 November, with a figure of 8,375.21 points. Also, prior to Wednesday, the lowest figure the S&P SL 20 Index fell to was 21 calendar days ago on 29 November, with a figure of 2,640.31 points, respectively. Further, prior to Wednesday, the bourse recorded a lower SV than Wednesday’s was eight calendar days ago on 13 December with a figure of 60.93 million. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
