title: Rs 8,000M ADB Grant for farmer subsidies
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture, Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Mahinda Amaraweera said steps will be taken from this week to provide a subsidy of Rs10,000 to Rs 20,000 to every farmer who cultivates paddy during the 2022 Maha season. The Asian Development Bank has given Rs 8000 million as a non-repayable grant for such purpose. Steps have been taken to provide Rs 10,000 to farmers who have less than one hectare of paddy land and Rs 20,000 to farmers who cultivate up to two hectares. Measures have been taken to transfer the subsidy to the personal accounts of farmers.  Amaraweera said, in the 2021 Maha season, due to the organic fertiliser policy, farmers were involved in agitations rather than in Agricultural endeavours. He added that this resulted in a shortage of rice and the Government had to import rice since January 2021. He said, however there was no need to import rice again due to successful cultivation of  paddy lands.

title: Neighbouring countries ramp up surveillance
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the sudden surge in Covid-19 in China, the Indian Health Ministry held a critical meeting yesterday (21) to step up Covid-19 alert. According to Bloomberg, the number of Covid-19 positive dead arriving at Beijing’s funeral homes and crematoriums is increasing, despite the country not officially reporting a fatality from the virus for two weeks (21). When Ceylon Today inquired about the latest on the Covid-19 situation in China, the Chinese Embassy in Colombo was tight-lipped. In the midst of growing concern about a new outbreak of Covid-19 in China, China’s State TV CGTN noted that the country’s optimised measures to prevent and control Covid-19 are assisting to stabilise the economy. Xiong Yi, Chief China Economist at Deutsche Bank, is optimistic about the Chinese economy in the coming year. He expects the epidemic to peak in January and February, followed by a rebound in economic activity. According to Xiong, China’s economy will likely continue to improve in the second half of next year. According to foreign media, China has reported only a handful of Covid deaths as a wave of Omicron infections sweep the country, raising concerns among public-health experts and relatives of the deceased about accurate accounting for the virus’s impact. However, Chinabriefing.com reported on December 20, 2022 that China recorded 3,101 new  COVID- 19 confirmed cases, of which 52 were imported and 3,049 were locally transmitted (1,171 in Guangdong, 544 in Beijing, 245 in Jiangxi, 204 in Chongqing, 184 in Fujian, 127 in Yunnan, 119 in Hunan, 108 in Shanghai, 86 in Sichuan, 59 in Tianjin, 37 in Zhejiang, 36 in Henan, 32 in Shanxi, 22 in Shaanxi, 17 in Shandong, 16 in Guizhou, 15 in Hebei, 7 in Jiangsu, 6 in Heilongjiang, 5 in Qinghai, 4 in Guangxi, 3 in Inner Mongolia, and 2 in Hainan). No new deaths were recorded, the website added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: 5 students, 3 teachers hospitalised after inhaling toxic smoke
author: Author not found
Content: Pussellawa Police said five students and three teachers of Saraswathi Tamil Maha Vidyalaya in Pussellawa were admitted to the Pussellawa Regional Hospital on 21 December when they were found to have breathing difficulties. According to Police, the students and teachers had inhaled harmful smoke emitted from a bottle with chemicals when it had broken while they were carrying out an experiment. Police added that the students and teachers from the science stream were carrying out an experiment when the bottle with chemicals had fallen and broken resulting in the harmful smoke emanating and being inhaled by the victims. Meanwhile, the principal had taken prompt action to admit the affected students and teachers to hospital while getting the other students out of the way. However, they were pronounced out of danger and transferred to the Gampola Teaching Hospital for further treatment. The Fire Brigade was also summoned to douse the smoke. By Chandrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: Speeding bus kills student
author: Author not found
Content: In an unfortunate turn of events, a 14-year-old boy who was waiting on the roadside to catch a bus to school was knocked down by a speeding bus while injuring a dozen others. Aranayake Police said, the schoolboy succumbed to injuries soon after being rushed to hospital. Another 14 people who sustained injuries were also admitted to hospital. Police said nine of them too were schoolchildren. The accident took place near the Rahala Primary Medical Care Unit (PMCU) on the Rahala-Aranayake road. The victim was identified as a student of Ravisanda Maha Vidyalaya in Ussapitiya. According to initial investigations, the driver of the bus had failed to control the speed resulting in knocking down the boy and another bus coming to a halt crashing into a nearby mango tree. The injured students were admitted to the Aranayake Hospital while the Police are conducting inquiries to determine if the accident had taken place due to negligence on the part of the driver of the bus or due to irregular road development work. BY K.V. Bandara – Mawanella

title: Children’s homes will be monitored – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe said all children’s homes in the country will be monitored going forward to ensure the safety of children. As of late, scores of complaints had been lodged with the Ministry regarding ill treatment and abuse at children’s homes. Thus, monitoring of such places will begin, she said. Kumarasinghe said, existing laws will also be amended to further protect children in the country from being abused or ill treated at these institutions. She said this during a meeting held at the Kandy Divisional Secretariat yesterday (21). By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Doctors to petition President
author: Author not found
Content: With grade medical officers having to pay two months’ salary as taxes following the enactment of the Inland Revenue Act, doctors are set to petition President Ranil Wickremesinghe, urging him to amend the new Act before it is enacted on 1 January 2023. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam lamented that doctors will have to pay two months’ salary as taxes if measures were not taken to introduce the proposed amendments. Accordingly, they will only receive 10 months wages. He said, a serious disparity in pay between grades due to the unusually high tax percentage gap between the highest and the lowest wages in the same service will only disrupt the existing National Wage Policy. Dr. Ratnasingam observed that the more serious point is that in a backdrop where salaries had not been increased in the public service to match the price inflation, the purchasing power in the State service will continue to reduce. The Union proposed therefore to raise the levy from Rs 1.2 million to Rs 2.4 million, and increase the annual tax slabs from Rs 500,000 to Rs 600,000. They also proposed a revision to the tax rates ranging from the six per cent to 36 per cent to four per cent to 24 per cent. The Media Committee member said doctors had also proposed that the Disturbance, Availability and Transport (DAT) and all other allowances they received be exempted from taxation. He said, the petition also proposed that a maximum limit on percentage of tax levied for professionals following the framework be introduced and not to compare them with profit-making businesses. Dr. Ratnasingam said his outfit had discussed the issue facing all professional categories, with several other professional trade unions including Federation of University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA), CEB Unions Registered Medical Officers Union etc. and were prepared to collaborate with all professionals affected by the unfairness of the Act.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: BOC executes first INR transaction with India
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka recently introduced Indian Rupee (INR) as a designated foreign currency to promote trade and tourism in the SAARC region. This enables Sri Lankan residents to carry out trade transactions in INR. The scope of India and Sri Lanka’s healthy economic and commercial partnership will reach new heights by executing the trade transactions directly in INR, which will immensely help exporters and importers in both countries. Bank of Ceylon has completed all necessary requirements to include INR as a designated currency and is now able to arrange bilateral transactions with India and assist its customers in transactions including exports, imports, and remittances while reducing the dependence on US dollars. The first INR transaction with India was executed by General Manager K.E.D. Sumanasiri, Deputy General Manager (International, Treasury & Investment) R.M.N. Jeewantha and Assistant General Manager (Treasury) A.W.R. Thushantha, yesterday (21).

title: Power Minister Vs CEB Engineers: Standoff Intensifies
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera issued a red alert to the Chairman of the Ceylon Electricity Board Engineers’ Union (CEBEU) for allegedly making “false and irrational statements” about the Norochcholai Power Plant and electricity generation in 2023. He said he will not allow trade unionists to act as “terrorists.” Referring to reports that Norochcholai coal reserves will be depleted by the end of December and daily power outages will exceed 10 hours, he said legal action will be taken against whoever made this statement, regardless of whether he is a trade union leader, officer, or labourer. Wijesekera said he is consulting legal advisers on how to take action against these individuals. Speaking to the media yesterday (21) at the Ministry of Power and Energy, Wijesekera referred to the CEBEU as a trade union that is working towards its own political agendas rather than the public’s interest and said it is attempting to instil fear in the public. “I have given directives to take necessary action against the CEBEU Chairman, who claimed that the National Grid will lose electricity in the coming days due to issues in coal procurement,” Wijesekera said. He denied the CEBEU’s claims about Norochcholai Power Plant and questioned the Engineer’s credentials. Further, he said the Power and Energy Secretary, as well as the Attorney General, will take action against individuals making false statements. By Thameenah Razeek

title: ‘No protests near Senate building’
author: Author not found
Content: Acting Vice-Chancellor of the University of Peradeniya yesterday (21) warned undergraduates that the administration will be compelled to take stern action against organisers and participants of the protest intended to be held opposite the Senate. Issuing a notice, the Acting Vice-Chancellor stated that it is reliably learnt that some undergrads intend to hold a protest opposite the Senate and that no one is permitted to hold protests in the vicinity of the Senate building.  “In the event of staging a protest in the Senate’s vicinity, the university is compelled to take punitive action against the organisers and participants,” the notice stated. The acting Vice-Chancellor added that it has been observed that over the recent past, certain student groups behaved in an unruly manner opposite the Senate building. “It should be borne in mind that the Senate is a sacred and iconic place and considered the heart of the University of Peradeniya,”the VC said. “The central administration operates within the Senate, where more than 200 university employees work, day and night to facilitate the smooth functioning of nine faculties and a multitude of centres and units. Shouting slogans, displaying banners, placards, and cutouts, and playing music during working hours undoubtedly interrupts the regular functions of the Senate,” the VC further said. (AK)

title: Electricity tariff hike inevitable in Jan – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Electricity tariffs will undoubtedly be revised in January 2023, with a detailed report due at the first Cabinet meeting of the year, scheduled for 2 January 2023, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said. He said the maximum electricity tariff hike will be Rs 56.90. However, the Minister expects to cut unnecessary expenses of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) staff in the coming year and to utilise the majority of CEB’s profits for electricity generation, whether that means cutting bonuses or anything else. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 5 students, 3 teachers hospitalised after inhaling toxic smoke
author: Author not found
Content: Pussellawa Police said five students and three teachers of Saraswathi Tamil Maha Vidyalaya in Pussellawa were admitted to the Pussellawa Regional Hospital on 21 December when they were found to have breathing difficulties. According to Police, the students and teachers had inhaled harmful smoke emitted from a bottle with chemicals when it had broken while they were carrying out an experiment. Police added that the students and teachers from the science stream were carrying out an experiment when the bottle with chemicals had fallen and broken resulting in the harmful smoke emanating and being inhaled by the victims. Meanwhile, the principal had taken prompt action to admit the affected students and teachers to hospital while getting the other students out of the way. However, they were pronounced out of danger and transferred to the Gampola Teaching Hospital for further treatment. The Fire Brigade was also summoned to douse the smoke. By Chandrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: Speeding bus kills student
author: Author not found
Content: In an unfortunate turn of events, a 14-year-old boy who was waiting on the roadside to catch a bus to school was knocked down by a speeding bus while injuring a dozen others. Aranayake Police said, the schoolboy succumbed to injuries soon after being rushed to hospital. Another 14 people who sustained injuries were also admitted to hospital. Police said nine of them too were schoolchildren. The accident took place near the Rahala Primary Medical Care Unit (PMCU) on the Rahala-Aranayake road. The victim was identified as a student of Ravisanda Maha Vidyalaya in Ussapitiya. According to initial investigations, the driver of the bus had failed to control the speed resulting in knocking down the boy and another bus coming to a halt crashing into a nearby mango tree. The injured students were admitted to the Aranayake Hospital while the Police are conducting inquiries to determine if the accident had taken place due to negligence on the part of the driver of the bus or due to irregular road development work. BY K.V. Bandara – Mawanella

title: Children’s homes will be monitored – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe said all children’s homes in the country will be monitored going forward to ensure the safety of children. As of late, scores of complaints had been lodged with the Ministry regarding ill treatment and abuse at children’s homes. Thus, monitoring of such places will begin, she said. Kumarasinghe said, existing laws will also be amended to further protect children in the country from being abused or ill treated at these institutions. She said this during a meeting held at the Kandy Divisional Secretariat yesterday (21). By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Doctors to petition President
author: Author not found
Content: With grade medical officers having to pay two months’ salary as taxes following the enactment of the Inland Revenue Act, doctors are set to petition President Ranil Wickremesinghe, urging him to amend the new Act before it is enacted on 1 January 2023. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam lamented that doctors will have to pay two months’ salary as taxes if measures were not taken to introduce the proposed amendments. Accordingly, they will only receive 10 months wages. He said, a serious disparity in pay between grades due to the unusually high tax percentage gap between the highest and the lowest wages in the same service will only disrupt the existing National Wage Policy. Dr. Ratnasingam observed that the more serious point is that in a backdrop where salaries had not been increased in the public service to match the price inflation, the purchasing power in the State service will continue to reduce. The Union proposed therefore to raise the levy from Rs 1.2 million to Rs 2.4 million, and increase the annual tax slabs from Rs 500,000 to Rs 600,000. They also proposed a revision to the tax rates ranging from the six per cent to 36 per cent to four per cent to 24 per cent. The Media Committee member said doctors had also proposed that the Disturbance, Availability and Transport (DAT) and all other allowances they received be exempted from taxation. He said, the petition also proposed that a maximum limit on percentage of tax levied for professionals following the framework be introduced and not to compare them with profit-making businesses. Dr. Ratnasingam said his outfit had discussed the issue facing all professional categories, with several other professional trade unions including Federation of University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA), CEB Unions Registered Medical Officers Union etc. and were prepared to collaborate with all professionals affected by the unfairness of the Act.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Nepal-SL dialogue held in Kathmandu
author: Author not found
Content: A dialogue titled ‘Nepal-Sri Lanka Friendship: From Ancient Links to the Present’ was held in Kathmandu on 19 December to celebrate the 65th anniversary of diplomatic relations, organised by the Embassy of Sri Lanka in collaboration with the Nepal Council of World Affairs (NCWA). Nepal’s Foreign Minister Narayan Khadka was the Chief Guest. Minister Khadka spoke of recent high-level political engagements including his visit to Sri Lanka in March for the BIMSTEC Ministerial Meeting. He also emphasised the importance of elevating trade relations with the participation of both public and private sectors. Minister of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka Ali Sabry issued a special message through video link and referred to the ancient links dating back to the time of Gautama Buddha. He referred to Lumbini as the umbilical cord that binds Sri Lanka and Nepal. He said the core strength of Sri Lanka – Nepal friendship is the unwavering willingness of the two countries to help each other at times of distress. Former Foreign Secretary of Nepal and Ambassador to Sri Lanka from 2005-2009 Durga Prasad Bhattarai delivered the keynote speech from Nepal and highlighted the ancient links both recorded and unrecorded, and how they contributed to improving relations notably through Buddhism and the Ramayana. He also spoke about the legal foundations laid through bilateral legal instruments to promote economic cooperation, notably through a Joint Commission and air services agreement. The re-establishment of air connectivity in 2021 was welcomed as an important initiative to advance trade and tourism. From Sri Lanka, former Secretary General of BIMSTEC and Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Nepal from 2009-2012, Sumith Nakandala delivered the keynote address via video link. He highlighted the importance of building momentum on trade and investment and the role for Sri Lanka to support Lumbini’s development as a centre of peace. He further stressed on potential opportunities to be explored collaboratively in the context of regional connectivity, focusing in particular on BIMSTEC as a useful platform that can help economic relations in a constructive manner. President of NCWA Hemantha Kharel and Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Nepal Himalee Arunatilaka also addressed the gathering. The event was attended by diplomats, Government officials, former Ambassadors, scholars, entrepreneurs, and Nepali dignitaries who have contributed to the enhancement of bilateral ties between the two countries.

title: Canadian Tamil Congress donates Rs 10M worth medicine to Tellipalai Cancer Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: Canadian Tamils donated Rs 10 million worth of life saving medicines to Tellipalai Trail Cancer Hospital using the funds allocated from their annual walk-a-thon held in Canada. The 14th annual Tamil Canadian Walk-a-thon raised funds to provide life-saving medical supplies to six hospitals in Sri Lanka this year. On 20 December, the Canadian Tamil Congress delivered the first shipment of medicine supplies to the Tellipalai Trail Cancer Hospital. Every year, the Canadian Tamil Congress (CTC) sponsors the Tamil Canadian Walk-a-thon. In the past, the Sick Kids Foundation, the Canadian Cancer Society, the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH), and Holland Bloorview Kids Hospital have all benefited from the walk-a-thon. As Sri Lanka continues to suffer from its worst financial crisis, hospitals are running out of life-saving medications. Hospitals and health professionals all over the island are still pleading for donations to purchase basic life-saving medical supplies. Cancer hospitals, such as Thellipalai Hospital, struggle to keep essential medicines on hand in order to provide uninterrupted patient care. Former Board director of the Canadian Tamil Congress,   Sivam Velupillai, Founder of Sivapoomi Trust, Dr. Aru Thirumurugan, Regional Director of Health Services (RDHS) for Jaffna, Dr. A. Ketheeswaran, Dean of Medical faculty at the University of Jaffna, Dr. R. Surenthirakumaran, Secretary for Tellipalai Trail Cancer Hospital Patients Welfare Society C. Hariharan, doctors, nurses and staff participated at this medicines handover ceremony. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Parking spaces reserved for public near Lotus Tower
author: Author not found
Content: Vehicle parking spaces have been reserved for the public who will participate in programmes around the Lotus Tower, organised by the Ministry of Tourism and Lands, in light of promoting tourism, from 19 to 28 December, Police said. Accordingly, vehicles can be parked in the parking lot in front of Lake House, Captain’s Garden temple parking lot and in vehicle parking spaces on the either side of the road from D.R. Wijewardena Road, Gamini Hall roundabout to the Regal Cinema. Police also said that vehicle parking spaces have been reserved for the public who will be participating in programmes at the President Secretial and Galle Face from 19 to 31 December. Accordingly, those vehicles can be parked in the MOD parking lot, Galle Face, Galle Road parking lot and in the parking lot in Nawa Baladaksha Mawatha. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Faxian Charity project to help needy Buddhist temples
author: Author not found
Content: The Buddhist Association of China with the participation the Guangji Temple and Lingguang Temple in Beijing, Cuangxiao Temple in Guangzhou, Hongfa Temple in Shenzhen, Putuo Temple in Zhuhai, Dafo Temple in Guangzhou and Anfu Temple in Wenzhou have collected nearly USD one million with contributions from Buddhist devotes to assist needy Buddhist Temples in Sri Lanka under the ‘Faxian charity project’. The Buddhist Association of China has made arrangements to donate 50,000 dry ration boxes to needy Buddhist Temples in Sri Lanka. The Sri Lanka China Buddhist Friendship Association with the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in Sri Lanka and Ven. Dr Kallanchiye Rathnasiri Thera, Chief Incumbent of Abhayagiri Raja Maha Viharaya will launch the Faxian Charity Project on 27 December 2022 at the historical Abhayagiri Raja Maha Viharaya in Anuradhapura. Sri Lanka – China Buddhist relations date back to over 1,600 years and Ven.Faxian Thera lived and studied Buddhism in the 4th Century at the historical Abhayagiriya Temple and took Buddhist text books to China. In 429 CE, Bhikkuni Dewasara led a delegation to China with a sapling of the Bo Tree and established the Bhikkuni Order in China.

title: Indonesian Embassy donates dry rrations to needy
author: Author not found
Content: Indonesian Ambassador to Sri Lanka Dewi Gustina Tobing handed over packages consisting of various types of dry rations to some Sri Lankan families, in need in this difficult time of the present economic crisis, on 19 December at the Indonesian Embassy in Colombo.  This is part of a series of distribution of charity packages since 17 August 2022, after the flag-hoisting ceremony commemorating the 77th Indonesian Independence Day, which continued in October, November and December 2022, for communities of Buddhist, Hindu, Christian, and Islam in some areas in Colombo and its suburbs, Hambantota, Hatton and Maskeliya, and witnessed by respective religious leaders.   The charity packages, in total 529 packages of dry rations, worth Rs 2.9 million, were obtained from the Indonesian community inSri Lanka, the Maldives, and Western Australia The series of Charity Programmes was organized by The Embassy of the Republic of Indonesia in Colombo in collaboration with Sri Lanka – Indonesian Friendship Association (SLIFA). It has symbolised the solidarity and friendship between both countries and also commemorated two milestone events which are the 70th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Indonesia and Sri Lanka and the 30th Anniversary of SLIFA.

title: Jaffna MC’s 2023 budget defeated: EPDP walks out
author: Author not found
Content: The Jaffna Municipal Council’s budget for 2023 presented by Jaffna Mayor,  Viswalingam Manivannan yesterday (21) was defeated by 18 votes, with 11 votes in favour.  Eelam People’s Democratic Party (EPDP) walked out and did not participate at the vote. Notably, 16 members of the 45-member Jaffna Municipal Council are affiliated with the IIankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK), 13 with the All Ceylon Tamil Congress, 10 with the EPDP, three with the UNP, and one with the Tamil United Liberation Front. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: To uplift hospitality education and bridge skills gap
author: Author not found
Content: To uplift the hospitality education sector in Sri Lanka, the Swiss Hospitality & Management Academy (SHMA) of A. Baur & Co. Pvt Ltd. also known as Baurs, a leading conglomerate with diversified business interests, recently set up a private and public sector partnership with the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC). The official signing was held on 8 December 2022, at the Embassy of Switzerland in Colombo. The contract exchange took place between Baurs MD and CEO Rolf Blaser and Dr. D. Furgler, Swiss Ambassador to Sri Lanka and Maldives. The Skills for Sustainable Growth (SSG) initiative came about during the height of the pandemic and has seen tremendous participation from both Baurs and SDC. At a time when the hospitality and tourism industry came to a standstill with increasing talent migration, Rolf Blaser discovered the Switzerland-based RIESCO programme and quickly felt fervent of it being a practical and immediate solution in addressing the widening skills gap.  During end last year, officials from Baurs held a briefing with the Swiss Ambassador and introduced SHMA and the various solutions from an educational standpoint. With further discussions earlier this year, Baurs proposed a collaboration opportunity with SDC to localize and implement the RIESCO programme in the country. Bringing Switzerland’s distinctive reputation and quality standards in hospitality education which is one of the best in the world to Sri Lanka is a timely and ideal solution to the country’s tourism and hospitality sector, where hundreds of thousands of livelihoods depend upon, in the backdrop of various ongoing challenges, and eventually contribute immensely to the overall economy, ensuring that a quality pool of talented and employable professionals are created especially among the youth in the rural areas. This will with no doubt minimise the industry’s skills gap, take off the burden on the state, and go on to uplifting the country as a whole Designed by Hotel & Gastro Formation, the RIESCO programme is aimed at migrants entering Switzerland, who are heavily reliant on state welfare system. The programme methodology and content ensure that one completes the programme in the shortest possible time and acquires the necessary skills that are highly employable, translating them into active participants in the hospitality sector and economy. SHMA plans to sustain this programme through advanced digitalisation platform, working with both the public and private sector. Coming under the SSG initiative, this will bring about immense benefits to the learners and country as a whole, in contrast to lengthy and conventional hospitality education programmes in Sri Lanka. By aligning and implementing a Swiss Vocational Skills Development (VSD) curriculum in hospitality management, SHMA will enhance local curriculums throughout the numerous learning centres island-wide. Through its train the trainer programmes, SHMA will go onto further strengthen impactful teaching methodologies. The SSG programme aims to create 2,240 skilled young men and women within three years, with the first batch of student intake of 240 scheduled to take place during July 2023, followed by training 800 students in 2024 and 1,200 students in 2025, including increasing female representation to 40pct from the current industry levels exhibiting below 10pct. This will cover core hospitality operations and soft skills development including hospitality English, grooming and etiquette, and basic IT skills. The Districts will include Jaffna, Trincomalee, Ampara, Puttalam, Kurunegala, Kandy, Badulla, Nuwara Eliya, Moneragala, Ratnapura, Batticaloa, Anuradhapura, Hambantota among others, with a drive to also identify potential learning centres within the districts. The certificate programme runs for nine months, with the first six months comprising  70 per cent practical classroom learning and 30 per cent theoretical knowledge, and thereafter take up a three month internship with possible extension to six months. Baurs has already partnered with many hotels in facilitating these internships, with more joining onboard. The programme will pursue a hybrid teaching model where a SHMA faculty member will be placed at each learning centre for six months upon implementation, ensuring that it’s well absorbed and in line with the standards and frameworks of the learning curriculum. The SSG programme will play a key role in minimising the skills gap and enhancing the quality of education through increased female participation, competent talent pool, quality standards in par with global trends, and making Sri Lanka among the best tourist destinations. The inclusion of females and returning workers is a main SDGs of this project, to increase equal employment opportunities and ensure correct and safe employment channels and migration paths. The SSG hospitality certificate provides a stepping stone towards enrolling for Professional Diploma programmes facilitated by SHMA and awarded by École hôtelière de Lausanne EHL, world’s number one hotel management school. SHMA provides world class education through its VET by EHL Professional Diploma programme, available in Culinary, Food and Beverage and Hotel Operations, with the next intake taking place in February and March 2023.

title: Increasing taxes vital – President
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has no other option other than to increase taxes to face the current situation in the country, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said. The President was speaking at the 21st ‘Achiever Awards 2022’ organised by the Ceylon National Chamber of Industries (CNCI) in collaboration with the Ministry of Industries, held at Hotel Galadari, Colombo, on Tuesday (20). Wickremesinghe said an environment will be created for small and medium-scale industrialists to become successful using modern technology and the Government was ready to empower industrialists as the main stakeholders in earning foreign exchange for Sri Lanka. The President pointed out that instead of looking at the fallen economy and regretting it, everyone should work together to create an environment for a prosperous future. He said Japan and Germany, which were destroyed by World Wars provide ample testimony of how to rebuild the country and the economy. The President added that the industrialists have a great responsibility to rebuild the fallen economy. “Industrialists are a group of people who contributed immensely to the economy,” he said. “We have no option but to increase taxes, but I am confident that we can pull through and we will pull through. We have gone through this earlier. You ran through wars. We have gone through the worst of what has happened this year. We have to pull through and that is where we have to look at all of you. Because we have to preserve what is left. We still have issues. Nevertheless, the Government’s aim is to revive and help as many businesses as possible. Many businesses must survive,” the President added. “The Government focuses on Small and Medium enterprises with economic difficulties, as without these enterprises no one can survive. The Government is going through a series of exercises to correct the economy and uplift small and medium-scale enterprises. Modern technology can be used for that. We should look at the development of small and medium-scale industries in other countries and use modern technology to develop these industries. We are ready to provide all the support we can as a government for that,” he said. The President queried from industrialists as to whether they would like to strengthen the economy with new innovations to win the international market or to remain with the same old methods. He further said with new technology and new innovations, industrialists have a good chance of becoming economically stronger to conquer the world. “For that, we need a change in attitude”, he said. At present the country needs foreign exchange, with increasing foreign exchange, the economy will be strengthened. This enables the Government to allocate more financial assistance to the education and health sectors and to solve problems that have arisen in the field of education and health. The President presented awards to top 10 achievers. The Vice Chancellor of the Jayewardenepura University, Prof. Sudanta Liyanage, Secretary to the Ministry of Industries Thilaka Jayasundara, CNCI Chairman Canisius Fernando and several others participated.

title: 68-year-old stranded in hospital
author: Author not found
Content: A doctor attached to the psychiatric ward at the Kegalla Hospital has informed Dewalagama Police urging them to intervene to take measures to transfer an elderly woman to an elders’ home. The doctor requested Police to produce submissions to Court in this regard. It is said that the 68-year-old’s relatives had failed to take her home from hospital upon her having recovered from her illness for the past four months. She was admitted due to a psycho-social disability. Police said according to  inquiries it was revealed that her only child and relatives  admitted her to hospital on 22 August this year. But following treatment the woman recovered but the doctor in charge of the ward stated that neither her child nor her relatives visited the hospital to get her discharge or even to look into her well-being. Hence the doctor has informed Police to make submissions in Court or to take action to provide her with lodging at an elders’ home as it is difficult to care for her at the hospital for want of adequate space and facilities. BY Chaminda Jayalath – Damunupola

title: CEB makes Rs 574M generation profit on Tuesday
author: Author not found
Content: State-owned Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), boosted by a 75 per cent increase in electricity rates, made a generation profit of Rs 574.25 million on Tuesday, CEB data from yesterday (21) showed. Electricity rates were increased by 75 per cent on 9 August by the Government of Sri Lanka. CEB data also showed that Sri Lanka consumed a total of 37.54 GWh of electricity on Tuesday (20). Average tariff rate of Rs 16.37 per kWh where the above calculations are based on, are as per Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, which is the latest of such data available in the public domain. An 8.72 per cent transmission and distribution loss as per last year’s cost estimates as estimated by the CEB is also taken into consideration in the above computation. Meanwhile, the breakdown of the 37.54 GWh of electricity generated on Tuesday comprised 15.89 GWh of CEB coal, 11.91 GWh of CEB hydroelectricity, 3.6 GWh from CEB fuel oil, 3.09 GWh from renewable energy (RE) other than CEB Hydroelectricity and the balance from independent power producers’ (IPP’)/ private sector fuel oil (3.05 GWh), respectively. According to the CBSL, the cheapest electricity generation cost to the CEB last year was CEB hydroelectricity at Rs 1.67 a unit of electricity (1 kWh of electricity), followed by CEB coal (Rs 10.68), ‘other RE’ (Rs 16.22), IPP fuel oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB fuel oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. The main driver of CEB Hydroelectricity is the Mahaweli which generated 7.82 GWh of electricity and which contributed to 20.83 per cent of total electricity generation of Tuesday. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Wild animals damage crops
author: Author not found
Content: As a result of the failure of the authorities to grant approval to cultivate the Ihala Yatawara, Madawela Yaya in the Kandy District, various crops that had been cultivated have been damaged by wild animals, farmers alleged. These areas come under the purview of the Wattegama Govijana Seva of the Pathadumbara Divisional Secretariat. They stated that repeated requests made to officials to carry out cultivation work in the paddy fields had fallen on deaf ears. BY S. N. Wiimalasiri – Wattegama

title: Inflation decreases to 65% YoY
author: Author not found
Content: Countrywide inflation decelerated for the second consecutive month last month, decelerating to 65 per cent, from 70.6 per cent reported in October, Census and Statistics Department (CSD) data released yesterday (21) showed. This deceleration was aided by food inflation also decelerating for the second consecutive month to last month to 69.8 per cent, from 80.9 per cent reported in October and non-food inflation also decelerating for the second consecutive month to last month, decelerating to 60.4 per cent, from 61.8 per cent reported in October. Nonetheless, a family’s living expenses have increased by Rs 32,438.62, compared to a mere Rs 2,735.43 increase a year ago. The drivers of inflation were the food bill of a family rising by Rs 16,944.41, compared to an increase of a mere Rs 2,406.66 a year ago and the cost of non-food items increasing by Rs 15,594.22, compared to a mere Rs 328.77 increase a year ago. The top seven YoY boost given to food inflation last month were led by a family’s rice budget increasing by Rs 2,900.80 Year-on-Year (YoY), milk powder (Rs 1,902.28), vegetable bill (Rs 1,302.81), fresh fish (Rs 1,053.37), bread (Rs 829.62), chicken (Rs 671.94) and dried fish (Rs 623.74). Meanwhile, the top nine non-food inflationary leaders eating into a family’s overall budget last month were the YoY increase in their household maintenance material costs (Rs 1,496.49), bus fare (Rs 1,158.14), petrol bill by Rs 1,086.98, health (Rs 1,082.33), clothing and footwear (Rs 1,009.79), toilet soap (Rs 855.67), alcohol, tobacco and narcotics (Rs 838.11), maintenance cost of housing materials and purchase of the same (Rs 819.24) and electricity bill (Rs 765.15). The YoY increase in a family’s living expenses has been over Rs 30,000 for a record five months to last month, beginning with July 2022. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Noted criminal involved in spate of thefts arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Western Province South Crimes Division arrested a suspect for stealing household items worth Rs 30 million having ransacked 11 houses during a 12-month period. Police said the suspect was a noted criminal. They added that following interrogation they recovered items such as wrist watches, electrical appliances, laptops, mobile phones, furniture, and small gemstones. Police said the suspect had stolen items worth Rs 20 million from a house owned by a millionaire businessman in Thalawathugoda. Police stated that these thefts had been carried out in and around areas such as Thalawathugoda, Malabe and Hokandara. According to Police, the suspect who is aged 37 and a resident of Indigolla, Gampaha had been released last year after serving a five-year prison term over his involvement with a spate of similar thefts previously. BY Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Commemorative stamp to mark Milad un-Nabi 2022
author: Author not found
Content: A ceremony to issue a commemorative stamp for Milad un-Nabi 2022 was held at the Postal Headquarters Auditorium, organised by the Department of Muslim Religious and Cultural Affairs and the Postal Department. The event was chaired by Ibrahim Anzar, Director of the Department of Muslim Religious And Cultural Affairs. Foreign Minister Ali Sabry was the Chief Guest. Guests of Honour included Minister Naseer Ahamed, Postmaster General Ranjith Ariyaratne, and State Minister of Mass Media Shantha Bandara. By Ashraff A. Samad

title: Nepal-SL dialogue held in Kathmandu
author: Author not found
Content: A dialogue titled ‘Nepal-Sri Lanka Friendship: From Ancient Links to the Present’ was held in Kathmandu on 19 December to celebrate the 65th anniversary of diplomatic relations, organised by the Embassy of Sri Lanka in collaboration with the Nepal Council of World Affairs (NCWA). Nepal’s Foreign Minister Narayan Khadka was the Chief Guest. Minister Khadka spoke of recent high-level political engagements including his visit to Sri Lanka in March for the BIMSTEC Ministerial Meeting. He also emphasised the importance of elevating trade relations with the participation of both public and private sectors. Minister of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka Ali Sabry issued a special message through video link and referred to the ancient links dating back to the time of Gautama Buddha. He referred to Lumbini as the umbilical cord that binds Sri Lanka and Nepal. He said the core strength of Sri Lanka – Nepal friendship is the unwavering willingness of the two countries to help each other at times of distress. Former Foreign Secretary of Nepal and Ambassador to Sri Lanka from 2005-2009 Durga Prasad Bhattarai delivered the keynote speech from Nepal and highlighted the ancient links both recorded and unrecorded, and how they contributed to improving relations notably through Buddhism and the Ramayana. He also spoke about the legal foundations laid through bilateral legal instruments to promote economic cooperation, notably through a Joint Commission and air services agreement. The re-establishment of air connectivity in 2021 was welcomed as an important initiative to advance trade and tourism. From Sri Lanka, former Secretary General of BIMSTEC and Sri Lanka’s Ambassador to Nepal from 2009-2012, Sumith Nakandala delivered the keynote address via video link. He highlighted the importance of building momentum on trade and investment and the role for Sri Lanka to support Lumbini’s development as a centre of peace. He further stressed on potential opportunities to be explored collaboratively in the context of regional connectivity, focusing in particular on BIMSTEC as a useful platform that can help economic relations in a constructive manner. President of NCWA Hemantha Kharel and Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Nepal Himalee Arunatilaka also addressed the gathering. The event was attended by diplomats, Government officials, former Ambassadors, scholars, entrepreneurs, and Nepali dignitaries who have contributed to the enhancement of bilateral ties between the two countries.

title: Canadian Tamil Congress donates Rs 10M worth medicine to Tellipalai Cancer Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: Canadian Tamils donated Rs 10 million worth of life saving medicines to Tellipalai Trail Cancer Hospital using the funds allocated from their annual walk-a-thon held in Canada. The 14th annual Tamil Canadian Walk-a-thon raised funds to provide life-saving medical supplies to six hospitals in Sri Lanka this year. On 20 December, the Canadian Tamil Congress delivered the first shipment of medicine supplies to the Tellipalai Trail Cancer Hospital. Every year, the Canadian Tamil Congress (CTC) sponsors the Tamil Canadian Walk-a-thon. In the past, the Sick Kids Foundation, the Canadian Cancer Society, the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH), and Holland Bloorview Kids Hospital have all benefited from the walk-a-thon. As Sri Lanka continues to suffer from its worst financial crisis, hospitals are running out of life-saving medications. Hospitals and health professionals all over the island are still pleading for donations to purchase basic life-saving medical supplies. Cancer hospitals, such as Thellipalai Hospital, struggle to keep essential medicines on hand in order to provide uninterrupted patient care. Former Board director of the Canadian Tamil Congress,   Sivam Velupillai, Founder of Sivapoomi Trust, Dr. Aru Thirumurugan, Regional Director of Health Services (RDHS) for Jaffna, Dr. A. Ketheeswaran, Dean of Medical faculty at the University of Jaffna, Dr. R. Surenthirakumaran, Secretary for Tellipalai Trail Cancer Hospital Patients Welfare Society C. Hariharan, doctors, nurses and staff participated at this medicines handover ceremony. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Norochcholai coal reserves only till end December
author: Author not found
Content: The coal reserves in the Norochcholai Coal Power Plant will run out completely at the end of December 2022, due to which the current daily power cuts could extend to over 10 hours in the New Year, the Ceylon Electricity Board Engineers’ Union (CEBEU) warned. CEBEU Chairman Nihal Weeraratne said although shipments of coal are due to arrive in the country in January, it will take at least five to six days to unload each shipment due to which only a limited number of consignments could be facilitated. He added, thereby arrangements should be made in consideration of the time to unload the coal consignment in order to ensure the smooth operation of the power plant. Weeraratne added that while over 38 shipments of 60,000 MT of coal is required for the operation of the power plant from September 2022 to April 2023, only five shipments have arrived. CEBEU previously warned that if all 38 shipments fail to arrive in the country by April, there could be a massive power outage by July, August or September 2023. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Police ordered to obtain phone data
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawela yesterday (20) ordered the Borella Police to obtain the data related to four mobile phones, in connection with the on-going probe into the murder of Janashakthi PLC Director Dinesh Schaffter and submit a report to Court. The Additional Magistrate gave his order, having considered submissions made by Borella Police. The Police added they have so far recorded statements from the victim’s spouse, as well as from two employees, from the firm owned by the deceased. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Nine Lankans arrested in Tamil Nadu
author: Author not found
Content: The National Investigation Agency (NIA) has arrested nine Sri Lankan nationals from the special camp for Tamil refugees at Tiruchirappalli for their alleged involvement in smuggling of drugs and arms to revive the activities of LTTE. Those arrested have been identified as C. Gunashekharan alias Guna, a resident of Colombo, who was key person in the alleged LTTE revival conspiracy in association with Pakistani national Haji Salim, Pushparajah alias Pookutti Kanna, Mohammad Asmin, Alahapperumaga Sunil Ghamini Fonseaa, Stanly Kennady Fernando, Ladiya Chandrasena, Dhanukka Roshan, Vella Suranka and Thilipan. “The case pertains to activities of a Sri Lankan drug mafia controlled by C. Gunashekharan and Guna and Pushparajah alias Pookutti Kanna, in association with Haji Salim, drug and arms supplier based in Pakistan, which has been operating in India and Sri Lanka in illegal drugs and arms for the revival of LTTE in India and Sri Lanka,” the NIA said in a statement. Haji Salim, according to a counter-terrorism official in Delhi, “runs one of the biggest networks of smuggling drugs and arms from Pakistan to Sri Lanka.” The agency did not describe the role of other arrested persons in the case. The federal anti-terror probe agency has registered at least four cases since last year to probe conspiracy by several LTTE cadres based in India and Sri Lanka to revive the activities of the banned outfit by indulging in arms smuggling, ferrying of drugs and using hawala for transfer of funds. Earlier, NIA charged some active LTTE cadres including a Sri Lankan woman Letchumanan Mary Franciska and five others for forging documents to use a bank account so that, LTTE’s activities can be funded. While filing a charge sheet against them on 29 March this year, the NIA said – “Mary Franciska, T. Kenniston Fernando and K. Baskaran entered into a conspiracy with foreign entities to siphon off deposits in dormant bank accounts by using Indian identity documents obtained fraudulently and forging identity documents to revive, revamp and regroup LTTE in India and Sri Lanka. They were abetted by Johnson Samuvel, Dharmendran and Mohan in forging Indian identity documents.” In October last year, a former intelligence officer of LTTE – Satkunam alias Sabesan was arrested in a probe into seizure of five AK-47 rifles, thousands of rounds of 9 mm ammunition and 300 kg of heroin from fishing vessel Ravihansi, which was intercepted by the Coast Guard off the coast of Minicoy in Lakshadweep on 18 March 2021. “Sebastian played a crucial role in routing the proceeds of drugs trafficking to former LTTE cadres in Sri Lanka for the revival of LTTE,” the agency said in a statement in October 2021. (The Hindustan Times)

title: Kanjipani Imran granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawela yesterday (20) released on bail illegal drug trafficker and underworld kingpin Mohammad Najim Imran alias Kanjipani Imran. Imran was ordered to furnish personal bail in five million rupees, in relation to a lawsuit filed before the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court. In the lawsuit, Kanjipani Imran has been charged with issuing a death threat via the phone, to an officer attached to the Keselwatta Police Station, during the course of an official probe. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: A’pura-Vavuniya rail line to close for five months
author: Author not found
Content: The Anuradhapura-Vavuniya stretch of the Northern railway line will remain closed for five months from 5 January 2023, the Department of Railways announced yesterday (20). Accordingly, the train schedule on the Anuradhapura-Vavuniya line has been revised and a new time table has been issued. Bus services will be provided to the respective destinations based on the arrival and departure times of trains at Anuradhapura and Vavuniya. In addition, the Yalrani train, which runs from Kankesanthurai to Mukkandi, will also run to Vavuniya within the above-mentioned time limit.  (TR)

title: Task Force on narcotics comes into effect from 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Presidential Task Force to prevent the use of toxic and dangerous drugs will start functioning from 2023. A special programme to prevent the use of toxic and dangerous drugs, by integrating all the agencies involved in drug prevention, is to be implemented under this task force. The President Media Division (PMD) said the future activities and plans were discussed at length and special attention was paid to the problem of the spread of drugs among schoolchildren. A discussion was held on 19 December presided by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reform Dr. Wijayadasa Rajapakshe and President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake at the Presidential Secretariat. The meeting focused on the immediate measures to be taken to prevent the spread of drugs and drug prevention, identifying drug addicts and drug dealers, providing treatment and counselling services to drug addicts. Attention was also paid to the inmates who are currently in prison due to drug addiction and the measures to be taken in this regarding and the formal treatment to be done for them in prisons. Further discussion regarding the passing of an Act to empower voluntary centres, community-based rehabilitation, probation services, as well as to rehabilitate drug addicts were also discussed at length. Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, Secretary to the Ministry of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reform Wasantha Perera, Commissioner of Prisons Thushara Upuldeniya, Commissioner General Rehabilitation Major General D. D. U. K. Hettiarachchi (Retired), Shakya Nanayakkara of the National Board of Control for Dangerous Drugs, Senior Deputy Inspector General of Police Kamal Silva, Director General of the Ministry of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment Rama Murthy and several others attended the meeting.

title: Buddhist and Pali Uni to re-open after Act amended
author: Author not found
Content: The Buddhist and Pali University of Sri Lanka, in Pitipana, Homagama will be re-opened under new amendments and conditions, said Cabinet Spokesperson Bandula Gunawardena. He revealed this during the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (20). The university was closed on 19 December until further notice following complaints of ragging. Gunawardene said, since the Buddhist and Pali University of Sri Lanka operates under an Act which is different from other State universities, it cannot follow the same traditions as other State universities. He said, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha informed the Cabinet about the situation at the university and has called for an extensive report. “The Buddhist and Pali University is established not for a common purpose but for a religious purpose. This university is subject to a special Act. That is why the Cabinet decided to meet all MahanayakaTheras to discuss the academic and administrative affairs of the university, and to close the university until then,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Drug-busting ops now a joke due to ‘ICE drama’ – Wasantha
author: Author not found
Content: Drug busting operations have become a joke now as a result of President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s ‘ICE drama’, JVP Politburo member Wasantha Samarasinghe said yesterday (20), adding, as a result of this ‘ICE drama’ schoolchildren are victimised and humiliated. Samarasinghe said before checking school bags, the Government should catch those who bring drugs into the country. “The Government should start this operation from Parliament. This drama is purely a creation of Ranil Wickremesinghe for his own political gain. There are children who are not receiving a proper meal. The Government should address this, not victimising children by this type of cheap propaganda,” he said. BY Anuradha Herath

title: Navin wants fixed nominations quota for UNP
author: Author not found
Content: Former National Organiser of the UNP, Navin Dissanayake, requested the Nuwara Eliya District leadership, to ensure that in the event of the UNP and SLPP forming an alliance to contest  upcoming elections, a pre-decided nominations quota should be given to the UNP and two UNP members must be included in nominations apart from him. Addressing a media briefing yesterday (20) at Sirikotha, Dissanayake said he does not have any problem with contesting elections with MPs like S.B. Dissanayake and C.B. Rathnayake. Dissanayake also said he personally would like to see Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and other Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) members rejoin the UNP. Speaking further, he said elections will be held at required time as it is one of the prime and fundamental rights of people in this country. The UNP believes that the Parliamentary democracy must be protected, he added. By Amith Maduranga Gamage and Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Sajith slams Govt over checking school bags
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa slammed the Government saying, “It is ridiculous to check school bags of children who do not have enough nutrition, without catching the ‘big fish’ who bring narcotics into the country. Addressing a ‘Sakwala’ educational programme, at Kilinochchi Central College, Premadasa said when children’s bags are checked on suspicion that they contain drugs, only “empty” lunch boxes will be found, as the parents are struggling to provide food for children due to current economic circumstances.A Government is supposed to empower children with Information Technology, computer science, and artificial intelligence. Instead, the current Government is terrorising the children by checking their school bags, he stressed.  “The role of the government should not be to check the school bags but to prepare a programme that will give them proper nutrition at a time that the malnutrition situation of schoolchildren has increased. For a long time, our country has had a rote-like education system.  But our country needs an education system that provides actual solutions to problems,” he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Complaint filed with CIABOC against Immigration Dept
author: Author not found
Content: A complaint was filed with the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) yesterday (20), calling for an investigation into the issuance of a diplomatic passport to State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage, by the Department of Immigration and Emigration. The complaint was filed by Social activist Oshala Herath stating that the issuance of a diplomatic passport to Gamage, who is a British citizen, is in contravention to the law and is thereby an abuse of power. Previously, the Court of Appeal (CoA) ordered the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration to submit all documents pertaining to Gamage’s citizenship status. This was when the Writ Application filed by Herath, seeking an order disqualifying Gamage from holding office as a Parliamentarian, was taken up by Court. The Petitioner sought an order in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, requiring Gamage to show by what authority she claims to hold office and continues to function as a Member of Parliament of Sri Lanka. Further, a mandate in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, declaring that the Gamage is disqualified from being an MP, was also sought. It was also stated in the Petition that Gamage is a British citizen and had concealed the fact that she was a British citizen, while stating that she is also not a Sri Lankan citizen. Further, the petitioner noted that Gamage had on several occasions used her British Passport to apply for and obtain visas to visit Sri Lanka. The Petitioner also noted that Gamage had furnished forged Birth Certificates and an invalid National Identity Card to apply for a Sri Lankan Passport and that at the time of signing her nomination papers and the holding of the 2020 General Election and taking oaths as a Member of Parliament, she was not a citizen of Sri Lanka. It was thereby stated that Gamage continues to hold office as a Member of Parliament without being a citizen of Sri Lanka.

title: Cabinet nod for SLBFE training centre in Moneragala
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet granted approval for the establishment of a training centre, for the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau, in the Moneragala District. Although Moneragala is the second largest district geographically, no office or a training centre of the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau (SLFEB) has been in operation in that district. The closest training centre to that district are the Hali-ela training centre in the Badulla District, Tangalle training centre in Hambantota District and the Ampara District training centre. While the training centre alongside the Moneragala – Bibila highway, which is under the supervision of the Department of Divi Neguma, is suitable for establishing a district training centre for the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau, it may be possible to provide required training facilities for foreign employment seekers in low income families in Moneragala. The joint Cabinet paper was submitted by the President, as the Minister of Women, Child Activities and Social Empowerment and the Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment to entrust the training centre along the Monaragala – Bibile highway under the supervision of the Department of Divi Neguma to the SLFEB.

title: ‘False case’ filed in SC due to fear of facing polls – Sagara
author: Author not found
Content: Certain persons from the Opposition and other political parties have filed a ‘false case’ before the Supreme Court  seeking that steps be taken to hold the Local Government elections, as they are afraid to face elections, General Secretary of Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) Sagara Kariyawasam said. He said the case was filed in a backdrop that a statement made by the Election Commission that a date for the Local Government Election will be fixed during the final week of December. Two Petitions were previously filed, by a group of MPs, seeking an interim order be issued to the Election Commission, for steps to be taken to hold the Local Government Election in March 2023. The petitions were filed by MPs Dayasiri Jayasekara, Lakshman Kiriella, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, M.A. Sumanthiran, Ranjith Madduma Bandara and G.L. Pieris, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Sandun Gamage. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Suspect remanded for assaulting 14-year-old
author: Author not found
Content: A person was arrested for brutally assaulting a 14-year-old who allegedly uprooted a cannabis plant. The incident took place in Bangadeniya, Chilaw. According to Police, the suspect owned a cannabis cultivation and a resident of the same area had uprooted one plant. However, he later told the suspect that it was the child who uprooted the plant. The incensed suspect had forcibly taken the child away from his family after which he beat him mercilessly. The suspect was arrested based on a complaint lodged with the Chilaw Police. The Chilaw Chief Magistrate’s Court ordered him to be remanded till 22 December. (To report violence against children, dial 1929, the hotline of the National Child Protection Authority (NCPA)) By Prasad Purnamal

title: Arrested for illegal gem mining
author: Author not found
Content: Norwood Police arrested two persons who were engaged in illegal gem mining while damaging the Keselgamu Oya, which supplies water to the Castlereigh Reservoir. Police conducted a raid at the Keselgamu Oya on a tip-off. The two suspects aged 47 and 50 are residents of Balangoda and they were due to be produced before the Hatton District Court. BY C.D.H.Hewage – Watawala

title: Contractors to be issued T-Bills – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Treasury Bills will be issued to pay the monies owed to the construction companies that carried out projects with the Road Development Authority (RDA) and Ministry of Transport and Highways, Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardana said. Treasury Bills with an annual interest of 22.50 per cent will be issued to the companies. This decision was taken at a recent discussion on the payment of arrears owed to construction companies. It was chaired by Gunawardana. Following this decision, the Treasury will arrange to issue Treasury Bills to the respective companies within a few days. (TR)

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: Climate change, the cultivation of coconut trees that are brought illegally to the country and the simultaneous reduction of natural parasites are the reasons behind Whitefly menace, severely affect coconut cultivation Islandwide. This was revealed at the discussion held at Presidential Secretariat on sustainable management of the Whitefly. The meeting was chaired by Secretary to President Saman Ekanayake and President’s Director General (Community Affairs) Rajith Keerthi Tennakoon. The responsible institutions, including the Coconut Research Institute have held various awareness programmes, to educate the coconut cultivators about the pest and measures being implemented at the rural level, including the problems that have arisen in their implementation. In the implementation of these awareness programmes, the participation of social media, including electronic and print media was also discussed. Whitefly has affected the areas of Colombo, Gampaha, Kegalle, Kalutara and several others, the officials noted. It was stated that the lack of officers has been a major problem in the practical implementation of the measures taken by the relevant institutions to combat this situation. As a solution, the President’s Secretary advised to prepare a programme to involve everyone from the Divisional Secretaries to the officers at grassroots level. He also advised to get the support of the university community working on this subject to suppress it. The President’s Secretary further advised to resort to quick solutions such as cultivating parasites and purchasing necessary machinery to control and suppress the emerging threat. Popular
